column2: PATERSON, N.J., March 22-- A 39,200-foot high-voltage cable weighing 722,400 pounds and filling nine raliroad gondola cars, left here this morning for its destination at the bottom of Puget Sound. When it reaches there it will be cut in two. There is a reason for this.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP)-- Jon M. Jonkel, campaign manager for Senator John M. Butler, Republican of Maryland, contradicted today the testimony of Mr Butler's campaign treasurer about the handling of election funds.
WASHINGTON, March 22--President Truman, thoroughly rested, returned late this afternoon from his twenty-day sojourn in Key West to face troublesome and unsettled issues.

The proposed new television channel assignments by the Federal Communications Commission will allow three more stations for New York City, all to broadcast on the upper high frequencies. Channel 25 has been designated for an educational station, while 18 and 31 would be commercial stations.

George Bernard Shaw's will, made public yesterday, shows that he did not change his mind on one important resolution made as far back as 1944. He thought then, and must have thought to the day of his death, that the English alphabet was perfectly terrible.

ALBANY, March 22--Governor Dewey signed into law today a bill assigning to the State Power Authority jurisdiction over the power resources of the Niagara River and Falls, in addition to those of the St. Lawrence River.

Jacob Marcus, tenor from New York who is also a cantor, made his recital debut last night in Town Hall. Since good tenors do not turn up every day in the year, this was a noteworthy event. A sizable audience was in attendance.

PATERSON, N.J., March 22-- A 39,200-foot high-voltage cable weighing 722,400 pounds and filling nine raliroad gondola cars, left here this morning for its destination at the bottom of Puget Sound. When it reaches there it will be cut in two. There is a reason for this.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP)-- Jon M. Jonkel, campaign manager for Senator John M. Butler, Republican of Maryland, contradicted today the testimony of Mr Butler's campaign treasurer about the handling of election funds.
FRANKFORT, Germany, March 10--Only the outer door to equal educational opportunity has been opened since the end of the war in the states forming the United States zone of West Germany.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 23 --The engagement of Miss Faith Annabelle Robbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Dudley Robbins, to James Thompson Phillips Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips of 200 East Sixty-sixth Street, New York City, formerly of Short Hills, has been announced by her parents. The wedding is expected to take place in the early autumn.

Two garage buidings occupying a plot 180 by 100 feet at 231 to 243 East Ninety-fourth Street have been sold by Ringland F. Kilpatrick and others to East Ninetyfourth Street Garage, Inc., which insured title with the City Title Insurance Company. The property is assessed at $300,000.

HONG KONG, March 23--The Chinese Communist Tibetan campaign, with only one army corps employed in the direct assault against the "roof of the world," turned out to be more expensive than the crossing of the Yangtze River by 1,000,000 Red troops in the spring of 1949, according to an engineer who helped plan it.

The Bureau of the Budget has recommended to the President that the Economic Cooperation Administration be retained indefinitely as a more or less permanent independent Government agency. President Truman will pass that recommendation on to the Congress for appropriate action, since E. C. A. would otherwise expire in June,...

FLORENCE, Italy, March 23-- At a quiet steady pace the Eastern European satellite states of the Soviet Union are stepping up their military preparations as traditional season of spring, maneuvers and nerve-war rumors commences.
REPORTS from a half-dozen near-by states indicate that the early spring and unusually high temperatures hold out a promise of one of the best openings in years for trout fishermen.
Three singers assumed leading roles in Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" for the first time with the New York City Opera in last night's performance at the City Center.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 23 (AP)--Marty Furgol, 33-year-old professional who plays out of Long Beach, Calif., rode out a troublesome wind today to score a threeunder-par 68 and lead the field by two strokes in the opening round of the $10,000 Greensboro Open golf tournament.

The ninety-fifth year of operations of the Crane Company, manufacturers of plumbing and heating equipment, produced the second highest sales in its history and an increase of 96 per cent in earnings, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

The board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange declared yesterday that an emergency existed in the March, 1951, delivery and that all contracts entered into were to be liquidated, with the settlement price to be determined at an adjourned meeting of the board.

A dozen troubled Easters lie behind us, and no one knows how many more years will pass before the return of spring and the feast of resurrection will be unshadowed by fear and foreboding. This year the mood of Good Friday seems more appropriate to the state of the world than the mood of Easter. But the human spirit is irrepressible, and the most striking feature...

A few hours now, and Fifth Avenue will be cleared of wheeled traffic for the Easter Sunday street festival that has taken the place of the Easter church parade, so long a cherished tradition of our city. Instead, we have now a colorful and cheerful turnout of a great number of our fellow-citizens...

The Red Cross blood program was enriched yesterday by 147 pints donated at the Manhattan center, 70 West Fortieth Street, by New Yorkers as part of their Good Friday observance. In addition, forty-five donations were made at the Brooklyn center, 57 Willoughby Street, which was open from noon to 6 P.M.
CHICAGO, March 23--America must strengthen its defenses against possible germ warfare, a top Government expert on biological weapons warned today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
CHICAGO, March 23 (UP)--A brisk traffic in bootleg slot machines and their parts has sprung up to evade the law that bans their shipment in interstate commerce.

Many thousands of New Yorkers observed Good Friday yesterday at solemn three-hour services commemorating the suffering of Christ on the cross. From noon to 3 P.M. devout churchgoers crowded their houses of worship for prayer and meditation.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) --The Government said today that things were looking up for the nation's farmers as a result of a 15 per cent increase in their gross income in January and February.
Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, outlined yesterday the details of a new program designed to bring the thirtytwo municipal hospitals and their communities closer together.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 23-- Representative John Taber, Republican of New York, charged here today that reconstruction work at the Sampson Air Force Base, near this city, was being carried on with "very large waste and unnecessary expenditures."

SANDHURST, England, March 23--Britain's post-war army, now being hurriedly expanded, is receiving about 300 highly trained young officers every six months from Sandhurst, famed Royal Military Academy.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 24-- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur flew to Korea this morning and, in a statement issued here after his departure, asserted he stood ready at any time to confer in the field with the commander in chief of the Chinese and North Korean forces to end the war.

LUKE AIR FORCE BASE, Ariz., March 23 (AP)--Two F-84 Thunderjet fighters crashed in the air near Litchfield Park today, sending one of the most decorated fliers in the Air Guard plunging to his death. He was Maj. Robert E. Welch, 27 years old, of Detroit.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 23-- The New England Council unanimously adopted today a resolution of confidence in its subsidiary steel development corporation on the strength of optimistic, but noncommittal, reports by ranking officials.

Mayor Impellitteri signed yesterday the bills previously passed by the City Council and the Board of Estimate making it mandatory for all policemen who are members of the Police Department's pension system to wait thirty days after application for their retirements to become effective.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 23-- Gov. James F. Byrnes made it clear today that "under on circumstances" would he be a candidate for President of the United States in 1952.
WASHINGTON, March 23--Another rise in the Consumers' Price Index today gave a million nonoperating railroad workers a claim to a wage increase of 6 cents an hour under their contracts.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23--The nickel, evicted from the subway turnstiles and not good enough by half for a phone call, still has enough buying power to keep a member of the United Nations in good standing.

CALGARY, Alta., March 23 (UP) --Richard Button, the world champion from Englewood, N.J., won the men's compulsory figures contest tonight in the North American figure skating championships. The 21-year-old Button, four-time winner of the world crown and sixtime United States titleholder, garnered a total of 1,136.4 points.

The board of directors of the Panama Railroad Company will meet in Washington on Monday to discuss means of increasing revenues and the problem of making the Panama Line, as well as its other operations, individually selfsufficient.

Sales of steel warehouse products in the New York area for the first quarter will top those of a year ago, it was learned yesterday. Inventories, however, are below what are considered normal to fill deliveries.

Michael H. Cardozo Jr. of 163 East Eighty-first Street, veteran attorney, died yesterday in his office at 115 Broadway. His age was 70. He was a cousin of the late Associate Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 23-- A new clash centering around the use of Colorado River water broke out today as California officials and members of the Upper Colorado River Commission raised the question of hydro-electric power versus irrigation with water to be impounded by Reclamation Bureau dams on the Utah sector of the river.

Easter-Week sales for department stores and similar retail outlets here was declared generally disappointing yesterday as the over-all dollar gain for the week was estimated at a maximum of 8 per cent over the like calendar week a year ago. The 1950 week's volume had shown a drop of about 4 per cent from the comparable 1949 week's volume.
Clear skies were predicted yesterday for tomorrow's Easter parade.

BUENOS AIRES, March 23-- The Federal police are reported to be watching all trains, automobiles and planes throughout Argentina in an effort to apprehend Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, whose arrest was ordered Wednesday night by the Congressional committee that has taken over the newspaper La Prensa.
MIAMI, Fla., March 23--The Dodgers are on the verge of entering into a contract that will establish their training quarters at Vero Beach for the next twenty-one years.

ARCADIA, Calif, March 23 (UP) --Your Host, California's crippled champion, faces a lingering death from his broken right foreleg unless his owner, William Goetz, decides to destroy the colt, veterinarian J. E. Peters disclosed today.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 23-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gaines Gwathmey of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy, to Cpl. John Andrews Harris 4th, son of Mrs. Flagler Harris of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and J. Andrews Harris 3d of White Marsh, Pa.

Eddie Giosa, veteran campaigne from Philadelphia, came through with an upset in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Gar den last night. Opposing the wel ballyhooed John L. Davis of Rich mond, Calif., Giosa turned in a fine boxing exhibition to earn a draw with his favored opponent.

ALBANY, March 23--Senate Republican Leader Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston will head a joint legislative committee that will investigate all phases of horse racing in the state, including offthe-track betting. The inquiry will start about May 15.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 23--A heretofore unpublicized and unemphasized aspect of the West German plan for the reorganization of the steel and coal industries should eliminate British objections that endanger the implementation of the Schuman plan in Germany, a United States official asserted today. McCloy Acted on French Bid 28 New Concerns Planned

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 23 (UP)--Jaroslav Drobny, the former Czech Davis Cup star, eliminated Dick Savitt from a foreign tennis tournament for the second straight time today when he defeated the Orange, N. J. player, 6-4, 6-2, 1-6, 6-4, in the men's singles semi-finals at the Alexandria championships.

A national plan for easing shortages of critical materials essential to defense production has been put into use by the H.M. Harper Company, Inc., metal parts producers, of Chicago. Purchasing agents for large industrial companies here are urging extensive use of the system for alleviating short-term shortages until the...

ALBANY, March 23--Serious doubt arose today as to whether Governor Dewey would approve New York City's request for the increased sales tax that Mayor Impellitteri contends is essential to balance the city's 1951-52 budget.

Kentucky, ranked No. 1 in national polls during the season, will oppose the Big Ten champion, Illinois, in the National Collegiate A. A. Eastern regional basketball final at Madison Square Garden tonight. The game will be preceded by the St. John's and North Carolina State battle at 7:45 o'clock to decide third place.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 23 (UP) --The Reds shut out the hardhitting Red Sox, 7 to 0, for the second time this spring today as knuckle-baller Willard Ramsdell gave up only five hits in a seveninning stint.

God is endeavoring to "tell us that every Good Friday shall have its Easter," the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, president of the Prot estant Council of the City of New York and retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday in an Easter message.
LONDON, March 23 (Reuters) --Tottenham Hotspur today defeated its London neighbor, Fulham, by 1--0 to maintain a fivepoint first-division lead in English soccer.

PARIS, March 23--Secret discussion among the Big Four foreign ministers' deputies today failed to break the deadlock on the wording of the agenda they have been attempting to prepare for an eventual meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 24 (UP)--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur issued the following statement today:

SEOUL, Korea, March 23--The Army band of a Korean division played through the streets of Seoul today but the forty-man band marched in a lonely parade, past empty sidewalks and long rows of barren buildings.

JESSELTON, North Borneo, March 23--Expectations of a quick large-scale development of the British colony of North Borneo aroused after the Japanese war have had to be curtailed in the light of experience and presentday world conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 23--The Monongahela Power Company of Fairmont, W. Va., filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for $10,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, series due in 1981.
Joseph Langerman of 912 Fifth Avenue, a founder and former president of Howard Stores Corporation, men's clothing chain, died yesterday in his winter home at Miami Beach, Fla. His age was 62.
MADRID, March 23--The Barcelona protest strike last week was such a shock to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime that worried consultations are still going on.

President Peron's interference with freedom of the press is none of our business and the Argentine Government will not tolerate any foreign intervention in the case of La Prensa. This was substantially what the Argentine Foreign Minister, Hipolito Jesus Paz, told a press conference in Washington when the reporters forced him...

Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire and a member of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, will be interviewed tomorrow afternoon from 4 to 4:30 o'clock on "Meet the Press," which is televised on Channel 4.

SANTIAGO. Chile, March 23-- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla said today he did not believe the Soviet Union would attack if the democracies went ahead with military preparations and presented a united front against aggression, but he warned that in that case the Kremlin would try indirect methods of expansion.

ALBANY, March 23--Governor Dewey today cleared the way for relief clients receiving aid for dependent children to get care in any hospital other than a mental institution or a tuberculosis sanitorium for as long as a year.

Dr. Abraham L. Goldwater of 415 Central Park West, who had practiced medicine here for more than fifty years, died yesterday at his home, after a brief illness, at the age of 79. His office was at 70 Central Park West.

Contracts were signed yesterday for Joan McCracken to take over the title role in "Peter Pan" after Jean Arthur withdraws from the attraction in Chicago on April 14. Miss McCracken, now working in "Angel in the Pawnshop," which closes its Broadway engagement March 31, was hired for two weeks only, according to Peter Lawrence, co-sponsor of the revival with R.L. Stevens.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 --Plans for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's British production of Sir Walter Scott's "Ivanhoe" have begun to take final shape, as Pandro S. Berman, who will produce the film, prepared to leave for London on Monday.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 23-- Oklahoma A. and M., fifteen-time winner of the title, and the University of Oklahoma, which handed the Aggies one of their rare defeats this year, emerged from the opening session of the twenty-first annual National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships as the top contenders for team honors.
WASHINGTON, March 23--The Army has cut its draft call for April by half.

WASHINGTON, March 23-- Teams of highly trained iron and steel scrap inspectors will be loosed shortly to investigate reports of widespread violations of price control regulations in the scrap Industry, Edward P. Morgan, director of enforcement for the Office of Price Stabilization, announced today.

When a man steps into the kitchen he's often rated just a nuisance, but that was not the case when Louis Posner gave in to his culinary curiosity and experimented with his wife's strudel dough. The result: A ready-to-bake Hungarian strudel dough that changed Mr. Posner's status from that of an amateur to a professional baker.

LAUREL, Md., March 23-- The major Eastern racing season started on a gay note today as a crowd of 10,944 turned out at Laurel and watched a program that included a colorful parade, plenty of long-shot winners and a dead heat in the six-furlong feature. And, adding to the occasion...

Income tax returns and supporting data filed in Brooklyn by Ambassador William. O'Dwyer, James J. Moran, resigned Commissioner of the Board of Water Supply, and John R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican leader, were moved yesterday for intensive investigation by agents of the Intelligence Unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

BIRMINGHAM, March 23 (AP)-- A three-judge Federal Court by a 2 to 1 decision has enjoined the Interstate Commerce Commission from allowing railroads to charge higher rates for switching freight brought to Knoxville, Tenn., by barge than shipped there by rail.

LONDON, Saturday, March 24--A United States Air Force officer at Shannon Airport said early today that the pilot of a search plane had reported sighting flares and wreckage along the Atlantic route followed by a huge United States Air Force C-124, missing for twenty-four hours with fifty-three persons aboard.

The exhaustion of Germany's $500,000,000 trade credit in the European Payments Union is forcing a reversal in that country's hitherto liberal economic policies, in favor of new controls and import restrictions. This not only impairs the economy of other countries, notably the Netherlands.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., March 23--The calm of a Good Friday afternoon in this suburban community was shattered today by the pistol fire of three gunmen who critically wounded a payroll messenger and escaped with $3,000.
MUNSAN, Korea, March 23-- For the second time in this war a major drop of parachute troops was made against the enemy today.

American business is risking its own destruction and the collapse of the American way of life by tolerating the infiltration of legitimate business by underworld characters, Spruille Braden, chairman of the New York City Anti-Crime Commission, warned yesterday in commenting on revelations of the Senate crime investigation.

KANSAS CITY, March 23 (AP)-- Ed Head, forward, hit in the clutch often enough tonight to bring Kansas State a 64-to-54 victory over Brigham Young in the first semi-final game of the Western N. C. A. A. basketball play-offs. The defeat ended the Utah team's hope of sweeping the season's ...

A warning against calling statesmen "appeasers" when they try to deal with Russia was voiced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, vice president and acting head of Columbia University. Such an epithet he said, derives from a feeling that war with Russia is inevitable.

Good Friday and the fiftieth anniversary, which this year represents the death of Giuseppe Verdi, were observed yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera house by a performance of the "Manzoni Requiem," and an excerpt from "Forza del Destino" that cannot be forgotten by any who were fortunate enough to be present.
The spring and summer collection of Oldric Royce,16 East Fiftysecond Street, is appealing in the restrained elegance of its detail, interesting fabrics and handsome simplicity.

LINCOLN PARK, N.J., March 23--The hope of finding alive the two missing sons of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Orchard, of 47 River Edge Road, dimmed today for 1,000 searchers, who have been combing the area around this small Morris County community since Wednesday.

With the approaching end of the current school year there will be at least an additional 500 Chinese students who will have completed their courses of study in American colleges and universities. More than 300 completed their work at the midyear. There are more than 3,500 of these students in the United States, most of them in graduate schools.

The Quartermaster Corps shortly will abandon at least part of the secrecy surrounding prices it pays for textiles and apparel, it was learned yesterday. Because of numerous complaints by small business and the trade press the Department of Defense, trade sources said, is discussing to what extent information on bids should be revealed.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)-- Since the Korean war started the Army has stepped up by 50 per cent its activity to ferret out Communists. The increase is measured both by added manpower for the counter-intelligence corps and by investigating activity, an Army official said today.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 24--A strong force of United Nations tanks, engineers and bridge-building equipment pushed overland in the area north of Seoul yesterday afternoon to join with the paratroopers who jumped during the morning in the flatlands of the Imjin River valley near Munsan, behind the Communist lines.

The America's Cup, the 100guinea silver "mug" for whose possession generations of yachtsmen have expended vast ingenuity, tremendous energy and fabulous sums of money, is going back to England--on loan.

Discussion of maritime labor's role in the operations of the new National Shipping Authority, along with over-all manpower problems, is expected to be a highlight of the fifth biennial convention of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., which opens in San Francisco on Monday. The meeting is scheduled to run through the week.

WASHINGTON, March 23--Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, proposed today that the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, of which he is a member, be prolonged for sixty days to clean up loose ends of its country-wide inquiry into criminal operations. The committee's life is limited to March 31 under present Senate authorization.

The problem of refugees in Central Europe, particularly Germany and Austria, has again been pushed into the foreground by the appeal for help issued recently by organizations claiming to represent 10,000,000 of these unfortunates. These organizations warn that the plight of the refugees has created an "explosive state," capable of potential "catastro-...
WASHINGTON, March 23--The National Production Authority announced today that the supplies of tires and tubes for new automobiles would be cut 25 per cent beginning April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)-- A new appeal for more and better channel space for educational television arose today in the wake of the Federal Communications Commission's announced plans for nation-wide TV service.

CHICAGO, March 23--The nation's railroads announced today they are asking a 15 per cent increase in freight rates to offset increased wage, material and supply costs. It is estimated that if granted the increase would add about $960,000,000 a year to the nation's freight bill.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 23--The Tanjug news agency reported today from Bucharest the dismissal of four leading Rumanian Cabinet Ministers, including a member of the Rumanian Politburo and one lieutenant general.

The dawn of Easter tomorrow will find many thousands of Christians assembled for religious services commemorating the Resurrection of Christ. They will gather in parks, on hills and mountains, or at central indoor services where communicants of many denominations will meet for common devotions.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 23--An international flavor was added to the homemakers' program of Cornell University's annual Farm and Home Week this year by demonstrations of foreign cookery and a panel discussion by nine foreign students on "Preparation for Homemaking in Other Lands."

The three-story, six-family apartment house at 32-51 Forty-third Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Frank W. Moser to Philip and Louise Nardella. Frederick G. Sleth was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

The wildcat strike of longshoremen on Pier 45, North River, continued through its fourth day yesterday, forcing the Grace Line to put off the sailing of the Santa Monica to next Friday and making it doubtful whether the liner Santa Clara would be able to dock here on Monday.

Bad manners are responsible for many of this city's traffic accidents and near-misses. Traffic Commissioner Lloyd B. Reid said yesterday. Spot checks made by members of his staff in conjunction with the Police Department's Safety Bureau and the Greater New...

In a city where organ grinders by the hundreds once appeared on the stroke of spring, 75-year-old Giuseppe Castignoli had the season's somewhat chilly onset all to himself this year. Bundled in a fleece-collared coat and blowing with cold through his long white mustache, he cranked out the wiry music that's tinkled like ice in the thin sunlight.
SCOTT FITZGERALD said that the two basic stories of all time were "Cinderella" and "Jack the Giant Killer." They need not be confined to fiction.

PARIS, March 23--Vice Premier Rene Pleven last night disclosed French dissatisfaction with British-American plans for the defense of the Mediterranean and declared that the French Government could not agree to any defense effort that did not include France in the early stages of strategic planning.

Lilies, hyacinths and all the flowers that at a linked to Easter manage to make their appearance on time every year, no matter when the observance date falls. Although March 25 is one of the earliest, florist shops in the city are overflowing with pot plants, cut flowers and short-stemmed blossoms for corsages.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 23--Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, president emeritus of Cornell University, died of a heart attack during an automobile ride this morning at the age of 67.

WASHINGTON, March 23--Objections to a recent initial decision by the Federal Communications Commission that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was within its rights in prohibiting use of the hush-a-phone as a "foreign attachment" to its instruments were filed with the F.C.C. today by the makers of the device.

PARIS, March 23--The Cabinet decided today to increase the minimum wage for private industry in the Paris region by 11.5 per cent and in the provinces by amounts ranging up to 15.6 per cent as from April 1. The decision was the result of an agreement yesterday by the National Collective Bargaining Commission that the cost of living had risen since last August by 12.5 per cent.
United Nations airborne troops were successfully dropped Friday morning in the Munsan area near the Imjin River.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23--Bucky Harris and his Senators, who seem to have a penchant for tripping up ball clubs rated infinitely superior, practiced on their specialty at the expense of the Giants today.
LONDON, March 23 (UP)--An American will be the coxswain in the Oxford shell for the first time in history tomorrow in the ninetyseventh Oxford-Cambridge crew race to be staged on the Thames River.

The police were investigating last night the death of 12-year-old Robert Schneider, whose body was found by his father in an aban doned refrigerator stored in the cellar of a building near the youngster's home in the Bronx. A preliminary examination by Medical Examiner Edward Santora of...

DENVER, March 23 (AP)--A $45,000,000 atomic plant for a major but secret type of production will be built northwest of Denver. Construction will start late next month and be completed next year. The plant, small in size compared to the giants at Hanford, Wash., and Oak Ridge, Tenn., will be on barren land.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Jesse H. Jones, former chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and one-time Federal Loan Administrator, gave direct support today to a bill to abolish the agency.

CHICAGO, March 23--Harry Keating Jr., 35 years old, State Motor Vehicles agent in Wildwood, N. J., who had confessed gambling away $9,327 in stolen state funds, sat in the detective bureau today awaiting return to Wildwood. He was seized earlier in the day in the Astor Hotel and said he would waive extradition.

WASHINGTON, March 23-- Terminal-to-terminal haulage of mail by truck instead of railroad will be started over four routes in New England within two weeks, John M. Redding, Assistant Postmaster General, announced today. Mr. Redding announced last month...

The "temporary" subway shuttle between Times Square and Grand Central Station is now thirty-three years old and has had no basic improvement in that time. The nearest approach has been to make somewhat more pleasant the too-long walk between the west end of it and the Lexington Avenue subway.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23--The Israeli Government was reported today to be planning to take up its suggestions for a Korean ceasefire directly with the State Department in Washington.

BUENOS AIRES, March 21-- Knowing that President Juan D. Peron is struggling with a difficult explosive internal situation and that his chief hope for consolidating power is to create an integral totalitarian state, it is easy to...

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23-- A feeling of alarm which overtook the Yankee camp today over the condition of Allie Reynolds' arm, was dissipated as Casey Stengel sent his champions into battle tonight against Lefty Frank O'Doul's Seals.
DETROIT, March 23 (AP)--How some of Detroit's famed mechanical know-how has benefited medical research was disclosed today by a rare combination of engineers and surgeons.

WHEN you pick up "Sink Em All" you may ask yourself, "Will this be another brass-hat memoir in which the author tells how he won the war all by himself?" The answer comes quickly. After a few pages you find that although...

Senate moves to restrict the President in deploying United States ground troops wherever he feels they are needed were denounced yesterday by Senator Herbert H. Lehman as "dangerous beyond description."

LONDON, March 24--Before a packed house, a new season of Shakespeare opened tonight at the Memorial Theatre in Stratford-onAvon with "Richard II" Michael Redgrave played the title role and Heather Stannard the Queen.
A NORTH-SIDE planting can be as colorful as any other perennial border. Quite a few plants will flourish in such a location to provide a sequence of colorful flowers from spring to autumn.

Maritime industry safety problems ranging from ship operation and stevedoring to shipbuilding and pleasure craft sailing will be discussed at the Greater New York Safety Council's twenty-first annual convention and safety exposition, which opens for four days on April 3. Sessions will be held in both the Statler and Governor Clinton Hotels.
Structural Steel Orders Off

MADRID, March 24--Lieut. Gen. Jose Enrique Varela, Spain's High Commissioner in Morocco since 1945, her most decorated soldier and considered one of her ablest men, died this morning in Tetuan, Morocco, of a heart attack after a long illness from leukemia. He was 59 years old.
Following is the text of Mayor Impellitteri's letter to Governor Dewey regarding an increase in the rate of the city's sales tax:

EACH year about 200 new titles of Western fiction are published. Included are a few that are genuinely good, others that might be classed as indifferent, and a third group of blood-and-thunder six-shooter tales splashed with gore and written without a thought of technical, historical or geographical accuracy.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 24--Irvin Dorfman of New York and Miss Doris Hart of Jacksonville, Fla., won the mixed doubles championship and Dick Savitt of Orange, N.J., teamed with Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt to give the United States a share in the men's doubles title today at the Alexandria lawn tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 24--The United States Government is asking the American people to adjust their lives to a more or less permanent state of preparedness or semi-war, but as a matter of fact it has not yet adjusted its own machinery or mentality to the long pull.
It's here. This is it. Boating's sitting-out season is no longer just around any corner. The sunny, warmish spring days have made every boat storage yard and every yacht club beehives of activity.

Regional correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES were asked last week to report on whether there has been any slackening of pace in the nation's defense effort. From their dispatches there emerges a somewhat contradictory picture. In some areas, the good news from Korea has been accompanied by a general indifference toward the mobilization program.

TAMPA, Fla., March 24 (UP)-- Hefty Ken Raffensberger pitched 2-3 innings--the longest any big league hurler has gone this spring --as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Washington Senators, 7 to 4, today before 1,279 fans.
RIVALRY with the Easter bunny, the florists and the swank couturiers in spreading sunshine and color dur ing these vernal holidays is a level of competition to which the movies have never aspired.
KANSAS CITY, March 24--Dr. D.M. Nigro said today that the testimony before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee by Lew Farrell, Iowa beer distributor, was "all wrong."

Wayne Gideon is a 7-year-old Houston (Tex.) boy who last Tuesday fell on a sharp stick near his home and punctured hiS throat near the tonsils. He lost a lot of blood when surgeons had difficulty in applying pressure in the area of the wound.

Shapiro had successfully transplanted small developing teeth, called "buds," from one cat to another. His achievement is of high scientific importance.

BUENOS AIRES, March 24-- President Juan D. Peron announced today that Argentina had found a way to produce atomic energy by a new, much simpler and cheaper method than that of any other country working on the problem.
The management of Children's Village has selected the April 5 evening performance of "The Autumn Garden" at the Coronet Theatre for its spring theatre benefit.
ALBANY, March 24--Seventy thousand state employee will receive emergency pay increases ranging from $300 to $1,000 a year beginning April 1 under the terms of a bill signed today by Governor Dewey.

The arrival of the first shipload of iron ore from Venezuela at Baltimore has a twofold significance. The first shipment will be followed by others bringing this vitally needed raw material for American iron and steel production, thus augmenting our own supplies.

The marriage of Miss AudreyJune Ritter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Ritter of Trenton and Hollywood, Fla,, to Donald Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Friedman of Denver, took place here last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman.

The winter has been warm, the snow heavy and the wet earth already gives forth a good smell under the coaxing of a persistent sun. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 24--An Italian village--still recovering from wartime destruction and post-war poverty--has turned down an offer of relief from the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 24--Mr. and Mrs. Charles Roberts Thomas of Lookout Mountain have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Matilda Louise, to Daniel West Oehmig, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Oehmig Jr. of Riverview.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 24 --Athur Doering, 34-year-old Richmond, Va., professional, who has won only $800 on golf's winter tour this year, shot par 71 today to take a three-strode lead at the halfway mark of the $10,000 Greensboro open tournament with a 141 total for 36 holes.

WITH speeding rated as a major cause of highway accidents throughout the country, the National Safety Council has analyzed speed limitation rules required to insure traffic safety. The conclusions show clearly that the driver should conform to the varying traffic situations that confront him rather than motor at the limit allowed by regional regulations.

ROME, March 24--The coming week will decide whether Premier Alcide de Gasperi will have to face a Cabinet crisis early in April or whether he will be able to carry on with the present coalition government.

Alastair Bradley Martin and has brother, Esmond Martin, won the national amateur court tennis doubles championship yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Once again Argentina is going into an international conference, slightly set apart from her twenty neighbors in the Americas. This time President Juan D. Peron's implacable fight against the newspaper La Prensa has had world-wide repercussions and touched off a battle of historic proportions for freedom of the press.

The average classroom teacher works forty-eight hours a week, according to a survey just completed by the Research Division of the National Education Association. Her work day is not over when the dismissal bell rings. Her homework includes correcting papers, preparing study assignments and making out records, among other jobs.

The subject of slave labor in the Soviet Union moved to the front of the world stage last week when the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations voted to institute an investigation of forced labor throughout the world. This move ended two years of warm controversy during which the Soviet Union and its satellites strenuously opposed such an investigation.

THE United States Army has just ordered 600 copies of "Bathroom's Down the Hall," by William Cameron Johnson. No connection, but General Bradley's "A Soldier's Story" was dictated into a tape recorder, although of the two and a half million words transcribed, only 230,000 got into the finished book.
Early summer occupancy is contemplated for a new group of 150 dwellings on which work has been started by Irving Sherman builder, in his 1,000-home community in the Rockwood Park section of Queens.

WASHINGTON, March 24--Official Government and diplomatic circles here while indicating great interest in President Peron's announcement of "controlled liberation" of atomic energy in experiments in Argentina,, were inclined to wait for the answer to several "ifs" before commenting finally.

LUXEMBOURG--By recalling nursery books depicting painted castles with thick walls and lofty spires in a setting of wooded heights, winding rivers and lush vineyards, American grown-ups may obtain a realistic impression of Luxembourg.

SHANNON, Ireland, March 24 (AP)--Recovery of an Air Force-type valise tonight swung fleets of ships and planes toward a new sector of the Atlantic in search of the United States Air Force Globemaster, missing since early Friday with fifty-three persons aboard.
SMALL tractors have taken much of the drudgery from the hobby of gardening. The home owner who decides to invest in this power machine should buy it before the garden is laid out in spring.

WORLD EYES IRAN ON OIL SEIZURE BID Action of both houses of the Iranian Parliament in voting to nationalize the oil industry again has focused attention on the Middle East to which the center of gravity of the world's oil production is being shifted rapidly.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) --The Army today ordered 1,100 majors and 400 lieutenant colonels in the reserves to active duty by June 29.

IT is festival time in the little town of Chardon in northeastern Ohio. Crisp nights, sunny days, snow melting, crows cawing in the woods--these are signs that the sap has begun to run, and in maple-sugar producing areas a period of hard intensive work has begun.

End of Dispute Delaying the Functioning Of W.S.B. Awaited by Pension Planners Financial institutions concerned with pension planning eagerly await an end of the dispute that has stalemated the functioning of the Wage Stabilization Board. An early agreement is hoped for, so that previously recommended changes in Regulation 6 of the W.S.B., pertaining to employe benefits, may be acted upon.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 24 --Amateur Pat O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., victor in the titleholder's tournament last week, and the veteran amateur Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill led the field today after the first round of the $3,000 Sandhills Women's open golf tournament. Each had a 75, one over par, on the near-by Pine Needles course.

Japan's merchant marine growth has been so rapid that she will be able to carry in her own vessels about one-half of the anticipated 1951 import volume of 13,000,000 tons, according to a report made public here by the National Federation of American Shipping.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 24 --In Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Joan Barnewell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hall Barnewell of Greenwich, was married to Edmund Richards Tweedy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tweedy of Darien.

Of the several bad features marring the Reciprocal Trade Act as it passed the House, the Dempsey amendment on farm products is as bad as any. This amendment would forbid tariff concessions to a foreign agricultural commodity if it is sold here at a price equal to or lower than the support price of the same product domestically produced.

RUDOLF BING showed last year that he is not one to wait until the fall to announce his plans for the Metropolitan Opera. He announced his first season on Feb. 1 while Edward Johnson was still the general manager. This year he is not telling his plans quite so far in advance, but he is early by old-time practice and the big press conference is set for April 2.

The villages that, were overrun and reduced to ashes in the recent war are today the centers of the most fervent celebrations of Greece's Independence Day. Greece has paid a high price to keep this holiday, and is ready to pay it again. No action has yet been taken...

MANY shrubs and vines in gardens of the South make excellent house plants in the North. There are many, of course, that grow too rapidly, have too large leaves or are not adaptable to indoor conditions. The selection is still wide enough to add interesting flowers and foliage patterns to a window garden.

The Board of Transportation operator of the city's vast network of subway, elevated and surface lines, is making plans for its big moving day, April 1.
LONDON, March 24--The strictest rule on doping of horses in the long history of British racing became operative today with the opening of the 1951 flat racing season.

WASHINGTON, March 24--The National Association of Manufac turers, describing the defense of the Western Hemisphere as a "joint responsibility." called today for the "equitable sharing" of production between the Latin-American countries and the United States.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 24 (AP)--W.J. Walden's Circus Clown upset heavily favored Lextown in the featured Suwanee River Purse at Gulfstream Park today before a crowd of 16,000.

PARIS, March 24--Although the Cabinet postponed until tomorrow its discussion of new wage levels for France, the railways were rapidly approaching normal operations tonight as the result of an agreement for pay increases made with the Socialist unions. The Paris transport strike continued unabated.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24--Weak and unfavorable winds kept the closely bunched St. Petersburg-to-Havana racing fleet still within Tampa Bay four hours after the start today.

WASHINGTON, March 24--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee was told today that professional gamblers suspected basketball games at Madison Square Garden of being "fixed" for a long time before the recent scandals broke into the open.

Cecil Leland Rutledge Jr., U.S.A.F., son of Colonel Rutledge, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Rutledge, of Columbus, Ga., took place yesterday afternoon in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. The Rev. Cyril Carrie performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception.

BENTON, Tenn., March 24--A crowd of about 200 men, some fingering pistols and others pointing rifle barrels from the windows of the second floor of the local courthouse, prevented a scheduled meeting of the eight-member Polk County Court today.

Department store volume for Easter was disappointing to merchants. Trade observers estimated the week's dollar volume gain at about 8 per cent, at the most, over the calendar week of 1950, which, in turn, was down about 4 per cent from 1949. As for a comparison with the pre-Easter week of 1950, sales were put at about 1 per cent above the 1950 week.

PARIS, March 24--The day that Shape (Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe) will become an operational command moved closer this week when Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower named nine military leaders who will share with him the responsibility of planning and commanding the defense of Western Europe.
The volume of home construction, except in defense areas, will begin to show a decline later in the year, according to an article in the Quarterly Letter of the United States Savings and Loan League.

A new phase in the Korean war-- which began just nine months ago today--seemed to be in the making last week. On Friday the U.N. commander, Gen. Douglas MacArthur, made a dramatic bid for an end to the fighting. He said he was ready to meet on the field of battle with the Chinese Communist commander, Gen. Lin Piao, to talk about an armistice.

He has a lot more forehead to mop, too, because his hairline is retreating fast. As usual, he was chattering away at a rate a magpie would have envied while holding court for touring baseball writers.

Nearly 6.5 per cent of the male population of the United States 18 years of age and over is expected to be in the armed forces by summer. The effect of the loss of about 3,150,000 potential customers to the clothing industry, however, will not be a reduction of 6.5 per cent in sales, manufacturers declared last week.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged yesterday to 30 points lower compared with the previous day's prices.

ALL exemptions to indirect air-transport agencies were ended when the Civil Aeronautics Board announced last Thursday its policy for transAtlantic airplane charter operations during 1951. Two of the chief indirect agencies affected by the new C.A.B. regulation are Youth Argosy and the Student Travel Service. Both of these agencies operated last year in booking charter flights between the United States and Europe.

SAVANNAH, Ga.--Nearing completion here on the northeast corner of Drayton and Liberty Streets is the twelve-story Drayton Arms Building, said to be the first completely air-conditioned apartment house in the State of Georgia.

A THOUSAND white lilies have been used in the Easter Display now on view in the Channel Gar dens of Rockefeller Center, Fifth Avenue at Forty-ninth Street. Planted against a background of taxus in the six fountain pools of the Channel Garden area, these traditional flowers form a pathway extending from Fifth Avenue to the Lower Plaza.

Between twenty and forty fellowships--each valued at $250--will be awarded to secondary-school science teachers who will participate in a special six-week summer program at the Carnegie Institute of Technology.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 24--Although it was their assent that finally made possible the initialing of the Schuman plan, the Ruhr steel and coal industrialists still harbor important doubts about the plan's implementation in Germany.

TWO big group annuals and a wide variety of one-man shows opening last week kept the season's activities at high pitch. The National Academy's 126th annual includes work by nonmembers to the extent of about one-third of the exhibitors. The ever lively national print annual at the Brooklyn Museum makes a very stimulating report on the healthy state of graphic art of today. And a number of the one-man shows are decided records of progress.

EASTER trade did not quite measure up to expectations in several sections of the country, although there was a spurt toward the end of last week. Weather conditions, the television appeal of the Kefauver crime investigation and the early arrival of the holiday were all cited as factors in the failure of figures to reach anticipated levels.

THE FINANCIAL WEEK The stock market turned reactionary in the final session last week, with war issues weakest. All of the earlier recovery in the averages was erased in yesterday's sinking spell. Prices eased in the first two sessions; subsequently rallied to wipe out the losses, and then fell 1 to 3 points yesterday.

PARIS (By Wireless). MARCEL HERTAULT, a pros perous farmer, planned to seed thirty-nine acres of his fertile property this year with wheat, clover and alfalfa. His farm, on the outskirts of the famous ancient forest of Marlyle-Roi, is in a region known to many generations as the Trou d'Enfer or Hellhole. The farm has been rented from the French Government, whose President, Vincent Auriol, liked to hunt...

WASHINGTON, March 24--The American University announced plans today for a $25,000,000 construction program and the formulation of a sixty-three member national development committee of leaders in industrial, political and professional life.

Three bills have been introduced in the Senate to encourage more experimenting with the rainmaking methods devised by Drs. Vincent Schaefer, Bernard Vonnegut and Irving Langmuir, and to stop indiscriminate rainmaking, especially by the commercial firms that have sprung up in the semi-arid regions of the West.

NORFOLK, Va., March 24--The Navy this week assigned two of its landing craft to reenact the famous battle of the Monitor and the Merrimack during the sixty-first and final reunion of the United Confederate Veterans here May 30 through June 3.

Deputy Sheriff Charles Lyon of Sasakwa, Okla., sent out to check a minor highway mishap, came back with an extra $4 in his pocket. The driver of a car which had hit a cow recognized Lyon as the man who'd lent him $4 in Texas twenty-seven years ago and insisted that he take it back.

WHEN a conductor mounts the podium and bows to his audience he draws a veil of formality between himself and his listeners. His relations with the musicians in his charge are similarly constrained. If somebody fails to deliver his part properly, the conductor can only scowl or make threatening gestures.

Six members of the Israeli Cabinet, including Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, will arrive in this country at intervals in the next ten weeks, to participate in the campaign of the United Jewish Appeal and the flotation of an Israeli bond issue of $500,000,000.

The evening performance on April 23 of "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," a musical comedy with Shirley Booth and Johnny Johnston in the leading roles, at the Alvin Theatre, has been taken over as a benefit for the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 24--Miss Constance Ann Hathaway was married to Edward Ball Thayer 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Thayer of New Hampton, N.Y., formerly of Maplewood, N.J., this afternoon at Heathway, the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Odell S. Hathaway.

AMERICAN collectors are voicing through the philatelic press and in letters of protest to Washington their extreme displeasure over the decision of the Post Office Department to issue only four special stamps for 1951 as compared with eleven last year, twelve in 1949 and twenty-nine in 1948. Post Office Department officials also are said to be unhappy about the situation.

ON Easter Sunday it is fitting to discuss an interesting group of sacred works that have appeared on records of late. In the collection at hand every work antedates the nineteenth century, and a good many of them go back to the sixteenth.

The reaction to General MacArthur's latest statement on the situation in Korea must inevitably be mixed. Some of what he said is unshakably sound. Some of it is likely to prove of doubtful strategic or tactical value, to say the least.
WASHINGTON, March 24--The story of how Millard E. Tydings, Democratic veteran of the Senate, was defeated by a political unknown in the 1950 Maryland elections is slowly being unfolded.

FANWOOD, N.J., March 24-- Robert Devere Hope of 60 Martine Avenue, head of a consulting engineering firm that he founded in Newark in 1919 and an Army officer in both World Wars, died yesterday at his home. His age was 67.

PARIS, March 24--If ratified by the Parliaments and carried out by the Governments, the Schuman Plan, initialed this week in Paris, will revolutionize the structure and status of the coal and steel industries of Western Europe. It may likewise greatly change conceptions of national sovereignty.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., March 24 --Miss Theresa Ann Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Kenneth Howard of Millbrook, was married to Edward Carlos Carter 3d, son of Mrs. Paul E. Carter of Rochester, and the late Mr. Carter, this afternoon in the Lyall Memorial Federated, Church. The Rev. Chalmers Holbrook performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Howard home.

TAX LOSS ALLOWED ON DEAL IN REALTY In times of exceptionally high tax rates the allowability of deductions of losses in lease-back transactions can become one of the most important factors in determining benefits to the sellerlessee.
WASHINGTON, March 24--A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board recommended today that a union be required to reimburse three employer who were kept from their jobs by a strike.

David C. Ball, organizer and chairman of the board of directors of the Oakite Products Corporation at 22 Thames Street, died Friday night at his summer home in Lake Placid, N.Y., at the age of 93. He had made his home there for the last ten years, while having remained active in the work of the corporation.

A $10,000 grant-in-aid to support a year of research on a new method of selecting qualified candidates for teacher-training has been awarded the Bank Street College of Education by the United States Public Health Service.

The possibility that Anthony (Duke) Maffetore--who turned from Murder, Inc., to informer-- might have been murdered or spirited away by gang accomplices assumed added credibility yesterday. The police announced that they had recovered twenty-five stolen automobiles since the informer was arrested last October for alleged car theft.

LONDON, March 24--Oxford University's "navy" with its American "admiral," sank in the first three minutes of what was supposed to be the ninety-seventh Oxford-Cambridge boat race today, and the race was postponed until Monday.

LONDON, March 24--The statement of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur that he was ready to meet the Commander in Chief of the Chinese Communist forces in Korea to bring the hostilities to a close attracted more attention here today than his further statement that he had directed the United States Eighth Army to cross the Thirty-eighth Parallel again "if and when its security makes it tactically advisable."

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA. WAR has turned this mountain ous peninsula into a land of crazy contrasts. The cold white sun stares down on primitive villages of huts, nestling with toadstool fragility against dust-choked roads along which race the most modern and lethal machinery in the world--tanks, mortars, guns of all sizes, half-tracks.
Don Forman, former New York University basketball star, was charged yesterday with having approached City College players in behalf of a gambler to fix games in the 1950-51 season.

Officials of America's foundry industry, representing more than 8,000 plants throughout the country, are preparing formal objections against the proposed "manufacturers' General Ceiling Price Regulations," for which a tentative draft has been widely circulated in the industry by the Office of Price Stabilization.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- President Truman called a major conference of his defense advisers today to consider growing inflation stresses in general and the problem of labor-management disputes machinery in particular.
Serious dislocations in the construction industry here are likely unless "realistic" revisions in controls are enacted, the New York Building Congress has warned the National Production Authority.

Development of the "world's most powerful" television transmitter for the ultra-high frequencies, the video spectrum where the Federal Communications Commission has announced it plans fiftytwo new channels for an expanded service throughout the country, was reported here last week by engineers of the General Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, March 24--As was inevitable, the Senate Crime Investigating Committee is spending its closing days in a shower of political fireworks. Political skyrockets are being shot into the air; where they will fall to earth the committee does not know.

THOSE for whom art is a means of escape have never found much solace in the painting of Fernand Leger. It may occasionally break into a certain ponderous poetry but, by and large, it is down-to-earth, objective and immune to feeling.

At Paris the Big Four deputies-- the men who are trying to arrange an order of business for a Foreign Ministers Conference--have been engaged in a kind of diplomatic marathon. LONDON, March 25--Financial commentators have been describing the stock markets as sulphurous, and have thus truthfully portrayed prevailing conditions.

Britain has ceased to be an empire; a Socialist Government rules, or does its best to rule, the island's economic destinies; the pound isn't what it was; the British sausage is notable for its absence of meat, as is also the British...

ZURICH, March 25--After two weeks of deliberations in Bern over execution of the Washington agreement of May 25, 1946, to liquidate German assets in Switzerland, the American, British, French and Swiss delegations have at last reached accord on so many controversial issues that the agreement is expected to go into effect shortly.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 25-- The Yankees beat Mel Ott's Oakland Oaks, 4--2, this morning, then went across the bay for an afternoon skirmish with Lefty Frank O'Doul's San Francisco Seals.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP)--Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, said today that the Senate-House Economic Committee, of which he is chairman...

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly last week, ending mostly in lower ground. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts were 47 points lower to 2 points above the levels of the previous week.
MIAMI, Fla., March 25--Line doubles by Solly (The Great) Hemus and Red Schoendienst in the ninth inning gave the Cardinals a 5-4 victory over the Dodgers today.
MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L.I., March 25--The First Air Force was rededicated here today, on the eve of its tenth anniversary, to the task of mustering its resources into the first line of defence.

There has been a large subscription for the world premiere of the film adaptation of "The Tales of Hoffmann," next Sunday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, with the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross as beneficiary.

PARIS, March 25--After a three-hour emergency meeting today the Cabinet was understood to have agreed that the new wage levels in nationalized industiries would necessitate rises in the prices of coal, electricity and gas, and that the pay of Government employes must be increased by an average of about 13 per cent.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25--Boston's star-studded Red Sox, who long have made it a habit to get in some manager's hair, got into what Leo Durocher has left today.
French art exhibitions are well to the fore in galleries here this week. The first exhibition in nineteen years of paintings by FantinLatour opens today at Scott Fowles.
TOKYO, Monday, March 26 (AP) --Communique 834 by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's Headquarters, covering period of 6 A.M., March 25, to 6 A.M., March 26:

The nation's gold pile, dwindling almost continuously since the Korean war started, was cut another $44,000,000 last week. To date, approximately $2,375,000,000 of the national hoard has been shifted to foreign accounts; thereby reducing the total on hand here to $21,856,000,000, the lowest level since September, 1947.

AMSTERDAM, March 25--The Netherlands this week suddenly plunged into the problem of shifting from civilian to defense production. The position of the new Cabinet in this respect was outlined in a broadcast by the Minister of Economic Affairs, Jan Vanderbrink, who stressed that in the coming four years 6,000,000,000...

A double bill composed of Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavalio's "Pagliacci" was presented yesterday afternoon by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center. Both works were excellently performed.

Karl Christiansen of 121 Columbia Street, Huntington Station, L.I., a survivor of the sinking of the U.S.S. Maine in Havana harbor on the night of Feb. 15, 1898, died yesterday morning in St. Albans (Queens) Naval Hospital at the age of 78.

WASHINGTON, March 25--J. Howard McGrath, Attorney General, and J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, will be the star witnesses before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee tomorrow.

Official reports of declines in unemployment insurance claims and in the number of persons receiving public assistance, coupled with rising average weekly earnings indicated yesterday that defense mobilization was being reflected in an upward economic trend in this area.
William G. Christy, director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, laid down yesterday the enforcement policy he proposed to pursue with respect to violators of city smokecontrol regulations.

The five-story dwelling containing twelve rooms and three baths at 51 East Ninety-second Street has been sold by Mrs. Maria M. Pontabry of Paris, France, to Dr. George S. Goldman for occupancyas his residence and office.

Back in the days of the stagecoach, the run from San Francisco to St. Louis took twenty-five days and nights, and many a stop was made along the 2,700-mile journey to change mule teams and to feed passengers.

The appointment of thirty-eight leaders of the maritime and affiliated industries to the national executive committee of the United States Merchant Marine Memorial Chapel Fund was announced yesterday by John M. Franklin, chairman of the drive. Ten states are represented on the committee.

The New York Rangers closed their season in the National Hockey, League race by defeating the Chicago Black. Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. Training a steady fire on Goalie Harry Lumley, the Blue Shirts broke a third-period tie to prevail by 5 to 2.
High inventories built by retailers since the Korean war should be restored to a sound basis by midyear, executives said last week.

Any number of ideas for enhancing desserts come to mind at first taste of three delightful new sauces concocted by Mrs. Jeanne Douglas of Chanteclair Food Delicacies. Each sauce has a distinctive flavor--piquant ginger, tangy mocha or cool peppermint; all are rich with butter, cream and sugar.

PARIS, March 25--French exports to the dollar zone in February reached the highest level they have ever attained since the liberation. They stood at 12,700,000,000 francs. This is two and one-half times as great as the monthly average of French sales to the dollar zone in 1950 and five times greater than the monthly average in 1949.

BERLIN, March 25--Delegates to the Communist-dominated International Workers Conference in East Berlin brought their sessions to a close this evening with an appeal to the four-power meeting in Paris to place the question of German rearmament on the agenda "with priority" in accordance with the decisions at Yalta and Potsdam.

Mrs. Edna Blue, international chairman of the Foster Parents' Plan for War Children, a nonprofit organization, which for fourteen years has devoted its efforts to the care of orphans throughout the world, died Saturday night of a heart ailment in her home, 118 East Fortieth Street. She was 49 years old.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., March 25--The lower Rio Grande Valley is the heart of the 1,600-mile wide border belt stretching from Texas to California into which more than 1,000,000 Mexicans annually infiltrate illegally is quest of work.

The sale last week to French and Belgian interests of the remainder of its stock holdings in two European glass companies by the $100,000,000 Libbey--OwensFord Glass Company marks the beginning of a move by glass manufacturers in the United States to concentrate attention on home markets, the effects of which are expected to be far-reaching.
The Philadelphia Nationals, champions of the American Soccer League and the only team of that body surviving in the National Challenge Cup competition, yesterday suffered their first defeat...

Elisha M. Friedman, consulting economist, author, lecturer and statistician, died early yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after an operation. His age was 61. He was a brother of Dr. E. David Friedman, Professor of Neurology and department head at the New York University College of Medicine.
With the skies bright, but cold brisk winds blowing, mink was the fashionable order of the day in yesterday's Easter parade, worn with small white and pastel flowered hats.

In reply to the "cynics" who contend that Easter Sunday sends people to church because it is a "national holiday and fashion parade," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, minister of the Riverside Church, told 5,000 worshippers yesterday that "the Easter message strikes a responsive chord that meets a craving of the human spirit."
LONDON, March 25 (UP)-- Calmer but colder conditions are predicted for tomorrow's rerowing of the Oxford-Cambridge boat race on the Thames.

WHEN Jimmy Dykes was managing the White Sox he permitted his trusty aide, Muddy Ruel, to take complete charge of the pitching staff. One day a reporter entered the dressing room and asked who'd pitch that afternoon.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)-- The Spanish Government is reported ready to conclude a direct military alliance with the United States modeled after the North Atlantic defense pact.
WASHINGTON, March 25-- President Truman will address the fourth consultative meeting of the foreign ministers of the American republics at the opening session in Constitution Hall tomorrow.
CALGARY, Alberta, March 25 (AP)--Dick Button of Englewood, N.J., is king of North American figure skaters for the third straight year and he has a new queen is 16-year-old Sonya Klopfer of Brooklyn.

The thrilling voice of Eileen Farrell graced the PhilharmonicSymphony's Easter afternoon program in Carnegie Hall. Victor De Sabata conducted the concert, which, like those on Thursday and Friday, was devoted to the music of Wagner.

A one-story taxpayer building containing eight stores and occupying a plot 50 by 116 feet at 156163 Westchester Avenue, northeast corner of Ward Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Anna Perlstein to an investing client of Martin Koeppel, attorney, for cash over mortgages amounting to $38,000.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., March 25 (AP)--Potential shortages--in raw material, manpower and even in productive capacity in event of an all-out war-- are expected to be prime discussion themes here this week.

Citations for meritorious acts were awarded yesterday to 178 members of the Police Department. Two of the men received honorable mention, which makes them eligible for consideration for the annual medal awards.
Thousands of New Yorkers attended traditional Easter dawn services in many of the city's churches, theatres and parks.

As the House Ways and Means Committee scrapes the bottom of the tax barrel, a leading utility executive offers-an avenue for the collection of $88,500,000 a year. His suggestion promises to draw the fire of public power operators, from whose facilities the additional revenue would flow into the Federal treasury.

PITTSBURGH, March 25--Steel output in the country last week was up 1 point to 100 per cent of capacity. The shutdown at the Pittsburgh works of a company in this area kept the level from reaching at least 101.5 per cent. There was evidence that steel mills have been able to keep their ore...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 --David O. Selznick, independent producer, has put the British film, "Gone to Earth," which Sir Alexander Korda, Michael Powell and Emetic Pressburger made in England with Mr. Selznick as a participating partner, before the cameras here for retakes that will amount to nearly one-third of the picture's footage.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 25--Those whose duty it is to weigh the chances of a Russian attack in Europe leading to war this year are surprised by the tendency in the United States to regard the world situation as improved to a point where some of the effort and vigilance awakened by the crisis of last December can be relaxed.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 (AP)--Cleveland got 31 hits to take two games today. They beat the San Francisco Seals in an exhibition game here this morning, 15 to 1, and in the afternoon went over to Oakland and won by 14--3 with 8 runs in the fifth. Bob Feller, going 6 innings, was the winning hurler.

SEOUL, March 25--United Nations military advisers with the South Korean Army are beginning to revise upward their estimates of the Korean soldiers' combat efficiency, and some advisers predict South Korean forces soon will be able to protect this country's security against any future North Korean aggressions.

Retail furniture inventories and dealers' forward commitments are at abnormally high levels, but so far this has not seriously affected furniture manufacturers' orders. This is reported by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants for the industry, in a summary of market conditions last month.

TWENTY-TWO years ago a little-known English author suddenly rocketed to international fame with a long and cheerful novel which reminded numerous critics of Dickens. For several important reasons the meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the, American republics, which opens in Washington today, will be as interesting as any international conference since the war.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 25 (AP)--Jaroslav Drobny, former Czechoslovak Davis Cup star now playing for Egypt, won the men's singles championship in the Alexandria international tennis tournament today by defeating Irving Dorfman of New York, 6-1, 12--10, 6--2.

WASHINGTON, March 25--Activity on Capitol Hill comes to a near standstill this week as most members of Congress, taking advantage of the Easter recess, mix with constituents back home to learn what America is thinking.

Record sales sent net income of Sun Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1950, to $36,291,498. Dunlop, president.

Easter lilies and Easter bonnets bloomed true to immemorial promise yesterday. But the earliness of the holy day and the anxieties of current events made it less a carnival of spring than a hopeful way station on the road to an uncertain future.

GULFPORT, Miss., March 25 (AP) --Pat Abbott, former public links champion from Memphis, Tenn., added the Gulf Coast invitation golf tournament to his collection of laurels today.

Staffs in more than half the states are inadequate to enforce child labor laws in the face of growing school-age employment in the expanding defense economy, the National Child Labor Committee reported yesterday.

One hundred and thirty members of the congregation of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn, meeting at the church last night, voted by 119 to 11 to ask the vestry to elect the Rev. William Howard Melish as rector to succeed his father.

WASHINGTON, March 26--A record outlay of $23,900,000,000 for new plant and equipment will be made by American industry this year, according to the latest estimates of such expenditures made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Commerce.
The trial of an action for $341,600,000 against the Ford Motor Company, Dearborn Motors Corporation, and other defendants, was begun yesterday before Judge Gregory F. Noonan in Federal Court.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 26 --Manager Charley Dressen watched a group of his Dodgers beat the Vero Beach all stars by 6--3 today. But an item of great interest to him was the decision to bring pitchers Rex Barney and Johnny Van Cuyk to Miami next Wednesday.

The announcement of President Juan D. Peron of Argentina that on Feb. 16, 1951, in a pilot plant on Huemul Island "thermonuclear experiments were carried out under conditions of control on a technical scale" would be readily accepted by physicists if nothing more had been said.

Confronted by a limited budget and a shortage of manpower, the city's borough presidents will start this week to repair streets that were ravaged by winter. In all boroughs except Manhattan new paving for roads opened in connection with the growth of housing also will be laid.
HAVANA, March 26 (AP)--The 57-foot yawl Caribbee, sailed by Carleton Mitchell of Annapolis, Md., tonight won the eighteenth annual St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race.

ALBANY, March 26--Governor Dewey signed today the controversial loyalty bill that provided for the discharge or transfer of any civil service workers in security positions who were suspected on "reasonable grounds" of being subversive.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 26--The revenue losses in Nassau County because of the Long Island Rail Road's failure to pay one-half of its 1949 and all of its 1950 taxes to school districts, the state, township and special districts were borne entirely by the county treasury.
In his address yesterday to the InterAmerican Foreign Ministers' meeting in Washington, President Truman issued a ringing call to the twenty-one American republics.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)-- Several hundred hospital beds used by veterans are being yielded because of the increase in marijuana smoking among teen-agers, officials of the Public Health Service have told a House committee.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 26-- Premier Hussein Ala tonight proclaimed martial law in three more Iranian towns after Communists had called a general strike in the strategic oil region. Martial law was clamped on Teheran one week ago.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 26--The wife of a Philadelphia airline pilot avoided trial in Federal Court here today when she pleaded guilty to four charges of impersonating an Army nurse in a scheme to obtain more than $65,000 in the "sale" of surplus automobiles.

Bidding at 11 A.M. today on the $40,000,000 issue of Consumers Power Company bonds will undoubtedly hold the attention of financial markets, in the light of what has been happening over the past two weeks to yields on newly floated bonds in the wake of the adjustment of the Government bond market.
