HONG KONG, March 26--The New China News Agency reported today that twenty-five persons accused of being "arch counter-revolutionary criminals" had been arraigned Saturday before 5,500 "people's representatives" in Peiping and sent to their doom.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 27 (AP) --General MacArthur's communique 835 on operations for the twenty-four hours up to 6 A.M., Tuesday (4 P.M. Monday, Eastern standard time):
LONDON, March 26--You want to bet a couple of quid on the second race at Newmarket? Well, you just ring up your bookmaker. In Great Britain that's all there is to it, and it's perfectly legal.

WASHINGTON, March 26--A second Senate committee opened an inquiry today into how a former member of the House of Representatives was able to build a $20,000 investment into a $250,000, personal profit subject to minimum taxation through the buying and leasing of five World War II oil tankers.

A limited recovery was negotiated by the stock market yesterday after the sudden plunge Saturday. Buyers re-entered the market yesterday afternoon, but at the close the 1,092 issues traded showed 480 losses against 349 gains. The composite rate, however, was up 0.54 point.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 27-- Chinese and North Korean invaders yesterday were moving back from their mountain salient below the Thirty-eighth Parallel north of Seoul, apparently retreating behind the Imjin River, last natural barrier in that area between the advancing United Nations Army and North Korean territory.

WASHINGTON, March 26--Behind-the-scenes maneuvering in Congress seeks an added $50,000 for the Senate-House investigation of industrial mobilization and controls, but the move is handicapped by the possibility that it might open the way to a new assault on the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Metropolitan college basketball will continue to be played at Madison Square Garden next season despite the current bribery scandals.

Walter Hoving, chairman of the Anti-Sales Tax Committee of New York City, charged last night in a letter to Governor Dewey that Mayor Impellitteri had attempted to over-sell to the Governor the City's management improvement program for the last three years.
DANBURY, Conn., March 26-- Danbury voters, casting a decided protest ballot against the Democratic organization, today elected John P. Previdi as the city's first Republican Mayor in fourteen years.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- President Truman touched off the first controversy of the Hemisphere foreign ministers' meeting today by an interpolation into his speech suggesting that Chile was eager to give Bolivia an outlet to the Pacific.

LONDON, March 26 (AP)--Cambridge outclassed Oxford with a twelve-length victory in their ninety-seventh annual rowing race on the rain-spattered Thames River today and thereby earned a trip to the United States, the first for a British varsity crew.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26-- The Seafarers International Union, representing some 60,000 American Federation of Labor sailors and allied workers, opened its fifth biennial convention here today with renewed charges against aspects of the Federal Government's defense program.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 26-- Delegations of the various nations directly concerned in the United Nations Korean problem today indicated their virtually unanimous "unhappiness" over the crisis precipitated last week-end by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's sortie into the field of high policy in his three-point plan to halt the fighting in Korea.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 26 --In St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church here this evening, Miss Mary Ellen Shumway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ritter Shumway of Rochester, was married to Preston Arms Gaylord Jr., son of Mrs. Gaylord of Sodus, and the late Mr. Gaylord.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 26-- The Board of Directors of the International League for the Rights of Man released today a resolution "condemning" measures taken by the Argentine authorities against the independent newspaper La Prensa of Buenos Aires.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- President Truman today signed the bill to authorize continued payment of interest on Series E Savings Bonds after their ten-year maturity date.

TRENTON, March 26--Defense attorneys in the retrial of six men accused of the hold-up killing of an elderly shopkeeper here three years ago began today a bitter battle to exclude from the evidence oral and written admissions made by five of the men after their arrests.

WASHINGTON, March 26--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that United States gold stocks were reduced by $1,700,000,000 during 1950, but totaled $22,800,000,000 at the end of the year, and represented about twothirds of the gold reserves of the entire world outside Soviet Russia.
Governor Dewey has signed into law the bill designed to keep poor security risks, among state and local civil service employes, out of "sensitive" defense jobs where they could do damage.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)-- The Government withdrew price controls from florist and nursery products today, explaining these prices do not have much effect upon the cost of living. It was the first major domestic industry to be released from the Jan. 25 General Price Freeze.
LONDON, March 26 (UP)--The Tottenham Spurs all but clinched the first division championship in English soccer with a 2-to-1 victory over Fulham as league teams wound up a heavy Easter program today.

After an Easter recess, debate in the Senate is expected to be resumed tomorrow on the troops-for-Europe issue.

WASHINGTON, March 26--The National Education Association reported today that the average teacher in the nation's schools worked a forty-eight-hour week. It appealed for an increase in teachers and new school buildings to ease this "heavy" burden.

CHICAGO, March 26--A crop scare in the Southwestern winter wheat belt proved effective in sending grain prices higher on the Board of Trade here today. Wheat closed 1 5/8 to 2 1/8 cents a bushel higher, new-crop months leading the advance.

As the Korean campaign goes on the stock of the South Korean soldier goes up. This process, as George Barrett has reported to this newspaper, has been going on for some time and has not yet been properly appreciated in the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 26--The senate Crime Investigating Committee ordered two gamblers held under arrest tonight until their next appearance Friday unless they post $10,000 bonds each. They had refused to testify unless television, newsreel and radio equipment was removed from the hearing room.

Col. Henryk Floyar Rajchman, Polish Minister of Industry and Commerce in 1932-36, who took a leading part in saving his nation's gold, reserves of $75,000,000 from the Germans in 1939-40 by having it carried secretly to France, died on Thursday in his home at 620 West 115th Street, after a threemonth illness. His age was 57.

The first use of Ansco color film by a major producer was revealed by Jack Frye, president of the General Aniline Film Corporation, in reporting record sales and a $4,073,710 increase in earnings last year.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- President Truman told twenty Latin-American foreign ministers today that the Western Hemisphere's only road to peace and security was to concert its defenses and combine its strength to support those who battle for freedom in both Europe and Asia.

JESSELTON, North Borneo, March 26--The high income from rubber is seriously disturbing the life and economy of North Borneo. Officials call the rubber boom "the worst thing that could have happened to Borneo" and hope for an early lowering and stabilization of prices.

More than 2,000,000 persons have been expelled from Communist parties in Eastern Europe and China during the last three years in purges that are still continuing and whose final toll may reach the 5,000,000 figure, evidence available in this country indicates.
CAGLIARI, Sardinia, March 18 (By Airmail)--The people here call Sardinia the forgotten island.

The Boeing Airplane Company, in its annual report issued for publication today, shows net earnings for 1950 rose to $10,826,558, or $10 a share, more than twice its profit of $4,411,348 or $4.07 a share the year before.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 26-- The Giants flashed no overpowering attack today, but the Tigers played the game with buttered fingers and that more than saved the situation for Leo Durocher.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 (AP)--A major shake-up intended to stiffen the Communist revolutionary forces in Indo-China was reported today by the Peiping radio, with implications that the Chinese Reds might now be calling the signals.

Dr. Charles Edward Lucke, Stevens Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Columbia University and an expert on internal cumbustion engines, died Sunday night in St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 74 years old. Dr. Lucke resided at Butler Hall, 400 West 119th Street.

A rally at noon yesterday in Rockefeller Center opened a coinbox drive by 1,000 women volunteers of local chapters of the American Red Cross who will try to raise $1,000,000 toward the city's goal of $6,500,000 by next Sunday.
DETROIT, March 26--An international campaign to stop inflation was urged today by George A. Sloan, president of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, March 26--Demands by the Communist party for further delay in its fight against compulsory registration under the Internal Security Act of 1950 were brushed aside today by the Supreme Court.

For the first time in the history of the city's school system, a Negro has been recommended for the important post of Assistant Superintendent of Schools. He is Dr. John B. King, principal of an elementary school in Brooklyn.

HOBOKEN, N.J., March 26-- Charles Yanowsky, ex-convict and waterfront racketeer, who was murdered in 1948, sought to establish a huge gambling syndicate here in 1947 with the aid of city officials and local business men, it was charged in the Shea report, first released in its entirety today.
LAUREL, Md., March 26 (UP)-- Alan T. Clark's Senator Joe, a Kentucky Derby candidate, scored a nose victory in the featured Mt. Vernon Purse at Laurel Race Track today in his first race of the year.

Ethel Greenglass Rosenberg, second of three defendants charged with the capital crime of war-- time atomic espionage for Soviet Russia, joined her husband, Julius, yesterday in claiming constitutional privilege against answering questions on their Communist party affiliations.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 26--Miss Constance Therese Dowd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Dowd of West Orange, was married to Vincent Alfred Forlenza, son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix Forlenza of South Orange, this morning in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church.

Coffee and rubber futures advanced on the exchanges here yesterday, but most other commodity futures were unchanged to slightly easier in listless trading.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26-- The six-year sruggle for control of the American President Lines has put the Executive Branch of the United States Government in direct defiance of the courts, Gregory Harrison, counsel for R. Stanley Dollar, charged in the Federal District Court here today.

TOKYO, March 26--The United States naval forces in the Far East could conduct a successful blockade of China if Washington so desired, Vice Admiral Arthur D. Struble, commander of the Seventh Fleet, said today at a press conference.

Inspiration for home seamstresses and incentive for non-sewers to learn will certainly be derived from the "Made of Cotton" show which is being presented three times a day in Macy's sixth-floor sewing center for the balance of the week.
ALBANY, March 26--New York state's voters are required, under a bill made law today to elect United States Senators only in even-numbered years.
"Odette," a British-made drama starring Anna Neagle in the title role, which arrives at the Park Avenue Theatre, is today's lone film newcomer.

The United States District Court is awaiting a request for a hearing on an unusual development in maritime law--a claim for a salvage award and expenses by the British Government for coming to the aid of a shell-damaged and burning American freighter.
The sources of inflation are too numerous and varied to permit a single or "painless" process of correction, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York declares in its annual report, issued today.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP)--Lightheavyweight Champion Joe Maxim, clever Cleveland boxer, today agreed to defend his title against Chicago's hard-punching Bob Satterfield at the Chicago Stadium June 27.
A program for setting aside a part of domestic production to supply requirements of the nation's export trade soon will be urged on mobilization authorities, key sources disclosed yesterday.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 26 (AP) --The Red Sox slugged out fourteen hits today in defeating the Athletics, 9--3. Chuck Stobbs and Harry Taylor limited the A's to seven singles.

TOKYO, March 26 (UP)--The United States Army took time out from the Korean war to give a New York sales manager and his sergeant son fresh from the, battle-front the happiest day of their lives today.

Children's wear specialty shops and neighborhood dry goods stores are taking a cautious buying attitude on spring and summer merchandise, it was noted yesterday at the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart, Inc., in the New Yorker Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 26--The Supreme Court was asked today to set aside an order of the Federal Communications Commission approving color television by a method developed by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 26 (AP)--Arthur Doering, 34-year-old Chicago golfer, who plays out of Richmond, Va., hit the jackpot today after five years of trying when he won $2,000 first money in the Greensboro open tournament.

Members of the New York County Medical Society voted here last night to start a series of television broadcasts to present authentic information on medical advances on a large scale to the general public.

A new accessory may have the same freshening effect for a dinner table as in a spring hat for a woman. A new shape in a bread crumber, a table bell or a carving set are among some of the accessories recently arrived.

Longshoremen returned to work on Pier 45, North River, yesterday. This ended a six-day wildcat strike that stemmed from plans of the Grace Line to move to Pier 56, North River.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 62 points net lower than Saturday's closing figures.

Sales volume of New York and Brooklyn department stores for the three weeks preceding Easter equaled that for the pre-Easter period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Jose Iturbi, after concerts in Europe and in other American cities this season, gave his first New York recital in six years last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Iturbi had a large and approving audience.

CAMP KILMER, N.J., March 26 --This Army camp, which was jumping off and welcome home spot for more than 4,000,000 World War II soldiers, climbed out of its weeds again today to prepare the first of new thousands of "cold war" reinforcements for shipment to Europe.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 27 (AP)--Francis W. White, president of American Woolen Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today that unfilled orders of the company were at a high record of $217,000,000.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 27 --Ground was broken today for Princeton University's $650,000 Woodrow Wilson Hall. There was no ceremony.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Republican efforts to give Congress an outright veto power over the dispatch of American ground troops to Europe were opened today in the Senate in the last week of its three-months-long debate.
KANSAS CITY, March 27 (AP)-- The Citizens Association held a solid lead in returns from today's election and appeared to have kept control of the city government.

ALBANY, March 27 (AP)--The arrest of a Catskill accountant and a United States internal revenue agent on bribery charges in connection with the filing of Federal income tax returns was disclosed today.

Queens police admitted yesterday that a new type of criminal has been operating in that borough. He is a thug, who, working singly or with an accomplice, has been answering car sales advertisements and robbing the prospective seller.

The American people and their Government join today in extending a cordial and sincere welcome to the most distinguished visitors France has ever sent to these shores--President Vincent Auriol and Mme. Auriol, who arrive in New York on the Ile de France this morning.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 27-- Professor O. Glenn Saxon of Yale University, former economic consultant to the Republican National Committee, declared in a report made public today that a steel mill cannot survive in New England unles it is heavily subsidized by the Federal Government or by the state in which it is located.

Louis Jouvet, French star, who is appearing in "L'Ecole des Femmes" at the Anta Playhouse, yesterday expressed his gratification at the goodwill and cordiality extended to him and his company by American theatregoers and critics.
LAUREL, Md., March 27 (AP)-- Halter, owned by Cedar Farm at Bel Air, Md., won the $4,000 Annapolis Purse by four lengths today before 10,207 fans at Laurel Race Track.
Mrs. Ellen Knauff quietly gave herself up yesterday and was taken back to Ellis Island.

LONDON, March 27--Sir Harold B. Butler, one of the principal sponsors of the International Labor Office at Geneva, and later its director, died yesterday in a hospital at Reading. He was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Price ceilings on livestock are essential to the control of meat prices, Michael V. DiSalle, Director of the Office of Price Stabilization, told representatives of the livestock industry who met with him here today.

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., demanded yesterday a meeting with the Board of Transportation by next Tuesday on the question of the forty-hour week and backed the demand with the threat of "appropriate action."

Unless there is a marked increase in the number of blood donations to the New York City blood program of the Red Cross it may not be possible to fill the special shipment of whole blood to Korea scheduled to leave La Guardia Airport tomorrow evening, Brig. Gen. C.M. Walson, program director, warned yesterday.
A drive was started yesterday to bring public pressure on the next session of the Legislature for licensing the sale of table wines in food stores.

Don't look now, but at this moment the Federal Government is the possessor of a handsome surplus. With the fiscal year now nearly nine months old (it ends each year as of June 30), the Treasury shows a surplus of more than $4,000,000,000.

Aaron Feld, a retired policeman convicted last Tuesday of perjury because of his testimony before the holdover grand jury investigating organized gambling in Brooklyn, received yesterday the maximum term of two and a half to five years in prison and was fined $5,000.

OTTAWA, March 27 (AP)--Canada has been invited to become a member of a special international committee to study means of carving up newsprint production more equitably among free-world consumers, a Government source disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee, in closing its public hearings today, urged officials of the Treasury Department to tighten administrative procedures in income tax returns of known gamblers, racketeers and criminals.

McGhee, United States Assistant Secretary of State, and Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Secretary of State Dean Acheson rallied the American republics today to the "partnership of the free world" against what he called the greatest menace this hemisphere has ever faced--the "mortal threat" of Soviet communism. He asked for action "now."

The Committee on Public Health Relations of the New York Academy of Medicine declared yesterday that "the antihistaminic preparations are of no value in the treatment of true colds and the public should be warned of the hazards attending their use."

The eastern seaboard from Massachusetts down to South Carolina has been assured of a supply of natural gas for 300 years. In addition, some southeastern states, including Alabama and Georgia may expect an uninterrupted flow of the fuel for another three centuries.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1950 a consolidated net income of $70,193,146 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $5.81 each on the 12,077,626 capital shares outstanding. Howard S. Cullman, Broadway's most active and successful theatre investor, acknowledged yesterday that he was making efforts to obtain a long-term lease to operate Washington's National Theatre as a legitimate playhouse on a "nonsegregation basis."

Grogan, president of the union.

The "workhorses" of World War II--the often maligned Liberty ships--are once again preparing to travel the seas with emergency cargoes. Forty-one are to be withdrawn from Government lay-up for this work.

Stock prices lost considerable ground yesterday in the heaviest trading in two weeks. Railroad issues were the weakest, most of them finishing at the lows for the year thus far. In the final minutes of trading, prices turned a shade steadier, but losses ranging up to 3 points were numerous throughout the list. The composite average of prices declined 2.12 points.

TOKYO, March 28--Any attempt by the Chinese Nationalists to invade the mainland of China will be blocked by the United States Navy, Vice Admiral Harold M. Martin said today as he assumed command of the Seventh Fleet.

A new novel by John Sheridan, "The Magnificent MacDarney," will be issued tomorrow by Pellegrini Cudahy. It is described as "a story of a magnificent Dublin ne'er-do-well, soaker, cadger and posturer."

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 28-- George Rajasooria, political adviser to the United Nations Truce Observation Committee in Palestine, raised today the possibility that the recent strife on Israel's borders would be submitted to the Security Council.

The Brooklyn chapter of the American Red Cross, operating from its headquarters at 57 Willoughby Street, has been aiding war casualties for many years. Now it is about to become a war casualty itself. It has to find a new home.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, commended the New York City Cancer Committee yesterday for its assistance in the fight against cancer. He spoke at the formal opening of the organization's permanent headquarters at 7 East Fifty-second Street.

Apparently foreseeing an interminably long case unless some phases of the complaint are subordinated, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina expressed the thought yesterday some of the points in the anti-trust suit against seventeen investment bankers should "go hang."
LONDON, March 28 (AP)--Two leading Conservative British newspapers today defended General MacArthur against criticism of his conduct of the Korean campaign.

Plans for the erection of a one or two-story commercial building were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the fourstory apartment house on lot 25 by 92 feet at 455 West Eighteenth Street by the estate of Walter C. Endler Jr. to a buyer in a deal negotiated by J.P. and L.A. Kissling, brokers. The house to be demolished is assessed at $13,000.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 28--Before an enthusiastic audience of 1,000 persons, Mary Robbs, 25-year-old Negro soprano, sang three numbers as a soloist with the Chattanooga Symphony Orchestra tonight.
CHICAGO, March 28--General selling developed in all grains on the Board of Trade here today, based on a revival of peace talk and fairly general rains in the Southwest.

Many parties will be given this afternoon at the third annual Spring Frolic and Tea Dance for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York. The event is being held in the main ballroom of the Plaza. All boxes and tables are reported to have been reserved.
Sam Aro, formerly of Rockville Centre, L.I., but in recent years a broadcaster in Daytona Beach, has been engaged to do the Giant jottings over New York station...

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., March 28--At least $750,000 of "scare" money, driven from Connecticut by the law that permits immediate attachment of assets of a defendant in a damage suit, was found in one bank in this state.
ALBANY, March 28--General use of fluorine in municipal water supplies as a teeth preservative was recommended officially today by the State Department of Health.

The Grand Jury Association of New York County said yesterday that the same "watch-dog" grand jury idea recommended to the Kefauver committee by J. Edgar Hoover as a means of checking on local officials had been passed over by the last session of the state Legislature.

The possibility of a sale of the American Broadcasting Company to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was indicated yesterday by officials of the latter concern. Spokesmen for A.B.S. declined to comment.

Reflecting the switchmen's strike and its after-effects, some of the nation's leading carriers have reported rather large deficits from operations in February. The New York Central, which probably suffered more than any other railroad from the strike, reported yesterday a deficit of $10,079,298.

CLEVELAND, March 29--The National Catholic Educational Association was called upon today to restore value to home ties by teaching children to respect, obey, love and serve parents and to do its utmost to halt family "disintegration" in America.

The Federal Communications Commission warned Hollywood motion-picture producers yesterday to make their leading players and films available to television if they expected favorable consideration of their own bids to enter video. The warning was contained in a statement issued in Washington.

Net income of the Electric Bond and Share Company, whose plan for compliance with the divestment orders of the Holding Company Act awaits a decision of the Securities and Exchange, Commission, earned $5,144,448, or 98 cents a share, last year. In 1949 the net income amounted to $2,631,134, or 50 cents a share.

CHICAGO, March 29--The Commission on Colleges and Universities of the North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools voted today to continue De Paul University on its accredited list for the next two years.

The stock market presented a ragged appearance again yesterday but leaned to the higher side. Changes were highly unconclusive. Brokers offered only scant bits of advice on the present condition of trading and price range. Largescale traders and investors remained on the sidelines, with the...

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 29--Charles Adriance Mead, consulting engineer, of 165 Wildwood Avenue, died last night of a heart attack in the Lackawanna Railroad terminal at Hoboken, while on the way home from New York. He would have been 81 years old on Sunday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 29-- A view that advertising must be kept up in national, cooperative and trade media, even in the face of acute product shortages, was expressed today before the meeting of the Association of National Advertisers here.

ST. PAUL, March 29 (AP)--Howard Kahn, Midwest newspaper man, died of a heart attack yesterday at the age of 65. He recently had been a columnist, under the name of Paul Light, for The St. Paul Pioneer Press.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., March 29--Urgent appeal to the Government to avoid bureaucratic controls which will hobble production and regiment the economy was voiced by all speakers at the opening of the second annual convention of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute here today.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The uneasiness of some Latin American nations over regional involvement in the security problems of the United Nations became a major factor today at the fourth consultative meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the American Repulics.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The United States has completed a working draft of the Japanese peace treaty, which will be in the hands of all fourteen nations concerned, including the Soviet Union, by tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 29--President Truman said today that he had made up his mind whether he would run for re-election in 1952, but he was going to keep the answer a secret for awhile.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The Administration's Senate leaders began a somewhat anxious reassessment of their strength today on an important phase of the troops-for-Europe issue against the showdown scheduled next Monday.
LAKE SUCCESS, March 29--Official United Nations political activity on the Korean case is at a standstill, and the organization is looking in two directions for a lead...

Nearly two years having elapsed since they invaded the South Pacific, Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d have moved over to the Gulf of Siam. "The King and I," which opened at the St. James last evening, is their musical rendering of Margaret Landon's "Anna and the King of Siam."
ALBANY, March 29--Following is the text of Governor Dewey's executive order creating a State Crime Commission:

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, whose conduct of operations in the Far East again is under fire in Washington, has been accused--particularly last fall after the Chinese Communist intervention in Korea--of mistakes in judgment and in military dispositions.

Emblems of the United States and the Netherlands as well as the flag and banners of the St. Nicholas Society, made a colorful background for the dinner and ball held by the organization last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
The twin vehicular tunnels under Battery Park that were begun a little more than two years ago will be opened to traffic on April 10.

AN airliner plummeted out of the skies and into a Kansas cornfield twenty years ago tomorrow. From the White House to the lowliest hovel an entire nation mourned because Knute Rockne had been killed in the crash. Who was Knute Rockne that he could plunge an entire nation into such genuine grief? He was an immigrant boy from Norway who became a football coach.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 29--Yugoslav sources report a sharpening of political conflict in Rumania, Bulgaria and Albania, Balkan satellites of the Soviet Union.

We hope the news is somehow kept from our soldiers fighting in Korea that New York City, after a month's campaign, has given only 56 per cent of its 1951 quota of $6,500,000 for the American Red Cross. E. Roland Harriman, president of the Red Cross, told a radio audience bluntly last night what will happen if New Yorkers do...
Half the 22,000 new cases of blindness each year in this country are preventable, Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, declared here last night.
Deputy Chief Inspector Abraham Goldman retired from the Police Department last night after having been questioned for two days on his relationship with Irving Sherman.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)-- Industrial production this month promises to equal or surpass the peacetime record level of February and January, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

The State Racing Commission yesterday received word from Albany that Governor Dewey had signed the bill which gives to the commission the licensing powers that previously had been exercised by the Jockey Club and National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

YONKERS, March 29--The late Mrs. Agnes Edgar Bigelow, whose ramshackle mansion here yielded another $33,841 to searchers yesterday, has created such a problem by leaving half her $1,000,000 estate in hidden cash instead of customary investments that an exceptional part of the fortune may be wiped away by taxes.
WASHINGTON, March 29--The chief investigator in the Senate inquiry into the 1950 Maryland Senatorial election said under oath today that he had been hired for the job on the recommendation of...
A temporary shortage of tires in this city was reported yesterday by Jerry Shaw, president of the Greater New York Tire and Battery Association.

TOKYO, March 29--Should the Korean war continue much longer, the United States Navy will begin using guided missiles, Rear Admiral Allen E. Smith, commander of Task Force 77, said today at a press conference.

E. Roland Harriman, president of the American National Red Cross, said last night that unless the organization could meet its national minimum goal of $85,000,000 its military welfare program in Korea and Japan would have to be curtailed.

WASHINGTON, March 29--President Truman, mindful of the strength in unity, expressed his confidence today that world peace "could and would" be maintained by the unshakeable union of the forces of democracy.
Rare postage stamps from the collection of former King Carol II of Rumania were sold at public auction here yesterday, the first time a king's collection had thus been sold.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Truman appealed anew today for prompt Congressional approval of his request for emergency aid to famine-ridden India.

Emily M. Keller has sold the three-story apartment building at 55-57 Eighth Avenue to Motor Service Center, Inc. The property occupies an irregular plot about 38 by 66 feet in the block between Horatio and Thirteenth Streets in the Greenwich Village section.

Loans to business by banks in this area since the first of this year were cut $13,000,000 last week, to $531,000,000. The reduction, third to be registered in 1951, brought the total of such loans outstanding to $6,836,000,000. In the comparable period last year business loans declined $58,000,000.

Two New York men and one woman have been found guilty of betraying secrets of the atomic bomb to Soviet Russia during the last war. They have denied their guilt and have appealed their case. But to the layman it must seem that they have been convicted...

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 29--Britain removed herself today from the path of the implementation of the Schuman plan in Germany, still informally protesting, however, that the agreement that made it possible was unsatisfactory.

Julius Rosenberg, the electrical engineer, will be 33 years old on May 12. Like his wife, Ethel, he was born into a poor family on the lower East Side. His father, Harry, and his mother, Sophie Cohen Rosenberg, both were born in Russia.

WASHINGTON, March 29--In rulings of extraordinary implications, the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board has refused to issue complaints in cases where unions procured the dismissal of two workers, one on the ground of suspected Communist activity, the other because of a bad job record.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--Following is the text of the address today by President Vincent Auriol of France before the National Press Club:

JERSEY CITY, March 29--Following a two-hour conference with Mayor John V. Kenny and Director of Public Safety Louis Messano of this city, Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., late today announced the appointment of Patrick Connolly as special trustee of Local 1,247, I.L.A., here.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 29 --Ligon Johnson, a leading copyright attorney, died here today in the Greenwich Hospital at the age of 78.

The number of persons who read some part of the daily and Sunday newspapers is about the same in homes with or without television, according to a national survey made by Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., advertising agency. The survey was made to determine the impact of television on the leisure time of Americans.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 29-- Another link in the chain of evidence that points to basketball as being a home-court sport was added tonight, as the Syracuse Nationals squared their semi-final series with the New York Knickerbockers.

The State of Israel's issue of $500,000,000 in interest-bearing and capital appreciation bonds has been cleared for offering by the Securities and Exchange Commission and their sale will get under way about May 1, it was announced yesterday.

HAVANA, March 20--A great increase in imports nurtured by a sugar prosperity and spurted by recent "war scare" buying, has brought to the Havana waterfront a feverish air of commerce regarded as unprecedented in the port's 400-year history.

ALBANY, March 29--Governor Dewey created by executive order today a five-member State Crime Commission vested with powers to investigate and act against racketeers and the links between organized crime and any unit of government anywhere in the state.

TODAY all roads seem to be leading toward the Finger Lakes and the special rainbow trout season, which has just been expanded to take in brooks and browns also, and reports indicate that the Standing Room Only sign will be displayed in many of the inns, taverns and guest houses of that popular area.
American industry offers new fields to conquer for autograph and manuscript collectors, R.W.G Vail, directors of the New York Historical Society, declared yesterday.
TOKYO, Friday, March 30--United Nations troops yesterday fought their way closer to the Thirty-eighth Parallel in Korea against stiffening resistance by the Chinese and North Korean enemy.

Establishment of a State Crime Commission is a logical and indeed essential sequel to the Kefauver investigation. Governor Dewey has made some excellent appointments in setting up the commission, which will have broad powers to "investigate generally the relationship between organized crime and any unit of government anywhere in the state."

New Fashions for a most important moment of the day, mealtime, are skillfully expressed in twelve table settings now on view on the ninth floor of Lord Taylor. Florence, the designer of the settings and also of the mats used on these tables, shows a lively imagination in her arrangements which...

WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Truman declared today that he had no intention of discharging Donald S. Dawson, his administrative assistant for personnel matters, because of his involvement in the Senate investigation into influence and favoritisim in lending operations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

LONDON, March 29--Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist troops on Formosa will be able to make a successful mass landing on the Communist-held coast of China within two years if they get landing craft, according to. Dr. Han Li-wu, former Chinese Cabinet Minister.
TORQUAY, England, March 29-- The contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade convened in a special session here today.

ALBANY, March 29--Joseph M. Proskauer, who was appointed by Governor Dewey as chairman of the newly created State Crime Commission, served as a justice of the Supreme Court, First Department, from 1922 to 1933. During the latter years of his service, he was a member of the Appellate Division.

Possible death sentences moved closer to three defendants in the nation's first atomic spy trial when a Federal Court jury found all three guilty of wartime espionage for Soviet Russia at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.
The new pricing regulations for food merchants won qualified approval from industry leaders yesterday.

PARIS, March 29--Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, who accompanied President Vincent Auriol to Washington, is expected to make a supreme attempt there to save the Big Four deputies' conference here from a breakdown.

Tin futures on the Commodity Exchange soared yesterday 800 to 1,000 points, or 8 to 10 cents a pound, in response to the Government's action in raising the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's quotation for the metal from $1.34 to $1.46 a pound.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, sent to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee yesterday for incorporation in its record a complete denial that Frank Costello now exercises any influence in Tammany Hall.
Grower A. Whalen announced plans yesterday for the ceremonies with which New York will do honor to President Vincent Auriol of France for three days next week.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 6 points higher to 34 points lower than on Wednesday.
TODAY, 2:30 P.M.: Walt Disney cartoons, Brooklyn Museum, Eastern Parkway. Free.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29--It was the Cardinals' turn to flash some high-powered pitching today and there just wasn't anything the Giants could do about it.

Because of the increasing shortage of ship radio officers the Federal Communications Commission has yielded to pressure from the shipping industry and will temporarily reduce certain qualifications and requirements in the issuing of licenses.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 (AP)--"All About Eve," Jose Ferrer and Judy Holliday were the winners tonight of Hollywood's twenty-third annual Academy Awards for the industry's top achievements of 1950.
LONDON, March 29--Britain's home furnishings designers have plunged into an imaginative "rebellion" against the depressing restrictions that surround this country's households.
The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, operator of a 2,400mile gas pipeline network between the Southwest and the Appalachian area, more than doubled its profits last year.

The American Gas and Electric Company, fourth largest utility system and serving the heart of the nation's defense arsenal, earned the greatest profit in its forty-three-year history during 1950. It amounted to $24,191,232, equal to $4.86 a common share, compared with $21,446,838, or $4.31 a share in 1949, a gain of 12.8 per cent.

Now that spring is here, many a young maid's fancy will turn to thoughts of wedding plans. One of her major concerns will be the choice of her gown and those of her attendants. Saks Fifth Avenue's selections for the spring bride, from the Salon Moderne, were previewed yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, March 29--La Prensa can be expected to appear again but only with a voice that will be pleasing to the Peron regime, an editorial in Democracia morning paper backing the Government, said in a roundabout way today.
In Korea Thursday the United Nations ground offensive continued, with action focused on the western front where enemy delaying elements failed to contain our attacks.

PARIS, March 29--The Economic Cooperation Administration, in conformity with the new role that Congress is to be asked to assign to it, has begun to channel United States aid to Europe so as to support its defense production and to counteract such economic setbacks as may result directly...

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 29 (AP)--Marty Furgol, Long Beach, Calif., professional and golf's fifthranking money winner this year, putted his way into the first-round lead of the $10,000 Azalea open tournament today with a 32, 35-- 67, five under par.

DANBURY, Conn., March 29-- The Fairfield County Superior Court has been asked to decide an involved question concerning the Connecticut General Statutes in their relation to members of the medical profession.
The Fruehauf Trailer Company, builder of truck-trailers, had the most successful year in its history in 1950 with sales and earnings at new high records.

CHICAGO, March 29--Government financed steel plants built at the expense of the taxpayer are not needed because of the current growth of the steel industry, Edward L. Ryerson, chairman of the Inland Steel Company, and Clarence B. Randall, president, said today in their annual report to stockholders.

Operations last year of International Paper Company and its subsidiaries, world's largest papermaking organization, were the best in the history of the company. Records were achieved in production, tonnage, sales and earnings and new highs were set in Government taxes, dividends paid stockholders and payrolls.

The memory of many a college alumnus must have been jogged the other day when Benjamin Fine, this news paper's education news editor, noted that religion has assumed new importance on the American college campus since the start of the Korean war.

President Vincent Auriol comes to this country as the spokesman of France rather than on any governmental business. He is the head of the state and not the head of the Government. He is not the leader of his party, as our President is, but he is elected for a fixed term of office--...

WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Truman told his news conference today that he saw no conflict in the diverse views on preparedness expressed by General of the Army George C. Marshall, Secretary of Defense, and Charles E. Wilson, Director of the Office of Defense Mobilization.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)-- Announced American casualties in Korea rose to 57,120 today, an increase of 1,306 since last week.
WASHINGTON, March 29--The Committee for Economic Development proposed today a $6,000,000,000 budget reduction and a $10000,000,000 tax increase to put the Government on a pay-as-you-go basis.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The Government of France will discharge its responsibilities fully under the North Atlantic defense pact and place twenty fully equipped divisions in the field by the end of 1953 without neglecting its comitments in Indo-China,...
BOSTON, March 29--Carl Dreyfus, business leader and former publisher of Hearst newspapers in Boston, died today in his hotel suite. He was 76 years old.

CHICAGO, March 29--Armour Co. reported higher first-quarter sales and earnings today. Price controls imposed just after the quarter closed, however, and higher costs since have been penalizing operations and raising the threat of open marketing, F.W. Specht, president, said.

CHICAGO, March 29--The grain markets reversed their action of yesterday on the Board of Trade here today and were as strong as they were weak. Rejection by Red China of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's offer to talk peace had a far-reaching effect on sentiment and brought in general buying with wheat leading in activity.
WASHINGTON, March 29--The Federal Communications Commission reported today that revenues of the television telecasting industry in 1950 more than tripled.

At Tel Aviv, after a visit to Iran, Assistant Secretary of State George C. McGhee is reported to have said that the Shah's turbulent kingdom is "threatened with chaos" but that the United States does not intend to interfere.

Kid Gavilan of Havana will oppose Eugene Hairston, Harlem middleweight, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight will be the last in the Garden until the circus moves out and it is likely to draw a crowd of 8,000 fans.

Arthur Frantz, who directed the 1949 season of the Lemonade Opera in the Greenwich Mews Playhouse, is trying again at the same location. This time the group is called the Frantz Opera Players. Everything except the singers, virtually, is the same.

Dimitri Mitropoulos appeared as conductor-pianist when he performed Malipiero's Fourth Piano Concerto for the first time in America at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall. On certain earlier occasions Mr. Mitropoulos had electrified us by his similar presentaiton of the Third Piano Concerto of Prokofieff.

The Islip and Smithtown, L.I., Union Free School District No. 6 sold yesterday $575,000 of bonds due from 1952 to 1980 to Roosevelt Cross, Francis I. du Pont Co. and Tilney Co. at a bid of 100.83 for 2 s. Reoffering was made at yields ranging from 1.25 to 2.50 per cent.

TRENTON, March 29--Detective Lieut. Andrew F. Delate, who played a leading role in obtaining confessions from five of six men being retried for the 1948 hold-up murder of a shopkeeper here, testified today that he did not see any of the men struck, threatened or promised anything at any time before they signed the statements.

The outlook in the fish markets today is brighter than it has been for some weeks. In contrast to last Friday's higher price tags on most species, five are lower and only one more costly. Fresh water fish, however, are scarce this week-end with the exception of carp, according to the Fishery Council.

Montgomery Ward Co., the nation's second largest merchandising organization, made more money last year than in any of its seventy-nine years, with net earnings of $74,159,977, 55 per cent ahead of the previous year, while sales were only 7.9 per cent higher.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 (AP)--The Schooner Tropicair with its male skipper and all-girl crew was towed into port here tonight. The missing craft had been found earlier by a Coast Guard plane.

BERLIN, March 29--The United States and British commandants in Berlin entered vigorous separate protests today against yesterday's episode in the Potsdamerplatz in which East German policemen fired on four United States Army sightseeing buses.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 29-- One Yankee explosion was enough to bury the Cubs today. Unable to win on an eighteen-hit quota yesterday, the Bronx Bombers bunched five of their six hits in the fourth inning today against southpaw Johnny Schmitz and scored all their runs for a 7-to-5 triumph.

THE most famous remark Horace Walpole ever made was: "The world is a comedy to those who think, a tragedy to those who feel." Although the master of Strawberry Hill felt quite strongly about a number of matters, he spent most of his life demonstrating that he was a thinker who thought the world comic.

Acting on a directive from Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, all Social Security field offices here will be open from 8:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow to enable persons who be came eligible for benefits in September, 1950, to make lastday applications.

BOMBAY, India, March 29-- Marked cleavages of opinion among Indian friends of democracy on the subjects of neutrality and the best methods of combating communism in Asia appeared at today's session of the Indian Congress for Cultural Freedom.

The long-sought agreement in the city's general trucking industry will become a reality on Monday. A five-year labor-management contract will be signed then in the Washington office of Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin.

MONTPELIER, Vt. March 29-- New England executives of state, labor and industry agreed tonight that periodic conferences at which individual differences should be subordinated for the regional good were the best approach to forestalling future post-emergency letdowns.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee voted today to ask the Senate to cite Frank Costello, the New York gambler, for contempt because of Costello's refusal to disclose his net worth.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 29-- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., will ask the industry for a 15 per cent wage increase in July or August, it was indicated today.

Dr. Lindsley F. Kimball, president of United Service Organizations, confirmed yesterday that the Secretary of Defense has commissioned U.S.O. to conduct its program outlined to serve members of the armed forces here and abroad.

A second payment of $25,000 is due the Council of the Living Theatre Foundation from Lester Cowan's Cinema Productions, which is to film Robert E. Sherwood's story, "Main Street to Broadway," here in the summer.

MIAMI, Fla., March 29--Five would-be Dodgers were lopped off the roster after a conference between Vice President Buzzie Bavasi and Manager Charley Dressen today. This was the first time these two officials have had a chance to consider the Brooklyn personnel because of Dressen's illness.
TAEGU, Korea, March 30-- South Korea is beginning to release some of the men in its army reserve camps because the Government cannot equip them or even feed or clothe them.
A study of unit and dollar volume in the women's apparel industry for the first three months of 1951 indicates that extreme pessimism is unwarranted, it was said yesterday.

An advisory council of the State Board of Regents urged yesterday that President Truman and Charles E. Wilson, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, give school construction the highest possible priority in the allocation of critical building materials.
DETROIT, March 30 (AP)--The postman paid his last call today on 6-year-old Bobby Hiftline.

The new $1,000,000 recreation center building in St. Mary's Park, at St. Ann's Avenue and East 144th Street, the Bronx, was dedicated yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri and other officials.

Miss Eleanor Mills Hillyer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Ellison Hillyer of Brooklyn, Was married to Garrard Bennett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Bennett, also of Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church here.
LONDON, March 28--From an office in the City of London, the British capital's financial district, Alfred Cope runs a multimillion dollar business, the biggest of its kind in the world.

ATLANTA, March 30--Dr. Alexander D, Langmuir warned today that scientific principles, supported by laboratory experience, indicated that biological warfare could be used effectively against the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Vincent Auriol of France formally expressed hope tonight that full international cooperation might yet achieve peace. He coupled this expression with a strong reaffirmation that France would remain vigilant against armed threat.

With reluctance Governor Dewey has signed the bill that permits New York City, by local law debatable later, to increase its sales tax to 3 per cent from 2 per cent. He recommended, also, that the tax only be increased to 2 per cent, a suggestion which will probably be ignored by the city.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30-- Unless greater production can be attained, Americans will have to accept a lower standard of living until defense needs are filled, John M. Hancock, chairman of the board of Lever Brothers, warned here tonight.

The battlefront in the war being waged by most of this city's business, labor, industrial and civic organizations against the proposed increase of the retail sales tax to 3 per cent shifted last night from Albany to the local front, with the City Council as the first target.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., March 30 --Gene Manfrini, Columbia University blind wrestler, was among those advancing in the first-day elimination of the New York State A.A.U. senior wrestling championships at the Amityville H.S. gymnasium tonight.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular 16 points lower to 5 points higher.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that public hearings on the proposed slum clearance projects known as Washington Square South and South Village, originally scheduled for Monday, would be postponed until the Board of Estimate's first meeting in May.
There is wide variety of style and subject-matter in four of the newly opened painting exhibitions.
The Ventura Union High School District of Ventura County, Calif., announced yesterday that it would receive bids April 24 on an issue of $5,750,000 of bonds due June 15, 1952 to 1966.

The Senate Crime Investigating Committee's New York headquarters was officially closed at 5 P.M. yesterday on a telephonic note. Until the last minute "tipsters" were calling to offer information on crime and politics.

Moscow is clearly the world capital of chess these days as the young Soviet challenger for the world's championship, David Bronstein, takes on the present titleholder, Mikhail Botvinnik. WASHINGTON, March 31--The Marshall Plan, in its three years of existence, already has accomplished almost everything that most of its most optimistic supporters hoped it could accomplish in the four years allotted to it, William C. Foster, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said today.

ALBANY, March 31--The appointment of John M. Harlan, 51-year-old New York City attorney and former state and Federal prosecutor, as counsel to the new State Crime Commission was announced today by Governor Dewey's office.

WASHINGTON, March 31--John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, appealed to state and local officials today for data on gambling in their areas to aid the Federal drive against tax dodging by gamblers and racketeers.

The Soviet Union in the past month has made substantial progress in cementing the economic unity and integration of the bloc of nations which it controls. THE first tulips are opening in gardens that are lucky enough to have been planted with some of the species or botanical kinds.

Deadly outside shooting and more effective work under the boards gave the West a 75-59 triumph over the East last night at Madison Square Garden in the sixth animal college all-star basketball game. A crowd of 10,431 watched the show, staged for the benefit of the Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund.

LANCASTER, Pa., March 31-- In a candlelit setting of white hyacinths, calls lilies and smilax in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Sylvia Gorton Woolworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester McNutt Woolworth of Lancaster, was married to Prentice Talmage Jr., son of Mrs. Williams Talmage of Warrenton, Va., and Prentice Talmage of Cedarhurst, L. I.

WITH the announcement last week that the American Theatre Wing was going to curtail its program during the summer, at least, a situation that has been under the surface came into sharper focus. The Wing's action was made necessary because of its steadily declining funds and whether its decision to raise new monies will succeed remains to be seen.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in March dropped to the lowest level since February, 1950. But the volume of business for the first quarter of this year, of 147,039,909 shares, was the heaviest for any similar period since 1937.

VIENNA, April 1 Recent events in the "people's democracies" indicate an increasing cleavage between the regimes and their workers that shows itself in new coercive measures on the one hand and "go slow" methods of sabotage on the other.

Grand Schwartz Bros. sold to an investing client of Daniel D. Cantor, broker, the one-story taxpayer building containing six stores on plot 100 by 100 feet at 224-10 to 224-25 Merrick Road, Laurelton, L. I. The property includes a parking lot and was sold for more than $130,000. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, April 1 "Miracles" of production have made this country "measurably safer" against possible aggression, it was reported today to President Truman by Charles E. Wilson, Director of the Office of Defense Mobilization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 Joan Blondell, who resumed her film career last year in Fox's. "For Heaven's Sake" after a three-year absence from the screen, has been signed by Jerry Wald and Norman Krasna, R.K.O. producers, for the role of a fading musicalcomedy actress in "The Blue Veil."

The heavy investment that the Pepsi-Cola Company is making in its expansion program has begun to show results in increased sales, both domestic and foreign, Alfred N. Steele, president, declared in the annual report mailed to stockholders over the week-end.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 1 Administration of publicly owned forest lands in the Pacific Northwest, particularly of 2,500,000 acres of virgin timber controlled by the Federal Department of the Interior, is becoming a subject of sharp controversy.
This week's program in local art galleries includes a large number of group and one-man shows.

When Congress reconvenes today it will be under great pressure to get the India food bill out of cold storage, where it has been shelved for many weeks while famine draws nearer to millions of people in the droughtstricken provinces.
MUNCIE, Ind., April 1 (AP) A head-on automobile collision killed five persons, including two small children and their parents, and injured two others just before dawn today on a highway near Muncie.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The National Federation of American Shipping, in reporting that the United States flag flew over only 5 per cent of the world's passenger fleet, declared today that this country was losing ground in the "international race" to restore this segment of its merchant marine to its pre-war level.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Senators moved tonight to launch within a week a broad investigation of fabulous profits on warsurplus ship deals.

The police confiscated six slot machines yesterday afternoon that had been in use aboard the cruise ship Europa of the Arnold Bernstein Shipping Company. They said the seizure was the first slot machine confiscation in this city in ten years.

This year's crop of cotton fabrics is more impressive than ever, for great progress has been made in weaving and finishing. Hundreds of designs are now available in ready-made fashions as well as by the yard, many of them hardly recognizable as cotton.

ALBANY, April 1 Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill that would have required court approval of any professional baseball contract signed by a prospective player less than 19 years old who had not yet graduated from high school.

Development of the world's natural resources by and for all mankind was urged yesterday morning by Msgr. Luigi G. Ligutti, official observer for the Vatican in the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations.

Regina Resnik, the Metropolitan soprano, gave her only New York recital of the season Saturday night in Hunter College Auditorium. UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 1 Mrs. Sidney T. Coale has announced the engagement of her daughter, Natalie Bayard, to John H. von Hollen of Montclair.

Prices of goods in some wholesale markets here last week have softened, resulting in a number of attractive values for special selling, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Disappointment over the holiday volume has made retailers reluctant to add to their heavy inventories.

The New York Central Railroad expects to demonstrate in this and in subsequent years the substantial progress shown in 1950, Gustav Metzman, president, observes in the road's 125th anniversary report issued for publication today. He was Ch. Cartref Canyon, owned by Harry Anyon, and he was placed first in one of the waning indoor season's bigger bench competitions. It drew 917 dogs.

Cotton prices moved irregularly during the past week. Except for the near-by May delivery, most of the emphasis was on the declining side. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net losses of 45 to 90 points. The May delivery held unchanged at the ceiling level of 45.39 cents a pound. At the close of the preceding week an advance of 2 points to a decline of 47 points had been recorded.

The congregation of South Congregational Church, Court and President Streets, Broooklyn, celebrated yesterday morning its 100th anniversary. The commemorative sermon was by the Rev. Dr. Douglas Horton, minister of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches.

WASHINGTON, April 1 General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has won a major argument with the United States Government over the location of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's headquarters.

More than half of all Soviet collective farms were abolished as independent entities last year, I.A. Benediktov, Minister of Agriculture in the Soviet Union, has revealed in the first comprehensive statement on the scope of the revolutionary amalgamation program begun in early 1950.

MEXICO CITY, April 1 Cheering applause from a packed house testified tonight and last night to this capital's happy pride in the revival of the National Symphony series and the spring season of the Mexican Ballet at the big marble Palace of Bellas Artes.

Fear that recent disclosures by the Senate crime committee investigation, the basketball scandals and the treason trials "might have had an unhealthy effect upon our growing boys and girls," was voiced last night by Mayor Impellitteri.

Jack Benny has learned his ABC's of TV. After two disappointing starts earlier in the season, the comedian broke completely with his radio past last night and promptly came up with a wryly amusing half hour that was good television (7:30 on Channel 2). Mr. Benny apparently has found his way out of the video woods.

President Vincent Auriol of France will arrive in New York this evening from Washington for a forty-eight-hour visit that will include the city's traditional welcome. Wednesday will be his last day in the United States.

A proposal to employ the techniques of free balloon flight on a mass scale to scatter a billion propaganda leaflets within Soviet areas was disclosed yesterday by a pioneer United States aviation manufacturer.

Prints that won prizes in a fabric design competition last December have been printed on a textured cotton and incorporated into some room schemes now on view at Gimbels. There are three patterns, all roller prints manufactured by the Colonial Drapery and Curtain Corporation, sponsor of the contest. Priced at $2.79 a yard, the fabrics are 48 inches wide, colorfast and pre-shrunk.

HONOLULU, April 1 Five hundred delegates from West Coast states and Hawaii will be faced with a number of controversial issues when the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union opens its five-day biennial convention here tomorrow in the Queen's Surf night club, palatial former Waikiki home of the late Chris Holmes.

The Clement Cleveland bronze medal for outstanding work during the year in the campaign to control cancer was awarded yesterday to Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of General Motors, at a luncheon of the New York City Cancer Committee at the Plaza Hotel.

Prime Minister Joseph Pholien of Belgium and his wife attended solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. In behalf of Cardinal Spellman, presiding in the sanctuary, Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, cathedral administrator, formally welcomed ...

WASHINGTON, April 1 The Senate, after three months of deliberations on the controversial issue, will start voting tomorrow on resolutions approving dispatch by the President of four more divisions of troops to Europe.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 1 (AP) Age caught up with Gardnar Mulloy today and 22-year-old Herbert Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., outlasted the veteran Miamian to win the third annual Good Neighbor tennis tournament men's finals, 4 6, 6 8, 7 5, 6 3, 6 1.

Edward M.M. Warburg, general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, addressed an overflow audience in the Broadway Theatre yesterday afternoon. He asserted that a minimum of $25,000,000 must be provided immediately to transfer 100,000 Jews to Israel from "danger and deadline areas" in Eastern Europe and Moslem countries in the next four months and to give them temporary shelter.

HONG KONG, Monday, April 2 The Chinese have turned down a Red Cross request urging the Peiping regime to ratify the Geneva Convention as a means of standardizing the treatment and welfare of war prisoners in Korea, an authoritative source disclosed this morning.
RICHMOND, Va., April 1 (AP) Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. proposed here today that a professional code of ethics be formulated for practicing politicians.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 1 Elliott Dean Harrington of Guilderland Center, head of mobilization activities of the small and medium motor divisions of the General Electric, Company died here today at his home of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.
MIAMI, April 1 Never satisfied to do anything the easy way, the Dodgers played their fourth extrainning game in five days, this afternoon beating the Braves in eleven innings, 4 3, before 3,457 fans.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 1 Positively for the last time this season, the New York Knickerbockers and Syracuse Nationals will meet Wednesday night at Manhattan's sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. That contest will determine the Eastern Division representative in the National Basketball Association championship play-off series.

The twelve-story loft building on plot 62 by 100 feet at 42 to 46 West Thirty-eighth Street has been sold by the Guzy Realty Company to a client of Jesse H. Barkin, attorney, who intends to hold the property for investment and part occupancy. Millinery and allied lines occupy the structure which is assessed at $380,000. Williams Co. were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 1 An Argentine attempt to get the es sence of Gen. Juan Peron's "rights of the worker" into the United States-backed resolution on internal security at the consultative meeting of Western Hemisphere Foreign Ministers failed last night by one vote, but may come up again tomorrow.

KUCHING, Sarawak, April 1 The Ibans of Sea Dayaks of Sarawak are outgrowing their primitive way of life so rapidly the British administrators here are worried. Officials are afraid the tribesmen, whose forefathers were the most feared headhunters in Borneo, may be gulping down new methods and new ideas too fast for their own good.
The weakness of Formosa once again in the spotlight as the "invasion season" opens is even more political and psychological than it is military.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Senator Estes Kefauver, chairman of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee named the Continental Press, a racing wire syndicate, today as "Public Enemy No. 1."

With four weeks to go, filing of pricing charts and other data required under Ceiling Price Regulation 7 is proceeding slowly in this area, according to officials of the Office of Price Stabilization regional headquarters at 2 Park Avenue.
In his debut recital last night in Times Hall, George Fiore showed a natural ability to play the piano, but coupled it with a lack of musical and technical discipline.

LONDON, April 1 The proximity of the budget and the Easter holidays have reduced stock market activity here appreciably but what the markets have lacked in business they have made up in the past few days in unexpected firmness.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, April 1 (U.P.) Officers and enlisted men of the Eighth Army are under orders to make no public statement about the Thirty-eighth Parallel in connection with the current military situation.
ANTWERP, Belgium, April 1 The Russians have invaded the field of international shipping, judging by orders placed by them with shipyards here.
If the suburbs can't get to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Metropolitan may soon be going to the suburbs.

The Senate is about to vote on a resolution concerning sending troops to Europe in support of the North Atlantic Treaty. The importance of this subject to the safety of our country can hardly be overstated.

The Senate Appropriations Committee has been asked by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., to restore to the Customs Bureau appropriation recently approved by the House at least enough to offset about $500,000 in mandatory salary increases.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 1 (AP) Southern textile workers struck for higher wages today. The action was largely technical because most mills are closed Sundays. The real test comes tomorrow morning.

Overemphasis on personal salvation in Russian, Indian and Christian religions was held a reason for "the failure, on the social side, of religion," in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. James Melville Hutchinson at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.
Scores of northeastern New Jersey communities lay sodden and battered yesterday under flood waters that had wrought havoc in the Passaic and Saddle River valleys.

WILMINGTON, N.C., April 1 (AP) Lloyd Mangrum, veteran Chicago professional, won the $10,000 Azalea Open golf tournament by 1 stroke today, shooting a closing 72 for 281. He had to wait for a forty-five minute rules committee meeting over a possible rules infraction before he pocketed the $2,000 winner's check.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 1 In a vigorous denunciation of the Schuman plan, Dr. Kurt Schumacher, Socialist leader, today raised the specter of unemployment as an inevitable result for Germany's coal miners and steel workers. He also said the Communists would profit by it.

There are some who insist that the occasion is twenty-four hours too late, that in appreciation of the fitness of things yesterday All Fools' Day should have been the time for it. Some impatient folk, though, waive the cap-andbells connection and assert that it should have taken place last Saturday, which was a beautiful day for the purpose.

LONDON, April 1 Sir Ralph Stevenson, Britain's Ambassador to Cairo, will return to his post this week, but very probably without any proposals that can produce a settlement of the protracted treaty dispute between Britain and Egypt.

Universal-International's "Oh Baby," a comedy starring Ethel Barrymore, will go before the cameras tomorrow. Castings at the studio this week-end included Barbara Ann Knudsen, a newcomer from the Little Theatre, in "Fine Day" and Hugh Sanders as a sheriff in "The Cave." U-I's recently-completed Claudette Colbert film, "Bonaventure," has been retitled Thunder on the Hill."

IN the year 1839 Czar Nicholas I had been safely ensconced upon the throne of all the Russias for fourteen years. Pushkin had been killed in a duel two years before and Tolstoy was a boy of 11. Louis Philippe reigned sedately in France and Alexis de Tocqueville was polishing up the concluding volumes of his celebrated work on "Democracy in America."

We suppose the public was never more cynical of the integrity of government officials, on all levels, than it is right now as a result of various inquiries, disclosures and suspicions not yet verified. There is a widespread yearning for reform, a determination variously expressed that the interest and indignation born of the Kefauver ....

In an appeal yesterday for 18,000 volunteers to complete lightduty rescue squads, Arthur W. Wallander, director of Civil Defense, made known the appointment of Howard McSpedon, president of the Building Trade Council, as city-wide director of the service.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 1 (UP) Native office workers have joined Communist-led strikes spreading through the rich oil-producing region of southern Iran and nearly 12,000 persons are idle, a spokesman for the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company said today.

TAIPEI, Formosa, April 1 The Chinese Nationalist Government will in the near future ask the United States for a short-term loan of $30,000,000. As soon as the expected military aid program is announced it also will ask for a separate appropriation from the United States to cover the expense of operating such equipment as may be furnished.

The newspapers and schools of the country must form a closer partnership if the ideals that give democracy vitality are to be preserved, Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, New York State Commissioner of Education, said yesterday. He spoke at the second annual education meeting of The Times Square Club in the Astor Hotel. The club is composed of Master Masons now or formerly employes of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, April 1 Development of a major crop scare on winter wheat owing to drought, insects, winter killing and freezing, temperatures resulted in all grains showing marked strength on the Board of Trade last week, with ...

In Korea Sunday, advancing United Nations ground forces encountered only isolated pockets of resistance. In the western sector substantial gains were registered as enemy rear-guard units displayed little disposition to hold in place. In the central and eastern sectors, patrols from Greek, United States, ...
ALBANY, April 1 A new defense housing program authorizing municipalities to undertake lowrent projects for defense workers and their families was approved by Governor Dewey today.

New securities offered publicly here in March were quite diversified and in marked contrast with offerings in recent months. The total of bonds marketed declined sharply from the month before and was the smallest for any March since 1946. Stock offerings, on the other hand, were the largest for any month since July, 1947, and the biggest amount for a March since 1929.

Dr. Robert W. Hunt, for the last eight years director of urology at St. Clare's Hospital, died Saturday night in the hospital at the age of 46. Dr. Hunt lived at 22 Deepdene Drive, Forest Hills, Queens.

MADRID, April 1 Generalissimo Francisco Franco reviewed today his twelfth anniversary victory parade here in celebration of the triumphal end of the Spanish Civil War in 1939. For the first time since 1946, United States, British and French Ambassadors ...

JUST about a month, ago a part of the racing strip at Jamaica was so undermined by seepage from a broken sewer that it collapsed. A yawning hole of bomb crater proportions suddenly appeared where the thoroughbreds had once been wont to gather themselves for the homestretch sprint. There is a moral in this. It might also be considered as something of a warning.

TOKYO, Monday, April 2 United Nations forces again stabbed across the Thirty-eighth Parallel in Korea yesterday. For the third time in two days a United States tank and infantry patrol crossed the old boundary between North and South Korea on the western front, shot up enemy concentrations north of the line, then pulled back for the night.

AMSTERDAM, April 1 Further deterioration in the foreign exchange position of the Netherlands of 64,000,000 guilders which will be reflected in March accounts with the European Payments Union shows how much the monetary situation of the nation has been affected by the drop in trade and Germany's ban on imports.
DOVER, N.J., April 1--A man, his wife and his sister were found slain in his home here today. Each had been shot through the head with bullets from a .22-caliber rifle.
Mayor Impellitteri dedicated yesterday the Sidney Friedman Association community and settlement house at 236 East Broadway.

WASHINGTON, April 1 Great strides by the free nations of Europe in raising their military and economic strength with the aid of the United States were reported today by Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1 Yugoslavia has decided to give the highest priority to the construction of new armament factories as a result of the serious military situation in the Balkans.

Although everyone had been under the impression that payment on the first mortgage held by the Shuberts on the Anta Playhouse wasn't due until today, it actually was turned over early Friday night. Otherwise, foreclosure proceedings would have been instituted at noon today. The successful outcome entailed a great deal of scurrying around on Friday by Anta's horde of disciples.

In a modest room, far removed from the elaborately decorated showrooms of a garment center manufacturing establishment, a woman whose mind works fast as quicksilver turns out one of the most amazing lines of clothes to be found in this or any country.

Miss Joan Lipkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Lipkins of 310 West End Avenue, and Alan Bentley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo H. Bernstein of the same address, were married last evening in the Roof of the St. Regis. The Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman performed the ceremony.

Wages and hours in manufacturing employment are rising faster than those in nonmanufacturing, according to announcement of the National Industrial Conference Board issued for release today. Straight-time hourly earnings in manufacturing have shown an aveage increase of 8.5 per cent in the last year.
J. Morton Curran Jr. has resigned from Curran Barry to form Morton Curran Co., Inc., 40 Worth Street, for the sale of heavy-cotton products manufactured by Southern mills.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The Committee on the Present Danger urged tonight that Congress take no action that might tend to cast any uncertainty or cloud upon the power of the President as Commander in Chief.
