UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 1 A United States manufacturer has promised 300 pairs of new shoes to the children of Pollica in southern Italy, and a United Nations agency has agreed to rush the gift overseas.
ALBANY, April 1 Life insurance companies will be able to invest an estimated $1,500,000,000 of their assets in common stock under a bill signed by Governor Dewey today.
Since last July, we have doubled the combined active strength of our Army, Navy, and Air Force and now have about 3,000,000 under arms.

CLEVELAND, April 1 A new attempt to forge a united American labor movement, one that would stand apart from the Democratic party, was proposed today by Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 1 Lord Russell of Liverpool, deputy judge advocate general at the British Army headquarters, attributed today to recent concessions to Germany an unpleasant incident last night, when his car was delayed by a procession in the Westphalian town of Vlotho, where he resides.

The steadily widening gap between social work salaries and the cost of living has brought "a serious threat" to the social services of the nation, the national board of the American Association of Social Workers warned yesterday.

Leon Keyserling, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, outlined yesterday three steps, which, coupled with a more effective price and wage stabilization program, he said, would enable this nation to meet the "greatest international problems" it now faces.

The name of Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican-Liberal of Washington Heights, has been mentioned recently with increasing frequency as a possible fusion candidate for President of the City Council, the principal office at stake in the election next fall.

Despite the action of the Army Quartermaster Corps that defers some textile purchases until the new fiscal year beginning July 1, there is no contemplated revision of projected procurement quantities, it was learned authoritatively last week. The Army, Navy and Marine Corps will buy the full scale of their requirements, Government procurement officials said, but payment will be made from 1952 appropriations.

Catalina Zandueta, Philippine sosoprano, was heard in her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Enthusiastically received by a friendly audience, Miss Zandueta made known a sweet, bright, lyric voice, even in scale, but too faultily produced to make adequate headway with the exacting list of selections attempted.

PITTSBURGH, April 1 It looked last week as if there would be no lull before the storm of defense orders the storm was already here. More than one mill last week found that order volume on the books, slated for defense or defense supporting, had skyrocketed at a rate far above estimates of only a few months ago.

Cardinal Spellman celebrated the 9 A. M. mass yesterday at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, Duane Street and Cardinal Hayes Place, commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of the Printers Mass.
PARIS, April 1 Whether the next French elections will be held June or October has become the principal issue that will go before the National Assembly when it reconvenes on Tuesday.

ALBANY, April 1 Governor Dewey announced today the designation of a State Supreme Court justice to preside at the special grand jury investigation of gambling in Saratoga County and a prosecutor to direct the state's case against any public officials or racketeers found to be involved.

A majority of Americans, we believe, will applaud the general tone in which John Foster Dulles has outlined the basis for a peace treaty with Japan. The actions of this country, in spending upward of two billion dollars thus far to sustain and rehabilitate the Japanese, have already shown a singular ....

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 1 Frederick H. Blake, former president of the American Book Company, textbook publishers, and a director of the Bloomfield Bank and Trust Company, died today in Memorial Hospital, Orange. His age was 73.

The International Society for Contemporary Music forum group put on an exciting concert last night in Columbia University's McMillin Theatre. There were three instrumental ensembles, two pianists, two singers, a program of provocative music and some excellent performances.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 The Giants outslugged the Cardinals, 12 to 8, today, in their final appearance of the year at Al Lang Field.

The inflation boomlet as a result of rearmament is tapering off in industrial supplies and equipment. Orders are slipping substantially in many lines and sales volume at the opening of the second quarter is running substantially below that of the first quarter of the year.

GENEVA, N.Y., April 1 An Armed Services Subcommittee of the House of Representatives appealed tonight to Central New York residents to attend a public hearing here tomorrow in its inquiry into complaints of wasteful spending in the rehabilitation of near-by Sampson Air Force Base.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report today warned that the nation was in the grip of "galloping inflation" in calling for quick enactment of a pay-as-yougo tax program.

Franco Autori, assistant conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony, had his turn on the podium in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. His solist was Andor Folders, who played the Bartok Second Piano Concerto.

GOETEBORG, Sweden, April 1 A clockmaker who helped 36,000 persons escape the Nazis and find a new way of life, brushed tears from his eyes today when delegations from fifteen nations honored him on his seventieth birthday anniversary.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 1 In the last few weeks four high-ranking British and United States officials have paid separate visits to Israel. The salient points of what they have heard in this country can be summed up as follows:

Continuance of the Federal Admissions Tax for five years more would compel the Metropolitan Opera to cease functioning long before the expiration of that period, George A. Sloan, chairman of the board and president of the Metropolitan Opera Association, warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) The Defense Department today identified 420 more casualties in the Korean war in a new casualty list including 88 dead, 270 wounded, 17 injured and 45 missing. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):
Although the world appears chaotic in its transitory aspects, "there is something eternal here and now," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, minister emeritus of Riverside Church, said yesterday.

Delegates of radio-television service organizations from thirty cities met here yesterday at a dinner-meeting at the New Yorker Hotel, at which it was declared that home receiver owners "are now getting a better grade of servicing than ever before."
The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it had set three new records in 1950.

PHOENIX, April 1 Mickey Mantle was back in action today after missing two starts. Joe DiMaggio was hitting the ball squarely. Eddie Lopat pitched superlatively in his second seven-inning outing. Yogi Berra got his first round-tripper of the year. In sum total the Yankees beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 3, before an overflow crowd of 6,083.

Adelaide Bishop, who made her debut with the New York City Opera three years ago, sang her first Violetta with that company on Saturday night, when Verdi's "La Traviata" was presented at the City Center. She made a decidedly favorable impression.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The National Labor Relations Board, for the first time in its sixteen-year history, today ordered union shop and representation elections in the building industry. Eight A.F.L. unions protested the action.

The fun-loving Harlem Globetrotters started an eighteen-game cross-country tour with the College All-Americans at Madison Square Garden and learned clowning may have to be cut to a minimum if they hope to win the series. At least, that's the way it seemed yesterday afternoon to a crowd of 17,114 who saw the Trotters triumph, 65 58.

WITH U.S. SEVENTH ARMY, in Western Germany, April 1 Whatever happens in Western Germany this year it is obvious that within the limits imposed by their numerical inferiority then men and officers of the Seventh United States Army will be ready to meet it.

ROME, April 1 While the Right Wing Socialists were debating hotly whether to withdraw from Premier Alcide de Gasperi's coalition Cabinet, which almost certainly would bring about a delay in approval by the Senate of rearmament appropriations, the ...

Foremost Dairies, Inc., whose business was built on the foundation of three ailing companies, last year had gross sales exceeding $50,000,000 for the first time in its history. Gross sales were $52,621,127, compared with $45,396,383 in 1949. Net sales also showed an increase of about 15 per cent, totaling $48,160,059 against $42,011,579.

CLEVELAND, April 2--A dues increase of $1 a month, designed to raise a strike fund of $15,000,000 and to meet the rising costs of operating the nation's largest union, was approved this evening by an overwhelming vote of the United Automobile Workers Convention.

Dr. George J. Fisher, Scout commissioner of the Boy Scouts of America, was honored yesterday on his eightieth birthday at a ceremony held in the offices of the organization at 2 Park Avenue. Three hundred and fifty members of the staff halted their work for a half hour to pay tribute to Dr. Fisher and present to him a bouquet of red carnations, a piece of luggage and a toilet kit.

BOSTON, April 2--Animal experiments in which resistance to tooth decay was produced by controlling the ratio of calcium to phosphorus in the diet were described here today at opening sessions of the annual spring meeting of the American Chemical Society.

ROME, April 2--The Right Wing Socialist party congress was startled late last evening by reports of a press conference held in Milan by the leader of the Left Wing Socialist party, Pietro Nenni, who indicated that the extreme left wing parties might abate their opposition to the Atlantic Pact.

Forty-five thousand square feet of additional storage space has been leased by the Messinger Trucking and Warehouse Corporation in Webb Knapp's Terminal Warehouse, which occupies the block bounded by West Twentyseventh and Twenty-eighth Streets and Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues. With the additional space, the floor area in the warehouse now occupied by the Messinger company totals 95,000 square feet.

No longer are rainy days the time to reach for that old or second best coat. For some time now designers have been coming up with all manner of attractive rain togs that bolster the spirit and lift the morale will their appealing chic. For this spring and summer the fashion creators seem to have outdone themselves with the lively and modish array available.
PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Frederic Drew Bond, financial and scientific writer and consultant, died here on Thursday in his home at the age of 80.

With the scheduled delivery this year of ten additional Diesel locomotives, the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad will have virtually completed the elimination of steam power, according to the road's 1950 annual report released yesterday.

The Kefauver committee investigation had its first two local political repercussions yesterday, one direct and the other indirect. The direct one was the summoning by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan of Angelo Simonetti, his secretary and a Tammany district leader, to explain Mr. Simonetti's relationship with Frank Costello.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 2-- Southpaw Pitcher Harry Brightman gave up only four hits in tossing Princeton to a 2-0 victory over Manhattan at University Field today. Both Princeton runs were unearned.
PHOENIX, April 2--The Yankees said farewell to the Valley of the Sun with a brace of home runs today and beat the Cleveland Indians, 4 to 2, in eleven innings.

Application of extremely tight credit restrictions on small business might precipitate "a cycle of competitive prices" to hasten unloading of heavy inventories, and lead to destruction of some small concerns, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, warned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2-- Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, announced this afternoon that Winston Churchill had accepted an invitation to deliver the main address at a convocation celebrating the 200th anniversary of the university's library on May 8.

WITH U.S. SEVENTH ARMY, in Western Germany, April 2-- The vigorous and intensive field training in which the Seventh Army is engaged has accomplished much more than raising its combat efficiency. It has revealed a number of weaknesses in equipment and personnel, has swept away most of the complacency that hung over from World War II and has produced a lot of intelligent staff planning for any emergency.

PARIS, April 2--Two long meetings of the Cabinet failed today to break a deadlock over the kind of new taxation to be levied to meet the financial crisis facing the French Government and to check the trend toward inflation.

Demand deposits of individuals, partnerships and corporations in a11 commercial banks in this district rose $1,047,000,000, or 5 per cent, last year to a record total of $21,985,000,000, at the end of January 1951, according to estimates of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The expansion, the...

Mr. and Mrs. Blaine Webb of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila, to George Rene Mathey, son of Mrs. Rene Mathey of Littleton, N.H., and the late Mr. Mathey of Paris.

In a small town upstate last week most of the local doctors turned up at the little hospital late one afternoon. women were waiting for them. The doctors took their places in a meeting room where the lighting gadgets that show up X-rays Were set in place. The weekly Tumor Clinic was about to hold its regular meeting.

The Empire State warehouse and storage building at Gates and Nostrand Avenues in Brooklyn has been leased for twelve years by Frederick Loeser Co., Inc. The nine-story building, with a onestory delivery garage in the rear, will absorb the warehousing, service and delivery facilities formerly housed in Loeser's warehouse on Livingston Street.
ALBANY, April 2--New York State ended its fiscal year last Saturday with an operating deficit of $9,535,780.

The adoption by the Senate yesterday of the McClellan amendment to the Troops-for-Europe resolution will be a serious setback for the Administration if it remains in the final version of this measure. The amendment declares it to be the sense of the Senate that not more than four American divisions shall be sent to Western Europe in implementation of the North Atlantic

Catherine Romano has sold the twenty-six-family apartment house at 2406 Lorillard Place, the Bronx, to John Zampetti in a transaction negotiated by G. Satriale Son as brokers. The property, at the corner of East 187th Street, is assessed at $55,000. It was sold for cash above a mortgage of $23,000.

It was folding day yesterday for banking syndicates thinking of putting in bids in two substantial new issues of public utility bonds coming up for sale at sealed bidding today at deadlines an hour apart. Of twelve syndicates originally formed to bid on $12,000,000 of bonds of Worcester County Electric Company and $10,000,000 of

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP)-- Selective Service assured promising high school graduates today that they would get a chance to go to college and simultaneously advised college students seeking draft deferments to apply at once to their local draft boards.
Reflecting its high level of activity last year, the consolidated net income of the Aluminum Company of America reached a new high of $46,856,597, more than doubling the 1949 net of $20,892,863.
SARASOTA, Fla., April 2 (AP)-- Walt Dropo, who led the Red Sox in home runs last year, today was lost to the team for possibly two months with a broken right wrist.

BONN, Germany, April 2--Farreaching relaxations of post-war Allied prohibitions on German war production became known today at the same time that the Allied High Commission announced acceptance of the Federal Government's proposals modifying the anti-trust law against coal and steel cartels of the industrial Ruhr area.

WASHINGTON, April 2-President Truman was reported tonight to be considering several important changes in the personnel and operations of the senior staff of the National Security Council. These changes in the country's top security agency were understood to include the following:

WASHINGTON, April 2--President Vincent Auriol of France told a joint session of Congress today that his people had learned from bitter experience that "isolation is death" and that "right without might is powerless,"
A comprehensive plan for the mass feeding of 1,000,000 persons in the event of atomic attack was announced yesterday by the New York State Civil Defense Commission.

PARIS, April 2--Deputies for the Western nations today offered a new draft aiming to combine in an impartial manner their proposals with the recent Soviet suggestions for the agenda of a Big Four Foreign Ministers conference.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 2 -Cooperation in the economic aspect of depending on the West has been pledged by the German-American Trade Promotion Company, an association of German business men originally formed to stimulate dollar-earning exports.
LONDON, April 2--A special working party has been established by contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to tackle the problem of disparities in European tariffs.

William H. Sudduth 2d of 17 East Eighty-seventh Street has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of his ward, Miss Asta Tamm of 115 Central Park West, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jaan Tamm of Estonia, to Mart Neumann of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Neumann, also of Estonia.

THE voyageurs and fur traders of the North West Company called it be pays sauvage, the vast wilderness that swept north and west from Lake Superior to the Arctic and Pacific Oceans. In 1800 it was a truly savage country, a land of cold and hunger and incredible loneliness, of privation and violence and local customs strangely disturbing to a young Vermonter...

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 2-- Star Class yachts competed today in the opening race of the spring championship series on Montagu Bay. The winner was E.W. (Skip) Etchells of Greenwich, Conn., in the Shillelah.

WASHINGTON, April 2--President Truman was reported today to be planning creation of a new eighteen-member Wage Stabilization Board this week to end the long deadlock over the powers to be assigned to such a body.

ROME, March 27--Even more beset than France by internal politics, but less undermined by Communist impediments to rearmament under the North Atlantic Treaty program, Italy as represented by the de Gasperi coalition Government is making a strong effort to play its part in providing an armed deterrent to Soviet aggression in Europe. The path to the goal is rough...

WASHINGTON, April 2--John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, informed Congress today that it would have to vote only $10,000,000,000 in additional taxes this year to keep the defense effort on a pay-as-we-go basis.
CHICAGO, April 2--The grain markets staged a strong rally in the late trading on the Board of Trade here today after an early break, the best prices of the day being made about at the close.

MIAMI, April 2--The Van Cuyk Brothers, Chris and Johnny, tried to collaborate in a victory over the Phils tonight but the elder of the two southpaws couldn't hold the lead the Dodgers gave Chris, the Phils scoring four runs in the ninth for an 8-7 triumph--their second over the Dodgers in three meetings.

LAUREL, Md., April 2 (UP)-- Senator Joe, Alan Clarke's Kentucky Derby candidate, scored his second 1951 victory in as many tries today when he beat Tamale in the featured Sandy Spring Purse at Laurel Park.
The city's air pollution regulations are impractical and ineffective, Thomas J. Barrett, director of the air pollution committee of the National Association of Power Engineers, charged yesterday.
Chandler Cowles and Anthony B. Farrell, co-producers of "Billy Budd," are departing for H. Hywood today to arrange several matters of theatrical import.

WASHINGTON, April 2--A united Europe standing beside a strong United States in defiance of all enemies of "this citadel of world freedom" was pledged today by Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, as the best way in which Europe could express its gratitude for the Marshall Plan.
For the first time in nearly four years maritime unions are finding it difficult to furnish a sufficient number of adequately trained personnel to man this country's merchant fleet.

WASHINGTON, April 2--With its economic decisions still bogged down in debate, the fourth consultative meeting of hemisphere foreign ministers today adopted the first proposals that will form a definite part of its final act to be ceremoniously signed Saturday morning.

In the smarter circles of television society, soap opera is now strictly passe. The new description is "a novel for television." At least that was the introduction yesterday afternoon for a new serial called "Hawkins Falls, Pop. 6,200," which hereafter will adorn Channel 4 at 5 o'clock, Mondays through Fridays.
ALBANY, April 2--Rent control ceilings on business and commercial buildings in New York City will remain in effect until July l, 1952, under a bill approved today by Governor Dewey.

Spokesmen for the city's teachers charged yesterday that Mayor Impellitteri's proposed $400 salary adjustment fell far short of meeting the need, predicting that the teachers would continue their boycott of voluntary after-school activities.

Mayor Impellitteri's first executive budget, for the fiscal year beginning July 1, is $1,336,102,798. It is $73,302,018 larger than the current, 1950-51, budget as modified to March 15 and $92,651,004 larger than Mayor O'Dwyer asked initially at this time last year.
HERSHEY, Pa., April 2 (UP)-- The town that chocolate built was crippled tonight by a walkout of 1,100 community workers.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 2--A nation-wide strike of 50,000 ship workers, called for midnight tonight, was averted today when the executive board of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O., acceded to Government requests for a thirty-day postponement.

Legal pitfalls confronting a management agency were discussed by Harold J. Treanor, counsel to the Real Estate Board of New York, at yesterday's session of the education series conducted by the board for young brokers. The meeting was held at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Fortyfourth Street.

BUENOS AIRES, April 2 (UP)-- The Congressional committee investigating the newspaper La Prensa announced today that it had finished an inventory at the newspaper's printing plant and was now taking stock at its various Buenos Aires warehouses.

Stockholders of the MerrittChapman Scott Corporation approved yesterday doubling, the company's authorized capital stock. It also was announced at the annual meeting that Thomas A. Scott, chairman of the board and secretary, would retire. Now 74 years old, Mr. Scott has been with the company fifty-three years. He will continue on the board as honorary chairman.
WASHINGTON, April 2--A fiveyear contract to stabilize New York City's trucking industry was signed here today in the office of Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin.
The New York City Youth Board will be forced on June 30 to withdraw its community center serving the youth of East Harlem because its lease is not being renewed.

WASHINGTON, April 2--The Government today made mandatory the elimination of the spare or fifth tire and tube currently supplied to buyers of new passenger automobiles. The action, taken through amending the National Production Authority's April allocation of rubber, supplanted the voluntary action of auto producers ten days ago, when the manufacturers promised to eliminate the spare tire on all new cars sold.

The failure of the International Red Cross to reach any sort of understanding with the Peiping regime is disheartening for several reasons. We are naturally concerned about United Nations war prisoners and would have some reassurance if they were brought under the terms of the Geneva Convention. Their lot would be eased, also,
LONDON, April 2--The substantial surplus shown in this year's revenue returns had an encouraging effect on most sections of the stock market here today.

The two sixteen-story apartment houses at 110 and 118 Riverside Drive, containing 165 suites, have been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to Morris Brown and Mortimer Furtsch, who plan to convert them into small units. Brill Brill were the brokers. Tanner, Sillcocks , Friend were attorneys for the seller. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, April 2--The Senate approved today President Truman's plans to send four more divisions to Europe, but it admonished him to make no additional commitment of troops for the common Western defense without "further Congressional approval."
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 7 per cent in March, compared with the like month of last year, according to a study made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TOKYO, April 2--Generally well received here, the John Foster Dulles outline of a prospective Japanese peace treaty at Whittier College on Saturday nevertheless began to provoke some critical Japanese reaction today.

Extending a record unique in the air transport industry--sixteen consecutive years of profitable operation--Eastern Air Lines, Inc., attained last year the largest earnings in its history, $3,289,969 above 1949.
The Community Service Society rushed the summer camp season yesterday by starting physical examinations for youngsters at its health clinics, 29 Park Avenue.

Fifty candidates, including twenty-two freshmen, opened Columbia's spring football practice at Baker Field yesterday. They plunged directly into light contact work to brush up on offensive assignments.
Some schools were closed yesterday in northern New Jersey as receding flood waters left a residue of mud and sewage in thousands of homes and business places.

THERE was an abundance of the "warm rain" that experts said was necessary to bring the big rainbows out of Seneca Lake and into the creek, and there was some cold rain also, but it did not deter several thousand anglers from trying their luck along Catherine Creek at the Sunday morning opening.

Arthur T. Roth, president of The Franklin National Bank, Franklin Square, Long Island, has been elected chairman and trustee at large of The New York State Bankers Rebert H. Fearon, Presisucceeds Robert H. Fearon, president of the Oneida Valley National Bank, Oneida, N.Y.

Juvenile enthusiasm over the new million-dollar recreation center in St. Mary's Park, the Bronx, boiled over at 3:30 P. M. yesterday when frustrated youngsters unable to gain admittance started pelting the place with stones.

Plans for the murder of Msgr. Bela Varga, exiled speaker of the Hungarian Parliament now living in a Catholic institution at 227 East Seventy-second Street, were reported last night by the National Committee for a Free Europe, Inc.

White dogwood, Easter and calla lilies combined with quince and pear blossoms formed a garden setting yesterday afternoon in the Hellenic Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Corinne Stephanidis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen D. Stephanidis of 1040 Fifth-Avenue and New Canaan, Conn., to George J. Gavas, Greek Consul at New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gavas of Athens.
LONDON, April 2--"This is a psychological moment" for all concerned in the struggle in Korea to bring the fighting to an end, Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison said tonight.

ST. LOUIS, April 2--Luther Ely Smith, lawyer and civic leader, known as the "father" of the proposed Thomas Jefferson Memorial along the Mississippi Ri er here, died today at the age of 77. He apparently was stricken with a heart attack and collapsed in the street while on the way to his office.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Switzer of 40 Central Park South and Vicksburg, Miss., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Switzer's daughter, Miss Diane Pollitz, to Dr. Robert Sohn Coles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham L. Coles of New York and Pawling, N.Y. The wedding will take place in September.

"Kon-Tiki," a feature-length documentary dealing with the 101day voyage of the raft Kon-Tiki from South America to the Polynesian islands, which arrives at the Sutton, is today's lone film newcomer. Thor Heyerdahl, who was a member of the six-man crew of Scandinavian scientists who made the trip, also narrates.

Mayor Impellitteri submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate an executive budget of $l,336,102,798 for the fiscal year beginning July 1. It was the largest in the city's history and the fifth in succession to exceed the billion dollar mark.
The following are excerpts from Mayor Impellitteri's message to the Board of Estimate and the City Council in submitting the executive budget for the fiscal year 1951-52:

PARIS, April 2--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower formally assumed command and activated the Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe (Shape) into an operational headquarters this morning.
ALBANY, April 2 (AP)--A bill setting Aug. 21 for this year's primary election was approved today by Governor Dewey.
A Federal grand jury indicted yesterday James J. Lyons, 47-yearold former assistant postmaster of Scarsdale, N.Y., on charges of embezzling and converting to his own use $ll,194 of Government funds.

A protest against farm parity prices on butter, along with a, demand for a complete overhaul of the whole farm parity system, was sent yesterday to Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan and to Senator Joseph C. O'Mahony, chairman of the Joint Committee on the Economy.
The Metropolitan Opera has set up a television department, which will prepare special productions for telecast.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were unchanged to 20 points net lower compared with Saturday's close.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 2 --The Yugoslav Government has decided to abolish Soviet-type management of collective farms because experience has demonstrated that Soviet practices have reduced agricultural productivity to a low level and alienated the peasants. These practices will be replaced by Western managerial methods based on day-to-day experience and scientific controls.

Trade associations should oppose militantly Government controls or other proposals they regard as "doubtful, impractical or otherwise unsatisfactory" to the industries they represent. This was declared yesterday by Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.
ST. LOUIS, April 2 (AP)--The Western Union Telegraph Company agreed tonight to cut the leased wire to Pioneer News, a race wire service. The wire is from Continental Press Service in Chicago.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 2-- Pakistan today pledged "fullest cooperation" to the United Nations future mediator for Kashmir and agreed to accept the Security Council's latest recommendations for ending the three-year-old dispute over the princely state.

Negotiations have been concluded through which the Allied Stores Corporation will acquire the Stern Brothers department store, it was disclosed yesterday. The transaction is subject to approval of Stern Brothers stockholders at a special meeting on April 10.

Total resources of the Manufacturers Trust Company on March 31 this year amounted to $2,592811,450, compared with $2,772,539,261 at the end of 1950, according to the bank's quarterly condition statement, published today. Deposits on the respective dates were $2,396,263,928 and $2,581,949,234.
Hospitals are threatened with a shortage of private duty nurses after April 15, unless the demands of the New York State Nurses Association to raise fees to $12 a day plus $1.50 for meals are met.

The Little Orchestra Society last night concluded its season with another concert of unusual music in Town Hall. Thomas K. Scherman conducted as usual, and the soloists were Erica Morini, violinist, and Wallace Shapiro, clarinetist.

Simon Barere, Russian pianist, collapsed and fell to the floor last night in Carnegie Hall as he was playing the Grieg Piano Concerto with the Philadelphia Orchestra half way through a concert of the American--Scandinavian Foundation. He was dead when medical assistance arrived.

The Continental Motors Corporation is arranging with banks for a $30,000,000 V-loan to finance its expanding production of military engines, C.J. Reese, president, announced yesterday. The credit is the first V-loan contracted by a major corporation under the present emergency, he said. The National Bank of Detroit is agent for the group of banks participating.

WASHINGTON, April 2--Encouraging results in finding stomach cancer at an early, curable stage through testing of stomach-- wall cells obtained by a new "papain washing technique" were reported today by the United States Public Health Service.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2-- Five and one-half years of effort by the R. Stanley Dollar interests to recover control of the Shipping company now known as American President Lines has resulted in "the most tragic joke in American judicial history," counsel for Mr. Dollar and his associates told the Federal District Court here today.

At the Aiken Trials a dozen days ago, in a race that was chiefly for fun, Mrs. Andy Schuttinger's Ferd beat James Cox Brady's Casemate by about a length and won a little silver cup. In the Paumonok Handicap at Jamaica yesterday with the blue chips stacked high, Ferd beat Casemate again, this time by three-quarters of a length, and won the price of a thousand or two little silver cups.

There has been "notable progress" in breaking down racial prejudices in American society and even the pace of progress has been increased, Dr. Charles S. Johnson, president of Fisk University, said last night.

Edward T. McCormick, until recently a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, yesterday became president of the New York Curb Exchange, succeeding Francis Adams Truslow, who resigned to accept an appointment in the State Department.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 2 (AP) --Future medical students--and those now in training--had better expect two years, service in the armed forces.

To offset the financial drain of its annually recurring deficits, the New York Philharmonic--Symphony is following the lead of the Boston Symphony in establishing an organization of "Friends," who will be invited to make a donation each year to help support the orchestra.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)--The Defense Department today identified 157 additional casualties of the Korean war in a new list that reported 8 killed, 80 wounded, 52 missing in action and 17 injured in accidents. The following were listed from New York and Connecticut (none from New Jersey):
WASHINGTON, April 2--A Senate subcommittee assigned to make recommendations to Congress concerning the creation of a commission on ethics in the Federal Government was appointed today.
George Voskovec, Czech dramatist and actor, was released yesterday from Ellis Island after detention for ten and a half months on unspecified security charges.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 2--Declaring that warfare "is still a business of men, materials and methods," J. Calvin Brown of Los Angeles, president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, called today for a more effective utilization of the nation's engineers in industry and the military establishments.

The fact that the noonday sun stands higher in the sky in summer than in winter has some interesting consequences which a busy world may overlook. Summer, in this sense, may be defined as the half year between the spring and autumn equinoxes, and winter as the other half.

Save for copper futures, which closed 15 to 75 points higher in two sales, miscellaneous commodities yesterday sought lower ground. Dealings were generally stagnant. There were no sales whatever in New York markets for zinc, crude rubber, lead and old raw rides.

The stock market encountered yesterday a resumption of selling, with forenoon losses only slightly shaded before the close. Prices tumbled with ease as offerings were forced to find considerably lower levels before being taken by buyers. The list at the worst level of the session approached the midMarch low.

HONOLULU, April 2--Harry R. Bridges, president of the independent International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, told convention delegates today that the union had made "tremendous economic gains" in the last two years as the "leadership took chances and stuck its neck out."

The LeBlanc Corporation, producer of Hadacol vitamin prepara tion, will spend $1,000,000 this month in a campaign promoting the product in thirty-one states, Louisiana State Senator Dudley LeBlanc, president, said yesterday. He spoke before a meeting of the sales promotion and merchandising group of the American Marketing Association in the Shelton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)-- Philip Jaffe's contempt-of-Congress trial opened today with an argument over whether Jaffe properly claimed his rights when he refused to answer twenty-six questions for a Senate subcommittee.

The Federal Communications Commission has overreached itself. Its warning to the Hollywood producers that they turn over their films and stars to television, lest they jeopardize their own chances to enter video broadcasting, is an arbitrary and capricious action that flouts the elementary principles of a competitive economy and raises serious questions of law.

WASHINGTON, April 2--A new stock market index devised by the Securities and Exchange Commission to "fill the need for a sensitive, yet representative, measure of stock market prices," was announced by the commission today.

LOUDONVILLE, N.Y., April 2 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lyman C. Thunfors of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Jacquelyn, to Joseph J. Tomassi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Tomassi of Jamaica, L.I.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP)-- An official of the Economic Cooperation Administration said tonight that two of the tankers involved in the profitable surplus ship deal engineered by former Representative Joseph E. Casey had carried oil to Communist China and Russia in 1949.
LONDON, April 2 (AP)--The death of Maj. George Cornwallis West, former stepfather of Winston Churchill, was disclosed today. He was 76 years old.

A historic change has taken place in Soviet agriculture, a change that justly ranks with such revolutionary developments as the "black partition" of 1917 and the forced collectivization of the early Thirties. In one year, 1950, the Soviet Government succeeded in wiping out more than half of its original 252,000 collective farms. With one blow it radically altered the organizational structure of its agriculture.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 2-- Larger timber operators of the Pacific Northwest are attacking as "confiscatory" some of the regulations under which 2,500,000 acres of publicly owned forest lands of western Oregon are being administered by the Federal Bureau of Land Management.

Nearly 2,500 employes of the Board of Transportation moved into their new building yesterday at 370 Jay Street, Brooklyn, but they had considerable difficulty trying to do their day's work, according to William Jerome Daly, secretary of the board.
Price-control officials announced yesterday the start of a check-up in this area on how well manufacturers and wholesalers are complying with the General Ceiling Price Regulation.
BAYONNE, N.J., April 2-Capt. P.H. Lyon betrayed moderate astonishment today when he dropped in at the chaplain's office on the aircraft carrier Oriskany and found two of his men
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)-- the opponents of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project opened their arguments today before a congressional committee considering a bill to authorize it.

President Vincent Auriol of France gave the Western world a slogan last night--"peace with freedom." And he lifted his glass in a toast to the United States and France, "today like yesterday fraternally united for the peace and the liberty of the world."

New bathroom accessories, ranging from a wall heater to a gadget to help eliminate splashing from faucets, are available for use in a room that once was considered well equipped if it was supplied with hot and cold running water.

Mikhail Botvinnik, world chess champion, maintained his lead in his title match with David Bronstein at the Tchaikovsky Concert Hall in Moscow after a draw in the eighth game of the series, adjourned...

GENEVA, N.Y., April 2--A House Armed Services subcommittee ended its on-the-spot investigation of near-by Sampson Air Force Base today after a public hearing at which only one of a dozen witnessea was able to testify to alleged waste in the $18,000,000 rehabilitation project.

Accident prevention as applied to home and highway, shop and schoolroom will be demonstrated and discussed at the twenty-first annual safety convention and exposition sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council opening today at the Statler Hotel.

New high records in the amount of property insurance provided to the insuring public and in total assets were achieved during 1950 by the Home Insurance Company, one of the largest property insurance carriers in the world, Harold
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)-- The proposed ban on live televising of college football games got a detailed going over in the antitrust division of the Justice Department today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2-- Oscar Brodney, Universal-International writer, has prepared a story outline for a sequel to the studio's two previous Army mule comedies, "Francis Goes to West Point." Filming of the story will be contingent on Army approval and cooperation, according to the studio.
GENEVA, Ill., April 2--Oscar Nelson, former State Auditor and Treasurer, died today in his home here at the age of 76. He had been a banker.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 3--Chinese and North Korean Communists have massed sixty-three divisions against United Nations forces in Korea. This is the strongest enemy potential in the field at any time since the war began, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur said today. With the present level of enemy divisions believed to be about 7,000 men each, the allied army faced more than 440,000 troops.
WASHINGTON, Ayril 2--Following is a translation of the address made today by President Vincent Auriol of France to Congress: Mr. President, Mr. Speaker, Senators and members of Congress,

The first English varsity crew to come to the United States for a boat race, the Cambridge University eight, arrived aboard a British Overseas Airways stratoliner late yesterday at Idlewild International Airport.

Lamp bases that seem to be made of stone or wood are included in a new collection of ceramic lamps and accessories designed by Mrs. Lee Rosen. They are available through decorators at Design-Technics, Inc., 44 East Twenty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP)-- Mrs. Elizabeth Moos, 61-year-old former mother-in-law of William Remington, pleaded innocent today to charges of failing to register as a foreign agent and was freed on $1,000 bond for a first hearing April 20.
WASHINGTON, April 2--Miss Marie Geneau, assistant to the sergeant of arms of the Senate, has become a candidate for the post of Ambassador to Haiti by an original method.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 2 (AP)-- Premier Nuri as-Said declared today that if the foreign-controlled oil industry in Iraq did not meet the demands for higher royalties being made on it by the Iraqi Government it might lose its concessions. If it does, he added, oil nationalization will not be necessary.

JACKSONVILLE, April 2--As the Giants rumbled along today on the first leg of their two-week barnstorming tour, Manager Leo Durocher seemed more confident than ever that his club would make that quick start so vital to success in the 1951 National League flag race.
PHILADELPHIA, April 2 (AP)-- Lu Rossini, Columbia University's pinch-hitting basketball coach, tonight was named college "coach of the year" by the Philadelphia Basketball Writer's Association.
LONDON, April 2--Britain's Cabinet is reported to have considered today a plan for the gradual withdrawal of British forces from the Suez Canal zone but to have come to no immediate decision.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2--Levin Rank, this city, president of the General Transportation Casualty and Surety Company, 1790 Broadway, New York, died here today in the Temple University Hospital in his sixty-first year. When in New York he resided at the New York Atheltic Club.

Brooklyn's hold-over grand jury investigating organized gambling and police corruption will begin tomorrow to question a number of present or former city officials who were closely associated with Ambassador William O'Dwyer when he was this city's Mayor.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP)-- Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican of Washington, today protested contempt citations against two gamblers who refused to testify before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee because of the presence of television cameras.

William Rivlin, a "small-time gambler" who served a penitentiary term two years ago for taking part in an attempt to rig a game between Manhattan College and George Washington University at Madison Square Garden, is being sought as an alleged "fixer" in the current basketball scandal, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 3 (AP)--Communique 842, by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's head quarters covering the period 6 A. M. April 2 to 6 A. M. April 3:

LONDON, April--2--Scotland Yard, the legendary nemesis of British lawbreakers, was afflicted today with an unusual attack of timidity. Its ingenious and diligent Hawkshaws apparently had tracked down those who stole the Stone of Scone from London's Westminster Abbey on Christmas Day, but for some reason they were hesitating to make any arrests.
WASHINGTON, April 2--President Truman asked Congress today for an additional $51,300,000 for "urgent production and research facilities" for the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)-- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that consumer debt for installation-plan buying had dropped in February for the second straight month.

The lowest level in price advances for any month since the start of the Korean War was reported by industrial purchasing agents yesterday. In many big companies top purchasing men said that no notices of increased costs of raw materials, equipment and supplies had been received. Instead of prices advances on the first working day of a new month, several voluntary price reductions were reported made by suppliers on desirable large contracts.

BUFFALO, April 2 (AP)--The Right Rev. John Z. Jasinski, Bishop of the Buffalo-Pittsburgh Diocese of the Polish National Catholic Church, died today at the age of 62. He was an internationally known worker in the cause of Christian unity.

WASHINGTON. April 2--The evolution of the Giannini banking empire from a modest beginning with the Bank of Italy at San Francisco in 1904 into a "predatory goliath" now controlling through Transamerica Corporation about 40 per cent of the banking facilities and deposits of five western states was described to the Federal Reserve Board today.

The board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday two eas for slum clearance and redevelopment recommended by the Committee on Slum Clearance, of which City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses is chairman.
Mayor Impellitteri gave his unqualified endorsement yesterday to Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy's warning that there was no place for unionism in the Police Department.

Recently this column quoted a chef, an expert on cheese cakes, who took the stand that housewives do not have and could not acquire the know-how to bake this dessert. But from the letters that have arrived since then it appears that home cooks--men as well as women--are not ready to concede defeat, even after this ultimatum.

The Public Service Commission began hearings yesterday on a petition by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for permission to distribute natural gas to consumers in Westchester County and limited areas of the Bronx and Queens. At present the company delivers manufactured gas to customers.
An anxious mother recently visited a neighborhood school to complain that "something is wrong with the achool work-my daughter enjoys it." The perplexed mother, whose consternation
WASHINGTON, April 3 President Truman has asked W. Stuart Symington, chairman of the National Security Resources Board," to consider the job of reorganizing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Changes in the top administration of Parke, Davis Co., including the election of Harry J. Loynd as president and Homer C. Fritsch as executive vice president, were announced yesterday following the annual meeting of stockholders in Detroit.

MIAMI, April 3 Dick Sisler came up in the eleventh inning tonight with two out and a man on base and after he had swung his bat the Dodgers must have said: "This is where we left off on the last day of the 1950 season."

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 4United States troops thrust across the Thirty-eighth Parallel in force on a ten-mile front in western Korea yesterday. At the same time General of the Army Douglas MacArthur with his highest Air Force and Naval aides flew to the east

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP)Students taking the new college qualification test must score 70 or better actually a higher mark than World War II officer candidates needed in order to win draft deferment, Selective Service officials revealed today .

WASHINGTON, April 3 President Truman holds that Americans must give strict observance to a moral code in private, public and international dealings "with the same determination the Communists give to their godless creed."

Rockwell Kent, illustrator and president of the International Workers Order, testified yesterday that he had "almost come to believe in Communists" but that he "did not believe in Russian communism for America."
The swollen rivers and streams of northern New Jersey eased off slowly yesterday, but the threat of floods continued to grow in New England.
WASHINGTON, April 3--President Truman has called labor leaders to a White House meeting on Thursday to discuss labor participation on the National Advisory Board on mobilization policy.

An April Fool issue of The Campus, one of City College's undergraduate student newspapers, which appeared on Monday, brought strong reactions of disapproval from faculty and administrators yesterday. Shocked by what he called the "blatant vulgarity of the issue, Dean James F. Peace of the department of student life remarked that it was "so disgusting that it could hardly be called funny."

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 4 (AP) -General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's communique 843, issued at 10 A. M. Wednesday (8 P. M., Eastern standard time, Tuesday) for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 6 A. M.:
Small business men who have been waiting to be covered by Social Security can now stop calling collectors of Internal Revenue about their problems. The new form for the self-employed has arrived.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) Federal Judge James W. Morris acquitted two union leaders today of contempt of Congress, but delayed a decision in the case of Philip Jaffe.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company, one of the nation's leading natural gas pipelines, reported yesterday a net income of $6,389,780 for 1950. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.32 a share on the utility's 2,388,538 shares of common stock outstanding. It compares with a net of $4,575,555, or $1.92 a common share, in the preceding year.
This week New York rolled out the red carpet and waved the flags for the visit of the President of the French Republic. It was not a perfunctory welcome. New Yorkers like to see the

"WHAT ever made you start swallowing live rats for a living?' The Ostrich had what was obviously a stock answer to this question. He always replied, 'One morning I simply thought, I want to swallow a live rat. So I did. Then it became a hobby with me. Other people go in for golf or bridge. I swallow rats.' "

France will seek to increase ex ports to the United States by $100,000,000 in 1951, according to Jean Jacques Guerlain, president of the Franc-DOllar Committee and chairman of the export committee of the French Association of Manufacturers. He estimated that French exports to this country and tourist dollars spent in France totaled $300,000,000 in 1950.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 3 Vic Raschi didn't have enough stuff to muffle the bat of the gigantic Luke Easter today. Indeed, Casey Stengel's right-handed Yankee ace didn't have the stuff to hobble the bats of any of the Indians as the American League clubs took their farewell of the desert country for the year.

This week, across the country, the large carpet companies are presenting through retail stores their new collections of rugs and carpets in the usual all-wool textures, as well as in the less familiar rayon and cotton and blends.

CHICAGO, April 3 Chicago reelected Martin H. Kennelly, its Democratic Mayor, to a second four-year term today and established the city's record low in percentage turnout of voters for a major election.

Top stars of every branch of show business, including grand opera and television, joined the circus yesterday for special appearances tonight at its opening performance in Madison Square Garden to aid the New York Heart Association's fund drive.

MITCHELL, S. D., April 3 (UP) W. R. Ronald, editor of The Mitchell Daily Republic and one of the architects of United States farm legislation in the Nineteen Thirties, died today after a long illness. He was 72 years old.
Jean Ravaud takes an optimistic, view of cooking in this country. He said yesterday that American cooking was becoming better that is, more Continental.

The decision of the Metropolitan Opera to go into television in a thorough, serious way is further evidence of the vigor and imagination that the management of Rudolf Bing is bringing to America's ranking opera company. This new step, like others that have gone before, should prove beneficial not only to the Metropolitan but also to the country at large.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 3 Orlando Vilasboas, leader of a Government expedition, reported today he believed he had found the bones of the long-missing British explorer, Col. P. H. Fawcett, in the Brazilian jungle.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 Sweden's envoy to Peiping has received standing instructions to keep sounding out the Chinese Communists on negotiations toward ending the Korean war. In the last couple
Pier installations in the Port of New York were reported yesterday to be sufficient in number but in many instances hopelessly outmoded and inadequate for present day commerce.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 The jurisdictional dispute between the new union, Television Authority, and the Screen Actors Guild over acting in films designed for television was narrowed today.

The ninth game for the world chess championship between Mikhail Botvinnik, the defender, and David Bronstein was started last night at the Tschaikovsky Concert Hall in Moscow and adjourned without reaching a decision after forty-two moves had been recorded, according to Soviet news sources.

The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations united yesterday to attack Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy for his recent advice to members of the force not to join a union.

A $500,000-a-year "abortion mill" that operated recently in a Stuyvesant Town apartment was smashed yesterday in a series of police raids that resulted in the arrest of three physicians, a selfstyled doctor and three women said to have been this doctor's assistants.

THE channel bass run is now underway off Oregon Inlet along the outer banks of North Carolina, and a report from Nags Head states that the first fish, a 35-pounder, was taken by D.J. Carter of Roanoke. Va.

Carrie Munn puts coquetry in her designs. She knows the witchery of lace frills, of molded bodices and tiny waists, of low curved decolletages and skirts flared for pretty swirl. In her spring and summer custom collection viewed yesterday at 640 Madison Avenue, she stressed the two-piece costume...

Several dinner parties will be given in advance of the performlance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of East Side House Settlement.

Like the proverbial bolt from the blue came word yesterday from Jose Ferrer's office of his resignation as director of the forthcoming "Anta Album." Who would take over the reins or whether the program would have to be deferred once more could not be ascertained last night. Scheduled to be presented May 6 at the Ziegfeld, the "Album," an annual benefit, already has undergone several postponements.

James Marshall, Manhattan member of the Board of Education, accused the city administration yesterday of giving the public school system "a shockingly bad deal" in the proposed 1951-52 budget and charged that Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson "has again messed up the teachers' salary problem."

Because all the seats for tonight's premiere of the motion picture, "Tales of Hoffmann," for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, were sold within twenty-four hours after the invitations were sent out, members of the organization have taken over additional showings of the film on the nights of April 9, 16 and 17 at the Bijou Theatre.
Joseph A. Anacreonte finally cleared his conscience yesterday, but the price may be a long prison term.
Ballet divertissements were features of the entertainment at the second annual dinner dance of the Ballet Associates in America last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Singapore tin, offered for April shipment at 1 cent a pound below the price set by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has been turned down by that agency, it was learned yesterday. Officials refused comment.

SEOUL, Korea, April 3 Little by little the ghosts are being chased out of this city by new refugee arrivals and military traffic. While efforts are being made to keep out refugees because of water and food shortages, hundreds of new arrivals are pouring into Seoul each night under cover of darkness.

BONN, Germany, April 3 Formally wiping out virtually all prohibitions and restrictions on peacetime production in West Germany, the Western occupying powers opened the way today for the restoration of Germany as the most powerful industrial nation in Western Europe.
A 34-year-old merchant seaman was arrested yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents as a result of an alleged scheme to mulct relatives of service men stationed overseas.

The President's executive order authorizing a new category of draft deferment "deferment by brains" is likely to be one of the subjects of debate in the House of Representatives' discussion of the military manpower bill, which that chamber took up yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 3 The termination of the educational phase of the Point Four technical assistance program between the United States and Chile was announced officially this evening. Claude G. Bowers, United States Ambassador, announced the termination in a long note personally delivered to the acting Minister of Education.

Twenty-one local public housing authorities received bids yesterday on issues of loan notes amounting to $94,529,000, backed by the Public Housing Administration. The notes, which will mature variously on Nov. 9 and Nov. 30, received bids ranging from 1.14 per cent to 1.20 per cent. For $82,210,000 of...
Net income of the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company increased last year to $5,265,266, from $3,734,528 in 1949, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

ROME, April 3 A bid for the return of Communists to the Government was made by Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti at the inauguration of his party's seventh national congress in Rome today. He argued that such a step was necessary to re-establish peace between the warring Italian political parties and to effect the social reforms required by the republican Constitution.

The firth and deciding game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Division semi-final play-off series between the New York Knickerbockers and the Syracuse Nationals will be played tonight at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street. The contest, which will not be televised, will start at 8:30 o'colck.

NEW DELHI, India, April 3 (AP) --Anti-American feeling among Indians has been roused to the point that some authoritative quarters fear violence against American officers serving at the United Nations cease-fire headquarters in Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, April 3 Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat of Georgia, told the House today that Universal Military Training might enable the United States to reduce the size of its armed forces to about 2,000,000 two years from now if world conditions grew no worse.

BRIGHTON, England, April 3 The high cost of living, which has been the main worry of all Britons for the past year, was the chief topic of debate today for the 700 delegates to the National Conference of Labor Women.
The Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company has announced its intention to build a demonstration coal-carrying pipeline near Cadiz, Ohio. The pipeline will be 17,000 feet long.
Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, announced yesterday he would recommend that the school refrain from playing any more basketball games at Madison Square Garden.
Parks Commissioner Robert Moses decided yesterday to make the children who rioted on Monday at the new St. Mary's Recreation Center in the Bronx pay for part of the $1,000 damage they caused.
WASHINGTON, April 3 The parents of four soldiers killed in valiant actions in Korea received today the nation's highest honor the Congressional Medal of Honor.

Perminanently crippled from war injuries, Cyril Claude Andersen, 34-year-old retired Army major, has been asked by the Federal Government, to provide proof of citizenship or face deportation, according to papers filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court, .

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 3-Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies made no new pledges when he opened the general election campaign for the Liberal and Country parties tonight, but he emphasized that the attack on communism remained one of the Government's chief preoccupationa.

Mayor Impellitteri's sales tax bill to increase the levy from 2 to 3 per cent for an estimated gain of $60,000,000 in city revenues was given to the City Council yesterday without an emergency message.
MONTREAL, April 3 (UP) The Detroit Red Wings downed the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 1, before 14,428 tonight and squared their semi-final Stanley Cup play-off series at two games apiece.

Those who think that handicrafts are practiced only in the country inspired by rural surroundings might visit the forty-sixth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Craftsmen. The show, which has as its theme "The Spirit of the City" will open today at the Hacker Gallery, 24 West Fortyeighth Street, and will continue through April 20.

LONDON, April 3 The Treasury gave the British people a glimpse into the economic future today. It was, in the Government's own words, an "unhappy prospect," in many ways "harsh and unpleasant," resulting largely from the necessity of shouldering a 4,700,000,000 rearmament bill over the next three years.

Resources of the National City Bank on March 31, this year, were about $74,000,000 greater than at the end of 1950, while deposits were up $37,000,000, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition, issued for publication today.

The Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum of Art's repository of medieval art, has received four important additions to its collection that will be on view today in its newly arranged fifteenth century Sculpture Hall in Fort Tryon Park overlooking the Hudson River.

The Cambridge University crew, first English eight to come to the United States to row against American oarsmen, relaxed in the hospitality of New York yesterday before leaving for New Haven today to begin training for its two races in this country.

NEWARK, April 3-The American Packing Corporation of Jersey City and nine individuals were indicted by the Federal grand jury today on charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government of an estimated $500,000 by substituting inferior meats for Army and Navy consumption.
Magistrate John M. Murtagh and James H. Sheils, Commissioner of Investigation, will testify this morning before Brooklyn's racket grand jury, District Attorney Miles F. McDonald announced yesterday.

The Federal Trade Commission's charge that mink fur traders had conspired to suppress competition was denied yesterday by Martin Schwartz, secretary of the Mink Traders Association, Inc. Mink traders walked out of fur trade auctions in 1949, he said, in a spontaneous protest against "almost intolerable trading conditions."

WASHINGTON, April 3 Mrs. Ruth McCormick Miller resigned today as editor in charge of The Washington Times-Herald, reportedly. after a policy disagreement with Col. Robert R. McCormick, publisher of the paper and of The Chicago Tribune.

What is cancer? For one thing, it is the nation's No. 2 killer. Figures on cancer deaths are readily available to bolster an appeal for funds, but figures are cold and impersonal things. Think instead of the friend or relative who succumbed to the living death of cancer and then to merciful death itself. Or think of 2-year-old Mary Jo May if you want to know what cancer is.

CLEVELAND, April 3 The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., by establishing a new "citizenship fund" will, in effect, make $1,275,000 available a year for political activity. This amount is ten times the amount the union raised in 1950 for the C.I.O. Political Action Committee.

Angelo Simonetti, Tammany leader of the Thirteenth Assembly trict. West, and secretary to Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan gave Mr. Wagner yesterday an affidavit that he had never had a telephone conversation with Frank Costello, or anything approaching a conference or a meeting.

Paul H. Pilgrim, veteran manager of athletics for the New York Athletic Club, yesterday was named by the New York Track Writers Association as 1951 recipient of the organization's annual award for long and meritorious service to track and field.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in March totaled $80,077,000, the largest amount for any corresponding month since 1946, when $140,480,000 was retired. Last month's total was the biggest for any month so far this year and compared with $27,739,000 in the preceding month and $58,863,000 in March, 1950.

Councilman Earl Brown, Democrat of Manhattan, introduced a resolution yesterday asking for the appointment of a special committee to study legislation designed to bolster the morale of city employes, which, he said, was at low ebb.
Mme. Vincent Auriol snatched an hour and a half from a tight official schedule yesterday afternoon to visit three hospitals.
PHILADELPHIA, April 3 An insurance policy covering Standard Oil Company of Indiana property valued at $500,000,000 in eight states has been underwritten by thirty-one American and

HONG KONG, April 3 An official signal for widening and deepening the Peiping regimes terroristic drive to stamp out the "enemies of the state" in China's urban centers was given today by The People's Daily, leading Chinese Communist organ, in an editorial

Mayor Impellitteri has fully endorsed Commissioner Murphy's advice to policemen not to join a union and we earnestly hope that their counsel will be followed. The advice comes a little late, for it was last August that Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union of the C. I. 0., let it be known that he was going to try to organize the police.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 3 A speed-up in Government efforts to erect a basis for German rearmament and intensification of Socialist opposition to the process were noted today, as the whole problem assumed a new urgency and importance in the politics of the Federal Republic.

MADRID, April 3 Madrid University students stoned street cars today, forced service to stop and refused to attend classes in protest over an increase in car fares. They smashed the windows of three cars out of six used on a branch line running to University City, and service was suspended on the line for the rest of the day.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 3 (AP) --The mighty Minneapolis Lakers were blasted out of the National Basketball Association play-offs tonight by the Rochester Royals, 80-75.

Lotowhite registered a decisive triumph in the Fighting Fox at Jamaica yesterday. Opposing only three others in the mile and a sixteenth event which served as the main race, Lotowhite upheld the favorite's role to the satisfaction of the crowd of 20,473 by scoring a four-length victory.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Wednesday, April 4 (AP) Denmark's coalition Government won almost half the approximately 650,000 votes cast in yesterday's election of twenty-eight members to the upper house of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, April 3 The fundamental difference of approach between the United States and the Latin-American republics on economic aspects of the present emergency came sharply into focus today at the meeting of Hemisphere foreign ministers.

In calling for a balanced federal budget for the fiscal year 1951-52 in his Economic Report last January, President Truman declared: "Legislation should be enacted at this session of the Congress to increase taxes by very much more than they were increased by the last two major tax bills which the Congress enacted."

American Bank Note Company will earn its 25-cent dividend for the first quarter of this year, Albert M. Schomp, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday. He added that the outlook for the second quarter is uncertain, with a smaller volume of orders on the books. American Bank Note, said Mr. Schomp, can earn up to $2 a share before it becomes liable for the Federal excess profits tax.

WASHINGTON, April 3--The chairman of three Senate investigating panels agreed today to cooperate for a single full-scale inquiry into purchases and charterings of surplus Government ships in deals that have resulted not only in large profits but heavy cuts in Federal taxes.

The United Negro College Fund's eighth annual campaign opened yesterday with a meeting of 500 persons at the Plaza Hotel. A national goal of $1,500,000 was announced, of which New York's quota will be $350,000.

BOSTON, April 3 (UP) The Toronto Maple Leafs came from behind with a trio of goals tonight to beat the Boston Bruins, 3 1, before 13.154 fans at Boston Garden and take a one-game lead in their semi-final Stanley Cup playoffs. Toronto now leads 2-1, one game having ended in a curfewcaused tie.
CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) As long rumored, heavyweight champion Ezzard Charles will defend his title against light-heavyweight champion Joe Maxim on May 30 at the Chicago Stadium.

ALBANY, April 3 Governor Dewey signed into affirmative law today the rent control regulations promulgated by Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator. Actually the regulations have been in effect since March 15.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The head of one of the nation's largest rubber products manufacturing concerns said today "a civilian crisis in rubber" may be imminent unless Government stockpiling and allocation policies are changed.

Margaret Turnley, soprano, who has sung here in "Street Scene" and "Regina" under the name of Peggy Turnley, gave her first local recital last night at Town Hall. She proved to be a singer of charm and refinement, but with somewhat narrow limits.
New York bestowed high honors and a warm welcome yesterday upon President Vincent Auriol of France. Seventy-five thousand persons, according to the police estimate, applauded and

PARIS, April 3--Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, was not disposed today to discuss the Western compromise agenda for a Big Four foreign ministers conference and instead he launched into a new attack on the North Atlantic Treaty.
WASHINGTON, April 3 The Senate rejected tonight an effort by the Old Guard Republicans to give Congress an outright and legally binding control over the dispatch of American troops to Europe.

All aspects of safety in the maritime industry are to be discussed at the two-day meeting of the marine section of the Twentyfirst Greater New York Annual Safety Convention and Exposition, which opens today at the Statler Hotel. Today's meeting will be devoted to shipbuilders in the morning and to ship operators in the afternoon.

The annual custom of ministration to the aged of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was observed yesterday by clergy and laity at the Home for the Aged of the Little Sisters of the Poor, 135 West 106th Street.

MOBILE, Ala., April 3 It was homecoming day for Eddie Stanky today but for quite a time it looked as though the Giants were going to let their peppery second sacker down before an overflow gathering of 7,881. For the Braves, making short shrift of Sheldon Jones, bowled them over for seven runs inside of two innings.

The report that President Truman is considering major changes in the organization and personnel now directing American psychological and political warfare activities focuses attention again upon a major area. Throughout the world Communist propaganda and misrepresentation are being fought with the spoken and printed word ...

Republican efforts to tie President Truman's hands so that he could send no troops out of the country without prior approval of Congress were beaten in the Senate yesterday. The major defeat came on a motion by Senator Bricker to change into a

Women who have long taken an active interest in St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases in the Bronx, formerly known as the Home for Incurables, are among the subscribers to the spring bridge and canasta party to be held this afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club for the benefit of the hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) Three witnesses linked with the Chicago Capone gang surrendered to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee today as police in five states opened a drive on telephone and telegraph facilities of gamblers and lawbreakers.

BOCA BATON, Fla., April. 3 Marking the first time it has ever been presented to a clinician, the annual research award of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association was given here today to Dr. Howard A. Rusk, director of the Institute of Rehabilitation and Physical Medicine of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center:

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Bijou, the attraction is "Tales of Hoffmann," the British-made adaptation of the Jacques Offenbach opera, written, produced and directed by Michael Powell...

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) Statehood for Hawaii and Alaska was approved by the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee today and Senator Joseph C, O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, chairman, said he would press for early floor action.

At a session of the Inter-American Press Conference in New York last Columbus Day, Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, publisher of La Prensa in Buenos Aires, made a prophetic speech. The irony of the present situation becomes deeper with the realization that the speech marked his acceptance of the annual award of The Americas Foundation for his services in promoting fraternal feeling among the peoples of the Americas by means of a free and independent press.

Prices of stocks eased again yesterday and neared the lows of January and March. After see-sawing the greater part of the session, prices fell under moderate selling in the late trading to produce an irregularly lower close. Major price changes were fewer than in recent sessions and consisted mostly of fractions. In terms of the averages the composite rate slipped 0.42 point.
There were 2,000 "finders keepers" in New York yesterday, each of whom picked up in some public place an envelope containing a Booker T. Washington Birthplace Memorial half dollar.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 3 Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, hurriedly departed for Washington today following a brief appearance before the convention of the Communications Workers Union, C.I.O., here.

A group of seven buildings containing stores and apartments at 1326 to 1336 Avenue of the Americas, southeast corner of Fiftyfourth Street, has been sold by Frederick Brown to B.J. and L.V. Weil in a deal negotiated by Arthur. L. Dryfoos, broker. Mr. Brown bought the property from the Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle, which owned the corner for thirty-one years.

THE first Olympic champion was Coroebus of Elis. He won the great foot race in a meadow beside the river Alpheus at Olympia in 776 B.C. The Emperor Theodosius halted the Olympic Games by decree in 394 A.D.

George R. Witte, 56-year-old former newspaper man, who at the age of 18 was an assistant correspondent for The United Press in Berlin, was found dead yesterday morning in his apartment at 30 East Ninth Street with gas escaping from five jets of a kitchenette range and a dispossess notice beside him.

Reappearance of profiteering, price-gouging and like abuses in the paper trade, as a result of national emergency pressures, were condemned yesterday by T.H. Mittendorf, manufacturing executive, in an address at the annual meeting of the National Paper Trade Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

"I don't like to have the reputation of being a chic woman; I like beautiful clothes, but they are purely incidental in my life," Mme. Vincent Auriol, wife of the President of France, said yesterday morning in her apartment in the Waldorf Towers.

NORTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 3 Donald W. Patterson, who resigned in February from his post as supervisor of educational operations at the City College Midtown Business Center, 430 West Fiftieth Street, New York, died last night in Muhlenberg Hospital here after a brief illness. His age was 49. He lived on Woodledge Road, Watchung, N. J.
The Polish liner Batory, to which the use of municipally owned piers has been denied by the City of New York, intends to return to this port May 2 as scheduled and probably will dock in Jersey City.

New financing transactions for industrial companies today will be marked by the public offering of two new issues of debentures totaling $40,000,000, and by offerings of more than $10,300,000 of new common stock to company shareholders. The offerings are as follows:
