HONOLULU, April 3 A proposal to urge all or a majority of American unions to quit work for a "national seventy-two-hour protest holiday" demanding repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act was adopted unanimously here today by delegates attending the biennial convention of the independent International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

WASHINGTON, April 3 The Latin American republics were today asked by John Foster Dulles, Ambassador-at-Large, to consider means to combat the Soviet veto in the United Nations. He said the veto had blocked the admission of other peace-loving nations and might block that of Japan should a peace treaty be signed.

A collection of traditional lamps that will blend well with the Regency and Empire styles currently in favor has just become available through decorators from Lightolier, 11 East Thirty-sixth Street. These period designs, which have been modernized and simplified, range in price from $54 to $150.
Fourteen underwriting syndicates competed at public sealed bidding yesterday for the award of about $45,000,000 of securities of railroad and public utility companies.

The national wage and price control program was criticized yesterday as a "botch" and one that had been administered without "statesmanship." Widespread labor walkouts were seen unless a "real" formula was worked out to deal with the problem.
WASHINGTON, April 3--The Communist party told the Subversive Activities Control Board yesterday that it was a champion of peace, "dominated" only by concern for the common man.

Jorge Bolet, who appeared in a piano recital at Carnegie Hall last night, commands one of the most formidable techniques in the business. His ten fingers are strong and true, and they will do anything that he asks of them. If you are interested in clean and dazzling execution, Mr. Bolet should be your pianist.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 3Robert Coleman Johnson Sr. of 800 North Broad Street, formerly maintenance-of-way engineer for the Board of Transportation of the City of New York, died today at his home after a long illness. His age was 73. He retired in 1945.

The vacant one-story building at the southeast corner of Roosevelt Avenue and Sixty-third Street in Woodside, Queens, formerly occupied as an automobile showroom and service station, has been sold by Theodore Grand and Nathan Vogel to a client of Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, who plans to remodel it for store occupancy. It contains 12,500 square feet of space. The William Adam Schulz Company was the broker.

Industrial heat-treating needs of national defense have soared to a six-year peak and further increases are expected. Unfilled orders for industrial furnaces at the end of the first quarter, it was estimated yesterday, are more than five times the volume of unfilled orders for the same period last...

After an ownership of more than half a century, the five-story apartment and store building at 973 Eighth Avenue, northwest corner of Fifty-seventh Street, has been sold by the Henry C. Copeland Estate to an investing client of Joseph G. Abramson, attorney.
CHICAGO, April 3 The grain markets developed a heavy under tone in the late trading on the Board of Trade here today after wheat had shown moderate strength early.

WASHINGTON, April 3 Private investors have subscribed for more than $5,635,000,000 of the Treasury's new 2 per cent nonmarketable bonds, Secretary John W. Snyder said today. The bonds are being offered in exchange for outstanding 2 per cent marketable bonds of 1967-72.

LAUREL, Md., April 3 (AP) Keeping to the middle of the track there the going was less muddy, Apprentice Donald Mitchell guided Four Chances to a neck victory over Eastern Flyway in the $3,500 Takoma Park Purse at Laurel today.
ALBANY, April 3 Governor Dewey started the official machinery rolling today for the special grand jury investigation of any illegal "gambling, bribery and corruption" in Saratoga County.

As the necessity of college education increases for young people, the need to plan financially for retirement at 65 or earlier is increasingly stressed among the middle-aged. This combination is putting middle-class parents into an economic squeeze that can produce "severe pressure and conflict within the family," Dr. Raymond Sobel, chief psychiatrist at Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School, said last night.

The need for closer cooperation among the Jews of the world to help solve the problems of displaced persons and immigrants to Israel was stressed yesterday by the Marchioness of Reading, member of the International Executive of the World Jewish Congress and president of the British section of the congress.

A detailed inventory of the most popular mail order gift merchandise in the Christmas catalogs of seventy-eight department stores throughout the country has been issued by Ralf Shockey Associates, Inc., merchandising consultants. It evaluates 175 items, from cosmetics to china in thirteen classifications, in terms of times shown or mentioned and strongest...

BOSTON, April 3 Studies shedding new light on the mechanism used by the body in mobilizing certain types of white blood cells to defend itself against bacterial invaders were reported here today at the annual spring meeting of the American Chemical Society.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and closed unchanged to 44 points net lower than on Monday.

LONDON, April 3--British Government securities were hit by forebodings contained in the Economic Survey published today. Before the issue and of the survey they had shown many rises. Later these were more than lost and prices fell further in unofficial business after hours.

MIAMI, FLa., April 3 (AP) Uniform interpretation of common trade practices in the alcoholic beverage industry in all states was recommended today by Charles W. Chattaway, associate counsel to the New York State Liquor Authority.
DURHAM, N.C., April 3 Inability to hit in the pinches proved costly to Yale today and Duke's Blue Devils gained a 3-1 victory in the opener of a two-game series. The teams play here again tomorrow.
Men's and women's clothing partly made of sand was visualized yesterday by John A. Dickinson of the National Bureau of Standards, United States Department of Commerce. Experiments

WASHINGTON, April 3 Agreement upon major points of a controlled materials plan under which the distribution of steel, aluminum and copper will be supervised by the Governmen, was reached here today by top officials of the Defense Production Committee. Concluding more a than a week of conferences on the subject with ...

Harry Mossberg has sold the five four-story buildings containing eighty-five apartments at 1462 to 1482 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, to the Jol-John Realty Corporation for cash above a mortgage of approximately $101,000. The property occupies a plot 190 by 93 feet.
RICHMOND, Va., April 3 The University of Richmond baseball team capitalized on Dartmouth pitching wildness to roll up a 12to-5 victory today.
"Darkness at Noon," "The Lady's Not for Burning" and "Guys and Dolls" were selected yesterday by the New York Drama Critics Circle as the best stage productions of the 1950-51 season on Broadway.

VIENNA, April 3 Austria will need more help from the Economic Cooperation Administration in 1951-52 than in the preceding year, according to a statement at a press conference here today by United States High Commissioner Walter J. Donnelly.
ALBANY, April 3 Private nursing homes for the convalescent and aged were put under the supervision of the State Board of Social Welfare in a bill approved by Governor Dewey today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 President Truman hailed today the progress that had been made in collective Western defense but warned that "the road ahead is still long and hard." His remarks were contained in a statement issued on the second anniversary of the signing of the North Atlantic Treaty.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., April 4--A former Army captain in World War II was fined $35 tonight for acting in what he considered the general interest by tossing "No Left Turn" traffic signs into the Saw Mill River hare.

LONDON, April 4--A military correspondent of The London Daily Telegraph said today that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had told him in an interview in Tokyo that the United Nations could defeat the Chinese Communists easily if politicians would face up to realities.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 4--Joseph W. Beirne, president of the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., announced today the election of eleven regional and two national directors of the union, which is holding its fifth annual convention here.

Thirty-one qualifying sites, two more than last year, have been picked for the United States Open golf tourney. The Open will be decided at the Oakland Hills Country Club at Birmingham, Mich., near Detroit, June 14-16.

Taking time out from his drive to unionize the police force, Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0., warned yesterday that 36,000 city subway, elevated and bus employes were ready to go on a one-day strike unless they got a forty-hour work week, plus a 10 per cent increase over the pay they now receive for forty-eight hours.
NEWARK, April 4--Dr. Charles M. Robbins, a past president of the Academy of Medicine of Northern New Jersey, died here today at his home, 62 Goldsmith Avenue. He was 58 Years old.

The so-called defense housing program now being considered in Congress has many socialistic features and offers a "major threat" to private business and property ownership, Alexander Summer of Teaneck, N. J., president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, warned the industry yesterday.

Two new issues of public utility bonds totaling $22,000,000, and two new issues of public utility and industrial company common stock valued at $7,220,000 will be offered to investors today. The new issues are as follows:

With a rise of 130 per cent in sales, Olympic Radio and Television, Inc., realized a record net income of $1,577,484 last year, 175 per cent over the $578,163 earned in 1949, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders last night.

The nation's gasoline stocks rose 947,000 barrels last week to a new peak of 142,186,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. They were 141,239,000 barrels a week earlier and 135,588,000 a year ago.

Hats literally light as a feather comprised the custom collection by William J., presented yesterday in his salon at 134 East Fifty-seventh Street. "Beauty by the ounce" as interpreted in millinery designs consisted primarily of feathers, used as trim or in the entire body of the hat.
ALBANY, April 4--Veterans of the Korean war will be eligible for the $1,400 scholarships awarded by the state each year to former service men under a bill approved today by Governor Dewey. Spon

BERLIN, April 4--Maj. Gen. Lemuel A. Mathewson, Commandant of the United States sector of Berlin, served notice today to Sergei A. Dengin, Berlin representative of the Soviet Control Commission in Berlin, that the episode last Wednesday in which East sector German police fired upon American sightseeing buses at the Potsdamer Platz was not yet a closed issue.
There was one night last year Mrs. John Gaines will never forget. She cried all through it, walked the floor, forcing back the tears. She kept asking herself: "Where have I failed?"

The State of California sold at sealed public bidding yesterday an issue of $50,000,000 of serial bonds to finance school building at an interest cost of 1.83 per cent. The obligations, which will come due from 1953 to 1977, were bought by a syndicate headed by Bank of America National Trust Company,

WASHINGTON, April 4--Maj. Gen. Francis H. Lanahan, commander of the Signal Corps Center at Forth Monmouth, N. J., will be assigned late this month to the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers in Europe (Shape). The Army did not disclose his specific duties.

WASHINGTON, Apri1 4--Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan announced today a conference at Des Moines, Iowa, on Saturday to begin an all-out effort to make up an indicated 5,000,000-acre shortage in corn plantings for the agricultural production program.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP)-- La Prensa, the suppressed Buenos Aires newspaper, will be mourned Friday by newspapers, radio stations and one news magazine in five major cities of the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4--Despite higher taxes and operating expenses seventeen of twentytwo Philadelphia banks reported increased earnings in the first quarter of this year. The city's six other leading banks did not disclose their earnings for the period.

Seven persons, including three Manhattan physicians, were arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on charges of conspiracy to commit criminal abortions. Assistant District Attorney Carl J. Rubino said his office wanted time to continue its investigation and present the case to the grand jury.

Joseph M. Proskauer, former State Supreme Court justice, arrived here yesterday to assume the chairmanship of the State Crime Commission, a post to which he was appointed by Governor Dewey. The 73-year-old attorney said that the group would arrange its initial meeting and confer with the Governor "immediately."

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 4-- Syrian Army troops who have crossed the border into Israel killed seven civilian policemen today and wounded at least three others, the Israeli Government announced tonight. The Syrians were said to be still on Israeli territory and apparently they held the village of Hamma near the border in the southern demilitarized zone southeast of Lake Tiberias.

CLEVELAND, April 4--A bazooka-like "shaped charge" that simplifies the tapping of openhearth furnaces in steel mills and minimizes the possibility of accidents was the feature attraction at the concluding session of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers' thirtyfourth annual conference today.
WASHINGTON, April 4--Secretary of State Dean Acheson took an active part today for the first time in the debates of the fourth consultative meeting of the American foreign ministers.

Our forces in Korea maintained the initiative Wednesday with operations proceeding as planned. Substantial gains were registered in the west-central and east-central sectors against resistance varying from negligible to aggressive. Northeast of Uijongbu the enemy launched a number of probing attacks during the night. The eastern and western sectors were relatively quiet.

PARIS, April 4--Countering the Western draft of an agenda for a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy, introduced today a new arrangement of the Soviet proposals to the Big Four deputies conference in the Palais Rose. The new version, in the view of the Western deputies, still offered several major objections but showed that the deputies were inching forward toward an ultimate success.

By tomorrow there should be some definite word as to whether "The Little Blue Light," ninth in the series of plays sponsored this season by the American National Theatre and Academy, opens here on April 22 with or without Burgess Meredith.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The troops-to-Europe debate here illustrates the Senate's unique capacity for magnifying the things that divide the United States and minimize the things that unite it.

BONN, Germany, April 4--About 1,000 women, apparently organized by the Communists but disavowing it, attempted to demonstrate in front of the Parliament Building here today but were moved on by uniformed city policemen.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, said today that Reconstruction Finance Corporation officials probably would be called before the Senate Small Business Committee to explain deficiencies in the synthetic rubber program.

Ground lost earlier this week was reclaimed yesterday by the stock market under a strong lasthour rally. Gains of fractions to about 2 points, with the composite rate raised 1.28 points, represented the largest rebound since March 16. The recovery followed further easiness during the morning in the list, with the leadership assumed by the rails.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 4 --Organizers for two labor unions were questioned today concerning damage to seven greens of the Wykagyl Country Club, but identity of the vandals remained a mystery tonight. The union men said they merely had been trying to organize the club's fifty-seven employes and had no desire to club property.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The current world-wide "peace offensive" is "the most dangerous hoax ever devised by the international Communist conspiracy," the House Committee on Un-American Activities charged today in a special report.
Columbia University launched its seventieth baseball season yesterday in the bleak, cold setting at Baker Field and lost, 4--1, to City College.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that an employer was not automatically forbidden to continue dealing with the established bargaining agent of his employes merely because a rival union had filed a petition to represent some of them.

A new kind of "double action" price escalator clause is being used by industrial purchasing agents to insure that orders placed now receive full benefit of future price reductions. This was disclosed here yesterday by members of the National Association of Purchasing Agents and confirmed by the association's methods and procedures experts.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- Announced American casualties in Korea reached 58,550 today, a rise of 1,430 in a week. The total, representing casualties reported to next of kin through March 30, included 8,753 killed, 39,023 wounded and 10,774 missing in action.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Public reaction to excessive price advances is beginning to make itself felt in industry through a falling off in sales, Charles E. Wilson, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, told a Congressional "watchdog" committee today.

WASHINGTON, April 4--A Federal drive to collect unpaid taxes on surplus war properties resold in this country came to light today as a House Expenditures subcommittee heard further testimony about large profits by middlemen in such transactions.

City College basketball players will not play for hotel teams in the Catskill Mountain circuit this summer, it was learned yesterday. Coach Nat Holman said he had told his team Tuesday that any player who represented a resort without the college's permission would be dropped from the squad.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday at a City Hall press con ference that he would vote for the local bill to increase the sales tax to 3 per cent if and when the measure came to the Board of Estimate for consideration.

Bernard M. Baruch went back last night to Public School 69, at 125 West Fifty-fourth Street, where he had been one of the younger pupils seventy years ago. Memories of the Victorian era--of hansom cabs, Fifth Avenue stage coaches, gas lamps, horse cars and bustles--were revived as Mr. Baruch joined 400 graduates, pupils, parents and teachers in celebrating the school's seventy-fifth anniversary.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The United States Atomic Energy Commission announced today the first move by private industry toward the commercial production of radioisotopes.

The addition of $9,500,000 to Mayor Impellitteri's proposed 19511952 budget of $1,336,000,000 to help voluntary hospitals carry the burden of caring for the indigent was urged yesterday by a special committee representing the hospitals.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The White House angrily disavowed today an article appearing in next Friday's issue of Collier's Magazine that quoted President Truman as advocating a twelve-year limit on the service of Representatives and Senators. Such a restriction would bar from Congress all of the President's top leaders and most of his principal critics.
The Fordham baseball team opened its home season yesterday by overpowering St. Peter's, 10--2, at Fordham Field.

Headliner at Jamaica yesterday was Mrs. Nora A. Mikell's Repetoire, the Happy Argo colt with the misspelled name. The Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes nominee won first money of $15,400 in the six-furlong Experimental Handicap No. 1. He was the $13.30-for-$2 third choice in a line-up of thirteen 3-year-olds.

A former Syracuse University assistant purchasing agent and two former War Assets Administration employes were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of purchasing $76,065 worth of surplus Government drugs for $3,803 for the university, then selling them on the open market for $62,174.

Fresh pineapples, so suggestive of that fresh taste of spring, are arriving in the New York markets in good supply. Last week there were 5,000 crates from Puerto Rico and yesterday 6,000 more came in; some also arrived from Cuba. All are of the red Spanish variety and most are in the smaller sizes, wellsuited to use in families of three or four people.

A national manpower council to appraise this country's human resources and manpower needs in a period of "enduring emergency" has been established at Columbia University. Its work will be financed with a grant of $100,000 from the Ford Foundation.

For most men the past is as irrevocably obscured as the future. This being so, Ralph Kirkpatrick's recital last night at Town Hall was profoundly illuminating, for, by playing with consummate artistry on two different keyboard instruments, he unveiled two different pasts within hearing of each other.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 4--So far as a capacity crowd of 5,799 fans was concerned, the Giants' second and last game of their brief series with the Braves ended today on a rather disappointing note since the game had to be called after eight innings to allow the New Yorkers to catch a train with the score deadlocked at 5-all.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4-- Increasing employment in the motion-picture industry was indicated by figures released today by the California Department of Industrial Relations, which showed that film craft work in February, traditionally the lowest month in the year, had been above the average for all twelve months of 1950.

ROME, March 28--The way is long from Washington to the Iron Curtain in Germany, through it to Berlin, and thence down the Italian peninsula to the watchtowers of the West on the Adriatic and the Mediterranean. On this frontier of the free world the North Atlantic Powers and their allies, voluntary and otherwise, present many spectacles, and among them this correspondent will long remember:

SAVANNAH, Ga., April 4--A pinch single by Jim Russell for one run and a sacrifice by Don Thompson set the stage for Carl Furillo to whack a two-run single to left center and give the Dodgers a 5-4, eleven-inning victory over the Phils at Grayson Stadium tonight.
CLEVELAND, April 4--Walter F. Reuther won his fourth term today as president of the United Automobile Workers of America, C. I. O. He was unopposed.

LONDON, April 4--The two highest committees directing the day-to-day activities of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization--the political Council of Deputies in London and the military Permanent Standing Group in Washington--were linked closely today on the second anniversary of the treaty.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 5--United Nations forces struck across the Thirty-eighth Parallel in Korea at a half dozen points yesterday in a limited offensive to stall an expected counter-blow... by heavily massing Chinese and North Koreans.

Two five-story buildings containing three stores and fifteen apartments on plot 50 by 100 feet at 1729-31 First Avenue, near East Eighty-ninth Street, were purchased by David S. Meister, operator, from a client of Jacob Rudd, attorney, in a deal negotiated by the Omnia Real Estate Corporation, broker. The apartments con
The homemaker confronted with her spring laundering tasks might note some new washing and ironing items.
TUCSON, Ariz., April 4 (AP)--Al Simmons today denied reports that he had resigned as coach of the Indians. He said he just asked permission to leave in order to see his doctor.

THAT December day in Cleveland had been bitterly cold and dismal. Nor was the gloom lightened by the fact that the Browns had just edged out the Giants in their pro football divisional play-off. Suddenly Steve Owen interrupted his post-mortems. A wistful look came into his eyes.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 4-- George Albert Smith, president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, died today at his home here on his eighty-first birthday. He had been in poor health since February, when he was stricken with a respiratory infection.

LAUREL, Md., April 4 (AP)--The John L. McKnight silks dominated the finish of the featured Orchid Purse at Laurel Park today when the entry of Mr. Buster and Play Toy took first and second money, respectively.

On the second anniversary of the signing of the North Atlantic Pact the Senate has approved by a large majority a resolution which constitutes another historic landmark in the development of American foreign policy. With this resolution the Senate reasserts the vital principle, long evidenced by the

Rising magnanimously above the season's slaughter, the New York Drama Critics Circle has named the official winners. For the best new American play of the season: Sidney Kingsley's "Darkness at Noon"; for the best foreign play produced on Broadway: Christopher Fry's "The Lady's Not for Burning"; for the best new musical

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh, who was Commissioner of Investigation for four years when William O'Dwyer was Mayor of this city, testified yesterday before the Brooklyn special grand jury that is investigating gambling.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, reported yesterday that the bistate agency had spent $371,000,000 in building sixteen major transport and terminal facilities in the thirty years since its creation.

Tin continued to recede yesterday in reflection of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's refusal on Tuesday to buy Singapore tin at a price 1 cent below its official level. Although there were no dealings save for switches in two lots, the bid price in New York dropped 150 points more, going down to $1.45 a pound for April delivery. This constrasted with the R. F. C. price of $1.50 , which was unchanged.
Disavowed statement in Colliers magazine article quoting President as advocating twelveyear limit for service of Representatives and Senators.

After four successive terms as chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, Robert P. Boylan has announced that he will not be a candidate for re-election either as chairman or board member. He will continue to hold his seat on the Exchange.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 4-- Arthur H. Ham of Scarsdale, N. Y., and Pinehurst, retired vice president and chief operating officer of the Provident Loan Society of New York, who had spent his entire business career in the field of small loans, died at his home here this morning after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

Ten minutes before the final buzzer, the New York Knickerbockers trailed the Syracuse Nationals by 12 points in the pay-off game of their semi-final play-offs last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. With every tick of the clock, Joe Lapchick's lads appeared to be fading farther out of the National Basketball Association post-season picture. The end of the road was in sight.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 4 (AP)-- Minister of Posts and Telegraphs Ahmed Zanageh announced today that Iran would refuse to transmit foreign press cables that appeared to endanger state security or to violate "decency."

Home furnishings stores and some other retail outlets face an average slash of 45 per cent in profits if a provision of Ceiling I Price Regulation 7, which governs retail pricing, is permitted to stand. Data supporting this contention were submitted yesterday to the Office of Price Administration by a special committee of the National Retail Furniture Association, representing more than 8,500 home furnishings stores throughout the country.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross has leased the third floor in 760 Eighth Avenue, at West Forty-sixth Street, for additional executive and administrative offices in Manhattan. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers, negotiated the lease with Walter Scott Co., agents for the building.

A notable and depressing fact about Chicago's Mayoralty election was that it brought out a smaller proportion of the registered vote than any previous election of comparable importance within memory. The return of Mayor Martin H. Kennelly to office for another four-year term may or may not be a good thing; but the amazing

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4-- Any legal right of Judge George B. Harris of the Federal District Court here to take any action contrary to the judgment of Federal courts in the District of Columbia in the R. Stanley Dollar case was challenged today by Moses Lasky, an attorney for the Dollar interests.

A Bronx policy bank with a daily business of $12,000 was broken up last night after members of the Police Commissioner's confidential squad had raided a two-family house in a residential section of the borough. Assistant Chief Inspector James R. Kennedy described the bank as the largest one he had ever seen.

Two organizations here yesterday attacked the proposal for a heavy tax on advertising put forward by the staff of the Joint Congressional Economic Committee. In a telegram to Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, the chairman of the committee who carefully refrained from endorsing the proposal, Robert A. Whitney, president of National Sales Executives, Inc., described the proposed tax as "another socialistic measure."
CONCORD, N. H., April 4 (AP)-- Gordon M. Tiffany, New Hampshire Attorney General, reported today that he could find no evidence that Senator Tobey had received campaign funds he did not list.

WASHINGTON, April, 4 (UP)-- Promotion of two Government aviation officials would give scheduled airlines absolute control of air transportation policy, Amos E. Heacock, president of the Aircoach Transport Association, asserted today.

The $75,000,000 expansion program of the Republic Steel Corporation, designed to add 672,000 net tons to its annual ingot capacity, will be financed for the most part by the private sale of $60,000,000 of 3 per cent convertible debentures to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, it was learned yesterday.

ROME, April 4--Miss Jane Pritchard Deegan, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Rollins Deegan of Rome and Ashville, N. C., and of the late John Edward Deegan of Mobile, Ala., was married here today to John Trowbridge Murphy, son of John J. P. Murphy of New York and Oyster Bay, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Barbara Harrison Trowbridge Murphy, took place here today in St. Peter's Basilica.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- The Government lost still another round today in its fight to retain control of American President Lines.

HONOLULU, April 4--Delegates to the biennial convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, independent, adopted resolutions today condemning the Coast Guard screening program, demanding repeal of the McCarran (Internal Security) Act, urging the armed forces to get out of the maritime industry and calling for defense of civil liberties.

A lone robber, posing as a detective, held up the manager of the Latin Quater, a Broadway night club, at 8 o'clock last night and escaped with $1,470. Several hundred patrons in the club at 200 West Forty-eighth Street were unaware of the robbery, which took place in a rear office one flight above the club.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 28, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The two-story taxpayer building containing four stores and a loft at 280 East 138th Street, southeast corner of Third Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Rivermount Realty Company to Betty Kalowsky for investment. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers in the sale of the property, which is 25 by 100 feet and is assessed at $28,000. The sale was for cash over mortgages amounting to $32,500.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4--A familiar gray-clad golfing figure diligently spent two hours on the practice tee today in final preparation for the Masters tournament starting tomorrow over the famed Augusta National Golf Club course.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4--The painful niceties of diplomatic protocol gave United Nations officialdom an unhappy day today, and the unhappiest of all was Secretary General Trygve Lie.

Phillip Pron, the 24-year-old seaman who had been blind for more than a year, could see again yesterday. The young man could see because another seaman last week sacrificed the cornea of his own failing eye and gave it to Phillip.

A struggle for economic survival, reminiscent of the old range conflicts between cattlemen and sheepmen, is raging on Long Island between the prospering duck farmers and the Great South Bay oyster industry, which is now virtually out of business.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The State Department said today that the United States, France and Britain were seeking a foreign ministers meeting with the Soviet Union because it might help "advance our program for peace."

President Vincent Auriol said farewell to New York and the United States last night in an address in which he toasted the triumph of "democracy and liberty" and the continuing friendship of France and the United States.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 4--Dr. Martin Niemoeller, stormy petrel of German Protestantism, today said he had fulfilled his political mission opposing rearmament and added that far from urging Dr. Konrad Adenauer's downfall he hoped the West German Chancellor would remain in office until East and West Germany were reunited.

ROME, APRIL 4--The Right-Wing Socialists decided this morning to merge with Unitarian Socialists and withdraw immediately from the Cabinet. The decision was laboriously reached after four days of debate at the Right-Wing Socialist party congress in Rome and was sanctioned finally by 54 per cent of the total votes cast.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 4-- Robert J. Menner, Sterling professor of English at Yale and a member of the faculty for thirty-two years, died today of a heart attack at Gaylord Farms Sanatorium in near-by Wallingford. His age was 59.

According to Washington reports, President Truman has asked W. Stuart Symington, chairman of the National Security Resources Board, to undertake the job of reorganizing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. This is an interesting development in the R. F. C. situation; so, also, was the testimony on Tuesday of Senator Fulbright before the Senate Expenditures Committee, in which the Arkansas Senator supported Mr. Truman's "second guess" plan of reorganization of the gigantic Government lending agency.

LOS ANGELES, April 4--The United States was chided at an inter-American medical meeting today for being the only major American nation that has not yet joined in the hemispheric campaign against the mosquito that carries urban yellow fever.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Sharp declines in prices of some fresh fruits and vegetables kept the average retail price of food from rising between Feb. 26 and March 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today on the basis of an eight-city survey. It was the second successive two-week period in which food prices did not show increases.

BRIDGETON, N. J., April 4-- Judge David L. Horuvitz of the Cumberland County Court ruled here today that the Western Union Telegraph Company must stand trial under four indictments charging that it allowed its local telegraph office to be used for the transmission of illegal racing bets.

PARIS, April 4--The obligation upon France to create and maintain a substantial army as part of the North Atlantic defense system coincides with an internal crisis over what kind of electoral system France shall have, and consequently over what type of Government she may expect.

The vital need of children for a well-balanced, democratic family life and for guidance by adults who understand themselves and others was stressed last night at a symposium arranged by the auxiliary council to the Association for the Advancement of Psychoanalysis.

Although it is highly Grim regarded in academic cirSpring cles, especially those of a Vacation lower order, the spring vacation is not an unmixed pleasure for all. It is not an unmixed pleasure for parents, to cite one group of unhappy malcontents, and it probably is no great pleasure for the neighbors. Indeed, when the spring

AYOT ST. LAWRENCE, England, April 3--George Bernard Shaw came to live in this tiny Hertfordshire village, which is at least nine centuries old, because it had peace, But today he might have laughed for Ayot St. Lawrence is one of the noisiest little spots in England.

Establishment next fall of a limited program of graduate studies in liberal arts at City College has been recommended by, a faculty committee headed by Dean Morton Gottschall of the College of Liberal Arts and Science.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP)-- The Department of Agriculture warned today it may have to order a cotton rationing program unless farmers produce the 16,000,000bale crop requested by the Government this year.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 4-- Lacy C. Haynes, manager of The Kansas City Star's office in Kansas City, Kan., died today at the age of 63.

Radical Deputy and Minister of State in the recent Pleven Cabinet in charge of directing France's electoral reform, died today in the American Hospital at Neuilly as a result of acute jaundice. He was 55 years old.

Booking contracts have been signed for "Angels Kiss Me," the new drama by Scott Michel, to make its New York debut at the National Theatre on Tuesday evening April 17. Trudi Michel, sponsor of the venture, has canceled the attraction's second week at Philadelphia's Walnut Theatre. Next week the offering will be brought to New York for heavy...

"The editors hope to have decided opinions on one side or the other, *** according to their individual sense of right, and they will certainly express their opinions without fear or favor, not hesitating, in any case, to call a_ spade a spade." So said the first issue of The Columbia University Spectator in 1877. This week "Spec" enters its seventy-fifth year of publication.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The Administration's Universal Military Training program faced possible defeat in the House of Representatives today as debate continued on a bill combining that longrange plan with extension and stiffening of the present military draft system.
The Pacific Western Oil Corporation shows a consolidated net income of $5,863,638 for 1950, compared with $4,973,830 in 1949.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (U.P.) The National Editorial Association told Congress today that small newspapers cannot afford more than a 30 per cent increase in their postal rates.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- Senator Robert S. Kerr, a nonbourbon Democrat from constitutionally dry Oklahoma, proposed today that cocktail parties be abolished as a Washington institution.

BOSTON, April 4--Synthesis of the central core of the complicated penicillin molecule by new methods that at last open the way to the practical synthesis of this powerful drug, which has already saved millions of lives, was reported today at the annual spring meeting of the American Chemical Society.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 4-- Pledging privileges of the Crown and Lance, a campus fraternity at Hofstra College, have been suspened as a result of over-rigorous hazing at an initiation last night.

Julian Karolyi, a 36-year-old displaced person To recently arrived in this country, gave his first Americann recital last night in Carnegie Hall. It was a recital that had a few points of interest, but it demonstrated piano playing that was inconsistent in the extreme.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Acting to assure the continued production of consumer goods in proportionate amounts for the civilian economy, despite a 20 per cent cut in the permissible use of iron and steel, the National Production Authority amended its limitation order today so that the curbs apply to small groups of closely related items.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The Senate approved today a policy of assigning American ground troops to the international force being raised in Europe for the common defense of the western world.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- The next-to-last missing witness in the Senate crime investigation, Morris (Mushy) Wexler, Cleveland gambling figure, gave himself up today.

NEW DELHI, India, April 4-- Despite repeated offers of food made by Communist China and the Soviet Union in the past week, informed parliamentary circles are inclined to regard the offers with some skepticism.

A committee representing all the voluntary hospitals here has presented to the Board of Estimate a well-documented appeal for ending a damaging injustice done to these hospitals by the city through the years. By paying the hospitals about half of what it costs to care for an indigent patient the city has been riding a good horse to death.

LONDON, April 4--The stock markets here opened in a restrained manner today after consideration of the Treasury's Economic Survey, made public today. British Government securities were subdued by the somber forecast and lost as much as 7/l6th point. Further declines were reported in dealings after hours. In other markets, however, prices threw off restraint. Indeed, in the case of some mining and rubber shares they made considerable
A man who gave away a milliondollar legacy twenty years ago for the "reality of being poor" inherited another $650,000 yesterday.

A six-room house on plot 40 by 105 feet at 62 Corbalis Place, in the Homefield section of Yonkers, Westchester County, was sold by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Heuchele, who have moved to New Hampshire, to Sara L. Muschel of the Bronx. Thomas S. Burke, Inc., was the broker.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that "freedom, human dignity and social justice" for this and future generations would depend on whether the twelve North Atlantic Treaty nations succeeded in their joint defense efforts.

Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus unfolded last night its eighty-first annual edition in Madison Square Garden amid familiar pomp and color, blare of brasses and stentorian calls to "children of all ages."

Rayon weaving mills are finding it difficult to dispose of secondquarter filament goods, according to market sources. Sales have slowed to a point where five-day operation is expected to become general. The over-all production is receding fast from recent record highs.

Stockholders of the American Tobacco Company at their annual meeting yesterday in Flemington, N. J., approved two proposals sub mitted by management, defeated two others put forward by four stockholders and elected Alfred F. Bowden as a director.

Weather permitting, all airline arrivals and departures are from La Guardia Airport unless otherwise noted. The cities below in capital letters are terminal points. With rare exceptions all inbound and outbound planes carry mail.

THE most irresponsible novel of the season, possibly of the year, is "The History of the Adventures of George Whigham and His Friend Mr. Claney Hobson,"* by Kyle Crichton. Mr. Crichton recently published a thoughtfully hilarious book about an American institution known as the Marx Brothers. You might say...
In heavy trading in cotton futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, final prices were unchanged to 90 points or $4.50 a bale lower than on Tuesday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 4--The Yugoslav Government rejected today a Hungarian note of ultimative and threatening character, and in reply, accused the Hungarian Government of seeking to create a dangerous situation.

Regulations and safety standards alone cannot prevent accidents--safety at sea or in port, in the final analysis, is in the hands of the men who maintain and sail our ships--Robert W. Williams, a member of the Federal Maritime Board, asserted yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, April 4--The United States Government has decided to turn down Britain's long-standing request for an undisclosed sum of "free dollars" that could be spent anywhere in the world to cushion British economy against the demands of rearmament.

CHICAGO, April 4--The grain markets felt the effect of a sharp break in cotton and ranged lower on the Board of Trade here today, although closing on a rally from the inside prices, which found wheat off as much as 1 cent a bushel from the previous close.

HONG KONG, April 4--An increasing percentage of agricultural exports from the Hankow area is going to the Soviet Union and Eastern Germany at the expense of Hong Kong in a general reorientation of Communist China's foreign trade. More than 300 railway stations in China are now accepting Russia-bound freight on through bills of lading under the Chinese-Soviet "through traffic" agreement signed recently in Peiping.

Air raid sirens will be tested on a neighborhood, borough and city-wide basis as soon as their installation is completed and the five borough control centers are set up, Arthur W. Wallander, Director of Civil Defense, promised yesterday.

Two new films will arrive in first-run houses today. At the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux the attraction is "Teresa," a drama presented by Metro-GoldwynMayer and starring two newcom ers, Pier Angeli and John Ericson. Fred Zinnemann directed and Arthur M. Loew produced the offering from a screen play by Stewart Stern and a story by Alfred Hayes and Mr. Stern. "Teresa" was filmed in Italy and New York:
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Swan of Newton Centre, Mass., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Grace, to Donald H. Balleisen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold L. Balleisen of Brooklyn.
Vanilla is now available in the largest quantity on record, al though retail prices, which are unchanged from a year ago, do not show it.

Carl Percy, president of Carl Percy, Inc., 450 Fourth Avenue, a window display advertising agency which he founded in 1922, died yesterday at his home, 15 Park Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 4--William H. Ruffin, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, accused organized labor's leaders tonight of "acting against the best interests of the nation's mobilization program, of all-out production, of industrial peace and of employes themselves" by demanding a Wage Stabilization Board authorized to deal with any character of industrial dispute.

Whereas the foreign policy and military strength of the United States are dedicated to the protection of our national security, the preservation of the liberties of the American people, and the maintenance of world peace; and

BRIGHTON, England, April 4-- Seven hundred British women, delgates to the National Conference of Labor Women, praised the Government today for what it has done for them so far but urged it to go even further in controlling prices and insuring fair shares of scarce materials for all.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Swan of Newton Centre, Mass., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Grace, to Donald H. Balleisen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold L. Balleisen of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Richard C. Patterson Jr., former Ambassador to Guatemala, was sworn in today as Minister to Switzerland. Associate Supreme Court Justice Stanley F. Reed, describing himself as a friend of Mr. Patterson, administered the oath.

This nation's role in defending the West against any aggression, the designation of General Eisenhower to head the North Atlantic military forces and President Truman's decision to send four divisions to Europe were approved by the Senate yesterday, 69 to 21. A resolution

WASHINGTON, April 4--New charges concerning the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and said to involve "big names" were presented in closed session today to the Senate subcommittee investigating influence and favoritism in the operations of the lending agency. The charges will be in

WASHINGTON, April 4--Speaker Sam Rayburn implied during debate in the House of Representatives today that the Soviet Union was massing troops in Manchuria and that the beginning of World War III might be near.

LONDON, April 4--For some time now British diplomatic and military quarters have been hearing rumors of troop concentrations in Manchuria similar to those mentioned by Speaker Rayburn in Washington today.

Fewer fur auctions, as advocated by the Mink Traders Association, would cause a glut of merchandise in the market and would prove detrimental to fur breeders, Sydney Murley, president of Lampson, Fraser Huth, Inc., fur auctioneers, asserted yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Earle Anderson Webster of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Earle Webster, to Richard Ober, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Ober of Scarsdale, N. Y. The wedding took place Saturday in the Presbyterian Church of Rockville, Md.

MADRID, April 4--Generalissimo Francisco Franco has issued a decree that all applications to share in the current United States credit of $62,500,000 to Spain must pass first through the Ministry of industry and Commerce and then the Ministry of Finance. This gives to Minister of Industry and Commerce Juan Antonio Suanzes a large measure of control over all the projects submitted.

EL PASO, Tex., April 4--Mickey Mantle, Yankees' rookie outfielder, boosted his batting average to 462 with three hits in four times at bat today as the Bombers routed the' Class C El Paso Texans, 16 to 10. In the Yankees' assortment of twenty-three hits were six homers and as many doubles. Mantle walloped a home run and a twobagger.

EL PASO, Tex., April 4--Mickey Mantle, Yankees' rookie outfielder, boosted his batting average to 462 with three hits in four times at bat today as the Bombers routed the' Class C El Paso Texans, 16 to 10. In the Yankees' assortment of twenty-three hits were six homers and as many doubles. Mantle walloped a home run and a twobagger.

E. W. Berger has been advanced to a new post as assistant to the vice president in charge of sales of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation. He joined the organization a year ago as assistant general sales manager.

Motor vehicle accidents are causing an average of five deaths and 400 injuries a day in this state, Commissioner Clifford J. Fletcher of the Motor Vehicle-Bureau said yesterday at the annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council. Property damage from the same cause last year was estimated by him at $572,700,000, or $18,000,000 above the 1949 total.

AN increase in the winter waterfowl census, coupled with the assurance of an unusually fine run-off on the great Canadian breeding and nesting grounds, offers the promise of a good duck season next fall.

BONN, Germany, April 4--Jean Monnet, Director of the French Planning Commission, arrived here today. His arrival coincided with growing German agitation about the role of the Saar in the Schuman plan and a vigorous debate over the rights of labor in the coal and steel industries marked for participation in the West European heavy industry pool.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4--Twelve Asian and Arab countries tomorrow will begin the first of a series of caucuses aimed at finding a formula for opening talks between the United Nations and the Chinese Communists and ending the Korean war.

PATCHOGUE, L. L., April 4-- R. Ford Hughes, Suffolk County Clerk and an intraparty opponent of W. Kingsland Macy, was chosen at a meeting here tonight as the recognized leader of the Republican organization of Suffolk County. Mr. Macy, recognized as the Republican leader in the county for twenty-five years, recently has been subjected to adverse criticism by members of the party.

TUXEDO, N.Y., April 5-- Through traffic was halted all day on the main line of the Erie Railroad as the result of a wreck at 5:10 A.M. today when twenty-four cars n the center of a 134-car freight train left the ...
A scheme by which ex-servicemen had to buy stock in a nonexistent corporation so they could learn the printing trade was exposed yesterday by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

CLEVELAND, April 5--The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., rejected proposals that it seek to form a third party at once and decided tonight at its convention here to urge the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations ...

Chief Justice Irving Ben Cooper of the Court of Special Sessions urged the New York County Lawyers Association yesterday to back his efforts to get more city ffunds for follow-up work with youthful offenders.
MIAMI, April 5 (AP)--Sugar Ray Robinson pounded out a ten-round unanimous decision over Holly Mims of Washington, D.C., tonight in his first fight since winning the middleweight championship.

CHICAGO, April 5--The grain markets were under pressure here early today after reports of rain over a large part of the western and southwestern winter wheat belt, but a strong rally came later and the close was irregular, with wheat off 3/8 to cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The Defense Transport Administration said today it expected improvement in the size and caliber of the rail freight car fleet as its program for new cars and repairs gets further along. There is a current shortage of cars.

MERRICK, L.I., April 5--Caution exercised by an alert Long Island Rail Road engineman averted a possible derailment of an eleven-car commuter train by a broken rail here this morning. There were 350 passengers aboard the train.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5--The Arab and Asian delegations, who have been inactive as a group since their peace bid failed last January, met again today to discuss a new effort to end the Korean war.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 5--The Israeli Air Force late today bombed Syrian Army fortified positions within Syria in "retaliatory action" for the Syrian attacks yesterday on Israeli police in the demilitarized zone southeast of the Sea of Galilee.

In response to the urging of Judge Harold R. Medina for some scaling down of the Government's anti-trust bill of complaint against seventeen investment banking concerns, Government counsel yesterday agreed to curtail six allegations.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP)-- Government production officials admitted today they gave steel concerns almost half a billion dollars in tax concessions without checking the facts in the cases--a revelation that drew charges of "stupidity" from Congressional investigators.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5--George Fazio of Conshohocken, Pa., one of the trio involved in the play-off for the 1950 United States Open title at Marion last June, took the lead in the opening round of the fifteenth Masters tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club today with a par-shattering 68.

The American military machine has already been set in motion to send additional troops to Europe to reinforce the defenses of the North Atlantic alliance. One Regular Army division is scheduled to sail within a month, another within two months; two National Guard divisions are to follow during the summer and early fall.

Uncertainty concerning the international situation continued to confuse the commodity markets yesterday. These have had a tendency, especially since the first of the year, to move upward with world tensions, down with every ray of hope.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Former Representative Joseph E. Casey, Democrat of Massachusetts, has asked that a date be set for his appearance before a Senate investigating subcommittee for questioning on a surplus Government ship deal.

SAN ANTONIO, April 5--Feeling pessimistic and optimistic by turns, Casey Stengel led his Yankees into this city for a game in which they beat the San Antonio Missions, 13--10, tonight before an overflow crowd of 11,807 that sent the Bombers' exhibition attendance soaring to 206,830.

HONG KONG, April 5--Sovietmanufactured military equipment, including planes and trucks, has been entering Manchuria at an accelerated rate to lend muscle to a Korean front build-up involving elements of four Chinese Communist field armies, according to reports reaching official quarters here.
BRIGHTON, England, April 5-- Uncle Sam and Gen. Douglas MacArthur were the whipping boys today at the final session of the National Conference of Labor Women.
Combined resources of the state supervised banking system of the United States, Hawaii and Puerto Rico rose $5,300,000,000 last year, raising total assets to $94,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Quick passage of a defense housing bill by the Senate became assured today as the Republicans, a minority by only two votes, announced they would take no party stand in basic opposition to the measure.
James Melton, the gentleman of the tenor voice and the collection of old automobiles, unveiled his own television program at 9 o'clock last night on Channel 4.

In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, Miss Dorothy Constance Whalen, daughter of Municipal Court Justice Thomas J. Whalen and Mrs. Whalen of 131 Riverside Drive, was married to John William Campo, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Campo of Forest Hills, Queens.
BUENOS AIRES, April 5 (AP)-- Alberto Caprile, publisher and president of the board of La Nacion, independent Buenos Aires newspaper, died early today of a heart attack. He was 79 years old.
AT the ninth hole of the final round Jimmy Demaret paused to study the score board. He shrugged his shoulders and grinned.
MELBOURNE, April 5 (AP)-- Australia, which won out in spirited bidding with other countries for the 1956 Olympic Games, may give up the great international sports carnival after all.

Bank loans to business resumed their climb last week, rising $3,000,000 after a decline of $13,000,000 in the previous week. The latest rise in business credits by New York City banks sent the total expansion since the first of this year to $534,000,000, compared with a decline of $61,000,000 in the similar period of last year.
CLEVELAND, April 5 (AP)--Private industry is showing "gradually awakening interest in isotopes" as materials which have commercial value, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission said tonight.

The Elise Young Gallerie, a shop that houses a collection of lamps as part of its wares, will open today at 4 East Sixty-fifth Street. Chandeliers, fabrics, antique furniture and accessories are also on view.

Everyone knows that "The Green Pastures" abounds with miracles of faith that have influenced mankind through the ages. But now the Pulitzer Prize play faces a crisis and finds itself needing a miracle to stave off the prospective closing April 14 at the ...

Several carpet manufacturers will reduce production before the end of the second quarter because of a falling off in retail orders. This was predicted yesterday by an executive of one of the largest mills in the country.

Institutional advertising promises in the near future to become almost as important, if not more important, than the standard task of product promotion, D.W. Figgis, chairman of the board of the American Can Company, said last night.

Eighty-seven new patrolmen, having finished their probationary period that started last Feb. 1, were graduated from the Police Academy yesterday at ceremonies in the Police Headquarters gymnasium, 240 Centre Street.

Calling for the end of racial and religious discrimination in private summer camps, Lillian Smith, author of "Strange Fruit" and a former camp director, asserted yesterday that minority discrimination in this country was hurting the United States in its ideological war against communism.

The United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce took issue yesterday with a recent United Nations master plan for combating global unemployment, contending that it fostered economic nationalism and losses of freedom and efficiency.

SINGAPORE, April 5--The Communist-led insurgent Vietnamese movement in Indo-China is regarded by political observers here as having, achieved a more typical Communist program and system of organization as a result of the recent reshaping of the insurgent political groups and the restatement of their plans and objectives.

J.I. Case Company, farm equipment manufacturer, is confronted with a critical shortage of material which could affect production, Theodore Johnson, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday. Sales are moving along at a satisfactory level, he said.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)-- Battle-weary veterans from Korea will start "rotating" home this month, to be replaced at the front by fresh troops from the United States.

In its first change of ownership in twenty-five years, the twelve-story loft building at 56 and 58 West Twenty-second Street was sold by an estate to the 56 West Twenty-second Street Corporation in a deal negotiated by Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers ...
PARIS, April 5--By 263 votes to 251, the French National Assembly today adopted on its first reading a bill for revising the nation's electoral system.

NICE, France, April 5 (AP)--Fred Kovaleski of Detroit confirmed today that he, Irvin Dorfman of New York and Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., have been ordered home by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

PARIS, April 5--Deputies of the Big Four powers dispensed with their official meeting today but talked informally and long at a luncheon given by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, at the Soviet Embassy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5-- Two new properties, a 1950 English novel by Roger Bax, "Two If By Sea," and a comedy written for the screen by Ira Avery, "Twenty-one Days," have been acquired by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)-- With a new appeal for quick settlement, the Senate Labor Committee today tentatively closed its public inquiry into the long dispute between the railroads and four labor unions.

The annual report of Textron Incorporated issued yesterday shows a 1950 net profit of $3,141,658 on sales of $87,546,886, in contrast to the $1,693,922 loss in 1949 although sales totaled $67,896,029.

LONDON, April 5--Britain's gold and dollar reserves are still rising. Hugh Gaitskell, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today that they amounted to $3,758,000,000 on March 31, a rise of $458,000,000 since Dec. 31.
Fear of a war in Europe has had a depressing effect on travel to Scandinavia, according to Svein Winge Simonsen, director of the Norwegian National Travel office in New York.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York adopted a resolution yesterday urging Congress to consider legislation to wipe out the "five per center" evil in government contract negotiation.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York has rejected the request of Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, for an investigation of any relationship between organized crime and the selection of judicial candidates by Tammany during Mr. DeSapio's leadership.

A $750,000 swindle of two New York banks and a half-dozen commercial factors and business concerns was unearthed yesterday through the arrest of a 49-year-old general insurance broker who admitted perpetrating the frauds over a three-year period.
WASHINGTON, April 5--During the week ended April 4 member bank reserves increased $118,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 5--A group of civilian medical consultants to the Air Force who this morning returned from Korea described the swift air evacuation of the wounded as the "most remarkable" development in combat medicine.

A tendency to oversimplify the problems of multiracial countries is assuming dangerous aspects and can result in "embarrassment to the Western world," Ambassador Gerhardus P. Jooste of the Union of South Africa declared last night.
Thurgood Marshall, special counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was cited yesterday at a luncheon in his honor as "America's outstanding civil rights lawyer."

WASHINGTON, April 5--Labor leaders, at President Truman's persuasion, returned to the defense program today at the topmost level--the National Advisory Board on Mobilization Policy. They said that they hoped this would lead to labor peace with all mobilization agencies.
WASHINGTON, April 5--President Truman acclaimed today the Senate's endorsement of his plan to send four American divisions to Europe to aid in the West's common defense.

Several dinner parties will be given in advance and supper parties after the performance of "The Moon Is Blue" tomorrow night at the Henry Miller Theatre, which has been taken over to augment the Finch Junior College Building Fund.
MIAMI, Fla., April 5 (AP)--The National Conference of State Liquor Administrators unanimously adopted a resolution today opposing any increase in Federal excise taxes on alcoholic beverages.
WASHINGTON, April 5--The United States Government is mounting a powerful mediumwave radio station on a fast oceangoing freighter for use in its "campaign of truth" against the Communist world.

Louis Levy, retired president of the Model Brassiere Company, died yesterday at the age of 100 in his home at 320 West End Avenue.
PARIS, April 5--The fact that West Germany was expected to show a favorable balance of about $10,000,000 in the European Payments Union for March has injected an optimistic element into ...
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)-- The Government extended today its retail margin-type price control to about 76,000 additional retail stores doing about $7,000,000,000 in consumer goods sales annually.

DETROIT, April 5 (U.P.)--The Montreal Canadiens roared from behind to drub the favored Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 2, tonight and sweep within one game of winning the Stanley Cup semi-finals playoff series.

MOSCOW, April 5--There was nothing in today's budget of Soviet news from the Far East to indicate that any new or startling developments were expected in that quarter of the world nor has there been anything but routine news reports from that region published by the Moscow press in the last month or so.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The Consolidated Natural Gas Company of New York filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for $50,000,000 of debentures due 1976. The securities are to be sold at competitive bidding.

OTTAWA, April 5--President Vincent Auriol of France and French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman arrived in Ottawa this morning from New York and will spend four days in Canada before returning to France by air on Monday. President Auriol will visit Toronto, Montreal and Quebec.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman, mild-mannered, soft-spoken but sharp in detecting legal trickery by attorneys, is the youngest jurist in the Southern District of New York.

ALBANY, April 5--Although income and business taxes failed to produce as much as in the previous year, the State Government's total revenue for the fiscal year that ended last Saturday was $24,392,288 higher than that for the 194950 fiscal year.
Television programs presented in darkened rooms are a danger to children's eyesight, Miss Mildred C. Sommer, assistant to the secretary of Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., said yesterday.

Bill McCarthy's thirtieth season as baseball coach at New York University was appropriately recognized yesterday with a pregame ceremony at Ohio Field's home plate, where the veteran mentor was handed a watch.

WASHINGTON, April 5--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur favors a Nationalist second front on China's mainland and is convinced that the fate of Europe will be decided in the war against communism in Asia.
The Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee has reported favorably two bills that would bring Alaska and Hawaii into the Union, where they logically belong.
Cotton futures market prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregularly yesterday, 17 points lower to 24 points higher than on Wednesday. Trading continued fairly active.

Fashion has burst into bloom in a riot of flowers, Not only are they tucked in decolletages, pinned at lapels and worn at waistlines. They are sprayed low on skirts, clustered at hemlines and caught in the folds of puffed sleeves.

The Senate's grudging approval of the dispatch of four more United States divisions to Germany coincides with the movement of the thirty Soviet divisions in East Germany into the field for their annual training.
A good budget-wise dinner menu for the week-end, based on market reports, totals $2.60 for four or 65 cents a person.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, is indulging in some new loose inflammatory talk in a familiar vein. While asserting that he and his union are trying to restrain impetuous followers he is actually, whether intending it or not, fomenting strike sentiment among transit workers.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that the city's public school system would be "severely hurt next year" if the cuts in the education allocations made in Mayor Impellitteri's executive budget were permitted to stand.

The Women's Tri-County Golf Association, organized last December by a group of ardent women golfers from Westchester, who wanted more competition in their district, will have one tournament a month starting June 6.

One of the few remaining mideighteenth century building in the city, the Van Cortlandt Museum in Van Cortlandt Park at 242d Street just off Broadway, still stands in the spreading acres of two centuries ago.

BONN, Germany, April 5-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared before the Bundestag today that the percentage of German war criminals was "so low and so small" that the "honor of German soldiers is not damaged in the least."

WASHINGTON, April 5--John Maragon, convicted last April of perjury in connection with the Senate "five per center" investigations, probably will be called to testify before a House Expenditures subcommittee investigating war surplus sales.

BOSTON, April 5--A new type of solar still to produce fresh water from sea water, promising to lead to a solution of the problem of supplying fresh water to arid, tropical lands at an economical cost, was described today at the closing sessions of the annual spring meeting of the American Chemical Society.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The twenty-one American republics completed approval early tonight of a set of declarations that affirmed their solidarity in the face of international communism, their ties to the United Nations and their desires to adjust their economies to both their emergency needs and their long-term aspirations.

Women in England "are getting extremely restive with continued shortages and the continual rise in prices," Lady Reading declared here yesterday.
HOUSTON, April 5--The Giants launched their traditional spring series with the Indians today slightly in reverse.

United States Industrial Chemicals, Inc., will be merged into the National Distillers Products Corporation, subject to approval by stockholders of the two companies at meetings to be held early in June.

HONOLULU, April 5--Minority opposition was expressed for the first time today during the fourth day of the biennial convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union as some members vigorously protested the section of the officers' report on the war crisis and the American economy.

In a history-making action, Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman imposed death sentences yesterday on two spies convicted of stealing the atomic bomb secret for Soviet Russia and sentenced a third spy to thirty years in a Federal penitentiary.

Arnold S. Askin, president of the New York Association for New Americans, a beneficiary of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, reported last night that his organization spent $16,526,267 in providing assistance to 38,000 Jewish immigrants who arrived here in the last two years and settled in New York.

Leonard Rose, solo 'cellist of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra since 1944, will be leaving the ensemble at the season's end, for a concert career, and his appearance as soloist in two works at Carnegie Hall last night was in the nature of a public farewell.

Plans to increase capital funds of the Public National Bank and Trust Company of New York by about $6,000,000, through the sale of 151,250 additional shares to stockholders, were announced yesterday.

America's oldest hospital for the care of the chronic ill, St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases, marked its eighty-fifth birthday yesterday by starting something new. It completed plans for a psychiatric unit, believed to be the first in an institution of this kind.

NEWARK, April 5--Miss Rosine Madeleine Snyder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Frederick Snyder of New York, was married here to William Gregory Hetherington, foreign correspondent of The Newark News, this morning in City Hall, with Mayor Ralph A. Villani officiating.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan started yesterday a grand jury inquiry into the financial activities of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
WASHINGTON, April 5--Consumers face the prospect of higher prices for suits and other garments made of woolen fabrics as the result of action today by the Office of Price Stabilization.
TRENTON, April 5 (AP)--The Trenton Six murder trial recessed today when one of the defendants became ill.
EDGEWATER, N.J., April 5-- The most venturesome of the shad have started their spawning run up the Hudson River, the big schools being due within a few days.
TODAY, 3:30 P.M.: "Legend of Aspara," dance-drame of IndoChina by Mara Co., American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at Seventy-ninth Street. Tickets 60-90 cents.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Former Senator Millard E. Tydings, Maryland Democrat, today filed with the Senate a formal complaint that his opponent, Senator John Marshall Butler, Republican, violated state and Federal laws in his victorious campaign last November.
The cost of feeding a New York family went down a little last month.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, instructed all school principals yesterday to give complete and accurate information to newspaper reporters even on matters involving an "unpleasant incident" in a school.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 5-- John Marshall, Yale's aquatic marvel from Australia, ripped off the fastest time ever recorded for the 1,500-meter free-style event tonight as the National Athletic Union indoor swimming championships got under way in the Ohio State University natorium.

ALBANY, April 5--A record $300,000,000 is available for Work during the current fiscal year on New York's highway system, much of which has been severly damaged by winter weather, it was reported today by Bertram D. Tallamy, State Superintendent of Public Works.

"Riptide," a French-made drama, starring Gerard Philipe, which was shown on the continent as "Une Si Jolie Petite Plage," opens today at the Art Theatre on Eighth Street. Madeleine Robinson, Jane Marken and Mona Dol are among the featured players.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)-- John L. Rogers, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, acknowledged today the commission might have been wrong in approving a reorganization plan for the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railroad in 1944.

Dow Chemical Company plans to spend in its 1952 fiscal year somewhat more than the $65,000,000 expended on plant expansion in the current fiscal year, ending May 31. Leland I. Doan, president, declared yesterday that this may involve some new financing later on.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 5-- Emanuel M. Spiegel of New Brunswick, president of the New Jersey Home Builders Association, urged here today that New Jersey be designated as a critical defense area.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 5 --The firm belief of a country parson that international misunderstandings can be combatted on the personal level bore fruit today in the little town of Chester, a rural community of Morris County, about forty-two miles west of New York.
LONDON, April 5 (AP)--The jail house door clanged shut today on "Little Arthur" Clinton, a race track tout who couldn't pick a loser.

Prodded by renewed emphasis on the threat of a great danger in the present international situation, the stock market scored its widest gains of the year yesterday with a marked expansion in business.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 5 (UP)--The Czechoslovak Ambassadors to the United States, Britain and France, now here "for consultations," have been "purged" and will not return to their posts, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 5--President Truman asked Congress today for an additional $6,421,681,000 to support the expanded armed forces in the next three months and to keep in motion the industrial machinery turning out the arms and equipment for 3,462,000 servicemen.
ALBANY, April 5--The state prosecutor in the investigation of any gambling or political corruption in Saratoga County asserted today that a search for indictable crime would be his main goal.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 5--Dr. Francis Russell Bichowsky, research chemist and one-time University of California lecturer, died today at an Alameda County Sanitarium. He was 52 years old.
Chicago, Ill., announced yesterday that it will receive bids April 20 on $5,000,000 of water revenue certificates dated May 1, 1951, and due May 1, 1967 to 1969.

ALTHOUGH the majority of the trout waters within a hundred-mile radius of the city now flow high and discolored, it is rain and now snow water brimming their banks, so anglers still have a chance of finding better than fair conditions a week from tomorrow.

An unfortunate aspect of the long delay on a grant of food grain for India is the clouding of the basic issue by a number of extraneous considerations. Much damage has already been done and the United States must act immediately if it is to be repaired.

The Quartermaster Procurement Agency will be compelled to take up the problems of pricing hardships before manufacturers of textiles, apparel and shoes can make further bids on many items, it was pointed out by suppliers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5--President Truman said today that the danger of a third world war was just as great as it ever had been but indicated that there had been no recent develop- ments to warrant new alarm.

EAST LANSING, Mich., April 5 (AP)--Two of last year's champions and a couple of lads who are figured as possible champions, stirred up the long opening day of the National Collegiate Athletic Association boxing tournament today.

Sheldon Weiner, a 17-year-old stage-struck Brooklyn high school student, who had stowed away on board the British liner Queen Mary when she last sailed from New York, was held under guard yesterday in Southampton harbor.

TOKYO, Friday, April 6--The United Nations offensive rolled deeper into North Korea yesterday, with elements of four United States and two South Korean divisions and of a British brigade across the Thirty-eighth Parallel, old boundary between the Korean Republic and the northern Communist state.
