JACKSONVILLE, April 5--The Phils and Dodgers concluded their spring series at City Park today, the Brooks winning, 5--4, in ten innings, before a crowd of 7,973, greatest attendance in the history of the local park.

The proposed local law to increase the city sales tax to 3 per cent beginning May 1 is expected to be passed by the City Council next week by a comfortable margin above the required majority of thirteen votes. It was predicted yesterday that nineteen of the twenty-five Council members would vote for the measure, despite the current storm of opposition from merchants, business men, labor organizations and civic groups.

JACKSONVILLE, April 5--The Phils and Dodgers concluded their spring series at City Park today, the Brooks winning, 5--4, in ten innings, before a crowd of 7,973, greatest attendance in the history of the local park.

The proposed local law to increase the city sales tax to 3 per cent beginning May 1 is expected to be passed by the City Council next week by a comfortable margin above the required majority of thirteen votes. It was predicted yesterday that nineteen of the twenty-five Council members would vote for the measure, despite the current storm of opposition from merchants, business men, labor organizations and civic groups.
ALBANY, April 5--Governor Dewey signed today three measures aimed at the illegal narcotics traffic.

WASHINGTON, April 6--Led by Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, a large Congressional bloc prepared today to put up a strong fight for doubling the size of the Marine Corps. The corps is now approaching 200,000 men and by present plans is to be permitted to reach a strength ceiling of 206,000.
ROME, April 6--Pope Pius XII praised today the principle of world government as a means to establish peace and bring about collaboration among all the nations for the common good of mankind.

EAST LANSING, Mich., April 6 (AP)--Idaho's three-man team moved into a commanding position in the National Collegiate A.A. boxing championships tonight when Frankie Echeverria, Len Walker and Larry Moyer all won their semi-final bouts.
TOKYO, Saturday, April 7--The Communist invaders pulled back in a surprise withdrawal along much of the western front in Korea yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, April 7--On both sides of the Mississippi River in this area the most hotly debated questions are whether the public is on an emotional binge as a result of revelations by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee and, if so, how long will it last?
Leonard G. Feinen, architect, has completed plans for Wright Village, 578-unit low-rent garden apartment project for defense workers in Lodi, N. J.

NICE, France, April 8 (AP)--Sven Davidsson, rising Swedish tennis star, staged a stirring rally today to defeat Straight Clark, Los Angeles, 6--3, 1--6, 3--6, 7--5, 6--2, and win the men's singles in the Nice international tennis tournament.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8-- Barbara Stanwyck has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the chief feminine role in "The Man With the Cloak," in which she will appear with Joseph Cotton, Louis Calhern and Leslie Caron.

ALBANY, April 8--Governor Dewey signed a bill today that would bring the state an estimated $500,000 a year in additional revenue by making interstate bus lines subject to the existing 2 per cent utility tax on gross receipts for the milage they travel within the state.

ON THE CENTRAL KOREAN FRONT, April 8--With no negotiations under way--as far as he knew--for a cease-fire and with the Chinese ignoring approaches by the United Nations for a settlement, a "diplomatic stalemate" is a future possibility in Korea, Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway said today.
ROME, April 8--The seventh national congress of the Italian Communist party ended this morning in an atmosphere of widespread boredom and apathy.

HANOI, Indo-China, April 8 (AP) --French Army headquarters here said today Chinese troops--probably Communist irregulars--invaded Northwest Indo-China last week in battalion strength and seized two border towns. French troops airlifted to the area failed, however, to establish contact with the invaders and aerial observers found no trace of them.
WASHINGTON, April 8--The anti-Moscow Communist Government of Yugoslavia has informally requested weapons and military equipment from the United States, Britain and France.

SINGAPORE, April 8--Establishment of a destination control over rubber exports from Malaya with a view to curbing excess shipments to Communist countries has added additional fuel to the fires of resentment against the United States smoldering among Britons and Asians here. When the Stone of Scone was stolen from London's Westminster Abbey on Christmas Day it was a foregone conclusion that Scotland Yard would be put on the job and would eventually come up with the culprits. That they have is evidenced by the stories in the newspapers a few days ago.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 (AP)-- The four best-known women professionals of present-day golf were elected to the women's golf Hall of Fame today by the board of selectors for the hall.

WASHINGTON, April 8--A crippled B-25 bomber, abandoned by its crew of three, smashed in flames into a suburban cottage today, killing two little girls and their uncle. The twin engine bomber had been headed toward the Chesapeake Bay before the three crewmen parachuted to safety from an altitude of 4,000 feet.
The just-concluded meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the twenty-one American republics had its difficulties. There were some issues beneath the surface that contributed moments of tension.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 8 --Nineteen West Virginia airmen, most of whom lived here, were killed today when an Air Force plane bringing them home as a funeral escort for a fellow flier crashed and burned in fog while attempting to land.

ST. JAMES, L.I., April 8-- Black Prince of Sag Harbor, a 4 year-old retriever owned by Mrs. Gerald M. Livingston of Huntington, today won the open all-age stake that was the main event of the spring trials of the Women's Field Trial Club.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 8--Information received by the Dutch Government that the White House is considering the appointment of Mrs. Perle Mesta, Ambassador to Luxembourg, as Ambassador to the Netherlands has created a flutter here.
Plastic decorating fabrics, which apparently are permanent additions to the home furnishings stocks of many stores, have been improved in styling and quality in the last year.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 8-- Improvement was evident in the play of the New York Knickerbockers tonight, but what there was of it proved insufficient to even the score with the Rochester Royals in the best-of-seven series to determine that National Basketball Association championship. The Royals went 2 up on Joe Lapchick's men with a 99--84 triumph that was not quite as top-heavy as the score might hint, but convincing nevertheless.

The Philadelphia Americans triumphed over the New York Americans by 4--1 in the Lewis Cup soccer game at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday. The victory was the second for the Philadelphians in the series.

HOUSTON, April 8--Young Tom Morgan, who had pitched twentyfive innings without yielding an earned run, lost his wizardry today as the Yankees tangled with the St. Louis Cardinals farm link, the Houston Buffs.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 8--To bolster Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's political position, the Western Allies are prepared to publish, a "statement of intentions" outlining new political and economic relaxations in the West German state by the occupying powers.

Aesop's fables had a real-life illustration yesterday as 4,000 children led their parents and friends a chase throughout the Children's Zoo in the Bronx Zoo. The parents were the turtles of the fable and the children were the hares as they toured the lilliputian animal village that occupies nearly a third of an acre in the larger zoo.
Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy has withdrawn his objection to a study of his department's administrative and personnel set-up.

Ingrid Rypinski, mezzo-soprano, gave a recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The first half of her program was devoted to German Lieder by Schubert, Mahler and Strauss. She was heard later in Debussy's "Proses lyriques" and a final group of songs of Israel.

CHICAGO, April 8--Demand for farm machinery has been holding at a high level at a time when manufacturers have experienced difficulty in obtaining supplies, industry sources said today. The situation was emphasized last week by a production slash by the International Harvester Company.

TOKYO, Monday, April 9-- United Nations troops stormed to the south bank of the big Hwachon Reservoir yesterday and other units dug in for the night below the city of Hwachon, one of the enemy's main bases on the central Korean front.

The British people do not flinch from facing harsh facts, and it is to the credit of the Labor Government that it has never painted a rosier picture of the future than the facts warrant. Calls for summer merchandise were received in most wholesale markets here last week, with some emphasis noted on graduation and party dresses and formals in organdy and organza, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
The Canadian dollar was under pressure last week, selling down to 94.75 cents, which matched the year's lowest made Jan. 24; the close was 94.82 cents, a loss of 7/16 cent from the preceding week.

WHEN Jimmy Dykes rejoined the Philadelphia Athletics a couple of years ago he was the junior coach. He was always very respectful to Al Simmons, who outranked him in seniority. That is to say, he was always respectful to Big Sim whenever he remembered the difference in rank. Frankly, it wasn't too often.

The outstanding art event of the week, opening Wednesday, will be the Museum of Modern Art's large retrospective showing of work by Modigliani. Other outstanding oneman shows include paintings by Willem de Kooning, opening today at the Egan Gallery, tomorrow's presentation of sculpture by Theodore Roszak at the Matisse Gallery and recent paintings by Arthur Osver at Grand Central Moderns.
ATLANTA, April 8--Kirby Higbe, who won twenty-two games for the Dodgers in their pennant year of 1941, today pitched nine innings to beat them, 8--6.
The most extensive investigation of the narcotics problem ever ordered in New York State will be opened today by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.
VIENNA, April 8--The Soviet Union not only is drawing on its satellites for slave labor for itself, but has begun moving political prisoners from one satellite into another.

Concern over the refusal of the Good Neighbor Federation to give the New York City Youth Board a renewal of its dollar-a-year lease on the Community Center at 115 East 106th Street was expressed yesterday by some of the city's leading social work and welfare authorities.

AMSTERDAM, April 8--Recent economic and monetary developments are reflected in the marked rise in the premium on American securities over New York parities to about 12 per cent against about 3 per cent at the beginning of the year.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7--Ben Hogan, the man who came back last June to win the United States Open Golf championship after they said he would never play again, captured the Masters tourney over the picturesque Augusta National course today with a 72-hole score of 280.

Recent developments in Iran, where nationalization of petroleum resources is threatened, makes necessary the immediate further exploitation of the oil resources of the continental shelf, Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Senator from Wyoming, declares in a letter to State Governors he made public last week.

The National Defense reserve fleet has been reduced to 1,764 vessels, the lowest point since the peak in May, 1950, the Maritime Administration reported yesterday. A still lower level will be reached within a few months with the withdrawal of more ships for military duty, Marshall Plan cargoes for Europe and the proposed food program for India.
With the exception of the nearby May delivery, cotton futures in the domestic market weakened in the first half of the past week, but erased some of their losses later.

When the Brooklyn Dodgers and Philadelphia Phillies open the National League season at Ebbets Field on Tuesday, April 17, WMGM will broadcast the contest beginning at 1:25 P.M. Walter (Red) Barber, Connie Desmond and Vince Scully will describe the Dodgers' games again this season. Games at Ebbets Field will be televised over Channel 9.

PITTSBURGH, April 8--The steel rate last week sagged a point to 102.5 per cent of rated capacity. That decline was in no way significant of any lessening in steel demand. It was no more or less than a usual fluctuation that can be expected as long as the rate is above 100 per cent.

BALDWINVILLE, Mass., April 8--On a hill overlooking this quiet town in central Massachusetts, a former children's hospital is serving as the first American home for stateless families newly arrived from Europe.

David Bronstein, challenger for the world championship at chess, last night succeeded in equalizing the score by defeating the champion, Mikhail Botvinnik, in the eleventh game of their series in Moscow after a hard-fought struggle.
MADRID, April 8--Roman Catholic leaders in Spain are giving powerful moral support to the workers in their demands for better living conditions.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 8 (AP)-- M.I.T.'s-Vigilant sailed to victory today in the MacMillan Cup races. The M.I.T. yawl, piloted by Howard Fawcett, ran second today behind Harvard, but its two-day total of 21 points took the trophy.

Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India has urged firmness tempered with a "spirit of friendliness and conciliation" but no appeasement of "evil" as a basis for approaches to settlement of international disagreements.

The Foreign Ministers of twenty-one American nations, including the United States Secretary of State, ended a twoweek conference in Washington last Saturday. They were called together to deal with a world emergency.
Children left in the care of baby-sitters were among several persons rescued early yesterday morning in fires in South Brooklyn and Bath Beach.
In response to recent urgent appeals for increased Blood donations, employes of 100 insurance companies have scheduled donor appointments with the Red Cross for the last two weeks of April.

President Truman's recent executive order granting draft deferments to college students of superior scholastic standing was denounced yesterday by two of the nation's leading educators as bad for the country, the colleges and the young men themselves.

United Nations forces have closed in on Hwachon, a main enemy base eight miles above the Thirty-eighth Parallel in Korea. Other sectors were relatively quiet. [1:8; maps P. 2.] The Communists "don't go home" and they "won't call this thing off," Lieutenant General Ridgway...

WASHINGTON, April 8--Fear was expressed, freely in Government circles today that the House of Representatives Appropriation Committee's slash of civil defense funds from $403,000,000 requested to $186,750,000 might cripple the program.
Hellenic-American societies celebrated the 130th anniversary of Greek independence yesterday with a Fifth Avenue parade that portrayed the colorful story of Greece's history.
The ghost of Diamond Jim Brady might well have paused last night to mark a nostalgic date on the calendar yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 8--Harry Salinger, retired vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago, died today, after a two-month illness, in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 68 years old.
Just a century ago "The Paris Fantastic Tales of Hoff in mann" became the spiritual '51 possession of a young 'cel list and composer of Paris, Jacques Offenbach.
TOKYO, April 8--A Soviet commander or a Soviet general staff may be masterminding the Chinese campaign in Korea, some experienced United States officers here have now come to believe.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has told Senators that a "hard core" of sabotage-trained Communists is ready to strike at vital industries if war comes.

Controlling interest in the twelve-story office and showroom building at 9-11 East Thirtyeighth Street, running through to 16 East Thirty-ninth Street, has been purchased through Williams Co., brokers, by a textile executive whose company will occupy large space in the structure.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 8-- Arthur Knapp guided the Agony to victory for the sixth time this season and the third in four weeks as the curtain closed on the Larchmont Yacht Club's frostbite dinghy competition today. However, unofficial computation of percentages for the spring series indicates that Bobby De Coppet, skipper of Zotom, had sufficient points to ton Knapp for the title.

Applications for day-care services for children have increased in key cities in the last five months at rates ranging from 10 to 166 per cent, the Child Welfare League of America reported yesterday. Latest figures indicate that for every child now in a day-care center there is at least one more on a waiting list.

Good-natured travesty was the predominant note of the entertainment furnished by the cast of "South Pacific" at a party held early yesterday morning at the Astor Hotel to celebrate the second Broadway anniversary of the musical.

Favorites among all American women are prints. They bloom with particular vigor in spring and summer for then they seem to form a part of the gay picture presented by these seasons. They bring enchanting colors with them.
ST. PAUL, April 8 (AP)--A Detroit bowler moved into the lead today in singles competition of the American Bowling Congress. Clarence Marshall rolled a 664 on games of 206, 213 and 245.

CAIRO, April 8--Sir Ralph Stevenson, British Ambassador to Egypt, returned to Cairo tonight, ready to resume arduous negotiations here for revision of the 1936 British-Egyptian treaty.

The current controversy between Israel and Syria was termed by Benjamin G. Browdy, president of the Zionist Organization of America, yesterday "an incident in the age-old struggle between civilization and the desert."
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that the Democrats were making it easy for the Republicans to win next year's elections.

Michel Chauveton, 21-year-old French violinist who made his local recital debut last night in Town Hall, is a musician of high attainment. He played a respectable program before an attentive audience with first-rate assistance from Brooks Smith at the piano. But his promise is still to be fulfilled.

Music of H.A. Schimmerling and Montague Cantor was displayed at Saturday evening's Composers' Forum in Columbia University's McMillin Theatre. Both men, singers and able musicmakers, filled their allotted time with vocal music in flowing--if not exactly modern--styles.

Cereal and milk form a combination ordained not only by custom but also, it develops, by science. A pamphlet recently issued to teachers by the Cereal Institute, edited for that agency by the authoritative Dr. Clara Mae...

WASHINGTON, April 3--George C. McGhee, Assistant Secretary of State, declared today that the nationalist spirit that had led the Iranian Parliament to approve Government possession of the country's oil fields would serve also to defeat Communist aggression in that area.

United Nations offensive operations in Korea continued Sunday with our ground units making advances on the eastern half of the front against heavy to light resistance. North of Chunchon, heavy hostile resistance was overcome and several counter-attacks repulsed during the advance.
A declaration that the United States and the Soviet Union "can and must find ways" to "coexist in a peaceful world" was issued yesterday by the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship.
DALLAS, April 8--All doubts as to where Jack Kramer figures in Leo Durocher's pitching plans for 1951 were dispelled today when Handsome Jack turned in a highly commendable nine-inning job.

Cardinal Spellman led the first of a series of monthly pilgrimages yesterday afternoon to extend for Roman Catholics the indulgences of the Holy Year 1950 through 1951. Starting shortly after 3 P.M. at St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Cardinal carried a simple black cross as he entered the cathedral at the head of 1,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, suggested today that Congress explore the possibility of "rationing" credit to combat inflation. The proposal was one of several he suggested for study in a statement announcing appointment of a House-Senate Economic subcommittee to investigate credit control and debt management.
Six new films, including an importation from Britain, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

BOSTON, April 8 (UP)--Toronto's vicious-checking Maple Leafs, hopeful of rolling to their seventh world hockey championship, reached the Stanley Cup finals tonight by shutting out the bewildered Boston Bruins, 6--0, before 10,557 fans at the Boston Garden.
Bernard M. Baruch favors the immediate enactment of a bill for universal military training.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, said today the Administration ought to remove all price and wage controls immediately.
The Communist party's statement to the Subversive Activities Control Board in reply to Attorney General McGrath's charges raises once again the question of the real nature of this party.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 8-- Raymond B. Baldwin, Associate Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors, gave a reading of Prokofieff's "Peter and the Wolf" before an audience of 3,000 here this afternoon.

The one-story and basement taxpayer store building on an irregular plot 207 by 133 feet at 29-01-21 Francis Lewis Boulevard, at Uto pia Parkway in Bayside, Queens, has been sold by a client of Brener Lewis Company, brokers,...

The large-scale deferment of college students on the basis of scholastic ability ordered by President Truman encountered increasing opposition last week as the military manpower bill ran into rough water in the House debate.

Algerd Brazis, American baritone, displayed a voice of spectacular dimension in Carnegie Hall late yesterday afternoon. It was his first recital here, but he had been heard in the Midwest primarily in opera. He was born in Chicago of Lithuanian parents.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- The Secretary of Commerce, Charles Sawyer, said today "There is not the slightest indication of any impropriety" on the part of his Department in connection with a surplus truck deal.

Enrollment of foreign students in United States colleges has now reached a record high of 30,000, the Institute of International Education reported yesterday. Engineering is the most popular subject among them, with the liberal arts and social sciences in second and third place.

Arnold S. Denker became champion of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday when he succeeded in drawing his last game with Arthur B. Bisguier in a Reti opening lasting twenty-seven moves. Denker, who was co-champion with George Shainswit a year ago, finished with a score of 10--3, half a point ahead of Bisguier.

The soloist on Saturday night's Philharmonic-Symphony program was Sidney Foster, who played Beethoven's Third Piano Concerto in C minor, which he had played with such outstanding success with the same orchestra in 1941.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 10--The Chinese Communists yesterday opened the floodgates of the big Hwachon Dam in central Korea in an attempt to wash the United Nations troops from the Pukhan River valley and to halt their advance into the enemy's main supply triangle north of the Thirtyeighth Parallel.

The office of Price Stabilization will issue in the next few weeks an order permitting bottlers of carbonated beverages to increase prices, E.D. Lowenstein, president, Booth Beverage Company, Philadelphia, announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, April 9--The peronista bloc in the Chamber of Deputies voted in caucus tonight for the expropriation of La Prensa after having heard a report of the joint Congressional committee that has been investigating the paper. The vote was by acclamation. Ninety-eight deputies were present.

Governor Dewey requested W. Kingsland Macy, Republican chairman of Suffolk County, to destroy the now famous "Hanley letter" before the letter was made public, according to both the defendant and the plaintiff in a pending libel suit, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (U.P.)-- The Supreme Court took under consideration today the question of whether a state had the right to keep out of public office any person who advocated the overthrow of the Government by force.

The Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange resumed trading in wool futures and wool tops yesterday after a nine-week hiatus and saw the commodity immediately decline by the 10-cent daily limit. May delivery sold at $3.97 a pound. Sales were estimated at 66,000 pounds for wool futures, 45,000 pounds for wool tops.

BOSTON, April 9 (AP)--The lone defending champion and two fighters who lost out in last year's finals remained in contention for national honors tonight after the first ten hours of the sixty-third Amateur Athletic Union boxing tournament at the Boston Garden

WASHINGTON, April 9(AP)-- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today that more than $13,450,000,000 of some $19,500,000,000 2 per cent marketable Government bonds had been exchanged for the new 2 per cent non-marketable issue. He said he was "gratified" by the response of holders.

On the 16th of July, 1949, a 17year-old white girl in Lake County, Fla., reported that she had been raped, at the point of a pistol, by dour Negroes, Six days later petitioners were indicted and, beginning Sept. 1, were tried for the offense, convicted without recommendation of mercy and sentenced to death. WASHINGTON, April 9--The Senate passed by a voice vote today a bill setting up the machinery for private enterprise and the Federal Government to work as a team to meet the nation's defense housing needs.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 9 (AP) --Middleweight Champion Sugar Ray Robinson knocked out Don Ellis of Atlantic City in the first round of their scheduled ten-round non-title fight at the Municipal Auditorium tonight. Robinson weighed 157 pounds, Ellis 168.

CHICAGO, April 9--A proposal to increase Federal taxes on cigarettes and cigars is unfair and unwise, Paul M. Hahn, president of the American Tobacco Company, said today at the opening session of the 1951 convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors.
Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein yesterday asked Federal, state and local authorities for their "close liaison and cooperation" in his inquiry into illegal drug traffic in New York State.
The American Cancer Society presented yesterday grants-in-aid and fellowships to thirty men and women engaged in cancer research.

Issuance of the first specialized price regulation affecting an imported commodity was hailed by foreign trade officials yesterday as beginning the release of longawaited stabilization measures for the import and export fields.

BOSTON, April 9--Dr. Robert H. Parry, honorary physician to King George VI of Great Britain, said tonight that although his country's Health Service Act had developed some weaknesses "we think that we are building on a solid foundation."

SINGAPORE, April 9--A unique mixing of races and religions will be achieved here tomorrow as Britain's program of instituting self-government in colonial territories advances another stage in Singapore.

Seymour M. Tannenbaum, operator, has resold the two five-story apartment houses at 237 and 239 West 148th Street to the 680 Wales Avenue Corporation. Each building contains forty-two apartments. The property is assessed at $84,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $31,000 on each building.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 9--The American Association of University Women opened its biennial convention today with at least one officer and an unknown number of delegates in a mood to re-examine its legislative program, which occupies a large part of the five-day agenda.
Thievery has increased fivefold in this city in the last six months, according to the police complaint file, but Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy said yesterday the records did not give a true picture.

DALLAS, Tex., April 9--Lulled into a false sense of security by a triumphal five-game tour against Texas' minor league teams, the Yankees today ran into some major league ball players weaung the insignia of the Boston Braves. The result was disastrous.

ALBANY, April 9--The State Civil Service Commission announced today that it would not invoke the machinery of the New York loyalty law unless a state or local agency ran into a specific case of an employe suspected of subversive activities endangering the defense.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it would lay off several thousand employes this week. It said the cuts were made necessary by a decline in frieght revenues, increased wage and material costs and losses sustained in the "sick strike" of switchmen last February.

Floodwaters of rivers in the upper Midwest have left 12,000 persons homeless, according to The Associated Press. Red Cross emergency parties compiled the figures. Property damage, too, may exceed $3,000,000.

Visitors to the Country Antiques Fair that opened yesterday in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, may well resign themselves to a case of "museum feet" if they attempt more than a cursory inspection of the hundreds of thousands of items there.

Bids will be received on April 24 by sixteen local housing authorities on issues of $56,363,000 of notes being issued under the guarantees of the Public Housing Administration. The notes will be dated May 23, 1951, with some due in 3 1/3 months and others in a year.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 9--Both Syria and Israel today officially tools their new border conflicts to the United Nations, each side submitting a series of specific complaints to the Security Council and demanding early action.

Five advisory committees in the Department of Welfare were reconstituted yesterday as Mayor Impellitteri swore in 150 civic leaders, business men and clergymen as members of these committees in ceremonies in the City Council Chamber at City Hall.

A thousand members of the Wine and Spirits Wholesalers of America at the first of their three-day sessions in the Waldorf Astoria Hotel were told yesterday that the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury would not stand for tie-in sales of scarce liquors with those selling slowly.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today re-affirmed a previous decision denying the Pacific Intermountain Express Company permission to set up transcontinental motor freight service.

TAMPA, Fla., April 9 (AP)--The University of Tampa crew rowed to an easy two-and-a-half-length victory over Dartmouth College today.

Several hundred women and children 'formed a human barricade yesterday at the three-way intersection of Manor Avenue and East 173d and 174th Streets, the Bronx, to demand adequate traffic safeguards there.

The Port of New York Authority received yesterday bids totaling $495,718 for the purchase of nine apartment buildings having an assessed valuation of $460,000. The agency had used the buildings to relocate tenants for its bus terminal and was required to dispose of the properties by June 30.

Dr. Simon Strauss, retired gynecologist and surgeon of 147 West Eighty-siXth Street, who had lived in St. Petersburg, Fla., for the last four years, died there Saturday. according to information received here yesterday. His age was 83.

WASHINGTON, April 9--Revival of the World War II practice of having the Government construct many of the defense plants it needs and lease them to private interests to operate has been suggested in a proposed amendment to the Defense Production Act sponsored by the defense production agencies of the Government.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 9-- A triple and a double combined with a long fly to center in the sixth inning enabled Army to gain a 5-to-5 tie with Manhattan Collegt in a seven-inning game called because of darkness at Doubleday Field today.

LONDON, April 9--Britain has joined the United States in representations to Israel and Syria advising them to show moderation in their current border dispute and in their appeals to the Security Council.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)-- The United States Court of Appeals delayed today its formal citation of contempt against Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer and nine others, including several high Government officials, in the Dollar Steamship case. The pronouncement is expected tomorrow.
A marked advance in social agency administration was reported yesterday by the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and Children's Aid Society, one of the nation's leading community service agencies.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday that it had completed plans for a nation-wide competitive exhibition of American sculpture to open at the museum on Dec. 7. This exhibi tion, second in a series of three, "is planned in accordance with the policy announced by the museum in January, 1949, of increasing its activities in the contemporary American field," said Francis Henry Taylor, director.

Bernard I. Green, an artist and chairman of the art department of Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, died of a heart ailment Sunday night in the Hospital for Joint Diseases at the age of 65. He resided at 344 West Seventysecond Street.
WASHINGTON, April 9--The Supreme Court upheld today the right of West Virginia to join an eight-state compact pledging cooperation in keeping the Ohio River basin free of pollution.

Advertising in seven New York dailies was off 2.83 per cent for the first three months of the year, according to a media analysis made public yesterday. Total linage was 35,934,098. Only classified, up 22.40 per cent, and financial, up 15.58 per cent, showed gains over the same period last year. Automotive led the losses, down 18.51 per cent, followed by general, down 8.28; retail, down 5.59 and department stores, down 4.72.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)-- The Disabled American Veterans in an announcement today said that curtailment of the veterans' hospital building program would be "a tragic betrayal of America's disabled fighting men."

As had been predicted, Richard M. Crooks was nominated yesterday to become chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange. The election will be held on May 14 and, if he is successful, Mr. Crooks will succeed Robert P. Baylan on May 21, serving for one year. Mr. Boylan is not a candidate for re-election to the chairmanship or to the board.

LONDON. April 9--With their thoughts on tomorrow's budget, investors were cautious and hesitant in dealings on the London stock market today. Despite minimum turnover, however, prices were fairly steady.

Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, whose fleet has expanded in three years from four to more than thirty vessels, will sign contracts shortly for the construction of three additional cargo-passenger ships. All will be built out of the company's net profits, which in 1950 were $3,000,000.

The increase to 3 per cent in the New York City sales tax has been approved by the City Council and now appears to be a certainty, although the Board of Estimate has still to act.

Deeply concerned over the future welfare of the American Theatre Wing, Actors Equity Association and its sister organization, Chorus Equity, have made a gift of $1,500 to the Wing to "keep its essential service alive."

ALBANY, April 11--Governor Dewey today vetoed a bill that would have set up a state-wide licensing system for psychologists, in an effort to eliminate "quacks" from the field. Mr. Dewey said the measure might have barred from practice some legitimate psychologists.

THE outstanding literary trend of 1951 is the triumphant progress of the ladies who write. And how they write! They have a good many admirable male competitors, it is true. But they can afford to be pretty genial, even compassionate, toward them.

NEW DELHI, India, April 11--Indians learned of the dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur with wholehearted relief. They regarded him as the "bogy-man of Western imperialism" and personifying the policy of total war in the Far East.

LONDON, April 11--Cheers greeted the announcement in the House of Commons today that President Truman had removed General of the Army Douglas MacArthur as the United Nations Commander in Chief in Korea.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 11 --Columbia's deal to acquire screen rights to the Anita Loos-Joseph Fields musical comedy, "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," for $165,000 has fallen through, the studio announced today, because the Broadway producers, Herman Levin and Oliver Smith, were "too restrictive" in their contractual demands.

Gen. Courtney Whitney, General MacArthur's military secretary, said today.

The Board of Estimate approved unanimously yesterday the bill passed by the City Council on Wednesday calling for the collection of a 3 per cent city sales tax beginning on May 1. CHICAGO, April 12 (AP)--The Pullman Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission at Washington today for authority to raise its sleeping car and parlor car rates 15 oer cent.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 12 --The Republican organization of Bergen County, long the backbone of the party in New Jersey, is facing its hardest primary fight in more than two decades as an aftermath of the public disclosures of widespread gambling in the county.

NEW DELHI, India, April 12-- The exit of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from the field has created a remarkable shift in Indian opinion in favor of the United States and, according to informed circles here, has considerably brightened the chances of a cease-fire in Korea.

WASHINGTON, April 12--The House of Representatives rejected today a substitute draft bill that omitted any mention of Universal Military Training and that contained no provision for reduction of the draft age. The vote was 232 to 140.

New York bank loans to business were cut $31,000,000 last week. The decline was the second to be registered in three weeks, and indicated that the current upward trend in business loans might have reached a turning point.

SINGAPORE, April 12--The importance of Rangoon as the southeast Asian center of international Communist activities is expected to increase with the opening there of the first Soviet embassy to function in the Burmese capital.

LONDON, April 12--The Scottish Nationalists were still campaigning today to keep the Stone of Scone in Scotland where it now lies--under police guard--for the first time in 655 years. Sassenach ministers of the United Kingdom Government in London were not saying what they proposed to do with it.

He was also reported to favor informal appearance before Congressional committees rather than before a joint session of both houses.

NORTH CHICAGO, Ill., April 12 --Net world sales of Abbott Laboratories for the first quarter of 1951 were the largest in the history of the company and increased 21 per cent over the same 1950 period, Dr. E.H. BAR HARBOR, Me., April 12-- The donation of the thirteen-acre oceanside estate of the late Morris Hawkes to the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory, cancer-research institution, was announced today by Dr. Clarence A. Little, executive director of the institution.

The signs of the Golden Pheasant and the Dragon at the Chinese Merchants Association, Canal and Mott Streets, heralded yesterday a wedding uniting two of the most famous Chinese restaurant families in this country. And all Chinatown rejoiced.

MILFORD, Conn., April 12-- Miss Betty Ann VanderMeer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney W. VanderMeer, has selected May 12 for her marriage to Bryan Lorey Donaldson of Pittsburgh, formerly of Fairfield, son of Mrs. John Ellis
Though beset by injuries to several key men, the Yankees came home last night, prepared to launch their run for a third straight American League pennant under Manager Casey Stengel.

GENEVA, April 12--There is fear in Europe that some of the very real economic problems of the smaller Western European countries are being overlooked both by the United States and by the larger Euproean countries.
Attempts to brand women in military service as "unfeminine" were decried as untrue by a colonel in the Marine Corps Women's Reserve last night.
First signs have appeared that a buyers market is developing in some domestic durable goods lines, purchasing executives for large industrial organizations said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 12--Only one law has possible application in the switch in New York whey Joe R. Hanley quit as candidate for Governor to stand for the United States Senate last fall.
Sabotage and the possibility of disaster resulting from war threaten the state's social insurance program, Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the Workmen's Compensation Board, said yesterday.
LOU BOUDREAU was sitting in front of his locker at the Red Sox training base in Sarasota. His uniform was drenched with per spiration as he unpeeled it on his way to the shower.

A study of forty-five private hospitals in the city to determine how they can best contribute to civil defense was announced yesterday by Grover Whalen, coordinator of recruiting and public information for the Office of Civil Defense.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 12 (AP)--The Red Sox scored three times without a hit in the seventh inning today to down the Springfield Cubs of the International League, 5--2.
Textile manufacturers, technicians, retailers and consumers went on record yesterday in agreement that a change in the nomenclature of rayon fabric is long overdue.

More than 2,000 longshoremen, employed on the Chelsea piers along the North River, walked off their jobs at 11 A.M. yesterday to engage in a two-hour demonstration of protest against the dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur by President Truman. A similar work stoppage was held at Pier 3, Erie Basin, Brooklyn.
Akron, Ohio, School District announced yesterday that it will receive bids on May 9 on an issue of $6,720,000 of bonds dated June 1, 1951, coming due from Nov. 1, 1952 to 1972.

PARIS, April 12--Under the leadership of Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor and Foreign Minister of the West German regime, and Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, the foreign ministers of six nations met today at the French Foreign Ministry to put the finishing touches to the Schuman plan preparatory to signing it early next week.
Sabotage and the possibility of disaster resulting from war threaten the state's social insurance program, Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the Workmen's Compensation Board, said yesterday.
LOU BOUDREAU was sitting in front of his locker at the Red Sox training base in Sarasota. His uniform was drenched with per spiration as he unpeeled it on his way to the shower.

A study of forty-five private hospitals in the city to determine how they can best contribute to civil defense was announced yesterday by Grover Whalen, coordinator of recruiting and public information for the Office of Civil Defense.
Akron, Ohio, School District announced yesterday that it will receive bids on May 9 on an issue of $6,720,000 of bonds dated June 1, 1951, coming due from Nov. 1, 1952 to 1972.

PARIS, April 12--Under the leadership of Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor and Foreign Minister of the West German regime, and Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, the foreign ministers of six nations met today at the French Foreign Ministry to put the finishing touches to the Schuman plan preparatory to signing it early next week.

One doesn't hear much these days of the Giants' young hurlers, George Bamberger, Norman Fox, Roger Bowman and George Spencer, which is a pity since all four were primed to make a strong showing this spring.

Trompe-l'oeil, a decorating device much used in the Renaissance, has been employed by Riccardo Magni in his hand-painted canvas panels for walls in contemporary homes. A display of some of his work opens today at Stoffel's Decorative Fabrics showroom at 598 Madison Avenue, where the panels are available through decorators.
Mrs. Henry A. Bull thinks President Truman was wrong to oust General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

MOSCOW, April 12--The recall of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was characterized in the initial comment by the Soviet press today as "convincing evidence of confusion in the camp of the American instigators of war."
Joseph Brown, he of the weatherbeaten face, is the low man on the banner pole of the Big Show, Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

Many parties were given at the "On the Avenue" luncheon and fashion show held yesterday in the main ballroom of the Plaza to mark the thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Nearly New Shop. Miss Louise Edgar, president of the shop, and Mrs. R. Clifford

HONG KONG, April 12--While the Peiping radio lagged behind with formal Chinese Communist reaction to the ouster of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, two Communist-supervised newspapers declared editorially today that President Truman's action would not alter Communist China's policy in Korea.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society and a cast of singers admirably selected and trained for the occasion gave a performance of Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" in concert form last night in Carnegie Hall which must rank as one of the historic achievements of the organization.

Increased shipments from Florida and as far north as New Jersey have reduced prices on several vegetables, in two cases by as much as 10 cents a pound. Salt water fish also is available, often at prices below those of a week ago. These, unfortunately, are the only items lower in cost than last Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 12-- States have power to force candidates for state and city offices to swear that they are not engaged in attempts to overthrow the government by force and violence, the United States Supreme Court ruled unanimously today in upholding the controversial Ober Loyalty Law of Maryland.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 11--All members of the United Nations were called on today to file reports on what they had done to carry out the General Assembly's request to "earmark" troops for duty with the world organization.
The American Foundation for the Blind opened a four-day conference at its headquarters yesterday on problems affecting the treatment and education of blind children of pre-school age.
A small band of Southerners, sided and encouraged by several friendly Northerners, raised a Confederate flag yesterday outside a hotel in West Forty-third Street-- the Dixie, naturally.
The city and the Port of New York Authority yesterday renewed their recommendations for helicopter passenger, mail and cargo service in the metropolitan area by calling upon the Civil Aeronautics

LONDON, April 13--Unknown to thousands of Scottish visitors in London, the Stone of Scone was restored to Westminster Abbey tonight. It left Scotland unceremoniously at dawn in a police car for the second time since it was taken to England by King Edward I in 1296.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)-- The Senate completed Congressional approval today for payment of a cost-free $10,000 death benefit on all persons in the armed services, including all casualties in Korea.

The United Nations' offensive continued Friday with heavy fighting in the western and east-central sectors. Southeast of Chorwon and east of Hwachon, our units encountered intense mortar fire and fought off enemy counter-attacks during the advance.
PARIS, April 13--Mme. Paul Dupuy, American-born widow of the former French Senator and newspaper owner, died at her home here, it was announced today by her son, Jacques Dupuy.

If private financiers do not succeed in checking the continued use of credit in non-productive, and non-defense fields by voluntary action, the job will be taken over by a Federal Government authority...

The city is meeting its minimum daily quota of blood donations to fill normal civilian and military needs, but must increase its contributions to fill special calls for whole blood for the wounded in Korea, a Red Cross spokesman said yesterday.
DETROIT, April 13--KaiserFrazer Corporation showed a consolidated net loss of $13,260,000 for 1950 in its annual report, mailed to stockholders today. The 1949 deficit was $30,329,351.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP)-- General of the Army George C. Marshall, Secretary of Defense, today "strongly" opposed legislation to give the Marine Corps a fixed basic strength and representation on the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

Ballet Theatre gave another bang-up performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, with the excellence of its presentation of the old works quite matching the interest of the new work which had its American premiere on this occasion.
A tour of New York Art galleries this week should include shows of paintings by four contemporary artists.

Commuters and other travelers on the Long Island Rail Road flocked to buy tickets yesterday at the old rates before higher rates went into effect at 12:01 A.M. today. These include a 20 per cent increase in commutation rates and a 12 per cent increase in basic one-way fares.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 13--Illegal West German trade with the Soviet zone of Germany, most of it in steel, machine tools, ball bearings and other strategic materials, is officially estimated at more than 1,000,000,000 Deutsche marks ($238,000,000) a year.

In many respects the present controversy over General MacArthur represents an elemental and emotional outburst expressing the anger and frustration of a nation which, less than six years after its greatest victory, finds itself again at war and facing the danger of another world war.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP)-- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will support the prices of the 1951 domestic and Puerto Rican tobacco crops at slightly higher levels than last year.
Sales and unfilled orders of the Autocar Company have both been rising since the beginning of the year, Edward F. Coogan, president, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 13--Although the railroads of the United States had freight rate increases of 57.3 per cent from 1938 to Sept. 1, 1949, the average increase to the ton-mile for 1950 compared with 1938 was only 35 per cent,...
A new pattern for radio time charges was indicated yesterday when the Columbia Broadcasting System announced that its network radio rates will be cut 10 to 15 per cent effective July 1.

The 20 per cent increase in commutation fares on the Long Island Rail Road granted by the Public Service Commission is hardly a surprise. As recently as June, 1950, the bankrupt road had put its needs at a 32 per cent increase.
SYRACUSE, April 13 (UP)--Two bookkeepers, trusted employes, were charged today with manipulating a bank's books to the amount of $308,521.22.
MIAMI, Okla., April 13 (AP)-- Rookie baseball star Mickey Mantle of the New York Yankees can go back to his promising diamond career. He is physically unqualified for Army service.

ALBANY, April 13--State Commerce Commissioner Harold Keller today branded as "wholly false" the charge that a son of former Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley was appointed to a Commerce Department post as part of a "deal" resulting from the Hanley letter incident.

WASHINGTON, April 13--The Senate approved President Truman's plan for a reorganization of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today, thus leaving him free to abolish the present fivemember board of directors and...

For sixteen years Oliver D. Collier, Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, has been tracking down criminals. Yesterday he resigned "to heed the call of God" and become pastor of a Queens church. Tomorrow he will preach his first sermon as pastor of the Calvary Gospel Tabernacle, Assemblies of God, 90-10 168th Street, Jamaica.

On the verge of defeat after their 17-point lead had turned into a 6-point deficit, the New York Knickerbockers rallied to down the Rochester Royals, 79--73, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz ordered yesterday a sweeping inquiry into the activities of the Department of Investigation while Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh was its Commissioner during the O'Dwyer administration.
CHICAGO, April 13--The grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade here today, with wheat closing 1/8 to 5/8 cents a bushel lower despite further damage reports from Kansas.

WASHINGTON, April 13--Government price ceiling regulations and controls over imports of such commodities as rubber and tin are proving too much for the New York Commodity Exchange, which will decide on Wednesday, May 2, whether or not to close its doors for the duration of the present emergency.

GENEVA, April 13--Europe's "surplus" population could be resettled in the parts of the world needing new hands and brains for not more than $301.50 a person, J. Donald Kingsley, director general, reported to the General Council of International Refugee Organization here today.

WASHINGTON, April 13--President Truman presented the Medal of Honor today to Lieut. (j.g.) Thomas J. Hudner Jr., a Navy fighter pilot who deliberately had crash-landed his plane deep in North Korea in a vain effort to save the life of Ensign Jesse Leroy Brown, the first Negro flier in the history of the United States Navy.

A modern version of piracy was unfolded yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation with the arrest of thirteen tugboat crew members charged with stealing, $150,000 in merchandise from freight trains on lighters the men were towing in New York harbor.
If there is any problem that taxes the ingenuity of an opera company--next to the most troublesome of all, finances--it is the one brought on by an outbreak of illness among the principal singers.
MOSCOW, April 13--Premier Stalin attended tonight the opening session of the Supreme Soviet of the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic--his fourth public appearance within a month.

Mayor Impellitteri's executive budget of $1,336,102,798 for 195152 was assailed yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission, unofficial watchdog of the city treasury, as part of a continuing "shell game" that has deceived the city's taxpayers for many years.

The Booker T. Washington Birthplace Memorial announced yesterday that $3,094 has been returned as a result of having "lost" $1,000 worth of Booker T. Washington Birthplace Memorial half dollars in New York.

PARIS, April 13--Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States deputy, made renewed efforts today to obtain from Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet deputy, a clear statement on the present Soviet idea of a complete agenda for a Big Four foreign ministers' meeting.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., April 13 (AP)--Five masked gunmen seized a $35,000 payroll in the yard of a sterling-silver plant today and shot their way out, critically wounding a policeman after his fire crippled their car.
WASHINGTON, April 13-- President Truman recalled casually to a group of visitors today that George Washington discharged two generals in the American Revolution--Charles Lee and Horatio Gates.
WASHINGTON, April 13--The Democratic Congressional leaders gave in today to a Republican ultimatum and agreed to permit General of the Army Douglas MacArthur to address a joint meeting of Congress.

CAIRO, April 13--The threat of a breakdown of authority and of a massacre in the Anglo-Iranian oil region in southern Iran has become overnight an all-Middle-Eastern issue and has sent a flash of fear as far as Cairo.

William L. Klein, a former deputy internal revenue collector, was convicted by a jury yesterday in Judge Leo F. Rayfiel's part of the Brooklyn Federal Court on a charge of accepting a $2,600 bribe for the adjustment of an income tax return.
The "Controlled Materials Plan" is a procedure under which available supplies of a given commodity are matched against military and civilian requirements and allotted accordingly.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13--Warren R. Austin, the Vermont Republican who heads the United States delegation to the United Nations, has come out in support of the dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur as part of a policy to prevent a third world war.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores rose 19.0 per cent in March, compared with a year ago, according to a compilation of forty-five companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase in February over February, 1950, was 17.0 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 13--A motion picture "starlet" who makes a hit at the box office may cash in on a new contract without violating wage stabilization rules.

Singing Needles, Inc., Millersville, Pa., has been formed for the manufacture of children's and 'teens' underwear. Russel Horne, president, announced that New York offices would be at 350 Fifth Avenue.

NORFOLK, Va., April 13--The Giants-Indians cross-country tour ended today amid a genuine blaze as a fire broke out in the wooden bleachers here, sending more than 2,000 fans scampering to the playing field.
WASHINGTON, April 13--Air Force officials here are known to be concerned over the growing enemy aggressiveness in the air over Korea.
Lion Island, in the African Plains section of Bronx Zoo, uninhabited since last fall, took on new tenants yesterday in the person of six frisky lions.

In the first stockholders' meeting ever held by the company on shipboard, seven executive officers were selected by the board of directors this week to help direct the Matson Navigation Company's operations this year. The session was held aboard the liner Lurline in San Francisco.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 13--Former State Supreme Court Justice John Francis Carew died here last night at his home, 141 South Park Avenue. He apparently had been in good health until a day or two ago. He would have been 78 years old on Monday.

OTTAWA, April 13--It has been made very plain here in the past two days that whatever criticism there may have been of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's attitude on policies held to be beyond his field it was not in any way activated by any desire to get out of the Korean war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 --William Wyler, motion picture producer-director, and Ruth and Augustus Goetz, playwrights and screen writers, have acquired the dramatic and film rights to "The Sailor's Return," a 1925 English novel by David Gannett.
The stock market completed yesterday the task of throwing off the so-called peace "jitters" and surged forward in the strongest buying wave in a month. Prices scored the widest gains of the year.

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 --India is stripping all royal titles, privileges and a $556,000 yearly pension from the wealthy Gaekwar of Baroda on charges involving both his monetary affairs and national security, informed sources said tonight.

Wool futures declined by the 10cent limit again yesterday in trading on the New York Cotton Exchange and ended below $3 a pound, down more than 20 per cent from the $3.75 peak. May was at $2.91 2/10, December at $2.79 2/10. Dealings aggregated 750,000 pounds.
Isidore Weiner sold the taxpayer at 66 to 74 Hillside Avenue, East Williston, L.I., containing a super market and four other stores, to the Beacar Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 13--Merrill Bernard, chief of the Climatological and Hydrological Services of the United States Weather Bureau, died today at his home after an illness of four months. His age was 59.

The British Government, by bringing suit for salvage against the American freighter Flying Arrow and the Isbrandtsen Company, is, in effect, asking the United States District Court to rule that warships are not duty bound to prevent loss of life and property resulting from criminal or unlawful attack at sea.
CHARLESTON, S.C., April 13 (AP)--"The Yankee Cheese Box"-- one of the world's first iron-clad warships--apparently has been located in 120 feet of water, twenty miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C.

LONGMIRE, Rainier National Park, Wash., April 13 (AP)--A flier who stunt-landed his light plane near the crater at the top of 14,408-foot Mount Rainier and was marooned there overnight took off under his own power at 3:45 P.M. today.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)-- An atomic scientist accused of contempt of Congress for refusing to answer questions during an investigation of atomic spying was acquitted today.

WASHINGTON, April 13--The anticipated order applying price ceilings to a wide range of goods at the manufacturing level will be issued during the coming week, Michael V. DiSalle, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, told reporters tonight.
The way practically has been cleared for Robert Alda to take a ten-week leave this summer from his featured role in "Guys and Dolls" to fulfill a movie commitment.

BOSTON, April 13--Mrs. Chase, Going Woodhouse, consultant to the Economic Stabilization Agency, said today that women had the task of "safeguarding the human values" during the present world emergency.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP)--Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, a member of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, was reported to have received two threats against his life today.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)-- Atlantic City Electric Company today applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration of 117,200 shares of $10 par common stock.

Dr. Harold Vincent Milligan of 853 Seventh Avenue, organist, composer and author on musical subjects, died in Mount Sinai Hospital Thursday night after a brief illness. His age was 67. He was former organist of Riverside Church.
A Navy fighter plane narrowly missed striking buildings on the lower East Side and plunged into the East River, killing its pilot, at 10:20 o'clock yesterday morning.

Relaxations by the Union of South Africa on import restrictions have greatly enhanced the value of Africa-United States trade with the result that two United Statesflag steamship lines are now increasing their sailings.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 13 (AP)-- Miss Mary Freeman of Washington ignored a bad cold and difficult weather conditions today to add two women's national senior A.A.U. swimming championships to the two junior records she set last year.

LONDON, April 13--Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison in a statement to the House of Commons today on yesterday's disturbances in the Abadan oil region of Iran said the British Government reserved the right "to act as we see fit to protect British lives and property."

WASHINGTON, April 13--Thirteen prominent Negroes today urged Secretary of State Dean Acheson to take steps to end discrimination against members of their race in State Department posts in this country and abroad.
WASHINGTON, April 13--The Federal Communications Commission denied today that it proposed to prejudge the applications of motion-picture producers if they should try to enter television.

BUENOS AIRES, April 13 (AP)-- La Nacion, last major independent newspaper, left in Argentina following Government expropriation of La Prensa, lashed out editorially today at the Government of President Juan Peron.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 13-- Malcolm Farmer, retired industrialist and former chairman of the board of athletic control at Yale, died today at the Grace-New Haven Community Hospital after a long illness. His age was 68.

During the last week 10,000 packets of "fact sheets" on legislation affecting children that is now before Congress have gone out to individuals and organizations all over the country from headquarters of Spokesmen for Children, 654 Madison Avenue.
City College has suspended intercollegiate football, Dr. Harry N. Wright, college president, announced yesterday, revealing a decision made Wednesday by the Faculty Athletic Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)-- The Federal Security Agency said today that steel, copper and aluminum supplies had been set aside for the first time to meet urgent needs in hospital and school construtcion.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., April l3--Miss. Joycelyn Macfarlane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald S. Macfarlane, has chosen May 12 for her marriage to R. Leonard Harrill, son of Mrs. Robert Frank Harrill of Charleston, S.C., and the late Mr. Harrill.
William Howlett has been elected president of Nesco, Inc., housewares manufacturer, to succeed Arthur Keating, largest single stockholder, who becomes chairman of the board.

The aversion of a "possible-toprobable" 1,560 fatalities and loss of aircraft, with an estimated value of $15,500,000, through the skill and alertness of Civil Aeronautics Administration radio communicators replying to 475 emergency calls has been reported by Donald W. Nyrop, who heads the C.A.A.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 13 --Alexander Levy, 55 years old, of 1647 Macombe Avenue, the Bronx, alleged to have been the manager of Frank Erickson's New Jersey gambling interests when Erickson maintained an office at 452 Palisade Avenue, Cliffside...

WASHINGTON, April 13--The House of Representatives passed a much-revised Universal Military Service and Training Bill today, 372 to 44. Thirty-seven Republicans and seven Democrats were recorded in opposition.

WASHINGTON, April 13-- Spokesmen for 1,000,000 non-operating railway employes warned the Government today that their contract with the carriers would be invalid if the escalator clause was disallowed, since it was a "package" agreement.

With the run of maple sap just beginning to taper off in topproducing states, latest reports indicate that maple syrup this year will not be quite as plentiful as in 1950. On the credit side is quality, described by most states as excellent.

CHICAGO, April 13--A notice of increases of as much as 10 per cent on round-trip railroad fares on transcontinental trips to California points will be filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission late this month, officials of the Western Passenger Association said today.

ALBANY, April 13--The State Banking Department announced today that the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, 70 Broadway, has been authorized to open a branch office at 214 Church Street, conditioned upon discontinuance of the branches at 271 Church Street and 335 Greenwich Street.

The Newspaper Guild of New York paid tribute last night to the newspaper men who produced La Prensa, the Argentine newspaper expropriated by the Peron regime, by presenting a special citation to its staff at the Guild's annual Page One Ball in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (U.P.) --The House Appropriations Committee today ordered a 3 per cent cut in the $2,732,000,000 that President Truman requested to operate the Department of Labor and the Social Security Agency in the next fiscal year.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 13-- An assertion that a "potentially explosive situation" existed in the Federal Penitentiary on Alcatraz Island was followed today by general denials by Federal officials that an escape plot had been disclosed on the "fortress" prison in San Francisco Bay.
HAGERSTOWN, Md., April 13 (AP)--Maj. Gen. Joseph Wilson Byron, U.S.A., retired, died while on a cruise in the Caribbean, his brother, David Byron, learned here last night. He was 59 years old.
LONDON, April 13--Industrials resumed their post-budget advance on the stock markets here today.
ALBANY, April 13--Governor Dewey signed today three bills that round out the general pay increase program for the state's 78,000 public school teachers.
WASHINGTON, April 13--The United States rejected in full today British suggestions that Communist China take part in the negotiations for a Japanese peace treaty.
The owners and trainers of ten 3-year-olds have decided to take shots at Joseph J. Colando's remarkable Uncle Miltie in the $25,000 added Experimental Handicap No. 2 at Jamaica today.
Cardinal Spellman will formally open the thirty-second annual appeal of Catholic Charities tomorrow at 10 A.M., by pontificating at a solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

JERSEY CITY, April 13--In politically minded Hudson County, members of the majority Democratic party will decide at next Tuesday's primary whether they want to re-enforce the power of John V. Kenny, Mayor of Jersey City, or revert to the inheritors of the deposed Hague machine for their political guidance.
A debut recital was sung last night in Town Hall by the bassbaritone, Robert Falk, who proved a singer of taste and discrimination.
Pee Wee Reese clipped Ed Lopat for a three-run homer in the fifth inning to give the Dodgers a 7-6 decision over the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday.

VIENNA, April 13--Hungarian Roman Catholic Bishops were accused today by Szabad Nep, chief organ of Hungarian communism, of having broken their last year's agreement with the Hungarian Government by refusing to sign a new Communist petition for a fivepower peace pact.

ROME, April 13 (UP)--Dick Savitt of Orange, N.J., and Budge Patty of Los Angeles gained the men's singles semi-finals in Rome's international tennis tournament today, but the defending champion, Jaroslav Drobny of...
The New York Trio, three able and serious musicians who are in residence at the City College, gave its first public concert last night in Times Hall.

An army of civilian aircraft spotters in twenty-one northeastern states will scar the skies today and tomorrow for "attacking" planes in the Eastern Air Defense Force's third test of its Ground Observer Corps.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)-- Two Hollywood actors and two writers refused today to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee whether they were Communists.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 13 --The marriage of Miss. Judith Brumley Eckart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Albert Eckart of Westport, Conn., to Pfc. Saturnino Lieven Salas, U.S.A.F., son of Mrs. Gevaert Salas of East...

TOKYO, Saturday, April 14-- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's decision on what role he will play in the hotly disputed political question of President Truman's action, it was believed here today, will not be taken until he arrives in the United States on his first trip home in fourteen years.
ALBANY, April 13--Needy retired state and local employes will receive at least $75 a month until July 1, 1952, under a bill signed today by Governor Dewey.
TOKYO, April 13 (AP)--Decorations have been awarded to fortythree Army chaplains--including two killed in action--since the beginning of the Korean war.

Industry welcomed announcement of the Controlled Materials Plan by the National Production Authority yesterday, because professional purchasing executives felt that the "Defense Order" priority system was breaking down.
WASHINGTON, April 13--Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended April 10, the second consecutive week, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

A two-story business structure containing eight stores and twelve offices known as the P.R. Meyer Building, at 124-132 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y., has been sold by Jack Brause, realty operator, to a client of Morris Nisonoff, attorney.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, Saturday, April 14--Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, new Supreme Allied Commander in the Far East, pledged today that "with God's guidance and with all my heart and mind I shall do my utmost to discharge my new responsibilities well."

QUITO, Ecuador, April 13-- Ecuador is providing one of the most remarkable of all Latin Amercan experiments in democracy. Because of her background of comic opera revolutions--twenty-seven in twenty-five years--it will doubtless come as a surprise to most...
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)-- The Treasury says its offering of a new 2 per cent non-marketable bond, put out as an anti-inflation aid, has scored a big subscription.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)-- Government officials accused by the United States Court of Appeals here of "contemptuous and contumacious" conduct in the Dollar steamship litigation actually acted "in the utmost good faith," Attorney General J. Howard McGrath told the Supreme Court today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13-- General MacArthur accepted today, "with pleasure," an invitation to be San Francisco's guest on his first visit in fourteen years to the United States mainland.
ALBANY, April 13 (AP)--All but two units of the New York Air National Guard will undergo two weeks of summer training at the Grenier Air Force Base, N. H., Aug. 11-25.

The chief engineer of the Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporation told the Public Service Commission yesterday that his concern could supply natural gas to the Consolidated Edison Company of New York even in case of a break in the pipelines from the Southwest.
Dr. Margaret Mead, anthropologist and author, said yesterday that anthropologists had a responsibility for an foreseeable events resulting from their recommendations to modern societies.

TRENTON, April 13 (AP)--Three of the typewritten confessions in the Trenton Six murder case were thrown out by Superior Court Judge Ralph J. Smalley today. He ruled the state had failed to prove they had been obtained legally.
The first international intercollegiate race between eight-oared crews in this country marks the four regattas ushering in the 1951 varsity rowing season in the East today.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP)--The present lull in business will be of brief duration and is not likely to involve a drop in employment, Sumner Slichter, Harvard University economist, said today.

The general reaction of steel, aluminum and copper producers to the Government's announcement that it will place in effect a Controlled Materials Plan for these metals on July 1 is that the move is a step in the right direction.

TODAY is the day, but how many of the anglers who crowd the lakes and streams of this state this morning will be eating trout tonight is a matter for some conjecture, but after spending opening day hip-deep in cold water a number of the hopefuls will want something more substantial than fish for supper.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 14-- United Nations troops thrust forward for small gains on the western and central Korean fronts yesterday, moving up toward what may be the main defense line of the Chinese and North Koreans south of their big re-supply area in the Chorwon-Kumhwa area of the central Korean mountains.

JERSEY CITY, April 13--A Hudson County grand jury asserted tonight that the now famous Shea report that pictured the city of Hoboken as rampant with vice and corruption was based on "hearsay, rumor, anonymous letters, anonymous telephone calls and incredible statements."

TRENTON, N.J., April 13 (AP)-- A 64-year-old former seaman was jailed tonight charged with the brutal bare-fist slaying of Leon A. West, a civic leader of Yardville.
Recognizing the need to stimulate business in the New York market, the Garment Salesmen's Guild of New York will hold its first combined showing in the New Yorker Hotel on June 17-21.

New York's traditional tickertape parade up Broadway and the city's official welcome at City Hall will be bestowed on General of the Army Douglas MacArthur on his return here next week, Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)-- A report of the Department of Agriculture showed today that speculative trading in cotton on the nation's futures market has declined about 25 per cent since the Government put price ceilings on cotton.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg reserved decision yesterday after nearly three months' trial of a suit brought by the State Superintendent of Insurance to liquidate the International Workers Order on the ground that it is "Communist dominated."

Bruno M. Bolls, general supervisor of the Pennsylvania Railroad's dining car department who retired yesterday after thirty-one years of catering to the whims of peripatetic palates has concluded that roast beef, steaks and ham and eggs still hold the same lure they always did.

CHICAGO, April 13--Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan ordered the Bowman Dairy Company today to answer nine complaints brought by individual grocery store owners charging violation of the anti-trust laws and seeking damages totaling $110,977.

A policy slip banker described as a "millionaire druggist" and his brother-in-law were indicted yesterday by the Bronx grand jury on charges of contriving a lottery and maintaining a place of gambling.

ROME, April 13--Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza, in a personal letter to Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, has suggested that Washington, London and Paris make "formal and substantial change" in Italy's international position by announcing the "moral extinction of the peace treaty."

A majority of hospitals will not change the present compensation for private duty nurses despite the possibility that many in the profession may decline to work after tomorrow unless a $12 daily fee is permitted.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 13-- Students seeking draft deferments in scholastic aptitude tests will be rated on their ability to do well in college work rather than on native intelligence alone, according to William W. Turnbull, vice president of the Educational Testing Service.

CHICAGO, April 13--Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, criticized the influence of the Zionist movement on American Jewish institutions today and charged that Zionist influence was aimed at implementing Israeli national policies among American Jews.
