In a renewed plea for additional support for the American Red Cross, David Sarnoff, national fund chairman, declared yesterday that even if the 1951 campaign quota of $85,000,000 were achieved, it still would be insufficient to meet all the responsibilities of the organization.
The author of a medical bestseller that has helped doctors all over the world to hasten the mending of broken bones is visiting this country for the first time in twenty-one years.
HELSINKI, Finland, April 16-- Once more the Finns appear to have said a firm "no" to communism.
Out of her Blue Room department--the one with an entrance on Forty-eighth Street, where the ready-to-wear styles are shown-- Hattie Carnegie spilled her spring...

BOSTON, April 16 (UP)--Crippled by a foul punch during the sixth round, Joe Rindone of Boston was declared the winner tonight over Irish Bob Murphy of San Diego, Calif., in a scheduled tenround boxing bout before 13,626 Boston Garden fans.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The State Department announced today its expected change in personnel policies. The new practice is designed to enlarge opportunities in career diplomacy and minimize the separation between departmental officials and Foreign Service officers.

CHICAGO, April 16--The natural gas industry is prepared to start an expansion program involving nearly $1,000,000,000 if adequate steel supplies and approval of the Federal Power Commission are forthcoming, Frederic C. Hess, president of the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association, said today.
The appointment of Matthew G. Forrest as principal naval architect and that of Hans J. Wennberg as senior assistant naval architect was announced yesterday by Gibbs Cox, Inc.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 16--Ivan Karaivanov, head of the Institute of International Studies in the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry, disclosed today new information concerning growing resistance of the people and the army in Bulgaria to Soviet domination.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, which operates the Museum of Non-Objective Paintings, has purchased a thirteenstory apartment house on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street and plans to erect a museum building on the site.

ROME, April 16 (UP)--Miss Doris Hart of Jacksonville, Fla., won her fourth straight foreign tennis title and her third straight at the expense of Miss Shirley Fry today when she defeated the Akron, Ohio, player, 6-3, 8-6, in the women's singles final at the Rome championships.

Net asset value of Tri-Continental Corporation, closed-end investment company, for the three months ended March 31 amounted to $18.21 a share, the company reported yesterday. Three months earlier, on Dec. 31, net asset value of the company's common stock was $17.08 a share, and on March 31, 1950, it was $14.61 a share.
WASHINGTON, April 16--The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the Railway Express Agency to add a charge of 20 cents on most less-than-carload shipments.

Prices for United States Government bonds had another sinking spell yesterday in a trading session in which the volume of exchanges was small and no distress selling was visible. Long-term obligations lost from 5/8 to 3/16 of a point, and the Treasury's longestterm bank-ineligible 2 s sold under par for the first time.

The season of Garden Weeks is moving rapidly upon us, a time when dignified ladies-- and a few gentlemen-- elegantly turned out will be seen fluttering from one immaculately kept estate to another, looking at the neatly...
BOSTON, April 16 (U.P.)--The Braves tonight purchased Sylvester (Blix) Donnelly, a right-handed pitcher, from the Phillies for an undisclosed sum.

For the sixth consecutive trading day wool futures and wool tops dropped the daily limit of 10 cents a pound yesterday. May wool ended at $2.812 and May tops at $3.47 a pound. This makes the cumulative loss 60 cents a pound since trading was resumed a week ago yesterday after a nine-week shutdown.

Despite a marked upsurge in offshore employment in the last six months of 1950, the Seamen's Church Institute of New York was hard pressed to meet its commitments in the twelve-month period ended Dec. 31.

A sharp decline in private residential construction has brought the total building activity in New York City down 13 per cent for the first three months of this year as compared with the corresponding period last year, according to...
The cotton, futures market was quiet yesterday, and final prices were unchanged to 26 points net higher, except for October, 1952, which closed 30 points lower.

HOBOKEN, N.J., April 16-- Castle Stevens, century-old home of one of New Jersey's first families and for the last forty years a center of activities on the campus, of Stevens Institute of Technology here, is being restored in a $100,000 project under the sponsorship of the Alumni Association of the institute.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 16--North Korea's first proposal for a peace conference to end the Korean war was received here today. Presumably the participants in such a conference would be the Big Five, with Peiping sitting for China.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 17-- John Foster Dulles, special Presidential envoy, told the Japanese people today that American political leadership, irrespective of party, was determined to conclude a prompt peace with Japan in line with the policies of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, April 16--Clark Griffith's finely calculated plans for a rousing opening of the 1951 American League season, featuring President Harry Truman, the world champion Yankees and the Senators, all had to be re-calculated today when rain caused a complete washout of the program.

Restful pale blond color schemes with sharp accents of brilliant color are used for four of seven model rooms opening today at Bloomingdale's. Two of these rooms, a bedroom and dining room, are furnished with new pieces by California designer Paul Frankl.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The Stars and Stripes snapshot of General Eisenhower--when he was told at Coblenz that General MacArthur had been relieved of his duties in the Far East--is one of those rare news photographs which reveal more than words can do.
Jim Rathschmidt of Yale paid his tribute yesterday to the Cambridge University crew that defeated the Elis on the Housatonic River Saturday at Derby, Conn.
Following is the text of Mayor Impellitteri's special proclamation yesterday naming Friday as "MacArthur Day":

WASHINGTON, April 16--The political leaders in exile of nine Iron Curtain countries organized today a Central-Eastern European Committee for the purpose of fighting the Communists at home and planning for the liberation and unification of all such nations into a regional union within a united Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The political leaders in exile of nine Iron Curtain countries organized today a Central-Eastern European Committee for the purpose of fighting the Communists at home and planning for the liberation and unification of all such nations into a regional union within a united Europe.

New York steel Warehouses are facing a dangerous depletion of inventories during June, pending arrival of the effective date of the Controlled Materials Plan on July 1, industry spokesmen disclosed here yesterday in a canvass of current trends.

New York housewives are doing a "first-rate job" in their first experience as Social Security tax collectors for Uncle Sam. This tribute came yesterday from internal revenue officials in the metropolitan area as they waded through the first flood of quarterly tax returns filed by local housewives in behalf of their domestic servants.

WASHINGTON, April 16--Senate Republicans demanded today an investigation of all the Truman Administration's foreign and military policies as a consequence of President Truman's dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from his Far East commands.

ATHENS, April 16 (AP)--Nearly complete returns from Greece's first municipal elections in seventeen years showed today that Right-Wing and Liberal coalition candidates scored crushing victories over Communist and LeftWing opponents in nearly all major towns and cities.

"NEXT to the atom bomb, the most ominous force in the world today is uncontrolled fertility." Too many people are being born in much of the world; the wrong people are being born in parts of the world. Very little is being done about the problem and most people don't even realize that it exists.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)-- Representative Walter E. Brehm, Republican of Ohio, went on trial in Federal court today, charged with unlawfully receiving campaign contributions from two women employes in his office.

Two New Jersey schoolboys, in search of "adventure," returned here yesterday aboard the French liner Ile de France after an unsuccessful attempt to visit Europe. The youths, convinced that the escapade was well worth any punishment they may face, stowed away on the promenade deck when the ship left here March 30.
Having been given a few appetizers in the way of spring exhibitions, the country's hungry baseball fans today will be served the main course by sixteen major league teams in eight cities.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16 (AP)-- Public Service Coordinated Transport will ask for a ten-cent bus fare soon, George H. Blake, company president, said today. The company serves most of New Jersey and has one of the largest bus fleets in the nation.

LONDON, April 16--Iran's Ambassador in London, Ali Soheily, issued a warning today against British intervention in the disturbances and strikes around the British-operated oil fields in Southern Iran.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 16--Operations were at a virtual standstill today at the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company's giant Abadan refinery on the Persian Gulf, although, in the absence of strike pickets, 3,300 men had reported for work this morning.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 17 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 856, covering twenty-four hours up to 6 A.M. Tuesday (4 P.M., Eastern standard time, Monday):

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., APRIL 16--Leaders of the Westchester Board of Supevrisors and county departments endorsed today the proposed granting of an $850,000 easement across park and parkway lands for a pipeline to carry natural gas from Texas and Louisiana to the New England states.

Squared Away, owned by Mrs. Jan Burke of Miami Beach, won the six-furlong feature event at Jamaica yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Piping Rock gave a fine exhibition to take the race, known as The Flags, against the challenges of five others.

THIS reporter's private pipeline in the American League is a star whose predictions have been uncannily accurate in the past. A year ago, for instance, he picked the Yankees to win without the slightest bit of hesitation. But his gift of prophecy is like that of fabled Cassandra. It goes unheeded.

We are convinced that Mayor Impellitteri is multiplying trouble for himself by remaining silent while the Transport Workers Union and Michael J. Quill voice open threats of a strike on the city transit system.
A philosophical dispute that left the theoretical plane and descended to fisticuffs between two Vassar College professors has split the Philosophy Department at the Poughkeepsie women's institution.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The American Bar Association's Commission on Organized Crime, meeting here today, decided that the Senate Crime Investigating Committee should be continued only long enough for it to draft and obtain passage of what Federal legislation it considered necessary to correct demonstrated evils.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The recent approval by Congress of President Truman's plan to reorganize the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has not deterred the efforts of Senator Harry F. Byrd to have the lending agency abolished.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The sixtieth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution opened tonight with a message from President Truman on the fight against "Communist imperialism" and an address by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath on spies and saboteurs in this country.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The Office of Price Stabilization said today that teams of enforcement officers had been ordered into several cities to investigate reports of ceiling price violations in three industrial fields.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- Southpaw Harry Truman, whose opening-game pitching assignment was postponed by rain, learned today he had a namesake in the major leagues back is 1892 who preferred to perform under an assumed name.
Brooklyn's special grand jury opened yesterday its inquiry into the activities of the Department of Investigation during four years of the administration of former May or William O'Dwyer.

Neil MacNeil will retire on Thursday as assistant night managing editor' of THE NEW YORK TIMES. He has served THE TIMES in that position since 1930. He joined its staff as a copy editor in the spring of 1918.

BUENOS AIRES, April 16 (AP)-- La Epoca, an afternoon paper that supports the policies of President Juan Peron, accused THE NEW YORK TIMES today of fostering the formation of an international press institute in Switzerland to get a monopoly of Europe's newsprint.
Today is regarded as the anniversary of the year-old public school teachers' boycott of extracurricular activities in New York City.
GENEVA, April 16--The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions has filed four complaints with the International Labor Office charging violation of trade union rights by governments.

"Angels Kiss Me," first play by Scott Michel, mystery story writer, will open this evening at 8:15 at the National Theatre. It is being produced by the author's sister, Truth Michel, a newcomer to the New York stage, whose theatrical experience includes putting on variety programs on the "borscht circuit."

SPLIT ROCK, Pa., April 16-- The proverb concerning the rain which falls upon the "just and unjust" has no application for trout fishermen, but the same rain that brimmed the Catskill trout streams fell upon eastern Pennsylvania and provided high, cold and discolored waters for the opening-day anglers.

A new curry base--not the first, to be sure, but very good of its kind--is here for those who cook in a hurry. Sometimes judging from the comments made to this department we gather that all New York homemakers are included in the cook-in-haste category.
WASHINGTON, April 16-- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, today began a campaign to restore a "singe-package" appropriations bill.

WASHINGTON, April 16--An attack on the constitutionality of New York's Sabbath Law that restricts but does not ban all commercial activities on Sundays was refused a review today by the Supreme Court. It held that no substantial Federal question was involved.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 16 (Reuters)--The Pakistani Minister for Kashmir Affairs, Mushtaq Ahmad Gurmani, warned today that "the simmering cauldron" of tension between India and Pakistan "may overflow at any moment."

Many school children who are backward in their classroom work could be transformed into bright students if the lighting and interior decoration of their classrooms were changed, Dr. Darell Boyd Harmon of Austin, Tex., told the Eastern States Optometric Congress yesterday.

ALEXANDRIA, La., April 16 (AP) --James Shelton, president of the American Bankers Association said today that the Government should look to persons earning less than $6,000 a year if big revenue was needed.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 16--Veljko Vlahovic, president of the Foreign Affairs Council of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced today that the Swiss Government had been asked to protect the Yugoslav Legation in Budapest in the event of a rupture between Yugoslavia and Hungary.
The Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish was named rector emeritus of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn at the regular meeting last night of the church vestry.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest single corporate enterprise, reported yesterday that its net income for the first quarter of this year amounted to $79,370,000. This was more than ample to cover the communication system's $2.25 ...

WASHINGTON, April 16 (U.P.)-- Representative O.K. Armstrong, Republican of Missouri, said today that Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway and "practically every high ranking officer" in Japan and Korea agreed a complete victory could not be won without carrying the Korean war into Manchuria.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)-- Secretary of State Dean Acheson today renewed his plea to Congress for wheat for India. Again, he stressed, famine was general in the country.
April 28, the Saturday before May Day, was designated as Loyalty Day by proclamation of Mayor Impellitteri yesterday.
Industry was told yesterday to assume leadership in solving community-wide "smog" problems.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 --Julian Lesser, independent pro ducer and son of Sol Lesser, and Col. James Carreras of London have formed a new company, Royal Productions, to film "Whispering Smith Investigates," a mystery involving the character created by Frank H. Spearman.

Moderate selling was sufficient yesterday to halt the stock market's recovery drive. Prices generally followed a zigzag course through the greater part of the session with worst quotations posted in the final hour.
In the belief that New York could be reasonably quiet if the public was made aware of and observed existing anti-noise laws, Mayor Impellitteri has set aside this week as Noise Abatement Week.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 16 (AP)--Dale Money, 29-year-old Southern amateur titleholder from Dallas, Tex., posted a three-under par 69 to win the qualifying medal today in the fifty-first North and South amateur golf tournament.
In two widely separated suburban communities women have been pressed into service as traffic officers to protect school crossings.
One hundred twenty rabbinical students in Brooklyn gave a pint of blood each yesterday to aid a fellow student who is a hemophiliac and who had been injured.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 17-- United Nations troops fought their way yesterday into Yachon, at the eastern end of the Hwachon Reservoir line.

LONDON, April 16--The suggestion by Italy's Foreign Minister, Count Carlo Sforza, that the United States, Britain and France should issue a statement renouncing the peace treaty with Italy has had an unenthusiastic reception in London.

The Duke of Windsor, as brisk and cheerful as any author whose first book has just bloomed in a shower of favorable notices, sat at a green baize table in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday and talked about his memoirs of education and abdication, "A King's Story."

LONDON, April 16--The staccato shouts of London's dignified tea brokers were heard again in Mincing Lane today in the first auctions since 1939 as the Government handed the makings of Britain's proverbial beverage back to private trading. However, tea remains subject to strict price controls, rationing and subsidies.

Importers expressed disappointment yesterday at the Office of Price Stabilization's continued delay in issuing a special order to free a large part of the trade from general ceiling controls. They were informed that action was expected "within twenty-four hours."

WASHINGTON, April 16--Representative Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, disclosed today he had suggested to President Truman that United States forces "dehumanize" a belt across the entire peninsula of Korea by radiological contamination, thus preventing any further counter-attacks by Chinese and North Korean Communist forces.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture announced today that permits would be issued for the export of about 1,939,000 tons, about 74,000,000 bushels, of wheat, coarse grains and soybeans in May.

WASHINGTON, April 16--Democratic members of the California delegation in the House of Representatives are urging a Congressional investigation into the House redistricting being conducted in that state.

PARIS, April 16--The deteriorating relations between France and the Moroccan Arab Nationalists, including Sultan Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef, were the subject of emergency consultations here today between Gen. AlphonsePierre Juin,...
The fighting in Korea yesterday was--as it has been for many months now--vicious but indecisive; no end was in sight.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (U.P.)-- The Government has paid out $8,166,151,533 in Civil War pensions and still is writing checks at a $6,000,000-a-year rate for that conflict--which ended eighty-six years ago.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.-- April 16--With its productive capacity 60 per cent larger than in 1940, American industry can meet the nation's defense needs and still produce enough for the civilian economy, Frank M. Folsom, president of the Radio Corporation of America, said tonight at the student legal forum of the University of Virginia.

Two compositions were played for the first time last night by the National Orchestral Association in Carnegie Hall. It was the last of four Monday evening concerts offered by the organization under the able direction of Leon Barzin. This is its twentieth season.

LONDON, April 16--Unless Britain's allocation of sulphur from the United States for the second quarter is bigger than for the first three months of this year, Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today, rayon production would have to be cut by 40 per cent.

YONKERS, April 16--Time was, not so long ago, when a daylong rain would have canceled a harness racing program. Now, however, when mutuel machines laugh at the weather, it's business as usual and so the local 1951 season for trotters and pacers...
Thirteen men and three women said to be sellers in a Harlem narcotics ring that supplied 300 addicts, including school children, were arrested yesterday by Federal agents.
WASHINGTON, April 16--President Truman notified Congress today that he had authorized the shipment of $29,000,000 worth of raw materials and other supplies to support the armed forces of Yugoslavia.
The Long Island Lighting Company in 1950 completed one of its most successful years, Edward F. Barrett, president, told stockholders in the annual report, released yesterday.

The moving tomorrow of Pan American World Airways, local terminal to the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, completes the relocation of 1,200 employes, tons of office and maintenance equipment and a fleet of thirty-three clippers.

PARIS, Tuesday, April 17-- Agreement on a board or High Authority of nine members to administer the proposed single market for coal and steel under the Schuman Plan was reached at a seven-hour meeting of the foreign ministers of the six negotiating Governments that ended early this morning.
United Paramount Theatres, Inc., showed consolidated net earnings of $12,351,000 last year, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, reports in the annual statement issued today.
The Senate has approved the reorganization plan for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation submitted to it by the President.
Completion, of final plans last night for "MacArthur Day" on Friday forecast a record-breaking reception by New York's millions for the returning General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

LONDON, April 16--The Soviet Union declared tonight it had successfully completed its latest five-year plan for industrial expansion and boosted production by 73 per cent over 1940. The Moscow radio broadcast the Soviet announcement.

HONOLULU, April 16--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, clad in his familiar battered; faded and gold-braided battle cap, olive drab battle jacket and slacks, received his first pub lic ovation since he came back to American soil here today.

WASHINGTON, April 16--A huge official welcome for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur on Thursday was assured today when the White House lined up behind a semiofficial program being developed by civic groups.
General MacArthur returns to the mainland of the United States today after an absence of fourteen years.
The distraught mother of a 7-month-old child, resigned to the verdict of doctors and ophthalmologists, gently moved her baby's hands over her face. He felt tears he would never see.

In an all-out drive to liquidate top-heavy factory and distributor television receiver inventories, Admiral Corporation gave its 25,000 dealers yesterday the strongest inducement to buy yet offered by any producer.

LONDON, April 16--A busy session on the stock market here saw continued demand today for good-class investments bring appreciable gains to the leading industrial issues. British Government securities remained dull.

The finding of $1,590 in cash in the flat of a $37.50-a-week night watchman at the Racquet and Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue, led to the arrest yesterday of three men on charges of complicity in last Saturday's theft of $13,800 in cash and travelers' checks from the club safe.

LONDON, April 16--Even as leaders of all political parties were eulogizing Ernest Bevin, former Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons today, there was considerable speculation regarding the effect his death might have on the fortunes of the Labor party.

Despite recent declines in the Australian auctions, wool prices still range from 25 to 50 cents a pound more than they did at the end of 1950 it was declared yesterday. Mills, therefore, are still unable to quote prices for civilian business under the Office of Price Stabilization interim wool order that permits "pass-through" of costs until Dec. 31.
Bulgaria's Communist Government is struggling desperately to stem a large-scale peasant exodus from newly formed collective farms, a broadcast by Sofia radio reveals.

CHICAGO, April 16--The grain markets showed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade here today, with wheat up around 2 cents a bushel at the top, with the close 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents higher, profittaking checking the advance.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)-- United Gas Improvement Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to allow it "to acquire not exceeding 363,285 shares of its outstanding capital stock in exchange for shares of Consumers Power Company and Philadelphia Electric Company."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 16 (U.P.)--United States Ambassador Robert Murphy declared bluntly tonight that there were "doubts" in Washington concerning the size of Belgium's contribution to Western defense.

A compact, portable machine that provides a completely mechanical system of collecting and processing human blood was demonstrated for the first time yesterday at the Cornell University Medical School.

CINCINNATI, April 18 (AP)--A pair of southpaws--Cliff Chambers and Willie Werle--today hurled the Pirates to a frigid 4--3 victory over the Reds in the opening game of the National League's seventysixth season.

WASHINGTON, April 17--Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, introduced a resolution today to extend the life of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee until next Jan. 15. Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, was a co-sponsor of the resolution.

PITTSBURGH, April 17 (AP)-- Southpaw Bill Werle put out the fire again today as the Pirates defeated the Cardinals, 5-4, before 25,894 chilled fans who braved snow flurries and 40-degree temperatures at Forbes Field.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 17--Top United Nations circles were in consultation today on whether to reply to North Korea's "demand" that the Korean problem be settled at a conference of all the countries concerned.

By way of opening its second week at the Metropolitan Opera House last night the Ballet Theatre elected to present the second ballet in the repertoire of its guest artists, Jean Babilee and Nathalie Philippart.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)-- Secretary of State Dean Acheson expressed the belief today that recent events should cause no delay in working out a Japanese Peace treaty.

Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City, who made political history two years ago in ending the thirty-year reign of Frank Hague, successfully weathered in the Democratic primaries yesterday a strong bid for a comeback by the remnants, of the Hague dynasty.

An international conference will be held next month in England and Scotland by representatives of the world's two major ruling golf bodies, the United States Association and the Royal and Ancient Club of St. Andrews. Scotland.

The recently announced Controlled Materials Plan of the National Production Authority is expected by industrial purchasing executives to work smoothly after its introductory period. This opinion is contrary to earlier views expressed in other quarters.

WASHINGTON, April 17--A Republican demand for a joint Congressional investigation of all the high military and foreign policies of the Truman Administration was blocked today, temporarily at least, by Senate Democrats.

WASHINGTON, April 17--Some Republican Senators have indicated privately that they are having some sober second thoughts about the political value of championing General of the Army Douglas MacArthur against President Truman, and especially about adopting wholesale General MacArthur's "Asia First" policy.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 17-- Struggling with the problem of functioning in a dual militarycivilian economy, the vanguard of an expected 11,000 packaging, production and marketing executives poured into Convention Hall here this afternoon for the opening of the twentieth National Packaging Exposition, largest in the history of the show which is sponsored by the American Management Association.

HANK SOAR the umpire, was stationed in the grandstand before the opening game at the Yankee Stadium yesterday with ex plicit instructions to see that the no-fraternizing rule was enforced. It's a pretty hopeless task because ball players are human enough to prefer shaking hands in greeting than spitting in the other guy's eye. But Hank's vision is conveniently short and doesn't expand to full range until game time. He saw nothing.

PARIS, April 17--Another Western redraft for a Big Four foreign ministers agenda was submitted to the deputies' conference in the Palais Rose today. Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet deputy, in preliminary comments raised his usual objections. He said that inclusion of an item on Trieste was a step forward and promised to give the text further study.
For the last time residents of the Hebrew Home for the Aged cast backward glances yesterday at their dilapidated brownstone residences at 114-20 East 105th Street.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP)--First Baseman Dee Fondy belted a basesloaded triple in his first major league time at bat to pace the Cubs to an 8-3 victory over the Reds before a Wrigley Field opening day crowd of 18,211 today.

CHICAGO, April 17--The grain markets were under pressure from the opening on the Board of Trade here today, except May wheat, which developed independent strength on talk that Britain and the Netherlands were in the market for 4,000,000 bushels and might take the grain over night. May wheat gained to 7/8 cent a bushel, with the new-crop months 5/8 to 1 5/8 cents lower, closing at about the bottom.

Two developments of opposite nature featured commodity trading in New York yesterday. First, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, sole importer and seller of tin in the United States, slashed its official price 5 cents a pound to $1.42. Second, wool, which has fallen 60 cents since trading was resumed on April 9 after a nineweek market suspension, failed to drop the 10-cent daily limit for the first time since its market reopened.
The possibility that New York City will have to seek an increase in its real estate levy to meet anticipated progressively higher budgets was conceded yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph.

All citizens of New York were invited yesterday to be vaccinated against tuberculosis at the Central Harlem Health Center, 2238 Fifth Avenue, and the Fort Green Health Center in Brooklyn, the only two stations run by the city that offer this service.

A new quarterly high record of $209,000,000 in sales was achieved in the first three months of this year by the United States Rubber Company, 60 per cent more than a year ago, shareholders learned yesterday at their annual meeting in Passaic, N.J. The previous peak was made in the final quarter of 1950 with sales of $208,619,007, Herbert E. Smith, chairman, reported.

Oriental touches lend an exotic tone to a group of new rooms at Abraham Straus. This look is emphasized by the fact that the new pieces of furniture these rooms introduce are made of teak, a wood usually associated with the Far East.

The beauty, wit and unflagging inspiration of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" won the hearts of the 1,500 persons who crowded Town Hall last night to hear the second of the three Mozart operas that the Little Orchestra Society is presenting there in concert versions under the auspices of the Town Hall Music Committee.

Seven international-minded schoolmates--all of high school age--with two sacks of wheat, $50 and a plan for a nation-wide campaign to send grain to India, presented themselves, their gifts and their idea yesterday at the Indian Consulate, 3 East Sixty-fourth Street.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 17--Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said here today that unless the present world situation changed critically the draft quotas for the next few months would be considerably lower than they had been.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 17--The Iranian Foreign Ministry tonight accused the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company of complicity in fomenting strikes and outbreaks of violence that forced the company's giant Abadan refinery to shut down Saturday evening.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP)-- Air Secretary Thomas K. Finletter told newspaper editors today that the Air Force "sincerely regrets the reported mistreatment" of news photographers by Air Force Military Police when General of the Army Douglas MacArthur arrived in Honolulu.
ORANGE, N.J., April 17--Dr. Linn Emerson, an oculist here for fifty years and a pioneer in several spheres of eye care, died today at Orange Memorial Hospital. His age was 77.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos, will make a return engagement at the Roxy Theatre. Opening on May 9, the engagement will, like the previous one, occupy two weeks, in which four performances daily will be given.

PARIS, April 17--The foreign ministers of the six Schuman plan countries virtually agreed tonight on a kind of economic government for coal and steel that was designed to serve as a model and a precursor for an eventual federal union of Europe.
On behalf of the Virginia Day Nursery, Mrs. George M. Grinnell, president of the organization, will give a reception and tea this afternoon in her home, 57 East Eightieth Street.

Station WINS and Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, ended their year-old dispute yesterday when the station agreed to rehire a staff of eight musicians under a new contract running to March 31, 1953. The station had declined to renew its union contract in March, 1950, and dismissed the musicians at that time, playing recorded music exclusively on its programs.

LONDON, April 17--National consternation that the Festival of Britain's "centerpiece," the exhibition on the Thames south bank, might not be ready for its opening on May 4 appeared to be allayed today. Festival spokesmen said it was "certain" that 95 per cent of the exhibition would be completed by opening day.

Jewish housewives preparing for the Passover, which starts Friday evening, will find that prices of whitefish, always a favorite for the holiday, have risen to approximately $1.50 a pound. Moscow announces that the Fourth Five-Year Plan of the U.S.S.R. has been successfully fulfilled. The goals for such commodities as steel, electric power, petroleum and coal were substantially exceeded, it adds proudly, noting too that the devastated industry of the west has been rebuilt, while production has risen sharply in the Urals and Siberia.

Five hundred persons prominent, in Jewish philanthropy and commural activity attended a dinner meeting last night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, at which the Greater New York Committee for State of Israel Bonds formally opened its campaign.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., April 17--Although the first flurry of angling excitement was dissapated over the week-end, most of the popular trout waters of eastern Pennsylvania and central New Jersey continued to attract a large number of anglers, despite the prevalence of high, cold and discolored waters.
The cotton, future market on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather quiet and final prices were unchanged to 39 points net lower.

Ground operations in Korea continued according to plan Tuesday, with our units advancing against negligible to light resistance.

Lady Astor, the American-born former member of the British Parliament, said yesterday that it was "of such vast importance" that the United States be united and strong at this time that it would be tragic and "very bad for the country" if a political fight developed over President Truman's dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

The stock market followed a middle-of-the-road course yesterday. As a result, the market closed almost in perfect balance although the composite rate showed an increase of 0.29 point due to the advance in a few components making up THE NEW YORK TIMES index.

More than twice as many Americans have been killed in home accidents as on the battle front since the start of the Korean war, Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin said last night. A ceiling price order on exports to be issued in a matter of days by the Office of Price Stabilization will be generally liberal and easy to understand, members of the Export Managers Club were informed yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 17-- Syria presented her charges against Israel today before the Security Council. She accused that country of having defied the United Nations and cited the fate of North Korea, which, she said, was the last country to indulge in similar defiance.

WASHINGTON, April 17--The Securities and Exchange Commission issued an order today granting the Electric Bond and Share Company of New York additional time in which to dispose of its remaining interests in the Florida Power and Light Company and the Montana Power Company. LONDON, April 17--The British Government issued a White Paper today defending its concurrence in the selection of an American admiral as supreme commander in the North Atlantic. The "hardest part of growing up" for many women comes in their first years is grandmothers, Dr. Mary Fisher Langmuir, chairman of the Department of Child Study, Vassar College, told a group of mothers and grandmothers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17--The State Department has eased its visa restrictions against former or current members of totalitarian organizations. The new rules exempt persons who joined involuntarily or who were not 16 years of age when they were members.

WASHINGTON, April 17--President Truman has given Secretary of State Dean Acheson the major voice in determining the allocation of an anticipated $10,500,000,000 foreign aid appropriation according to military assistance, economic support programs and by principal political areas.

WASHINGTON,--April 17--A delegation from the National Farmers Union called on President Truman today to urge against any Administration request fox Congressional authority to fix farm price ceilings below parity.

Vandenberg, Republican foreign policy leader and advocate of international cooperation for world peace, who had fought against failing health in order to continue his service in Washington, died peacefully in his sleep at 9:40 o'clock tonight in his home. The musical version of Betty Smith's best-seller, "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Alvin Theatre. Arthur Schwartz has composed the music and Dorothy Fields has written the lyrics.
