Say a word of thanks to Nanette Fabray and the other performers of "Make a Wish," which opened at the Winter Garden last evening. Say a particular word of thanks to Gower Champion, who has designed one of the swiftest satirical ballets we have had in any musical show. For these are the people who have made the most enjoyable contributions to a routine comedy with a grab-bag book and a mediocre score.

Somewhere along the line as they go gunning for Casey Stengel's third successive pennant, our Yankees are expected to run into a spot of trouble. But if it's to come from the Red Sox, these perennial spring favorites once again are taking their own sweet time getting around to it.

MYERS PARKS, N.C., April 18 --In the Myers Park Presbyterian Church this evening, Miss Kathryn king Goods of Charlotte, daughter of Mrs. Newson Goods of Sarasota Fla., and Flat Rock, and A. Lloyd Goods of Charlotte was married to David Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thorne Clark of Lincolnton, this state.

WASHINGTON, April 18--About 400 prominent figures of the newspaper world from all parts of the nation will assemble here tomorrow for the annual convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

JERSEY CITY, April 18--Manpower shortages in more than 150 leading industries are being eased by new systems of "unit loading" for such products as frozen foods, electronic equipment, machine parts and castings, it was disclosed here today.

Two small boys, whose yearning for a pet drove them to spend a night in a barrel, were safe at home yesterday. And by a stroke of good fortune and the kindness of two neighbors, the lads had their pet--a small black and white kitten.

PARIS, April 18--The treaty to give effect to the Schuman plan to create a single market for the coal and steel production of France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg was signed at the French Foreign Ministry today by the foreign ministers of those six countries. It will now be submitted to their parliaments for ratification.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 18 (AP)--Anton Novak, former radio operator at the Yugoslav Embassy here, said at a news conference today he had resigned from the Embassy last week and asked for political asylum on his own free will.
Strength in the Australian wool auctions was felt here yesterday, when wool futures and wool top futures rose the 10-cent daily limit, sharply reversing the trend of the seven trading days preceding.

More than two dozen little girls from 2 to 10 years old frolicked down the runway of the Sert Room at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel during luncheon yesterday. The occasion was Georg Jensen's fashion show of children's clothes.
OTTAWA, April 18 (Canadian Press)--The Canadian Defense Production Department today declared newsprint an essential material and prepared to bring it under Government control.

Our ground forces patrolled deep into hostile territory Wednesday without significant contact as enemy opposition continued to be generally light. Substantial advances were registered in the Chipo sector against negligible resistance, while farther east advancing units dispersed a delaying group in the mountains north of Inje.
Tenants in Manhattan's towering apartment buildings got tentative assurances yesterday that a strike of elevator operators would not force the residents to trudge up and down stairs this week-end.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18-- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur brought to a climax one of the greatest receptions ever given to a famous visitor by San Francisco with the announcement today that he did not intend to run for political office.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP)-- Mrs. Clara Soliday, 75-year-old former clerk, told a Federal court jury today she turned over part of her salary to Representative Walter E. Brehm, Republican of Ohio, for three years while she worked in his office.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 18 (AP) --Amateur golf's name players toppled like tenpins today as the North and South tournament's second and third rounds produced an unprecedented number of astonishing results.

A bronze plaque testifying to consistent leadership in accuracy, completeness and impartiality of news reporting was presented yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Advertising Club of New York to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the founding of THE TIMES.
LECCE, Italy, April 6 (By Airmail)--Lack of funds and technical equipment is seriously handicapping and retarding the development of Italy's Air Force.

Lack of essential materials needed for both civilian and defense-supporting industry will force curtailment of production in the New York metropolitan area and cause widespread unemployment in the coming months, according to testimony yesterday at a Brooklyn hearing of a subcommittee of the House Small Business Committee.
TRENTON, April 18 (AP)-- Superior Court Judge Ralph J. Smalley refused today to allow one of the alleged confessions in the Trenton six murder case to be read to the jury.

The sixth floor in the twentyfour-story office building being completed by the Madison-60th Corporation at 655 Madison Avenue has been leased by the Lawrence C. Gumbinner Advertising Agency, Inc., through Cushman

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- The State Department today branded North Korea's week-end message to the United Nations as a "propaganda" statement that "does not look to us even remotely like a peace feeler."

Two recently promoted lieutenants in the Fire Department and a former records clerk for the Veterans Administration were indicted yesterday on charges they had conspired to forge records in the V.A. that had allowed the firemen to obtain promotions. The firemen, suspended from duty, were accused of paying the clerk $600 each to falsify medical certificates.

PARIS, April 18--As a result of the unsatisfactory confidence vote that he obtained from the National Assembly yesterday, Premier Henri Queuille was obliged today to ask for another vote. The result of M. Queuille's decision was to place before the Assembly the alternative of accepting elections on June 10 or of forcing a Cabinet crisis.

NEW HAVEN, April 18--"Going Places," a guide to the campuses, customs and codes of nineteen Eastern colleges for women, compiled by a group of Yale students, has just been pub lished here. The handbook gives details of the dating habits, modes of dress and attitudes towards collegiate courtship, according to its editors. It was compiled "because so many college men spend both time and money on week-ends at women's colleges.

WASHINGTON, April 18--President Truman decided today to set up an eighteen-man Wage Stabilization Board of labor, industry and public members as recommended by his National Advisory Board on Mobilization Policy yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18--President Truman announced formally today plans to negotiate mutual assistance treaties linking the United States, New Zealand and Australia to come to the aid of one another if any one of them faced armed attack in the Pacific.

Fifty members of the Investment Association of New York yesterday heard a debate on incorporation of New York Stock Exchange firms between Amyas Ames of Kidder, Peabody Co. and Walter Maynard of Shearson, Hammill Co.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 18--The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company reported here tonight that the labor situation had deteriorated further at its Abadan refinery in the course of the day, that intimidation of men wishing to return to their job was increasing and that frequent threats of violence had been heard.

A point-by-point comparison of transport type planes powered by jet and piston engines shows that neither has a clear-cut overall advantage over the other, according to a report submitted to the Society of Automotive Engineers yesterday by two test pilots.

A freshly painted black-andwhite ship tied up at a Brooklyn pier yesterday to discharge a full load of sugar. She was the new Japanese cargo-passenger vessel Toho Maru, forty-four days out of Nagasaki on her maiden voyage.

CHICAGO, April 18--A forecast for occasional showers in the Southwestern winter wheat belt, peace talk and absence of an expected large export business were responsible for a lower range of wheat prices on the Board of Trade today. Final sales showed losses of to 1 cents.

The Cambridge University crew that defeated Yale by four lengths on the Housatonic Saturday in the first appearance of an English college eight in American waters will row its final race today before departing for home tomorrow at midnight.

Even in this era of historic and melancholy events the death of Senator Arthur Vandenberg of Michigan will take a notable place. Perhaps more than any other political figure of his time he typified America's capacity for change and growth, and symbolized our political conversion from a policy of isolation to world responsibility.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today regarding talks concerning a post-Japanese treaty security arrangement in the Pacific:

The Nation's gasoline stocks declined slightly last week, while supplies of light and heavy fuel oil increased, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline stocks amounted to 139,431,000 barrels, against the previous week's 139,728,000. A year ago supplies were 133,458,000 barrels.

LISBON, Portugal, April 18-- Marshal Antonio Oscar de Fragoso Carmona, President of the Portuguese Republic for the last twentyfive years, died today. He was in his eighty-second year. He had suffered a relapse yesterday after apparently recovering from influenza.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 18-- The nation's packaging industry was advised today to conserve packaging material by refusing more supplies or discovering other ways to make supplies go further.

MOSCOW, April 18--Charging that President Truman has made General of the Army Douglas MacArthur the scapegoat for the failure of the United States policy in the Far East, Pravda raised today the question of what steps the United States proposed to take for the peaceful settlement of the Korean conflict.
BOSTON, April 18--The Giants tumbled into their first defeat of the new campaign at the hands of Billy Southworth's Braves today.
Investors acquired store buildings in the Highbridge and Fordham sections of the Bronx in transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18--Delegates of the Daughters of the American Revolution burst into applause today at the announcement that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur would visit their Sixtieth Continental Congress tomorrow.

The latest ideas on rearing children are so strange to many parents they are liable to feel as conspicuous and uncomfortable with them as they sometimes do in brand-new clothes, Dr. Lens Levine, psychiatrist, declared yesterday. It is important, she said, for teachers to realize this and to work with parents until the ideas they accept intellectually, become a real part of their attitude.

General MacArthur left the West Coast for Washington last night with cheers of a giant San Francisco reception in his ears and his disclaimer of any political ambition being debated throughout the nation. "I have no political aspirations whatsoever," he told a crowd of 100,000 at the City Hall. "I do not intend to run for any political office. I hope that my name will never be used in any political way." [1:8.]

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 18-- The governing junta decreed a national electoral statute tonight providing for the election of a Constituent Assembly by all Venezuelans over 21 years of age regardless of literacy. The date of election will be fixed by the Supreme Electoral Council. It is expected that the voting will take place early next year.

Controller Lazarus Joseph bitterly assailed yesterday the premature release of an Education Management Study report that criticized Board of Education school construction plans and called for reorganization of the school system's administrative procedures.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts is considering receiving bids next month on a sale of $25,000,000 of bonds. The issue is to include $20,000,000 of highway bonds due over ten years and $5,000,000 of water bonds due over thirty years. The sale will take place on or about May 14.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- A Senate Banking subcommittee opened hearings today on proposals to provide a vast program of war risk insurance, broader even than that of World War II.

Officials of the National Farmers Union have announced their opposition to any change in the Defense Production Act which would place farm prices on the same basis as others for purposes of over-all price control.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- The television committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, in what it said was a move to save intercollegiate sports, today approved a plan for limited telecasts of next fall's college football games.

After an uninterrupted ownership of about 150 years, the property at the southeast corner of the Bowery and East Second Street has been sold by descendants of Augustus Wynkoop to an investing client of Henry Shapiro Co., brokers in the deal in conjunction

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18--Although all other top officials of the United Nations have been asked to Friday's reception welcoming General of the Army Douglas MacArthur to New York, the Acting Secretary General has not received an invitation, it was reliably reported today. He is Constantin E. Zinchenko, a Soviet citizen.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 18 (AP)-- Defense Production in New York State is mushrooming into a multibillion-dollar venture. Much of the story is secret, but the broad outline shows New York's diverse industry playing a major role in national preparedness.

Errol Kerr, of Scarsdale, N.Y., senior partner of Harris, Kerr, Forster Co., a national accounting firm at 18 East Forty-eighth Street, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He would have been 73 years old today.

WASHINGTON, April 18--Former President Herbert C. Hoover, in whose administration the muchinvestigated Reconstruction Finance Corporation was created as a depression measure, agreed today to testify before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on bills to reform further or abolish the lending agency.

WASHINGTON, April 18--The Congressional staff of tax experts predicted today that Federal revenues in the 1952 fiscal year, which begins July 1, would exceed revised Treasury estimates by $2,400,000,000.

Without benefit of any new developments either on the domestic, economic or international fronts, the stock market extended gains yesterday, but in a highly selective manner. The list established what is generally termed in financial circles as a "triple top."
The annual Members' Spring Concert of the Collegiate Chorale took place last night in Town Hall, with William Jonsori conducting in place of Robert Shaw, who is on leave of absence.

Allocation of the motorship Lightning under bareboat charter to the American President Lines has been approved by the Maritime Administration. The ship is intended for use primarily in transpacific refrigerated service for the Military Sea Transportation Service. She is at present in the laidup fleet at Suisun Bay, Calif.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18-- Four new properties, "A Touch of Nutmeg," "Roman Holiday" and two untitled stories, have been added to the package feature-production schedule of Huntington Hartford 3d, Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company heir, who already has filmed two such properties for inclusion in the first of three multiple-subject pictures he plans to make.

WASHINGTON, April 18--Dean Acheson, Secretaty of State, strongly defended Administration Far East policy tonight and indirectly classed General of the Army Douglas MacArthur as an extremist who would risk world war.
CHICAGO, April 18--A new kind of blasting agent that is said to emit no flame or spark to set off deadly underground explosions is being tested experimentally in Illinois coal mines.

ROME, April 18--In an officially inspired statement to be published in tomorrow's press the Italian Government says this is the right moment to deal with "the question of the Italian peace treaty as a whole" and not later as suggested abroad.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP)-- Dr. Edward A. Rumely, executive secretary of the Committee for Constitutional Government, was convicted today on three contemptof-Congress counts despite favorable last-minute testimony by a Republican member of the committee he defied.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, to whom this city will pay an all-out tribute tomorrow, is to arrive tonight at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, at about 8 o'clock instead of at 5:30, as originally scheduled.

A sale of modern paintings scheduled tonight at the Lincoln Galleries, Inc., has been canceled. "We are not canceling the sale on the basis that the paintings are fakes," said F. Coughlan, vice president, "but simply because there is a difference of opinion about them."

WASHINGTON, Aprl 18--The Department of Defense, proposing a long-range civilian Reserve program to provide "realistic security" for the nation, disclosed today that the fighting forces in June would start releasing Reservists called up to meet emergency needs as a result of the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- Following is the text of the address by Secretary of State Dean Acheson tonight to the Women's National Press Club:

SAN MATEO, Calif., April 18 (AP)--Mighty Citation, the ace of the great Calumet Farm racing stable and the greatest money winner in race track history, ran the worst race of his life today before 9,080 at Bay Meadows.

CARDIFF, Wales, April 18-- Britain's rearmament drive is beginning to show results. Slowly but with gathering speed, new weapons are coming off production lines and, to quote one Government arms expert, "There isn't much yet but what there is, is good."

The Freedom Bell clanged yesterday through the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel as Miss Dorothy Shaver, president of Lord Taylor, presented its fourteenth annual American Design awards to four recipients for helping to preserve the ideals of freedom.

The first major report to emerge from the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey is a 311-page document submitted by George D. Strayer and Louis E. Yavner dealing with "some aspects" of the problem of public school plant, its more efficient use, its better maintenance, and how ...
All radio and television facilities will be turned over at 12:30 P.M. today for coverage of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's speech before a joint session of Congress.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18-- The Port of Philadelphia won today its two-month fight to block the Marine Corps from seizing its new $6,000,000 pier for use as a warehouse.
High in importance on the trousseau list of every bride-to-be are negligee and lingerie items. The selections of both in the stores now are lovely enough to fulfill every dream.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- The air chiefs of the United States, Britain, France and Canada will meet here within two weeks. The Air Force announced today only that the joint meeting "will afford an opportunity to review the progress being made by the air forces of the four nations concerned."
Mrs. Rose Baran of 2345 Broadway, founder of the New York Philanthropic League of the United Order of True Sisters, which aids crippled children, died yesterday in French Hospital at the age of 92.

ALOYSIUS JEROME EGAN died last week. In the death of Wish Egan baseball lost one of its most fabulously successful scouts and this reporter lost one of the closest friends he had in the sport. It is no accident that the Detroit Tigers have been prime pennant contenders ever since they were organized. But no one man contributed more than Wish Egan.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- Russel A. Heddleston, a former War Assets Administration official, testified today that he saw nothing irregular in the agency's accepting payment from a Michigan aircraft parts dealer for surplus property sent to an Indiana public school.

The Port of New York is maintaining its pre-eminence despite a steady barrage of propaganda by ambitious outports seeking to win away some of its business, Hubert C. Magee, president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York, asserted last night.

The cumbersome structure of the State Department has baffled many a Secretary before Mr. Acheson, but few have been better acquainted with the problems involved. For the present Secretary was himself a member of the Hoover Commission on Reorganization of the Government, and a good many of the Hoover recommendations concerning ...

The lobby of the Ritz-Carlton has an air of hushed waiting for the day--coming within a few weeks--when the hotel will close forever. But below stairs, the kitchens still hum with the organized turmoil of many hands busy at meal preparations. The dining rooms will remain open till the hotel's last day. Presiding over the staff is the famous chef, Louis Diat, who has been with the Ritz fifty years.

Although great strides have been made in recent years toward helping handicapped children, much still remains to be done, Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chairman of the Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center and associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared last night.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet Wednesday, and closing prices were unchanged to 9 points higher.
The possibility of a system of children's allowances for the protection of the children of New York should be looked into, Henry L. McCarthy, the city's next Welfare Commissioner, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- Announced United States casualties in Korea reached 60,775 today, an increase of 1,379 over last week.

William S. Richardson, president of B.F. Goodrich Chemical Company, has been elected a vice president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, John L. Collyer, chairman and president, announced yesterday. Mr. Richardson will continue as president of the chemical company.

NEWARK, April 18--A bond issue of $10,000,000 to $20,000,000 to finance the acquisition of 500,000 acres of submarginal land in New Jersey for future improvement was among the recommendations in a report issued tonight by the Division of Planning and Development of the Department of Conservation and Economic Development of New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, April 19--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended April 14 totaled 777,989 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 19--Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan won the second round today in a bitter parliamentary battle to take a common vote with the whites from South Africa's halfcastes after an all-night sitting.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19--After a top-level meeting of Secretariat officials today it was decided that the United Nations would commence its final evacuation of Lake Success May 11.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its affiliates, world's largest oil company and third largest private enterprise in the nation, last year sold a record volume of products and made the largest profit in its history, approximating $1,114,000 a day.
The Bohack Realty Corporation has sold the two-story building at 107-23 Metropolitan Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens, to James D. Landauer Associates, Inc.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 18-- The motto on Colombia's coat of arms is "Liberty and Order." Today there is neither liberty nor order in Colombia.

ST. PAUL, April 19 (AP)--Overshadowing his more illustrious doubles partner, Clyde Potter of Akron, Ohio, rolled the first 700 series in the singles division of the forty-eighth annual American Bowling Congress today.

Physically and mentally handicapped children can, with proper care, be made a community asset or, through neglect and indifference, become a burden to themselves and their families and a financial problem to the entire community, A. Harry Moore, former Governor of New Jersey, declared yesterday.

A helicopter belonging to the Port of New York Authority made three round-trip flights yesterday between the heliport atop the Port Authority Building at 111 Eighth Avenue and New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

Private East Coast shipyards have received in the last ten days $1,956,807 worth of maintenance and repair contracts for nine vessels of the Atlantic division of the Military Sea Transportation Service.

The engagement of Miss Eleanor Buell Morris, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. DuBois S. Morris of 515 Park Avenue and Westport, Conn., to John McFarlane Morrison of Edinburgh, Scotland, son of the Rev. and Mrs. David Alexander Morrison of Dysart, Scotland, has been announced by her parents.

PARIS, April 19--Those Roman Catholic Bishops in Czechslovakia who have sworn allegiance to the Communist regime and thus incurred the wrath of the Vatican, have now apparently assured the Prague Government that they will disregard any "sanctions" applied by Rome.

LONDON, April 19--Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison revealed in the House of Commons today that Britain would have welcomed an opportunity to join in the proposed Pacific pact and hinted that Australia and New Zealand had opposed Britain's adherence.
The Finnish merchant marine, which lost more than 60 per cent of its vessels in World War II, is rapidly being expanded to its prewar size and may soon surpass its 1939 tonnage.

Plans for merging Consolidated Grocers Corporation of Chicago with the Union Sugar Company of California, were announced jointly yesterday by Nathan Cummings, chairman of Consolidated Grocers, and Roland Tognazzini, president of Union Sugar. The entire sugar business of Union Sugar and its townsite, Bettarabia, exclusive of ...

General of the Army DouglasMacArthur got a substantial foretaste last night of the welcome awaiting him today when more than 1,000,000 New Yorkers greetled him after he landed at 9:16 P. M. from his Constellation Bataan at New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices were 3 points lower to 7 points higher.

WASHINGTON, April 19--A throng that had waited through an intermittently sunny and glowering morning until General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had spoken to a joint meeting of Congress welcomed him this afternoon in ceremonies on the great green Mall on which the Washington monument is located.
Chicago, Ill., has under consideration receiving bids May 9 on issues of bonds totaling $17,400,000.
WASHINGTON, April 19--A compromise proposal aimed at breaking a six-week deadlock on aid to India was approved today by the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives.

Loans to business by banks in this area declined sharply last week, dropping $67,000,000 in the heaviest decline since April 19 of last year. The reduction, the third to be registered in the last four weeks, appears to establish a definite downtrend, and brings the total contraction since the peak this year to $108,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 19--During the week ended April 18, member bank reserves increased $141,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Patrolman John C. Lang, 47 years old, treasurer of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, left his six-room apartment in the Bronx at noon yesterday, walked over to a quiet spot in Bronx Park and killed himself with a bullet through the temple from his own service revolver.

An equestrian statue of Simon Bolivar, South American liberator, was re-dedicated in Central Park yesterday amid solemn pledges that the Americas would continue to stand firm against foreign aggression.

WASHINGTON, April 19--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's dramatic address to Congress and the country today set off immediate demands in both houses for a full investigation into the prosecution of the Korean campaign and a restudy of the situation in the Far East.

I stand on this rostrum with a sense of deep humility and great pride--humility in the wake of those great architects of our history who have stood here before me, pride in the reflection that this home of legislative debate represents human liberty in the purest form yet devised.

Ownership of the new gardentype apartment house at 6225-6245 Broadway, the Bronx, has changed through the purchase of stock of Taconic Gardens, Inc., by a customer of Pearce, Mayer Greer, brokers in the transaction. The three-story building contains ninety-six apartments and thirty garages.

LONDON, April 19--By a margin of eleven votes, the British Labor Government was upheld to-- night in the House of Commons in its decision with other members of the North Atlantic pact to give the supreme command of the Western naval forces in the North Atlantic to a United States admiral.

Use of most metals for costume jewelry can continue only as long as present inventories last, Robert Reiter, an attorney and member of Spalding, Reiter Rose, Washington, asserted at the first meeting of the Costume Jewelry Trade Association at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 19 (UP)--Southpaw Paul Minner puzzled the Reds to gain a seven-hit, 3-to-0 shut-out for the Cubs before 4,626 fans in 48 degree temperatures at Wrigley Field today.
WASHINGTON, April 19--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur got a rousing, hero's welcome today as he entered the nation's Capitol to address a joint meeting of House and Senate.

ST. LOUIS, April 19 (UP)-- Home runs by Al Zarilla and Ed Robinson, each with two men on, got the Chicago White Sox away to a flying start today and they routed the St. Louis Browns for the second straight time, 13--5.

The homemaker desirous of comparing her tea service with one fit for a queen will find reproductions of two royal tea sets in a display opening Monday at Altman's. One hundred fifty silver tea services will be on view, ranging from $40 to more them $3,000.

Mayor Impellitteri will leave the city late this afternoon or early tonight for a vacation trip to the Isle of Pines off the coast of Cuba. It was announced yesterday at City Hall that he would be gone for ten days or two weeks.

SENDAI, Japan, April 19 (UP)-- Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway told United States troops here today that "we stand under the imminent threat of war which can be unleashed at the time and place of choosing of other people."

MONTREAL, April 19 (UP)--A "sudden-death" overtime goal by Harry Watson gave the Toronto Maple Leafs 3-2 triumph over the Canadiens tonight and carried the Leafs to within one victory of capturing the Stanley Cup.
Accompanied by the usual opening-day fanfare, the Giants will lift the home lid at the Polo Grounds today against the Dodgers, the team they beat three straight in exhibitions at Miami this spring.

WASHINGTON, April 19--President Truman's designation of Secretary of State Dean Acheson to apportion foreign aid funds according to military and economic programs drew a sharp protest today from the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

The Veterans Administration will examine files relating to every policeman and fireman promoted in rank during 1950 to determine if other instances of falsified documents exist, it was announced yesterday.

One broker feels that the stock market, from a technical standpoint, is in a broad distribution area that may continue to form for some further time. In some respects, the pattern is shaping up similar to that which accompanied the 1947 top. This was followed by a sharp sell-off after February of that year, a rally by the industrials ...
WASHINGTON, April 19--The Interstate Commerce Commission today spelled out the degree to which motor trucks, carrying fish and farm commodities, are exempt from Federal regulation.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 19 (AP)--The North and South amateur golf tournament settled down to a North-Carolina-Georgia match today as Georgia's Hobart Manley and Bill (Dynamite) Goodloe joined Pinehurst's Dick Chapman and Billy Joe Patton, Morganton, N.C., in notching quarter-final victories.

Continued failure of the Senate Judiciary Committee to act on their nominations has placed the members of the Subversive Activities Control Board in an impossible position on the eve of their first and by all odds most important hearing.

Poultry this week-end provides the most worth-while choices for Sunday dinner. Shoppers will find broilers and fryers plentiful at 49 cents a pound, the same as last Friday. By way of a change from chicken, there is duck, down 6 cents to 39 a pound.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19--Regardless of their views on his policy and personality, United Nations delegates were almost as impressed by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's address today as were members of Congress.

TOKYO, Friday, April 20-- United Nations troops fought with flamethrowers and in hand-to-hand conflict yesterday to rout the enemy from the last remaining high ground south of Chorwon,, western peg of the Communist triangle in central Korea.

The shadow of the coming election hangs over all the current proceedings and decisions of the French National Assembly. Premier Queuille, head of the caretaker Cabinet formed to carry on until a new Parliament is chosen, feels that he cannot maintain even that temporary position without more decisive support.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, in its report for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 issued yesterday by Robert J. McKim, president, shows sales of $150,372,953, or 4.5 per cent above the previous year's volume of $143,949,178 and only $530,415 under the 1948 record of $150,903,368.

Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" received its final performance of the season by the New York City Opera Company last might. The delightful Englishlanguage version presented two singers new to their role, although they are familiar to habitues of the City Center.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 19-- The first visit of an English university crew to this country came to a close on the Charles River Basin at dusk today with another sweeping triumph.
TODAY, 4 P.M.: The story of "The Bird in the Linden Tree," New York Public Library Kingsbridge Branch, 3041 Kingsbridge Avenue, the Bronx. Call branch libraries for other story-hour programs.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 19 (AP)--Louis N. Brockway called on the advertising industry today to take the lead in promoting new standards and ethics, which he said the Kefauver Senatorial Crime Committee hearings showed are breaking down.

Hall of Fame exhibited his longstriding propensities to a crowd of 18,311 at Jamaica yesterday. Competing in the mile and a sixteenth On Watch Purse which served as the feature on the card, the Greentree Stable's 3-year-old enjoyed a triumph over five others to uphold his role of favorite.

BOGOTA, N.J., April 19--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Russell Mumford of the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Mae, to Edward Furnas Snyder, son of Mrs. Edward F. Snyder of Orono, Me., and the late Mr. Snyder. Plans have been made for a June wedding.
DETROIT, April 19--Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan conferred today with Democratic state leaders on a successor to Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, who died last night.

PARIS, April 19--The FrenchGerman tie that forms the foundation of the Schuman plan for merging Western Europe's coal and steel production has been compared with the Treaty of Locarno signed in 1925 to bring France and Germany into friendly relations after World War I.

LONDON, April 19--The British people, listening to excerpts of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's speech, broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation with descriptive commentaries by their own reporters, dimly realized tonight that on the other side of the Atlantic a great debate had started that might lead to peace or war, but over which they had no control.

HONG KONG, April 19--Bzasak Khemeypa, former commander in chief of the Tibetan army, declared here today there were still no Chinese Communist troops in Tibet proper. He said Communist soldiers had penetrated only as far as the western part of Sikang Province.

Leon Kelley, speaking on behalf of the Babylon Commuters Association, urged Governor Dewey yesterday to appoint the three commissioners of the newly created Long Island Rail Road Authority with all possible speed. Otherwise, he said, there is danger that nothing will be done to remedy the deficiencies of the road until there is another disaster.

RYE, N. Y., April 19--Rejection of the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation's plans for a $1,000,000 compressor station near the Ridge Street School in the unincorporated area of Rye Township was demanded in school board and taxpayer resolutions filed today with the Town Council.
Harlem sales, including a "package" deal that involved a group of twelve parcels, featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.
BERNE, Switzerland, April 18-- Switzerland no longer is an important transit zone for strategic commodities going from Western to Eastern Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19-- Shirley Booth, co-starring on Broadway in "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," has been signed by Hal Wallis, Paramount producer, to repeat her earlier stage role in "Come Back, Little Sheba" on the screen, the Wallis office announced here today.

TOMORROW will find the Connecticut trout enthusiasts thronging every body of water possible of harboring a trout, but the reports from most popular streams indicate that the opening day there will be somewhat similar to the New York and New Jersey inaugurals of last week-end.

TAEGU, Korea, April 19--Persistent reports of large concentrations of enemy planes in Manchuria have put South Korea on a constant sky watch, and troops of the United Nations have rushed all-out preparations for meeting sudden Fair strikes by the Communists.

MOSCOW, April 19--A new Soviet opera of collective farm life, "From the Depths of the Heart" was condemned today by Pravda as a serious failure and the composer, librettists, the Bolshoi Theater, directors of the Union of Soviet Composers and the committee on art were sharply criticized.

The Bax "Overture to a Picaresque Comedy," "Morning Music" for flute and string orchestra by Boris Koutzen, the Mozart E-flat Symphony--first of the great three--and the Brahms B-flat Piano Concerto with Artur Rubinstein as its protagonist, comprised the final Thursday night program of the Philharmonic-Symphony season last night in Carnegie Hall.
The body of Philip Mangano, described by the police as a waterfront racketeer, who had been shot three times in the head, was found yesterday near Jamaica Bay in the Bergen Beach section of Brooklyn.

The Bankers Trust Company plans to take over the business of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company in the fourth and largest merger since the adoption of its expansion policy a year ago, according to a joint announcement made yesterday by officials of the two banks.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)-- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath asked the United States Court of Appeals today to put off its contempt-of-court proceedings against Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer and other Government officials pending final action by the Supreme Court.

Bobby Locke, the South African golf professional who holds the British Open crown, will return here to take part in the Palm Beach round-robin tourney at the Wykagyl Country Club, New Rochelle, June 7-10. Locke cabled acceptance of an invitation, Harold McSpaden, tournament chairman, said yesterday.

ROME, Friday, April 20 (UP)-- Ivanoe Bonomi, president of the Senate and elder statesman of Italy, died early today at the age of 78. The former Premier suffered a relapse yesterday after circulatory complications.

PARIS, April 19--Castillo of Lanvin inaugurates the mid-season fashion openings with summer ensembles notable for their simple elegance, for silhouette, for lovely blues from pale gray blue through flower tones to brilliant Biarritz blue, which is a light royal.

A party that looked as if it were something done with mirrors celebrated yesterday the fifth birthday of the triplet sons of Mr. and Mrs. Arris Poulos-- Thomas, George and Thenneywho live at 165 Nagel Avenue.

Reflecting the $10,245,329 increase in sales, the consolidated net profit of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 improved to $7,106,657 from the $6,171,773 earned the year before, despite substantially larger taxes.

WASHINGTON, April 19--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's address already has divided Washington more profoundly than it has been divided at any time since the start of... the "cold war." Even at the highest levels of the Government, it was conceded tonight that the General had made a memorable speech.

Largely because anticipated Federal and state aid has failed to materialize, the gap between the city's needs for capital improvements and the money to finance them is larger than ever, according to a ten-year report of the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 19--Dr. George W. Taylor of the University of Pennsylvania was drafted today by President Truman to serve as chairman of the new eighteen-member Wage Stabilization Board.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 19-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Casper B. Ughetta of the engagement of their daughter, Marianne B., to Harold T. Brew, son of Mrs. Myra Brew of Thomaston, Conn.

BOSTON, April 19--The Giants spent six hours and fifteen minutes in two Patriots' Day battles with the Braves before 12,682 fans today. They basked in the warm rays of the mid-afternoon sun after skirting earlier rain and finished under the lights in a downpour.

WASHINGTON, April 19--The tremendous ovation that greeted, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur today as he opened one of the bitterest political fights in the nation's history blurred but could not obscure the unremitting thunder of the guns in Korea.

Wool and wool tops continued their rebound on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and again rose the full 10-cent limit in each delivery, influenced by Australian auction figures. Wool sold 480,000 pounds and tops 460,000 pounds.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP)-- John Maragon, one-time Kansas City bootblack who became a White House hanger-on, testified today that a British trader used "crooked elements" in foreign purchasing missions to get United States surplus war material in Europe.

What is considered proof of the "film industry's claim that there is no shortage of good movies," was presented in a report of the motion picture preview committee of the. General Federation of Women's Clubs, which recommended 122 films released during the ...
ATHENS, April 19 (AP)--Roger D. Lapham, Economic Cooperation Administration chief for Greece, had asked the Greek Government to rebate more than $100,000 allegedly misspent on one road project.

WASHINGTON, April 19--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur told the Daughters of the American Revolution today to assert their leadership in regaining the ground lost in this country to subversive forces. He said the danger was great from "internal subversion, corruption and detailed regimentation over our daily life."

TOKYO, Friday, April 20--The initial reaction of Japanese to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's appearance before Congress were one of gratification that the general, who for almost six years commanded the occupation of Japan, had expressed what comes close to being their viewpoint on Asia and the Pacific.

LONDON, April 19--Substantial gains were made in the leading industrials on the stock market here today, with profit-taking sales easily absorbed. The best advances were made is the shipping shares, under the influence of the increased dividend announcements by Cunard and Peninsular and Oriental. Conversely, fixed-interest securities turned weak. British Government issues lost yesterday's firmness and closed with losses of 1/8 to point.
WASHINGTON, April 19--British-American talks on the Iranian oil situation ended today with an announcement by the State Department that the "conversations were satisfactory to both Governments."

More than 400 veterans and their guests, including Mayor Impellitteri and high-ranking city officials, witnessed the first formal meeting of a new political party during a dinner for the Mayor at the Plaza Hotel last evening.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 19--United States military police will extend to the United StatesSoviet zone boundaries their assignment o fassisting West German customs officials in controlling illegal shipments of merchandise across the international frontiers of the Federal Republic, the United States High Commissioner's Office and Headquarters of the European Command jointly announced today.

CHICAGO, April 19--The grain markets developed a weak undertone in the late trading on the Board of Trade here today, most deliveries closing at about the bottom, except May wheat, which was 1/8 cent a bushel higher while the new crop months were off as much as 7/8 cent.

The annual celebration of Passover, the Jewish festival of freedom that will last seven days for Reform and eight for Conservative and Orthodox congregations, will begin at sundown today with religious services in temples and synagogues. Jewish G. I.'s and hospitalized veterans will join in the festival wherever they are.

BOSTON, April 19--Shigeki Tanaka, 19-year-old survivor of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, won the fifty-fifth annual Boston Athletic Association marathon run in near-record time today, as foreign entrants captured seven of the first eleven places in the Patriots' Day endurance classic.
A counter-attack by an enemy company north of Yonchon was repulsed. Hand-to-hand combat and flamethrowers routed the enemy southeast of Chorwon.

The homes of twenty present and former members of the Police Department were raided yesterday by representatives of the Kings County District Attorney's office in an effort to obtain corroborative evidence linking the policemen with Harry Gross' bookmaking ring.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)-- The Pentagon said tonight that President Truman removed General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from all his commands "upon the unanimous recommendations of the President's principal civilian and military advisers, including the Joint Chiefs of Staff."
HORNELL, N.Y., April 19 (AP) --John Jake Merrill, president of the Alfred Sand and Gravel Company and former member of the State Tax Commission, died today at a Hornell Hospital at the age of 89.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's prediction yesterday that, like the old soldier of the warrier's immemorial ballad, he would just "fade away" sent many of his listeners scurrying to sources of familiar quotations with small success.

TRENTON, April 19--The State Anti-Discrimination Division, which in six years of operation has settled all racial and religious complaints by conference and conciliation, announced today its first case requiring a public hearing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19--The Soviet Union's turnover tax, a kind of sales tax that bears most heavily on the low-income groups, accounts for 55 to 60 per cent of total budget receipts, including government loans, according to the United Nations fiscal division.

Rising costs recently have thrown a monkey-wrench into housing rental schedules for large new investment projects of insurance companies, Otto Nelson, vice president in charge of housing for the New York Life Insurance Company, yesterday.

The [Portland] Press Herald (Ind.Rep.) He spoke as a patriot of towering stature against the dark ground of an Administration honeycombed with traitors and moral delinquents. He spoke as the American best qualified to point the right course; and unless we take this course, it will be more than the old soldier who "doesn't die, but just fades away." Our national destiny is in the decision which must now be in the making.
The J. Walter Thompson Company was host yesterday to a group of French industrialists visiting the United States under the auspices of the Economic Cooperation Administration.
JOE DIMAGGIO leaned against the batting cage just before the Yankee opener last Tuesday and gazed critically at the long line of pennants which blanketed the facade of the topmost deck of the stands.

Otis Co., the Cleveland investment banking firm, began its defense yesterday in the multi-million-dollar damage suit brought against it by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation by charging that the automotive company had given false and misleading statements in connection with the scheduled 1948 stock offering from which Otis withdrew.
LAUREL, Md., April 19 (AP)-- Risk A Whirl, owned and trained by Max Kahlbaum, won the Potomac Park Purse, feature of Laurel's closing day program this afternoon.

Information has reached these premises about the Wattled Starling, a bird of Africa, and the fact that one of its traits has be come of vast interest to researchers in alopecia, or baldness. It seems there is hope.

The "worst" of the current inflation appears to be past, but price movements later this year will be determined primarily by the extent of agricultural production, Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution of Washington, forecast last night.

Softening of consumer goods prices can be largely attributed to the general freeze instituted by the Office of Price Stabilization, according to Joseph Kallick, chief of the consumer soft goods division of the O.P.S. The price freeze, he said, removed the need for excessive buying.

For the many persons who have written her anxiously for news, Mrs. Noble L. Hetherington of the Bronx had a note of reassurance yesterday--Perriette has returned to her fire escape home at 3050 Grand Concourse for the eighth straight year.
Industry will ask Congress to reverse President Truman's decision to give the Wage Stabilization Board power over non-wage disputes.
WASHINGTON, April 19--Four consultants were named today to the newspaper branch of the printing and publishing division of the National Production Authority.

Actors Equity Association went on record yesterday as holding that "participants in the Communist Conspiracy should be exposed as enemies of the nation." The actors' union made known its attitude when asked to define its position on the summoning of some members before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Dr. Alan Valentine, former Director of Economic Stabilization, charged yesterday that the Administration in Washington had largely disregarded the advice of sound economists and men experienced in World War II controls when it set up the present price control program.

Directors of American Water Works Company, Inc., declared a semi-annual dividend of 25 cents yesterday on the common stock, payable on May 15. The company previously distributed 30 cents at semi-annual intervals.
TRENTON, April 19--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll sharply rejected today a proposal that he fill most of the state judiciary positions with Republicans.

Moderately heavy selling kept the stock market from making further progress yesterday. It was a natural reaction price-wise in view of the fact that the list had on Wednesday made a triple top, a technical situation usually followed by an immediate reaction. Sections which had shown considerable strength earlier in the week were the easiest prey to the light liquidation.
Mrs. Douglas MacArthur took the first installment of New York's welcome last night with a big smile.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur dominated the television screen yesterday as a man who not only had his own strong convictions but displayed an intuitive stage sense and a keen awareness of his dramatic hour. It was extraordinary television, whatever a viewer's political feelings.
To help improve education at all levels, the Ford Foundation has created a Fund for the Advancement of Education, with an initial grant of $7,154,000.

Ballet Theatre last night gave a new turn to its succession of novelties at the Metropolitan Opera House by presenting a ballet by its leading ballerina, Alicia Alonso. It is entitled "Ensayo Sinfonico" and is set to Brahms' Haydn variations.
Dr. John J. Loftus, former assistant superintendent of schools in charge of elementary school curricula, died yesterday in his home at 516 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn. His age was 68.

More than 1,000,000 persons, according to police estimates, braved the chill air and cutting winds last night to catch a glimpse of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur as he rode in an open car from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19--Few United Nations top officials--four to be exact--plan to turn up tomorrow for New York City's luncheon-reception for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday that if the state had granted the city's "absolutely justifiable" request for an additional $64,000,000, largely for welfare work, the city would not have needed to raise the sales tax from 2 to 3 per cent to try to raise $60,000,000.

Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the State University of New York, announced yesterday that with the formation of a privately financed research foundation the university had taken one of the most important steps since its establishment.

At the Office of Price Stabilization, officials announced late today a revision of the order fixing pricing methods for iron and steel scrap and clarifying the original regulation governing prices in the industry. The revised order becomes effective April 24.
WASHINGTON, April 19--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur laid before Congress and the country today his side in his controversy with President Truman over military policy in Asia.

Publication of the annual report of the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street, New York 4, has proved again that to meet the many needs of seafaring men this agency has had to use all of its ingenuity, resources and strength. During the first half of 1950 wide unemployment among seamen resulted as appropriations for building ...
Philippa Macdonald put the adage, "the show must go on," to test yesterday when she presented her latest collection of ready-towear originals at a luncheon in the Plaza Hotel.

The President's announcement that substantial groundwork has already been done on mutual defense pacts with Australia and New Zealand is reassuring. These pacts constitute a vital link in the chain leading up to a satisfactory peace treaty with Japan. Their consummation will make the rest of the task easier.

Directors of the Aluminum Company of America elected Irving W. Wilson as president yesterday. The former senior vice president succeeds Roy A. Hunt, who was made chairman of the executive committee after twenty-three years as president. Arthur V. Davis continues as chairman of the board.

In an eloquent and deeply moving speech before a tumultuously applauding Congress, General MacArthur yesterday clarified his views on the Far Eastern situation that precipitated the controversy which led to his dismissal. He spoke, as he emphasized, not as advocate of any partisan cause, nor as one pursuing political aspirations, but as an American who is trying to serve his country. The speech bore out that claim.

Rice production in this country was greatly expanded during the war, when rice trade with the Orient was cut off. Since the end of the war, exports to large riceusing areas have declined and the United States has been faced with a surplus of this ancient, versatile food. Of the two and a half billion pounds now grown, only about half is eaten here.

WASHINGTON, April 19--In General MacArthur's speech to the joint session of Congress today, a public paper noble in tone and language and composed with the highest sense of responsibility for what grave events it might set in train, he stressed the wellknown fact that for months his military counsels have been rejected by the civil authority of the United States and the United Nations.

"The Long Days," opening at 8 o'clock tonight at the Empire, is the fourth and last of the week's entries (one of them already has kissed the dust). Avoiding the rigmarole of a pre-Broadway tryout, the offering was content to rely on four previews.

WASHINGTON, April 19--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur made an unexpected appearance before the American Society of Newspaper Editors tonight and shook hands with several hundred persons. The military leader and Mrs. MacArthur showed extreme cordiality and gave time to many who had met them before and desired to recall the acquaintance.

PARISH April 19--The ground forces allocated to Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe will not be ready to engage in combined ground maneuvers for another year at least, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, deputy commander to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's voice was piped through the public address system of the United Nations today, just about the time the former commander's latest report-- a warning of enemy build-up for a new offensive--was delivered here.

Chester I. Barnard, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, reported yesterday that in the first quarter of 1951 it had made grants of $1,481,718. The recipients included educational and scientific organizations in this and other countries.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association went on record yesterday with eight recommendations for revision of the Defense Production Act of 1950. The group represents more than 7,000 department, chain and specialty stores throughout the country with an estimated annual volume of $10,000,000,000 annually.

One hundred former students of the Graham School for refined young ladies that flourished here from 1816 to 1917 told tales out of school yesterday at the fiftieth anniversary reunion of the Graham Alumnae Association.

Samuel R. Rosoff, who began his career as a newsboy and became one of the country's leading subway and tunnel constructors, left nearly all of his estate to his two sons, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court for probate. Mr. Rosoff, who was a resident of 112 Central Park South, died in Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, on April 12 at the age of 68.
WASHINGTON, April 19--President Truman and Senatorial col leagues of the late Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Michigan Republican, paid him tribute today in the most laudatory terms.

ROME, April 20 Rubber-producing countries have so far refused to commit themselves to any agreement that would guarantee to consumer countries a yearly quota of rubber based on their normal percentage of imports, according to Globo, financial daily.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) The Army announced a decision today to reopen Fort Hancock, N.J., and at the same time offered to lease a part of the Sandy Hook Peninsula to New Jersey for park purposes.
Fifty thousand public and parochial school children paid a brief but highly vocal tribute to General MacArthur in Central Park yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 Dr. Frank P. Graham, defense manpower administrator for the Department of Labor, is expected to be appointed United Nations mediator in the dispute between Pakistan and India over possession of the princely state of Kashmir.

THOSE who want to get in their landlocked salmon right after ice-out in northern Maine wil have to gas up the car and get moving, for word has been received that Washington County streams are now clear, with some of Aroostook County's waters losing ice rapidly.

Three new films will arrive in town over the week-end. Opening today at the Globe is "Lucky Nick Cain," a romantic melodrama filmed in Italy and starring George Raft and Coleen Gray. Joseph M. Newman directed and Joseph Kaufman produced the Twentieth Century-Fox presentation from a script by George Callahan and William Rose based on the novel, "I'll Get You For This," by James Hadley Chase.

The formation of a business and professional women's unit of the Manhattan Council of Church Women, an affiliate of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, has been announced by Clifford W. Petitt, executive director of the Protestant Council.

WASHINGTON, April 20. President Truman was booed today at Griffith Stadium where he tossed out the first ball in a delayed opening day ceremony here and watched the Washington Senators defeat the New York Yankees, 5 to 3.

The present high rate of steel production may be curtailed soon and the industry's expansion program may be "nullified," unless the flow of scrap to steel mills is increased, Robert W. Wolcott, chairman of the Lukens Steel Company, warned yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 20 In front of the Shah Mosque in central Teheran today 5,000 persons heard leaders of Fadayan Islam, a fanatical Moslem brotherhood specializing in political assassination, admonish Premier Hussein Ala, ominously, to release their imprisoned confederates and "return to a right course."
Manhattan's jubilant cliff dwellers, who hailed General of the Army Douglas MacArthur yesterday with a blizzard of sun-flecked paper flakes, made Sanitation Department history.

After a fifty-minute public hearing in his office, Mayor Impellitteri signed into law last night the retail sales tax increase from 2 to 3 per cent. He said he was doing so. "regretfully," but that the city could not balance its 1951-52 budget without the higher sales levy.
Nearly 50 per cent of the city's police force fought and won a good humored battle yesterday with the throngs eager to acclaim General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

Mayor Impellitteri's prediction that the reception for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur would be the greatest in the city's history was fulfilled yesterday and led old-timers and others not so old to recall some of the observances that have given the city a world-wide reputation for the warmth of its welcomes and the size of its celebrations.

The Passover festival of freedom began at sundown last night as Jewish families throughout the world partook of the seder feast and heard again the traditional reading of the Haggadah, the ancient story of the deliverance of the Jews from Egyptian bondage.

At last three weeks after the April 1 deadline and more than two months after President Truman made his initial request Congress is moving again on the food-to-India bill. When and if the help does finally arrive in time to avert starvation, it will of course be welcome.

ARMONK, N.Y., April 20--Seventy-five women and their commuter-husbands have put heads together here to produce and operate the unusual North Castle free library. Equally free to readers and taxpayers, it charges nothing for books and no real estate levies support it.
Both in spirit and numbers New York made history yesterday with the intensity and magnitude of its thunderous welcome to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur on his homecoming from the wars.

BUFFALO, April 20 Students of the University of Buffalo turned out in force today for a conference on civil liberties that was conceived, presented, financed and managed by undergraduates as a service to their institution and to the community at large.

Pravda's sharp attack on the new Soviet opera, "From the Depths of the Heart," is undoubtedly causing sharp new anguish in musical and cultural circles throughout the U.S.S.R. Here was a production which had won high praise from all the crities, which had...

NEWARK, April 20 Providence College and Cardinal Hayes High School were double winners in today's opening session of the fifth annual Seton Hall relays, first major carnival of the outdoor track and field season in the East.

VIENNA, April 20 The formation of the Western European Electric Power Union, to which Austria, Italy, Switzerland, Western Germany, France, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg will belong, was decided on at a recent meeting in Paris, according to an announcement tonight from the Austrian Ministry of Power and Transport.

Four men were held in $75,000 bail each yesterday on perjury charges in connection with what police say was a murder committed a year ago in a Bronx restaurant but one in which the body was never recovered.

George Abbott, producer of "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," categorically denied yesterday the West Coast report that Shirley Booth, co-star of his musical production, had signed a long-term contract with Hal Wallis, Paramount producer.

UTICA, April 20 (AP) A threejudge Federal Court upheld today an Interstate Commerce Commission order increasing commutation fares on New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad travel in New York State.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 20 More than 1,500 saddened townsmen of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, who died here Wednesday night, filed slowly past his bier today in a Grand Rapids mortuary, as city officials completed preparations for an impressive funeral tomorrow.

For a few fleeting moments yesterday at the Polo Grounds the Giants had visions of a victorious home opener. The sun shone brightly. Despite the counter-influence of the city's welcome to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, there were 30,870 fans in the stands.
Harry Gross owes his favorite tailor $2,000 for garments purchased by the gambler for present and former members of the Police Department, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 20 The consumers' price index rose 0.4 per cent between Feb. 15 and March 15, a definite showing of the trend of the last eight months, the Labor Department reported today.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur wound up his tremendous day in New York yesterday with an emotion-filled little speech in which he told the city's millions that they had forced him to do what no enemy in the Pacific had ever done capitulate.

HONG KONG, April 20 Firing squads are still working overtime in China with no signs of let-up in the nation-wide purge of "counterrevolutionaries" officially launched by the Communist-led Peiping regime two months ago today.

Cotton futures trading was moderately active on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final prices were unchanged to 27 points net higher.

The three-story building with a two-story extension at 790 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, containing two stores, two offices and two apartments, has been sold by Henry Sugerman to a client of M. C. O'Brien, Inc., broker in the transaction.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) An Owensboro, Ky., steel plant received approval for $8,500,000 in defense loans despite objections the plant would hurt the defense effort, Government experts testified today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (UP) Max Surkont pitched masterful two-hit ball today as the Braves spoiled the 1951 home debut of the National League champion Phillies with a 2-1 victory before 17,423 fans.
CINCINNATI, April 20 (AP) A group of farm and industry leaders agreed today America has a new frontier whose development can win wars and pay the $255,000,000,000 public debt.
ST. PAUL, April 20 (AP) Detroit's E. B. team broke the 3,000 mark for the first time tonight to crash into squad leadership in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

RICHMOND, Va., April 20 In St. James Protestant Episcopal Church this evening Miss Frances Hundley Riggs, niece of Mrs. Julia Riggs Tanner and Frank Hundley Riggs of Richmond, was married to Alfred Sidney Nalle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nalle of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Churchill J. Gibson, the rector, performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Country Club of Virginia.

The city's welcome to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur reached a blinding, full-throated climax of sound and color in the formal parade along the traditional route of heroes from the Battery to City Hall.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 20 The question as to whether or not a steel mill will be built in Connecticut remained undecided tonight following a conference between Gov. John Davis Lodge and his Connecticut Steel Advisory Committee.

The arrangement of flowers for the home is the theme of six books published this spring. Four are by Americans; the other two, by Englishwomen, also have appeared in this country.

New York City gave its warm welcome yesterday to a General home from the wars, a man in whom it recognized more than mere military greatness. He traveled the hero's route, through the ticker tape, the streets lined with the millions who love a parade.

Reporting a net profit of $419,804 for the first three months this year, Irving B. Babcock, chairman of the ACF-Brill Motors Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Philadelphia yesterday...

The wool fabric industry is passing through a sharp market slump, according to Eugene Ackerman, president of the Wool Bureau, Inc. The current situation appears, however, to be temporary, he said in a statement released yesterday,...

It was a big day for a small boy. He played his part with a dignity, somewhat strained for a 13-year-old, but befitting a youth whose years have been divided among military campaigns, public pomp and lonely seclusion.

HOUSTON, April 20 (UP) Art Larsen, national amateur tennis champion, staged a sensational comeback today to defeat Robert Curtis, 6 4, 4 6, 4 6, 6 2, 6 4, and advance to the semi-finals of the River Oaks tournament.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 20 The Egyptian Government hopes to put through the Chamber of Deputies by next Monday a law that will give it control over the type of fanatical organization responsible for the assassinations of Iranian Premier Ali Razmara.

The subways and Hudson Tubes bore the brunt of spectator traffic yesterday to points along the route of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's parade, while trains and vehicular approaches to Manhattan reported loads only slightly more than normal.

Two hundred and fifty leaders in the fields of education, social work, religion, child development and race relations voted yesterday to request Governor Dewey to call a "Little White House Conference" to discuss ways of applying throughout the state the recommendations of the Midcentury...
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) The Veterans Administration said today it would start paying a $685,000,000 special dividend on G.I. life insurance next week.

Four advertisers of grocery store products are concluding an experiment involving the placement of newspaper advertising on weekdays other than Thursday and report it successful in many respects. The experiment was started, it was explained by Hilton and Riggio, agency for the advertisers,...

WASHINGTON, April 20 Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent over the week ended April 17, as increases in foods, textiles and miscellaneous commodities more than offset decreases in farm products, metals, building materials and chemicals,...

WASHINGTON, April 20 A bequest of $1,000,000 to the Daughters of the American Revolution, making possible the restoration of Colonial Tryon Palace at New Bern, N.C., was announced at today's closing session of the Sixtieth Continental Congress.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 20 Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, warned tonight that an Allied attack on China might precipitate World War III by compelling Russia to come to China's aid under the Sino-Russian mutual-assistance treaty.

Action on the Korean front Friday was centered in the sector south of Chorwon where attacking United Nations troops repulsed three company-sized counter-attacks by enemy delaying elements attempting to slow our advance. Elsewhere along the front, aggressive patrolling precipitated minor clashes, with enemy resistance generally light.
WASHINGTON, April 20 President Truman accepted today the resignation of Cyrus S. Ching as chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board "in accordance with our understanding of last September."

DAVIS, Calif., April 20 Regents of the University of California took two actions here today, each by a vote of 11 to 10, aimed at ending the two-year battle over special loyalty oaths and contractual declarations and restoring non-signers to their jobs on the faculty.
NEW ORLEANS, April 20 Two oil tankers collided in a dense dawn fog in the Gulf of Mexico today with a probable death toll of thirty-eight. Both ships were swept by flames after the crash.

The Electro Metallurgical Company is now well under way on a multiple-plant expansion program designed to achieve a 200 per cent increase over the 1940 output level of ferro-alloy production capacity. Ferro-alloys are basic materials essential to the manufacture of almost all steel products by steel mills.

English furniture of unusual style and elegance of the William and Mary, Queen Anne and Georgian periods from the estate of the late Benjamin G. Paskus, New York, will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, on Friday and Saturday.

Gen. Douglas MacArthur has given a dignified and statesmanlike but vigorous and provocative analysis of his position in respect to the Korean conflict. It must be met with thoughtful study. The General declared with some emphasis that he was not speaking as a partisan, and it will be well if those who listen can also forget partisanship.

Questions of literary interest--whether relating to authors or their writings --should be addressed to the Queries Editor. Inquiries must contain the name and address of the writer on the page with the query. All queries must be accompanied by postage. The Editor will publish those that seem to have the greatest general interest. Others are answered by letter.

PARTLY because of the limitations of 78 r.p.m. records, jazz has become identified with the popular song in length and even in style. Longplaying disks provide opportunity to give a more realistic picture.

Miss Anne Frances Zengerle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Zengerle of New Dorp, S.I., was married to Bertram Ward Allen of Manchester, Mass., and Boston, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bertram W. Allen, yesterday afternoon in the New Dorp Moravian Church.

Only in a free country such as the United States would a dismissed military commander be received with the acclaim accorded to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, Rabbi Julius Mark of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, said yesterday in his Passover sermon.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)-- Nine of twenty-three Republican Governors are on record as favoring General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the top G.O.P. nomination in 1952.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- Twelve members of the Senate and House of Representatives will sit down in joint conference next week to determine how the far-reaching concept of Universal Military Training shall be written into the law of the land.

GENEVA, April 21--A series of agreements that will fix the tariff levels of the world's major trading countries for the next three years was opened for signature at Torquay, England, today, marking the official close of the second longest of three post-war tariff conferences.

In India today famine is creeping slowly through the land. From Bombay to Bengal, from Kashmir to Travancore, the vast majority of India's 340,000,000 persons are existing on food rations below subsistence levels.

OUT at Adelphi College in Garden City one evening recently, Dr. Agnes Snyder, chairman of the Education Department, told a group of parents that "all children are artists and will continue to be if they are not tricked or forced into the acceptance of adult standards."

ONCE again Margaret S. Ernst, the author of "In a Word," has traced a fresh group of words to their beginnings, pungently translating the hieroglyphics in brackets which follow the columned entries in our dictionaries. A drawing by W.A. Dwiggins wittily illustrates the point of each little essay.

Regional correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES were asked last week to report on the sentiment in their areas on the MacArthur controversy, in the light of the general's speech to Congress. Their dispatches indicate that public reaction is based largely on the personalities involved and strongly favors MacArthur, while editorial reaction tends more to a discussion of the issues. The reports follow.

The circus family calls him "Twelve Minutes." His real name is Charles Peterson, and matinees and evenings you'll find him in the west end of the tanbark arena in Madison Square Garden fulfilling the drum beater's rhapsodic introduction of "internationally famous riding canines--Peterson's jockey dogs."
STAMFORD, Conn., April 21-- A new approach hereabouts to the problem of industrial relations is credited with bringing a high degree of labor-management peace in this area in the last five years.

The Welin Davit and Boat Division of Continental Copper and Steel Industries, Inc., has contracted to furnish lifeboats, davits and winches for twenty of twentyfive new fast Mariner-class ships under construction. The vessels, designed as successors of the Liberty and Victory type ships of World War II, were ordered recently by the Federal Maritime Administration.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 21-- The 1950-51 basketball season ended tonight, with the Rochester Royals crowned National Association champions. They wrapped up the title with a dramatic finish that defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 79--75, in the seventh game of this best-of-seven series.

THE fiftieth anniversary of the first automobile license plates required by law in New York State takes place next Wednesday. It was on April 25, 1901, that state control over motor-vehicle registration began, under an amendment to the highway law that required car owners to register with the Secretary of State.

The Government last week took another long step to bring organized labor into full participation in the nation's mobilization program. It agreed to reconstitute the two-months-dormant Wage Stabilization Board along lines insisted on by labor as a prerequisite for its cooperation.

JERSEY CITY, April 21--With four Hudson County municipalities electing commissioners on May 8, Hoboken holds the spotlight with forty-eight candidates competing for the five places on the commission. Bayonne with twenty-four candidates, North Bergen with eighteen and West New York with eleven complete the list.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP)-- The 1950 special grand jury investigating corruption in city offices returned a presentment today naming twenty-nine present and former city officials as takers of graft.

Jack Goldsmith, 31-year-old former basketball star at Long Island University, was arrested yesterday on charges of bribing four L.I.U. players to "fix" a game with Duquesne University on Jan. 1, 1949.
