WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 21--The American Association of Advertising Agencies indulged in some soul searching here today. Three speakers at the last session of the annual convention discussed advertising's faults and suggested remedies.

Some of the most lurid dreams that visited the population here in the small hours of yesterday morning were concentrated at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel where about 2,000 waking and sleeping hallucinations came to life in the annual costume ball of the Art Students League.

The success the New York Curb Exchange and Chicago Board of Trade have had in changing their methods of selling quotations services to members and the public has aroused new interest in the subject on the New York Stock Exchange.

ROME, April 21--Charles M. Spofford, chairman of the Council of Deputies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, today urged all North Atlantic Pact nations to complete "as soon as possible" their defense program because, he said, "it is only through collective strength, guided by our unity of purpose, that we can guarantee the protection of our countries from aggression."

HOLLYWOOD. THE denunciation of quondam Hollywood Communist Party members by other quondam Hollywood Communist Party members during two weeks of testimony before the House Un-American Activities Committee has finally produced a state of acute unease in the film community.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 21-- In The First Presbyterian Church at noon today Miss Diana Melville Morgan, daughter of Prof. Sherley Warner Morgan, director of the School of Architecture at Princeton University, and Mrs. Morgan of Princeton and Manchester, Vt., was married to Alfred Van Santvoord Olcott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Olcott of New York and Southport, Me.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 21--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is considering a plan for financing a $5,000,000,000 European road network inspired by United States federal highway system, it was reported at a regional meeting here of the International Road Federation.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP)-- The Daughters of the American Revolution have decided to let Dorothy Maynor, Negro soprano, sing at their Constitution Hall for pay. Officials said they believed this would be the first commercial performance for a Negro artist at the hall since some time before 1939. In that year Marian Anderson was barred.

Attired for at least part of the day in his old West Point dressing gown, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur spent yesterday resting in his Waldorf-Astoria Hotel suite and catching up on a tremendous volume of mail and telegrams.

ATLANTA, April 21--Georgia will spend an estimated $170,000,000 the next fiscal year for the operation and expansion of its schools and colleges. Officials gave the figure today as preparations went ahead to put into operation the most ambitious educational program in the state's history.

ARMONK, N.Y., April 21-- Dogs owned by E.S. de Meyer of Long Meadow, Mass., placed first and third in the open all-age stake on the second day's program in the twenty-fourth trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Club today. Both were handled by Bill Conlan.

WASHINGTON, April 21--On Lincoln's Birthday the President's Commission on Internal Security and Individual Rights (the Nimitz Commission) held its first meeting. Entrusted with a high mission, the nine members approached it with enthusiasm. Today they have yet to accomplish anything. They have been stymied by red tape that only Congress can slash.

A two-story wing serving as a parking garage for 750 cars is a feature of the twelve-story office building rising at 10 Commerce in the heart of the financial, commercial and shopping district of Newark, N.J. The wing is an integral part of the main structure and has direct entrances from the lobby of the office building.

IN his preface Mr. Masefield declares that this is not a re print of his earlier volume of similar title, "but a changed selection, drawn from many different books, and offered now as the best I have been able to do."

GREAT poets are not always great letter writers. John Keats was one. So was Emily Dickinson. The more than ninety letters she wrote to Dr. and Mrs. J.G. Holland, two-thirds of them here published for the first time, are among the finest written by the American poet, and in their way inimitable.

A GARDENER is often tempted to buy a perennial that requires care he is not yet experienced enough to give, or which is unsuited to the exposure or space available. But with a little guidance the amateur can select and grow long-lived perennials for a succession of bloom from spring until frost.

Miss Marianne Schappert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony F. Schappert of New York and Cheshire, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Stephen Van Rensselaer Strong, son of Mrs. Theodore Strong of New Brunswick, N.J., and the late Mr. Strong, former New Jersey State Senator.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Apri1 21-- Though unable to match Army's power at the plate, Columbia nevertheless had the knack of bunching its hits and consequently won a 6-to-5 decision over the cadets in an Eastern Intercollegiate League fray at Doubleday Field today.

TRENTON, April 21--A troop and military cargo plane, developed by the Chase Airciaft Company, was flown successfully today from Mercer Field, powered with four jet engines. Company officials said they believed it was the first time in aviation history that such a plane, designed for heavy loads, flew with jet engines.
FREDERICK, Md., April 21-- General of the Army George C. Marshall, strongly criticized educators today for not guiding their students to a greater realization of the problems of other peoples.
WASHINGTON, April 21--President Truman reconstituted, the Wage Stabilization Board today as an eighteen-member agency with authority to recommend settlements in certain non-wage disputes.

MOSCOW. SERGEI PROKOFIEFF, one of the great musical geniuses of Russia, celebrates on April 23 his sixtieth birthday and forty-odd years of creative work which has given the world some of the greatest musical compositions of our times.
WASHINGTON. WITH all the respect in the world, men who know President Truman well agree that he has many of the qualities of the mule, the first famous export of his home State of Missouri.

Shirt manufacturers will open their fall lines next month and, unless the Office of Price Stabilization issues a manufacturers' order within the next few weeks, the majority of the producers will open "at value."

A new plan for selling its product on college campuses, started as a test in the metropolitan area at the beginning of this year by the Pepsi-Cola Metropolitan Bottling Company of New York, has proved a success and will be continued.

THIS evening, over at the Town Hall Club, Maurice Evans receives a special award from the Shakespearean Club of New York for "meritorious service in the Shakespearean theatre." Equally satisfying to Mr. Evans, however, should be the stamp of confidence which the New York public--especially that segment which wants sound theatre at prices it can afford-- has put on his programs at the City Center.

The attempted assassination of Romulo Betancourt, former President of Venezuela, in Havana was the fourth attempted political murder of a Latin-American democratic leader in the last four months, Jose Figueres, former President of Costa Rica, said here yesterday.

As the nation feted General of the Army MacArthur and heard him present his views, the stock market, while displaying a firmer tone, was not too sure of itself. The recovery continued into the third successive week, but there was less buoyancy to the trading. Prices moved to the best levels of the year, then backed away after carrying the "averages" at the highest point in twenty years. On balance, the market closed slightly lower.
Expansion of statutory limits, in recognition of the realities of inflation and the depreciated dollar, is a characteristic of new state legislation for all fields of banking.

LONDON, April 21--The British Labor Government is passing through an uneasy time. Not only are signs apparent that it is losing the confidence of the country but Prime Minister Attlee is finding it difficult, in the face of rival ambitions and divergent views within the Cabinet, to keep his ministers working as a team.
ALBANY--Construction of an other link of the Taconic State Parkway, starting this spring, will extend to eighty-seven miles the parkway system leading north from New York City.

Spaciousness in fewer rooms is the dominant feature of the luxury style apartments under construction at 110 East End Avenue. The 144 suites of three to five and one-half rooms in the fourteen-story building are scheduled for occupancy in October.

IN homes throughout the world today one finds an increasing use of ceramics for decorative as well as functional accents in modern rooms. Indeed, the forming of clay into plaques, platters and pitchers is no longer regarded as a mere craft, but has attained the dignity of a true art form.

On the island of Abadan, in the delta of the Tigris and Euphrates in Iran, is the world's largest oil refinery. It has a capacity of more than 400,000 barrels a day; the oil it produces powers Britain's Royal Navy and helps turn the wheels of industry in Western Europe, India and Australia.

MAJ. GEN. LEWIS B. HERSHEY'S statement last week that college students will be deferred pending aptitude tests and that most highschool graduates can be sure of at least a summer before being drafted is expected to step up enrollment in student tours abroad this summer. Until recently it looked as if uncertainties over the draft would keep the number of students going abroad well below the 20,000 figure set last year.

FRANKFORT. IN postwar Germany, where nothing is quite normal, the movie situation is going through a particularly freak ish phase. While the industry as a whole is teetering on the verge of collapse, two recently released films are creating uproar and tumult from one end of the Federal Republic to the other.

PONCA CITY, Okla., April 21-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gray Osborn of Ponca City and Avery Island, La., of the engagement of their daughter, Sarah McIlhenny, to Thomas Browning Hewitt 2d, son of Mrs. Thomas Denison Hewitt of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Hewitt. Plans have been made for a July wedding.

The weather turned bad in North Korea last week. Along the Parallel, clouds hung low on the mountains. The valleys were filled with smoke from brush fires set by the Chinese troops to screen their movements. Rain fell intermittently.
LAWRENCE, Kan., April 21-- Don Cooper of Nebraska stole the show from the famous milers in the Kansas Relays today by clearing the pole vault bar at 15 feet 1/8 inch for a new intercollegiate record.
New shopping centers in Irvington and East paterson, N.J., will provide large store areas to serve the rapidly growing housing developments in those sections.

The first small but definite break in prices of bedroom and dining room furniture occurred last week when two leading case goods producers offered a limited number of bedroom suites at 10 to 20 per cent discounts. One of these manufacturers derives volume almost entirely from credit home furnishings stores and the other does a substantial department store business.

If oilmen can prove to the Canadian authorities that Alberta has the makings of another Texas in natural gas reserves, there is a good prospect that an official goahead may be given soon for construction of an all-Canadian "Big Inch" pipeline, the largest of its kind in the world.

Department store sales for the week were estimated at about 10 per cent below the level for the corresponding 1950 week. Trade observers ascribed the decline to the great interest in the arrival of General MacArthur, his address to Congress and the reception and parade in his honor here, which kept millions at radio or television sets or along his route.
Yale's overwhelming strength in the field and over-all depth enabled the Elis to crush Columbia 102 1/3 to 37 2/3, in a dual track and field meet at Baker Field, yesterday.

A SMALL bed of the so-called culinary herbs might be located for convenience of picking as near the kitchen door as possible. Only a few are needed to provide interesting flavorings that will add savor and piquancy to many a meal.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 21-- The Rev Dr. Gustav Steams, widely known Lutheran clergyrman, died today at his home of pneumonia. He was 77 years old.

Continued activity marks the home building market on Long Island where a large number of new dwellings are rising and large tracts have been purchased for the immediate construction of still more houses.

The final break in sea commerce between New York and the Polish port of Gdynia is not surprising and it was not altogether unexpected. The Polish Government has announced that the liner Batory will be withdrawn from the North Atlantic run and that ships of the American Scantic Line will be barred from the Polish port. Thus will end a tenuous track into the land behind the iron curtain.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21-- While the Pacific Northwest looks dourly upon suggestions for diverting Columbia River waters to thirsty areas of California, some of them 1,000 miles from the river, this state is being introduced to preliminary plans for a vast intrastate program of water distribution.

Too few of our top film directors are able to advance and expand their particular creative capacities in the tight and uneasy atmosphere of pressure and demands for "popular" product that prevails in Hollywood today.

Representative Albert Gore of Tennessee has suggested that a belt across Korea be contaminated by radioactive isotopes which would give off deadly rays and so hold Chinese and North Korean troops in check. Naturally, inhabitants of the belt would be forewarned and evacuated. A radio broadcast would warn the Communist invaders that they would cross the belt at their peril.

BLISTERS and stiff muscles are common complaints of the gardening fraternity on Monday mornings in April. More serious injuries need not occur; if they do, they can generally be traced to inept handling of tools.

The Southern Probation and Parole Conference can count substantial gains for an advancing penology in its region as it convenes today for its annual meeting in Charleston, S.C. One by one the Southern States have been abandoning corporal punishment and ending the use of chains in road camps. Several probation and parole systems below the Potomac can now be ranked among the best in the nation.

IN KOREA. AMONG the hills of South Korea 373 of the finest Korean youths are studying and training about eighteen hours a day for $1 a month. If they can keep from being flunked out during the next three years, can avoid marriage, desist from smoking or drinking, they will graduate from the Annapolis of the Republic of Korea.

Television's popularity among teenage youth is growing at the expense of movies, reading and radio, according to Dr. Paul Witty of Northwestern University. The effects of the Korean war and the national emergency on the real estate market and valuation problems will be analyzed by nationally known experts and appraisers at a conference which will be held here next Friday and Saturday at the Biltmore Hotel.

A garden and card party for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will be given on May 3 at Brookside, the Rye, N.Y., home of Mrs. Flagler Matthews. Proceeds from this event will aid the beneficiary to care for babies pending their adoption from the agency.

The State Building Code Commission today reported that the state building construction code, now in preparation, would be available not only to 339 municipalities of the state having building regulations, but to more than 1,200 other municipalities without regulations of their own.

Wood is composed of cellulose and lignin. The cellulose has many uses; the lignin is a nuisance. This is so because more is known about cellulose than about lignin. Until now, lignin could not be isolated in its natural state. Hence this lack of knowledge. The lignin chemically obtained from wood is not the same as lignin in living wood.

NAUGATUCK, Conn., April 21-- Miss Virginia Chittenden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William McKinley Chittenden of this place and East River, was married here this afternoon in the Congregational Church to Nathan Merrill Pierpont Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierpont of Waterbury.

WASHINGTON, April 21.--The big questions raised by General MacArthur's speech in Congress are not whether we want what the General wants but whether we are prepared to risk what he is prepared to risk and whether we are prepared to risk it alone.

EARLY daffodils, single cherries and species tulips may be seen in abundance at the annual spring show opening today at Wayside Gardens, Brook ville, L.I. The United Nations' offensive in Korea continued Saturday as general advances were made against moderate resistance. BRISTOL, England, April 19-- In a valley near this war-scarred port bomblike explosions broke the country silence last night. Carroll Condict of Thayetmyo, Burma, this morning in the home of her mother, Mrs. Frank Hale Thurston. The Rev. Dr. Daniel Miller of the First Baptist Church in Mount Vernon, performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception.

RYE, N.Y., April 21--Christ's Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Adele Albro Hedges, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, James Sylvester Hedges of Rye, to Francis du Pont Cornelius of New York, son of Mrs. Henry Robert Cornelius of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Cornelius.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 21--Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican architect of the bipartisan foreign policy, was buried here today in Oak Hill Cemetery, near his parents and his first wife, Elizabeth Watson Vandenberg.

Stores were in a position to buy in the wholesale markets here last week as consumers purchased promotional items, easing inventories, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. TORONTO, April 21--The Toronto Maple Leafs won the Stanley Cup tonight as they defeated Montreal, 3 to 2, in overtime on Bill Barilko's "sudden death" goal at 2:53. The Leafs won the series, four games to one.

LONDON, April 21 (Reuters)-- The Glasgow Celtic soccer club captured the Scottish League Cup today with a 1-0 victory over Motherwell in the final at Glasgow. The Celtic club will cross the Atlantics for a nine-game tour in the United States and Canada.

PIGEON POINT, Del., April 21-- With the main cables spun, workmen on the Delaware Memorial Bridge were proceeding steadily today with the exacting and dangerous task of hanging the steel frame that will Barry the roadway across a mile of water.
MOBILE, Ala., April 21 (AP)-- With seventeen dead counted and twenty-two missing men presumed dead, two tankers that collided and exploded into flames on the Gulf of Mexico headed for ports tonight.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 21 (AP) --Wistful romped home first by six lengths today in the $10,000-added Ben Ali Handicap at Keeneland and gave Calumet Farm its fifth victory in the classic.

WASHINGTON, April 21--It is quite likely you could have tapped Casey Stengel with a feather this afternoon and knocked him right into the Potomac River. For those astonishing Senators almost did it again. But the Yankees, with the help of the rule book and a decisive twobagger by their rookie star, Mickey Mantle, managed to carry the day, turning back Bucky Harris' Nats, 8 to 7.
WASHINGTON, April 21--The "boss" in the Soviet Union can send a worker to jail for twenty days for refusing to move to another job. No court action is necessary and no appeal is permitted.
In the Scarsdale area of Westchester County, builders have started work on two more groups of ranch-style homes in the luxury price class.

TENAFLY, N.J., April 21--The marriage of Miss Jean Colver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic B. Colver, to Robert W. Brink, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Louis Brink, took place here this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church.
The Giants lost to the Dodgers, 7--3, at the Polo Grounds yesterday, their second setback in a row at the hands of the Brooks.
Labor and management should cooperate more closely to benefit society as a whole and lift the economic status of the nation, a panel of six high school students agreed yesterday.

Handmacher-Vogel, Inc., one of the country's largest manufacturers of suits for women, is planning for a 100,000-unit increase in production, according to Alvin Handmacher, president. Expressing confidence in the outcome of the fall season, Mr. Handmacher said last week he expected a gain of 25 per cent in dollar volume this year and a 10 to 15 per cent increase in units.

THERE is a new kid on our block and it's about time you made his acquaintance. In fact there are five new kids on our block but four you already know because they've been around before, the four being Jimmie Dykes, Al Lopez, Marty Marion and Charlie Dressen. But the fifth of the new managers in the major leagues is Paul Richards of the White Sox, a versatile Texan from the thriving metropolis of Waxahachie.

Principles of figure-drawing will be the topic of the free art lecture on Tuesday at 6:15 P.M. in the series on various phases of art sponsored by the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Fortysecond Street. Alexander Dobkin, whose paintings have been exhibited in some of the country's leading institutions, will be the lecturer.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP)-- Formation of the first National Catholic Youth Council in the United States was announced today by Msgr. Joseph E. Schieder, director of the youth department, National Catholic Welfare Conference.

HARLAN, Iowa, April 21--The engagement of Miss Luann Lewis to Patten Bemister Harvey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Harvey of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., has been announced by her mother, Mrs. William Jackson Lewis.

NEWARK, April 21--Records toppled in five of the seven varsity title events today as Manhattan and Georgetown romped off with chief honors in the fifth annual Seton Hall relays. The first big show of the Eastern outdoor track and field campaign, watched by 3,500 spectators at Newark School stadium, saw the Jaspers capture three crowns and the Hoyas two.

ALTHOUGH most vegetables are annuals and have to be planted each year, there are a few--asparagus, rhubarb and the multiplier onions among them--that live through the winter and produce crops year after year.

THE New York PhilharmonicSymphony Society will finish a notable season today. From the modernist's point of view, this season was brought to a head last Sunday afternoon, with the society's third performance of Alban Berg's opera, "Wozzeck," in concert form, all the performances having attracted sold-out houses and enthusiastic audiences.

Tuberous-rooted begonias and gladiolus are both started during April for summer bloom. But while begonia tubers are sprouting in pots of damp sand indoors, gladiolus make their start in the garden. Corms may be planted whenever there is no longer danger of frost. They may be panted every two weeks until early July for a sucession of bloom. Tuberous begonias are not moved to the garden until nights are balmy.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 21 (AP) --Hobart Manley of Savannah, a terrific competitor under fire, threw five finishing threes at Billy Joe Patton of Morganton, N.C., today to win the North and South amateur golf championship, one up, in a tense thirty-six-hole final.

The alarm that the British are coming, spread on April 18-19, 1775, was commemorated last week in five New England states by the concerted ringing of bells cast by the famous patriot of the midnight ride, Paul Revere, and by modern Minute Men.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- the Bethlehem Chapel of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul here this afternoon, Miss Lucia Beverly Hollerith, daughter of Herman Hollerith Jr. of Baltimore and Mrs. James Howard Waddell of Gloucester, Va., was married to Gillet Lefferts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lefferts of 36 Sutton Place South, New York.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 21--The Yugoslav Review of International Affairs reported today that Dobri Terpeshev, commander of the Bulgarian resistance movement during the Nazi occupation and one of the late Georgi Dimitrov's trusted lieutenants, had been eliminated from the political scene by Premier Vulko Chervenkov and exiled to Bucharest as Ambassador.

The Mortgage Bankers Association of America will hold its first West Coast convention and exhibit of building, industry and services in San Francisco on Sept. 11 to 14, with co-headquarters in the Mark Hopkins and Fairmont Hotels.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)-- The American Society of Newspaper Editors heard today that there was "appalling evidence" that Government officials are trying to withhold news from the people.
FRANKFORT, Germany, April 22 The political absorption of Eastern Germany into the Soviet system of the satellites is moving at a much faster pace than the Western powers expected.

A series of demands including a nine cents an hour increase and the introduction of a cost of living escalator provision will be made on the Westinghouse Electric Company under a wage program drafted yesterday by officials of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O.
LONDON, April 22 In the past few days the President of the Board of Trade has warned the nation that Britain faces industrial disaster unless sulphur supplies are immediately increased.

WASHINGTON, April 22 With industry seeking $24,000,000,000 for new plant and equipment, the Voluntary Credit Restraint Committee in effect told the nation's bankers today to "tighten up" on loans that do "not tend to increase output essential to the defense program."

MADRID, April 22 (Reuters) Leaflets secretly distributed in Bilbao during the past twenty-four hours called on workers in the Basque city and industrial center to strike tomorrow against the high cost of living.

Black walnuts in vacuum tins so that they retain their freshness and exceedingly individual flavor (doubtless one must learn to like the taste, as one does that of olives) are here for the first time, packed by R.E. Funsten Company of St. Louis.

PARIS, April 16 (by Airmail) French explorers and scientists have pushed forward their country's 111-year-old claim in Antarctica by establishing the first permanent human habitation in the desolate waste of Adelie Land. They spent a year on the southern continent.

Carl Furillo straightened out one of Sal Maglie's side-arm curves for a home run in the tenth inning at the Polo Grounds yesterday and sent the Giants crashing to their third straight defeat at the hands of the Dodgers. The score was 4 3, with 32,954 looking on.

One of the last of the old brownstone residences along Madison Avenue between Forty-second and Seventy-second Streets still in the private-home category has just changed hands.

Conversion deals for obtaining finished steel products are more difficult to arrange, it was reported here yesterday by the steel committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

So far the unacceded demand of the New York Counties Registered Nurses Association that special duty nurses be paid $12 a day has not impaired hospital care of the very sick. Though there have been some refusals to work for less than $12 a day, no strike is contemplated.

WASHINGTON, April 22 Rain today wiped out the series finale between the Yankees and Senators, thereby leaving Bucky Harris' surprising Nats in possession of the honors for the set, two games to one, and sending the Bombers back to New York for a busy week.

Pure sulphur melted by superheated water is pumped out of the ground along the Gulf Coast in huge quantities. It is also obtained from natural gas a source not yet fully developed. In 1939 some 2,330,000 tons of sulphur were sold in this country and abroad; last year 5,400,000 tons were sold but only 5,100,000 tons were mined.

HERMOSILLO, Mexico, April 22 A once-beautiful city park, now scarred and poverty-ridden, has become the staging point of thousands of ragged workers from all parts of Mexico. They are gambling their all on the slim chance of getting into the United States as contract farm laborers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP) Willie Jones, who had homered an inning earlier, slammed a bases-full single in the ninth inning today to give the Phillies a 6-5 victory over Johnny Sain and the Boston Braves.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) Thirty officers of the Committee for the Nation's Health accused the American Medical Association tonight of resorting to "mere name-calling" in opposition to national health insurance. They asked publicly for space in the association's Journal to back the plan.

Jack Goldsmith, 31-year-old former Long Island University basket ball star arrested on Saturday in the alleged fixing of the L.I.U.-Duquesne University game in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 1,1949, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday.

Edward Silver, formerly merchandiser of main-floor blouses for Mandel Brothers, Inc., Chicago, has been appointed merchandise manager of the basement division of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, effective May 7.

In a six-hour closed annual meeting the the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, the American Council on Education for Journalism voted to expand its ten-man committee to nineteen.

Next to that of the politicians, the strongest resistance to proposals for giving the Reconstruction Finance Corporation what Jesse Jones calls "a decent burial" is that which originates with the friends (professional and non-professional) of small business.

Aneurin Bevan, Britain's Labor Minister, resigned yesterday in protest against the budget, which, he said, stressed rearming over civilian needs, cut social services and did not distribute costs fairly "between different social classes."

Word that the first American soldiers, 1,545 of them, have started on their way home under the Army's new rotation program is heart-warming. Under the plan soldiers who have endured long and arduous service in the combat zone are being returned to the United States in numbers that are as large as the continued combat efficiency of the field forces will permit.

PARIS, April 22 Since the old method of signing peace treaties has proved to be a failure, Foreign minister Robert Schuman, said today European diplomacy must adopt the method of organizing a community of institutions to establish peace.
Negotiations have been made for the sale of the fourteen-story apartment building with six stores and seventy-one family units at 2730-38 Broadway and 230 West 105th Street.

PITTSBURGH, April 22 The steel industry was able last week to expand the steel ingot rate onehalf a point to 103 per cent of rated capacity. This improvement is all the more phenomenal when considered in the face of the tightness in raw materials, such as pig iron and steel scrap.

The young approach to an easy summer wardrobe is in a group of coordinated separates made of washable fabrics. The three patterns today offer a variety of possibilities. Adding up the pieces contained in all three envelopes some of the individual items are not sketched there are three...
PARIS, April 20 Scarf-panels are the leit motif of Robert Piguet's midsummer collection diffused with fruit and flower yellows.

Although price movements in the domestic cotton market were irregular last Week, quotations at the close of the period were moderately higher for the most part. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures, from the nearby July position to the distant July,...

CINCINNATI, April 22 (AP) The Pirates scored two runs in the top of the ninth inning today to break a 5-5 deadlock and defeat the Reds, 7 5. Gus Bell blasted a homer, three doubles and a single in five times up for the Pirates.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence R. Hayes of 170 East Seventy-ninth Street, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Saeger, to Theodore S. Watson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Watson of Greenwich, Conn., and New York.

HASWELL, England, April 22 (AP) Defense Minister Emanuel Shinwell said today that the removal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur gave the United Nations and representatives of the Chinese Communist Government a new chance to negotiate peace in Korea.

The new system of ship warrants as proposed by the Maritime Administration and now before Congress as H.R. 3437 seeks to impose considerably more drastic controls than were contained in similar World War II legislation, the Association of American Ship owners said yesterday.

UNITED STATES EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Korea, April 22 Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, United Nations commander in Korea, said today that the Soviet Union had given indication of planning a "third round of aggression" here with some new "miscellaneous so-called volunteers" taking their places beside the North Korean and Communist Chinese armies.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 22 Peg's Pride, owned by the Hutchinson Farms and ridden by Miss Nancy Clapp, captured the jumper championship as the Boulder Brook's two-day spring horse show ended tonight. Placed in reserve was Arthur M. Nardin's black gelding Trader Bedford.

LONDON, April 22 A revolt of the Left Wing within the Cabinet over the scale of expenditure of British rearmament threatened tonight to upset the delicate balance that has enabled Prime Minister Attlee's Labor Government to remain in power.

WASHINGTON, April 22 The baffling, intriguing personality of MacArthur the man cast a long shadow across the country at the week-end as the nation recovered from its biggest emotional binge in many years.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 22 French and Vietnamese forces eliminated over the week-end about 1,000 Vietminh combatants in the biggest guerrilla clean-up operation ever staged in Indo-China, when elements of three armies closed around a guerrilla base area twenty-five miles southwest of the Tongking port of Haiphong.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 22 Staves and knives came into play in downtown Teheran today when rival groups of student demonstrators clashed in the course of manifesting their patriotic fervor. Beyond a few cracked skulls and minor cuts and bruises no serious damage was done.

DETROIT, April 22 Efforts to settle the transit strike that has immobilized street cars and buses in Detroit since early yesterday failed today when no progress was made at a negotiating session. The city-owned transit system is known as the Detroit Street Railways.

John A. Hennessy, retired newspaper editor whose disclosures of corruption in the city and state governments aided reform movements in the first two decades of the century, died yesterday at his home in Brooklyn after several months' illness. He was 91 years old.

AMSTERDAM, April 22 Raising of the Dutch bank rate from 3 to 4 per cent was due to lack of success last week of the Government's 200,000,000-guilder 3 per cent consolidation loan and means an end of the cheap money era.

In the semi-darkness of the damp underground terminal beneath the Manhattan plaza of the Queensboro Bridge yesterday morning, fifty-one bus haters, or trolley lovers the terms appeared to be synonymous climbed aboard an aging street car to begin the...

Vladimir Horowitz, pianist, will be heard tonight for the first time in a broadcast from one of his concert recitals. Beginning after the intermission at Carnegie Hall, the pianist will play Mussorgsky's...

Four hundred Army and Navy cadets from Venezuela, Peru and Colombia heard the Catholic Choir of the United States Military Academy sing the musical setting of solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

For almost seven months the representatives of nearly twoscore nations have been quietly working away in the seaside town of Torquay, in the south of England, in the interests of world peace. The kind of peace they have been working for is economic rather than political.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) Billy Pierce and Eddie Robinson collaborated in a 3-2 victory today for the White Sox in the rubber tilt of their three-game series with the Tigers.

Australian and New Zealand war dead from Gallipoli to Korea were honored yesterday at various memorial services here to mark Anzac Day. The actual anniversary falls on Wednesday, thirty-six years after the first Anzacs landed in Gallipoli, Turkey.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 22 Israel declared tonight that an "intolerable situation" had arisen in the troubled demilitarized zone on the Syrian border and, whether or not one agreed with the Israelis' description, the situation certainly was not one to inspire confidence that peaceful conditions on the border could be restored soon.

Mme. Olive Fremstad, for years one of the most notable members of the Metropolitan Opera Company, died Saturday night at a nursing home in Irvington, Westchester County, after a long illness. Although accounts of her career do not disclose her exact age, it is known that she was in her eighties.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur remained in seclusion in his Waldorf-Astoria Hotel suite yesterday for the second day in succession.
LAFAYETTE, Ala., April 22 (AP) Former United States Senator J. Thomas Heflin, who broke with the Democratic party after the President in 1928, died today at the age of 82.
BAYVILLE, L.I., April 22 Two men and a boy were lost in the choppy waters of Long Island Sound and one man was rescued this morning when their skiff capsized on a fishing trip.

That versatile container, the basket, is produced in so many sizes, shapes and weaves by various countries throughout the world that one New York shop devotes itself to selling just this one item. Called the Basket Bazaar, it is in the quarters formerly occupied by the Haitian Bazaar at 133 West Third Street.
ST. PAUL, April 22 (AP) Picking up where they left off last night, the Meister Braus of Chicago broke a ten-year American Bowling Congress record today.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) The Defense Department today identified 503 more casualties in the Korean war in a list that includes the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

TOKYO, Monday, April 23 The United States will not neglect the security of Asia against the rising tide of communism despite commitments under the North Atlantic pact, John Foster Dulles, special Presidential envoy, told the Japanese today.

ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP) Andy Pafko brought the Cubs from behind twice today, batting in five runs on two homers to help defeat the Cardinals, 10 5. Bob Schultz held the Redbirds hitless in five innings of relief pitching after the Cards got to starter Bob Rush for eight safeties.

MANILA, Monday, April 23 (AP) Communist Hukbalahap rebels attacked a Philippine Army barracks Sunday night near where five American enlisted airmen and the Philippine-born wife of one of them were slain in ambush Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) The Senate committee that is investigating crime will ask Congress to authorize a full-scale campaign against the illicit traffic in narcotics. Legislative proposals to that end are among the recommendations tentatively approved for inclusion in the crime committee's final report which must be filed by April 30.

WHEN James A. Michener wrote "Tales of the South Pacific" he was only a writer of "professional educational books with lots of footnotes" who had kept his eyes open during his service in the Navy. Today he is a famous and prosperous author. His South Sea "Tales" still ranks among the half dozen best books yet written by an American about the war.
Two Far Rockaway, Queens, youths were being held in the Franklin County jail at St. Albans, V yesterday in connection with the theft of $6,200 from a Far Rockaway synagogue.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) Strong backing by businss men for a Federal sales tax was reported today by Representative Richard M. Simpson, Republican of Pennsylvania, on the basis of a countrywide survey.

Announcement has been made by Mr, and Mrs. Frederic W. Lincoln of 1060 Fifth Avenue, and Deerpark, Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Isabel, to Basil Beebe Elmer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer of New York. An early summer wedding is planned.

The city's 2 per cent sales tax yielded a total revenue of $109,076,174 for the nine months ended March 31, as compared with $99,309,866 for the same period in the 1949-50 fiscal year a 10 per cent increase according to figures made public yesterday by the Department of Finance.

Mrs. Douglas MacArthur and her 13-year-old son, Arthur, became plain sightseeing tourists yesterday afternoon. They gaped at the wonders of New York's waterfront, stood hand-in-hand in silent awe at the foot of the Statue of Liberty and craned their necks for a long look at the headquarters of the United Nations.

The late Ernest Bevin was the counterweight of Aneurin Bevan in Britain's Labor Government. Prime Minister Attlee, harassed into illness by the strain of holding his team together and maintaining the marginal power of his party, has lost the two strongest trade union leaders in the Cabinet, one...

The Civil Air Patrol, consisting of 2,300 active members in this state, including some women pilots, has offered its services to the New York State Civil Defense Commission, Col. Lawrence Wilkinson, director of the commission, announced yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, April 22 The food situation in Bihar State has deteriorated to a point where the disastrous effects of famine have begun to appear. Prices of rice and other grains have gone up so high that small landowners are forced to sell their farms and cattle to buy food.

Latin American export drafts in process of collection rose in March, for the sixth successive month, from $119,000,00 in February to $129,000,000. The figures are taken from the export draft collection experience of the fifteen banks which report each month to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

No one needs to be told why Americans celebrate Thanksgiving, but another holiday that also dates from a Puri tan custom has passed out of American life. Passed out, that is, in every state except New Hampshire.

ARMONK, N.Y., April 22 The twenty-fourth spring trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Club came to the end of their three-day run today with the chief prize, the "top" Turnure Trophy, in the possession of Harry Townsend of New Haven.

A program of twentieth-century music by Belgian composers, sponsored jointly by the library's music section and the Belgian Government Information Center, was offered at the Public Library yesterday afternoon.

ONE of the most remarkable of the superchampions of Sport's Golden Age was Johnny weissmuller. The present generation remembers him only as a somewhat portly Tarzan of the movies, an inarticulate fellow who swings out of trees and strangles lions or crocodiles with his bare hands.
Construction of a new four-track vertical lift bridge over the Harlem River to cost in excess of $10,000,000 will be started next week by the New York Central Railroad.

CHICAGO, April 22 Wheat prices avaraged higher last week on the Board of Trade while corn and oats were lower. Unfavorable crop comments from Oklahoma and Kansas were responsible for the upturn in wheat while hedging pressure caused the downturn in coarse grains.

Roger Bannister, middle distance star who is regarded as the British Empire's best mile prospect since the late Jack Lovelock, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, early yesterday morning aboard a Pan American World Airways plane from London.
No serious challenge to Carmine G. DeSapio as leader of Tammany is expected at today's meeting of its executive committee.

The plan to send a substantial military mission to Formosa to supervise the use of American aid and to assist in some technical fields is part of the implementation of a fundamentally sound policy. It does not mean that the United States is underwriting an expedition to the Chinese mainland by the Nationalist forces.

The Emery Air Freight Corporation is planning the largest national campaigh in its history. Full page advertiements will be printed in national magazines and large ads will be run in business publications. The drive will continue through the end of 1951.
TOKYO, Monday, April 23 (AP) General Headquarters communique 862 covering Sunday's operations:
GENEVA, April 22 Disintegration of the European market for steel and its components is now greater than it ever has been in modern times apart from war.
Blanche Yurka returned to Broadway yesterday and, as she has done so often in the past, enriched the stage with her artistry.

Add "The Long Days" to last week's wholesale number of departures from Broadway. The total now stands at five. With a cast headed by Frances Starr and Jeffrey Lynn, the Davis Snow drama of New England opened Friday night at the Empire after having four previews.

Six members of Yale University's political science department are leaving it to join the faculty of Princeton University after a disagreement over educational policy with Dr. A. Whit ney Griswold, president of Yale

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 22 One hundred and forty pilots and 150 observers of the Civil Air Patrol, an Air Force auxiliary made up of volunteers from civilian life, flew from Westchester County Airport here today in a search and rescue practice mission designed to demonstrate their preparedness to help in the event of an enemy attack upon this area.
WASHINGTON, April 22 Selective Service today, through a high spokesman urged, and all but demanded, that every draft-eligible college student take the forthcoming aptitude test.

Before overflow audiences at the. Waldorf-Astoria and Commodore Hotels last night, Israeli and Zionist leaders asked support of the Israel bond issue of $500,000,000 which will be floated in this country beginning May 1.
ACF-Brill Motors Company--March quarter: Net profit, $419,804, equal to 43c a share on net sales of $3,921,919, compared with a loss of $87,520 on sales of $3,029,843 a year earlier.
A strong rise in volume of foreign goods available in the American market will follow longawaited issuance of an import price control order, trade members predicted last week.

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra closed its 109th season yesterday afternoon with a concert that drew an audience of 2,600 to Carnegie Hall. In response to prolonged applause at the end, Dimitri Mitropoulos, the musical director, made a brief speech.

M'ARTHUR DISCORD DEPLORED BY CLAY Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former United States Military Governor of Germany, declared in a radio interview last night that he hoped the controversy centering about General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had not endangered our European defense program.

BOSTON, April 22 (AP) The Red Sox won their second and third games of the season today, whipping the Athletics, 6 5 and 7 4. The second game was shortened to five and a half innings because of a peculiarity in the Sunday law which provides that a baseball game played under lights must finish at 6:30 P.M., local time.

John Ranck, young American pianist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His program comprised a Partita by Frederick Werle, which received its first hearing; Milhaud's Sonata, two preludes by Messiaen, Poulenc's "Napoli" and offerings by Liszt and Chopin.
International shipping lines with services to Australia are greatly concerned over the steady deterioration of port and cargo-handling conditions in the Antipodes.

Another appeal for donations of blood needed for immediate shipment to Korea was made yesterday by the Greater New York Chapters of the Red Cross Blood Program. At the same time, an nouncement was made that two collection records of the Greater...

The Hakoah F.C. blanked the Brooklyn Hispanos, 2 0, and thereby finished first in the Lewis Cup soccer competition at Hawthorne Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. The Hakoahs will play off for the cup with the Philadelphia Nationals who were second.
CHARLESTON, S.C., April 22 (AP) Probation and prison officials of fourteen Southeastern States were urged tonight to consider reform of the sentencing process for young offenders.
A well-known cartoonist and a New York lawyer have just acquired estates and acreage in the northern part of Westchester County for their homes.

The United States Merchant Marine is one of the most useful but least lauded organizations for its military and peacetime service to its country. During the Second World War its members bravely faced the dangers of the seas to supply our embattled forces,...
Tie-in sales, particularly in the case of scotch whisky, remain the most vexatious problem of the liquor trade, it was reported last week.
Industry was asked yesterday for its cooperation in "ending prejudice against workers with a relief history."

The Bach Cantata Guild, a cooperative group of twenty-five singers and fourteen instrumentalists, culminated its activities of the 1950-51 season late yesterday afternoon with its annual concert at Town Hall under the leadership of Peter Sozio, who was in charge last year when the guild gave its first concert at Times Hall.
Executives of leading newspapers throughout the country, here for their annual Newspaper Week, reported yesterday that business generally was good, and in some places booming with defense orders.

Many group shows and one-man exhibitions of paintings and sculpture will be on view here this week. Beginning tomorrow, the Wildenstein Galleries will show paintings and drawings by Dau mier and Delacroix.
The mounting costs of highway construction and an unprecedented rise in highway traffic are forcing the return of toll roads throughout the country, the Brookings Institution reported yesterday.
CLEVELAND; April 22 (AP) The Indians won their first doubleheader of the season from the Browns today, 10 3 and 4 3, behind the pitching of righthanders Early Wynn and Mike Garcia.
ASCENT TO HEAVEN, by Adolf Rudnicki; translated by H.C. Stevens (Roy, $2.50). Four true stories about Warsaw in the war.
LONDON, April 22 It has been almost a year now since Larry Adler, the harmonica player, has appeared in any theatre, night club or radio studio in the United States.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 22 The feature that distinguishes Colombia from any Latin-American country today and that perhaps makes it unhappily unique in the world is the country-wide violence.

"General MacArthur's address to Congress will go down as one of the greatest in history," the Rev. Dr. F. Howard Callahan said yesterday in his sermon at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eigty-sixth Street.

Requests for graduation dresses and short and long formals and open orders on sheer street dresses and shantungs dominated the wholesale market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Fluorescent colors sold well in men's wear novelty items and in girls' sportswear.

The final barrier to the construction of a $6,000,000 replacement for Pier 57, North River, was eliminated yesterday with the announcement of lease arrangements for a site for the building of the three huge concrete boxes that will support the new dock.

BERLIN, April 22 Accompanied by a delegation of his Cabinet members, Boleslav Bierut, President of Poland, arrived in Berlin this morning to be the guest for several days of the pro-Soviet Eastern German Government.

Democracy, to become rooted in Japan, must begin with "faith in God," Lieut. Col, Paul Rusch of the Army Reserves declared in a sermon yesterday morning at St. James' Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today that United Nations planes would follow any Communist planes attacking Allied troops in Korea "until we get them."

PARIS, April 23--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, accompanied by a small personal staff, will fly to northern Italy tomorrow afternoon to inspect ground and air units of that country's defense forces.

In a speedy grand jury action, Jack Goldsmith, former Long Island University basketball player, and a 45-year-old convicted fixer in a college sports scandal two years ago, were indicted yesterday on bribery charges.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 23 (UP)--Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., shot seven birdies and an eagle to win medalist honors in the forty-ninth North and South women's golf championship today with a four-under-par 70.

The estate of Caroline McCormack Slade has sold the four-story dwelling at 49 East Sixty-seventh Street to a client of Kenneth Ives Co., brokers in the transaction. The property is assessed at $62,500.
The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation "really was operating with suppliers' money on Jan. 31, 1948," a witness told Judge John W. Clancy in Federal Court here yesterday.
TRENTON, April 23--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll accused the Port of New York Authority today of obscuring some of its activities by assigning them to committees.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The Temporary Emergency Railroad Wage Panel has recommended to Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization chief, that he approve the 6-cents-an-hour escalator wage increase provided by the agreement between the railroads and 1,000,000 nonoperating employes.

San Francisco sold yesterday issues of school and airport bonds amounting to $12,100,000. A banking syndicate headed by Bank of America National Trust Savings Association bought $10,000,000 of school bonds due on April 1, 1952 to 1966, on a bid of 100.0941 for 1 s and 1 s, for an interest cost of 1.713 per cent.
Following is the text of the speech made yesterday by Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to Great Britain, at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press:
The National Manpower Council will seek to determine how the nation may best employ its manpower to meet the expanding military, industrial and technical demands of its global responsibilities.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 23--The efforts of the Iranian Parliament to implement its decision of last month to nationalize the country's vast oil reserves bore their first fruit today with the emergence of two programs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 23 In a discordant meeting the Westchester Board, of Supervisors granted an $850,000 easement across the county today for a natural gas pipeline and gave the first land to the state for construction of the New England Thruway.

LONDON, April 23 (AP)--Eight world track and field records were recognized by the International Amateur Athletic Federation today. Four were made by the United States, three by Russia and one by Sweden.

Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to Great Britain, urged this country yesterday to maintain its "grand alliance" and "united front" with the British Commonwealth as "indispensable" to the security of the United States.

A powwow was held yesterday at the Park Lane Hotel, with Navajo blankets eclipsing the Flemish petit-point in the "tapestry room" and Indian chiefs beating Indian drums. there and the Sioux, in their best eagle-feather headdresses and beadwork, like Red Wing, who played opposite Dustin Farnum in "The Squaw Man."

Against the Athletics, a club that may--with luck--finish seventh in the American League (if the pre-season predictions hold up), the Yankees virtually bunted their way to a 5-4 victory at the Stadium yesterday. True, the solid smashing of Phil Rizzuto, Joe DiMaggio and Jackie Jensen helped Vic Raschi gain his second triumph, but finesse and speed, as much as power, determined the outcome.

The strategy of price-wage stabilization, as administered in the present emergency, has been to move not from the particular to the general but from general controls that are loose and flexible to general controls that are refined and tight.
ZURICH, April 23--On Sunday a week ago, two proposals to amend the Swiss Federal Constitution were submitted to a national referendum.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The Senate's investigation of military and foreign policy in Asia and of the dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from his Far Eastern commands may begin next Monday with the general as the first witness.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower announced yesterday the names of thirteen persons, including representatives of business, labor and agriculture, who will serve on the national policy board of Columbia University's American Assembly.
The conventional fence of dunnage and shoring timbers that has always been built around the cargo in a vessel's holds may give way soon to a modern, lightweight net of cable.
