Television has gone to sea. The Sun Oil Company has placed sets with 12 -inch screens aboard its eight tankers in coastwise service. Off-watch seamen may now keep further vigil over the air waves as their ships ply between the Gulf of Mexico and ports northwards.

Stanley Kempner and Morton wormser have sold the two-story taxpayer at 147-20 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, to an investing client of the Brener Lewis Company, broker. Albert Fribourg was attorney for the seller and E. Wolf acted for the buyer. The property, on a plot 20 by 100 feet, was conveyed for cash above a first mortgage of $72,500.

Heavy fighting was general yesterday along the entire front as United Nations forces inflicted heavy casualties on attacking enemy formations. In the western sector, our units adjusted positions under steady pressure. Enemy attacks were contained in the eastcentral sector although heavy enemy pressure was exerted in this area. The eastern sector remained relatively quiet.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The allocation of rubber available for civilian use will be increased by 10 per cent next month, the National Production Authority announced today. It added, however, that the increased supply will not be usable for passenger car tires and a variety of other products.

CINCINNATI, April 23--Ninety-two per cent of 694 teachers and school officials interviewed in the metropolitan Cincinnati area are in favor of bringing television into the classroom as an... educational tool, according to a University of Cincinnati survey. The educators are connected with fourteen public and parochial high schools.

Ike Williams yesterday appeared at the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission and signed formal articles for the longdeferred defense of his world lightweight title. His opponent in a fifteen-round match at Madison Square Garden on May 11 will be James Carter of the Bronx.

The Willis Avenue Bridge, busiest toll-free traffic link between Manhattan and the East Bronx, will be closed for eighteen months starting next Tuesday to permit rehabilitation of the approaches of the fifty-year-old span.

A new citizenship education program for the armed forces, designed to give servicemen a practical understanding of what they are training and fighting for, will be introduced soon at Army, Navy and Air Force training installations throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Animal experiments at the University of Chicago, reported here today at the annual spring meeting of the National Academy of Sciences, have shown that minute amounts of potassium, phosphorus and magnesium are essential for the proper utilization of the body-building protein foods.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Once more, summoning his imagination, this correspondent is privileged to lay bare the contents of another secret communication to a Chief of State behind the Iron Curtain from Comrade Astigmatoff, the celebrated, and oftenintercepted, Communist diplomat in Washington. It follows:

HARTFORD, Conn., April 23-- A sub-committee of the Congressional committee on small business heard testimony today from a steady stream of Connecticut small business operators that the survival of their business is threatened by Government stockpiling of critical materials such as copper and nickel.

Evidence of the increasing acceptance of metal furniture for the contemporary home was an announcement yesterday that a sofa with an iron frame had won first prize in the furniture category in the annual home furnishings products competition conducted by the American Institute of Decorators.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., April 23 --Richard Hallett Meredith Robinson, retired industrialist and expert on maritime matters, died in his home here today, after a brief illness, at the age of 78.

Aneurin Bevan's resignation from the British Cabinet--followed by that of Harold Wilson--has clearly precipitated a new and dangerous crisis for Prime Minister Attlee's regime. Even before Mr. Bevan's defection the Labor party's parliamentary majority was small. Now, if even only a small group of Labor deputies follow Mr. Bevan into...
Uncle Miltie definitely will not be a starter in the Kentucky Derby.

WHEN you consider the volume of anglers that crowd the banks of popular Catskill trout streams, offering an assortment of baits and lures, you wonder how a trout could resist temptation and live long enough to weigh five pounds, but latest reports indicate that some of them do.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The Supreme Court, dividing 5 to 4, reversed today the convictions of four Miami policemen for conspiracy to violate civil rights by using what the tribunal described as brutal third-degree methods to obtain confessions from lumber yard employes accused of theft.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 23--An almost complete integration of the economy of East Germany with that of the Soviet Union and its satellites, and a gradual but general rise in living standards, are two of the main reasons why the Russians have achieved an apparently unshakable grip on the Soviet zone and why the division of this country is assuming an air of permanence as far as East Germany is concerned.

Continuance of some Marshall Plan aid to Austria for two more years is essential to complete its real economic recovery, it was declared yesterday at a luncheon of the United States Austrian Chamber of Commerce at the Town Hall Club.
Coordination of this country's foreign and military policies was urged last night by Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23--The machinery by which Leo Durocher had hoped to get his Giants off to a flying start in the National League flag race was still running in reverse tonight as the Polo Grounders went down to defeat before Eddie Sawyer's Phillies, 8 to 4, before a crowd of 17,283.

GENEVA, April 23--A number of leading representatives of labor, religious and cultural groups are beginning to wonder whether efforts to draft a United Nations covenant of human rights may not in the end do more harm than good to actual human rights throughout the world.

Wool and wool top trading settled down to a wait-and-see policy yesterday and both were steady. Traders are looking for guidance on developments in foreign markets and action from Washington on ceiling prices.

VIENNA, April 22--Rationing of bread, instituted this week in Hungary, once known as the granary of Europe, was the latest of a series of indications that the "people's democracies" were heading toward what the West would consider an economic breakdown.

THE Philadelphia Athletics came to town yesterday and for the first time in fifty years the sparse figure of Connie Mack was missing from the dugout along with his famous trade-marks, the high, starched collar and the wigwagging scorecard. Any ordinary individual would have quailed at the thought of becoming the replacement for Baseball's Oldest Inhabitant. But James Joseph Dykes is no ordinary individual.

Opening what appears to be their long-expected spring offensive, the Communist armies in Korea have turned on the advancing United Nations forces and launched counterattacks that have precipitated a raging battle all along the 100-mile front across the peninsula. There is still some caution in evaluating the enemy's intentions but no doubt that he has embarked on a major military effort.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The appointment of Mr. Moody apparently will strengthen President Truman's hand in foreign policy. This was suggested today both by Administration Democrats and by such internationalist Republicans as Senators James H. Duff of Pennsylvania and Wayne Morse of Oregon.
BILBAO, Spain, April 23-- About 250,000 workers in Spain's heavy industrial belt went on strike today, and the Government issued an ultimatum to them to return to work tomorrow or lose their jobs.

PARIS, April 23--With fresh variations upon his apron theme, Jesse Desses shows midseason frocks of great feminine charm in shantung taffeta, organza, stiffened laces and net. Discretion in coloring, the grays, cream whites and navy blues, add to the impression of elegance.

Barring a national emergency, the summer playhouses soon will take up the Broadway slack and provide employment for the rank and file in all branches of the theatre. Inquiry yesterday at the Actors Equity Association disclosed that thirty-five theatres already had registered their intention to conform with union regulations.
WASHINGTON, April 23--The Supreme Court apparently sealed the fate today of the seven Nazis sentenced to hang in Germany for atrocities committed in concentration camps during World War II.
WASHINGTON, April 23--The Department of Defense announced today it would start to draft doctors in July because the number of volunteers was too small to fill the needs of the armed services.

The Ford Foundation, which set up last week a fund for the advancement of education with a first grant of $7,154,000, announced yesterday the establishment of a fund for adult education, with an interim budget of $3,000,000.
Underwriting of securities effective today include new issues of natural gas company and commercial bank capital shares valued at more than $26,800,000. The offerings are as follows:

CHICAGO, April 23--Less favorable news from the Korean war front dominated the action of the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today with short-covering and new buying resulting in higher prices, wheat being up as much as 2 cents a bushel at one time, and new-crop months leading, as the May position was under hedging pressure.

SHIRLEY JACKSON, the brilliant young woman who wrote "The Lottery," is a prac titioner of literary witchcraft. But even the most conscientious witches can't always cast spells of equal power. "The Lottery" is one of the most effective short stories of our time, a haunting combination of sinister symbolism and enigmatic shocks.

WASHINGTON, April 23-- Analyzing the cost of flotation of about $30,000,000,000 of securities in the five-year period, 1945-1949, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the expense averaged $2.64 for every $100 of gross proceeds. Of the $2.64, commissions and discounts to investment bankers amounted to $2.12, and other expenses to $0.52.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23 --Additional details were made known here today of the recent discovery and excavation at Jericho of the largest ancient palace yet uncovered in Palestine.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 23--The Yugoslav Government has appealed to the United States and British Governments to underwrite its heavy annual trade deficits for 1951-54 to make it possible for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to grant a series of capital investment loans totaling $200,000,000.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP)--Dr. Elmer L. Henderson, president of the American Medical Association, said today his characterization of the Committee for the Nation's Health as "pinkish" was "an understatement rather than an exaggeration."
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)-- Holly Mims, 157 pounds, Washington, needed only 41 seconds to knock out Pat Byers, 150, Reading, Pa., tonight in a scheduled ten rounder.

The people of Europe in the main are in sympathy with American foreign policy in the Far East crisis, according to various editors and writers among thirty-five newspaper men who arrived at La Guardia Airport yesterday from Paris.

The first meeting of the Tammany Hall executive committee since the November election was marked yesterday by the failure of supporters of Mayor Impellitteri to make inroads against the continued Tammany leadership of Carmine G. DeSapio.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur never was informed officially of the reasons for his dismissal by President Truman and still does not have the "faintest idea" why the action was taken, an aide said yesterday.

Over the week-end a statement on General MacArthur's behalf was issued by his military secretary, Maj. Gen. Courtney Whitney. The statement dealt with the much-discussed question of whether General MacArthur should have anticipated the intervention of Communist China in the Korean war. According to this statement:

The National Civil Service League charged yesterday that political influence and civil service procedure had "become inextricably entwined" in the selection of employes by the Office of Price Stabilization. The regional O.P.S., with jurisdiction over New York and New Jersey, retorted that employment methods here belied the charge.

PARIS, April 23--Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin, French Resident General in Morocco, will not assume the key post of Commander in Chief of Western Ground Forces in the Central European Sector until Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef effects drastic reforms in the native administration of Morocco.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Hearings on whether the Communist party and its members must register as part of a foreign-controlled agency got under way today after the new Subversive Activities Control Board had ruled it had power to handle the case.

The first meeting of the Joseph Collins Foundation, a million-dollar fund to provide for the needs of medical students, was held yesterday, Dr. L. Beverley Chaney, in whose office at 572 Park Avenue the session was held, was elected president of the new foundation.
The sentencing of Harry Gross was postponed yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions for the third time.
TRENTON, April 23--The Port of New York Authority may be sued under a measure approved today by the New Jersey Senate, 17 to 2.

Civil defense volunteers throughout the nation were awaiting yesterday the outcome of the debate in the Senate Subcommittee on Banking on a bill designed to provide insurance coverage for them. Neither the Federal Government nor the states have assumed that responsibility.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and final prices were 6 points lower to 19 higher, compared with last Saturday's closing prices.

LONDON, April 23--The rift in the British Labor party over rearmament spread and deepened today When Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, followed Aneurin Bevan out of... the Government fold.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 24--Chinese Communist troops tore a big hole in United Nations lines today and plunged south of the Thirtyeighth Parallel in central Korea. A Chinese division with cavalry mounted on Mongolian ponies was reported in the forefront of the drive.

Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to Great Britain, chose a good time to remind us how imperative it is, in the cause of preserving the free world, for the British and the Americans to understand each other and to remain good friends.

Morris Wolf, senior partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Wolf, Block, Schorr and Solis-Cohen, has been elected a director of the Pennsylvania Company for Banking and Trust, Philadelphia. Robert A. Wilson, vice president, has been named senior vice president of the bank's trust department.
A 13-year-old American boy saw the Big Show--Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus--for the first time yesterday afternoon. In fact, it was his first circus.
Big American manufacturers who are large consumers of pig lead are considering buying the metal directly from producers abroad to obtain adequate supplies.

Nine of the eleven new Waverly decorative fabrics, which will be exhibited at the meeting of the American Institute of Decorators in Grand Rapids next week, are now available through decorators at F. Schumacher Co., 60 West Fortieth Street.
LANSING Mich., April 23--Blair Moody, 49-year-old Washington correspondent of The Detroit News, was appointed United States Senator today to succeed the late Arthur H. Vandenberg,

WASHINGTON, April 23--The Office of Education today announced that grants totaling $46,500,000 had been reserved for 100 school construction projects in "Federally-affected" school districts and on Federal property.

WASHINGTON, April 23--John Garfield, motion picture actor, swore before the committee on UnAmerican Activities of the House of Representatives today that he not only never had been a Communist but, to his knowledge, never had known one.

ROME, April 23--City authorities today ordered the police to close down the printing establishment of The Rome Daily American, the only English-language daily in Italy, on the charge that the noise of its presses disturbed the tranquillity of the tenants in near-by houses.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)-- John Maragon today quoted a British trader in United States surplus war goods as saying his group had an "understanding" with a State Department official and had bought the official a set of Wedgwood china.
Members of The Associated Press re-elected three directors yesterday and chose four new ones.
The city again is finding it difficult to buy beef for municipal hospitals and other institutions, Commissioner of Purchase John Splain said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 23--A legal battle over the little toy pig that clings to Junior's cereal bowl was decided by the Federal Supreme Court today. Now it can be a pig, a puppy or anything else.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP)-- Democratic members of the Senate Crime Committee today proposed the establishment of a Federal Crime Commission and a Senate-House "watchdog" committee to carry on the investigation of nation-wide crime.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)-- Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, predicted today that Congress will make it "specifically illegal" for the Administration to freeze farm parity in any move to cut food prices.

Charles Keck, sculptor of one of the city's best-known monuments, the statue of the Rev. Francis P. Duffy, famous chaplain of New York's "Fighting 69th" of the first World War, died yesterday morning at his home, Gypsy Trail Camp, in Carmel, N.Y.

The Communist counter-offensive in Korea tore a large hole in Allied lines. United Nations forces gave up Yonchon as they fell back before possibly 700,000 Reds. Fighting was bitter along a 100-mile front, but the enemy was suffering heavy losses as he crossed into South Korea in some places. An unidentified bomber attacked United Nations supply lines. [1:8.]
CHICAGO, Apri1 23--Gen. Charles G. Dawes, former Vice President of the United States, died tonight at his home in near-by Evanston, Ill. His age was 85.

The stock market followed yesterday a highly irregular pattern. No definite conclusions were reached and the indecisive close illustrated by the fact that although more issues lost ground than gained the composite rate enjoyed an edge of 0.45 point. It was the most indefinite session in recent weeks.

Like shad from the Hudson River and the first lilacs in florist shops, the arrival of outdoorgrown rhubarb is a welcome sign of spring. Classified botanically as a vegetable but gastronomically as a fruit, the tart, reddish stalks put in a timely appearance when most other fruits are scarce.
DETROIT, April 23 (AP)--The Tigers, who had hit only one home run previously this season, opened up with a barrage by Joe Ginsberg, Pat Mullin and Vic Wertz to trip the Browns, 7 to 4, today.
HERMOSILLO Mexico, Apri1 23 --This spring's recruiting of Mexican workers for farm labor in the Western United States is assuming the proportion of a major governmental headache for Mexico.

BUENOS AIRES, April 23-- Britain and Argentina signed a new meat agreement tonight that will soon give more beef to Britons. The agreement ends a ten-month deadlock over Argentine demands for higher prices.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Small business today was given additional assurance that its interests will get prime consideration in the placing of defense contracts. William H. Harrison, head of the Defense Production Administration, told a news conference that his agency is giving special study to the problem of steering defense contracts to small business enterprises.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23-- An anonymous benefaction of $500,000 for the establishment of a fund for world-affairs research was announced today by the president of Yale, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold.

Charlie Payerle, sophomore center fielder, clicked for eight successive hits as he led New York University to a 29-8 victory over the United States Merchant Marine Academy in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Ohio Field yesterday.
Common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange in the first 1951 quarter broke every American record, according to a compilation by that institution.

HONG KONG, April 22--There are few aspects of Chinese life that have not been touched by the Communist revolution and multiple propaganda campaigns being waged by the Peiping Government. The newspaper advertisement is no exception.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23-- Robert L. Lippert, independent film producer and distributor, announced today that he has concluded a precedential agreement with James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, which will permit the release of motion pictures made for theatrical distribution to television.

Men's and boy's outerwear manufacturers this year expect gains of 10 to 25 per cent in dollar volume and 10 per cent increases in unit volume, according to the National Outerwear and Sportswear Association, Inc.

Hundreds of tons of fighting equipment for the defense of Western Europe swung into the hold of the 15,000-ton French aircraft carrier Dixmude yesterday as she swayed gently at dockside in the Staten Island Terminal of the New York Port of Embarkation.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP)-- The Senate ignored the pleas of Democratic leaders today and sent the Administration's capital dispersal bill back to its Public Works Committee for further study.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP)-- The Secretary of Commerce, Charles Sawyer, and nine other officials today won an eleventh-hour postponement of contempt charges handed down against them in the case of the Dollar Steamship Line.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The House Foreign Affairs Committee, bowing to an ultimatum from the House Rules Committee, tentatively approved today the draft of a new bill extending grain aid to famine-threatened India as a loan rather than a gift.

For the second straight day Carl Furillo delivered the winning blow for the Dodgers in an extra-inning game when he belted a two-andtwo pitch high off the Ebbets Field scoreboard in the sixteenth inning yesterday off Warren Spahn of the Braves.

"Season in the Sun," the comedy by Wolcott Gibbs, is scheduled to end its run at the Cort Theatre Saturday night, May 5. A reprieve is possible, however, if business improves or if the sponsors, Courtney Burr and Malcolm Pearson, can reach new terms with the cast.

A plea for American aid in obtaining newsprint for the newspapers of India was voiced yesterday by J.C. Jain, general manager of Banett Coleman Co., which publishes The Times of India, Bombay, The Illustrated Weekly of India and other publications.

MOBILE, Ala., April 24 (AP)-- Two ship officers testified today the Esso Suez was moving full speed through the fog when it collided with another tanker in the open sea and killed perhaps thirtynine men.

HONG KONG, April 24--The pro-Nationalist Sin Wen Tien-ti said in its current issue here that an international Communist military organization with the Red flag bearing eleven yellow stars had been established in Mukden under the command of Soviet Marshal Kurenkov.

WASHINGTON, April 24--John Foster Dulles, President Truman's special envoy to Tokyo, declared today that United States policy toward Japan carried forward General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's "unwavering will to resist Communist aggression in the Western Pacific."

A small Quaker clinic that has worked for three years on the most intimate personal problems of a thousand New Yorkers will close today and leave a vacuum distressing alike to public authorities and private welfare agencies.

The blame for corruption and in efficiency in local government rests with the voters themselves, Paul Crowell and Warren Moscow, political reporters for THE NEW YORK TIMES, told an audience of teachers yesterday in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 --Prospects of a showdown on the principle of repayment of creators when a theatrical motion picture is used for television appeared today with an announcement by the Screen Actors Guild that it would support the Screen Writers Guild on the issue in dealings with the Independent Motion Picture Producers Association.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 24 (UP) --Seventeen thousand employes returned to work today at the big Anglo-Iranian Oil Company refinery in Abadan. A Government official said the series of strikes against the company could be considered at an end.

Again the whys, wheres, hows and whens of traffic accidents are set forth by the Travelers Insurance Companies in their annual booklet on the subject, which this year bears the thoughtcompelling title, "Rest in Pieces."

PARIS, April 24--Outstanding for fresh, delicate coloring and youthful silhouette are the Marcel Rochas frocks for garden parties or informal dancing on a summer evening. Short bouffant skirt over many layers of petticoat are fully gathered to a smooth hip yoke that matches a demure bodice with plain short sleeves and low square or V neckline.

Acting on court orders, the Pacific Coast Company has just declared a cash dividend of $2.2252 on each share of its first preferred stock. But the first preferred shareholders will get none of it. The money will go to pay court costs on their unsuccessful effort...
A bill was introduced yesterday in the City Council to fix new moderate rates to be charged by towing-car operators so as to safeguard the public "against fraud, exorbitant rates and similar abuses."

PINEHURST, N.C., April 24 (AP)--Paced by the steady par shooting of the defending champion, Miss Pat O'Sullivan, the favorites led the way through the first round of match play today in the forty-ninth women's North and South amateur golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Soviet Union had a highly efficient organization operating clandestinely in this country as early as 1921, twelve years before the United States had established diplomatic relations with that country, a witness testified today in the second hearing before the new Subversive Activities Control Board.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)-- Representative Walter E. Brehm, Republican of Ohio, swore today that he had never received any money from Mrs. Clara Soliday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24-- Demands for a "substantial" wage increase and a forty-hour week were presented to the Pacific Maritime Association today by a negotiating committee for the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, C.I.O.
John P. Crane will resign as president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association on May 5, he said yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP)-- Board chairman Ben Moreell of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation today called for clear thinking in the industrial phase of the defense program to "avoid considerable economic waste."

The RCA Victor division of the Radio Corporation halted all production of television receivers and some radio output yesterday. The shutdown, which involves a layoff of 5,837 employes, will be for a full week with resumption of operations scheduled for May 1, the company said.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP)-- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today that the new price-control system for 75,000 manufacturers may hamper business efforts to expand output, continue research and development and meet higher transportation costs.

WASHINGTON, April 24--Business continued its upward movewent in March and April and business men expect 1951 sales to rise 10 per cent above the high dollar total of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
The State of New Hampshire sold yesterday bonds totaling $12,600,000 and maturing from May 1, 1952, to May 1, 1976, to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
Aneurin Bevan's address to Parliament, setting forth his reasons for resigning from the Cabinet, was delivered with its author's customary eloquence and persuasiveness.

BILBAO, Spain, April 24 (AP)-- A quarter million workers in Spain's northern industrial belt maintained their protest strike against the high cost of living today, and their unity may make Government punishment impossible.
Two Venezuelan naval vessels, one carrying 360 ground, sea and air cadets, sailed for home yesterday after a 10-day, good-will visit here.

MOSCOW, April 24--The Soviet Union has decided to enter the International Olympic Games in 1952. This marks the first occasion in which Soviet athletes will be placed in general competition with top-ranking athletes of all countries of the world under Olympic auspices.

LONDON, April 24--Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, told the English Speaking Union here today that he believed there was a good, "one might even say excellent," chance of avoiding World War III.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 25-- United Nations troops blunted the Communist attack across the Thirty-eighth Parallel yesterday, stopping the Chinese breakthrough in the center, seven miles below the old Korean boundary and four miles north of the key city of Kapyong on the vital lateral road from Seoul to Chunchon.

TOKYO, April 24--Results are now available of the first of a series of local elections that Japan is carrying out and though the candidates are largely independent and the issues generally local, Japanese commentators tonight feel that a grass roots vote of confidence has been given to the conservative government and to the policy of a quick peace treaty and a security agreement with the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 24--Administration Democrats in the Senate opened today their counter-attack in force in an attempt to wrest the initiative from the Republicans in the national debate over Far East policy.

LONDON, April 24--Tension in the Labor party eased today as it appeared that the storm started by the revolt of Aneurin Bevan, former Labor Minister, against the Labor Government's arms program had just about spent itself with one more explanatory speech and another letter of resignation.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 24 --Edward O. Diggs, 30 years old, of Winston-Salem, N.C., today became the first Negro to be accepted for admission to the university of North Carolina.
WASHINGTON, April 24--Price controls affecting $70,000,000,000 worth of products turned out annually by 75,000 American manufacturers were clamped down today by the Office of Price Stabilization.
CHICAGO, April 24--Unknown inventors are to be given big business backing to help them develop any processes that would benefit the petroleum industry, it was announced here today.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 24--More than 125 Protestant church leaders were urged here today to "resell" the American public on the humanitarian objectives of the Point Four program of Government assistance to underdeveloped areas.

Nothirdchance scored a smashing victory in the mile-and-a-sixteenth Idlewild Purse which was the main attraction on the racing program at Jamaica yesterday. Saddled by Hirsch Jacobs and ridden by Benny Green, the 3-yearold daughter of Blue Swords defeated

The market for United States Government obligations yesterday showed its greatest assurance since the February accord between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve System brought on the recent stiffening of basic interest rates.

Manager Casey Stengel, hospitalized just before game time yesterday with a painful abdominal seizure later diagnosed as having been caused by "a kidney stone," had the added misfortune of missing another highly edifying performance by Ed Lopat.
The National Urban League, in its annual report made public yesterday, declared that in the field of race relations 1950 was a "good year." It was good, according to the report, insofar as there...
ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP)--Stan Musial broke out of his batting slump as the Cardinals turned back the Reds, 3--1, today behind the effective pitching of Southpaw Max Lanier.
Sixteen investment banking syndicates competed yesterday for the award of three issues of public utility securities amounting to $23,500,000. The awards were as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Establishment of a three-man appeals board to which manufacturers can carry complaints about failure to obtain adjustments in their allocations of critical materails was announced today by Manly Fleischmann, head of the National Production Authority.

Counsel for former Police Inspector Frederick A. Hofsaes was advised yesterday by the Kings County District Attorney's office to produce his client before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury this morning for questioning.
WASHINGTON, April 24--The Administration's omnibus pricewage-rent control bill will reach Congress Thursday with a request for quick handling but with a rather dubious prospect of getting it.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 24-- Mrs. R.M. Torgerson, New York State and metropolitan champion, displayed a steady brand of play today in capturing the top gross award with an 80 in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A one-day tournament over the wind--swept Meadow Brook Club course.

Weather permitting, all airline arrivals and departures are from La Guardia Airport unless otherwise noted. The cities below in capital letters are terminal points. With rare exceptions all inbound and outbound planes carry mail.

A new low-cost television sending station designed to operate in small cities or towns of 30,000 population is being developed by the General Electric Company, it was learned here yesterday. The apparatus will cost about $75,000, will be ready for sale about the...
TOM DALEY, an engine room oiler on the destroyer Thompson, had blown his top and tried to strangle the old man himself.

If the United States Government loses in current litigation over stock in the American President Lines, Federal shipping authorities will give full cooperation to the interests now suing for control of the company, Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Administration began today to present its current policy on food prices, with Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, opposing any move to freeze such prices below parity or to kill the farm parity provision in the Defense Production Act.

The six-story apartment house for thirty families at 1337 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Seymour M. Tannenbaum, operator, from Phoebe Berley and Blanche Thayer. It is assessed at $39,000.

Plan Christmas Gift Promotion Bart Hydorn, advertising direc tor of Fortune magazine, estimated yesterday that fifty-eight leading department stores and 5,000 members of the American National Retail Jewelers Association would cooperate in a campaign to promote Christmas gifts by large corporations ...

United Nations forces checked Chinese Communists who had crossed into South Korea in gaining up to twenty miles in the center. The enemy pressed forward despite heavy losses in what Lieut. Gen. Ridgway said might be the decisive battle of the war. [1:8; map P. 2.]
John Blair of the New York Zoological Park, the Bronx, has announced the engagement of his ward, Penelope, to Cecil, also under the guardianship of Mr. Blair. A summer wedding has been planned.

MEXICO CITY, April 24--United States Ambassador William O'Dwyer said today it was for President Truman to decide "and not my conscience" whether he was doing his country a service by continuing to occupy his post here.
John Henry was a sort of Mississipian Paul Bunyan. He weighed 44 pounds when he was born, was more than six feet tall and spoke with a bass voice.

VINHBAO, Tongking, Indo-China, April 24--Fighting appears to be about over in the French-Vietnamese clean-up campaign against insurgent guerrillas in this coastal Red River delta area twenty-five miles southwest of Haiphong.

Distributors of industrial durable goods lines here, including such items as heavy machinery, engines, compressors, tools, pumps and steel pipe, are taking first steps to get the armed services to place small orders, with local distributors, instead of with manufacturers.

WHITE PLAINS, April 24--An enthusiastic group of sixty-two Westchester Class A players turned out for the first one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the Fenway Club course today.
CLEVELAND, April 24--(AP)-- Bob Feller tamed the surprising White Sox today with a 5-2 victory that kept the Inidans in undisputed first place.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24--The formation of a fourteen-country committee to take over military direction of the war in Korea was proposed today by the American Association for the United Nations.

Transmission of news from the fronts of Korea is now handled with such speed that The United Press can distribute a war dispatch throughout the United States while a correspondent is still dictating from the war zone, Earl J. Johnston, vice president of the news gathering agency and general news manager, said yesterday.

A new compromise salary plan, aimed at ending the year-long stoppage of extracurricular activities in the public schools, was rejected yesterday by the High School Teachers Association, which plans to continue its fight for higher wages.
Is it anticipation or defiance of fate that gives a special fillip these days to the work of the archaeologists?

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Senate Rules Committee is expected to decide tomorrow whether investigation will be continued into the circumstances under which Joe R. Hanley withdrew as a Republican candidate for Governor in New York to run for the Senate.

City College's baseball team yesterday handed previously unbeaten Long Island University its first setback in seven games, defeating the Blackbirds, 5--4, at Prospect Park's Parade Grounds in Brooklyn.
Robert McLean, president of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, was re-elected yesterday as president of The Associated Press. He has been president since 1938.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Jersey Central Power and Light Company, of Asbury, N.J., today filed an amended financing proposal with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The proposal calls for the issuance and sale at this time of preferred and common stock and for deferring action on the sale of bonds.
The fashion for suits has been so universally adopted by American women that even the summerfabric suit has become an essential part of the fashion picture.
Enrollment of Girl Scouts in New York hit a peak of 41,333, the annual report of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York disclosed yesterday.

POINTE-A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, French West Indies, April 19--The war in Korea and the recent interAmerican conference in Washington seem remote from this humid island, which since 1946 has been a Department of Metropolitan France.

The world's largest operating utility, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported a consolidated net income yesterday of $40,018,646 for the twelve months to March 31. This was after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges and was...

Unsettled conditions now prevailing in the housing mortgage market may lead to the resumption of loan purchases by the Federal National Mortgage Association, according to forecasts made by experts in the business at the seventh annual Long Island...

"A definite person, this Dawes," a magazine writer once said of him. The former Vice President, whose life span looked back to the final year of the Civil War, was a vigorous, picturesque personality who brought intense energy to every post in the public service to which he was called.

A plea of not guilty was made yesterday in General Sessions by Jack Goldsmith, 31-year-old former Long Island University basketball star, to an indictment charging that he and William Rivlin, a fugitive, had bribed participants of a college basketball contest.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 24--The Municipal Council of Bamberg, a town fourteen miles from the Soviet zonal border, reluctantly and belatedly voted tonight to give United States authorities engineering plans so that demolition chambers could be prepared in local bridges over the strategically important Main River.
THE early run of pollock should be arriving off Montauk Point any day now to provide some really interesting fishing for the light-tackle brigade now marking time by taking codfish by the bushel.
Borden's has a plant at 35-18 Steinway Street, Long Island City, Queens, that has been so effectively enlarged and remodeled that its output has doubled in one year.
The 301st Radio Broadcasting and Leaflet Group, a psychological warfare reserve unit of radiomen mostly from the New York area, will enter active service next Tuesday.
Despite heavier tax charges, substantially larger earnings over the 1950 period were reported yesterday by six petroleum companies in their statements covering the initial three months of this year.
A formidable representation of United States amateur golfers will participate in foreign championships this year according to the list of entries announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Senate approved late today a continuance of its investigation into interstate crime beyond the present April 30 deadline to Sept. 1. At the same time it made immediately available an additional $100,000 so that the inquiry might proceed without interruption.

MANILA, April 24--President Elpidio Quirino and Foreign Secretary Carlos P. Romulo found a meeting of minds over whatever differences caused the publicly obvious neglect of official courtesies on the latter's arrival yesterday. The meeting resulted in the issuance of a formal denial that Mr. Romulo had been "snubbed."
The National Association of Women Artists will open their 1951 annual exhibition with a preview reception this evening in the galleries of the National Academy.
George Santayana holds that the United States will be wasting the lives of its young men if it sends them to defend Europe, which he believes is "already a wreck."

Dense clouds of black smoke caused by burning bags of naphthalene and a large quantity of cork on Pier 32, at Degraw Street, Brooklyn, darkened the shore of Buttermilk Channel for more than an hour after 1:55 P.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)-- Public Health Service outlined today what it described as "a pattern for the development of coordinated health service area plans in the states" through cooperation of public health agencies and hospitals.

BOWIE, Md., April 24 (AP)--Walter A. Edgar's Jack the Great, a 3-1 shot, took the featured Fair Sex Purse today, winning by a half length over The Eagle. Senator Joe, a Kentucky Derby nominee, was held at even-money favoritism by the crowd of 8,054 but could do no better than third.

Despite the war's desolation, Koreans are deeply grateful for United Nations help in their struggle against the Communists, a Korean woman said yesterday. Dr. Helen Kim, president of Ewha Colloge, now evacuated for the second time to makeshift quarters in Pusan, said that "Korea chooses death rather than slavery."

WASHINGTON, April 24--Marc Lawrence, Hollywood actor and specialist in gunman roles, told the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that he had signed a Communist party card in 1938. Now, he said, he viewed his action and the associations that followed as a "hideous" mistake.
A heap of pillows, or a few, tossed on sofa, chair, bed or even the floor is becoming a favorite accessory to bring unity to a room's decorating scheme.

Since the first of the year unfilled orders of the American Brake Shoe Company have risen from 42,000,000 to $57,000,000, a high record, William B. Given Jr., chairman, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

Despite consumer resistance to current high prices of coffee, both the Pan-American growers and the domestic roasters and distributors agreed yesterday that there was scant prospect of relief until new trees come into production is the coffee countries within the next two years.

General, of the Army Douglas MacArthur contended yesterday, through his spokesman and military secretary, that his desire to throw Chiang Kai-shek's 600,000 Nationalist Chinese troops into the fight against the Chinese Communists had been shared by all senior officers and by the naval and air commanders in the Far East.

PARIS, April 24--The speech by Aneurin Bevan in the House of Commons yesterday challenging Britain's rearmament program raised in dramatic form an issue that might lead in Europe to a great debate like that in the United States over strategic policy, in the opinion of European and American officials here who have given most attention to the economics of rearmament.
While the attention of the Western World is focused primarily on domestic political controversies the Communist spring offensive in Korea continues to make headway.

GENEVA, April 24--Europe's coal imports from the United States passed the 1,000,000-ton mark in February.

CHICAGO, April 24--Wheat prices continued on the upgrade on the Board of Trade here today, going to a new high since midFebruary, and closed 3 to 3 5/8 cents a bushel higher, although the volume of trade was only moderate.

THERE is a certain quiet charm to the sprawling racing plant at Churchill Downs. It hasn't the tropical splendor of Hialeah, the majestic backdrop of Santa Anita, the spaciousness of Belmont or the quiet serenity of Delaware Park. It has the dignity and the tradition of old age.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The thunder of the "Great Debate" still resounded in Washington today, but as some of the emotion of last week dwindled, Congress commenced, though still with partisanship, to examine in closer detail some of the facts and issues.
Two articles in this newspaper yesterday sketched a revealing picture of what Sovietization has done to the economies of Eastern Europe.

Stock generally drifted downward and closed on the lower side due to a selling flurry late in the session yesterday. Measured by the composite rate, the market showed a loss of 1.05 points on the day.

John F. Gehan, executive vice president of the American Export Lines, was re-elected president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York yesterday at the group's annual meeting in the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

Over-the-counter securities dealers are studying the question of year-round Saturday closings. A questionnaire on the subject has been circulated by the District No. 13 Committee of the National Association of Securities Dealers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24-- When a ball club goes into a tailspin there invariably seems to be something new coming up each twenty-four hours to accelerate its downward flight and tonight it was the Giant outfield that helped send the Polo Grounders to their sixth successive defeat.

The Ballet Theatre opened the final week of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, with a program which included as its special feature the only performance of Antony Tudor's "Romeo and Juliet," with Alicia Alonso once more as Juliet and Igor Youskevitch as Romeo for the first time in New York.

News that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had signed a new agreement to buy Bolivian tin on the basis of Singapore tin prices lifted the New York tin market yesterday. Although the R.F.C. official price remained unchanged at $1.42 a pound, the fact that ...
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 25 (AP) --General Headquarters communique 864, covering the twenty-fourhour period up to 6 A.M. Wednesday (4 P.M., Eastern standard time, Tuesday):

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24--An irate Soviet delegate protested today to the members of a United Nations commission that he had received an anonymous note threatening that the United States would make war against the Soviet Union.

In its first change of ownership in sixty years the fivestory building at 56 Harrison Street, between Washington and West Streets, was sold for cash by the estate of Julia Wray to Dewey Carver, operator, in a deal negotiated by ...

"The Taming of the Shrew"-- the straight version without Cole Porter's music--will usher in at 8 o'clock tonight the six-week Festival of Comedy season, divided into three fortnightly bills, at the City Center. Reference to the Porter score is made since it embellishes "Kiss Me, Kate," a latterday variation of the Shakespearean capers.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., April 24--The Signal Corps wants to make certain that its new equipment, vastly improved in many ways, will be put to proper use in the field.

LONDON, April 24 (AP)--Don Cockell, British and European lightheavyweight champion, pounded out a one-sided decision victory over Freddie Beshore of Harrisburg, Pa., tonight in a nontitle ten-rounder before a capacity crowd of 10,400 in Harringay Arena. Beshore outweighed the Londoner, 185 to 181.
E. Joseph Bensler, sales administration manager of the Pepso dent division of Lever Brothers Company, has been appointed marketing service manager.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Wednesday, April 25 (UP)--One hundred and three persons, including three United States soldiers, were burned to death yesterday when a broken power line fell on the roof of an express train and turned two cars into flaming coffins.

CHICAGO, April 24 (UP)--Wally Westlake belted a home run and a single today to drive in four runs and pace Pittsburgh to a 6-4 victory over the Cubs. The two teams are now tied for second place in the league race.
A.H. Woods, one of the most successful theatrical producers of the Twenties, died yesterday in the Beacon Hotel, Broadway and Seventy-fifth Street, his residence in recent years. His age was 81.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 24-- Dressed from stem to stern with flags and pennants, the new tug Eugene F. Moran, latest addition to the fleet of modern harbor craft operated by the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, went down the ways today at the Jakobson Shipyard here.

A local law calling for mandatory retirement of members of the Police Department at the age of 63 years was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council. At present there is no age limit in the department.

One went to Town Hall last night with much anticipation to hear the performance of Mozart's least familiar opera of his later period, "Idomeneo," given in concert form by the Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman, conductor, with assisting vocal soloists and chorus.

Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, warned the American business community last night that the costs of the nation's military program and its shortages of critical materials would rise sharply in the near future.
A resolution "strongly urging" Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, to grant a top priority rating immediately for school constructiion was adopted yesterday by the City Council.

PARIS, April 24--Gen. Alphonse Georges, Chief of Staff of France in the 1940 campaign, who was severely wounded when, accompanying King Alexander of Yugoslavia on the day of the latter's assassination in Marseilles, died here today in Val de Grace Military Hospital. His age was 75. He had been suffering from a heart ailment for some time.
There were two Boston villains at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Dodgers' winning streak was snapped at five games, with the Braves coming from behind to win, 7--4, before 8,449 half-frozen fans.

Gerardo Anastasio, 39-year-old longshoremen's union delegate, was admitted to United States citizenship yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch after a hearing in the Brooklyn Federal Court. The application was approved thirty days after Anastasio's brother, Anthony, told the members of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee that five brothers, including Albert Anastasia, reputed underworld boss, had come into the country from Italy illegally by "jumping ship."
Increased censorship abroad and growing attacks on the freedom of the press at home were reported at yesterday's meetings of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 24--The Yugoslav Government's efforts to convince the United States and British Governments and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to finance the industrialization of Yugoslavia have provoked serious debate even among the staunchest Yugoslav advocates.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Apri1 24-- A red-bearded Scottish adventurer is preparing here to lead a dozen young Americans on a round-theworld sailing cruise on the route followed more than a century ago by the great naturalist, Charles Darwin, in H.M.S. Beagle.

Governor Dewey's State Crime Commission ran into a snag in its opening investigation yesterday when four witnesses subpoenaed in an inquiry into waterfront racketeering and gambling on Staten Island refused to sign waivers of immunity.

Record first quarter sales of $98,103,907, an increase of 43 per cent over the $68,474,328 volume for the initial three months last year, were reported by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman of the board of the Continental Can Company, at the annual stockholders meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 24--Formosa now ranks with Western Europe in terms of priority of shipment of arms and munitions, Robert A. Lovett, Deputy Secretary of Defense, said today.

A program of "personal action," through which those concerned with the welfare of children may help translate into action knowledge of what is good for the young, was presented last night by Dr. Leona Baumgartner, assistant commissioner, New York City Department of Health, and former associate chief of the United States Children's Bureau.
An exhibition of French book arts, literature and master drawings at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street, will open to the public today.

WASHINGTON, April 24--Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Director, approved today the temporary emergency railroad wage panel's recommendation that the wage increase of six cents an hour provided by a cost-of-living escalator clause be paid to 1,000,000 nonoperating railway employes.

President Truman yesterday extended his personal wishes for success to the American National Theatre and Academy, Congress chartered organization, for its endeavors in promoting the growth spread and betterment of the theatre.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 24-- A bill was introduced in the General Assembly today proposing that the state-owned airport in Groton, known as Trumbull Airport, be sold or leased to any corporation that intends to build a steel mill on the site.

PARIS, April 24 (AP)--Led by Budge Patty of Los Angeles, who earned a place in the semi-finals, American players scored a clean sweep of their matches today in the Paris international tennis tournament.

Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday assailed the industryearnings standard announced last week by Economic Stabilization Administrator Eric Johnston as the criterion for judging requests for price increases.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Twenty-nine American scientists were elected to membership in the National Academy of Sciences at the annual business meeting of the academy here today, bringing the membership to 481.

WASHINGTON, April 24--Reductions aggregating $9,450,000 in funds for three big Federal power projects were voted by the House of Representatives today in a renewal of the perennial public-versus-private power fight.
UDINE, Italy, April 24--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived here today by plane from Paris for a tour of inspection of Italian troops in this Alpine region bordering on Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Aril 24 (AP)--The Office of Price Stabilization issued today this "fact sheet" telling "the what and why" of its new General Manufacturers' Ceiling Price Regulation:

Albert Spalding, who closed his public career as a violinist last June at the Lewisohn Stadium, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner attended by nearly 300 persons given at the WaldorfAstoria by the Musicians Emergency Fund.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 24--The Soviet Union was told bluntly today that the United States would not return political refugees to the Soviet Union or its satellites where their lives and freedom were in jeopardy.

LONDON, April 24--The British Government, which has embarked on a three-year rearmament program at a cost of about 4,700,000,000 [approximately $12,000,000,000] has no intention of departing from it, a Treasury spokesman declared today.
The versatility of clay as an art medium is demonstrated in a collection of ceramics now on display at Finland House, 41 East Fiftieth Street.

Hugh A. Mulligan, a 1944 graduate of Cathedral College, Brooklyn, and now a journalism student at Boston University, received yesterday first prize in the tenth annual journalism essay contest sponsored by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Since most of the clients at the City Center were laughing heartily at "The Taming of the Shrew" last evening, the ensuing remarks in this column need not be particularly revered. Margaret Webster has opened the spring revels at the Center with one of Shakespeare's....

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan moved yesterday for the dis missal of indictments resulting from an alleged wiretapping plot two years ago against city officials. The true bills named John G. Broady, a private investigator, and four other men.
The mysterious disappearance of a weighty load of tin in ingot form from the pier of the HollandAmerica Line in Hoboken has been reported to port and Federal authorities.

PARIS, April 25--Four votes of confidence, asked by Premier Henri Queuille, were taken in the National Assembly late tonight; the official results will be announced tomorrow. An unofficial count on the first ballot indicated a favorable vote of about 320 to 200 for the Government coalition.

The largest sales and earnings for any first quarter in the history of American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation were recorded in the first three months this year, Theodore E. Mueller, president, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting held here.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 26-- Chinese Communists poured reinforcements into the western sector of the Korean front yesterday as United Nations troops fell back under the decreased immediate pressure to meet the new attack from planned positions south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

WASHINGTON, April 25--Whatever the State Department may have to say in its announcement on May 12 of the results of the Torquay tariff negotiations, the inability of the United States and Britain to reach agreement has stamped the meeting a failure in the view of economic policy officials here.

Increasing dissatisfaction of foreign traders over delays by the Office of Price Stabilization in issuing "tailored" controls for exports and imports was expressed yesterday in a strongly-worded appeal to Michael V. DiSalle, Director of Price Stabilization.

MOBILE, Ala., April 25 (AP)-- The captain of the ill-fated Esso Suez acknowledged at a Coast Guard inquiry today he was traveling too fast through the fog just before it collided with another tanker and killed perhaps thirtynine men.

HONG KONG, April 25--The bloody purge of "counter-revolutionaries" in Communist China, where thousands already have been liquidated by firing squads, produced spine-tingling tremors here today as Chinese radio listeners heard twenty-three persons sentenced to death before a howling mob in near-by Canton.

Motor vehicles operated by or for 353 American and Canadian newspapers, covering a total of 104,230,993 miles last year, established a new safety record with only 2,138 accidents, the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association was informed yesterday.

TORONTO, April 25 (AP)--Negotiations between paper-making unions and Canadian newsprint companies broke off tonight with neither side able to bridge a gap on wages and hours. The unions indicated that the dispute would be submitted to conciliation.

Ted Atkinson, the list-topping jockey at Jamaica, made his thirtieth score of the meeting when the 4-year-old filly Growing Up, owned by Major Albert Warner's Warbern Stable, carried him to a late-charging victory in the $17,975 Correction Handicap yesterday.
The homemaker of a century ago was as concerned with the problem of space as her twentieth century descendant, judging from furniture on display in Altman's Country Shop.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 26 (AP) --General Headquarters communique 865, covering the twenty-four hours to 6 A.M., Thursday:

WASHINGTON, April 25--A new defense production bill, described by Administration officials as "tough," will be presented to Congress tomorrow. The measure, to replace the law that expires on June 30, will be sent to Congress with a message from President Truman and will be introduced in both the Senate and House.

PARIS, April 25--The politica uncertainties following the split in the British Cabinet's ranks, the renewal of the Asia-versus-Europe priority debate in the United States, and the development of a "wait until the elections" psychology in some European countries are beginning to worry certain leaders of the Western democratic coalition.

A material expression of ideas presented this spring in book form may be seen in a group of furniture introduced here yesterday. The collection was designed by Russel Wright, who collaborated with his wife, Mary, on a "Guide to...
DETROIT, April 25--Negotiations to end the transit strike that has kept buses and streetcars off Detroit streets since Saturday were broken off today. No date was set for a resumption.

IT was indeed welcome news to the free world that the Soviet Union had finally decided to enter the 1952 Olympic Games at Helsinki. Who can tell? It might even teach the Red brothers a few elementary principles of sportsmanship.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 25 (UP)--The late Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan, believed "we cannot wait much longer to move into action" to strengthen "collective security" measures in the interest of peace.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 25--The United States has notified countries with military forces fighting for the United Nations in Korea that enemy air bases in Manchuria will be attacked if the Chinese Communists throw heavy air power against the troops of the international army.

WASHINGTON, April 25--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 18, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

LONDON, April 25--Speaking for the British Government today Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison rejected the suggestion of Aneurin Bevan, former Labor Minister who left the Cabinet on Sunday, that the welfare state should have priority over British rearmament.

Whether former Police Inspector Frederick A. Hofsaes received a television set from Harry Gross, bigtime bookmaker, remained a secret to the public yesterday, but at least the rackets grand jury in Brooklyn finally got the answer.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Edward Dmytryk, who rose in Hollywood from a $6-a-week messenger to a $2,500-a-week motionpicture director, told the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that he was a member of the Communist party in 1944 and 1945.
Frank Shea, Yankee righthander, yesterday blanked the Athletics, 4--0, with four-hit hurling that was reminiscent of the freshman who came up in 1947 and scored fourteen victories.
City budget directors should have no jurisdiction over the Departments of Health or Hospitals, Leonard Mayo, director of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, asserted yesterday.

TORONTO, April 25. (UP)--Development of the Canadian nickel industry has provided the free world with an overwhelming nickel superiority over the Iron Curtain countries, John F. Thompson, chairman, told shareholders of the International Nickel Company of Canada at their annual meeting today.
The McKettrick collection of women's wear shown twice yesterday at McCreery's had a tip price of $20.
PARIS, April 25--As usual, Schiaparelli presents a stimulating collection and this time it is so largely because of her choice of delicate summer fabrics and the way she uses them.

A 22-year-old man, arrested after he had refused to report for induction into the armed forces, asked permission in Federal Court yesterday to change his mind. But Judge Sidney Sugarman decided that the prisoner had not really changed his mind and ordered him to trial on a charge of violating the Selective Service Act.

WASHINGTON, April 25--An opportunity for the House to vote on grain aid for famine-threatened India was assured today as leadership pressure on Southern Democrats broke up a coalition with Republicans that had kept the program locked in the Rules Committee for seven weeks.

"Gramercy Ghost," a comedy by John Cecil Holm, opens at 8:15 this evening in the Morosco Theatre. Sarah Churchill, daughter of the former British Prime Minister, and Robert Sterling are co-starred in the production. Both players will be making their Broadway acting bows.

WASHINGTON, April 25--Economic Stabilization Administrator Eric Johnston, in approving a 6cent-an-hour increase for 1,000,000 nonoperating railroad employes, accepted formally today the recommendations of a special panel that the increase be granted despite the fact that it pierced the 10 per cent ceiling on wage increases.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 25-- The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Cousins Morell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Morell of Apple Tree Hollow, to Donald Duhwody,...

A New York furniture dealer, Alfred J. Finkenberg was a graduate of Franklin and Marshall College. Mr. Finkenberg was on a business and pleasure trip. He was on his way home at the time of the crash. He lived at 50 West Ninety-sixth Street.

Chico Vejar, unbeaten 19-yearold school boy from Stamford, Conn., captured his twenty-eighth ring triumph last night by defeating Billy Murphy, veteran Brooklyn welterweight, in the eightround feature at the St. Nicholas Arena.

Russia's decision to enter the 1952 Olympic Games is a welcome one, as would be any decision of the Soviet regime to cooperate with other nations of the world on a basis of decency, tolerance and good faith.

WASHINGTON, April 25--The Algonquin Gas Transmission Company of Boston today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to sell $24,000,000 of its first mortgage pipeline bonds to a group of insurance companies for investment. The application also asked that a provision be included which would permit the company, at its option, to increase the amount sold by 15 per cent.

The entire new fleet of 100 streamlined, air-conditioned commuters' cars has been delivered and one-third of the week-day electric zone passengers and 50 per cent of all Saturday suburban passengers will ride in them this summer, the New York Central Railroad announced yesterday. The divisions of the road affected are the Hudson and Harlem.
WASHINGTON, April 25--Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin will be a "dead duck" if he attacks the United States in 1953, Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, said today.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 25--Disease, poverty and hunger in the world's underdeveloped areas no longer can be met on a "spot emergency" basis, Nelson A. Rockefeller, chairman of the International Development Advisory Board, said today.

The view that a balanced Federal budget is an adequate assurance against inflation, regardless of where the revenue comes from, is among the "persistent fallacies" regarding national defense financing, according to the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 25--A Cuban airliner and a United States Navy plane rammed into each other over Key West today with a noise like a bomb explosion, then plunged into the sea, carrying forty-three people to sudden death.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., April 25 (AP)--The University of Florida announced today the discovery of a new source of the childbirth medicine ergot in a Florida mushroom.

WASHINGTON, April 25--The city fathers of Bamberg, a Bavarian town close to the Soviet zone, required an "or else" demand from John J. McCloy, High Commissioner of the United States in Germany, before they would give our engineers the plans which will make possible prompt demolition of a Main River bridge if this becomes necessary to check a Russian invasion.
Herbert Hoover dedicated last night the new Lighthouse, training and recreation center for the blind at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, which has just been enlarged and reconstructed.

UDINE, Italy, April 25--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower; in his capacity as Commander-in-Chief of the North Atlantic forces, today saw crack Italian Alpine troops in action and in a brief address praised them for their "magnificent exhibition."
WASHINGTON, April 25--Regardless of who is right or wrong about the strategy of the war in the Far East, the MacArthur incident has had some positive effects.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 25 (AP) --Miss Charlotte DeCozen of Parsippany, N.J., upset the parade of winning favorites today by eliminating Curtis Cup star Dorothy Kielty, 1 up, in the North-andSouth amateur golf tournament's second round.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)-- A widely known New Yorker who has been viewed with alarm by the House Committee on Un-American Activities has received a public stamp of approval from General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and the State Department.

WASHINGTON, April 25--Acting less than three weeks after the request was put before it, the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives approved today a $6,468,206,000 emergency appropriation to cover the nation's arms build-up during the next few months.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, April 25 (UP)--Most of 300,000 cost-ofliving strikers returned to their jobs in the factories and shops of northeastern Spain today as a forty-eight-hour walkout ended.

The 3 per cent city tax on retail sales, which becomes effective next Tuesday, will be collected in accordance with the following schedule made public yesterday by Special Deputy Controller Morris W. Weiner: ...

Irwin Maier, publisher of The Milwaukee Journal and chairman of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told yesterday's meeting of the association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that 1950 marked a new peak in annual expenditures for daily newspaper advertising.
WASHINGTON, April 25--What happens when home rents are uncontrolled was reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor, today after a survey of nine areas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 --"Slaughter Trail," a Western film produced independently by Irving Allen, will be released without screen credit for Howard Da Silva, who played a leading role in the picture, it was learned today from the producer.

Judging from the realities of the situation, earlier comments of city officials, and the known reluctance to impose any further new taxes, we expect that the budget to be approved by the Board of Estimate today will fall considerably short of doing some of the things we should like to see done. We have in mind particularly a...
WASHINGTON, April 25-- General of the Army George C. Marshall, Secretary of Defense, became today the owner of an ornately carved Sicilian donkey cart painted in brilliant colors.

MEXICO CITY, April 25--State and municipal authorities in three northern cities of Mexico have appealed to their Federal Government here to help them cope with the problem of caring for 30,000 migrant farm laborers who want to work in the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP)-- President Truman signed legislation today providing $10,000 free life insurance coverage to all members of the United States armed forces.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)-- Super-speed jet planes from the Air Force, Navy and Marine Corps will have the field to themselves this year for the first time in three of the Nation Air Races four outstanding events.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) achieved a new high record in the first quarter, with estimated consolidated net earnings of $118,000,000 after taxes and all charges, according to the report announced yesterday.

ALTHOUGH the trout fishermen have finished their period of anxious waiting, the salmon anglers face at least a month of impatient chafing before they can pack their duffel and wait for the word on bright fish moving up the rivers of Canada.

A willingness on the part of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur to have television cameras trained on him when he appears at the Senate inquiry in Washington next Thursday was expressed yesterday by Maj. Gen. Courtney Whitney, spokesman for the fivestar general.

PARIS, April 25--Hurling insults at Western statesmen in a fashion that the British representative said "broke the bounds of decency," Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet deputy, warned the Western foreign ministers' deputies today that the "interventionists" in Korea faced almost limitless casualties unless the fighting ended.

WASHINGTON, April 25--The United States must persevere in its present foreign policies to maintain its security and prevent another world war, W. Averell Harriman, special assistant to the President, told a council meeting of the League of Women Voters tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 25--The first total synthesis, out of cheap and abundant raw materials, of a chemical that will make possible the production of the wonder drug cortisone in unlimited amounts, has been accomplished at Harvard University by a team of chemists headed by Prof. Robert Burns Woodward.

PARIS, April 25--Encouraged by the signing of the Schuman coal-steel plan by six countries last week, the French Government is pressing forward with detailed blueprints for the creation of a unified agricultural market to include at the outset the Continent's wheat and dairy products, sugar and wine.

Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy announced yesterday that he had written to the International Association of Police Chiefs informing them of New York City's revised system of reporting crime statistics and seeking their, approval.

VINHBAO, Tongking, IndoChina, April 25--This rich, thickly populated farm province south of Haiphong will be the testing ground during the next few months of whether full FrenchVietnamese pacification and control of the Tongking delta rice bowl is possible.

The Department of Sanitation's annual two-week spring clean-up drive will get under way on Monday. New Yorkers will be urged to refrain from littering streets, to dispose of household refuse in a sanitary manner and to clean up attics, cellars, yards and lots where debris has accumulated.

John Kuharetz, slim righthander, yesterday hurled New York University to a 7-5 triumph over Manhattan College in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Van Cortlandt Park. Kuharetz gave six hits and issued only two walks in registering his second victory against a pair of losses.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)-- The right of a city to compel its employes to take loyalty oaths was argued today in the Supreme Court.

Many parties were given yesterday at the luncheon and fashion show far the benefit of the Bargain Box, a permanent thrift shop, in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astorla. Mrs. Lewis F. Fris sell is president of the beneficiary.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, April 25--Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet asserted tonight that the United Nations troops had proved their superiority over the Communists in "a third round of the unprovoked, ruthless aggression."

WASHINGTON, April 25--The Army will reduce its monthly draft call to 20,000 for June and start a 20,000-per-month rotation program from Korea in May, according to testimony released today by the House Appropriations Committee.
TRENTON, April 25--Measures to stiffen penalties for traffic in narcotics were approved without a dissenting vote today by the New Jersey Assembly.

WASHINGTON, April 25--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur has made no move to have his status changed from active duty, an Army spokesman said today. However, Maj. Gen. Courtney Whitney, chief spokesman for the deposed general, applied for retirement two weeks ago.

Maj. Gen. Courtney Whitney, who has emerged as "official spokesman" for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, is regarded by those familiar with the workings of the MacArthur Tokyo headquarters as perhaps the closest and most influential friend the former Pacific commander has ever had.

WASHINGTON, April 25--Senate Republican leaders insisted today that the investigation of President Truman's dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur be held in open sessions. They also demanded that the inquiry be widened to include all Far Eastern policy since the Yalta Conference in 1945.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)-- United States oil companies operating in the Eastern Hemisphere voiced alarm today lest the Iranian crisis bring about a world-wide shortage of petroleum.

The proposed abolition of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was denounced last night by speakers at a meeting of several hundred small business men in the Astor Hotel. The meeting was held under the sponsorship of the Manufacturers Emergency Committee.
GENEVA, April 25--The United States State Department is facing a difficult decision over how far to press the British Government at this time on some basic issues of international economic policy.
EVANSTON, Ill., April 25--Two funeral services were held here today for Gen. Charles G. Dawes, former Vice President of the United States, banker, civic leader and diplomat.

CHICAGO, April 25--Production and sales of the Inland Steel Company set new quarterly records in the three months ended on March 31, Edward L. Ryerson, chairman, and Clarence B. Randall, president, told stockholders today at their annual meeting.
Baseball's controversial reserve clause is under attack again.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 25--Israel today apologized for her-- recent bombing of a Syrian-occupied frontier village but disputed the civil authority of United Nations truce supervisors in the area. Abba S. Eban of Israel likewise presented to the United Nations Security Council his country's charges against Syria.

PATERSON, N.J., April 25-- Litigation that would have deprived a former Lyndhurst volunteer fireman of his home because he killed a man in an accident four years ago while driving a fire truck, was resolved today in favor of the fireman.

WASHINGTON, April 25--Experiments at the University of Rochester, said to provide a "significant new clue" to the nature of the cosmic forces within the nuclei of the atoms, one of the major mysteries of the universe,...

Clyde King was just one pitch away from victory against the Braves at Ebbets Field last night. But he could not get that pitch past Sam Jethroe. The Boston centerfielder walloped it over the right field screen for a two-run homer that gave his team a 6-5...
The Gay Thirties, an annual subscription dinner dance, was held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.

Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, earned a total of $626,300 in salary, director's fees and bonus last year from the nation's largest automotive company. This was $40,200 more than his compensation in 1949.
