Despite the resignation of three Government Ministers over the issue, Foreign Secretary Morrison announces, in line with a similar declaration by the Treasury, that Britain will stand by its planned rearmament program, calling for the expenditure of $12,000,000,000 over the next three years.
When does the taxpayer's turn come to stage a demonstration in Washington and threaten a "walkout" on the defense effort?
FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, French West Indies, April 23-- This lush island, where the Empress Josephine was born, is ridden with unrest.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 25 (AP) --Two long shots, Recover and Crownlet, won the two divisions of the Lafayette Stakes at Keeneland today.

WASHINGTON, April 25--The Senate (Fulbright) subcommittee investigating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation formally requested Donald S. Dawson, a Presidential administrative assistant, today to appear before it on May 10 to testify concerning alleged political influence and favoritism in lending operations of that agency.
MIAMI, April 25 (UP)--Following are the names of the thirtynine persons aboard the Compania de Aviacion plane, as identified today by Pan American World Airways:

The stock market found it difficult to maintain its balance yesterday, although a downward trend was checked under the leadership of the oils, rails and aircrafts. Again, indicative of the inability of traders to decide on a definite course was the fact that the market closed almost in perfect bal-...

RUSSIAN Purge and the Extraction of Confession," an important new book by F. Beck and W. Godin, is a useful volume to have around when you are reading the news these days from--and about--Imperial Muscovy.

The budget-wise housewife had better dig in the recipe drawer for dishes based on beef substitutes. And her lord and master had better learn to appreciate the ingenuity of his wife's cookery. For the outlook for beef-eaters in the next few weeks is positively dim.

Six years ago yesterday, on April 25, 1945, two events occurred which most of us believed at the time would change the history of the world. On the day of the opening of the San Francisco conference that produced the Charter of the United Nations the vanguards of the American and Soviet Armies met on the banks of the Elbe River.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 25--West Germanys protection in the event of war will depend largely on the Federal Republic's participation in its own defense, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, declared tonight.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 25 --Dr. Nicholas S. Ransohoff, orthopedic surgeon, who perfected treatment of infantile paralysis with curare plus intensive physical therapy, died today in his home here after a long illness. His age was 55.
FRANKFORT, Germany, April 25 (AP)--William N. Oatis, chief of The Associated Press bureau in Czechoslovakia, disappeared Monday and the United States Embassy in Prague fears he is under arrest.

The nine-story apartment house for forty families at 40 West Fifty-fifth Street, formerly a cooperative, has been sold by the Brolau Realty Company to an investor who was obtained through R. Leonard Lanning and Nathan Wilson, operator.

The Teachers Union, United Public Workers, called upon Mayor Impellitteri yesterday to appoint Arthur S. Meyer, former chairman of the State Board of Mediation, as mediator in the current teachers' salary controversy, which has caused a teachers' boycott against extracurricular activities in the public schools.

NEWARK, April 25--The Board of Public Utility Commissioners formally accepted today the recent offer of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company to reduce electric rates $5,010,200 annually. The new rates will become effective with bills rendered on or after June 1.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25--For a change, the Giants today did nothing to lose a ball game. But, on the other hand, they also did nothing, or very little, to win one, and so it came to pass that Leo Durocher's floundering Polo Grounders tumbled down to their...

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 25--The United Nations today withdrew the press credentials of Stanley Clifford Weyman after his identification as Stephen Weinberg, one-time masquerader who managed to pass himself off for years as a friend of diplomatic personages.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)-- With a sort of special dispensation from Vice President Alben W. Barkley, newspaper correspondents applauded from the Senate Press Gallery today as Blair Moody, one of their colleagues, became Senator Moody, Democrat of Michigan.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25-- Forty-five hundred dock workers in this port left their jobs today to attend a four-hour meeting in the Civic Auditorium and discuss actions taken at the recent Honolulu convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated.

WASHINGTON, April 25--Secretary of State Dean Acheson revealed today a ten-week-old commitment by the United States to give the Chinese Nationalist Government military aid for "the legitimate self-defense" of Formosa.

United Palestine Appeal agencies spent $431,450,000 in the last three years for immigration, resettlement and upbuilding of Israel, Rudolf G. Sonneborn, national chairman of the appeal, declared last night.

The North American Company, once one of the nation's largest public utility holding companies but which has been in the process of gradual liquidation for the past ten years, has decided to continue in business.

LISBON, Portugal, April 25-- Portugal's National Assembly decided last night to ignore constitutional procedure and delay the naming of a successor to President Oscar de Fragosa Carmona who died a week ago.

Robert M. Fowler, president of the Newsprint Association of Canada, warned the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday that if United States price ceilings were imposed on newsprint, Canadian mills might divert some newsprint to other countries.
HARTFORD, Conn., April-25-- Connecticut has no authority to regulate the location of natural gas pipelines in this state, Gov. John Davis Lodge and leaders of the General Assembly said today.
A preponderance of larger home freezers with a capacity of thirteen cubic feet or more is one of the current trends in equipment for food preservation.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Harry Pollitt, a former Communist member of the British Parliament, came to the United States in 1929 as one of two personal delegates of Joseph Stalin to "force through" the latter's demands on a Communist convention in Chi-- cago, it was testified today at a hearing before the Subversive Activities Control Board.
MINELOA, L.I., April 25--A small, well-trained army, equipped with a formidable array of chemical and mechanical warfare weapons, has started its thirty-fifth annual all-out offen-...

Soviet Russia's decision to participate in the 1952 Olympics indicates that the Kremlin is satisfied that its two-and-a-half year effort to develop athletes of world championship caliber has progressed far enough to give the U.S.S.R. an excellent chance of winning at Helsinki next year.

The item of principal interest on last night's program by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was the presentation of Carmelita Maracci's new "Circo de Espana" for the first time without her in the cast. Because she is an artist of such unique qualities and...
A birthday cake was shared yesterday by patients, parents and staff at the first anniversary of the clinic for retarded children at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, 106th Street and Fifth Avenue.

Publication of a letter from Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan to the Senate Agriculture Committee hardened sugar prices yesterday. The Secretary said that he had opposed lowering American import quotas because forthcoming heavy purchases by military...
Claire McCardell's summer collection, shown to luncheon guests in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday, bore the distinctive look and silhouette which made her famous.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)-- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, urged today that steps be taken at once toward amending the Charter of the United Nations, which he said had "broken down as a means of preventing war."
New issues of bonds and notes totaling $28,338,900, representing borrowings of two public utility enterprises and a steel company, will be offered to investors today, at follows:

As the result of a series of crimes ranging from minor vandalism to a criminal attack on a young girl, extra police have been assigned to patrol the isolated part of the Canarsie section of Brooklyn in which the Glenwood Houses project is located.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 26--The West German Government moved decisively today to check the latest Communist political offensive by banning all committee meetings supporting a plebiscite May 15 "against remilitarization" and for a peace treaty.

After a three-hour closed meeting yesterday, the Board of Education moved toward a complete reorganization of the public school system's administrative procedures by creating six top jobs involving an added expenditure of $100,000 a year.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 26 (UP)-- The Government filed an anti-trust suit against Investors Diversifie Services, Inc., of Minneapolis in Federal Court today, charging the firm forced customers to buy insurance from them when making mortgage loans.
PHILADELPHIA, April 26--The Phils made only three hits and committed one error, while the Dodgers whacked out eight hits and made no errors tonight, but the Phils won, 2-0, behind Robin Roberts.

Pan American World Airways petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to investigate the extent of the control of the Grace steamship interests over National Airlines. It was pointed out that steamship control over airlines is contrary to national policy.

The Big Brother Movement of Greater New York reported yesterday that in 1950 its rehabilitation work among juvenile delinquents had helped 2,081 "unwanted, unpiloted" boys "get back on the road" to leading useful lives.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP)-- Post Office officials said today they have "proved" departmental jobs were "sold" by pro-Administration forces in Mississippi and disclosed that forty-eight employes had been dismissed or charged as a result of their investigation.

WASHINGTON, April 26--Dr. George W. Taylor of Philadelphia was sworn in today as chairman of a reconstituted eighteen-member Wage Stabilization Board and said he hoped the board could start work in less than a week on some major policy problems and the backlog of 800 individual cases.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Profits of manufacturing corporations touched the highest point in history during 1950, the Securities and Exchange Commission and Federal Trade Commission announced today. The two agencies reported upon a joint survey of the quarterly earnings of companies in the last year.

Proposing one of the most effective color duets yet viewed, Rus seks based a complete presentation of summer fashions on shadowy black and the palest tone of sand, used separately and in combination. Yesterday's showing at the Plaza Hotel provided delightful glimpses of all manner of summer togs from swim suits to evening frocks, including several Paris adaptations.

WASHINGTON, April 26--President Truman's selection of W. Stuart Symington to be the new administrator of the reorganized Reconstruction Finance Corporation was approved today by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency. The decision of the Senate was expected to be made next week.

The Otis Co, defense against a $4,000,000 damage suit brought against the Cleveland investment banking concern by the KaiserFrazer Corporation ran into a snag yesterday when Federal Judge John W. Clancy ruled against further development of a point on which Otis lawyers had the testimony of five witnesses ready.

To help alleviate the sufferings of an estimated 10,000,000 Koreans made destitute by the continuing seesaw military campaigns on the peninsula across and south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel, ten relief agencies have banded together here to form American Relief for Korea, it was announced yesterday.

TREVISO, Italy, April 26--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower told Italian military leaders today that the main task ahead for both the United States and Western Europe was that of "preserving the free world" and urged them "to work for this together as good comrades." This, he said, was the reason why he was here, and not to bring gifts.

Following is the text of an address delivered by Charles E. Wilson, Defense Mobilization Director, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night at the annual dinner of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association:

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)-- The Senate Finance Committee today approved a bill ordering the President "as soon as practicable" to withdraw tariff concessions to Russia and other Communist-dominated nations.

The Board of Estimate adopted unanimously yesterday a 1951-52 budget of $1,336,400,575. It was the highest in the city's history, exceeding by $297,777 the executive budget of $1,336, 102,798 submitted by Mayor Impellitteri on April 2.

A collection of furniture that borrows motifs fom the past but interprets them in a manner that belongs unmistakably to the present has been introduced by the Sherrill Furniture Corporation, 201 East Fifty-sixth Street. Any of these designs, all of which were done by Deering Davis, is available there through decorators.

PARIS, April 26 (UP)--Dick Savitt, Orange, N. J., player who became one of America's chief Davis Cup hopes last January when he won the Australian championship, today displayed the best tennis he has shown in Europe to defeat Budge Patty of Los Angeles, 6-3, 6-3, 4-6, 6-8, 6-2, and gain the men's singles final of the Paris tournament.

THE Irish, God save them, are a wonderful people. Only a little more than half as many people live in their entire island as live in the City of New York. But the number of good writers per capita on "the Pope's green isle" must be the largest of any nation on earth. Nothing can discourage an Irish writer, neither poverty nor pride nor prejudice, not even the in-...
CHICAGO, April 26--Grain prices held within narrow limits on the Board of Trade with the exchange closing at noon for the city's reception to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, April 26--Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, appealed to the Senate today to adopt his bill for admission of Mexican farm labor so as "to continue cordial relations between this country and Mexico." He is chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)-- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today asking for extension and strengthening of the Defense Production Act:

Attorney General Nathaniel E. Goldstein, who recently opened a state-wide inquiry into the narcotics problem, proposed yesterday a plan by which high school students would organize themselves into "young vigilantes" to help combat the "growing menace" of drug addiction among teen-agers.
Retail store executives condemned the city's new sales tax schedule yesterday as representing a policy of "squeezing out every last cent."

WASHINGTON, April 26--The Daily Worker, organ of the Communist party in this country, was reprimanded by Moscow in 1927 for deviation in "minimizing the predatory role of American imperialism in China."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26 --A new U-shaped classroom with swivel chairs for 110 students to facilitate discussion and with no windows to invite distraction has just gone into use at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration here.

Frank Costello, gambler and underworld leader, appeared yesterday at the Kings County District Attorney's office for questioning in the gangster slaying last week of Philip Mangano, waterfront racketeer.

A visiting cook in THE TIMES test kitchen recently was Mrs. Stella Standard, whose "Whole Grain Cookery: A Gourmet Guide to Glowing Health" was published yesterday by John Day, with a foreword by Miss Pearl S. Buck.

Seymour Berkson, vice president and general manager of the International News Service, reported yesterday to the agency's news and business executives that it had expanded its service to newspapers, radio and television clients and put into operation a new high-speed radioprinter circuit to South America.

Declining for the third successive time, loans to business by New York banks dropped $28,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The reduction, according to the figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, brought the total decline...

In his address last night before the American Newspaper Publishers Association, Mobilization Director Charles E. Wilson declared that the period of greatest risk for the free nations lies between the present time and the end of 1953. It is an interval which demands, on the one hand, that we do nothing that could relieve the Soviets of the onus of their decision, if they..
Henry D. Sharpe Jr. was named president of the Brown Sharpe Manufacturing Company to succeed his father, who was elected chairman, it was announced.
After a slow start the 500-car parking area atop the block-square Port Authority Bus Terminal now is operating at near capacity and on two recent days has been forced to turn trade away.

Baseball's executive council yesterday cleared the path for the immediate resignation of Commissioner A. B. Chandler by yielding to his demand that the secretarytreasurer of baseball, Walter Mulbry, go out at the same time.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 26 (AP) For the second successive day Miss Charlotte DeCozen of Parsipanny, N.J.; disrupted the march of favorites in the North and South women's amateur golf tournament. The 25-year-old Jersey woman won a tense 1-up match today from Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N. C., on the nineteenth hole.
Pittsburgh, Pa., will receive bids May 8 on issues of bonds totaling $3,200,000. Dated May 1, 1951, the bonds will come due May 1, 1952 to 1971.
National leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations demanded last night a new Defense Production Act that would stop abuses and check inflation.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 26--The Egyptian Government is taking steps to check the effects of the agitation for the nationalization of foreign assets, which has spread to Egypt from other parts of the Middle East as a result of Iran's steps to nationalize the AngloIranian Oil Company.

Charles E. Wilson, Defense Mobilization Director, asserted last night that the production "miracles" of World War II could now be doubled and that in three years America's industrial machine could insure world peace. But he warned that inflation could ruin the whole defense program and called for "toil and sweat" to avert "blood and tears."

Young women, including the Misses Pauline Mirabaud and Simone Smith, are serving on the junior committee for the annual dinner dance, known as the Bal des Berceaux, to be given tomorrow night in the St. Regis Roof under the auspices of the Committee of French-American Wives for the benefit of Refuge des Petits and War Relief in Korea.

BERLIN, April 26--Rudolf Friedrichs, Minister-President of Saxony, who died suddenly in 1947 from what was officially reported as a heart attack, was the victim of a political murder, his brother, Fritz, asserted here today.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company has sold the fourstory building at 826-830 Fox Street, the Bronx, containing sixteen apartments to Geisinger Rau, operators. The property occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet.

The expanded Greenwich Hospital at Greenwich, Conn., to be opened May 5 upon completion of improvements costing $4,750,000, will be affiliated with the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center here, it was announced yesterday by Randolph C. Harrison,...

To judge by the cheerfulness of the Morosco audience last evening, people who are delighted by ghost stories like "Gramercy Ghost," which brought Sarah Churchill to the neighborhood for her New York debut. Despite her exalted family connections, Miss Churchill is an intelligent and animated actress who can act a part like a professional, as her father does in his business, too.

LONDON, April 26--The importance of getting a fair share of the scarce raw materials, not only for Britain's rearmament but for her civilian needs as well, was recognized by Prime Minister Attlee today when he completed the recasting of his Cabinet, depleted by death and defections from the Left.
LONDON, April 26--Ralph Vaughan Williams' opera, "Pilgrim's Progress," which was presented at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden tonight, received warm notices in London newspapers today.

PARIS, April 26--Premier Henri Queuille today made progress, but was not sure of success, in his fight in the National Assembly for electoral reform and for elections some time in June. The debate in the Assembly was put over until tomorrow, while the Government forces sought to rally the majority of 311 votes needed for passage of the electoral bill.

Six former addicts told last night how their mutual help had enabled them to avoid narcotics for the last year. They were the persistent ones among nearly 100 who have attended some of the secret meetings of Narcotics Anonymous.

PARIS, April 26--Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States deputy, told Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet deputy, this afternoon that "the Soviet Union has persistently supported the North Korean aggressors, politically and materially." Dr. Jessup added that "the Soviet Union has persistently opposed and tried to block the efforts of the United Nations to restore peace."

Plans for reconstructing and enlarging the library building at City College at a cost of $1,625,000 were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Under the plans, the two sides and rear of the building will be extended, creating a T-shaped structure.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP)-- The Government announced today an inquiry into complaints about egg trading practices on organized markets in the New York area.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 26-- The five-year plan of former President Eurico G. Dutra, which, if carried out in full, would call for an expenditure of 20,000,000,000 cruzeiros, is on its way out, it was reported today. It is said that President Vargas considers that the plan is too ambitious in the present financial situation, with a deficit of present and past budgets amounting to more than 10,000,000,000 cruzeiros.
WASHINGTON, April 26--President Truman sent to Congress today a legislative program proposing broader controls to get the nation "over the hump" in the defense mobilization program.

WASHINGTON, April 26--With a minimum of debate and no appreciable opposition, the House of Representatives passed today a $6,468,206,000 supplemental appropriations bill for the armed services and the Atomic Energy Commission.

An injured man en route to Knickerbocker Hospital in an ambulance suffered a second mishap yesterday when the driver of the vehicle, trying to avoid striking a pedestrian, crashed into a car parked at 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Mounting demands for structural steel are reaching the point where a stricter control over construction of all types will be inevitable by fall.

It may have been Sal Maglie's birthday, but the gifts went to Johnny Sain last night at the Polo Grounds when the Braves downed the Giants, 3-0, making it eight straight setbacks for the slumping New Yorkers.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26-- Mrs. Emil Denemark's Ruhe, on a stewards' decision after a rodeo finish, and C.V. Whitney's Mameluke, with a remarkable run through the mud in which the jockey went the full mile and an eighth with a broken stirrup, took the money in the two divisions of the $25,000 added Blue Grass Stakes as the Keeneland meeting ended today.
The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday selection of a site in Wenatchee, Wash., for a new aluminum smelting plant, capable of supplying 170,000,000 pounds of primary aluminum annually.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (AP) --Three thousand athletes from 500 colleges and schools will romp over Franklin Field tomorrow and Saturday in the Penn Relays eighty-nine events, but the focal race will be an international assault on the carnival's mile mark.

Sugar markets settled down yesterday after the upward flurry caused by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan's prediction that United States sugar consumption would rise this year. Sales of the No. 4 sugar contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Ex-...

The four-story building at 173137 Broadway, northwest corner of West Fifty-fifth Street, formerly occupied by the Glidden-Buick auto agency as a showroom, has been sold by the Tishman Realty Construction Company to an investing client of Walter Scott Co.

TOKYO, Friday, April 27--Elements of five enemy divisions drove yesterday at United Nations units fighting stubborn delaying actions north of Seoul as the main allied forces withdrew slowly and in order to new defensive positions north of the old Korean capital.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP)-- The Reciprocal Trade Extension Bill now goes to the Senate, where a stiff fight is anticipated over clauses which would allow foreign farm produce to come in at prices lower than domestic support levels.

BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., April 26--A statement of principle designed to guide the Protestant foreign mission enterprise throughout the world in its relations with government was approved here today by 125 church executives and mission officials.
WASHINGTON, April 26--Labor Department excperts set the country's manpower goal at an additional 7,200,000 men and women for defense industry and the armed forces by the end of 1952.

To further a contemplated expansion program that would "include the more frequent production of plays by outside authors," the Playwrights Company elected Roger L. Stevens, producer and realtor, to full membership at its meeting on Wednesday.

President Truman's message to Congress yesterday combined a review of the activities carried out to date under the Defense Production Act of 1950 and the Administration's suggestions for changes in the law when it comes before Congress for renewal sometime between now and June 30.
The American Association of Newspaper Representatives welcomed television to the advertising field yesterday--but with qualifications.
United Nations forces drew back closer to Seoul behind stubborn delaying attacks that slowed the enemy's offensive. Communist casualties mounted to 30,000 since the Reds' jumpoff. [1:8; map P. 2.]

Lively bidding which sent the price well above the assessed valuation marked the court hearing yesterday on a proposal made to trustees of Series C-2 mortgage certificates for the purchase of the nineteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 895 Park...

Two manufacturers of electrical appliances gave guarantees to their distributors yesterday against losses resulting from possible factory price rollbacks under the new general manufacturers pricing order. The guarantees are believed...

Paced by Dick Hofleit, who pounded two home runs and a pair of singles, Long Island University's nine crushed Iona College of New Rochelle, 22--9, at the Parade Grounds in Brooklyn yesterday. The triumph was the sixth in seven starts for the Blackbirds.

General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman approved yesterday the dismissal of inidictments against five alleged participants in a fantastic wiretap plot aimed at city officials during, former Mayor O'Dwyer's administration two years ago.
NORFOLK, Va., April 26--One hundred naval vessels, several hundred naval planes and 50,000 officers and men will start Monday on a three-week maneuver in the Western Atlantic. The exercise will...

Two youthful stowaways returned here yesterday on the French liner De Grasse with completely changed ideas on the reputed hospitality and cuisine of the Frenchman and an even dimmer view of the so-called wonders and ease of an ocean voyage.

Fifteen artists, writers and composers were named yesterday by Douglas Moore, president of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, as the 1951 recipients of $1,000 grants made, annually to non-members.
Net earnings of the National Distillers Products Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries in the March quarter increased to $8,563,226,the report revealed yesterday.

A $2,280,000 fellowship program, designed to increase the teaching competency of younger college instructors while "reducing the shock of mobilization to college and university faculties," was announced yesterday by the Fund for the Advancement of Education.

WASHINGTON, April 26--Senate and House conferees on the draft and military training bill agreed today on language that would reserve to local Selective Service boards the final authority on deferment of college students.

Net income of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in the first quarter of this year amounted to $25,066,205, equal to $2.45 a common share, compared with $25,572,930, or $2.50 a share, in the corresponding period of 1950, E. G. Grace, chairman, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 26--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican policy leader of the Senate, questioned from the floor today the integrity of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

It is really exciting to see fashions of "now and then"(that is, of today and 1876) appearing side by side, and to have a realistic illustration of how much more comfortable and attractive the styles created for the woman of 1951 are than those rich and cumbersome affairs that grandmother wore when she went shopping, dancing and swimming.

In due course fitting evaluation will be made of the great service to his country and to the maintenance of a free world which was rendered by the late Senator Vandenberg. In that record a proposal he made on Jan. 10, 1945; and the prescience which evoked it will be outstanding.

BOSTON, April 26--A wan Casey Stengel was back in uniform at the head of his Yankees today, leading his champions against the Red Sox in their first visit of the season at Fenway Park. But, what happened wasn't calculated to have any beneficial influence on the skipper's ailing kidney.
GENEVA, April 26--The United States submitted today a new set of "economic and social rights" for incorporation in the proposed international covenant of human rights.
The skies might threaten, and the breezes blow, but it was a grand day yesterday in New York--and let who will prefer April is Paris. The mercury in the city's thermometers climbed to a...

PUTNAM, Conn., April 26--Dr. Hamilton Holt, president emeritus of Rollins College, Winter Park, Fla., who once was editor and owner of the old Independent, a national liberal weekly, died today in Day-Kimball Hospital here of a heart attack suffered last night in his home at Woodstock, Conn. His age was 78.

MOBILE, Ala., April 26 (UP)-- The Coast Guard charged a sea captain and his third mate with negligence today in the fiery collision of two tankers that killed thirty-nine seamen and set a hearing to determine whether their licenses should be revoked.

JERSEY CITY, April 26--Hudson County Judge John Drewen today upheld the validity of indictments brought by the Hudson County-Grand Jury, charging for met Deputy Mayor John F. Malone and former City Commissioner Daniel Casey of Jersey City with...

Six persons, including a 45-yearold woman union official, were named yesterday in a fifty-count indictment charging the operation of a kickback racket in the employment of concessionaires in "grind" motion picture houses in Times Square and parts of Harlem and Brooklyn.

TORONTO, April 26 (Canadian Press)--International Petroleum Company, Ltd., had a net profit in 1950 of $24,812,918, or $1.71 a share, compared with $13,051,382, for 90 cents a share in 1949, the best since 1938.

Steel Blue, under an excellent ride by George Hettinger, closed the fastest to take the Caballero Classified Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The 4-year-old gelding came up in the last few strides to register a victory over American Glory, while the favored Rock Span finished third.

Richard Walter Jones, a retired banker, died Wednesday in his home at 135 South Irving Street, Ridgewood, N.J., at the age of 86. He was the father of Charles Hill Jones, a vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company.

MOSCOW, April 26--Pravda contended today that people lived much longer in the land of communism than they did under the conditions of capitalism, citing a survey that showed there were more than 30,000 men and women in the Soviet Union more than 100 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP)-- The United States shipped about 330,000 tons of arms to its overseas Allies during the second six months of the Mutual Defense Assistance Program, it was announced today.

Housewives were reminded yesterday by Joseph B. O'Connor, regional director of the Federal Security Administration, that the first social security reports and payroll taxes on domestic servants are due no later than Monday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 --Margaret Truman made her debut as a radio actress here tonight before a National Broadcasting Company studio audience of 375, which expressed enthusiastic approval of her performance.

Following a final practice round at the Knollwood Country Club, White Plains, yesterday, seven members of the United States Walker Cup golf team were set to sail today aboard the S. S. Parthia for the international matches with the British amateurs, May 11 and 12, at the Birkdale Golf Club near Liverpool.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 26 (AP)-- A special Parliamentary oil commission voted tonight to ask Parliament to set up a twelve-man Iranian Government board to take immediate control of the huge British-owned Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., April 26--Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge, New Jersey State champion, showed the way to a large group of Class A and B women players today in the opening one-day tournament of the New Jersey division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the Green Brook Country Club. Mrs. Tracy turned in 41, 39--80 to win low gross honors in the Class A group.
ALBANY, April 26--Automobile races and other public sports not specifically authorized by the Legislature are illegal on Sunday, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has ruled.

Four, five and six cent a pound increases were scored by some meat prices on the week, Departwent of Markets shoppers reported yesterday, in the face of the dislocation of distribution caused by the current price tangle.
WASHINGTON, April 26--President Truman said today there was nothing new in the current "MacArthur incident" and cited several instances in American history to prove it.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)-- Maj. Gen. Charles A. Willoughby, 59 years old, who was assistant chief of staff under General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, is to be relieved in May, the Defense Department reported tonight.

BALBOA, C.Z., April 26--When the American Hawaiian freighter Nevadan arrived here this morning her captain, F. H. Roberts, received from Acting Gov. Herbert D. Vogel a certificate showing that the ship was the 150,000th commercial vessel to use the canal since...
Senator Owen Brewster of Maine suggested last night that it might be well to use Chiang Kai-shek's Chinese Nationalist troops in the war in Korea.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation may have some big new expansion project under consideration. At least that was the impression drawn from remarks made yesterday by E. G. Grace, chairman of the nation's second largest steel producer, at a press meeting here.

WASHINGTON, April 26--A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the Philadelphia Orchestra Association, which operates the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, directead by Eugene Ormandy, is under the jurisdiction of the board and the Taft-Hartley Act.

WASHINGTON, April 26--President Truman replied today to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and other critics of Administration policy with a declaration that it remained the aim of the United Nations to limit the war in Korea.

LONDON, April 26--Britain and the United States were reliably reported today to have put aside momentarily their differences about consulting Communist China on the Japanese peace treaty and the future of Formosa and to be concentrating on agreement on the terms of the treaty.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 26--The Yugoslav Government's plan to permit its export industries to retain a percentage of their foreign exchange earnings for their own uses has given rise to a report that the Yugoslav Communist party is contemplating a new economic policy (N.E.P.) similar to the one used by Lenin to revive the Soviet Union's shattered economy in the Nineteen Twenties.

Nine of the thirty-three meat cuts regularly checked by the City Department of Markets are up 2 to 5 cents a pound this week. Lamb is scarce and, according to Markets Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli, "at new, all-time peak levels." Beef, veal and pork are sufficient, he said, for the continued slow demand and available to consumers who want to pay the prices. At least three chains listed some beef among their "week-end specials."
WASHINGTON, April 26--The Government of Iraq put emigrant Iraqi Jews on notice today that they would lose their citizenship if they did not return to Iraq within two months of tomorrow.
ST. PAUL, April 26 (AP)--Phil Icuss, former American Bowling Congress doubles champion, moved into fourth place in all-events of the forty-eighth annual tournament today with a 1,922 total.

Leases with four American-flag steamship companies for the use of city-owned piers, as submitted by the Department of Marine and Aviation, received final approval yesterday from the Board of Estimate.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, April 25--A good deal of the unrest plaguing the French West Indies and permitting strong Communist inroads into the native population stems from the fact that since March, 1946, Martinique and Guadeloupe have been Departments of Metropolitan France.
The threat of censorship in this state loomed for publishers of comic magazines yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 26--A small Greek steamship sailed into the tiny port of Elath, on the Gulf of Aqaba, today, completing a three-week voyage from Mombasa, Kenya, that may open vast new trade possibilities for Israel and help solve this country's large food deficit.

CHICAGO, April 26--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur capped an enthusiastic Midwestern welcome here tonight with the declaration that a realistic American policy for Korea must replace the present "political vacuum heretofore unknown to war."

Operations proceeded according to plan Thursday as United Nations ground forces continued withdrawals to new defensive positions. Disengagements were generally successful although fighting was severe is the west and west-central sectors where heavy casualties were inflicted on the enemy. Probing attacks in the east-central sector were contained as units adjusted positions. The eastern sector remained relatively quiet.

The only suitable answer to Mr. Gromyko's tirades in Paris is an American general's famous reply to the enemy in the late war: "Nuts!" At the end of the eighth week his performance has not only gone beyond "the bounds of decency," in the words of the British representative; it has reduced international conferences to the depths of absurdity. As the Soviet deputy harangues his distinguished colleagues in the words and manner of a prosecutor...

OTTAWA, April 26--In the House of Commons this afternoon Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs, made it plain that he adhered to the view that the war should not be extended beyond the borders of Korea without specific authority from the United Nations.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 26--The Czechoslovak Government has jailed William N. Oatis, one of two American correspondents remaining in Prague, on charges of hostile activities and spreading secret information.

MONTREAL, April 26 (Canadian Press)--Decisions to launch immediately a new expansion program in the Canadian aluminum industry, involving the first stage of a vast new integrated aluminum development in the remote areas of British Columbia, were an-...
PARIS, April 26--The principal consultations that Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, will have in Paris, where he is due to arrive Saturday, will be with General of the Army Dwight
The American Broadcasting Company won a special award yesterday for its "courageous stand in resisting organized pressure and its reaffirmation of basic American principles"
Dollar volume of furniture orders has fallen below the corresponding 1950 period and cancellations are on the increase.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 26 (AP)-- A naval board of inquiry was told today that a Cuban airliner and a Navy trainer plane apparently did not see each other until just a moment before the collision that cost forty-three lives yesterday.

The new Furness luxury liner Ocean Monarch, designed and built specifically as a cruise ship, will make her debut in New York harbor today. The 14,000-ton, singlestacked vessel is expected to slip quietly into port before daybreak after a leisurely ten-day crossing from Tilbury, England.
WASHINGTON, April 26--Blair Moody, who has been at the White House many times as a reporter for The Detroit News, paid his first call today as the newly appointed Democratic Senator from Michigan.

THE local trout enthusiasts have been viewing the sunny skies and warm weather of the past few days with considerable disfavor, for most of them are convinced that this constitutes a build-up for a cold, wet weekend on the stream.

Inventive genius has been at work in the fabric mills and fall aad winter, fabrics that resulted from its labor were gathered together in a grand display by the Fashion Group, Inc., yesterday. The occasion was the luncheon meeting of members and guests held at the Astor Hotel for the purpose of reviewing next season's fabrics.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., showed the largest profit for any first quarter in its history during the first three months of this year. At the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday B. Brewster Jennings, president, reported estimated earnings...

Jerzy Fitelberg, Polish composer, died here Wednesday in his home at 244 West Seventy-second Street. His age was 48. He was the son of Grzegorz Fitelberg, composer and conductor of the Warsaw Philharmonic until the second World War.

SAN MATEO, Calif., April 26 (UP)--Citation, unable to run as he did in his championship days, finished third for the second time in his career today when a horse named Pancho Supreme won the $5,000 Veterans Hospital Handicap at Bay Meadows.

One of the benefits that have accrued, at least in part, from the heavy Chinese Communist commitment in Korea is an improvement in the situation on the Indo-Chinese front. A short time ago the Communist rebels under Ho Chi Minh announced that they had abandoned frontal or positional warfare for the time being and would revert to guerrilla tactics.

MADRID, April 26--Clashes between Spanish strikers and policemen armed with clubs occurred this afternoon in San Sebastian, where workers were angered by refusal of the authorities to release a number of their comrades from prison. A judge has been appointed to examine the cases of the men under arrest.

Hugo S. Rothschild, Kenneth L. Curtis, John Potesky, in the Park-Gramercy, 7 Lexington Ave; Carl Siegel, in 923 5th Ave; Robert Y. Brown, in 161 E 61st St; Mildred A. Buckley, in 7 E 75th St--William A. White Sons, brokers.
Expansion of industrial furnace production to meet the demands of the national mobilization program is being held up by a critical shortage of draftsmen.
The Harlem River and Onondaga Lake at Syracuse will be the scenes of the two major rowing regattas in the East this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, April 27--Ceiling prices on live meat animals are expected to be announced by the Office of Price Stabilization over the week-end.
OTTAWA, April 27 (Canadian Press)--Canada was open a drive to get more United States defense orders as a means of overcoming a worrisome trade deficit, trade officials said today.

Stockholders received only $9,000,000,000 of the $40,000,000,000 "bookkeeping" profits earned by corporations last year. The United States Chamber of Commerce so stated in a reply to a Federal Trade Commission report yesterday showing manufacturers' profits rose 61.
More than 3,500 members of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., will participate in the organization's second annual communion breakfast tomorrow morning.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., April 27-- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association launched its Long Island division Class B schedule today at the Brookville Country Club with sixty-six players competing. Eight prizes were at stake and by the time the last foursome finished, the results showed that Mrs. William B. Mudge of the host club was the day's outstanding golfer.

The Advisory Board on the Pulitzer Prizes met for the last time this year at Columbia University yesterday before passing on award recommendations to the University trustees. The trustees will act on ehe recommendations at their meeting on May 7 and the 1951 prizes will be announced at that time.
Dan Bucceroni, 178 pounds, of Philadelphia, gained a unanimous decision over Dick Wagner, 172, of Toppenish, Wash., in the feature bout of ten rounds at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

WASHINGTON, April 27--The engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Mary Sanders to Sgt. John Francis Shindelar, U.S.M.C., of Quantico, Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Vincent Shindelar of Lisle, Ill., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. William Howard Sanders.

Although appreciating the action of the Board of Estimate on Thursday in raising the rates to be paid to voluntary hospitals for care and treatment of indigent sick sent to them by the city, the private institutions were planning yesterday to press for additional funds.

While the battle rages in Korea the United Nations, in whose cause and under whose banner this war is being fought, today presents the extraordinary spectacle of having virtually washed its hands of the struggle. The Security Council remains paralyzed by Russia's veto power; the General Assembly, which took over some of the Council's peace-enforcement functions, ...

CHICAGO, April 27--Grain markets showed a heavy undertone in the early trading today but coarse grains rallied sharply, corn and oats closing 1/8 to 5/8 cent higher on the Board of Trade. Wheat, however, felt the effect of persistent hedging sales in May and July While the new crop months were sustained by commission house buying.

A total of $275,000 in salary increases for 2,900 field workers under the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., has been voted effective July 1. Three thousand five hundred projects in the United States, West Indies and Alaska are affected. The announcement was made yesterday at the closing session of an annual two-day convention of the board at 155 Fifth Avenue.

Sugar futures continued to feature the commodity markets yesterday, displaying the best gains. In other commodities, cocoa, wool and tin futures displayed some strength in moderate dealings. There is a feeling that continued hostilities presage mounting demand.

LONDON, April 27--Winston Churchill formally announced today that he had postponed "for a while" his visit to Philadelphia to speak at the bicentenary of the University of Pennsylvania Library originally scheduled for May 8.

CHICAGO, April 27 (UP)--The St. Louis Cardinals stretched five hits off rookie Bob Schultz into a 3-to-0 shutout over the Chicago Cubs today and took undisputed possession of first place in the National League, breaking a tie for the lead with the Phils.

LONDON, April 27--In a May Day manifesto published today the National Council of Labor appealed to the leaders of Soviet Russia to "lift the burden of fear from the world." The council represents the Labor party, the Trades Union Congress and the Cooperative Union.

The stock market extended the recovery yesterday and went to new tops since 1930. Buying support was fairly steady and gains of fractions to slightly more than 3 points were registered. Some of the oils and chemicals staged spectacular performances. Measured by the composite rate, the share list advanced 1.43 points.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 28-- United Nations forces broke contact with the enemy along most of the Korean front yesterday, retreating behind a wide No Man's Land as rain and mud bogged the roads. For the first time since the Communist spring offensive began last Sunday the air attack that has cost the Chinese and North Koreans many thousands of casualties was slowed.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 27 (AP)--A paper industry spokesman said today that the United States makes nearly twice as much paper as it did eleven years ago "and still we're told there's a shortage."
The following is a round-up of new products designed to facilitate housekeeping:

The American Sugar Refining Company has begun a new and intensive advertising campaign stressing the energy value of pure sugar, particularly for the young. Joseph W. Mooney, vice president for sales and advertising, says the copy will stress the need "for a continuous flow of food-energy" under modern conditions. Using more than 300 daily newspapers, Sunday supplements and farm journals, he calculates delivery of more than 900,000,000 sales messages until the end of the year.

LONDON, April 27--An impressive rise in profits announced by Imperial Chemical Industries stimulated leading industrials on the stock markets here today. The organization's profits for 1950, before taxation, reached 31,018,457, against 17,325,509 in 1949. Net profits were 18,562,765--up nearly 7,750,000 on the year.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 27 --A group of Fairfield County residents, opposed to placing natural gas pipelines in their territory, will meet Sunday to plan the next move in their campaign for legislative control over the project.

YONKERS, April 27--Mrs. Luther Lemon of Whippoorwill set the pace in the opening class B one-day tournament of the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the hilly Dunwoodie Club today.

Miss Kate Wollman received a cordially noisy expression of thanks yesterday for her recent gift to the city--the new skating rink in the southeast corner of Central Park. About 150 Yorkville youngsters assembled at Public School 151, Ninety-first Street and First Avenue, to thank her for the donation of $600,000 that made it possible to keep the ice-skating flag flying from autumn until spring.
DES MOINES, April 27 (AP)--A quartet of surprising milers from Michigan State College today set a new four-mile record in the opening of the forty-second Drake Relay Carnival.
LONDON, April 27--The Conservative Opposition moved today to put the Government and its fractious elements on the spot.

A meeting of Protestant clergymen to set forth the responsibilities of Christians in meeting community problems in New York will be held Monday at 10:30 A.M. in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

THE bright sunshine seems to have dissipated the frozen water which has been keeping the ice-out anglers from many of the Maine lakes, and late reports indicate only a few of the popular waters still closed.
Two brazen teen-agers attempted yesterday to buy heroin in a Harlem apartment from a suspected seller in front of two startled Federal narcotics agents.

NEWARK, April 27--Paul S. Whitescarver, 60 years old, wealthy truck fleet operator, who last April 12 pleaded guilty in Federal Court to evasion of income taxes totaling $68,000, was fined $20,000 today, received a suspended sentence of two years and placed on probation for three years.

American Communists were ordered yesterday to subordinate all lesser party objectives to a search for common ground with labor, church and non-Communist political groups in a united front for "peace."
TRENTON, April 27--State Treasurer Walter T. Margetts Jr. questioned today whether an increased Federal tax on alcholic beverages might encourage return of "the liquor racketeer."

Mr. and Mrs. George Hamlin Shaw of River House gave a tea in their home yesterday, at which they announced the engagement of Mr. Shaw's daughter, Dora Drake, to Peter Coates Neidecker, son of Mrs. Cyrus Newkirk Johns of Glen Head, L.I., and B. Coles Neidecker of Palm Beach, Fla. An August wedding is planned.

Harold W. Schaefer has been named director of refrigeration and range engineering by the Philco Corporation. He formerly was a special assistant to Leslie J. Woods, vice president, director of research and engineering.

Members of Congress, their families and entourage, numbering well over 150 persons arrived yesterday at Pennsylvania Station for an annual week-end holiday in New York. Many of the newly elected members had never visited here before.
A stocky 16-year-old Scranton, Pa., high school student who says he doesn't especially like sports was named yesterday the Young Men's Christian Association boy athlete of the year.

Representatives of the Kings County District Attorney's office continued yesterday to question reputed leaders of the Mafia, notorious underworld syndicate, for clues in the gangster killing last week of Philip Mangano, Brooklyn waterfront racketeer.

Edmund Wilson's play in two parts, "The Little Blue Light," will be presented tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Anta Playhouse, 245 West Fifty-second Street. Produced by Quietus Productions, comprising Peter Cookson, Hume Cronyn, Joe Magee, Martin Manulis and the Brattle Theatre Company, it will ...

THOMPSON RIDGE, N.Y., April 27--Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. Charles Beattie Thompson of the engagement of their daughter, Jean Kerr, to Robert Vogelbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Vogelbach of Searsville. The wedding is planned for August.

WITH TWENTY-NINTH BRITISH BRIGADE, in Korea, April 27--A heroic tale of the First Battalion of the Gloucestershire Regiment, which was isolated on a rugged peak near the town of Solma, about 4,000 yards southwest of the Imjin River, and became encircled just before dawn on Monday, has just become known.
PARIS, April 27--Jacques Griffe's midseason collection opens with gay beachwear in colorful prints combined with plain.

CHICAGO, April 27--Sewell Avery, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., said today he is "terrified" by the possible economic effects of the national movement to provide pensions for everybody. He told stockholders at the company's annual meeting that he believed many of the pension plans adopted by corporations are "doomed to failure."

The annual spring clean-up campaign of the Department of Sanitation was started yesterday noon at a ceremony in City Hall Plaza, where Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey issued a proclamation designation as "Spring Clean-up Weeks" the period beginning next Monday and running through May 13.

A huge 180,000-horsepower wind tunnel drive that can provide enough power to generate blasts of air several times the speed of sound is now being built by the General Electric Company, Schenertady, N.Y.
GUTHRIE, Okla., April 27--A B-36 Superbomber and a P-51 gunnery target plane collided high above Central Oklahoma during combat maneuvers today, killing thirteen fliers.

Some of the best-known dealers in the East in the field of country antiques will set up shop at the Eastern States Antiques Fair, opening on Monday at the Westchester County Center in White Plains, N.Y., for a run through Saturday.

GIBRALTAR, April 27 (AP)--The 1,152-ton British ammunition ship Bedenham blew up today with an earth-shaking blast as she unloaded at this Mediterranean rock fortress. Ten workers were believed killed and more than 1,000 injured.

ST. PAUL, April 27 (UP)--Four changes among the top ten American Bowling Congress leaders were chalked up today, with St. Paul, New York, Minneapolis and Kenosha, Wis., keglers providing the fireworks.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 27--The first important United States reinforcement of the Allied forces manning the West's front line in Europe will arrive in Germany late next month when the initial contingent of the United States Fourth Infantry Division will land at Bremerhaven.
WASHINGTON, April 27--The United States and Denmark signed today an agreement for the joint defense of Greenland against the threat of attack or invasion.

If housing production can be continued at the rate estimated for this year, no housing shortage of national proportions is in prospect, Thomas S. Holden, president of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, told members of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers yesterday at their annual regional conference at the Hotel Biltmore.

Rated competently by Warren Mehrtens, Renew of the King Ranch made the figures in her favor stand up at Jamaica yesterday. The 4-year-old daughter of Blue Larkspur opposed four others of her sex in the mile and a sixteenth Recce which occupied the feature spot, stepping the distance in 1:45 to score by more than a length.
WAKE FOREST, N.C., April 27 (AP)--A pitched shotgun and rifle battle broke out at the struck Royal Cotton Mills here tonight. Several persons were hit but none was injured seriously.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico, voiced opposition today to the Ellender bill, which would admit Mexican contract farm labor under an international agreement negotiated in January.
Among the many current rewarding exhibitions in New York galleries is one at John Nicholson's, devoted to sixteenth-century Flemish paintings--work by Bosch, the two Brueghels and their associates.

HARTFORD, April 27--Construction of a steel mill in the New London area would have a tremendous impact upon communities in eastern Connecticut and would threaten the expansion of the public water supply of New London and three other towns, a committee on community problems resulting from the building of a mill reported today.

PARIS, April 27--A special investigating subcommittee of the Council of the Republic charged tonight that administrative bungling was hamstringing France's five-year air rearmament program. It reported that none of the credits voted last August had been used and that virtually no orders for planes had been given.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP)-- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, considers the Communist party in this country more dangerous than the Nazi Fifth Column during World War II and is ready to arrest 14,000 "dangerous" Reds in event of war with Russia.

For the fifth time in ten months the Korean struggle centers on the martyr city of Seoul. The capital of South Korea is now more a skeleton than a city, and the skeleton is a symbol of the price, marked up with every round, which the Korean people and the armies fighting with them have paid and are paying to resist aggression and prevent a third world war.

The present military situation in Korea and the fashion in which it is developing are not materially different from the majority of the combat estimates. The large-scale Chinese Communist counter-offensive was predicted. To meet it, United Nations forces were held to a firm front that was not overextended. It was expected that substantial withdrawals would be necessary if the enemy attacked in great force.
PANAMA, April 26--Venezuelan politics is at least as inflammable as the colossal and fantastic wealth of oil that seems to seep from every rock.

Michigan yesterday designated May 8 for receiving bids on a $65,000,000 bond issue to finance construction and improvement of charitable and penal institutions. The offering was authorized in a referendum last November.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio asserted today that the United States, in planning decisive action in Korea to end a war of stalemate, "must not be stopped by any hesitation about the possibility that the Russians may come into the war."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27-- Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, called upon 65,000 members of the organization today to "wake up" and fight the Government's securityscreening program for dock workers.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 27 --The "peril of conformity" is a threat to human progress, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, minister of Riverside Church in New York, told 200 women here this afternoon at the spring conference of the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs.

WASHINGTON, April 27--The Senate (Fulbright) subcommittee investigating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has set out to correct a flaw in the law which, it is conceded widely, has made "influence peddling" in connection with R.F.C. loans a safe procedure.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 27--Premier Hussein Ala unexpectedly presented his resignation to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi tonight on the eve of a special session of the Majlis [Parliament], which was expected to enact machinery tomorrow for the immediate nationalization of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

Housewives doing the week-end shopping found many butchers yesterday pushing sales of eggs bought in tie-in sales to get beer from wholesalers. With lamb scarce, the retail butchers had to buy price-control exempt eggs to get some beef to keep up their sales volumes.

The reminder that housewives must file the first Social Security reports and payroll taxes on domestics no later than Monday sent many of them yesterday on a desperate but fruitless search for the forms.

United Nations withdrawals continued Friday with enemy pressure decreasing generally along the front, although heavy fighting was still in progress north of Seoul. In the central sector, our units assumed new defensive positions after breaking contact with hostile elements. The eastern sector remained relatively quiet.

STONY BROOK, L.I., April 27 --W. Kingsland Macy, a member of the State Board of Regents, suggested tonight that successful completion of a religious instruction course be made a prerequisite to graduation from the public schools of New York State.

PARIS, April 27--Failing by three votes to get the required majority in the National Assembly for the electoral reform bill, Premier Henri Queuille's coalition Cabinet was in a state near a crisis late tonight.

CLEVELAND, April 27--Animal experiments at the National Cancer Institute of the United States Public Health Service have provided evidence that a hormone from the adrenal gland, related to cortisone, protects the animals against a chemical that produces cancer of the liver.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)-- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath asked today a delay of at least thirty days in the contempt-of-court proceedings against Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer and nine others.

WASHINGTON, Aprll 27--The Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha, Neb., today received authority from the Securities and Exchange Commission to borrow up to $30,000,000 from banks during the period ending March 22, 1952.

Seven members of the nine-man United States golf team that will defend the Walker Cup against a British amateur squad on May 1112 at the Birkdale Club near Liverpool, sailed aboard the S.S. Parthia yesterday.

PARIS, April 27--The three Western deputies presented without result today a revised agenda that included for the first time assent to a discussion of the Itallian treaty at a future meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Louis Matthews Wicklein, secretarytreasurer of the Sheet Metal Workers' International Association, A.F.L., died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He had been suffering from a heart ailment since October. His age was 59.

Although the Office of Price Stabilization's Order No. 22 would provide for a roll-forward of some rayon textile prices, mills and converters indicated yesterday that no extensive revision of price schedules will be undertaken at this time. Business has not been good enough, they pointed out, to warrant any move that would tend to discourage buyers.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 27--Evidence that a modern form of man lived at the same time as previously known primitive types some 75,000 years ago was produced here today by Prof. Carleton S. Coon of the University of Pennsylvania.

SHRIVENHAM, England, April 27--Push-button warfare may still be some distance off, but Britain's new post-war Army is training intensively its most brilliant young soldier scientists for the day when it comes.

Ed Stanky returned to second, Rafael Noble replaced Wes Westrum behind the plate and Jackie Maguire took over right field for the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. These changes by Leo Durocher were calculated to give the slumping Giants, who had dropped eight in a row, a lift against the Braves. They did, but, it wasn't enough.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP)-- The House Appropriations Committee made its strongest economy drive of the present session today by ordering a 10 per cent cut in the $6,837,677,465 fund requested by President Truman to operate twenty-seven Government agencies in the next fiscal year.

A protest against the manner in which General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was ousted as Supreme Allied Commander in the Far East was introduced yesterday at the executive council meeting of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Senate and House conferees abandoned hope today of early agreement on a compromise draft and Universal Military Training bill and decided not to hold any more meetings for the next two weeks or possibly longer.

Kazuko Tajitsu plays the violin with enthusiasm. Born in Seattle of Japanese descent, she has played professionally since she was 11, but last night marked her Town Hall debut. She was cordially received by an admiring audience. Brooks Smith was the assisting pianist.

WASHINGTON, April 27--President Truman may be having trouble with the politicians and large sections of the public for dismissing General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, but the political scientists and the historians are rallying to his support.

WASHINGTON, April 27--A city-to-city flight by a helicopter operating solely on an automatic pilot was completed on schedule today when a twin-rotor Piasecki landed at the United States Naval Air Base at Aanacostia, D.C., to end a flight that started at Morton, Pa., one hour and 30 minutes earlier.

GENEVA, April 27--Both the United States and British Governments have been guilty of losing perspective in the current debate over raw materials, in the view of international economic experts in Europe.
MOBILE, Ala., April 27 (AP)-- The master and third mate of the Esso Suez were convicted of negligence today in last week's Gulf of Mexico tanker collision in which thirty-nine men were lost.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27-- Stanley Kramer, independent producer at Columbia, has purchased a comedy fantasy, "The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T.," written for the screen by Ted Geisel, who uses the pseudonym of Dr. Seuss.

BOSTON, April 27--Joe DiMaggio exploded his first home run of the campaign atop the left-field wall at Fenway Park today but the blow was struck in a lost cause. For Steve O'Neill finally came up with a pitcher capable of going the route and the Red Sox won, 4--3, for a sweep of the twogame series here.

Protests by Protestant groups and individuals caused the Veterans of Foreign Wars, sponsor of today's Loyalty Day Parade, to change announced plans for Cardinal Spellman to ride with General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in the vanguard of the procession.

CINCINNATI, April 27 (UP)-- Baseball's Executive Council accepted the resignation of Walter Mulbry as secretary-treasurer of baseball today, fulfilling in part a request made by Commissioner A.B. Chandler when major league owners decided not to renew Chandler's contract.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27-- Georgetown romped off with the distance medley title and carnival records were broken by Army's Dick Shea and Seton Hall's Andy Stanfield today as the fifty-seventh annual Pennsylvania Relays opened in clear and pleasant weather at Franklin Field.

For more than a century the Community Service Society has held an honored and useful place in the life of this city. From the very beginning it has been a pioneer, sponsoring social reforms that have proved lasting and beneficial. It has, for many years, been a center for community welfare ...
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)-- Representative Frank Buchanan, Democrat of Pennsylvania, died tonight in the Naval Hospital, Bethesda, Md., after an illness of four weeks. His age was 48.

WASHINGTON, April 27--The Democratic National Committee jumped squarely today into the middle of the political controversy now raging over President Truman's dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from all his Far Eastern commands.

The last of eight new numbers in the Ballet Theatre's schedule at the Metropolitan Opera House was presented last night in the form of a "Tropical Pas de Deux" by the company's own Enrique Martinez, set to the music of Amadeo Roldan, Cuban composer, and danced by Alicia Alonso and Igor Youskevitch.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27-- The Dodgers connected for three home runs, a triple, three doubles and three singles today to defeat the Phils, 11--5.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 27-- War correspondents killed in the line of duty in Korea are among those honored in the National Headliner Club's journalistic awards for 1950 announced here today by Tom Paprocki, Associated Press sports cartoonist, chairman of the board of judges. In all, seventeen headliner medal winners were announced.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Marriner S. Eccles, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had long since outlived its usefulness and "should be abolished without further delay."

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP)-- A National Labor Relations Board trial examiner ruled today that the New York Daily News and the New York Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union had violated the Taft-Hartley Act's ban on the closed shop.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Roswell L. Gilpatric, New York attorney, is scheduled to succeed Harold C. Stuart as an Assistant Secretary of the Air Force. The White House is expected to announce the change of officials within the next few weeks.
WASHINGTON, April 27--A labor union, the United Textile Workers, A.F.L., chided the government today for failing to provide what it described as adequate security for the bonds it asks people to buy.

MILWAUKEE, April 27--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur re-emphasized here today that he had no ambitions for public life, despite a substantial reaction to his "realistic-policy-forKorea" speech last night in Chicago.

The new Furness liner Ocean Monarch steamed sedately into New York Harbor at noon yesterday, her spacious white sport decks and tastefully appointed public rooms and passenger cabins a promise of happy hours at sea for thousands of Americans.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 27 (UP)--Miss Mae Murray of Rutland, Vt., ended the upset dreams of Miss Charlotte DeCozen of Parsippany, N.J., today with an easy 6-and-5 victory to reach the final of the forty-ninth North-andSouth women's amateur golf tournament along with the defending champion, Pat O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn.

Proof of the fact that classical orchestral music can be a superior drawing card, even at the movies, is evident from the return engagement of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of New York at the Roxy Theatre, starting May 9. The first engagement of the orchestra in September of last ...

Two alleged leaders of an international smuggling syndicate failed to answer an indictment charging them with the illegal possession of gold bullion when the case was called yesterday before Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in Brooklyn Federal Court. Four other defendants pleaded guilty and another entered a plea of not guilty.

BOWIE, Md., April 28 (AP)--Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable took first and third money in the $15,000-added Southern Maryland Handicap today as Why Not Now scored a half-length victory over King Ranch's On the Mark. The winner's stablemate, War King,...

The fast growing prefabrication industry, which in 1950 built one of every twenty single-family houses in the country, will in five years raise the ratio to one of every five dwellings, according to John C. Taylor Jr., head of American Houses, Inc., of New York, who is the new president of the Prefabricated Home Manufacturers Institute.

The Brookings Institution has made a useful study of the re-emergence of the toll road, published under the names of Wilfred Owen and Charles L. bearing. Already twenty-eight states, have given consideration to building toll facilities, and eighteen have some kind of toll-road legislation in effect.

The arrest of a basketball fixing suspect who was trailed "all over Florida" before he was tracked down outside a Miami night club Friday midnight was announced here yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

The annual report of Eversharp, Inc., for the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, 1951, released yesterday, showed a net profit of $2,231,989, equal to $2.30 per common share outstanding after regular preferred dividend charges.

The four young singers that George Leyden Colledge has been presenting at Town Hall each spring under the name of Aristo Artists generally have proved to be gifted. The fifth of such groups, which appeared there late yesterday afternoon, upheld the standards of the series.

The conditions noted by the recent inquiry into criminal operations here by the Senate Crime investigating Committee call for fresh emphasis on moral and spiritual principles, because "something has happened to out ideas of right and wrong in private and public life," the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street.
Despite the heavy demands of Great Britain's rearmament program, that nation's industrial and business leaders are making preparations to increase exports to the dollar market.

The 50-cent pieces collected from motorists are the keystone of the Port of New York Authority's sound financial structure and are enabling the agency to develop its marginal airport and marine projects in the New York-New Jersey port district.

Pressing demands have been placed on builders of machine tools through the large-scale re-tooling involved in the transition from civilian to military production, the National Industrial Conference Board reports. Production of machine tools has increased about 50 per cent since the start of the Korean conflict, but new orders have more than quadrupled, it is disclosed.

Thirty years ago today, in the ornate Great Hall of the old Chamber of Commerce Building on Liberty Street, the compact for the creation of a Port of New York District and the establishment of the Port of New York Authority was signed. Alfred E. Smith, Walter E. Edge, Charles S. Whitman, Nathan L. Miller, William R. Willcox, Lewis H. Pounds and Julius Henry ...

HONG KONG, April 29-- Premier Chou En-lai issued an order today requisitioning all oil stocks, installations, barges, tank cars and other equipment owned in China by the British Asiatic Petroleum Company. It was the first seizure by the Chinese Communists of property belonging to a British concern.

Mirza Abol Hassan Ispahani, Pakistani Ambassador to Washington, declared here yesterday that the long-standing dispute between India and Pakistan for control of Kashmir was preventing both states from contributing a full share to the maintenance of world peace.

WASHINGTON, April 29--The State Department today issued a pamphlet, "Confuse and Control," in which it described Russian efforts to reduce the German people to a helpless confusion of distrust and divided purpose.
The medical aspects of civil defense will be emphasized at the 145th annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York today through Friday at the Statler Hotel in Buffalo.

Has it occurred to you that one style can be interpreted in many different fabrics, each making a dress suitable for a different hour of the day and a different occasion? The Patterns of The Times feature for today, Advance Pattern 5826, is such a style.

WEIRTON, W. Va., April 29-- A runaway bus loaded with churchbound passengers careened out of control down a mile-long hill today, and smashed into a concrete wall, killing eight persons, including the driver.

LONDON, April 29--The domestic political crisis which suddenly developed last week produced a milder reaction in the City and the stock markets than might have been expected in view of the previous fortnight's market boom.

AMSTERDAM, April 29--Dr. Marius W. Holtrop, president of the Netherlands Bank, in the annual report published this week, says he is convinced that Dutch monetary equilibrium and equilibrium in the balance of payments can be restored if all inflationary financing is ended.

A defense of the new teaching program in the city's schools will be brought directly to parents by parents this week with publication of "Look At Your School," a booklet prepared by the Childhood Education Committee of the Public Education Association.

PARIS, April 29--The Government of Premier Henri Queuille will make another attempt tomorrow night to complete action on the first reading of electoral reform bill in the National Assembly to keep alive its hopes for holding general elections in June.

The Department of Health will begin today a thorough inspection of all gas-burning appliances in 120,000 housing units in Manhattan south of Ninety-first Street on the east side of Central Park, and south of Seventy-fourth Street on the west side of the park.

WASHINGTON, April 29--Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, said today that the third interim report of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, due Tuesday, would "put a crimp in the style of a good many criminals across the country."

Enemy pressure against United Nations lines slackened Sunday although fighting continued in the western and eastern sectors where enemy forces continued to probe our positions. No significant enemy contact was reported in the westcentral and east-central sectors as United Nations units adjusted positions.

UNITED STATES EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Korea, April 29--Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet declared today that the Communists had been beaten in the initial phase of their offensive but were now massing for the second part of the assault.

MURFREESBORO, Tenn., April 29 (UP)--This dairy town of 11,000, nestled in the Cumberland basin in the exact center of Tennessee, prepared tonight for one of the biggest events here since the Battle of Murfreesboro in 1862.
Since Edmund Wilson is preoccupied with serious ideas, he has written a play of serious ideas, "The Little Blue Light," which had its official opening at the Anta Playhouse last evening.
WASHINGTON, April 29-- President Truman soon will be playing what might be called a "United Nations" piano.

FRESNO, Calif., April 29 (AP)-- Matching men's par and beating the women's standards by five strokes in adverse conditions, Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio posted a 72 today to lead the first round of the 54-hole, $3,000 Valley open golf tournament here.
