DES MOINES, Iowa, April 29-- Numerous suggestions are being put forward for solution of the threatened shortage of manpower on American farms as the country needs an ever-increasing food production to meet its expanding defense needs.

The draft of a completely new city zoning law that basically would substitute a single set of zoning districts for the existing three-map system was offered for public consideration yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

On tenterhooks are the four producers of a gold mine, "South Pacific." They are anxious to know as quickly as possible when Roger Rico, French bass baritone, can take over the male lead, a role that was created by Ezio Pinza and is to be vacated on June 2 by his successor, Ray Middleton.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 29--The United States Government has rejected a Dutch proposal that the United States pay in dollars for supplies to be produced in the Netherlands for the North Atlantic defense.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 29-- Trygve Lie's Middle East tour, which ended tonight, has brought to the fore all the doubts and misgivings about the United Nations machinery and methods for attempting to secure peace and solve the problems between Israel and her Arab neighbors.
PARIS, April 29 (Reuters)-- Budge Patty, Wimbledon champion, and Dick Savitt, Australian title holder, teamed today to win the men's doubles titles in the Paris lawn tennis championships.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 29 (UP) --Twenty-six horses perished in a spectacular fire that destroyed their barn before dawn today at Beulah Park race track in near-by Grove City.

CHICAGO, April 29--Higher prices for grains prevailed on the Board of Trade last week despite liquidation in May contracts. Crop reports on winter wheat from the Southwest and West indicated yields this year would be below those anticipated on April 1. The general belief was that the final returns would be under 700,000,000 bushels, compared with 726,000,000 bushels on April 1 and 751,000,000 bushels harvested last year. The ten-year average is 792,000,000 bushels.
New York got its first taste of summer weather for 1951 yesterday--high temperatures followed by a heavy thunderstorm, which came in company with its usual mates, lightning and squally winds.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)-- Bank profits in 1950 were the greatest in history, Maple T. Harl, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (F.D.I.C.), said today.
The Giants lost their eleventh straight yesterday. This one was a 6-3 setback at the Dodgers' hands at Ebbets Field before 28,124 fans, the largest home crowd of the young season.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)A Washington specialist says he believes he has found a quick treatment for the sore arms that are the bane of baseball--something that could give the pennant races a new look.

THE entire major league career of William J. Coliver consisted of one game as an out fielder for the Boston Nationals in 1885. His batting average for that brief appearance was a rousing .000. Does that interest you? Me neither. By itself that item is as inconsequential a piece of information as anyone ever could hope to find.
In his message to Congress last Thursday, in which he made certain suggestions for changes in the Defense Production Act of 1950, President Truman said at one point:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29-- William Powell, who has been absent from the screen for nearly two years, will star in "The Treasure of Franchard," to be produced in June at Universal-International, the studio has announced.

ROME, April 29 (UP)--A high Vatican source said today that history might prove that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had a case of "great merits" in Korea, but that President Truman was right in removing him because the action tended "to pave the way toward peace negotiations."
Robert Ahders bought for investment from the estate of William Lauro the apartment house for thirty families at 2140 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx, in a deal negotiated by G. Satriale Son, brokers.

New York pioneered in zoning, with its resolution of 1916, which now is laden with more than 1,400 amendments acquired through the years. In 1948 the City Planning Commission decided to go ahead with a basically new approach.

King George VI of England will be heard in this country on Thursday in connection with the opening ceremonies of the Festival of Britain, to be held at Royal Festival Hall, London. Sir Oliver Frank, British Ambassador to the United States, will speak from Washington. WCBS will carry the program at 11:45 P.M.

Arie Ben-Eliezer, a member of the Israel Knesset (Parliament) and former leader of Irgun Zvai Leumi, deposed underground organization, was detained yesterday with his wife when they arrived at the International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, from Paris. Immigration authorities said their visas were not in order.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 29--All signs pointed tonight to the prompt investiture of Mohammed Mossadegh leader of the extremist National Front, as Premier of Iran.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 29 (AP) --Michael V. DiSalle, Price Stabilization Director, said today the new beef price control order made producers "liable for any attempts to conspire" against the regulation.

Robert Sherwood denounced last night as "plain insanity" the point of view that holds that Europe could be abandoned and that the United States should turn the full force of its effort toward fighting communism in China.
Communist and non-Communist leftist groups will stage rival May Day celebrations in observance of the May 1 international workers' holiday tomorrow.

The Most Rev. Thomas J. McDonnell, former Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, who was recently appointed Coadjutor Bishop of Wheeling, W. Va., celebrated pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday on the eve of his departure for the southern diocese. Cardinal Spellman presided.

At least one issue in the Australian election will sway the voters in every democratic country. Important national elections are in prospect in Great Britain and France. Municipal elections which will test the present strength of the Communist party are due in Italy. State elections are in process in Western Germany.

PARIS, April 29--Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, had a long talk with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today regarding the arms, the machine tools and the raw materials that the United States will supply to European nations to insure their rearmament.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 29-- Concern in several of this state's counties over efforts of utilities to establish eminent domain rights led today to a secret meeting of the Committee for Legislation to Control Gas Pipe Lines. The meeting place was not disclosed. Some details were later released here by a spokesman for the group.

At a meeting here yesterday with division chiefs of the Office of Price Stabilization, leaders of the meat processing and wholesaling industry urged that the Government establish immediately mandatory allocations of supplies.
COLUMBIA, Mo., April 29--A newspaper, two editors, a Washington columnist and an opinionpoll specialist will be honored May 4 with the Missouri awards for distinguished service in journalism.

Today's sugar market is heavy with imponderables. In spite of Government subsidies ranging from 30 to 80 cents a hundredweight, in spite of sales limits on domestic production and quotas for imports, the American price for sugar is below the world price and has been, with the exception of one or two brief flurries, ever since last July.

LONDON, April 29--The Maharajah of Rajpipla, one of the wealthiest of Indian Princes, died today at his English home, The Manor, Old Windsor, at the age of 61. It was his custom to spend the summers in England and the winters in India, but ill health prevented his return to India last autumn.

Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, announced yesterday that conferences had begun on integrating athletic programs in the city's high schools, possibly under the direction of a city-wide director of athletics.

Labor and management must forget any unhappy relations of the past and apply mutual trust if industrial peace is to be gained, the Rev. Philip Dobson, director of industrial relations at St. Peter's College, Jersey City, warned 1,600 railroad workers yesterday morning.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 29--The quality of living accommodations that should be provided to migrant farm workers has developed into a subject of hot controversy in central Arizona.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (UP)-- Wally Westlake's pinch home run in the ninth inning gave the Pirates a 1-to-1 ten-inning tie with the Reds in the second half of a doubleheader today after the Pirates won the opener in thirteen innings, 9 to 8.

EBBW VALE, Wales, April 29-- Aneurin Bevan, who resigned from the Labor Government last week in protest against the pace of rearmament and charged that Britain was being "dragged" too far behind United States diplomacy, sought and won tonight from some of his constituents overwhelming approval of his action.

NEW DELHI, India, Monday, April 30--United States food with conditions attached will not be acceptable to India, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was reported to have declared yesterday at a meeting of Congress party workers at Bulandshahr in Utter Pradesh State.

Parliamentary developments in Iran indicate that there will be no check on the precipitate expropriation of the property of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company. The lower legislative house has already voted for seizing the holdings and there is overwhelming confirmation for a Premier who has spearheaded the drive for nationalization. The course that events have taken is understandable, but it is unfortunate. Recklessness in Iran may have costly repercussions.

Insertions in national, business and trade magazines and television spot announcements are planned by the Zippo Manufacturing Company, Bradford, Pa., maker of pocket and table lighters. The campaign, now being scheduled, will use half-page black-and-white space units every month during the spring in three national magazines. Television stations in thirty cities will carry twenty-second spots regularly throughout the spring. Geyer, Newell Ganger, Inc. is the agency.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP)-- The Marine Corps plans to begin releasing its reservists in June and expects to have all those serving involuntarily mustered out by July of 1952, it was announced today.

The release of Robert A. Vogeler after seventeen months in a Budapest prison on a charge of espionage is none the less welcome although it happens to represent successful application of the highly developed Communist art of international blackmail.

The Rev. Dr. James Hutchinson Cockburn, former director of the department of reconstruction and inter-church aid of the World Council of Churches, gave an account of the council's past and present work in his sermon yesterday morning at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square.

Intensive interrogation of recent defectors from the Soviet Union has revealed that psychological warfare can play a substantial role in the struggle against the rulers of the Soviet Union. Their testimony indicates that the people ruled by Moscow are far from being taken in completely by the propaganda to which they are incessantly subjected and that much resentment smolders underneath the surface appearance of unanimity.

HANOI, Indo-China, April 29-- After some attempts to check the French-Vietnamese sweep, Communist-led Vietminh fighters in the guerrilla area have sought to disperse in order to try to come back after the main French military forces had passed.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP)-- The World Bank reported today a $1,626,374 increase in net income over the nine-month period ended March 31.

TOKYO, Monday, April 30-- Night-flying fighters and light bombers of the United States Fifth Air Force struck their heaviest blows of the war last night against long convoys of vehicles moving up to the Korean front as the Communist invaders apparently massed men and supplies for a possible May Day offensive.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., April 29--Soviet bloc delegates to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, which is generally a harmonious group, are expected to come up at tomorrow's opening meeting with a new "peace" declaration denouncing the war in Korea and the steppedup military programs of the Western allies.

Government agencies in the forefront of a decades-old campaign for the St. Lawrence Seaway have "arbitrarily" altered their estimates of potential traffic and revenue on the seaway to promote their arguments, it is charged in a comprehensive brief on the subject filed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP)-- The Federal Trade Commission dismissed today long-standing restraint-of-trade charges against four associations in the women's garment industry.

WASHINGTON, April 29--Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, said today that hearings on Far East foreign policy getting under way this week would be aimed at giving the public all facts possible on the controversy that led to the dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from his command.

Deliverance from "the abyss of doubt and despair" into "real religion" is drawing nigh, the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee declared yesterday morning from the pulpit of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.
Sales of houses in the Park Slope section featured Brooklyn realty deals reported over the week-end. Most of the buyers were investors.

PARIS, April 29--Certain United States leaders are beginning to consider the advisability of appointing a regional envoy or Ambassador-at-large to help coordinate United States interests and desires in the Eastern Mediterranean area.
For ten hours yesterday students and faculty of City College ignored the academic line that usually separates them and ate, played, hiked and sang together at Valley Stream State Park on...
Allied Stores Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries, attained the highest sales and the second largest earnings in its history during its fiscal year ended with last January.

Realignment of company organization and executives of Alexander Smith, Inc., was announced yesterday, for release today, by William F.C. Ewing, president and chairman. Alexander Smith, Inc., was formerly Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP)-- The policy committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today that continued heavy Government spending would lead to "large scale inflation."

Markets were generally quiet here last week as stores started the summer goods season, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading residents buying offices. Some replenishing of special items was noted.

Except for Phil Rizzuto's longrange and game-winning clouting, the fielders were ahead of the hitters yesterday at the Stadium, where the Yankees, behind Ed Lopat, blanked the Senators, 4--0. Lopat, completing twenty consecutive scoreless innings, did not mind that his work was dwarfed by Rizzuto's.

Thirty-one large companies have adopted definite policies on compensation of first-line supervisors for overtime work. This was reported last week by Gordon Thayer, director, personnel management bureau of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

CHARLES W. THAYER, a career diplomat in the service of his country and the State Department for the last seventeen years, has never allowed diplomacy to interfere with his "serious relaxation." The evidence is plain for all to see in his "Bears in the Caviar," a brash and highly diverting book of reminiscences, which, if it isn't exactly about bears in caviar, is about seals in the ballroom and other diplomatic crises.

Mildred Hill, soprano, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. A Marian Anderson Scholarship Award winner, born and trained in Philadelphia, the vocalist was heard in a program containing arias by Handel and Mozart, a Brahms group, the Bell Song from Delibes' "Lakme," Milhaud's "Chansons de Ronsard" and a group consisting of Negro spirituals and other songs in English.

The Goldman Band will open its thirty-fourth season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts in Central Park, Manhattan, and Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Edwin Franko Goldman and his son, Richard, will conduct the fifty concerts, the first of which is scheduled for June 15 on the Mall, Central Park.

CLEVELAND, April 29--Synthesis of a new substance that, when mixed with human blood serum, has revealed the presence of cancer with an accuracy of more than 98 per cent in a large number of cases was reported here today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research, Inc.

The many exhibitions opening in New York galleries this week include sculpture and drawings from 1915 to the present, by Jacques Lipchitz, to be shown at the Buchholz Gallery, beginning tomorrow. Today's openings include one-man shows of paintings by Matta at the Hugo Gallery, ...

With the closing of the Willis Avenue bridge set for tomorrow the Department of Traffic has established alternate routes to enable motorists from Manhattan to cross to the Bronx with a minimum of congestion.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP)-- Recent revelations that men with deformed feet and backs had been inducted into the Army have drawn a sharp edict from the Army Surgeon General's office, it was disclosed today.

ZAGORSK, U.S.S.R., April 29-- The iron bells of Troitski Monastery pealed out early today the eternal tidings of Christ's resurrection to thousands of believers assembled on these sacred grounds for Orthodox Easter services.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 29 (AP)--Eleven bodies were brought out today from a muddy stubble field where a United Air Lines plane crashed and exploded last night in a violent thunderstorm.
The New York City Board of Education has moved to support a decision by the New Jersey Supreme Court upholding the constitutionality of the reading of Bible verses in school assemblies in New Jersey.

Joseph Kadans, director of the International Institute of Port Regulations at Port Huron, Mich" announced yesterday that the institute had gathered a large amount of technical material on ports over the world and was ready to make its resources available to interested persons in all countries.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Monday, April 30--Campaigning against the Schuman plan and other West German Government policies, the Socialists scored heavy gains in an important state election yesterday, although Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic party managed to retain superiority in a traditional stronghold.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) --The Red Sox scored four times in he thirteenth inning of the first game of a scheduled double-header today to send the Athletics down to their tenth straight defeat, 12--8.

VIENNA, April 29--Apparently more shaky than when he was released from a Budapest prison, Robert A. Vogeler had to break off today a statement for a television broadcast after having warned that what had happened to him behind the Iron Curtain "could happen to anybody."

Joseph L. Abrams, department manager of men's sportswear for Macy's New York, has been appointed department manager of stationery and typewriters, effective May 7. He succeeds Stanley M. Berman, who has resigned.

BOSTON, April 29 (AP)--The Braves dropped back into a triple National League first-place tie with Brooklyn and St. Louis today by dividing a double-header with the Phils. Though held to two hits, the Tribesmen won the opener, 1-0, but were overhauled for a 10-9 setback in the nightcap.

DETROIT, April 29 (AP)--Ken Holcombe of the White Sox made his first appearance of the season today and shut out the Tigers, 4 to 0. A crowd of 21,301 watched the 32-year-old right-hander allow only five hits.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 129--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today declared that business conterns trading illegally with Iron Curtain countries would be deprived of necessary raw materials. He also asserted that the West German Federal Republic was ready to take, with the West, any measures that might lead to the end of all Western trade with Communist China.

From the angle of presentation, a showing yesterday in the ballroom of the Pierre Hotel was unusual. It combined the efforts of an interior decorator, James L.G. Mitton, and of a dress designer, Murray Nieman. The dress fashions were shown against projected backgrounds of rooms done in full color.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 30--Soviet bloc efforts to get a United Nations airing for a new "peace" declaration condemning "warmongering" and military preparations by the Western allies were rejected today at the opening meeting of the Commission on the Status of Women.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., April 30--Such reputed underworld leaders as Frank Costello, Joseph (Joe Adonis) Doto and Meyer (Socks) Lansky may be called to this small upstate village to testify before the grand jury that will investigate gambling and political corruption in Saratoga County.
THE big mackerel run is now under way, and boats from Brielle to Freeport are returning with large catches of these fish, which made their appearance about two weeks ahead of their normal schedule.

Public support for the basic principles of rezoning New York as proposed by Harrison, Ballard Allen, planning consultants, was urged yesterday by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

Householders by the thousands besieged internal revenue offices in the metropolitan area yesterday, the last day for filing the quarterly tax return for domestics under the extension of the Social Security law that went into effect Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)-- The Government announced today that it will permit the export of 200,000 additional bales of cotton during the marketing year ending July 31.

Sears, Roebuck Co. expects in its current fiscal year to equal the record $318,000,000 operating profit of the fiscal year ended last January, but heavier taxes will cut earnings to about $5 from the $6.08 a share earned last year.

Soviet-annexed Estonia has undergone a major purge that has removed large numbers of "bourgeois nationalists" from leading posts in the area's political, economic and cultural life. Within the smaller framework of Estonian life the purge was relatively as great as the similar events that racked the Soviet Union itself in 1936-38.

LONDON, April 30--Another shortage of raw materials has hit Britain. For the first time since the war steel production in this country will fall instead of rising this year, George Strauss, Minister of Supply, said today. Some steel furnaces already have been closed or damped down.

PARIS, April 30--By a vote of 339 to 251, the National Assembly approved tonight, on its first reading, a slightly altered version of the bill to reform France's electoral system. The much-contested bill now will go before the advisory Council of the Republic and then for a second reading, in the Assembly, where it is assured of final passage.
An optimistic picture of trade between the United States and South America was presented here yesterday by Robert C. Lee, executive vice-president of the MooreMcCormack Lines.
Margaret Stern's recital debut in Town Hall last night was a spirited event. Not only was she a pianist of talent and temperament but she presented an appealing stage personality.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were unchanged to 25 points lower.

Saint Subber and Lemuel Ayers, producers of "Out of This World," have decided to advance the show's closing date from May 19 to Saturday. The Cole Porter musical, for which Dwight Taylor and Reginald Lawrence wrote the book, will retire from the Century Theatre after having been seen 157 times.

CHICAGO, April 30--If American industry would make effective use of modern materials handling devices much waste in money and manpower could be eliminated, representatives of two large producers of this type of equipment said today. Their comments were given in interviews at the Fourth Materials Handling Exposition and Conference in the International Amphitheater.

"You can't miss it!" These four words have probably produced more errant wanderings, more jangled nerves and more fruitless abuse of shoe leather than the proud paradings of all the conquering armies since the first tick-tocks of recorded time.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 30--The United States and British Governments are nearing agreement to underwrite the annual balance of payments deficits of Yugoslavia in order to enable the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to grant the Yugoslav Government long-term capital investment loans totaling $200,000,000.

An odd salvage case involving a ship that broke in two in March, 1946, has been ended in United States District Court with a ruling by Judge William Bondy that maritime lawyers believe is without parallel in sea law.

Miss Dorothy Anne Driscoll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Driscoll of Kew Gardens, Queens, has completed plans for her marriage to Carlo D. Cella Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cella of Ridgewood, N.J., on June 9 in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs in Forest Hills, Queens. There will be a reception here at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A drive to obtain support for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican nomination for President next year has been started here by Arthur J. Goldsmith, a wealthy business man who in 1948 headed the Harold E. Stassen supporters in this city.

LONDON, April 30--The British Industries Fair, at which this nation annually displays to the world the accumulated range of its craftsmanship and industrial design, went on display today at Earls Court and Olympia here and at Castle Bromwich in Birmingham.
Former Police Inspector Frederick A. Hofsaes appeared yesterday for the fourth time before the rackets grand jury in Brooklyn.
Leonard P. Brauman will become a general partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Voorhis Co. today. He has been in charge of the research department.

Young women headed by the Misses Mary Agnes Reilly and Anne Murray, as co-chairmen, and including Miss Patricia Kane are aiding in the plans for the annual tea dance to be given on May 15 in the St. Regis Roof under the auspices of the alumnae of four Sacred Heart Convents: Manhattanville College, Maplehurst, Ninety-first Street and Noroton, Conn.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 30 --Brilliant two-hit pitching by Ted Griesinger featured Army's 11-1 victory over New York University at Doubleday Field today. The big right-hander struck out five and walked three, but was deprived of a shut-out in the fourth frame when Charlie Irace of the Violets led off with a triple and scored on a fly to left by Mike DiAngelis. Griesinger set the side down in order in all but three innings.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 30--By a unanimous vote the Iranian Senate tonight enacted into law the oil nationalization bill providing for the expropriation of all assets of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company in Iran, retroactive to March 20.

WASHINGTON, April 30--Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, declared today that the Soviet Union now had air as well as land superiority over the United States. He proposed immediate establishment of a 150-wing Air Force.
Charles A. Wolf has been appointed sales manager of the Eclipse-Pioneer division of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, Teterboro, N.J. He formerly was chief sales engineer for the division.

Net earnings of the United States Rubber Company for the quarter ended on March 31, last, increased to $9,076,755 from $3,927,375 for the first quarter of 1950, although taxes were up $20,256,692, according to the report issued yesterday.

June is a month of many special occasions which require very special fashions--all in white. It is a month for young brides and graduates. Whether it be a first graduation for a youngster or her final one before entering college, her choice of dress can be as individual and discriminating as it would be if she were selecting a party frock.
LONDON, April 30--Despite labor disputes that lowered production in some shipyards by as much as 50 per cent, Britain continued her world leadership in shipbuilding in the first three months of 1951.

CHICAGO, April 30--Heavy deliveries of wheat, corn and oats on May contracts unsettled the grain markets today, overshadowing the sensationally bad crop news. The estimated deliveries were 1,455,000 bushels of wheat, 3,160,000 of corn and 1,485,000 of oats.

MONTREAL, April 30 (AP)-- Leonard (Red) Kelly, Detroit's versatile hockey star, today was named winner of the National Hockey League's Lady Byng Memorial Trophy. He became the second defenseman in twenty-seven years to win one of the sport's most prized awards.

The opening of bids at 11 o'clock this morning on a new issue of $40,000,000 of bonds of Consolidated Edison Company will likely blaze some more of the bond market's uncharted way back to an unmanaged basis.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 30--Decorators from twenty-two states attending the twentieth anniversary conference of the American Institute of Decorators here have found this a good opportunity to review the progress made by their organization in the last two decades.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The Senate debated for three hours today the bill to import Mexican labor, but a vote again was delayed, this time by discussion of whether committee hearings on foreign policy later this week should be open or closed.

LOS ANGELES, April 30--Answering "misrepresentations and false statements" he said were being made about United States foreign policy, W. Averell Harriman, special assistant to President Truman, declared here tonight that the President and all his advisers rejected any idea of appeasement of the Chinese Communists.
BOURNEMOUTH, Eng., April 30 (AP)--Three of America's touring women players scored easy first-round victories in the British hard courts tennis championships today.

LOUISVILLE, April 30--The last warm-up for Saturday's $100,000 Kentucky Derby is to be run tomorrow at Churchill Downs. It is the $10,000 added Derby Trial, over the one-mile course. The point to remember about the Trial is that it is strictly a warm-up; the performances in it rarely provide a true line on the big-money number four days later.

President Truman submitted to Congress yesterday a detailed military defense budget calling for more than sixty-two billion dollars for our armed forces for the next fiscal year. Because this budget includes previous authorizations and does not include atomic bomb expenditures or special accounts, the total in new authorizations is put at $60,679,414,690.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The role of political orator in uniform, which General Bradley was assuming when, on April 17, he advocated the Administration's Far East policy vis-a-vis General MacArthur's, has been a gradual development, but accelerated since the Administration was put publicly on the defensive with respect to Pacific affairs.

Emphasis by proponents of "natural childbirth" on the idea that any "normal" woman can be delivered successfully by the method is a "condemnable act that attempts to stigmatize all those who fail to participate," according to Dr. Arthur J. Mandy, director of the obstetrical and gynecological psychosomatic clinic of Sinai Hospital, Baltimore. Adapted to the needs of individual patients, however, the method can be "a useful obstetrical adjunct," he said.
A Point Four grant of $624,000 to finance a two-year training program at the American University of Beirut in Lebanon was made public here yesterday.

HANOI, Indo-China, April 30-- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's criticisms of the French Army in Indo-China, as revealed in THE NEW YORK TIMES report on the Truman-MacArthur conversations at Wake Island, have caused pained surprise and resentment in French quarters here.

WASHINGTON, April 30--Former President Herbert Hoover urged Congress today to abolish the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which he helped create in 1932, because it was undermining popular respect for government.

The National Broadcasting Company is planning a reduction of its network radio time charges to meet a similar competitive move announced last week by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The latter chain, the first among the four major radio networks to announce a cut, had said its reduction of 10 to 15 per cent would become effective on July 1.

Emerson Radio Phonograph Corporation will reduce prices $15 to $145 today on all its television receivers. In announcing the cuts yesterday, Benjamin Abrams, president, emphasized that they would remain in effect for sixty days only.

Sugar prices continued to inch upward yesterday although commodities generally showed traces of easiness. The No. 4 world contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange rose 2 to 14 points on deals of 11,050 tons.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 1--United Nations forces tightened their defense lines around the Korean capital at Seoul yesterday, awaiting an offensive on May Day, traditional international Communist holiday.

The Tanglewood Alumni Chorus, a group of nineteen women and eleven men who at one time or other have studied at the Berkshire Music Center, gave a program last night at Times Hall that was billed as its "First Annual Spring Concert." The chorus was led by its organizer, Margaret Hillis, a former student of Robert Shaw.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower court decision that the Lorain, Ohio, Journal violated Federal anti-trust laws when it refused space to advertisers who also patronized a local radio station. District Judge Emerich B. Freed of Cleveland upheld last November the charge of the Justice Department that the newspaper was guilty of illegal monopolistic practice.

The $4,000,000 damage suit brought by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation against Otis Co., Cleveland investment banking firm, for failure to go through with a stock underwriting contract entered its fifth week in Federal Court here yesterday. Attorneys argued over how much the automobile concern spent for advertising in 1947.

CAIRO, Ill., April 30 (UP)--The Cliffs Victory, reputedly the longest craft to make the Mississippi-Illinois River trip from New Orleans to the Great Lakes, moved slowly upstream today toward a problem in mathematics.

The sale of Christmas seals in 1950 set a new record at the same time that the tuberculosis death rate dropped 25 per cent from 1949, according to reports yesterday at the annual spring conference of the State Charities Aid Association. The organization, celebrating its seventy-ninth year, is concerned with health activities in the state outside this city.

CLEVELAND, April 30 (UP)-- Lou Brissie was traded to the Indians today and Gus Zernial went to the Athletics in the year's biggest baseball deal, which involved three clubs and a total of seven players.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)-- Following is the text of President Truman's letter to Speaker Sam Rayburn today submitting the Administration's $60,679,414,690 military budget for the fiscal year starting July 1.
WASHINGTON, April 30--The Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., today deferred for thirty days a strike of 50,000 shipyard workers. The walkout had been set for this Thursday.

The 1951 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, 11 West Forty-second Street, now getting under way in behalf of virtually all voluntary health, welfare, family and hospital agencies in the city, this year presents a challenge to all New Yorkers. Out of the $45,000,000 sought by the Fund for its 423 agencies, business is asked for $9,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, April 30-- Samuel Goldwyn has revived his plan to film "Mackintosh," a story by W. Somerset Maugham which he acquired more than a decade ago, and has announced that he will produce it under the title, "South of Samoa," with Farley Granger and Joan Evans as the stars.

The current Communist offensive in Korea is doomed to failure and "it is my personal opinion we will have peace there in a couple of months," Donald Kingsley, director general of the International Refugee Organization, said yesterday.

Spurred by the fact that last Friday's carbon monoxide death from a gas refrigerator was the eighteenth recorded here since Christmas, 1949, a specially trained corps of fifty Health Department inspectors yesterday began covering a "critical area" in Manhattan for faulty household gas-burning appliances of all kinds.

Herbert Hoover added his own vigorous arguments yesterday to those of such veteran banking authorities as Jesse Jones and Marriner S. Eccles in advocating the liquidation of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

VIENNA, April 30--Robert A. Vogeler, vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, who was freed Saturday morning by the Hungarian Government after seventeen months of solitary confinement, left Vienna at 3:12 this afternoon with his wife, sister-in-law and his two sons, en route to New York.

WASHINGTON, April 30--President Truman urgently asked Congress today to grant a defense fund of $60,679,414,690. By such a military expenditure, he said, the United States, acting in concert with other free nations, might be able to stave off "another and more frightful global war."

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 30--The prospect of a Government majority of four in the Senate emerged today in the still incomplete count of votes in Saturday's elections for a new Australian Parliament. That outcome would break the deadlock between the two houses that had blocked the Government's program in the last Parliament.

MURFREESBORO, Tenn., April 30--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur took a back seat today while this little Southern town poured out its warmest welcome for its favorite daughter, Mrs. Jean Marie Faircloth MacArthur.

On the basis of weight, white potatoes, now a fraction less than a nickel a pound, are less expensive than any other food available. This tip to shoppers comes from the New York Metropolitan Area office of the State Extension Food Marketing Program, which adds further arguments on the practicality of the lowly spud.

BUFFALO, April 30 (AP)--The president-elect of the Medical Society of the State of New York today urged the group to work toward making physicians available for emergencies in every part of the state.
By The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The world situation "could explode at any time" into an all-out war and therefore this country "must make every day count" in its program for building up its defenses, William H. Harrison, head of the Defense Production Administration, told a news gathering today.

MUNICH, Germany, April 30-- A carefully planned offensive in the "cold war" for the minds of the men behind the Iron Curtain will be launched tomorrow here --and in Prague--with the dedication of Radio Free Europe's powerful new medium-wave transmitter assigned exclusively to programs for Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, April 30--Two important decisions concerning President Truman's loyalty program were announced by the Supreme Court today. Robert H. Jackson so entirely inconsistent that he said: "This is justice turned bottom-side up." The decisions were as follows:

ONE day in St. Petersburg two months ago Leo Durocher this doing the talking, a not unusual relaxation of his. The Dandy Little Manager was brimful of confidence as he spoke in an it-can't-happen-to-us-again fashion.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The combined Senate Armed Services and Foreign Relations Committees voted fourteen to nine today to begin in closed sessions their forthcoming investigation of the dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from his Far East commands.

Heliowise, the 3-year-old chestnut gelding that campaigned with considerable success in allowance races in Florida last season indicated he can do pretty well in that type of company hereabouts when he dashed to his second straight local success yesterday.

ALBANY, April 30 (AP)--The Attorney General, Nathaniel L. Goldstein, said today that the state could not compromise a $6,550,000 debt owed by the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road for grade-crossing projects. The obligation represents the Island carrier's share of the cost of grade-crossing projects undertaken before Jan. 1, 1939.

The taxpayer building at 147-20 Jamaica Avenue and 92-12 147th Place in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by Stanley W. Kempner to Jack Liechtung, who insured title with the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company. Brener Lewis, Inc., was the broker.
Plans for a six-story apartment house at 1376-1378 Lexington Avenue were disclosed yesterday in connection with the announcement of the sale of the property by the Guaranty Trust Company.

Frank J. Quayle, former Fire Commissioner, will be a witness in the near future before one of three New York County grand juries investigating the Fire Department, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The State Department said today that Harold B. Hoskins, a specialist on the Near East, would soon make a tour of East Mediterranean countries to help co-ordinate United States planning in that area.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 1 (AP)-- Eighth Army Communique 340 issued at 10:30 A.M., Tuesday (9:30 P.M., Eastern daylight time, Monday):

WASHINGTON, April 30--The Senate subcommittee investigating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was left guessing again tonight as to whether Donald S. Dawson, an administrative assistant to President Truman, would testify concerning charges that he apparently had influenced certain R.F.C. directors on loan matters and had accepted favors from a "luxury hotel," a client of the corporation.

LONDON, April 30--D sir e Ellinger, who played the lead in "Rose Marie" in New York in 1925, died at her London home today. Her age was 57. She had sung operatic roles under Sir Thomas Beecham's direction and appeared with Mme. Melba on one occasion.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The Securities and Exchange Commission received today an application for registration of $10,468,000 of debentures of Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. The debentures will be marketed in series maturing from May 1, 1965 to May 1, 1981.

Two trim gray warships of the Israeli Navy--a 1,500-ton frigate and a 1,000-ton corvette--steamed into American waters for the first time yesterday morning on a training cruise and goodwill visit to cities along the Eastern coast.

With construction work more than one month ahead of schedule, occupancy now is expected by Aug. 1 for the seventeenth-story and penthouse apartment building at 750 Park Avenue. The luxury style building will contain seventytwo apartments and three medical offices.

In the month just ended steel production in this country reached a new record high of close to 9,000,000 tons. Few more significant events occurred during the past thirty days. Steel is the foundation metal of our economy, the basic raw material for automobiles, railroad locomotives, refrigerators and a host of other peacetime products, as well as the essential required to produce tanks and guns.

Raymond L. Chambrey of Toledo, Ohio, has announced here the engagement and approaching marriage of his sister, Miss Marguerite H. Chambrey of Bridgeport, Conn., to John J. Fitzgerald Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fitzgerald of Madison, N.J. The wedding will take place on June 9 in St. Vincent's Roman Catholic Church, Madison.
The Protestant churches of New York were called upon yesterday to divest themselves of their "parish provincialism" in favor of a cooperative city-wide program of civic improvement.

Twelve former players who starred on basketball teams of City College, Long Island University and New York University were indicted yesterday on bribery charges along with the so-called master fixer, Salvatore T. Sollazzo.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)-- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath today strongly recommended central planning in the Government's defense purchasing and contracting. In a report to the White House and Congress, the Attorney General said a survey of production procurement had disclosed a failure to make adequate use of all the nation's business and industrial resources in the military build-up.

WASHINGTON, April 30--Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, demanded today a more aggressive attitude toward Communist China to wind up the Korean war, but Secretary of State Dean Acheson insisted the policy of keeping the conflict from spreading must be pursued.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 30-- A Brussels court declared valid today the attachment of $7,000,000 of Marshall aid by a Belgian private company.

The State of Massachusetts announced yesterday that it would receive bids on May 14 on bond issues totaling $25,500,000. Dated Feb. 1, March 1, May 1 and June 1, 1951, the bonds will come due from 1952 to 1981.

The Joint Defense Appeal of the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith observed its tenth anniversary last night with a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. One thousand business and communal leaders attended.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)-- The House adjourned today out of respect to Representative Frank Buchanan, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who died on Friday in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital at the age of 48.
Volunteer bond salesmen will attempt to raise $500,000,000 for the State of Israel by means of a neighborhood canvassing campaign to get under way today here and in other cities.
BOWIE, Md., April 30 (AP)--H. W. Shaffer's Oom Paul raced to a convincing victory in the featured Seabrook Purse here today. The 5-year-old son of Teufel went the six furlongs in 1:12 3-5.

Since the cleanliness of our city is largely a matter of self-discipline, this would be an excellent time to take hold of ourselves. The period from now until May 13 has been proclaimed by the Mayor as "Spring Clean-Up Weeks."

The Board of Higher Education yesterday prohibited City College and other municipal colleges from playing basketball games at Madison Square Garden, where contests allegedly were "fixed" by big-time gamblers. The teams were barred also from all other commercially operated sports arenas.
SAN JUAN, P.R., April 30-- Chief Justice Angel De Jesus of the Puerto Rican Supreme Court died at noon today at the age of 60.

CHICAGO, April 30 (UP)--The father of a young Army recruit declared today he had removed his son from an Army camp without permission because the youth had not received medical treatment although the family doctor had said he had peritonitis.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)-- The House Public Works Committee wound up today a long hearing in legislation to authorize construction of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project.

Seeking to end twenty years of "illegal practices" in apparel deliveries, the Government filed yesterday in Federal Court civil antitrust suits against five truckowner associations serving the garment center.

An increase of $5,070,404 in earnings for the March quarter this year over the corresponding three months of 1950 is reported by the Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries, despite tax charges that were $9,450,000 larger.

PARIS, April 30--Experts in both North America and Europe are concerned about the morass of difficulties in adjusting the intricate buying and manufacturing systems of the democratic world to speed up and amplify defense production.

LONDON, April 30--Some light selling, mainly accounted for by the end of the bookkeeping account, took the edge off some industrial share prices here today. Losses were modest and the market closed fairly firm.

THE Devil drives a notoriously hard bargain. In the present century few people think it worth their while to deal with him. But in 1925 a Cambridge history professor of 58 sold the Devil his soul (but with a concealed string attached to it). Nicholas Fenton knew more about seventeenth-century English history than any man alive, but he was insatiably curious to know...

GREAT NECK, April 30--Al Brosch, the Cherry Valley pro who accounted for a record P.G.A. round of 60 during the winter campaign, marked his return to Long Island tournament play with a 68 today at the Fresh Meadow Country Club.

HARRISON, N.Y., April 30-- Of the 1,788 persons registered in Union Free School District 6 here to vote on the school budget tomorrow and candidates for school trustee on Wednesday, 20 per cent are not legally qualified, the Honest Ballot Association of New York charged today. The accusations were denied.

Among the most privileged of the 10,025 adults registered in New York University's mammoth division of general education are twelve beginners in the newest non-credit project--the division's first sculpture course.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in April was the smallest since February, 1950, and was less than that in April last year. Sales were above the million-share mark in every full day's session, as they have been since October, 1949.
Mrs. Mitchell Davis Follansbee of Chicago has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Julie, to Charles Pratt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pratt of 46 East Sixtyfifth Street and Glen Cove, L.I.

NEW DELHI, India, April 30-- The extremist Hindu and Moslem communal organizations in India and Pakistan have taken decisions during the last week to fight for the reunification of the subcontinent and bring it under the rule of their respective organizations.

CLEVELAND, April 30--Studies at Harvard University that have led to the discovery of a fundamental mechanism in growth and development and promise a new rational approach to the chemical treatment of cancer were reported here tonight at the opening of the annual meeting of the American Societies for Experimental Biology.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., April 30-- The engagement of Miss Fay Ethel Willey to David Alexander Barron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Barron of Goshen, has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Gordon Fay Willey of Maple Knoll.

The 162d anniversary of George Washington's inaugural was celebrated yesterday in ceremonies here. At the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street, the Bible on which the first President was sworn in was displayed.

ON THE KOREAN FRONT, April 30--All villages and sheltered terrain north and east of Seoul used as grouping points for Chinese Communist divisions were shelled relentlessly today by United Nations artillery.
WASHINGTON, April 30--Labor voted today to return representatives to all defense agencies, which it boycotted on Feb. 16.
New securities offered publicly here in April totaled less than in March, but bond flotations were sharptly higher and stock offerings lower than in April 1, 1950.

A newly formed nation-wide narcotic syndicate that boasted it had a five-year supply of heroin was believed to have been broken up by Federal narcotics agents with the arrest of five alleged members, United States Attorney Irving H. Saypol announced yesterday. The supply was not found.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP)-- The House Ways and Means Committee today voted tentatively for the collection of Federal income taxes on dividends and interest payments through a withholding system similar to that already in force on individual incomes.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 30-- Evidence that the anemias frequently observed in late stages of some types of human cancer are not merely side effects of the pervading cancerous growths was presented here today at the forty-third annual meeting of the American Society for Clinical Investigation.

The stock market exhibited little ability yesterday to further last week's advance. Prices moved in a narrow range the greater part of the session, then sagged under a late flurry of sales. Brokers were not too concerned over the pause in the upward movement in view of the course of the fighting in Korea and the interlude which usually develops after any spirited rise.

Filing of pricing charts and related data by retailers subject to Ceiling Price Regulation 7 has picked up considerably in this area, the regional Office of Price Stabilization, 2 Park Avenue, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP)-- The Authors' League of America voiced regret today that Congress did not foresee radio, television and long-playing records when it drafted the copyright laws in 1909.

PARIS, April 30--Charles E. Wilson, United States Director of Defense Mobilization, said today he hoped the Europeans would speed up their defense programs by adopting blueprints and time tables as the United States had done. He compared the present progress of European rearmament to that of the United States "in its early stages."
MILWAUKEE, April 30 (AP)-- Irish Bob Murphy, liberal with his powerful left uppercut, punished Cecil Hudson of Milwaukee for four rounds tonight, then knocked him out in the fifth.
LONDON, April 30 (AP)--The British Film Institute today demstrated three technical developments that it believes may revolutionize the motion-picture theatre.
Although it has far fewer investigators than are needed for enforcement of the new meat price ceilings, the Office of Price Stabilization does not expect any largescale black marketing.

On record gross income last year of $76,362,665, which was 69 per cent more than the 1949 total of $45,267,089, Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., more than doubled its earnings, which were the highest in its history, according to the report of Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, president, to be mailed to stockholders today.
PARIS, April 30--Exotic designs introduce dark rich colors to Manguin's cotton beachwear, resort evening gowns, and to linen coats as well.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., April 30--A tie involving the team of Phil Turnesa and Fred Lux and the duo of Pat Circelli and Harry Dee marked the pro-pro tournament which inaugurated the new campaign for the Westchester chapter of the Professional Golfers' Association at Ardsley Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)-- the Senate Appropriations Committee today concurred with the House in making a 90 per cent slash in the fund that was asked by the State Department for operation of its Voice of America program for foreign lands.

FRESNO, Calif., April 30 (AP)-- Making a spectacular recovery on the incoming nine after having apparently blown her chances going out, Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio retained her lead today in the $3,000 Valley women's 54hole golf tournament. She compiled a two-day total of 150.

WASHINGTON, April 30--Representative Walter E. Brehm, Republican of Ohio, was found guilty in Federal court tonight of illegally accepting campaign contributions from a woman clerk in his office here.
Tightening of purse strings by retail management is curtailing the placing of orders for boys' wear at the boys' industry market week in the New Yorker Hotel.
TRENTON, April 30--The State Assembly voted $15,000 today to Clifford T. Shepard of East Orange, for loss of reputation, prestige and earnings through mistaken conviction of forgery.

THE all-around angling picture is getting brighter each day, and yesterday brought reports of the first good dry fly fishing, good spring salmon fishing and the first big catches of pollock off Montauk Point.

Counsel for Otis Co., Cleveland investment house, pressed further in Federal Court yesterday the defense contention in the $4,000,000 damage suit brought by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation that the automobile company's 1948 prospectus was false and mis leading.

CLEVELAND, May 1--A simple salt and water solution taken by mouth will save the lives of tens of thousands of persons in the emergency treatment of mass casualties in the event of an atomic attack against our cities, according to a report submitted here today at the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

LONDON, May 1--For a year and nearly four months now Britain has been in the embarrassing position of an old settler who has tipped his hat to a newcomer in town and been snubbed--snubbed, insulted and elbowed off the sidewalk.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1--Ralph E. Taggart, head of the Anthracite Operators Wage Committee and president of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, died today of a heart attack at his home in near-by Radnor. He was 64 years old.

Reporting on operations of the Kennecott Copper Corporation at yesterday's annual stockholder meeting, Charles R. Cox, president, estimated the consolidated net income for the first quarter at $25,200,000. Equal to $2.33 a share, it compares with an estimated $1.54 a share earned in the similar three months of last year.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Wednesday, May 2---- The Chinese Communists pulled back from Seoul yesterday, their spring offensive shot to pieces by massed artillery fire from land and sea and by the Allied Air Force which flew record numbers of missions to smash the advancing enemy columns.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an average increase of 4 per cent in April, compared with the corresponding month of last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1-- George G. Wilson, professor emeritus of international law at Harvard, died last night at the age of 88. He had retired in 1936.

While the principle of price rollback as reflected in recent Office of Price Stabilization orders is highly commendable, consumers want lower prices now, Henry Modell, president of Henry Modell Co., Inc., asserted yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 1-Brazil would vote in favor of the imposition of economic sanctions against Communist China by the United Nations General Assembly, Foreign Minister Joao Neves da Fontoura said today.

A three-power "declaration of peace" with West Germany, by which the United States, Britain and France would in a sense bypass repeated deadlocks with the Soviet Union on a German peace treaty, was described as near yesterday by Heinz L. Krekeler, German Consul General.
ST. PAUL, May 1 (AP)--C.W. Rardin of Grand Forks, N.D., turned in the outstanding individual performances today at the American Bowling Congress tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Kefauver Committee, in its report today, devoted thirty-five printed pages to telling the detailed story of what it found in New York City. The conclusions were listed by the committee as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP)-- Government attorneys said today that membership in three organizations, tagged as subversive by the Attorney General, would continue to carry weight in Federal employes' loyalty investigations.

The greatest air effort of the Korean War by Far East Air Forces and attached planes yesterday smashed a determined and largescale Communist supply build-up with a record, 1,277 sorties, flown in good weather. Previous high was 1,254 individual flights made March 23.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 (AP)-- President Juan Peron made a personal plea today to the American republics to back Argentina in her long-standing dispute with Britain over the Falkland Islands and the Antarctic territory.

The ancient spring festival of May Day was again perverted yesterday by international communism to proclaim a doctrine that has become synonymous with militarism and imperialism, with aggression, enslavement and spiritual and physical death.

WASHINGTON, May 1-The charge that local politicians profited from "open gambling" in existence "for many years" in Saratoga County with their knowledge is made in the Senate... Crime Investigating Committee's report for that area.

The overworked and much abused word "appeasement" is being stretched to new lengths by some critics of the Administration's policy in Korea. If we do not immediately bomb troop concentration points in Manchuria, it is "appeasement."

The failure of 90 per cent of the restaurants and drinking places in the metropolitan area to file cost and sales information in compliance with ceiling price regulations resulted yesterday in an intensive law-enforcement drive by the local division of the Office of Price Stabilization.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of department stores, attained in the fiscal year ended last February the largest sales and earnings in its history, according to the annual report of Fred Lazarus Jr., president, issued to stockholders today.

The bar of the men's cafe in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel has been purchased by Amon G. Carter, Fort Worth, Tex., newspaper publisher, and is on its way to Shady Oak Farm, the home of Mr. Carter's son, Amon G. Carter Jr., near Fort Worth. The senior
On Alvin Dark's bases-filled home run in the sixth inning, the Giants broke another losing streak last night.

The opening of Radio Free Europe's new, powerful transmitter in Munich yesterday was good news. Beamed at Czechoslovakia, particularly Prague, the new station will broadcast from morning to night, transmitting news, music and other material in competition with the Prague radio and, of course, presenting a sharply different point of view.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1-- Capt. Barton E. Bacon Jr., commander of the Navy hospital ship Benevolence when it sank in a collision outside the Golden Gate on Aug. 25 with the loss of twentythree lives, pleaded innocent today to charges against him as his court-martial opened here.

The Greater New York Fund began its fourteenth annual campaign last night to raise $9,000,000 for 423 voluntary health, welfare, family and hospital organizations, which annually provide services for 3,000,000 New Yorkers.

TOKYO, May 1 (UP)--Dr. Takashi Nagai, a Japanese scientistmartyr who spent nearly six years experiencing the slow ebb of life after he survived the Nagaski atomic bomb blast, died tonight of leukemia. He was 43 years old.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman declared here yesterday that the views of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur on Far Eastern affairs, if upheld by our Government, might well lead to World War III.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 1 --The rapid expansion of governmental research activities is drawing scientists away from industrial laboratories, a report of the Southern Association of Science and Industry said today.

CAIRO, May 1--King Farouk distributed today the first social security books to begin operation of the first nation-wide, concrete social security system in the Near East or in any oriental country, United States Point Four aid has been called in by the Egyptian Government to help put the social security system in operation under legislation passed last year.

DETROIT, May 1--A $100,000 suit for damages, based largely on testimony made public by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, was filed here today by Kenneth Morris, president of Briggs Local 212 of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O.
The stock market returned yesterday to the rallying side with a considerable rebound in prices which lifted the composite rate by 0.63 point.

Asserting that Government officials felt there was imminent danger of an atomic attack, Col. Lawrence Wilkinson and Leonard Dreyfuss, civil defense directors for New Yerk and New Jersey, criticized the Federal Defense and State Departments yesterday for not assisting state defense organizations.

A fifteen-hit attack that included Ralph Kiner's third home run of the season carried the Pirates to a 6-2 victory over the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday. Pittsburgh, which defeated the Brooks only three times last year, scored all its runs in the first five innings.
The Israel Independence Bond Issue of $500,000,000, the largest foreign offering of its kind ever made in the United States, was placed on sale yesterday in more than 100 cities.

With E. Roland Harriman, president of the Ameircan Red Cross, officiating, the Greater New York Red Cross Blood Program formally opened yesterday a new central headquarters at 214 East Twenty-first Street that will enable it to...

Thousands of tulips in glowing colors, flown here from the Netherlands for the occasion by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, transformed the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria into a huge Dutch flower garden for the entertainment, known as "A Night in Holland," held there last night for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service. Dr. Jan Herman van Royen, Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, and Mrs. van Royen were guests of honor.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1--With a sharp attack on the Coast Guard's security screening program the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, unaffiliated, opened its fiftieth anniversary convention here today.

The City College basketball team, which has been prohibited from appearing in Madison Square Garden where some contests were fixed by big-time gamblers, may play four games next season at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory, it was learned yesterday.
FRESNO, Calif., May 1 (AP)-- Posting a final-round 73, one over men's par, Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias won the $3,000 Valley women's open golf tournament today with a fifty-four-hole total of 225.

BOSTON, May 1 (Ap)--The St. Louis Cardinals broke their firstplace tie with the Boston Braves tonight with a 5-2 victory behind the six-hit pitching of rookie righthander Tommy Poholsky. Stan Musial and big Steve Bilko each hit a homer to ruin Boston's 1951 floodlight inaugural for 15,213 spectators.

LONDON, May 1--Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison disclosed today that Britain had offered to take the Iranian Government into partnership in the operation of the British oil concession in Iran as an alternative to nationalization.
The Cantata Singers gave what one hopes is not their last performance of Bach's "St. John Passion" last night at the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

A pretty Brooklyn high school girl, Mary Company, was crowned Queen of the May yesterday by Mrs. Vincent Impellitteri, wife of the Mayor. The coronation took place on the Cherry Esplanade of the Botanic Garden, Brooklyn, in a setting of pink Kwanzan cherry blossoms.

To escape trial and possible conviction that could lead to a fourteen-year state prison sentence, two recently promoted lieutenants in the Fire Department pleaded guilty yesterday to a conspiracy charge for paying $600 each to procure advancement as disabled veterans.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 1--The United States warned today that the smuggling of heroin was this country's greatest narcotics problem and listed Italy, Greece, Turkey and Communist China as the chief supply centers.

Allegheny County, Pa., sold yesterday $6,190,000 of bonds due from April 15, 1952 to April 15, 1981, to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 101.0199 for interest of 2 per cent.
The question of Mediterranean defense--who shall command it, how far it will extend--has become a matter of great concern and controversy among the members of the Atlantic coalition.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 1-- Nelson F. Stamler, Deputy Attorney General, who has been directing the Bergen County grand jury investigation into gambling and corruption, said today he agreed with the Senate Crime Investigating Committee report "as to the immunity" with which bookmakers operated in his county.
LOUISVILLE, May 1--Yesterday B.A. Jones, Calumet Farm's master trainer and master propagandist, said he didn't know whether he had a Kentucky Derby horse.

Warren R. Austin, head of the United States delegation to the United Nations, last night defended the present policy in Korea as "clear, positive and consistent" and declared that wrangling over it would play into the hands of the Soviet Union.

Pan American World Airways earned $4,064,000 last year on record gross revenues of $153,802,000, Juan T. Trippe, president, reported yesterday. This was equal to 66 cents a capital share and compared with a net profit of $2,489,000 or 40 cents a share in 1949, when revenues aggregated $151,987,000.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1-- Twentieth Century-Fox has suspended Betty Grable from salary for refusing to star in "The Girl Next Door," a comedy scheduled to start July 1.

"Season in the Sun" has received a new lease on life. Instead of closing Saturday night at the Cort as announced, the Wolcott Gibbs comedy will continue there next week. Barring unforeseen developments, the hit is to be transferred on May 14 to the Booth, a move that is expected to have a salutary effect at the box office.

CHICAGO, May 1--A conference held concurrently with the fourth national materials handling exposition was told today that "there has been a complete reversal of attitude on the part of labor toward mechanical handling methods in the past few years."

WITH TASK FORCE 77, off Ko rea, May 1--Eight Navy Skyraiders took off from the aircraft carrier Princeton today with big torpedoes and by army request divebombed them into the flood gates of the Hwachon Dam to try to swell the Pukhan River, which still divides the United Nations troops from the Chinese Communists in eastern Korea.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Automobile manufacturers were ordered today to make allowance in their proces for the fact that they no longer supplied a spare tire and tube with new passenger cars.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The White House announced this evening that Donald S. Dawson, a Presidential administrative assistant, would testify before the Senate subcommittee investigating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation about his involvement in its inquiry into influence and favoritism in the agency's lending operations.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 1 --The growing acceptance by interior decorators of modern designs for the home was accented by the fact that all the designers who received awards here today in the American Institute of Decorators in 1950 Good Design Competition for Home Furnishing work in a decidedly contemporary vein.

The major political problem in Korea is that of carrying out the Moscow Agreement of December 1945 for the formation of a provisional Korean Government to be followed by a four-power trusteeship over Korea.

Present plans for slum clearance and relief of the traffic "maelstrom" in the city were criticized yesterday by State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman because they failed to provide for the reorganization of areas into unified and balanced neighborhoods.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer urged President Truman nearly four years ago to create an Americanled force of South Koreans strong enough "to cope with the threat from the North."

Throughout the city consumers yesterday began paying the newly increased retail sales tax, now applied generally at 3 per cent. From all boroughs it was reported that with few exceptions customers were doing little grumbling or complaining.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches got under way yesterday, with over 800 women competing.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and former President Herbert Hoover conferred for an hour yesterday in the General's tower suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. What they talked about was not disclosed. It was the second known conference between the two.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 1 (UP)--Top-seeded Doris Hart third-seeded Shirley Fry and eighth-ranked Beverly Baker--the only Americans entered in the British hard-court tennis championships--gained the third round in women's singles today without the loss of a set.

British shipyards are so crammed with new construction and have such a backlog of orders that it is doubtful that any one of them could promise delivery on a ship ordered today in less than four years.
BERLIN, May 1--The voice of the free world challenged the Soviet Union and communism in Berlin today as once again freedom overshadowed fear in this great battleground of ideologies.

Robert A. Vogeler came home yesterday, still shaken by his ordeal of Communist trial and seventeen months' imprisonment in Hungary. He said he hoped his experience would "serve as a lesson to keep us on guard against the attacks constantly being made against a really true democracy."
DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, May 1 (AP)--The Arabian American Oil Company celebrated its twelfth birthday today with a good possibility of becoming the biggest producer in the world before the year's end.

The 12 East Forty-fourth Street Corporation sold the eight-story and penthouse building at that address to an investing client of Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, for cash over a first mortgage of $135,000.

Well-known women, including Mme. Roger Seydoux, wife of the French Consul General in New York, and Mrs. John Barry Ryan, are furthering the success of the Paris Birthday Ball to be held Monday night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of French Hospital. They have been holding luncheon meetings recently in the Sert Room of the hotel to advance the plans for the benefit.
The first in a series of food fashion shows to be conducted by the Nassau County Chapter of the American Red Cross was held yesterday in Mineola.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 1-- Eight patients whose adrenal glands were removed at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston late last summer have been maintained for nine months by the injection of man-made substitutes for the complex mixture of the natural adrenal secretions.

LOUISVILLE, May 1--A tourist who whisks down to Kentucky's Bluegrass country for today's Derby Trial and, eventually, Satur day's Run for the Roses, shouldn't let his mind wander away from the horses.

Piet presented a patroon performance to the onlookers at the Jamaica race track yesterday. The 6-year-old campaigner whose Netherlands appellation derives from the first name of his owner, Peter A. Markey, won the six-furlong Apache Handicap against five others in an exciting race that was witnessed by a crowd of 22,799.

As any reader of Gladwin Hill's recent series in this newspaper will know, the illegal entry of cheap agricultural labor from Mexico has created a situation in the Southwest so serious that there is no longer any doubt that "something will have to be done about...

LONDON, May 1--The Labor Government successfully parried in the House of Commons tonight a major Opposition attack on the raw materials issue. Liberal members abstained from taking sides but the Labor party "rebels," Aneurin Bevan, former Labor Minister; Harold Wilson, former President of the Board of Trade, and John Freeman, former Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Supply, voted with the Government and the critical Opposition motion was defeated by 305 votes to 292.

Persistent peace rumors yesterday unsettled commodity markets. They checked a sharp upward movement in sugar, which had climbed abruptly on what was described as "necessitous short covering"; sent wool futures off by the 10-cent level, although these subsequently improved and put pressure on vegetable oils.

The Equity Library Theatre has now completed its eighth season of play production. In the main its aim has been to afford actors the opportunity to showcase their talents before producers and theatrical agents.

A ready means whereby investment bankers can screen proposed financing deals to meet the financial strain of the defense effort was described here yesterday by Percy M. Stewart, chairman of the Eastern Investment Banking Voluntary Restraint Committee.
The Federal Trade Commission is now actively engaged in making compliance surveys for the National Production Authority, John M. Mead, the Trade Commission chairman, said yesterday.
LONDON, May 1--Business broadened as the current bookkeeping account ended on a firm note on the Stock Exchange today.

MUNICH, Germany, May 1-- Predicting that the dictatorship and armies of Premier Stalin would not long endure, Irving Brown, European representative of the American Federation of Labor, issued a May Day appeal today to workers of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

Communists and affiliated May Day paraders carried banners and Left-Wing slogans for four hours yesterday through sporadic applause, salvos of eggs and obscenity and long stretches of apathetic silence.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The report of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, made public today, identified New York City as "one of the major centers of organized crime," headquarters of the Frank Costello-Joe AdonisMeyer Lansky "crime syndicate." At the same time the committee cited the city as one that stood out, in favorable contrast to others, because of the fight being waged against organized crime by District Attorneys Frank S. Hogan and Miles McDonald.

LONDON, May 1--Acting to provide more direct responsibility for the defense of the United Kingdom in the event of war, the Government appointed today three Commander in Chief immediately subordinate to the Chiefs of Staff to coordinate both military and civilian planning against the possibility of an attack.

The appointment of Lloyd Paul Stryker as a Federal District Judge here is regarded as unlikely now, according to informed Washington sources. Mr. Stryker was recommended to the President two months ago by Carmine G. DeSapio. Tammany leader, and Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Alfred C. Coxe.

A complex combination of national pride, human emotions, differing strategic concepts, confusing command relationships and political, geographic and technical problems has postponed indefinitely the establishment of a Mediterranean command, and may force a reconsideration of the Atlantic Ocean command structure.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., May 1 --Women leaders from all parts of the world today gave a go-ahead signal for the United Nations to map a new global treaty to promote the political rights of women.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 1 (AP)-- John Gavegnano's Pensava, a 4year-old black gelded son of Pensive-Stimbala who is trained by Tom J. Barry, won the feature race at Garden State Park today before a crowd of about 15,500 in a sizzling 1:11.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)-- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, told the Senate today that a Cleveland, Ohio, company made a profit of nearly 600 per cent out of renting a plant from one Government agency and leasing it to another one.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)--The Senate defeated, 59 to 12, today an attempt by Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico, to limit the scope of a bill authorizing the United States Government to recruit farm workers in Mexico.
Six weeks have passed since the Senate Crime Investigating Committee closed the hearings in New York which were watched with such fascinated interest.

CAIRO, May 1--Salem ed Din, Egyptian Foreign Minister, closed a fiery debate on British-Egyptian relations in Parliament tonight with the promise that Egypt would be satisfied with nothing less than the British evacuation of the Suez Canal zone and unity with the Sudan.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP)-- Robin Roberts survived a five-hit, five-run eighth inning to chalk up his third victory of the season tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies nosed out the Cincinnati Reds, 6--5.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Two Democratic Senators, one of them pro-Administration, called today for cuts in federal spending, including military outlays, to ease the tax burden and abate inflation.

AMHERST, Mass., May 1--A funeral service for Dr. Stanley King, president emeritus of Amherst College, who died Saturday of a heart attack at his summer home in Martha's Vineyard, was held today here in Johnson Chapel.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)--The Senate Interior Committee turned down today a proposal to give the states clear title to the lands beneath the marginal seas.
