MOSCOW, May 1 (UP)--More than 200 warplanes, including flashing single and two engined jets, thousands of military vehicles and scores of thousands of troops joined in a gigantic May Day parade in Moscow's Red Square today.

KANSAS CITY, May 1--James R. Watson, executive director of the National Civil Service League charged here tonight that New York's Mayor Impellitteri had done nothing to fulfill the promise with which he was swept into office last November.

PARIS, May 1--In a vigorous speech opening the electoral campaign for his party today, Gen. Charles de Gaulle made a political issue of the air bases in France sought by the North Atlantic Treaty nations.

Three buildings containing stores, offices and apartments at 2069 to 2079 Broadway and 200 to 210 West Seventy-second Street, the southwest corner, have been sold by Central Manhattan proporties, Inc., George R. Coughlan, president, to Resnick Zipes, operators. Fronting 115 feet on Broadway and ninety-four feet on the street, the property was refinanced at...
ATLANTIC CITY, May 1--Earl Constantine of New York was reelected president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers at the forty-seventh annual meeting today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 7 to 41 points net lower.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP)-- The Senate Crime Investigating Committee said today it would recommend a bill to ban racing wire services that are devoted primarily to supplying betting information for gamblers and make it possible for organized crime to exist.

In Korea Monday, action was limited to patrol clashes with our reconnaissance elements encountering only scattered hostile groups as they reconnoitered well forward of United Nations lines, Enemy efforts to resupply forward units continued during the night.

Organized criminal gangs operating in interstate commerce are firmly entrenched in our large cities in the operation of many different gambling enterprises such as bookmaking, policy, slot machines, as well as in other rackets such as the sale and distribution of narcotics and commercialized prostitution. They are the survivors of the murderous underworld wars of the prohibition era.
A collection of antique wheel hubs that have been converted into lamp bases are now on view at the Penthouse Gallery, 15 West Fiftyfifth Street.

The report of the New York State Citizens Committee for Children and Youth, originally undertaken as research for last December's Mid-Century White House Conference, is in final draft form, it was learned yesterday. When it will be ready for distribution is not certain, however.
CHICAGO, May 1--Heavy deliveries sparked a selling movement which resulted in sharp declines throughout the grain list.
DETROIT, May 1 (UP)--The Athletics staged an eight-run rally in the eleventh inning to trounce the Tigers, 9 to 1, today and snap a ten-game losing streak.

TOKYO, May 1--Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, in a statement in advance of the third anniversary of the postwar Japanese Constitution, told the Japanese people today the Supreme Allied Command was prepared to modify the occupation directive under which they have lived since the surrender, as far as "past experience and the present situation render necessary and desirable."
Stockholders of the Borne Scrymser Company approved a five-for-one split of its capital stock at a meeting yesterday.

Conditions for the Annapolis race, the longest on the Atlantic seaboard this year, were completed yesterday by the committees of the New York Yacht Club, which will run the test in cooperation with the United States Naval Academy Sailing Squadron and the Annapolis Yacht Club.

The American Guild of Musical Artists has made no decision at this time on the controversy between Robert Merrill, one of its members, and the Metropolitan Opera Association, which has lodged a complaint with the union against the baritone for alleged breach of contract.

TOKYO, May 1--Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, in a statement in advance of the third anniversary of the postwar Japanese Constitution, told the Japanese people today the Supreme Allied Command was prepared to modify the occupation directive under which they have lived since the surrender, as far as "past experience and the present situation render necessary and desirable."
Stockholders of the Borne Scrymser Company approved a five-for-one split of its capital stock at a meeting yesterday.

A plan to bring relief to "our great musical organizations starving in a land of planty" has been proposed by S. Hurok, artists' manager, to the principal symphonic and operatic groups and to the leading record companies.

WHEN John W. Taylor went on his last honeymoon he thought it would be nice to make it a fishing and camping trip. He took with him two wagon loads of provisions, two cows, twenty-four children and four wives. His first and third wife were not present. What his sixth, the bride, thought of it all is not on record; but she could not have been surprised.

The American Guild of Musical Artists has made no decision at this time on the controversy between Robert Merrill, one of its members, and the Metropolitan Opera Association, which has lodged a complaint with the union against the baritone for alleged breach of contract.
The Archbishopric of New York has purchased a plot containing 50,000 square feet of land at Van Cortlandt Park South, Review Place and Putnam Avenue in the Bronx.
A 2-year-old boy tumbled fifteen floors out of an open window at the Alfred Emanuel Smith Housing Project, 20 Catherine Slip, yesterday morning and lived.
Strongly endorsing black and white as a color team, Martin's of Brooklyn launched its season yesterday with a presentation of warm weather designs.
BALTIMORE, May 1 (AP)--The nation's vital copper industry is taking a two way punch, C. Donald Dallas, chairman of the board of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., said today.

The Capella Choir of Concordia Teachers College in River Forest, Ill., paid its first visit to New York last night and sang a program of religious music at Town Hall under the direction of Victor Hildner, who holds the college's chair of music education. The event was sponsored by the Lutheran Teachers of New York.

Gene Tunney of Stamford, Conn., and Arthur G. Waywyn of Toronto, Canada, have been elected directors of Brown Company, according to L.F. Whittemore, president. The new directors were elected under the recapitalization plan which became effective on March 26.
NEW DELHI, India, May 1-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that India, though grateful for help, would not accept food from any country if it had "any political strings attached to it."
Television and motion pictures show the same tendency of catering too much to the juvenile mind, an audience of school teachers was told yesterday.
Leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in New York were accused last night of having "developed a super-government that has become almost as pervasive and powerful as Tammany Hall at its worst."

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)-- The House Public Works Committee voted today to fly over the route of the proposed $818,000,000 St. Lawrence seaway before taking action on the legislation authorizing the project.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee, summing up results of a year's investigation, asserted today that William O'Dwyer, now Ambassador to Mexico, contributed directly and indirectly "to the growth of organized crime, racketeering and gangsterism in New York City."
The Department of Health continued yesterday its check of a "critical area" in Manhattan for faulty household gas-burning appliances of all kinds.

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning. At the Strand, the attraction is "I Was a Communist for the F.B.I.," a Warner Brothers drama with Frank Lovejoy, Dorothy Hart, Philip Carey, James Millican and Richard Webb. Gordon Douglas directed and Bryan Foy produced from a screen play by Crane Wilbur and a Saturday Evening Post article by Matt Cvetic and Pete Martin.
Consolidated Edison Company of New York borrowed in the public market yesterday $40,000,000 on first and refunding mortgage bonds due May 1, 1981, at an interest cost of about 3.135 per cent.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 1--Iran's outlawed Tudeh (Communist) party packed Parliament Square in Teheran today with 30,000 May Day demonstrators who, with fists raised, gave their ... most frantic cheers when a speaker hailed the "heroic nations of the Soviet Union."
ROME, May 1--A new Italian Socialist party was born today out of the merger of the Right-Wing Socialists headed by Giuseppe Saragat and the Unitarian Socialists headed by Giuseppe Romita.
Television took a back seat yesterday as more than 900 stockholders of the Radio Corporation of America took over the largest television studio in Radio City for their annual meeting.
TRENTON, May 1 (AP)--A father testified as a state witness today at his son's murder trial.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 1--An eighth-inning triple by Jim Fairchild follwed by Bill Prior's single gave Princeton three runs and a 4-3 victory over Rutgers today.

The first witness to appear in the anti-trust trial of seventeen investment banking concerns and the Investment Banking Association of America took the stand in Federal Court here yesterday before Judge Harold R. Medina.

The drop in wool prices may cause the British dominions to favor a plan to split up wool among the Allies, although such a plan was turned down by the dominions last fall, when prospects were for rising prices.
The earliest original documents known on the provisioning of one of Columbus' fleets bound for the New World are on their way here from Oxford, England, to be sold.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 1--An eighth-inning triple by Jim Fairchild follwed by Bill Prior's single gave Princeton three runs and a 4-3 victory over Rutgers today.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1--A "get tough" policy toward farmers of the Far West who enploy Mexican "wetback" labor was announced here today.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 1--Maj. Gen. William Curtis Chase, head of the military aid advisory group to Nationalist China, arrived here today.
Less than 5 per cent of the nation's rearmament production program is now "in trouble" because of scarcities of metals, high officials of the National Production Authority said yesterday.

The Radio Corporation of America, in a dramatic and unannounced move, transmitted television in full color yesterday morning from atop the Empire State Building without interfering with reception on present black-and-white receivers.
LAKE SUCCESS, May 2--The United States will go before the United Nations sanctions committee tomorrow to call for a complete arms embargo against Communist China.
WASHINGTON, May 2--Dr. Henry Honeyman Hazen, an internationally known specialist in dermatology and syphilology, died yesterday at his home. He was 71 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The Administration's Wake Island documents, made public today, quote General of the Army Douglas MacArthur as having told President Truman that there was "very little" chance of Red China's intervention in Korea.

Theophile Kieffer, chef at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel since 1927, said that indeed not, he had no tremors preparing a lunch yesterday in honor of his colleagues in the culinary art. They were Louis Barthe, chef of Maxim's, here for a week from that 60-yearold Parisian institution to "guestcook" at New York's Chambord restaurant; Marcel Grange, the Chambord chef, and Joseph Donon, general secretary of the American Culinary Federation.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2--The Kentucky Derby guessing game keeps getting--as Alice in Wonderland might have phrased it--curi ouser and curiouser, and also more confusing. There is no favorite. The race is wide open.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 2 (AP) --A strike of American Federation of Labor construction workers on a huge atomic plant project spread today--even as union leaders "urgently" requested the strikers to return to their jobs.

PARIS, May 2--Inflation is still likely to damage the Western defense effort more than the recently discovered problem of raw material shortages, in the opinion of Europeans and Americans closest to European economic developments.
Panel members of the New York Times Youth Forum agreed yesterday that television competition with motion pictures would improve the quality of the motion picture.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that United States actions in Korea "paralleled" those urged by Lieut, Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer and followed all but one of the general's recommendations.

PARIS, Thursday, May 3--For the second time this week skillful Communist maneuvering in the National Assembly has forced a postponement of final passage of France's much-debated electoral law and has obliged Premier Henri Queuille to ask for a vote of confidence.
The Need for increased rates to meet higher costs was explained by W.A. Mather, president of the Canadian Pacific Railway at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday in Montreal.

At this time of the year, when screens and garden furniture are being brought out into the open again, many homemakers find themselves faced with some special painting chores. The amateur might avail himself of some advice offered by two companies as well as some new additions to the Sapolin paint line.

The City Stores Company and its subsidiaries, operating thirty-three department and special stores, in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 lifted sales to the largest volume in its history. The total of $205,703,941 was 12.8 per cent over the previous year's sales of $182,303,340, according to the annual report issued today.

Joseph W. Frazer, vice chairman, and Edgar F. Kaiser, president of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, were called as defense witnesses yesterday in the company's $4,000,000 damage suit against Otis Co., Cleveland investment house which withdrew from a $10,000,000 underwriting of KaiserFrazer stock in February, 1948.
The ancient coal-burning pilot boat New York lay idle at her berth alongside Pier 18, Staten Island, yesterday, out of commission after fifty-four years of service in the waters of New York Harbor.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The Economic Cooperation Administration suspended Marshall Plan aid to the Irish Republic today following agreement with that Government that it no longer needed outside dollar assistance to sustain its economy.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 2--Iran's oil-nationalizing law became operative today after it had been issued as an imperial decree under the hand and seal of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi. Its provisions are retroactive to March 20.

NEWMARKET, England, May 2 (AP)--Ki Ming, an Irish-bred colt owned by a Chinese restaurateur and ridden by an Australian jockey, raced to a surprise victory today in the Two Thousand Guineas, first of the English flat-racing classics.

A hearing was begun yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox to determine whether the Government had transferred Mrs. Ethel Rosenberg, convicted atom spy sentenced to death, to Sing Sings death house to subject her to "cruel and inhuman" treatment to make her talk.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 25, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

Radio and television artists who are accused of pro-Communist sympathies will have a chance to tell their side of the story to prospective employers through a plan adopted yesterday by a broadcasting industry committee. Representing artists, networks and sponsors, the committee had been seeking a method to alleviate the probleins arising when a performer's loyalty is questioned.

Construction of a $500,000 Astoria, Queens, branch of the Madison Square Boys Club with a grant from the Charles Hayden Foundation was virtually assured yesterday with the announcement by a sponsoring group in Queens that $47,800 of $200,000 required for operating expenses already had been raised.

Strength in the rails helped the stock market to a new gain yesterday despite laggard tendencies in a few of the pivotal issues. Gains were furthered in the general list to new highs for the movement in slightly largr trading. Although the composite rate only rose 0.86 point, much larger increases developed in the oils, rails, rubbers, chemicals and aircrafts.

A four-hour wildcat strike by 600 workers at the Statler Hotel yesterday shut down all the hotel's restaurants, stranded many of its 2,800 guests on upper stories and filled the lobby with a tumultuous strike rally. Two union leaders who tried to persuade the workers to return to their jobs were escorted to the street before the strikers decided to call off their demonstration at 1 P.M.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Economy forces scored their most decisive victory of the session today as the House passed a $496,764,500 appropriatons bill for operation of the Interior Department in the fiscal year starting next July 1.
BUFFALO, May 2 (AP)--Some hospitals force their visiting staff physicians to participate in what amounts to "fee splitting," the Medical Society of the State of New York declared today.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur said here last night that the Administration's Wake Island documents, made public yesterday, had "just about as much bearing on the problem of... Korea today as would a report on the military operations on Bunker Hill."

LONDON, May 2--Charles E. Wilson, Defense Mobilization Director, told the British people today that the United States was determined that there should be an "equitable" distribution of raw materials and machine tools necessary for defense.
Two new luxury liners ordered for the American Export Lines' Mediterranean service may be turned back to Government ownership under a cost renegotiation arrangement made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The Senate subcommittee investigating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today set May 10 and also reserved the day following for taking testimony from Donald S. Dawson, a Presidential administrative assistant cited as having apparently influenced the agency's loan operations. This action followed Mr. Dawson's agreement yesterday, after having ignored previous invitations, to appear before the group.

Sorely pressed for pitchers, Manager Charley Dressen hopefully sent Don Newcombe to the mound against the Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday. The results were not too encouraging. Brooklyn's ace right-hander, sidelined for a week with a sore arm, failed to survive the eighth inning as the Dodgers suffered their third straight defeat, 4--3, before 6,238.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 2 (UP)--The only three American girls who entered moved into the quarter-finals of the British hard courts tennis championships today, and the English titleholder was eliminated.
The south roadway of the Brooklyn Bridge was opened to traffic at noon yesterday after being closed since March 6, 1950, for reconstruction work that included the addition of a third lane.

Various influences combined yesterday to inject new strength into the sugar market. There were scattered reports that demand for refined sugar is beginning to pick up. There was the Cuban dock strike that already has crippled Havana and Matanzas. There were reports of a series of deals at good advances in price.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 2 (AP)--Police Chief Patrick F. Rox, who the Senate Crime Investigating Committee said had shut his eyes to organized gambling here, retired today.

The Argentine labor unions have received an ironic gift, and they have had to sell their souls to get it. President Peron has triumphantly announced that he is turning over the lifeless body of La Prensa "to the workers"--meaning to the General Confederation of...

WASHINGTON, May 2--A list of more than 4,000 manufactured articles containing steel, copper or aluminum, and which are designated as Class "B" articles under the Controlled Materials Plan, was issued today by the National Production Authority. The plan goes into effect on July 1.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Fear that the beef price regulations announced Saturday by the Office of Price Stabilization will result in a nation-wide meat famine prompted the Senate Agriculture Committee to adopt today a resolution calling for repeal of the order "without delay."

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons, including Miss Anne Whitman and, Miss Jane Douglas, are serving on the junior committee aiding in the plans for the Night Cap Party to be held May 24 in the Carnaval Room of...

With the single exception of a brief statement that "unquestionably he accomplished many noteworthy achievements" in the field of social and community improvements, the Senate Crime Investigating Committee's report as to William O'Dwyer is a damaging, devaluating appraisal of the former New York Mayor.

Dr. Clarence F. Hiskey, who was cleared April 13, of charges of contempt of Congress, has been reinstated with full back pay, to his professorship at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. He had been suspended as head of the institute's Division of Analytical Chemistry, last Nov. 20, immediately after his indictment in Washington.

The Hearing Foundation, 5 East Forty-seventh Street, will increase its nation-wide educational campaign to persuade business organizations to take steps to end jobconnected hearing impairment of employes.

ALBANY, May 2--Construction of the controversial Thruway bridge across the Hudson River between South Nyack and Tarrytown has been approved by the Department of the Army, thus clearing the last legal obstacle for building the 15,000-foot span.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The Chamber of Commerce of the United States called today for the prompt end of all wage and price controls, including those on rents, and for a sharper attack on inflation at its roots.
DETROIT, May 2 (UP)--Joe Louis again failed to show his once devastating punch tonight as he scored an unimpressive ten-round decision over Omelio Agramonte at Olympia Stadium.

It was well decided to call the exhibition lately opened at the Morgan Library in East Thirty-sixth Street "The French Tradi tion," even if it is specifically a tribute to Paris on her 2,000th birthday. For Paris' horizons, no good man would deny, run far beyond her suburbs, and in fact are bounded only by that tradition which is French in the largest sense.
MEXICO CITY, May 2--Ambassador William O'Dwyer issued a vigorous denial today of charges brought against him in the report of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.
WASHINGTON, May 2--Nearly 40,000 miners have received pensions from the United Mine Workers of America welfare and retirement fund, it was announced today.

Though Jackie Robinson has incurred the official wrath of the National League president, Ford Frick, for his part in last Monday night's Dodger-Giant flare-up at Ebbets Field, the Brooklyn club yesterday made it clear that it stands behind the star second baseman.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2-- Studies of the digestion of a breakfast of radioactive scrambled eggs, reported here today at the sixtyfourth annual meeting of the Association of American Physicians, indicate that the dietary intake of iron usually recommended may not be high enough.

TRENTON, May 2--Republican Assemblymen, balking at passage of Delaware River toll-bridge legislation, gave their support tonight only under direct pressure from Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll. Representatives of the Governor went to the floor of the Assembly to speak to reluctant members. Among the emissaries was Republican State Chairman John J. Dickerson.

NYACK, N.Y,, May 2--Opinion was mixed throughout Rockland County when word was received today of the Army approval of the Tappan Zee site for the Thruway bridge. Officials and residents of Nyack, South Nyack and Grand View were outspoken in condemning the site, but residents of the interior were in favor of it.

STRASBOURG, France, May 2 --West Germany became a fullfledged member of the Council of Europe today and Dr. Konrad Adenaur, Bonn Chancellor and Foreign Minister, took his seat in the deliberations of the Committee of Foreign Ministers.
LONDON, May 2--Arguments over the conflicting United States and British policies toward China broke out in Parliament today.

It is a matter of record that I volunteered to attend the hearings of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee. I did so because I felt that my testimony would be of help in destroying organized crime in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (U.P.)-- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today a bill to fix the top strength of the Marine Corps at 400,000 men--double the present goal--and give the corps a stronger voice with the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

The "negligence" of seven banks in the Queens-Long Island area in making Federal Housing Administration loans for household materials that were never installed was sharply criticized yesterday by J. Irwin Shapiro, Chief Assistant Queens County District Attorney.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2-- Paramount's contract for Maurice Chevalier to star in the Billy Wilder production, "A New Kind of Love," has been called off and plans for making the picture have been abandoned, the studio announced today.

A syndicate of Detroit realty investors has purchased two large garden apartment developments in the New York metropolitan area containing a total of more than 2,000 families, it was announced yesterday. The housing communities are in Astoria, Queens, and East Paterson, N.J., and represent a combined investment of about $25,000,000.
The Korean front remained relatively quiet Wednesday as United Nations units patrolled well forward of friendly lines without significant hostile contact.
East Harlem is one of the most congested neighborhoods in New York City. This congestion applies to its community services as well as to housing.

CHICAGO, May 2--An injuryriddled Yankee club that simply would not be denied rode high above the physical ailments which claimed some of its key men and the discouraging influence of a four-run deficit today to conquer the White Sox, 6--4, with a ninthinning surge before 8,802.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Senate Democrats narrowly blocked tonight Republican demands for public hearings in the investigation opening tomorrow of the dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from his Far East commands.
Western Union asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday for permission to raise its telegraph rates by 9.6 per cent. to increase employe wages.

A little less than a year ago the Messrs. Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse were saying that they wanted to "get away from being business men in the theatre" to concentrate on writing. Yesterday Mr. Lindsay confirmed a report that he and his partner had signed contracts to produce "One Bright Day," by Sigmund Miller, next January.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 2--Translations of two captured orders issued by the North Korean Army the week before it invaded South Korea were submitted to the United Nations Security Council by the United States today as a final answer to repeated Communist charges that South Korea started the war.

Dacron, the new polyester texthe fiber manufactured by E.I. du Pont de Nemours, Inc., stands ready to take its place as an important outerwear fabric, Dr. Louis L. Larson, manager of sales development in the company's nylon division, said last night.

Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy's departmental survey into organization and administration brought the decision yesterday to abolish the Greenwich Street precinct, serving the west tip of Manhattan, and the Flushing Meadow Park precinct in Queens.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 2-- Police Chief Alexander Flannery of Edgewater "obviously is avoiding service of a subpoena to testify before the Bergen County grand jury," Nelson F. Stamler, deputy Attorney General, head of the state's gambling investigation, charged today.

The Cleburne, a thirteen-story apartment house for sixty-four families occupying the blockfront on the north side of West 105th Street from Broadway to West End Avenue and known as 924 West End Avenue, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to the 924 West End Avenue...
"Santa Fe," which arrives at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Randolph Scott is starred in the Technicolor Western, which was produced by ScottBrown production for Columbia release.

SHANNON AIRPORT, Ireland, May 2 (UP)--David Ben-Gurion, Premier of Israel, arrived here tonight on his way to the United States in hope of obtaining enough money to bring 600,000 more immigrants to Israel.

The Warner Brother, pioneer developers of the motion picture industry and heads of the vast film production and theatre operating company that bears their name, will sell out all their... stock holdings and retire from the business "if somebody makes the right offer," Harry M. Warner, president of the organization, said last night.

A $6,500,000 program to provide fast, modern ferryboats for Staten Island commuter service was completed yesterday with the acceptance of the city's Department of Marine and Aviation of the Giovanni da Verrazzano, third and final unit of the plan.
Two five-story buildings containing stores and apartments and occupying a plot 50 by 100 feet at 1729-31 First Avenue, between Eighty-ninth and Ninetieth Streets,...

PARIS, May 2--After more than eight weeks of barren negotiations, the three Western deputies sought to force a showdown today by submitting three alternative proposals for a Big Four foreign ministers' agenda to Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet deputy, and challenging him... to declare whether the Soviet Union truly wished to have a fourpower conference to ease international tension.
LAKE SUCCESS, May 2--Israel today charged Syrian forces with "unprovoked aggression" in the clash this morning in which several Israeli soldiers were killed.
The Giants, who appear determined to come up for air, and the Cubs, who are rapidly running out of it, each took another long stride yesterday toward what should be their appointed destinies.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 2--Contributors totaling about $225,000,000 have been pledged for the relief and rehabilitation of war-devasted Korea under the United Nations, according to a summation made public here today.

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman of the Crusade for Freedom, announced yesterday a new drive to raise $3,000,000 from 25,000,000 to 30,000,000 Americans to expand the broadcasting operations of Radio Free Europe behind the Iron Curtain.

When the 5,000th member of the Babies Alumni is born "not later than next Tuesday" at Flushing Hospital, business men in the surrounding Queens neighborhood will bestow upon him--or her--their blessing of gifts.

The summer fashion picture was presented by Arnold Constable yesterday noon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Featured were several of New York's well-known fashion representatives --Carolyn Schnurer, Larry Aldrich, Harvey Berin, Herbert Sondheim-- and the designers Claire McCardell and Ceil Chapman. From the West Coast came bathing suits by Mabs and Marie Reid.
The first step to enroll 60,000 parents as civil defense aides in schools of the city was taken yesterday at civil defense recruiting headquarters, 500 Park Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 2 --The election tonight of four members of a new citizens committee to the Tarrytown school board splits the group four-to-four on several questions and may block construction of a proposed $3,500,000 comprehensive high school. The contest was one of three in Westchester County.

A new plan for insurance against medical and surgical costs was announced yesterday by Group Health Insurance, Inc. The plan of the non-profit organization removes income limitations for full coverage against medical and surgical costs while a patient is hos-... pitalized, providede the patient's hospital accommodations do not exceed semi-private facilities.

Plans were made by a key business group yesterday to have the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce named claimant agency for operation of a proposed general export priorities system.

Aqueduct Race Track in Queens is here to stay, and its permanence in New York life is in no way affected by gambling disclosures of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, Cyrus Julian, president of the Queens County Jockey Club, told the City Planning Commission yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2--John Gover, Greentree Stable's trainer, provided what perhaps was today's most interesting bit of information about Saturday's seventy-seventh Kentucky Derby. Theodore Fredric Atkinson, the stable's contract jockey, is to ride Hall of Fame instead of Big Stretch.

Youth Consultation Service will be the beneficiary of an entertainment, known as the Petal Pink Ball, to be held in the St. Regis Roof on the night of May 23, the preopening of the roof garden. Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell heads the benefit committee. The occasion will mark the fortieth anniversary of the foundine of the beneficiary.

Irving Sherman, friend of Ambassador William O'Dwyer, Frank Costello and Joe Adonis, whom the Senate Crime Investigating Committee had sought unsuccessfully as a witness for more than two months, offered yesterday to testify.

DANBURY, Conn., May 2--The Rev. Elliot B. Barber, pastor of the Universalist Church here for twenty years until 1931 when he retired from the active ministry, died last night in his home at near-by Salem Center, N.Y. His age was 89.

CLEVELAND, May 2--A fundamental discovery shedding new light on the mechanism by which green plants capture the energy of sunlight to build the food that provides the energy for all higher forms of life was announced here today at the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

CHICAGO, May 2--The grain markets were full of speculative cross-currents today, with further liquidation by longs in May wheat and also in corn, while there was better support in deferred wheat futures and also in December corn and September oats.

THOSE who want to line up the prospects for the coming week-end before making a move now have a wide choice in both fresh and salt water, and if the weather man will cooperate this should be the first good angling week-end of the season.

A short order cook who tried to serve a fast one to an off-duty policeman confessed yesterday, detectives said later, that he had made a mistake. He was charged with larceny in the theft of the patrolman's wallet, which contained $33.

The United States has nothing to gain by jeopardizing its position in Europe because of a controversy over its position in Asia, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former United States Military Governor in occupied Germany, said yesterday.

Current preoccupation by LatinAmerican countries with the terms of trade with the United States reflects fears that their wartime experiences will be repeated and they will again be unable to obtain imports, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York declares in its Monthly Review, published today.
The record of our action in Korea is plain. Certainly our course in Korea has paralleled the recommendations of General Wedemeyer.
Frederick Brown reported yesterday that he had purchased store and office properties in Manhattan and Westchester County and sold a garage building in Long Island City, Queens.

Out of the thunder and the agony of the Korean battlefields comes the most cheering news that has brightened the free world for some time. This is the announcement by General Van Fleet that the most powerful Communist offensive ever launched in that area has...

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- House action on the grain-for-India bill was postponed today, partly because of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's statement that United States aid would be unacceptable if strings ware tied to it.
Romantic as the inspiration that originated them, the sixth edition of youthful "Love Letter" summer cottons appeared yesterday at B. Altman.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 2 (UP)--Gov. Fuller Warren of Florida charged today that Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, had "smeared" him in the Senate Crime Investigating Committee's report in return for a promise of help from the Governor's political ene,ies to get the 1952 Democratis Presidential nomination.

British deficiencies in some of the technical applications of seapower to modern warfare are one of the reasons for the tendency in Washington to study carefully the projected command establishments for the Atlantic and the Mediterranean.
Robert A. Vogeler is to enter a Government hospital today, leaving unanswered the question of what was true in the confession that led to his conviction in Hungary of espionage.

For the first time in two years balance sheet and earnings data for Ford S. A., traded on the New York Curb Exchange as Ford of France, have become available to American investors in general. The stock is not listed on the Curb and regulations have not required the filing of periodical statements.
In poker, the chances of drawing a pat royal flush are one in 649,740; a full house one in 694; a flush one in 509, and a straight one in 255.

Apparently there is no retreat, no compromise, and no regard either for freely ratified agreements or for future consequences, in the decision of Iran to seize the property of the AngloIranian Company and nationalize the oil fields.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2-- "Labor gentlemen" identified as William Green, Philip Murray and several associates were condemned today by the biennial convention of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards as having participated in the "biggest of all swindles against the workers of this country."

The Northeastern Roofing, Siding and Insulating Contractors Association appealed yesterday to President Truman for immediate action to end the black market in nails, C. N, Nichols, managing director of the association, which is said to represent 100,000 small home improvement and maintenance contractors, said nails were unavailable at normal prices.

BROOKS ATKINSON'S "Once Around the Sun" is the town and country journal of a civilized American's crowded and yet tran quil year in a boisterously uncivilized century. In our new epoch of diaries--sharp trend ahead!-- you will not find a better one.

WASHINGTON, May 2--If one Supreme Court justice, whoever he may be, had not, in the Dorothy Bailey case, parted from the brethren with whom he stood in the "subversive lists" case, the President's entire program for "loyalty" tests of Government employes would be under the highest judicial challenge today.

Blue Case, owned by J.R. Roebling and ridden by Warren Mehrtens, won the forty-second running of the Rosedale Stakes at Jamaica yesterday. The daughter of Case Ace just made it with a closing burst to score by a neck over Hal Price Headley's Papoose. Jack W. Schiffer's Cigar Maid was third in the five-furlong sprint, trailing Papoose by a head.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 3--United Nations armored task forces pushed out far ahead of Allied lines in western Korea yesterday as the lull in the fighting settled down over most of the front. The tanks struck north from Seoul almost to Uijongbu, meeting only small groups of the enemy.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 2-- The Eastman School of Music opened its Twenty-first annual Festival of American Music tonight before a capacity audience in Kilbourn Hall. Dr. Howard Hanson conducted the Eastman-Rochester Symphony Orchestra in a program that included four premieres.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 2--After nearly twelve hours of hard fighting, Syrian forces, who had crossed the demilitarized zone and occupied two Israeli villages early today, were thrown back into Syria by an Israeli counter-attack, it was announced here tonight.

Operating rates are being cut back in many iron foundries in Eastern areas because of shortages of pig iron and heavy cast scrap. Further curtailments are certain unless increased supplies of raw materials are obtained, foundry executives said yesterday.
Dr. William C. Menninger, psychiatrist and general secretary of the Menninger Foundation in Topeka, Kan., cautioned the home front yesterday against sending disturbing letters to service men.

TOKYO, May 2--The Japanese Government announced today it would call a special session of Parliament before the opening of peace negotiations to revise ordinances issued to implement occupation directives in line with the authorization given by Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridway.

Three soloists joined forces with Dimitri Mitropoulos and the Philharmonic-Symphony in last night's Carnegie Hall concert. It was a benefit performance for Athens College and the Queen's Fund for the Orphan children of Greece, sponsored by the Greek War Relief Organization.

ABOARD U.S.S. Princeton, in Korean Waters, May 2--Each day aboard this flagship of Carrier Task Force 77 a 26-year-old veteran of World War II works long hours carting and stowing bombs, napalm tanks and rockets slated for plane delivery to the Chinese Communists in Korea.
Humphrey Summer, one of the leading historians of his generation in Britain, died in Oxford on April 25, it was learned here yesterday. His age was 57.

Special works that will be presented during the 1951-52 season of the Philharmonic-Symphony were announced yesterday by the society. The list is headed by some rarely-heard pieces that Dimitri Mitropoulos, the musical director, will conduct.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- The Agriculture Department reported today that the prices of farm land have vaulted to the highest levels in the nation's history.

Well-known women of the social and theatrical worlds headed by Mrs. Vincent Astor, Mrs. J. Cheever Cowdin and Miss Celeste Holm are aiding in the plans for the preview cocktail party to be held on the afternoon of May 10 at the memorial loan exhibition of paintings...

WASHINGTON, May 3 President Truman has directed the Department of Defense to avoid overspending and to see that there are no "unnecessary jolts" to the civilian economy growing out of the arms build-up.
FRANKLIN, Tenn., May 3 (AP) Maj. Gen. Lytle Brown, former Chief of the Army Corps of Engineers, died at his home near here today after a brief illness. His age was 78.

WASHINGTON, May 3 General of the Army Douglas MacArthur declared today that the United States should give an ultimatum to Communist China to withdraw from Korea or face war against all the free world.
Plans to modernize the port of Baltimore rest on the decision of that city's voters on Tuesday.

W.P. Getty has been appointed assistant to the vice president in charge of operations of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, Pittsburgh. C. M. Lichy succeeds him as assistant general manager Of raw materials and C. E. Amos has been named assistant to the general manager of raw materials.

Substantially larger earnings for the first quarter of 1951 over a year ago were reported by five oil companies yesterday. Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Tide Water Associated Oil Company announced their operating results at their annual meetings.

WASHINGTON, May 3 President Truman told reporters today that the meat price control order that has been the target of Congressional critics since it was issued last Saturday, was put up to him before it was announced and that he, personally, approved the measure.

PEORIA, Ill., May 3 (U.P.) United States Army engineers eased the 620-foot Cliffs Victory over a dam eighty miles south of here tonight, literally holding their breaths in fear that a puff of wind might sink the biggest ship ever to travel the Illinois River.
HARTFORD, Conn.,May 3 Fairfield County Republican legislators voted unanimously today to favor location of natural gas pipelines in their county along the Merritt Parkway, if it is legally possible.
A major economic upheaval in the radio industry appeared imminent last night as a result of two developments reflecting the growing competition offered by television.
CHICAGO, May 3--Montgomery Ward Co. announced today the resignation of Joseph C. Kracht as vice president in charge of soft goods lines and the appointment of Herbert Riegelman as his successor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3--J. Leonard Sessler, bibliophile, print expert and dealer in manuscripts and art, died last night in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital after an illness of two months. He was 55 years old.
A strike of 12,000 elevator operators and other service employes in Manhattan's lofty apartment houses was called "inevitable" last night by the head of their union.
STRASBOURG, France, May 3 --European foreign ministers rejected today a demand of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe for permission to deal with questions of defense.
The poor record of the United States Congress on the food-for-India bill may as well be faced. In answer to the Indian Government's request for 2,000,000 tons of grain, the House Committee

One of the advantages of the spring group shows is the opportunity to renew acquaintance with paintings that have been admired in one-man exhibitions at the height of the season. And new works are almost invariably included as well.

WASHINGTON, May 3 John Foster Dulles, special representative of President Truman for negotiating a peace treaty with Japan, reported to President Truman today that the Japanese people now were aware that the ...

TULSA, Okla., May 3-A new V-type eight-cylinder automotive engine with a compression ratio of 12 to 1 was presented today by Charles L. McCuen, vice president of General Motors Corporation. The power plant, still in an experimental stage, was described as a mechanical advance designed to increase efficiency and economy in motoring.

WASHINGTON, May 3 President Truman asserted today that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had prevented effective operation of the Central Intelligence Agency in his Far East command until after he was very much surprised by the intervention of the Chinese Communists in the Korean war.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Boardd of Review, a voluntary organiation composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, today through Sun

Using current food prices and wages compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics as a basis, Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan recently announced that, despite the high cost of living, an hour's earnings now will buy more food than in the past.
WASHINGTON, May 3 General MacArthur had not been long in the witness chair of the Senate committees today before one important thing was established. This was that General
A shift is occurring in the interest of American visitors to Europe they are more concerned with people than with places, according to Alexandre de Manziarly.

Jacob Glass, through his his Midboro Realty Corporation, has purchased the six-story ninety-family apartment house at 1041 Findlay Avenue, the Sronx, from Kenton Hall, Inc. The property, in the same ownership for eighteen years, occupies a plot 185 by 100 feet.
The committees met, pursuant to adjournment at 10:30 A. M. in the Caucus Room, Senate Office Building, Senator Richard B. Russell (chairman, Committee on Armed Services) presiding.
Offerings of about $19,500,000 worth of new public utility common stock to shareholders of Ohio Edison Company and Long Island Lighting Company will be made today.
CHICAGO, May 3-Because of Government restrictions, America's machine tool industry will be able to produce in 1951 only one-third as many tools as it turned out during the rearmament program in 1941.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 3 Ground was broken today on the former Whitelaw Reid estate for the $14,000,000 buildings of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart. Cardinal Spellman turned the first shovel of earth. A guest was Archbishop Borgognoni Duca of the Vatican.

Two new films will arrive in local houses this morning. At the Cinema 48 the attraction is "Au Grande Balcon," a French-made drama dealing with the early days of aviation, starring Pierre Fresnay. The C. I. C. C. production, which is being presented by Raphael and Gaston Hakim, has French dialogue and English subtitles.
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy embarked on a new campaign yesterday to rid his department of the "last, ragged remnants" Of Communist influence.
WASHINGTON, May 3--A reconstituted Wage Stabilization Board, with a full complement of eighteen members, will start work Tuesday, and a new salary stabilization board is expected to be set up soon.

TOKYO, Friday, May 4 United Nations forces struck back aggressively along the Korean front yesterday with armored task forces, air and artillery jabbing at an enemy again on the defensive after the allied withdrawals north of Seoul last week.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 The Kefauver investigation closed down the gambling industry with such abrupt finality that only 100,000 on-the-spot witnesses will be able to wager on the Kentucky Derby. Not another soul in the entire country will be able to risk a pfennig on the Run for the Roses. Off-the-track betting is a relic of the past. Or is it?

W. R. Grace and Company filed a brief with the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday asking the board to deny the request of Pan American World Airways and Eastern Air Lines to re-open hearings into the question of whether Grace had acquired or exercised control of National Airlines.
Before long you will be able to make a transcontinental telephone call merely by dialing the desired number.

WASHINGTON, May 3 General of the Army Omar N. Bradley warned Senate investigators today that published testimony by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur might enable an enemy to crack this country's secret military codes. General MacArthur promptly denied it.

Prices on all meats this weekend are at exactly the same levels as last Friday. Since it will be some time before the recent orders fixing beef tariffs result in lower retail costs, shoppers for the present will find it more practical to consider alternative protein foods.

WASHINGTON, May 3 Cheering crowds, bands, the big brass and the fanfare were missing as General of the Army Douglas MacArthur returned to the capital today to give Congress his version of high policy differences with President Truman.

LONDON, May 3 Shortly before the United States had proposed a United Nations embargo on strategic goods for Communist China, Prime Minister Attlee declared today, no materials of warmaking value had been shipped to China from Britain in the last three months.

The question whether a newspaper man must divulge the source of his information will be argued Monday before Federal Judge John C. Knox by the Government and counsel for Mrs. Ethel Rosenberg, convicted atom spy sentenced to death.

Thefts amounting to $72,052 were charged yesterday to ten former New York University students and a present undergraduate in grand larceny and forgery indictments that accused them of operating a lucrative fraud on the school's bookstore at the Washington Square branch.

CINCINNATI, May 3 A considerable increase in the number of psychoanalysts in practice and training in this country was reported today at the opening of the annual meeting of the American Psychoanalytic Association, attended by many of the nation's most prominent psychoanalysts.

TOKYO, May 3 (UP) Members of the right-wing General Council of Labor Unions today defied an Allied ban on political rallies in the imperial palace plaza and scuffled briefly with police during a Constitution Day celebration.

WASHINGTON, May 3 Senate Democrats for a second time forced by a close margin this evening a recess, without permitting a vote, on Republican demands that the hearings on the removal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from his Far Eastern commands be thrown open to the public.

TODAY, 3 P.M.: Spring Carnival, featuring pony rides and merry-go-round, Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 East Ninety-second Street. Children beyond third grade not admitted. No general admission, small fees for games and rides.

United Nations ground forces continued aggressive patrolling along the western and central sectors Thursday, encountering only sporadic hostile resistance. Sharp fighting occurred southeast of Hangye as our unite adjusted positions.

Judging by the crisp fashionable cottons shown yesterday by Saks34th Street at the Plaza Hotel, modish young career women need have no fears of the forthcoming summer heat or of budgets getting out of hand.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 3 A United Nations call for an immediate cease-fire went unheeded by both Syria and Israel today. Their forces continued to fight in an engagement that had already spread from its starting point and threatened to engulf the entire troubled border region.

The admission of the German Federal Republic into the Council of Europe is an event of great symbolic importance. While the deputies in Paris are still wrangling over the chewed-up agenda for a Big Four conference on a German settlement Chancellor Adenauer, representing a Germany "90 per cent sovereign," he asserted, took his place

The State of Washington announced yesterday that it would receive bids May 23 on an issue of $60,000,000 of building bonds. Of the total $40,000,000 will be for schools and the rest for institutional improvements.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 A rank-and-file movement for unity among maritime unions was proposed today by the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, an unaffiliated union, at its biennial convention.

Diamond Full Fashioned Hosiery Company has reduced the wholesale price of Fruit of the Loom seamfree nylon hosiery by $1 a dozen, and the retail price from $1.19 to 99 cents a pair, it was announced yesterday, Mojud Hosiery Company, Inc., announced price cuts on three numbers ranging from 50 cents to $1.05 a dozen wholesale and retail reductions of 10 to 20 cents a pair.
The military plans and operations of the United States in Korea must be subordinate to the nation's major political objectives, Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, declared last night.

State civil service law says that public employes shall not belong to organizations that advocate overthrow of the Government by force. The City Charter says that an employe is required to answer questions put to him in official inquiry.

Mainly in anticipation of the Sunday midnight deadline on the change in the police retirement law, 280 members of the department have applied for retirement and 350 more have indicated that they would put in their papers over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively turned down an Administration request today to reduce tax credits allowed for depletion of oil wells. It also doubled the current 5 per cent depletion allowance for coal mines.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet, and final prices were 5 points lower to 23 points higher than on Wednesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 3 The Republic of Korea charged leaders of the Soviet Union, Communist China and North Korea today with a criminal conspiracy to commit mass murder and destroy the Korean nation, and demanded an investigation by the United Nations.
DETROIT, May 3 (AP) Walt Dropo, benched for weak hitting for the last ten games, smashed in four runs with a double and single to spark the Red Sox to a 6-1 victory over the Tigers today.

J. Stanley Davis of Wilson Point, South Norwalk, Conn., an associate of Shields Co., stock brokerage firm of 44 Wall Street, and of the Brunner Manufacturing Company, makers of air compressors, of Utica, N. Y., died on Monday at Hamilton, Bermuda, where he was vacationing. His age was 60.
Converting left-overs into appetizing dishes that win the family's approval is an art that any good cook with a little imagination can easily master.
ST. LOUIS, May 3 The Yankees shattered a 39-year-old American League record and tied two other marks today in crushing the Browns, 17 to 3.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) Philip Bart, general manager of, The New York Communist Daily Worker, was found guilty today of contempt of Congress for defying the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 Diane Betty Halprin, a 6-year-old violin pupil at the Curtis Institute of Music, was named today as one of seven soloists for the Philadelphia Orchestra Children's Concerts next season.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) House budget cutters scored a preliminary victory today in a drive to slash at least $750,000,000 from agency spending in 1952, including sharp cutbacks in public housing outlays and shinning subsidies.

The craftsman's problem of displaying his wares effectively is the theme of this month's exhibit by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council in its gallery at America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

In General MacArthur's recommendations on military measures in East Asia the first two points concerned what might be called a type of sanctions. He urged, first, "the intensification of our economic blockade against China," and, second, "the imposition of a naval blockade against the China coast."

It will not be long before the Post Office Department, to save money, will be sending all longhaul first-class mail by air rather than by railroad, Ralph S. Damon, president of Trans World Airlines, Inc., asserted here yesterday.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur started three months before his dismissal by President Truman from his Far Eastern commands to prepare documentary evidence in support of his campaign against the Administration's military policy in Asia, the magazine Newsweek asserted yesterday.

The City College baseball team came from behind yesterday to defeat Brooklyn, 10 to 9, in a Metropolitan Conference game at Babe Ruth Field, Bronx. Trailing by 8-1 in the second inning, the Beavers settled down behind Warren Neuberger and won with three-run rallies in the seventh and eighth.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3 Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has borrowed Broderick Crawford from Columbia to appear with Clark Gable and Ava Gardner in "Lone Star," a film about the annexation of Texas which Z. Wayne Griffin will produce. Lionel Barrymore has been named to play President Andrew Jackson in the picture.
Reversing the downward trend of the three previous weeks, loans to business concerns by New York banks rose $21,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.
The Red Cross appealed for blood donations in quantity today and thus to avoid a "last hour" rush to fill the weekly emergency quota for Korea such as worried officials last Saturday.
WASHINGTON, May 3 The Department of Defense placed before Congress today its longawaited plan for release of reservists called to active duty since the Korean emergency.

THE New Jersey anglers have two general methods of get ting a creelful of trout: first, start early and cover a lot of water with bait or fly and, second, follow the hatchery truck until it dumps a hundred or so trout into the stream.

Gifts of $35,000 toward the $10,000,000 goal of the Barnard College Development Fund were announced yesterday by Mrs. Frank Altschul, national chairman of the drive. The contributions were $25,000 from THE NEW YORK TIMES and $10,000 from the Vincent Astor Foundation, both sums to be used at the discretion of the college.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 3 (AP)--J. A. Pallante's Larry A., a 7-to-1 shot, nicely placed, hugged the inner rail and went on to win a thrilling victory in a photo finish over J. L. McKnight's Mr. Buster before a crowd of 14,050 at Garden State Park today.

Sugar markets, sensitive because of the diminishing "free" Cuban supply, reacted yesterday to an unconfirmed report that the British Ministry of Foods had bought 50,000 tons of beet sugar from Eastern Germany and Poland, because of Cuban shipping difficulties.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) Federal Mediation Director Cyrus S. Ching appealed to the Textile Workers of America, C. I. O., today to call off its strike in eight Southern states in the interest of "national safety and welfare."
LONDON, May 3 Dr. Henryk Strasburger, Polish Ambassador in London from 1944 to 1946, died yesterday in this city, where he lived in exile. He was 63 years old.

Ted M., a 5-year-old son of Peace Chance, made a fast run in the stretch yesterday to win the Naturalist, Jamaica's feature presentation. Jack Colaneri rode the well-played second choice to success over the favored Quick Fire, with Free Strider third.

WASHINGTON, May 3 State Department officials today praised Britain for having restricted ship ments of rubber to the Soviet Union and Communist China, but they left no doubt that at the same time they hoped more stringent curbs would be imposed.

TRENTON, May 3--Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons, in a report today to a State Senate committee investigating the Woodbridge train wreck, recommended a general inquiry into passenger safety on New Jersey railroads.

WASHINGTON, May 3 Department store sales in the United States during the week ended April 28 rose 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 Sylvester Veitch, the C. V. Whitney trainer, has the idea that the King Ranch's Sonic should be the favorite for Saturday's seventy-seventh Kentucky Derby.

CLEVELAND, May 3 Studies indicating that ACTH and cortisone will exert a much more powerful effect on rheumatoid arthritis and a number of other chronic ailments if given together were described here today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

Aided by an unusually early spring in many parts of the Soviet Union, Soviet farmers are making good progress in plowing and sowing for the 1951 harvest. Many southern areas have completed planting of key crops, while in more northerly areas spring sowing activity covers a wide region.

The Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association, of which Mrs. Nicholas R. Jones is president, will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Flahooley," with Yma Sumac, Peruvian singer, in a leading role, on the night of May 16 at the Broadhurst Theatre. Mrs. Daven

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) Counsel for Mrs. Ellen Knauff, German-born war bride seeking entry to this country, charged today that her exclusion was based on a desire to "save face" for Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Clark, who was attorney general when she first came to this country.

HONG KONG, May 3 Chinese Communist authorities in Shanghai are organizing "committees for the extermination of counter-revolutionaries" in factories, schools, public offices and residential blocks to ferret out "enemies of the state" with greater efficiency.
The Crosley division of Avco Manufacturing Corporation will reduce refrigerator production 20 per cent on Monday, John W. Craig, Avco vice president and Crosley general manager, announced yesterday.

Pittsburgh, which polished off the Dodgers twice in a row before invading Manhattan, checked the comeback drive of the Giants last night. To the disappointment of 9,649 fans who visited the Polo Grounds in hopes of seeing the home team extend its winning streak to four straight, the Pirates, instead, attained that goal.
A commercial jet transport capable of cruising at 500 miles an hour and making a slow landing in a relatively small space was envisioned yesterday by an aviation expert.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP)--A four-run eighth inning rally by the Cardinals proved more effective than three Phillies home runs as the Redbirds defeated the National League champions, 8-4, tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)-- The only woman at the Wake Island conference--a brunette State Department secretary--told today how she sat behind a slatted door and made stenographic notes while President Truman, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and their aides talked.

Net income of the Chrysler Corporation in the first three months of 1951 was $15,316,672, equal to $1.53 a capital share and a return of 2.13 per cent on net sales of $626,204,540, K. T. Keller, chairman, reported yesterday.

JUST as you can't necessarily tell from the size of a frog how far he can jump so you can't necessarily tell from the size of a novel whether it is any good. Sheer fictional bulk can be impressive. And it seems to be irresistibly alluring to hunters for bargains in literature.

CHICAGO, May 3(AP) A Federal judge said today he would accept the promises of 4,000 eye doctors not to take rebates on the sale of glasses. The pledge, also to be signed by officials of six optical manufacturing companies would dispose of the Government's antitrust suit based on the rebate system.

Although the boom in consumer goods has slowed, the demand for capital goods, because of plant expansion and defense orders, remains unchecked and the industrial outlook is strong. This situation is cited by the National City Bank of New York in its Monthly Letter, issued today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 3 Ernest A. Gross, Deputy United States Representative, proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly recommend an arms embargo against Communist China.

LONDON, May 3 A new international council, which might in an emergency become the supreme political directorate for the West ern democracies, has been set up within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

LONDON, May 3 This great center of austerity never knew it would see such ceremonial gaiety again. But today, as King George threw open the 1951 Festival of Britain as a symbol of this country's "abiding courage and vitality," there was the ancient pomp and an air of lightheartedness to match the times of the Tudors.
DETROIT, May 3(U.P.) Joe Louis and Lee Savold were matched today for a twelve-round heavyweight contenders' fight at Net York's Polo Grounds on June 13.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) General of the Army Douglas MacArthur said today that his reports to the United Nations were censored in Washington and that the, State Department once made "unwarranted" changes to achieve a "political slant."
TEHERAN, Iran, May 3 Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, new Premier of Iran, presented his Cabinet and its program to the Majlis, or lower House of Parliament, this morning.

An unexpected and unusual award was made by the Architectural League of New York last night when it presented at its Gold Medal Mural Painter's dinner two gold medals instead of the customary single prize. The awards

In St. James Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon Miss Phoebe Rentschler, daughter of Mrs. Gordon S. Rentschler of 1030 Fifth Avenue and Hamilton, Ohio, and the late Mr. Rentschler, was married to Louis Lee Stanton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton of 580 Park Avenue.

A charge that James J. Moran, former Commissioner of Water Supply and a close friend of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, lied to the Kefauver crime committee to avoid questions that would have exposed his relationship with Louis Weber, Brooklyn policy figure, was made yesterday at the opening of Moran's trial on perjury charges.

Nineteen members of the Eintracht Sport Club of Frankfort, Germany, arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for a good-will tour of eight soccer matches in' this country, starting Sunday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

Brooklyn's first shut-out victory of the season was fashioned last night at Ebbets Field by Preacher Roe. He blanked the Reds, 8-0, with a six-hit, front-running performance that did not permit a visitor to reach third. The undefeated southpaw also contributed a run-scoring single toward his third triumph of the campaign.
WASHINGTON, May 3 Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended April 28 totaled 824,662 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The Freedoms Foundation of Valley Forge, Pa., presented its 1950 national awards yesterday to 160 individuals and organizations from New York and Connecticut.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 3 A memorial day for the 6,000,000 Jews exterminated by the Nazis during World War II and for the martyrs of Jewish ghetto uprisings was observed here today.

The highest place in Connecticut is Bear Mountain, which is at the point where Connecticut, New York and Massachusetts meet a little more than ninety miles north of Manhattan. Halfway between Connecticut's Bear Mountain and the Hudson River is the village of Pine Plains, population 665.

PARIS, May 3 Additional United States air strength has been put at the disposal of Shape (Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe) through the creation of the Third United States Air Force, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Allied commander in Europe, announced today.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 3 (UP) Miss Doris Hart, 25-yearold Jacksonville (Fla.) star who specializes in man-size services, overpowered Jean Quertier, veteran British Wightman Cup player, 6-1, 6-1, today to lead two other Americans into the women's singles semi-finals of the British hard-court tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, May 3 David Ben-Gurion, Prime Minister of Israel, arrived here on his first official visit today with an expression of gratitude for help given by the United States in the rebuilding of an independent home for Jews.

LONDON, May 3 Prices continued to rise on the stock markets here today. Handsome gains were made in industrials, especially by textile and brewery groups and in oil and copper mining groups.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP)The Federal Trade Commission ordered the Clay Products Association, Inc., and fourteen of its members today to break up "an admitted conspiracy to fix prices."

K. T. Kelley, board chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday that there was a steady increase throughout the country of "black market" operations in essential restricted metals. Deals for materials such as copper, Zinc, nickel and lead are made at 100 per cent over quoted market value, he said, thereby imposing a handicap on the automobile industry, which operates within the law.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Opponents of Secretary of State Dean Acheson in the House of Representatives are organizing a move to force him out of office by shutting off his salary after June 30.
WELLINGTON, N, Z., May 3 (Reuters)--Members of New Zealand's new volunteer emergency force tonight stood guard over the homes of dockworkers who went back to work after striking for ten weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 3 General of the Army Douglas MacArthur not only clarified his own position on Capitol Hill today but he also provided all members of Congress with an opportunity to stand and vote on whether they favor his policy or not.
A total of $250,000 was pledged to the building fund of the Brooklyn Women's Hospital by members of the campaign committee meeting yesterday at a cocktail party at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, May 3 (Reuters) The Royal Festival Hall, the world's most modern concert auditorium, was opened tonight with traditional British pomp and ceremony. The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, dedicated the hall and King George VI unveiled a memorial tablet.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 3 Ernest M. Morris, widely known business man and philanthropist, died early today in Memorial Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 68. He had been in poor health for two years.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., May 3 Miss Charlotte De Cozen of Baltusrol won low gross honors in the opening one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association over the Forest Hill Field Club course today with 1-over-par 40, 37-77.
The Metropolitan Opera Fund 1951-52 is within $100,000 of its goal, George A. Sloan, chairman, said yesterday, announcing that $650,000 had been received.
The first training course for civil defense volunteers to staff the thirty-one report and control centers in New York City will begin this noon.

WASHINGTON, May 3 The Office of Price Stabilization sought restoration of normal trading conditions in the import of manufactured goods today through the issuance of pricing formulas covering products ranging from Scotch whisky to automobiles.

Paul G. Hoffman warned last night that the United States faced disaster if it failed to maintain unity with Western Europe against the threat of Communist aggression. He urged Americans to stop, quarreling among themselves and to follow a policy of cooperation and mutual aid at home and abroad.

TRENTON, May 4--The New Jersey Legislature ended its 1951 session tonight after denying Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll only a few of his legislative proposals.

COLUMBIA, Mo., May 4--John Cowles, president of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, deplored today the emotionalism of some American newspapers in the MacArthur-Truman situation and called for greater responsibility to preserve freedom of the press.

WASHINGTON, May 4--The American Council of Education, opening its thirty-fourth annual meeting today, installed as president Arthur Stanton Adams, succeeding George F. Zook, president for sixteen years.

Plans of the Columbia Broadcasting System to acquire the American Broadcasting Company for a reported price of $28,000,000 do not call for a reduction in the existing number of either radio or television networks, it was made known yesterday.

PATTERSON, N.Y., May 4-- Herbert M. Holton, for forty years a member of the faculty at City College in New York, until his retirement five years ago, and founder of the Reserve Officer Training Corps at the institution, died today at his home, Brimstone Farm, after a long illness. His age was 74.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 4 United States circles expressed confidence today that a proposal for economic sanctions against Communist China would be approved within two weeks by the Additional Measures Committee of the United Nations General Assembly. Thirty-four firemen, past and present members of the Fire Department's Division of Licensed Places of Public Assembly, were questioned yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's rackets staff.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4-- Sol Lesser, independent film producer, financier and theatre operator, has joined the syndicate headed by Louis R. Lurie of San Francisco which is negotiating the purchase of the Warner Brothers' 24 per cent interest in Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., Mr. Lesser disclosed today. He is expected to contribute $1,000,000 to the purchase price of $25,000,000.

The strengthening of family life in the United States is the objective of the ninth annual interfaith observance of National Family Week, which starts tomorrow. The theme is "Parents, Children and God."

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned quiet yesterday, and final prices were unchanged to 23 points net lower than on Thursday.

Three air raid sirens were sounded accidentally in lower Manhattan on four occasions yesterday afternoon. As a result the telephone switchboards at City Hall, Police Headquarters and newspapers were swamped with calls from anxious inquirers asking. If the alarms were air raid alerts.

A grant of $300,000 by the Ford Foundation to promote public education by radio was announced yesterday by Seymour N. Siegel, president of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters and director of New York City's radio station WNYC.

CHICAGO, May 4--Salesmen for steel warehouse companies were asked here today to take the lead in a national scrap drive to obtain increased supplies needed by steel mills and foundries throughout the country.

Prof. Harold Rugg, author of social studies textbooks that have been attacked in many parts of the country as "subversive," will retire on July 1 after thirty-one years on the faculty of Columbia University's Teachers College.

Members of the armed forces at fifty-seven overseas points soon will be able to see kinescope film recordings of television programs from the United States, according to a plan formulated by the four video networks and the Department of Defense. Recurrent minor waves of selling stalled the advance of the stock market yesterday. Sal Maglie pitched a one-hitter and his team-mates clouted four home runs as the Giants slipped back into winning gear with a 5-1 triumph over the Pirates at the Pole Grounds yesterday before a Ladies Day assemblage of 4,926.

Sugar trading threw off its Thursday scare over British purchases from Poland and Eastern Germany and prices climbed steadily in yesterday's market. The explanation that the 50,000-ton lot was merely a routine purchase under an old agreement was accepted.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 4 (AP)-- The little man with the little wallet and the big rent would have enjoyed a meeting here today. Builders were figuring ways to put up good low-cost rental housing.

WASHINGTON, May 4--United States imports from the twenty Latin-American Republics during 1950 climbed to a new high of $2,907,200,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. This reflects an increase of 25 per cent over the previous high of $2,351,000,000 in 1948.

New York City's parks are "neither safe nor adequately protected and maintained at the present time," Park Commissioner Robert Moses asserted yesterday in a letter to Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy.

Business on low-end and budget price dresses has picked up sharply in the market here, it was learned yesterday. CHARLES, Ill., May 6--The Illinois State Training School for Boys dedicated its new "all faith" chapel here today amid signs of growing recognition of its distinction as one of a small handful of state institutions for juvenile correction that operates on a thorough going philosophy of rehabilitation.

The Packard Motor Car Company reports earnings of $2,499,973 in the first quarter of this year after providing $3,477,000 for taxes, in contrast to a $259,586 loss sustained in the March quarter of 1950 after giving effect to a tax carryback refund of $161,000.
TRENTON, May 7 (UP)--State Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons today laid down regulations designed to keep big-time gamblers away from race tracks in New Jersey.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 7-- The Ohio House of Representatives tonight approved a bill to permit television of Ohio State University football games. The vote was 93 to 17. The measure now goes to the Senate.

LONDON, May 7-The Soviet Union's proposal tonight for a four-power meeting to draft a Japanese peace treaty was regarded here as a maneuver to split the Western allies and forestall a separate treaty between them and Japan. It posed a delicate problem for the British Government.
