HONG KONG, May 7-The rampaging Kan River, swollen by incessant heavy rains, has broken through dikes in Kiangsi and inundated thousands of acres of farmland.
Mrs. Alfred F. Hess will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 875 Park Avenue for Mrs. William Crawford White, president of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 7 (AP)--Warner Baxter, veteran motion-picture actor, died at his home tonight after a long illness. His age was 59. He had suffered from arthritis for years and a lobotomy was performed three weeks ago to alleviate his pain. Bronchial pneumonia set in recently.
Millard J. Friday Sr. has succeeded Robert L. Kielich as head of the E.W. Blatchford branch of the National Lead Company. Albert J. Monaco will assist in mannaging the brench's sales.
Erwin Knoll of 919 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, has been elected president of the Evening Students Organization at New York University's Washington

PANAMA, May 7--President Arnuito Arias tonight suspended Panama's Constitution which was adopted by the Constitutional Congress March 1, 1946, and restored by executive order the Constitution adopted in 1941 in a plebiscite in which only "yes" votes were available.

TOKYO, May 7 (AO)--Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgeway has commended the First Battalion of the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders, transferred recently from Korea to Hong Kong. The United Nations commander praised the Highlanders for their "heroic actions and achievements in Korea."

PHILADELPHIA, May 7--A motion calling on the United Gas Improvement Company to use about $2O,000,000 of Treasury securities for a capital distribution or to acquire outstanding shares of the company's capital stock was defeated at today's annual meeting of stockholders.

BOMBAY, India, Tuesday, May 8 (UP)--Twenty persons were injured early today when the police opened fire on a rioting mob in North Bombay.

The new State Crime Commission has been asked by the American Civil Liberties Union to include in its current inquiry investigation of police brutality and improper police action. The counsel and extensive files of the union have been offered to the commission.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)--The Senate played it fair. It gave the two famous generals the same treatment, right down to the welcoming committee.

STRASBOURG, France, May 7 --Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, chairman of the Council of Europe's Committee of Ministers, addressing the Consultative Assembly at its session here today, predicted that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Council of Europe might be merged at some time to create a European-Atlantic Union.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 7.--The management of the United States Steel Corporation won approval-- with only minor opposition--of its stock option incentive plan for key employes here today at the fiftieth annual meeting, attended by a record gathering of 605 stockholders.
WASHINGTON, May 7--The Secretary of Defense General of the Army George C. Marshall, testified under oath at the Senate inquiry today--as General of the Army Douglas MacArthur did last week.

WASHINGTON.May 7--Civilian defense leaders from across the country were told today their ability to organize cities and populations to recover from atomic attack without losing the will to fight might help deter any country considering war upon the United States.
Monroe Calculating Machine Company has arranged to borrow $5,000,000 privately from an institutional investor, W.G. Zaenglein,

PARIS, May 7--A recommendation has been submitted to the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions that, by a military alliance, the members of the North Atlantic pact should guarantee Turkey against aggression.
ST. PAUL, May 7 (AP)--The Stroh's bowlers from Detroit dominated today's session of the American Bowling Congress tournament, adding three first places to one already held.

Joseph Bancroft Son Company is preparing for volume production of a new textile finish that gives cotton the look and feel of wool, it was announced yesterday. The finish, named "Stazenu," will be featured in apparel for men, women and children.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 (UP)-- Plutonium, the major ingredient of the atomic bomb, now costs only half as much to produce as it did in 1946, George R. Prout, general ...

The ingenuity of American business soon may bring the current seller's market to an end, it was declared yesterday by F.C. Russell, president of the F.C. Russell Company. It makes metal window frames in Cleveland.

The volume of paper work in-- volved in complying with the new "tailored" ceiling price regulations of the Office of Price Stabilization is proving staggering to many merchants, particularly hardware ...
The chairman of the British Railways Executive, John Elliot, said yesterday that nationalization had saved the railroads of Britain $12,000,000 ($33,600,000) a year in operating costs.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)--The Attorney General, J. Howard McGrath, today announced he had completed arrangements to sell the old German Embassy mansion here for $165,000.

CALGARY, May 7(Canadian Press)--Production of crude oil in Alberta, during the last week in April was down more than 20,000 barrels daily. Daily average production for the week ended April 30 amounted to 60,904 barrels against a daily average of 82,061 the week before.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 7-- Israel has urged the Security Council to give top priority to her charge of "armed aggression in violation of the United Nations Charter" against Syria.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- Following is the censored transcript of today's hearing by the Senate Armed Services and Foreign Relations Committees into the Admivistration foreign policy. (Censorship deletions are indicated by * * *):

Fire confined to a furnished room on the top floor of a fivestory rooming house at 119 West Sixty-first Street killed its two occupants, a woman and a dog, early yesterday. The woman was identified as Mrs. Helen McCarthy, a widow, 56 years old.

The Mead Corporation announced yesterday the election of Howard E. Whitaker as executive vice president and director to succeed J.O. Mason, who retired but will continue in an advisory capacity to the paper manufacturing concern.

Piet, the sturdy horse owned by Peter A. Markey, demonstrated to a crowd of 25,916 fans at Jamaica yesterday that he just can't break a habit. The 6-year-old son of Grand Slam won the Jamaica Handicap for the third successive year.

The Governor of West Virginia wrote a letter yesterday in which he turned down Defense Mobilization Director Charles E. Wilson's request that the state postpone the sale of $67,500,000 of war veterans' bonus bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The Senate adopted by voice vote today the Mexican Farm Labor Importation Bill, with amendments that would penalize farmers who employed "wetbacks," illegal entrants who swim or wade across the Rio Grande River.
The last of seven Yugoslav-flag ships built in the Netherlands is now at sea on a maiden voyage from Amsterdam to American ports in the Gulf of Mexico.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 7 (AP) --Brig. Gen. Edward J. McGaw landed by air today with the first contingent of United States Army, Navy and Air Forces to help defend this North Atlantic republic. [The Defense Department in Washington said the force consisted of 200 men.]

A frightened police horse with steeplechasing instincts ran away yesterday after throwing its rider and damaged two automobiles in wild leaps during a dash from the north end of Central Park to Ninety-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.
George (Elbows) McFadden, who starred in the ring as a lightweight in the Eighteen Nineties and early Nineteen Hundreds, died on Sunday in a Long Island hospital after a long illness. His age was 79.

WASHINGTON May 7--Secretary of Defence George C. Marshall accused General of the Army Douglas MacArthur today of having destroyed, in violaition of orders, the only chance to date of negotiating an end to the Korean war.

The City Council adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution urging Congress to reject legislation that would result in a drastic curtailment of Federally-aided public housing construction here in the fiscal year 1951-52. The action has been approved by the House of Representatives.
The Women's Army Corps and the Women in the Air Force opened a national campaign here yesterday to recruit 70,000 young women into the two services.

Dr. Halfan Hebo, 41-year-old chemical engineer, was released from jail yesterday after promising that the daughter he had sent to relatives in Denmark during a custody hearing would be returned here within ninety days.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 8-- Properly selected and timed equity investments can add to the overall rate of return provided by portfolios of mutual savings banks, as of other institutions, without material increase in risk, Dr. Jules I. Bogen, Professor of Finance at New York University, said here today.

The American Merchant Marine's first superliner, the United States, which is expected to bring back to this country the mythical "Blue Ribbon of the Atlantic," emblematic of the merchant ship speed championship, will be launched on June 23 at the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)-- Subject to approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission, an agreement was reported reached today calling for the Jersey Central Power and Light Company to dispose of its gas properties.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 8--In an attempt to save its holdings in Iran from imminent expropriation, the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company served notice today of its request for arbitration under the terms of the 1933 concession agreement.

"Stalag 17" sounds grim, and so is the headlong play of that title which opened at the Forty-eighth Street yesterday afternoon. The title refers to a German war prison-camp where the authors, Donald Bevan and Edmund Trzcinski, spent two captive years.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The disputed limitation in the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill relating to the price payable for Government-requisitioned ships has received the approval of Controller General Lindsay C. Warren.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested nine more tugboat men of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Maritime Division yesterday on charges of looting freight cars and stealing goods worth $150,000.
In all the complicated meat pricing regulations there is one fact easy to understand and welcome. Beginning next Friday, virtually all meat except pork must be Federally graded as to quality.

Hank Sauer's two-run homer in the first inning and skillful pitching by Bob Schultz tumbled the Dodgers to a 2-1 defeat at Ebbets Field yesterday in the opening contest of a three-game series with the Cubs.
PARIS, May 8--The Assembly of the French Union observed a minute of silence today in memory of Willie McGee, Negro who was executed in Mississippi shortly after midnight for rape.
Only one district team seemed assured of retaining its title as the third phase of play was Concluded yesterday in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub matches.
Commodity markets in New York were generally stronger yesterday. Wool stiffened at the close on rumors of Washington action but other markets advanced on trade developments alone.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8-- Farmers of Southern California are beginning to feel the economic effects of a new "get-tough" policy of the Federal Government, announced a week ago, that is designed to stamp out the illegal employment of Mexican "wetbacks."

CHICAGO, May 8--A plea for "more practical and more realistic" plans for redeveloping existing cities, and for more accurate estimates on the part of architects and builders on future construction project costs, was made here today by Charles Luckman, former industrialist who has turned to architecture.

DANBURY, Conn., May 8-- George J. Schoen, police chief here for twenty-eight years and one of Connecticut's most prominent military leaders, died today in Danbury Hospital after a long illness. His age was 66.

DALLAS, Tex., May 8 (AP)-- Shortages of natural gas in some of the nation's large cities next winter were predicted today by a Government spokesman. He said they might be severe enough to "adversely affect defense production."

Maj. Gen. Courtney Whitney, press spokesman for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, disagreed yesterday with Mrs. Marguerite V. Shea, a real estate broker of Stamford, Conn., on reports of General MacArthur's house hunting.

The volume of freight moving in the forty-six ships of the companyowned fleet of cargo vessels of the United States Lines Company has increased steadily in a few months, John M. Franklin, president, has informed shareholders in the annual report for 1950.
CHICAGO, May 8--Judge Michael L. McKinley, who had been on the Cook County (Chicago) Superior Court bench continuously since 1911, died today in his home of a heart ailment. He was 78 years old.

ALBANY, May 8--Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding general of the New York National Guard, urged today that all employers in the state cooperate in releasing their workers who were members of the guard for summer field training.

The State of Michigan borrowed $65,000,000 yesterday in the public market through hospital and penal institution construction bonds due on May 1, 1952, to May 1, 1971, at an interest cost of 1.5696 per cent.

Operating costs have risen sharply at Mount Sinai Hospital since the beginning of the Korean conflict last June, Alfred L. Rose, hospital president, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Gov. Earl Warren warned today that a world conspiracy existed with the United States the main object of its wrath, and he called for an intensified "great crusade" by those enlisted in the task of civil defense.

Color is the keynote in jewelry for the summer days ahead. It is used in many ways, but it is most prevalent in the multitude of glass and porcelain beads, either opaque or crystal, in a myriad of shapes. While color predominates, chalk white has made a very favorable appearance in many styles.

LONDON, May 8--The British Industries Fair has much that will interest the housewife--mother and woman of fashion--who has either the stamina for long miles of walking or, as Queen Mary had when she visited the huge exhibition, a wheel chair.

BOSTON, May 8 (AP)--Sid Gordon's ninth-inning homer tonight gave the Braves a 2-1 victory over the Reds at the expense of Herman Wehmeier. The Cincinnati hurler and Boston's Max Surkont, who won his fourth game, each allowed six hits.

Negotiations opened yesterday afternoon for a new contract between the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., and East and Gulf Coast steamship operators, with the latter rejecting two of the union's principal demands.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8--Walter S. Franklin, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, told the annual meeting today that the carrier plans to place orders, probably this week, for an additional 132 Diesel electric locomotives costing $45,000,000.

NEW DELHI, India, May 8-- Following a reported breakdown in the administration of the neighboring Himalayan Kingdom of Nepal, Maharaj Mohum Shumshere, Nepalese Prime Minister, will arrive here tomorrow for an interview with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

Elevator operators and other service employes struck yesterday in 100 downtown commercial buildings, but they returned to work so quickly that few of the tenants had a chance to develop sore feet. Only five of the strikes were still in progress last night.

The May Department Stores Company and its subsidiaries attained the highest sales and earnings in their history in the fiscal year ended with last January, according to the annual report of Morton J. May, president, mailed to stockholders today.
LONDON, May 8--The British Government announced today two further steps to speed up its rearmament and to divert critical industrial machinery from civilian to defense production.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (AP)-- Mel Queen limited the Phillies to two hits in seven innings tonight while the Pirates pounded Ken Heintzelman and Milo Candini for ten and a 9-3 victory over the National League champions. One of the Pirates' blows was a homer by Ralph Kiner.

The feature at the Jamaica race track yesterday, the sixfurlong Clearview, was run in two divisions, with Jet Fleet, owned by Fred Hooper, taking the first half and Definitely of the Braeburn Farm capturing the second.

Mayor Impellitteri presented the Automobile Club of New York's distinguished service medals yesterday to three youngsters for heroism while on duty with school safety patrols in this city. All three saved children from death or injury by oncoming vehicles.

New Jersey voters cut sharply yesterday into the prestige and political power of Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City, Democratic leader of Hudson County, by electing anti-Kenny candidates in commission government elections in four Hudson communities.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Dollars and-cents ceilings on ferrotungsten and other tungsten products, both domestic and imported, were established today by the Office of Price Stabilization.

CHICAGO, May 8--Wheat had an irregular trend today but there was a firm undertone. Professionals were inclined to mark time pending the Government report for May, due Thursday. Reports of high winds and dust storms in Kansas and Oklahoma caused a little buying, but this rally failed to hold.

Efforts to enlarge the program of the League of Women Voters of New York State to include the safeguarding of civil liberties and a study of sex crimes were defeated yesterday at the opening of its biennial convention at the Henry Hudson Hotel.
CHICAGO, May 8--A ray of hope that consumers in the East and other parts of the country might eventually purchase hams and other pork cuts at still lower prices than at present appeared here today.

Don't look now, but New York City may be getting some parking meters at last. Traffic Commissioner Reid announces that he has asked the city's Purchase Department to buy 1,500 meters, which will be placed at the curbs in test areas in four boroughs, including Manhattan.
BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP)--Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro led Baltimore's Democrats to another total victory in the city's election today. No Republican has been elected to a municipal post since 1943.
Approved by 10 to 0 with Russia abstaining, a joint resolution presented by United States, Britain, Turkey and France, calling for halt to fighting along SyrianIsraeli border.
The Right Ree. Horace W.B. Donegan urged yesterday a reorganization of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, to promote coordination of its functions.

Brooklyn's racket-investigating grand jury handed up yesterday in Kings County Court a sealed indictment charging sixty-five to seventy present and former members of the Police Department with participation in a conspiracy to obstruct justice.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 8-- A high Government spokesman said today that local press censorship would continue "only as a formality" during the coming political campaigns.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 8--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower spent the sixth anniversary of V-E Day at his job of building a North Atlantic defense force and made clear that he had no intention of being diverted from this task by calls to Washington, Strasbourg or anywhere else.

WASHINGTON, May 8--President Truman celebrated his sixtyseventh birthday today, and one of his presents was a public declaration by the Democratic National Chairman that a majority of party leaders hoped he would be a candidate for re-election in 1952 because they believed he would win.
Maximilian Moss and Vito F. Lanza were re-elected yesterday to their third one-year terms as president and vice president, respectively, of the Board of Education.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Hazard Brown of 163 East Eighty-first Street of the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Laura Hazard, to A. Philippe Montant of New York, son of Mrs. Anderton Montant of New York and of Louis T. Montent of Ridgewood, N.J.

Forty-seven cars of a 143-car Pennsylvania Railroad freight train were derailed yesterday afternoon just east of New Brunswick, N.J., blocking all four tracks of the main line and causing... train delays of from two to three hours.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 8 --The West German Government plans to test the constitutionality of the Socialist Reich party, the strongest neo-Nazl party, before the Federal Constitutional Court.

WASHINGTON, May 8--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was accused today of harming the Allied position in Korea by emphasizing the casualties among United States troops and by implying that they were dying "without justified purpose."

WASHINGTON, May 8--The deep split in the American body politic, exemplified by the current Senate hearings in the "great debate," has its own major counterpart in the armed services-- particularly in the Army, today's testimony by Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall made amply clear.
WASHINGTON, May 8--The newly constituted eighteen-member Wage Stabilization Board planned a broad attack on a backlog of 1,100 cases at its first meeting today.
BUENOS AIRES, May 8-- Diego Baamonde, secretary-general of the pro-Government Newspaper Men's Union, said last night La Prensa would be reopened soon as "a daily for Argentine workers."

In endless procession on any arraignment day in the Federal Courts for the Southern and Eastern Districts of New York, youthful narcotic addicts--numbed, stupified, bewildered and looking not at all like criminals--are brought before the bar.
A soft-spoken grandmother who likes to play a little baseball now and then with the youngsters living in her home was honored yesterday as the city's foster mother of the year.
Norman Thomas, veteran Socialist leader, said yesterday he was "in the Truman-Marshall corner" in the debate over foreign policy.

A concert of contemporary music for chamber orchestra was played last night in McMillin Theatre, Columbia University. It was organized by the New Music Society, of New Music Editions, which felt that some worthwhile material from the 'Twenties was unduly neglected and that it would sound well in combination with certain more recent compositions.

A man can have, or can work for or dream about, a good many satisfactory possessions. A bank statement showing an end-of the-month balance of three-quarters of a million might be regarded with satisfaction, although naturally the full million would be ostentatious.

"The gentlemen in charge of the bureau prefer 'education' and 'cooperation' to enforcement with penalties." This is the conclusion reached as to the city's Bureau of Smoke Control by the Citizens Committee for Smoke Control, which is now mailing out to thousands of New York residents an intelligently written and arousing pamphlet that tells of the damage to health and property that comes from air pollution.

REPORTS from the salt water front are improving every day, and although the striped bass and weakfish are slow in arriving in real numbers, the pollock are very plentiful off Montauk and thousands of mackerel are being taken.

Two museum displays open to the public today--the sixteenth biennial international water-color exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum and a show of the work in all media acquired by the Whitney in the period 1947-50, inclusive.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8--The American Friends Service Committee called today for a "rightabout face" by the Truman Administration to provide a new approach to disarmament, more reliance on negotiation and mutual aid, and the strengthening of the United Nations.

THE university was situated in its own compound near a small village on the great North China plain. A bus ride to the south east was the city, presumably Peking. The students were Chinese and so were all the members of the faculty except Andrew Girard, a young American who taught Shakespeare, who wore Chinese clothes and spoke Chinese.

RUMSON, N.J., May 8--Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Register Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cornelia Elizabeth, to Porter Hoagland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoagland of 21 East Sixty-sixth Street, New York, and Rumson.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Senate Democrats took over two additional seats on key committees today. One was the Committee on Appropriations, where the Democratic advantage was changed from 11 to 10 to 12 to 9. The other was the Committee on Banking and Currency, where the ratio shifted from 7 to 6 to 8 to 5.

LAKE SUCCESS, May 8--The United Nations Security Council today called on the "parties or persons concerned" in the SyrianIsraeli dispute to cease fighting. The vote was unanimous except for a Soviet abstention.

Issuance by the Office of Price Stabilization on Monday of a special order permitting producer exporters to fulfill certain contracts without the restriction of the general price "freeze" of Jan. 26, last, caused confusion and concern among traders yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)-- Veterans and service men under 40 years old with National Service Life Insurance term policies are being paid a dividend of 50 cents a month for each $1,000 of insurance.

WASHINGTON, May 8--For the first time since 1933 the Treasury Department passed up a chance today to call a bond issue for redemption at the first opportunity. The issue on which the call opportunity was passed is one of 2 per cent bonds issued in 1913 and due on Sept. 15, 1953, upon which the outstanding total is $7,986,262,500.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 8-- Through its Acting Chief of Staff in the field the United Nations submitted today to Israel and Syria a five-point formula for a truce in the border fighting between the two countries. In polite but sharp language, Israel rejected the proposals.
BOONE, Iowa, May 8 (AP)--A public school teacher who declined to comply with a school board suggestion that he take his son out of a Catholic parochial school is out of a job here.

Two arrests on charges of criminally receiving stolen property were made in the Bronx yesterday as a sequel to Monday's wild downtown chase in which one pedestrian was killed and three others injured by a car in which two men suspected of stealing parcel post packages escaped from postal inspectors and the police.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 8 (AP) --Four Negroes have appealed to the United States Supreme Court a Federal court ruling that permitted them to enter the University of Tennessee but that did not enjoin the university from refusing to admit Negroes.
The proposal of Acting City Council President Joseph T. Sharkey for a 1 per cent tax on the incomes of non-residents employed in the city was laid before City Council yesterday.

Many dinner parties were given last night at the formal opening of the Ritz-Carlton Restaurant in Carlton House on Madison Avenue between Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets. The restaurant, designed in the Adam period, is built on two levels.

CINCINNATI, May 8 (AP)--Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler today denied a plea by four Michigan members of the Class A Central League for $40,000 of the money paid to the Detroit Tigers for radio broadcasting rights.

CHICAGO, May 8--The American Institute of Architects today called on the Government to clarify its policies with respect to future private building operations and to specify "at once" the approximate amount of nondefense construction which will be permitted to proceed in 1952.

HONOLULU, May 8--Oren E. Long, educator and more recently Secretary of Hawaii, was inaugurated today as Governor of Hawaii in front of Iolani Palace. He pledged that he would fight for Hawaiian statehood and to stamp out communism.

PAMPLONA, Spain, May 8 --Civil guardsmen fired tommy guns into the air tonight to halt demonstrations of strikers in Pamplona.

LONDON, May 8--Prices fell in the stock markets here today and profit-taking increased. The declines, however, generally were small, especially compared with recent rises.

Asserting that deficit spending was the heart of inflation, John G. Forrest, financial editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday that unless the Government demonstrated its ability to sacrifice nonessential spending programs it could not expect the American people to tighten their belts with any enthusiasm.

Truck, bus and passenger-car traffic on the Boston Post Road, an important New York-New England highway, was tangled severely yesterday noon, when 100 mothers from the Pelham Parkway area blocked the roadway at Waring Avenue.
ROME, May 8--Italian labor unions today asserted that the nationwide twenty-four-hour strike of 1,100,000 state employes had been 90 per cent successful, Government ...

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 9-- United Nations forces pushed ahead on all sectors of the Korean front yesterday, meeting little resistance from the Communist invaders, pulling back after the breakdown of their vaunted spring offensive.
WASHINGTON, May 8--David Ben-Gurion, Prime Minister of Israel, pledged his country today to the full support of "every measure which strengthens world peace and opposes aggression."
LONDON, May 8--King Frederik and Queen Ingrid of Denmark arrived here today, adding more flavor to the Festival of Britain with the first state visit by a Danish sovereign to this country since 1914.
Enemies of modern education were charged by the Public Education Association last night with subjecting the nation's schools to a growing barrage of irresponsible attacks.

Three Staten Island brothers gave information yesterday to the State Crime Commission after their uncle, a waterfront labor official, balked at testifying and brought suit in Supreme Court to challenge the commission's authority.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)--A final Government report today increased the 1950 cotton crop estimate by 148,000 bales, leaving it the fourth smallest in twenty-five years and far short of needs.

Paeans of praise to the pretzel were sung in the august House of Representatives the other day by Representative Dague, Republican of Pennsylvania. He reminded the House that today the American pretzel is ninety years old, and called the event an important anniversary in the industrial and social life of the nation.

Last week when the United States presented to the United Nations a resolution calling for an arms embargo on Communist China the proposal had a cold and critical reception from Great Britain, Australia and other nations opposed from the first to applying sanctions to the aggressor in the Korean war.

FRANK FRISCH, the noted horticulturist, was relaxing in a chair on the front lawn of his ancestral acres in New Rochelle yes terday morning. He gazed affectionately on the copper beech tree, the Japanese maples, the azalea bushes, the magnolia and the burgeoning flowers. There was a rapt look in his eyes, almost as if each was a .300 hitter or twenty-game winner.
A collection of murals and a group of new wallpapers are on view at Murals, Inc., 501 Madison Avenue. This shop is a showroom for designers James Seeman and James Patton.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The testimony of Secretary of Defense Marshall has created one impression that is regarded here by persons familiar with the circumstances as unfair to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

Out of the National League cellar moved the Giants behind Larry Jansen's four-hit, 6-2 victory over the Cardinals before 20,379 fans at the Polo Grounds last night. Simultaneously, Marty Marion's men fell out of first place, yielding the lead to the Braves.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 8--Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, predicted tighter credit controls today, as he promised to be "tough" about achieving stability for the country.

The Washington Square Outdoor Art Show, which spring and fall takes over on Greenwich Village streets, had its semi-annual opening yesterday on schedule for the first time in two years. It didn't rain, but artists with sharp memories of a procession of previous washouts, kept their canvases off the streets, just in case.

Seymour M. Tannenbaum, operator, has purchased the two fivestory store and apartment building at 714 and 718 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, from Oscar Ruff. The buildings, on a plot 45 by 90 feet at the corner of Wales Avenue, contain six stores and twenty apartments. Jacob Schulman and Awid Wechsier were the brokers.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy the attraction is "I'd Climb the Highest Mountain," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama, with Susan Hayward and William Lundigan. Henry King directed and Lamar Trotti adapted and ...

BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP)--Missing the track record by only onefifth of a second, Alan T. Clarke's Senator Joe scampered five and a half furlongs in 1:06 3/5 to win the Display Purse, featured sixth race at Pimlico today.

After an ownership of a few days, the four-story building containing two stores and five apartments at 1113 Lexington Avenue, adjoining the southeast corner of Seventy-eighth Street, has ben resold by Frederick Brown to Roy Foster in a deal negotiated by Rose Bratter, broker. Benjamin F. Foster was the attorney for the buyer and Joshua Bernstein for Mr. Brown.
DETROIT, May 8--Vic Wertz, pulling away in self defense from a pitch in the eleventh inning, accidentally struck a single that gave the Tigers a 6-5 victory over the Yanks before 11,653 fans today.
STRASBOURG, France, May 8-- The scarcity of raw materials and its effects on rearmament and inflation were the principal topics of debate today in the Council of Europe.

A syndicate of investment bankers headed by Stone Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $10,000,000 of $100 par value 5.10 per cent cumulative dividend preferred stock of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 8--A serious flight of capital from Europe is endangering the functioning of the European Payments Union.

Title to the blockfront on the east side of Madison Avenue between East Seventy-seventh and Seventy-eighth Streets has passed to Maurice Epstein, who bought the property from the Charles Gulden Estate. It is assessed at close to $1,000,000 and was sold in a deal negotiated by Louis Carreau, Inc., broker.

The stock market reversed its trend yesterday but gains proved highly selective, with the greatest force supplied by the chemicals. In fact the advance of the chemicals was almost independent of the remainder of the list and accounted for a rise of 0.91 point in the composite rate.

Co-starring Judy Holliday, the Broadway actress who walked off with moviedom's coveted emblem --the Academy Award--and Don DeFore, who has been absent from the New York stage since "The Male Animal" (1940), "Dream Girl" will be escorted into the City Center at 8 o'clock this evening.

An eighteen-family garden apartment house at 33-35 Prospect Street, Great Neck, L.I. has been sold by Andrew Callan to John White and James Wisnause. Thomas O'Connell Sons and Walter O'Melia were the brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
James J. Moran, former Water Supply Commissioner and close friend of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, was convicted of perjury in Federal Court here yesterday.

The establishment of an agency committee to act on the applications by steamship companies for agency, general agency or berth agency agreements with the Government was announced yesterday by the National Shipping Authority.

A men's suiting fabric made of the new Dacron fiber and wool will be introduced this summer, it was announced jointly yesterday by Deering, Milliken Co., Inc., and Hart Schaffner Marx. In the initial promotion, 4,000 lightweight suits will be available for the New York area through Wallachs, Inc., retail, clothiers, at $79.50.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Representative John Kee, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, died of a heart attack today during a meeting of the committee. He was 76 years of age.

The new general manufacturers pricing order, Ceiling Price Regulation 22, effective May 28, will be strenuously opposed by many business interests, Dr. Julius Hirsch, consulting economist, predicted yesterday. He spoke before a meeting of the Floor Covering Distributors Council in the Statler Hotel.
JONES BEACH, L.I., May 8-- Visitors to Jones Beach this summer will find a new oceanfront parking field, a longer boardwalk, a bigger beach shop and other improvements costing $1,375,000.
The Metropolitan Opera Association and the New York Philharmonic Society have been invited to construct a modern music center in Columbus Circle.

BIRKDALE, England, May 8 (AP) --Bitter weather, more fitting for December than May, hampered both British and United States Walker Cup golfers today as they stumbled through thirty-six holes of practice.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced the reshuffling today of the cast of two pictures, "Ivanhoe" and "Scaramouche." Elizabeth Taylor was named to replace Deborah Kerr as Rebecca in "Ivanhoe," with Robert Taylor, Miss Kerr having ...
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 8 (AP)-- Two Moline, Ill., bowlers, Gerry Anderson and Penny Spaulding, took second place in doubles of the American Bowling Congress tournament today with a total of 1,320.
The stock market built up a moderate amount of momentum yesterday under the leadership of the railroad issues. Profit-taking in the final hour reduced the gains and left the list only irregularly

The nation's supplies of gasoline declined 1,710,000 barrels to 135,764,000 last week, from 137,474,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline supplies a year ago were 127,431,000 barrels.

Verdi's "La Traviata" led off the Salmaggi Opera Company's nineperformance series in Carnegie Hall last night. The Brooklyn organization has brought opera to this auditorium in other seasons and has presented open-air performances during the summer in Triborough Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 9 Better high-school instruction in economic problems was emphasized as an urgent need today in speeches and workshop sessions of the national conference of the Joint Council on Economic Education.

ALBANY, May 9 The Appellate Division, Third Department, of the State Supreme Court, unanimously affirmed today the action of the State Board of Regents in revoking the license of the Italian motion picture, "The Miracle," on the ground that it way sacrilegious.

WASHINGTON, May 9 Failure of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization staff to defend sufficiently the United Nations in its program against aggression in Korea was charged by Dr. Luther Evans, Librarian of Congress and United...

TEHERAN, Iran, May 9 Last ditch British efforts to keep the door open to further negotiations in the dispute over the rights of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company appeared to have come to naught, judging from today's pronouncements by Iranian leaders.
TRENTON, May 9 (AP) One of the six defendants in the Trenton murder trial testified today he knew nothing about the killing of a Trenton shopkeeper.

PARIS, May 9 Deliveries of military equipment and supplies from the United States have enabled the French forces in IndoChina to repel attacks of the rebel Vietminh army and to win important offensive actions in the last five months, Jean Letourneau Minister for the Associated States said today.

Exactly three years since it closed its long run at the St. James Theatre, the fabulous "Oklahoma!" will return to the local scene for a limited engagement of five weeks. The Theatre Guild musical, which brought fame and fortune to the team of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, will open at the Broadway Theatre on May 29.

Only four persons were heard yesterday by the City Council finance committee at its statutory public hearing on the 1951-52 budget of $1,336,400,575 adopted on April 20 by the Board of Estimate. Three speakers called for reduction of the budget and the fourth asked that it be modified to provide larger pay rises for city employes.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 9 The awful fate of the tropical fish fancier who increases the ichthyological population too rapidly and then is forced, in self-defense, to become a commercial breeder, was presented in court here today.
Richard J. Madden, international play broker and authors' representative, died Tuesday night in Roosevelt Hospital, where he had undergone a series of operations. His age was 71.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 9 (AP) Christians were urged today to reject any good they might find in communism because it "is an entering wedge for evil," said the Rev. Dr. John C. Bennett, Professor of Christian Ethics at Union Theological Seminary.

The State Crime Commission dug deeper yesterday into Staten Island waterfront crime and gambling and conferred with an attorney of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, which had questioned witnesses about the same matters more than a month ago.

A subtle, creeping paralysis of freedom of thought and speech is attacking college campuses in many parts of the country, limiting both students and faculty in the area traditionally reserved for the free exploration of knowledge and truth.
CINCINNATI, May 9 Histamine, held recently to show much promise in the treatment of mental illness, was reported today to have doubtful value.

Sales of the Celanese Corporation of America in the first quarter of this year increased $10,315,330 to a record $63,537,932 from the $53,222,602 volume in the 1950 quarter, but the net income declined because of larger taxes.

Twenty thousand dollars' worth of jewels disappeared from the penthouse apartment of Mrs. Edith Forschner, 30 East Thirty-seventh Street, during the past three days, the police of the East Thirty-fifth Street station reported last night. They added that they would question forty employes and tradesmen.
TOLEDO, Ohio, May 9 The University of Toledo awarded three honorary degrees at inauguration ceremonies today for President Asa S. Knowles.

It is to be hoped that Secretary Acheson's sharp statement on the deadlock of the Big Four deputies in Paris does not mean that the American Government will move to adjourn the meeting. The Secretary of State is right in declaring that after ten weeks of backing and filling the conference is just where it started.
Newsprint mills of Canada and the United States will be able to turn out more than 6,500,000 tons of newsprint this year, or about 200,000 tons more than in 1950.

WASHINGTON, May 9-- The House Ways and Means Committee approved a $2,950,000,000 increase in individual income taxes today as the first major step in preparing a multi-billion-dollar revenue bill to help pay for rearmament.

A "chain of amendments" will be needed to make the new Ceiling Price Regulation 31 on imports realistic, it was declared yesterday by Harry S. Radcliffe, executive vice president of the National Council of American Importers.

PHATDIEM, Tongking, Indochina, May 4 Two Vietnamese Roman Catholic Bishops are leaders of the Church, the Army and the state in the war against Communism in this remote fertile coastal part of the Red River delta seventy-five miles southwest of Haiphong.
One thousand union leaders honored Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Thirty representatives of civic, religious, and welfare societies organized an emergency committee yesterday to combat pending legislation that would virtually end Federal funds for public housing for a year.
An electronic device designed to speed up the detection of internal cancers at early stages of growth was demonstrated here last night.

The Police Department's decision to abolish two park precincts was described as "false economy" yesterday by the Park Association of New York City, Inc. Telegrams opposing the move were sent to Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy and Mayor Impellitteri.

A pioneer medical project, aimed at keeping persons well rather than waiting until illness strikes, got under way yesterday at Montefiore Hospital.

STRASBOURG, France, May 9 By a large majority the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe rejected a proposal today to invite General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to be present at the Assembly's debate Saturday on the defense of Europe.
Establishment yesterday of new wool price ceilings 7 per cent below the old and 19 to 23 per cent above the current market left the wool trade bewildered.
DETROIT, May 9 (AP) Hal Newhouser of the Tigers scattered seven hits to shut out the Senators, 4 0, today and win his second game of the season.
A two-class fare structure for air carriers flying the Atlantic between the United States and Europe would be looked upon with favor by the Civil Aeronautics Board, it was learned here yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 9-- Dr. Ernst Reuter, Social Democratic Mayor of Free Berlin, gave qualified support to the Schuman Plan for the integration of Europe's heavy industries tonight, although it is still anathema to his party leader, Dr. Kurt Schumacher.

WASHINGTON, May 9 By an aggressive effort to reduce waste, the newspaper industry should be able to get enough newsprint to meet its needs this year, the National Production Authority told the industry advisory committee today.

Locking the door of the shoe store, the old gentleman walked through the twilight last evening to Grand Central, there to celebrate in the Oyster Bar fifty-five years of commuting from Tarrytown. He dined alone, yet he wasn't lonely.

CHICAGO, May 9 American cities must Step up tha tempo of decentralization of factories and homes sharply or face disastrous consequences of congestion in case of atomic attack, the nation's architects were warned today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 President Truman received a "United Nations" piano as a present today, promptly played a brief informal concert and lectured a group of music lovers on the kind of good selections he likes to hear.
WASHINGTON, May 9 President Truman sent a personal message last Jan. 13 to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur explaining why there must be "great prudence" so as not to widen the Korean fighting.

THE first really interesting report on the landlocked salmon fishing in Maine arrived from two New Yorkers, Gil Paust and John Schildknecht, who seem to have discovered something of an angler's haven and heaven at East Grand Lake.
VIENNA, May 9 (AP) West Germany will take part in the 1952 Olympic Games, Otto Mayer, Olympic general secretary, declared today.
Eight hundred employes of Borough President John Cashmore's office crowded into the Brooklyn Red Cross Center, 57 Willoughby Street, yesterday to give blood for the armed forces in Korea.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 16 points higher to 2 points lower than on Tuesday.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 9 (AP) The Florida Legislature was asked today to investigate one of the state's major daily newspapers for "violent attacks upon public officials."
An art-lending service for members of the Museum of Modern Art is being set up and is expected to be an established fact by fall.

T.M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Flemington, N.J., yesterday that the company is carrying out a $250,000,000 five-year expansion plan and has arranged to borrow up to $40,000,000 from the General Motors Corporation.

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, May 9 (UP) United States officers who have served with the South Korean Army said today that Korea's "slave nation psychology" had caused first-class outfits to break and run under enemy fire.
CHICAGO, May 9 The highest prices for wheat today were set in the early part of the session, after which the demand turned slow and prices dragged irregularly downward.

PARIS, May 9 Frocks exquisite in freshness, with dramatically full skirts lengthened slightly to almost cover the calf, are dedicated by Jacques Fath to the coming festivities connected with the two thousandth birthday of Paris.

To the tune of "Give My Regards to Broadway," a dress rehearsal of the first United Service Organizations unit of Camp Shows, Inc., bound for Korea to entertain service men was run off yesterday at the Malin Studio, 225 West Fortysixth Street.

The Giants staged their most impressive offensive of the campaign at the Polo Grounds yesterday as they crushed the flu-ridden Cardinals, 17 to 3, for their second successive triumph of the threegame series.
CLEVELAND, May 9 Ed Lopat's southpaw pitching wizardry and his batting prowess led the Yankees to a 9 2 victory over the Indians tonight at Municipal Stadium.

To instant tea and instant coffee the Nestle Company now adds another instant a chicken bouillon cube that goes into solution immediately. All of which recently inspired the bon mot; "Take Nettle's, for instance."

WASHINGTON, May 9 The House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries appeared to be balking today at a move to give President Truman authority to write new maritime rules of the road for the prevention of collision between vessels.
The Office of Price Stabilization "cracked down" yesterday on five alleged violators of its regulations.

HONG KONG, Thursday, May 10 Seven hundred and nineteen persons, charged with being "counter-revolutionaries," were liquidated by Communist firing squads in East China on April 29 and 30, according to official mainland reports that reached here today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 President Truman declared today that the present tendency of Americans to relax their efforts with each lull in hostilities is harder to overcome than Communist aggression or economic inflation.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP)-- Irish Bob Murphy, free-swinging light-heavyweight from San Diego, tonight scored a spectacular knockout over Danny Nardico of Tampa, Fla., in the fourth round of their scheduled ten-rounder in Chicago Stadium.

CHICAGO, May 9 As Office of Price Stabilization ceilings on beef sold at wholesale became effective today, reports reaching the Chicago stock yards indicated that a vast black market would develop in steaks, roasts and other cuts if the Government's price program were carried through.

WASHINGTON, May 9-- Dollars-and-cents ceiling prices for standard grades of wool were set by the Office of Price Stabilization today. The order, which is effective at once, sets prices at levels 63 to 70 per cent above those prevailing before the outbreak of the Korean war, officials of the agency conceded.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer to investors today a new issue of $33,600,000 of Rock Island Hydro-Electric System electric revenue bonds of Public Utility District No. 1 of Chelan County, Wash.

City College gained revenge yesterday for an early-season defeat by routing New York University, 17 to 4, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Babe Ruth Field, Bronx. Mel Norman, the Beavers' left-handed ace, went all the way for his fourth triumph against one defeat.

An increase in efforts by private individuals and public officials to impose political censorship on the book publishing industry was charged last night by Donald Klopfer, chairman of the censorship committee of the Book Publishers Council.

A canvass of agencies and distillers yesterday indicated no drop in schedules for liquor advertising this summer, whether or not the Government asks the distillers to suspend actual production of whisky in the interest of grain conservation.
When the Philharmonic-Symphony started its two-week, fourconcerts-a-day engagement yesterday at the Roxy Theatre, events followed a pattern not unlike those of last fall, when the series was opened.

SIX years ago, when the baseball folk were seeking a commissioner, there was one man who would have been perfect for the job, Edward Grant Barrow. But Cousin Ed requested that his name be withdrawn from consideration.

That annual housekeeping chore, storing fabrics for the summer so that they are protected from moth damage, might be made lighter for the homemaker by the use of some new products.

DARIEN, Conn., May 9 Miss Emma P. Hirth, retired general secretary of the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association, died yesterday in her home here, 424 Boston Post Road, after a long illness.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 9 In Israel's decorated and festooned streets there was dancing tonight to celebrate the third anniversary of the state's founding. Brass bands mounted on trucks cruised the streets of major towns.

BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) Qualifying for the $75,000 added Preakness Stakes to be run on May 19, the Brookmeade Stable's Bold scored an easy victory in the Jacobus Purse, Pimlico's featured sixth race today, when he went a mile and a sixteenth in 1:45.
The market for Government securities had another sinking shell yesterday on exchanges of light volume, with prices going below the previous low market levels of late April.

Testimony in the $4,000,000 lawsuit by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation against the Cleveland investment banking concern of Otis Co. was devoted yesterday to depositions concerning the salability of Kaiser-Frazer amtomobiles.

Friends and admirers of Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State, have established in his name an educational foundation to promote world peace and good will through an international scholarship program.

The Warner brothers will remain in the motion-picture business and retain their stock holdings in Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., Harry M. Warner, president of the company, said yesterday in announcing the cancellation of negotiations with a syndicate headed by Louis R. Lurie, San Francisco financing and real estate operator.

CINCINNATI, May 10--Experiments with drugs that create mental disorder in a normal person and make a mentally ill person even sicker were described today by Dr. Paul H. Hoch, chief of research of the Psychiatric Institute of New York. The experiments were performed to further the understanding of-mental illness, he explained.

Next Wednesday night's premiere of "Courtin' Time" at the National has been canceled. Because of various factors, no one was in a position yesterday to say definitely when the James RussoMichael Ellis musical would arrive here. Realizing that his throat had not had sufficient time to heal,...
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)-- Baseball's long-time problem--the "reserve clause"--will come up once again next month, in a Congressional investigation of the club owners' hold on players.

VIENNA, May 10--Declaring that their soldiers had the right to be where they were and had fired only in self defense, the Rusaians have withdrawn from the joint investigation that was to have been made into the fatal shooting in Vienna's Inner City May 4 of Corp. Paul J. Gresena of Rochester, N. Y.

The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation has acquired a 49 per cent interest in the Chase Aircraft Company of West Trenton, N.J., through a purchase of stock from the company, it was announced jointly yesterday by Michael Stroukoff, president of Chase, and Edgar Kaiser, president of the automotive company.

HOLLYWOOD, May 10--Philip Waxman, Broadway stage producer whose initial motion-picture venture will be a screen version of Stanley Ellin's 1948 novel, "The Dreadful Summit," announced today that he has borrowed John Barrymore Jr. from George Templeton to play the role of the son in the film. Joseph Losey, who, with Ellin, has written the screen adaptation of the novel, will direct the picture.
TULSA, Okla., May 10--The Republican convention site committee tonight recommended Chicago as the host city for the 1952 Presidential nominating convention and set July 21 as the opening date.

A campaign to collect clothing, medicines and food for the 20,000 families made homeless by the earthquake that struck the Central-American Republic of El Salvador last Sunday was formulated here yesterday.
Gifts totaling $2,078,409 have been received thus far in the 1951 appeal of the Greater New York Fund, which started officially at the beginning of the month.

SCHUYLERVILLE, N.Y., May 10--Michael Gratian Yatsevitch, chief metallurgist for the War Department during the second World War, died yesterday in the Cambridge (N.Y.) Nursing Home, after a brief illness. His age was 71.

Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, escorted by high ranking Israeli officials, journeyed to West Point yesterday morning and placed a wreath on the grave of Col. David (Mickey) Marcus, who was killed in 1948 while serving with the Israeli forces during the war in the Holy Land.

PARIS, May 10--There was some hope tonight that the icepack that had frozen the four power deputies' meetings into a solid block of verbiage might be beginning to break up. But the yield so far has been slight.

BIRKDALE, England, May 10 (AP)--The American Walker Cup golf team played itself into top form today with final practices and went to bed confident that it would at least split tomorrow's foursomes and might sweep all four opening contests of the 1951 international series against Britain's leading amateurs.

Sugar trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange worked into new high ground yesterday. The No. 4 world contract closed unchanged to 4 points higher in trading of 9,600 tons and ended with the July delivery at 6.50 cents a pound bid. The domestic No. 6 contract, which did 13,100 tons, showed a tendency to follow but closed 10 points lower to 1 point higher.

Local communities throughout New York and Connecticut are finding through diligent searches that there are many steps that can be taken to increase local protection against hazards of high pressure interstate natural gas pipeline installations that are unregulated under any national code of safety.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Senator Herbert R. O'Conor of Maryland, chairman of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, announced today the appointment of Richard G. Mosey of Summit, N. J., as the committee's chief counsel and said his first major assignment would be to set up an investigation of illegal narcotics operations.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 10 (U.P.)--Jim Ferrier of San Francisco today scored birdies on five of the last nine holes for a six-under-par 64 and the first-round lead in the $10,000 Greenbrier invitation golf tournament.

Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion of Israel asserted last night that the State of Israel was established to preserve human dignity and freedom and to safeguard the concept of democratic ideals and principles. The Israeli statesman asserted that his nation, cherishing the ideals of humanity, would serve as an example "to our neighbors that they need not live in slavery and poverty."
David Greenstein has sold the sixstory building containing eightysix apartments at 1181-87 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, to a client of Murray Gillman, attorney.
The nation's steel mills continued to improve their productive pace during April; but the month's output of raw steel declined slightly below the record March total because of one fewer working day.

YONKERS, May 10--The writing of children now in the public schools here is superior to that of those of a generation ago, an experiment at Public School 24 on Violin Street indicated today to a group of educators.
STRASBOURG, France, May 10 --In a tense session, the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe heard today a wide and often conflicting variety of views on the Schuman plan.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, today through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

Vann Woodward published in the same week, Mr. Santayana discusses politics in philosophical theory only, in the abstract ...

A covered wagon has added a frontier touch to the victorias and "surreys-with-the-fringe-on-top" that line Grand Army Plaza, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. But the small converted Army trailer is not there to bid for fares and compete with the 150 cabbies hankering to drive romantic couples, round the park now that spring is here.

Reverting to the practice of the years immediately before its involvement in World War II, the Soviet Government has plugged the last major loopholes in the curtain of secrecy it maintains over the development of industry and transport in the Soviet Union. This became known yesterday with receipt of the transcript of the official economic report covering the first quarter of 1951.
The State of Arkansas announced yesterday that it will receive bids on May 29 on $7,000,000 of highway bonds dated May 1, 1951, and due May 1, 1952 to 1961.
The American Bible Society, founded 135 years ago yesterday to carry the gospel to Western plainsmen, has set its sights on a new frontier in the East.

Discussing the Point Four program with New York City high school seniors yesterday at the New York Times Youth Forum, Nelson Rockefeller, chairman of the International Development Advisory Board, urged coordination of the agencies seeking to implement the program and advocated aid to private investors abroad.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Senator Saltonstall, trying in his honest New England way to cut through the swirling fog of emotion that has enveloped the Truman-MacArthur controversy to the basic points of difference, asked General Marshall yesterday (who agreed) if these do not "really boil down" to two. The first the Senator described as "the question of his [MacArthur's] disobeyal of orders that led to his dismissal."
Anton Busch, 75 years old, a retired fireman living at 323 Hollywood Avenue, the Bronx, entered Bronx Eye and Ear Infirmary on Wednesday night to have a cataract removed from his right eye.

UNITED STATES EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, May 10 (UP)--Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway said today that history might some day record that "the crest of the Communist wave" was broken by the United Nations forces in Korea.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- Rumors of a new secret weapon were heard at the Senate today, but were widely discounted. The rumors developed like this:

American textile exporters are in danger of losing their most important market for rayon fabrics and their second largest market for cotton as the result of the concessions made to Cuba at the recent Torquay conference, accord ing to the Textile Export Association of the United States.

It would be interesting to penetrate the multiple walls of the Kremlin these days and break into the inner sanctum where the Politburo holds top-secret sessions to mull over the top-secret revelations of American war strategy. Nowhere, we may be sure, are the verbatim reports of the Senate hearings more carefully studied.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (U.P.)--The Maryland racing Commission today barred Jockey Robert J. Martin from riding for ten years at nearly all tracks in this country, Mexico and Cuba after it was testified that he bet against himself at the Laurel, Md. track.

TRENTON, May 10--The Republican and Democratic state organizations adopted today campaign platforms that made major issues of legislative caucus rule and tax revision, as debated in the annual conventions of the parties.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)-- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, told the Senate today the Administration "has not hesitated to give Russia cause for war" in Europe and should not hesitate to take Steps to beat the Chinese Communists and end the Korean war.
At the moment it looks as if there will be no bids submitted for the issue of $67,500,000 of war bonus bonds which West Virginia will put up for sale on May 23.

OTTAWA, May 10--Canadian newsprint companies are not subject to inquiry under United States anti-trust laws because the United States has never ratified the Havana charter for International Trade Organizations, Justice Minister Stuart Girson said in the House of Commons today in reply to a question.

A new justification for declining to reveal possible prior membership in the Communist party was presented yesterday to the city Welfare Department, now engaged in purging employes it believes are "suspect."
The Potomac Electric Power Company has entered into an agreement with a group of seventeen banks under which it may borrow up to $10,000,000 on 2 per cent notes, maturing April 1, 1952.

Spurred on by the Kefauver report of corruption and graft among officials, the League of Women Voters of New York, a state-wide organization, voted yesterday to work to strengthen the primary system at the closing convention session at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 10--A best-ball score of 64 captured low net honors in the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur tourney at the Innis Arden Golf Club course today for Bill Goldbeck, Mt. Kisco professional, and Jack Shaw, Bedford, N.Y., amateur.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 10--Syria charged today that Israel had shelled Syrian territory and violated Tuesday's cease-fire order by the Security Council. United Nations observers on the scene confirmed that ten shells from a twenty-five pounder had landed near a Syrian Army outpost at Hassel.

The strikes that began in Catalonia in March and that spread to the Basque coast and now to Navarra are by all odds the most impressive Spanish development since the World War. Nothing about this development is more significant than the fact that neither communism nor foreign pressure has anything to do with it.

Adoption agencies throughout the country are working out of the extreme "perfectionistic" attitude that has governed much of their work and are seeking homes for all children who need adoption, regardless of physical, mental and emotional handicaps.

Eleven local public housing authorities have borrowed $79,064,000 in the public market on taxexempt-interest notes due variously from Aug. 31 to Dec. 14 at interest rates ranging from 1.14 per cent to 1.24 per cent. The notes are backed by the Public Housing Administration.
The armed forces are experimenting with television as a training medium for reserves and recruits, Rear Admiral S.F. Patten, U.S. N., retired, said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 10--Members of the United Nations Additional Measures Committee reached virtually complete agreement at an informal meeting this morning on the United States resolution for an arms embargo against Communist China. This paved the way for the committee to recommend the resolution to the General Assembly next week. The Political and Security Committee of the Assembly is expected to meet next week, probably Wednesday.

LONDON, May 10--Britain yielded again today to the public outery in the United States against trading with Communist China. Prodded by Winston Churchill, the Government banned any further sales of rubber to China during 1951.

Many engaging ideas held the audience's attention yesterday at B. Altman's Young Colony Shop showing. Colors were mixed with dazzling effect in separates outfits, pinks with raspberry and gold with rust.

Completing a sweep of the three-game series, the Giants beat the Cardinals, 3--2, before a Ladies Day crowd of 6,652 at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was the fourth straight victory for Leo Durocher's resurgent forces, who have won nine of eleven games since snapping out of the early slump that saw them lose eleven in a row.

Union and management negotiators agreed yesterday on a formula for heading off a threatened strike Monday of 12,000 elevator operators and other service employes in Manhattan's towering apartment buildings.

LONDON, May 10--An event probably unique in theatrical history--the first half of a double first night of plays by Shaw and Shakespeare--took place here tonight. The stars were Sir Laurence Olivier and his wife, Vivien Leigh, appearing in Bernard Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra."

Customs collections at this port for April aggregated $22,689,366, an increase of nearly 50 per cent above the same month last year, it was reported yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 10--A thirteen-member commission of scientists and educators to assist in the development of the South's regional education program was named today by the Board of Control for Southern Regional Education.
TOKYO, Friday, May 11 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 880, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Friday (4 P. M., Thursday, Eastern daylight time):

Camille Gutt, until recently managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said yesterday there was still too much nationalistic politics influencing the world organization's fourteenmember executive board.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP)-- George D. Widener's Battlefield is regarded as a most likely starter in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico.
Offsetting the increase in the previous week, loans to business by New York banks declined $21,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 10--The Senate, in a blunt warning to Great Britain and this country's other European Allies, voted today to cut off all United States economic aid to nations that ship war materials to Russia and its satellites.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)-- Following is the censored transcript of today's hearing by the Senate Armed Servces and Foreight Relations Committees into the Administration foreign policy (censorship deletions are indicated by ***):

TOKYO, Friday, May 11.--A United Nations patrol smashed into Munsan, ten miles south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel and about twenty miles northwest of the Korean capital at Seoul, yesterday after air strikes and artillery fire dispersed two Chinese Communist regiments that for the last week had held up the allied advance.
The most decorated colonel in American history indicated yesterday that the United States planned to continue intensive prosecution of the fighting in Korea.

After a share rebuke from Federal Judge John W. Clancy for wasting time, attorneys for Otis Co., Cleveland investment banking firm, rested their defense yesterday afternoon in the $4,000,000 damage suit brought against the firm by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation for failing to go through with a stock underwriting contract with the automotive company in 1948.

NEW DELHI, India, May 10-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said in Parliament today that 50,000 tons of Soviet wheat purchased on a "cash basis" were already en route to India. He said the grain was being carried in Soviet ships and was expected to arrive by the end of July. The announcement was greeted by prolonged cheers and applause.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Peter Tseng Chi, chairman of the Young China Party's Central Executive Committee and Supreme Political Adviser to President Chiang Kai shek, died Monday in George Washington University Hospital after a long illness. His age was 60.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur declared yesterday that he had interpreted a message from President Truman on Jan. 13 to mean that Washington had reversed previous views in favor of evacuation and had decided to hold on indefinitely in Korea. He also said he had regarded the message as advice and not as a directive.

WASHINGTON, May 10--In less than two hours, Congress today unanimously passed and sent to President Truman for signature a resolution giving to veterans of the Korean war many of the benefits, including medical care, already voted for veterans of previous wars.

Ten of the price ceilings on beef that go into effect at the retail level Monday were released yesterday by the City Department of Markets. The figures show that some cuts, usually the more desirable ones, will be higher than at present; others will be lower. One, rib roast, remains steady at .89 cents a pound.

A sudden strike by sixty-one staff engineers and technicians yesterday morning against television station WPIX in support of a 5 per cent wage increase resulted in the station canceling all of its "live" programs for the day, including the baseball game between the New York Giants and the St. Louis Cardinals. Film programs were substituted.

The stock market drifted downward yesterday although offerings seldom proved heavy. Softness in the steels and motors set the pattern for the session although strength cropped out in a selected list of rubbers and public utilities.

My Bebby, owned by Isidor Bieber, made a front-running performance of it to take the Shamrock, the $4,500 race that held the feature spot on the program at Jamaica yesterday. With Bennie Green in the saddle, the 3-year-old daughter of Discovery scored by three-quarters of a length in the six-furlong test for fillies.

The Senate hearings on the dismissal of General MacArthur are spreading on the record not only the broad outlines of our foreign policies but also some of the most secret information we possess regarding our estimates of the enemy's plans, resources and the disposition of his armed forces, as well as of our war plans in Korea.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 10 --Development of three new arterial traffic routes through this city to end a danger of "traffic strangulation" was advocated today by the State Department of Public Works.

Opening today in those galleries of the Metropolitan Museum which recently bore Habsburg and other princely treasures is an exhibition of original drawings of American comic strips and humorous and editorial cartoons.

ORADELL, N.J., May 10--Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge, New Jersey state champion, captured low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association over the Hackensack club course with a five-over-par 40, 38--78 today.

BOSTON, May 10--Dr. Robert M. Strozier, dean of students at the University of Chicago, asserted today that most of the country's student governments lacked responsibility, authority or power because of the reluctance of "benevolent" faculties and administrations to deal with them as governments.
Reflecting the general increase in revenues for the airlines in the first quarter this year, substantially larger earnings were reported by five companies.

NANCY, France, May 10 (AP) --Archduke Otto of Habsburg, whose followers call him ruler of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, was married today to Princess Regina of Saxony-Meiningen in the lavish pomp of old.
FRANKFORT, Germany, May 10 --The process of dissolving the sixyear-old occupation of West Germany and turning the neemy of yesterday into an ally of today entered its final phase this afternoon.

PANAMA, May 10--The people of Panama, assisted by the National Police, won a complete victory for constitutional government today when the white flag of surrender was hoisted over the Presidential Palace and President Arnulfo Arias yielded after some of the bitterest fighting in the history of Panama.

SO far as fishermen are concerned, almost anything can happen over the coming weekend, and with the Weather Man frowning at the prospects, the best bet probably will be a very short trip or a very long one.
Among college administrators, faculties and students there is a small but alert and growing army of defenders of free inquiry and speech, pressing with increasing vigor against repression.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 10-- Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, predicted tonight that Soviet technology "will almost certainly stop" once "the borrowed momentum of the science of the free world has been exhausted."
WINTER PARK, Fla., May 10 (U.P.)--Students boycotted classes today at little Rollins College in an attempt to force trustees to discharge the school's 33-year-old president.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP)-- Murry Dickson pitched a four-hit shut-out today as the surprising Pirates won the rubber game of a three-game, series from the Phillies, 2 to 0, before 3,562 at Shibe Park.

CHICAGO, May 10--Government handling of building controls came in for new and sharper criticism from leaders of the American Institute of Architects at today's sessions of the eighty-third annual convention.

The designer of the most widely known sculpture in the United States, one with which every America is familiar--the buffalo nickel--has been chosen to receive the gold medal of the National Institute and American Academy of Arts and Letters. The medal is awarded twice annually to artists and writers in the various creative fields.
A row of four four-story buildings operated as rooming houses at 203, 205, 207 and 209 West....
Philip Morris Co. announced yesterday it had put "Johnny," the page boy of its cigarette advertising, to work fighting forest fires.

A drive to sign up 600 motionpicture theatres in the city as civil defense recruiting stations opened yesterday with a ceremony in Times Square at which speakers emphasized the vital importance of defense work and the need for volunteers.

MOSCOW, May 10 (AP)--The army newspaper Red Star announced today the death of Col. Gen. Vasily Vasilevitch Ulrich, who, it said, "devoted all his conscious life to the cause of the party of Lenin and Stalin." His age was 62.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 10 (AP)-- John M. Budd, 43, who started his career with the Great Northern Railway as a measuring man with an engineering party, today became president of the road.

Deep frying is almost a lost culinary art in American homes; French fried potatoes and doughnuts have been relegated to professional cooks. But these crisp golden favorites may be scheduled for a home-kitchen comeback, thanks to automatic electric deepfat fryers. Introduced within the last year or so, they have hightly accurate thermostats and other features that make for perfect frying.

In issuing its report yesterday for the nine months ended March 31, 1951, directors of E.R. Squibb Sons disclosed plans to sell 300,000 shares of additional common stock and to split the present common stock, including stock to be sold under the proposed public offering.
WASHINGTON. May 10 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's droughtplagued winter wheat crop at 682,196,000 bushels.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 10-- Robert Struthers of Boston Post Road, Noroton, Conn., special partner of Wood, Struthers Co., New York securities dealers, died here today while playing golf at the Woodway Country Club. He would have been 72 years old on Aug. 22.
WASHINGTON, May 10--Black became white and history was what the government said it was in George Orwell's frightening fiction, "1984."
ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP)--The owners of the St. Louis Browns denied knowledge today of a reported plan to move the club to Milwaukee but admitted poor attendance might force the club out of St. Louis.

PARIS, May 10--The ensuing dispatch may be considered a footnote appended to the voluminous formal testimony now being given in the great MacArthur debate.
