NEWPORT, R.I., May 10--Mrs. Lina Post Webster, widow of Hamilton Fish Webster, long prominent in society, died today at Pen Craig, her home overlooking Newport Harbor. Mrs. Webster, who was 84 years old, had been confined to her home by ill health for several years.
Indictments charging abortion and conspiracy were voted yesterday by a New York County grand jury against eight persons allegedly involved in the operation of a $500,000-a-year abortion "mill."

TODAY, 7:30 P.M.: Meeting of newly organized Miniature Camera Club Juniour Group, 14 to 18-yearolds, 668 Fifth Avenue, entrance on Fifty-third Street. Membership still open, dues $5 a year. Requirements: Basic knowledge of photography and own camera equipment. 8 P.M.: Hayden Planetarium Junior Astronomy Club meeting, fifth floor Lecture Hall, Roosevelt Memorial Building, American Museum of Natural History. Topic: "Stellar Flare-Ups:" Open to all interested young people. Free.
BOSTON, May 10 (AP)--Ewell Blackwell snapped a three-game losing streak for the Cincinnati Reds today with a seven-hit pitching performance that gave him a -1 decision over the league-leading Braves.

CLEVELAND, May 10--Rain today forced a postponement of the second game of the Yankee series with the Indians. It provided a day of rest as the finale to a trip which saw Casey Stengel's champions win seven of the nine games in which they engaged and gain undisputed possession of first place for the first time this season.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 10-- One of the very few great European ideas born in the turmoil of World War II that has not died of exhaustion is that of Benelux.
JERUSALEM, May 10--Israel capped the celebrations of the third anniversary of her independence today with a display of her armed forces through the streets of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, May 10--William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged today the extension and strengthening of economic controls because "prospects for getting inflation under control are now better than at any time since Korea."

The Weather Bureau confirmed yesterday, with scientific impassiveness, what every commuter, every shopper, every lunch-hour loiterer, every nursemaid in the park has been saying for weeks-- "what lovely weather we've had lately!"

A group of warehouses and a garage on Second Avenue, between Eighth and Tenth Streets, in Brooklyn, formerly occupied by the Roulston grocery chain, have been sold by the Chase National Bank and Herman Goldman, as executors of the estate of Thomas H. Roulston, to Harry P. Albert. The sale was negotiated by Fred C. Stanclift as broker.

LONDON, May 10--A virtual deadlock has been reached between the United States and British military circles on the organization of Mediterranean defense as part of the North Atlantic Treaty, according to officials here. They forecast the problem will soon have to be taken to the foreign ministers for decision.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall declared his belief today that the American people would stand with the Truman Administration against General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in the great controversy over military policy in Korea.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet but steady yesterday and prices were 4 points lower to 3 points hither at the close.

Mr. and Mrs. John Moseley Abbot of Bletchingly, Beverly Farms, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anita Vivian, to Jonathan Russell Snelling, son of Henry B.W. Snelling of Boston and Mrs. Jessica Henderson Snelling of Weston, Mass.

CHICAGO, May 10--Wheat futures were weak both here and in the outside markets, further liquidation being in evidence, and while there was some short-covering in anticipation of the Government report, rallies were feeble and short-lived. Indications pointed to considerable closing-out of spreads between wheat and soybeans, which weakened the wheat and strengthened soybeans.

THE foundation stone on which the structure of organized baseball has rested for most of its existence has been its reserve clause. In all that time the diamond fathers have never known whether that foundation was resting on granite or sawdust. They were quite content to remain in blissful ignorance and fought off anyone who might be curious enough to want to. test its substance--and its legality.

PUSAN, South Korea, Friday, May 11 (UP)--The South Korean National Assembly refused today to accept the resignation of Vice President Lee Si Yung and there was angry talk of impeaching President Syngman Rhee or limiting his authority.

The new building construction regulations of the National Poduction Authority will work a great hardship on Manhattan and will have a harmful effect on the economy of the entire city, Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. asserted yesterday.
A reputed Harlem vice overlord and eleven alleged henchmen in a narcotics ring were arrested yesterday by Federal agents, who have had contact with the gang for three months.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Donald S. Dawson, President Truman's administrative assistant on patronage, swore today to the Senate subcommittee investigating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that he never exercised or had any influence over directors of that agency or had anything to do with its lending operations.

PATZCUARO, Mexico, May 9-- This country gained today the honor of opening the first training center in a world network that the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization plans to establish for specialists in basic education who will be dedicated to wiping out illiteracy among more than half the earth's population in backward areas.

WASHINGTON, May 10--The future tonnage needs of the Military Sea Transportation Service will be filled principally by allocations from the National Shipping Authority, under an arrangement worked out by the two shipping agencies.

The last of the twenty-one defendants indicted Tuesday by Brooklyn's racket-investigating grand jury as conspirators in Harry Gross' bookmaking activities surrendered yesterday to the Kings County District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, May 10--A new electronic arm, powered by a small motor, and a prosthetic leg, equipped with an efficient hydraulic mechanism, were among devices demonstrated here today in a showing of the latest developments in artificial limbs.

The state's revised unemployment insurance law will improve the economy of the state by attracting new industry and encouraging the expansion of existing industry, Harry G. Waltner Jr., chairman of the social security committee of the Commerce and Industry Association, declared yesterday.

Twenty or thirty years ago one criticism of the American college student was that he was not politically minced. Those were the days of "Joe College," who cheered the team, ate goldfish and took his four undergraduate years as a happy prolongation of boyhood. Then the fashion changed, at least for a conspicuous minority.
Big Don Newcombe, apparently free from all aches and pains, pitched and helped bat the Dodgers to a 6-1 victory over the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday before a Ladies-Day crowd of 9,962.

Fashions for the vacation-bound were presented last night at De Pinna. Wardrobes for three different types of vacations--to Europe by air, to Cape Cod by rail or car and to Nassau by boat --were displayed, with each planned about the activities at the respective destination.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 10-- Announcement has been made by the Rev. William T. Walsh and Mrs. Walsh of Tarrytown and Siasconset, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Joan, to Maynard Malcolm Miller, son of Mrs. Queens D. Miller of Seattle and Joseph A. Miller of Mount Vernon, Wash.

WASHINGTON, May 10--The country has received itself about the rise in liquid assets, business earning, and dividends, Dr. Leland Rex Robinson said today at a luncheon conference of the Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy.

Forty-five thousand apartments planned for the city with Federal assistance will have to be deferred for an indefinite period if the deep cut voted for the program in the House of Representatives last Friday is sustained. Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, issued the warning to delegates to the Middle Atlantic Conference of the National Association of Housing Officials at the New Yorker Hotel.
Bernard Baruch said last night that the choice of the people of this nation lay between "self-discipline or slavery."

Commissioner Moses has been applying his imagination again to a variety of city problems and, as one result, the Columbus Coliseum has come back to life. The Metropolitan Opera Association and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society have been invited to join in this project in the Columbus Circle area, which would combine the attractions of a music center, a convention hall, a parking garage and an apartment house in a vast redevelopment.
WASHINGTON, May 10--Federal shipping authorities have asked Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of the Selective Service System, to take prompt action on draft deferments for essential seamen.

Governor Dewey proposed last night an eleven-point program to meet the threat of Russian Communist aggression against the free nations of the world. Of these two were general, five pertained to Asia and the Orient and two to Europe, and two were on domestic policy.

In his testimony before the Senate committees inquiring into the dismissal of General MacArthur, Secretary Marshall declared that it was his "very decided impression at the present time" that the United States should use its veto power to kill any attempt to admit the Chinese Communist regime into the United Nations.

A high Department of Health official implied yesterday that accidental carbon monoxide deaths from household gas appliances-- 2,442 fatalities were recorded here in less than a decade--would be at a minimum if all the utilities converted from manufactured to straight natural gas.
WASHINGTON, May 11--The United States rejected today as "specious" and without foundation the reasons given by Poland for withdrawing the liner Batory from service to New York.

The current exhibition of paintings at the de Nagy Gallery is entitled "The New Generation." Along with the selection of drawings, pastels and small sculpture at the Kootz Gallery, two important tributaries of what may be called "The School of New York" are easily identifiable.
Prime Minister David BenGurion of Israel took time off from an arduous schedule early yesterday afternoon and indulged in a favorite pursuit.

Bernard Shaw's comic indictment on the state of matrimony, "Getting Married," will be revived tomorrow evening at 8:15 o'clock at the Anta Playhouse. The Shavian comedy, the tenth and final production in this season's Anta play series, is produced by Marjorie and Sherman Ewing in association with the American National Theatre and Academy.
The Tricolator Company announced an extensive national advertising campaign yesterday with an equal allocation for localized advertising by sixteen newly appointed manufacturer's representatives.
The commercial banks have joined the investment banks in disapproving the proposed $67,500,000 issue of West Virginia bonus bonds, it was disclosed yesterday.

COLUMBIA, Mo., May 11--The University of Missouri disclosed today that it was setting up a new program to pay athletes. School administrative and athletic officials voiced hope that the program would end the hypocrisy of secret deals and take the stigma off college athletics.

CHICAGO, May 11--The nation's architects today called on the Federal Government to take prompt steps to relieve dislocations in private business growing out of operation of the defense emergency program in key industrial and population centers such as New York.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 11--The eight-oared crews of Yale, Princeton, Cornell and Syracuse will row here tomorrow in varsity, junior varsity and freshman races over a two-mile course on Lake Cayuga.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores showed a composite gain of 4.5 per cent in April, compared with a year ago, according to a compilation of forty-two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase in March over that month in 1950 was 19 per cent.
The shipping industry of this country is opposed to the amendment of navigation rules by Presidential proclamation and does not approve a bill before Congress providing such authority.

PANAMA, May 11--The general strike that played an important part in the Panamanians' fight to save the Constitution of 1946 and in ousting President Arnulfo Arias yesterday, ended this morning. The people returned to work with new hope and confidence.

James J. Moran, who rose from an obscure court attendant to become a close friend and confidant of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, was sentenced to prison for five years and fined $2,000 yesterday in Federal Court on his conviction of perjury.

The Sanitation Department's program to clean streets on the upper West Side by invoking alternate-side-of-the-street parking was set back indefinitely yesterday because the low bid to fabricate and install the 1,205 essential signs amounted to 75 per cent more than the $12,000 that had been appropriated by the Board of Estimate.
Just after midnight one day this week five young men, clad in illfitting surgical gowns, sipped coffee and waited for a baby to be born.

PARIS, May 11--The Soviet Union's latest "compromise" agenda proposal for a Big Four foreign ministers' conference was criticized again today by Dr. Philip C. Jessup, and Ernest Davies, United States and British deputies respectively, as an attempt to extort further concessions from the West. At the same time Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet deputy, held fast on all Soviet points.

Mayor Impellitteri has been in office for about eight months now. For two months after William O'Dwyer resigned on Sept. 2 not much was expected of an Acting Mayor who was merely holding the line and campaigning for election.
The four-year six-billion guilder, industrial development program of the Netherlands, started in 1948, has reached the half-way mark, it was disclosed here yesterday.

The great debate on foreign policy reached a peak during the last week with the MacArthurMarshall testimony on the Korean war. To report the historic event the nation's press has reached new heights in coverage.
June 4 was set yesterday as the date for the mass trial of the twenty-one present and former members of the Police Department indicted by the Brooklyn rackets grand jury on conspiracy charges.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP)-- Two State Department officials gave the Senate Banking Committee a secret briefing today on United States plans to halt trade between America's allies and the Communist world.

Dr. Frank P. Graham, head of the Defense Manpower Administration in the Labor Department, intimated yesterday that the Government will oppose any proposal from business calling for the abolition of premium pay for overtime.

A Cleveland lawyer, who previously had refused to answer certain questions on the grounds of lawyer-client privilege, will be called as a witness by the defense on Monday in the $4,000,000 damage suit being pressed in Federal Court here against Otis Co., by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.
The Department of Welfare announced yesterday that three employes who had been suspected of having Communist sympathies had resigned.

The Huntington Gardens development on West Main Street in Huntington, L.I. consisting of a group of two-story buildings built under Section 608 of the Federal Housing Act, has been sold by Max M. Friedman to Harry and Sydney W. Waxman.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., May 11 (AP)--Jim Ferrier of San Francisco pulled away to a three-stroke lead at the half-way point of the 72-hole Greenbrier Open today by finishing with three birdies.

Profit-taking in the No. 6 domestic sugar contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange prevented an advance yesterday but the market was optimistic on reports of virtually unanimous action by refiners to raise refined sugar prices from 8 to 8 cents a pound, beginning on Monday.

TULSA, May 11--The Republican National Committee decided tonight to hold its 1952 Presidential nominating convention in Chicago in the week beginning July 7 as the Republican party was urged to go on the warpath to victory against the Truman Administration.

PARIS, Saturday, May 12-- The National Assembly voted early today to end its term in office July 4 and thereby insured that France's 25,000,000 voters would go to the polls June 17 to elect a new legislature. The vote was 362 to 219.

Sixty-one television engineers and technicians agreed to end their two-day-old strike last night against station WPIX and submit a wage dispute to arbitration. The station will resume its regular program schedule this morning at 11 o'clock.
CHAIRMAN RUSSELL--The committee will now come to order. When the committee recessed yesterday, Senator Hickenlooper had not concluded questions, so we will now proceed with Senator Hickenlooper.
A prayer for Whitsunday, the Christian Pentecost, will be read at regular services tomorrow by pastors in communions in this and other countries affiliated with the World Council of Churches.
WASHINGTON, May 11--The Office of Price Stabilization today rolled back prices for used steel drums and their reconditioning services at all sales levels in the industry.

The Appellate Division designated yesterday Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga to sit in a special term of the court on all matters arising out of the challenge of Governor Dewey's exercise of power in naming the State Crime Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)--Following is the paraphrased version of a message sent by President Truman Jan. 13 to General MacArthur, as read into the record today in the Senate committees' hearing on our policy in the Far East. The original text of the message was paraphrased to protect the United States' codes:

WASHINGTON, May 11--President Truman cautioned General of the Army Douglas MacArthur Jan. 13 that the overriding imperative in Korea was not to lose the allies the United States would "desperately need" in any war forced by the Soviet Union.

PARIS, May 11--The French have their own special slant on General of the Army Douglas MacArthur because they have often experienced spectacular and politically active generals. They have one now in Gen. Charles de Gaulle, who resembles General MacArthur in some notable respects.
Debutantes of this and recent seasons are aiding in the plans for the Petal Pink Ball to be held on the night of May 23 in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the Youth Consultation Service.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 11-- Top Government leaders sought today the backing of big industry for the extension and strengthening of the Defense Production Act, which is pending in Congress.
CHICAGO, May 11 (UP)--There is only a slight chance that the Big Ten will approve a renewal of its Rose Bowl agreement with the Pacific Coast conference, it was learned today.

HONG KONG, May 11--The newspaper Southern Daily, official Chinese Communist organ in Canton, asserted proudly today that some Kwangtung people were beginning to realize that they owed it to the state to denounce their relatives for "counter-revolutionary activity."

The match for the world chess championship between Mikhail Botvinnik and David Bronstein, ended last night in Moscow with Botvinnik still titleholder as the twenty-fourth game resulted in a draw after twenty-two moves.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur expressed satisfaction yesterday at the strengthening of United States and British attitudes toward the Chinese Communists. He attributed this to his success in carrying his fight before the bar of public opinion.

LONDON, May 11 (AP)--Miss Beverly Baker of Santa Monica, Calif., and Miss Kay Tuckey of England today advanced to the final round of the Hurlingham tennis tournament. They will play for the title tomorrow.

For a few hours yesterday the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, which operates the Hudson Tubes between New Jersey and Manhattan, appeared to be on the verge of profitable operations for the first time since 1932.
A group of members of the New York Stock Exchange has started a new campaign to force that institution to close on Saturdays throughout the year.

WASHINGTON, May 11--The Office of Price Stabilization announced today reductions in the retail ceiling prices of certain cuts of beef by as much as 12 cents a pound. These and other changes will be effective Monday.

The large bituminous coal users here are buying for use in coming months about 25 per cent more coal than they used in the same period last year, it was shown here yesterday by members of the National Coal Association.
Extensive amendment of the new Ceiling Price Regulation 31 on imports will be sought, the National Council of American Importers announced yesterday following a meeting in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 11--Eric Johnston, economic stabilizer, and Michael V. DiSalle, price administrator, warned Congress today of the need for intensified efforts to control inflation. They called for adoption of the Defense Production Bill before the present act expires on June 30.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11-- Allyn McLerie, who appeared with Ray Bolger on Broadway in "Where's Charley?" has been signed to repeat her stage role as Amy Spettigue in the screen version of the musical comedy at Warner Brothers.

"THE Mills of the Kavanaughs,"* by Robert Lowell, who won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry in 1946, is a fine new collection of poems in angular, stony meters, sometimes as obscure as one end of an overheard telephone conversation, always savagely brilliant in their hard impact on the mind.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)--O. John Rogge, one-time head of the Justice Department's criminal division, was charged today with inexcusable neglect in looking out for the interests of a client under criminal sentence.

TAEGU, Korea, May 11--Cabinet resignations and bitter disputes in the Korean National Assembly have called attention once more to reports of widespread corruption in the Government at Pusan and have revived charges that President Syngman Rhee is assuming too much power.

ROME, May 11--A bid by the Italian Social Movement (M.S.I.), an extreme right-wing party, to obtain the support of militant Roman Catholics in the forthcoming municipal elections elicited a sharp rebuke, tantamount to a rejection, from today's L'Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper.

Dr. William Meddaugh Dunning, for more than thirty-five years a member of the surgical staff of the Bronx Eye and Ear Infirmary, retiring five years ago, died yesterday in his home, 24 Pell Place, City Island, the Bronx, after a long illness. His age was 82.

Reports made by the Department of Investigation concerning practices in the Smoke Control Board are under study by District Attorney Frank G. Hogan. Mr. Hogan conceded yesterday that he was making an inquiry "to determine if criminal prosecution is warranted."

National engineering societies and trade organizations and individual manufacturers of safety devices are contributing substantially to aid the adoption of higher standards of safety in high pressure interstate natural gas pipeline construction and operation practices.

An urgent call for Government allocation of critical metals to essential non-defense activities was issued yesterday by Gerald J. Carey, executive director of the New York City Housing Authority. The alternative is a black market, he told delegates to the Middle Atlantic conference of the National Association of Housing Officials at the New Yorker Hotel.

MANILA, May 11--A Philippine court today sentenced six top Communist leaders to death and nine others to life imprisonment for murders, robberies and armed rebellion aimed at overthrowing the Philippine Government.

In a case marked by the utmost secrecy, a frightened 15-year-old Nassau County schoolboy was brought into Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday to face a charge of seeking to extort $10,000 from Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, society and race track figure.

WASHINGTON, May 11--The House Ways and Means Committee approved $250,500,000 of increases in liquor, beer and wine taxes today, far less than the $671,000,000 the Truman Adminis tration had recommended. If written into law, the proposals would mean a 30-cent increase in the price of a fifth of a gallon of 100-proof whisky and probably a 1-cent rise on a bottle of beer.
Acceptance of a three-year peace pact by union and management negotiators averted yesterday a strike set for Monday by 12,000 elevator operators and service workers in Manhattan apartment buildings.

WASHINGTON, May 11--Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet of Mexico, Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, today urged before the United States Commission for Unesco his plan for a 12year $20,000,000 world-wide attack on mass-illiteracy.
Sale of twelve additional DC-6B's has raised total orders for this improved model of the four-engined Douglas airliner to 103. Including the Ider DC-6, the company has sold 287 aircraft of that type.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 11 (AP)-- The best scoring tournament in the forty-eight-year history of the American Bowling Congress reached its climax today with one 300 game and another of 299.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 11 (AP) --Citation failed in the third trip along his current comeback trail today as a speed-burning California filly, Special Touch, captured the $15,000 Premiere Handicap at Hollywood Park.
Canned fruits packed without sugar but sweet to taste and low in calories are a recent development of Ditex Foods, Incorporated.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 11 --Another chapter in the political saga of turbulent Tuckahoe was written here today when a Westchester County grand jury investigated the strange disappearance of Page 3501-2 from the village board's ledger of official minutes.
The British Government had decided to ban sales of rubber to Communist China before Winston Churchill made his peremptory appeal in the House of Commons for immediate action in the matter.

No developmental test of infants yet worked out can predict with complete accuracy that a baby will grow up "normal," Dr. Milton J. E. Senn, director of the Yale University Child Study Center, declared yesterday.

CINCINNATI, May 11--Two separate studies--one of 5,000 cases of juvenile delinquency in Canada, the other of 1,000 women criminals in California--today reported the same conclusion: That the homes from which the offenders came were unhappy.

BALTIMORE, May 11 (AP)--F. Ambrose Clark's Lone Fisherman won the $7,500-added Jervis Spencer Steeplechase Handicap at Pimlico today, finishing with twelve lengths to spare over Whatta Knight in the two-mile event.

PHATDIEM, Tongking, IndoChina, May 6--A drive of a few miles down a bumpy unpaved road south from this little Roman Catholic community brings one suddenly to a hilltop fortress that marks the boundary with insurgent territory.
CHICAGO, May II--The May Government report on winter wheat showing a much more optimistic view than recent private forecasts caused some pressure on the wheat market here today.
FRANKFORT, Germany, May 11--German fascism is losing no time in restoring its links with Fascist movements in other countries now that it is once more a going political concern.
ALBANY, May 11--The State Banking Department announced today the appointment of Mark T. Walsh, 412 East Sixty-fifth Street, as principal attorney.

The Board of Education is confronted with the problem of what to do about a teacher-veteran of World War II who refused to obey an official directive to take part in the city's welcome for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur on April 20.

WASHINGTON, May 11--Donald S. Dawson, President Truman's aide on patronage matters, was accused today of having influenced certain directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation whether he meant to or not.
CHICAGO, May 11 (UP)--Joe Dobson, a ten-year veteran of the American League, limited the Indians to one hit tonight as the White Sox scored a 12-1 victory.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 12-- Planes and tank-infantry patrols slashed yesterday at the Communist invaders, apparently again building up their forces in central Korea in an attempt to resume their spring offensive stalled a fortnight ago before the Korean capital at Seoul by massive United Nations firepower.

UNITED NATIONS, May 11-- On the twentieth floor of this skyscraper of the diplomatic trade is a barber shop--two chairs, two barbers, no waiting and beard trims and hair cuts tailored to the customer's nationality.

United Nations ground forces in Korea probed deep into enemy territory Friday, encountering strong screening forces in the central sector. In the western sector, contact was scattered with resistance generally light. Limited objective attacks continued in the eastern sector against increasing hostile opposition.
With Venus blazing away in the west, watchers of the evening sky may be giving less attention than is deserved to a duller but very interesting planet in the south.

BIRKDALE, England, May 11 (AP)--Four fighting finishes that left the British hanging on the ropes gave the United States a 2-0 lead at the end of the first day of the thirteenth Walker Cup golf series today.

THE National Rifle Association finally decided it would be politic to pay some attention to the "ordinary" member, so a special committee was appointed to study the matter of "open" rather than "closed" national matches, and after considerable discussion this committee voted in favor of the "open" championships.

LONDON, May 11--Before the House of Commons recessed today for its Whitsun holiday, Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison declared that in the British Government view it would be "premature" to discuss the future of Formosa "while operations continue in Korea."

Setting out to modernize Shakespeare by "making Willie hep," the junior class of Hunter College won the thirty-fifth annual "Sing" competition yesterday, the tenth time that the junior class has won the silver baton. The senior class production, "New York Is A Wonderful Town," took second place.
Nearly five months have gone by since Madame Pandit, Indian Ambassador to the United States, asked this country for two million tons of wheat, to be paid for by a long-term loan.

Despite rising prices in the United States and the recent lowering of some Soviet prices ordered last March 1, the United States worker still has a far greater purchasing power than the average Soviet worker, a study of the comparative work times required to purchase various foods and manufactured goods indicates.
The strange silhouette of the newly acquired Israel-America Line freighter Elath will baffle many waterfront watchers as she sails down the harbor today on her first trip from here to Haifa.
An orangutan kissed a tiger yesterday. Yes, Sandra, a gentle Bronx orangutan, peered through her sleepy, white-lidded eyes into a basket of four one-day-old cubs, the daughters of Dacca.

One of the two most important flower days of the spring, if not of the year, is Mother's Day. Since it is observed on the second Sunday in May, lilacs, tulips and other fine spring flowers that are grown outdoors are added to the greenhouse blooms in the florist's refrigerator.

The Metropolitan Jockey Club's six-week spring meeting at Jamaica ends today, when the $60,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap will head the program. This richest stake of the session has drawn a field of a dozen, and there seems to be no solid favorite in it.
Walter Cartier scored a dramatic victory over Eugene Hairston, deaf middleweight battler from the Bronx, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

BENTON, Tenn., May 11--W. August Lewis, chairman of the Polk County Court, which for the last two months has been the center of a political feud in the mountains of southeastern Tennessee, was shot and killed from ambush late tonight.

Norman Thomas warned yesterday that this country's failure to send wheat to help India in its time of famine has almost lost for the United States a chance to change the "moral climate" there. He said that Congress still had a chance to act in this sphere "before it is too late."

STRASBOURG, France, May 11 --The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe voted, 80 to 7, today in favor of ratification of the Schuman plan treaty for a sixpower Western European community for coal and steel, and then became entangled in procedure and adjourned in a deadlock.

WASHINGTON, May 12--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur has not succeeded in reversing the Far Eastern policy of the United states, but he has demonstrated once more that a powerful figure who makes enough noise for a long enough time can influence and modify the policies of the Truman Administration.

TEL AVIV. MANY illustrious conductors, soloists and ensembles have visited Israel in the past few years, and dur ing the height of the season the concert bills have seemed as full as those of any major European or American city.
The United Nations was called upon yesterday to reprimand Syria for its "exhibition of aggressive military tactics on the Israeli frontier."
SINCE Somerset Maugham seems to have pleased both the British film makers and the public via "Quartet" and "Trio," the producers can't be blamed for following a successful pattern.

In the chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Susannah Boyer Wilshire, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Murray Wilshire of Riverside, Conn., was married to Douglass M. Bomeisler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bomeisler of Greenwich, Conn.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 12--Radio Leipzig in the Soviet zone has broadcast threats against both the American and German staff of Radio Free Europe since the Crusade for Freedom's medium-wave transmitter to Czechoslovakia went on the air in Munich ten days ago.

High bail was fixed yesterday for four men and a woman arrested Friday night as narcotics wholesalers who allegedly utilized East 108th Street, between First and Second Avenues, as their operating base for sales of large quantities of heroin to dealers.
HANOI, Indo-China, May 12-- The warfare in which Britain and France are engaged in Indo-China and Malaya imposes a heavy drain on the resources of these two nations.
WASHINGTON, May 12--Retail druggists are asking Congress to write a prescription for their business.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va. FLOWERING shrubs, trees and other plants known prior to the beginning of the nineteenth century dominate the gardens of this former capital of the Colonial period, where the 175th anniversary of the proclamation of independence will be celebrated on May 15.
The final chapter in one of the greatest financial stories in the history of the public utility holding company industry was written last week.

ZINNIAS are among the most popular and useful of annuals. These warm-weather favorites are so generally grown that they seem almost common. Yet, if the possibilities are explored and their preferences catered to, the results can be quite out-of-the-ordinary.
Population trends and changes in dwelling units in Manhattan during the past decade show some startling variations, according to an analysis of the 264 census tracts in the borough.
ONCE, a long while ago, I chanced to speak admir ingly to one of my mentors in economics of something Stuart Chase had written.
DURING the three decades of its existence Soviet lit erature has undergone many shifts and changes and has had to adapt itself continuously to the tortuous party line.
WASHINGTON, May 12--Old soldiers here recall the Presidential censure of a top-ranking general other than General of the Army MacArthur for making statements the White House did not like.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)-- Following is the censored transcript of the morning session of today's hearing by the Senate Armed Services and Foreign Relations Committees into the Administration's foreign policy (censorship deletions are indicated by ***):

The Scotch is on the sea, to paraphrase an old song. Two vessels, heavily laden, are expected in New York in a few days with the first of the British fiscal year's allotments to the dollar markets of the United States.

PURCHASING for Mother's Day helped retail trade last week, but the increase over a year ago was regarded as moderate by store executives. Generally, however, retail volume continues to reflect seasonal influences which are aiding sales of apparel and accessories. Stocks are still heavy, but are in better condition than they were.
A young American pianist, Leonard Pennario, and a famous European veteran, Wilhelm Kempff, have just been recorded in twelveinch disks of Liszt's piano music, for Capitol and London, respectively.

VIENNA, May 12--The "gathering of 50,000 young people for peace and freedom," arranged by the Communists this Whitsun in Vienna, looked for a time today as if it would turn into a battle between Socialist and Communist youth.

Miss Ann Louise Mendelson, daughter of Herbert Mendelson of 172 East Sixty-fourth Street, and the late Mrs. Clara Goldsmith Mendelson, was married yesterday afternoon to Arne Howell Gronningsater, son of Anton Gronningsater of 49 East Ninety-sixth Street and Kristiansand, Norway, and the late Mrs. Annie Raeburn Howell Gronningsater, in the Unitarian Church of All Souls.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 12--The marriage of Miss Anne Henriette Herbermann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Herbermann, to Francis Joseph McGrath Jr., son of Mrs. Francis J. McGrath ...
To help meet the "great challenge" of improving teaching in the nation's secondary schools and junior colleges, Yale University has introduced a new program for the Master of Arts in education.

HONOLULU--An expanded Waikiki Beach, one completed new beach hotel and another in the process of construction and the usual quota of traditional Hawaiian holidays and special events will greet tourists to these islands this spring and summer.

TULSA, Okla., May 12--The prevailing sentiment among leading Republicans who wound up a three-day national meeting here today was that President Truman could be beaten if he were the Democratic nominee next year.

TO a browser among the departmental files it appears fairly safe this morning to note that, with the aid of Andre Roussin and Jean Anouilh, France may lead England next season as a play exporter to Broadway.

ANNOUNCEMENT by the New York State Board of Regents of a plan to establish a state-wide network of educational, non-commercial television stations by all odds is one of the most encouraging developments yet to occur in video.

ANY undeveloped shady area is a challenge to the gardener's imagination. Such a place may be no larger than an unappreciated, out-of-the-way corner or a shabby thicket grown dense with neglect.

IN presenting the first book on Francois Couperin in English and perhaps the first thoroughgoing examination of his music in any language, Wilfrid Mellers freely acknowledges his debt to previous writers. From them he has drawn not only factual matter bearing on the composer's life and works, but also material about the musical traditions which Couperin inherited and the society in which he worked

THE question of tourist-rate fares for the international airlines flying the Atlantic between the United States and Europe came up again last week as the International Air Transport Association opened its sixth traffic conference in Bermuda.

THE fifteen stamps--eleven from 1 cent through $1 for normal postage and 6c, 10c, 15c and 25c for airmail-- which the United Nations will issue are to have their releases staggered across several months in order to enable collectors to arrange for first-day covers with postmarks not all on one date.
CHICAGO, May 12--Oscar Stanton De Priest, former Representative in Congress and the first Negro to serve on the Chicago City Council, died today in Provident Hospital. He was 80 years old.

WARNER ROBINS, Ga., May 12 (AP)--Two soldier-prisoners, unarmed and handcuffed together, were slain last night by a police chief, Thomas Bragg of Hawkinsville, Ga., who reported that they "jumped" him, yelling, "Get his gun and kill him."

BIRKDALE, England, May 12-- The United States gave the British their once-every-two-years glimpse of the Walker Cup today, then wrapped up the big golf trophy to return it to its perennial American home.
HOLLYWOOD'S studios would not permit them to enter, Pravda's two American correspondents com plain in the latest issue of that paper to arrive here.

WASHINGTON, May 12--Shipments from Hong Kong to Communist China in 1950 were more than double the 1949 dollar value.

Unusually large inventories in the retail jewelry stores probably will be reduced to normal levels by Christmas and the holiday season, Leo Weisfield, president of Weisfield's, a West Coast jewelry chain, said in an interview here last week.
ST. PIERRE, Martinique--It happened forty-nine years ago last Tuesday. Only that year it was a Thursday.

Down in Wall Street they tell the story about the busy executive who moaned daily about the long delays, loss of time and headaches, caused by commuting between his Long Island home and lower Manhattan.

SPRING seems to produce an abundance of activity on all sides. Certainly the concert schedule is a busy one this week, with a little something for practically everybody's taste. The principal events are as follows:

HOLLYWOOD. VIEWING the distress of the major film companies, which have begun a new spasm of pessimism be cause of shrinking revenues, Samuel Goldwyn joyfully brushed up his familiar maxim that "quantity is no substitute for quality in motion pictures" and announced last week that he plans to spend more than $8,000,000 on four productions in the next year.

A homicide charge was lodged yesterday against John J. Forkin, a longshoreman. The police said he was the passenger in a jeep station wagon that on Monday plowed through a crowd of pedestrians on East Eighteenth Street near Broadway, killing one person and injuring three others.

In 1946 Prof. Conrad A. Elvehjem and his co-workers at the University of Wisconsin discovered that certain vitamin deficiencies can be produced by inhibiting the growth of some species of intestinal bacteria by the use of specific drugs.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 12 (U.P.)-- Seyed Mojtaba Navab Safavi, leader of Fadayan Islam--the powerful nationalist organization that admits responsibility for the recent assassination of Premier Gen. Ali Razmara--said today that ...

The Republican National Committee has just stretched a long-standing tradition in two ways. As its chairman, Guy Gabrielson, stated, its meeting at Tulsa on Friday was the first national Republican meeting that "has been held south of the Mason and Dixon Line."

Domestic manufacturers and retailers of china and glassware soon may spearhead an all-out fight against enactment of a proposed 20 per cent manufacturers' excise tax on their products and other home furnishings not now covered by such levies.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 12-- Government officials appeared confident tonight that they had won the support of business and industry to their program for a continuation of price, wage and production controls through 1952.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 12 (AP)-- Duke Nalon, veteran race driver of Sherman Oaks, Calif., returned today to the Indianapolis motor speedway where he almost lost his life two years ago, and smashed all qualifying records for the 500mile Memorial Day race.
The first report of the ad hoc committee on Treasury-Federal Reserve problems and the need for additional credit controls is expected to be issued tomorrow when the group meets in Washington, D.C.

WITH the early runs of Atlantic salmon heavier than usual in many rivers of the Canadian Maritime provinces, this promises to be an excellent season, and reports from several Nova Scotia rivers indicate excellent fishing.

A report by a three-man committee suggesting eighteen possible sites within or near the city for construction of a "Television City" was made public yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri.

A tall, slender mariner with a shock of white hair visible beneath his braided cap stood at attention yesterday on the State University Maritime College parade ground at Fort Schuyler. He was Vice Admiral Herbert F. Leary, retiring president of the institution.

WASHINGTON, May 16--The House Ways and Means Committee, in a move to make professional gambling a less-desirable occupation, voted today to impose a special 10 per cent tax on the gross business of bookmakers and policy operators.

LONDON, May 16--Sale of an issue of 5,000,000 ($14,000,000) of sterling bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to a syndicate of banking firms here was announced today jointly by Eugene R. Black, president of the bank, and by Baring Brothers Co., Ltd., one of the buyers of the issue.

LONDON, May 16--The ancient Chapter House adjoining Westminster Abby, first home of the English House of Commons which was severely damaged during World War II has been fully restored after two and a half years of painstaking work.

The New York City Center of Music and Drama has had an operating loss of $72,338.47 for its fiscal year ending April 28, Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors, revealed yesterday at the eighth annual meeting of the Incorporators of the City Center.

Freedman Die Cutters, Inc., now at 10 West Twentieth Street, has purchased the six-story industrial building on plot 126 by 124 feet at 285-91 Lafayette Street from Hawley Hoops, Inc., in a deal negotiated by Carstens Linnekin, brokers.
Because of their geographical position and their record of resistance to Russian pressure, Turkey and Greece are important buttresses of Western security.

WASHINGTON, May 16--Further cuts in production of passenger cars and other consumer durable goods, such as refrigerators, washing machines and vacuum cleaners, will begin July 1, under plans of the National Production Authority for diverting more steel, copper and aluminum for rearmament needs.

The official recommendation that the city negotiate the purchase of the Rockaway Beach branch of the Long Island Rail Road as an adjunct to its rapidtransit system aroused disappointment among some Queens civic and business groups yesterday.
Neatly tailored chairs and couches suitable for small living quarters are among new furniture made by Valley, Inc. Large, somewhat bulky pieces are its major productions.

TRENTON, May 16--A closing chapter in the strange case of the "Phantom Forger" was written today when Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll granted a full pardon to a 62-year-old housewife, Mrs. C. Elizabeth Wean,...

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP)-- Draft boards were ordered today to postpone induction of college students until results of their deferment tests were known or their scholastic standings had been submitted to draft officials.

Charles W. Furlong has been appointed assistant to the director of personnel relations of General Aniline and Film Corporation. Richard H. Faust has been named manager of personnel research and statistics and John J. Speed has been made personnel relations manager of the company's New York City offices.
CINCINNATI, May 16 (AP)--The Reds pulled to within two and onehalf games of first place in the league race today as an eighthinning rally produced a 4-3 victory over the Braves.

PARIS, May 16--An International Press Institute to improve understanding among peoples through better understanding among the world's newspapers was formally established here today, with adoption of a constitution by an organizing committee of newspaper editors. The committee had been working on the project for seven months.
Public school teachers who continue their boycott of extracurricular activities face possible dismissal, it was reported yesterday at the Board of Education.
Six reporters and a photographer received the 1950 annual awards of the Overseas Press Club of America last night at the club's annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PARIS, May 16 (AP)--Sugar Ray Robinson, the Negro middleweight boxing champion, kissed the wife of the President of France four times today--twice on each cheek --with the enthusiastic approval of a salon-full of France's social uppercrust.

Though efforts of mutual friends to end the feud between Mayor Impellitteri and Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, may bear fruit in the future, there was no indication yesterday that any of the prospective primary fights for Assembly district leaders and control of the Tammany executive committee had been called off.

Jimmy Herring, 157 of Ozone Park, outpointed Artie Diamond, 161, of Middle Village, in the star eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A gathering of 1,497 saw the Long Island battlers clash.
Arthur Miller yesterday confirmed a report that he was writing a new play, untitled as yet, that will be submitted to Kermit Bloomgarden for Broadway presentation next fall.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 16--The collapse of a plan to find homes in Paraguay for 700 Kalmucks, a Mongolian people believed to be descendants of Genghis Khan's Golden Horde, has been conceded regretfully by the International Refugee Organization.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 16--Official United States food observers will meet this week-end in Dubrovnik (Ragusa) to wind up the United States Government's interim aid program that enabled Yugoslavia to overcome successfully her most dangerous economic crisis since the break with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP)-- The Army wonders why all its soldiers do not shoot their weapons in battle.
HOUSTON, May 16--Opposition to a resolution endorsing Universal Military Training broke out today on the floor of the General Federation of Women's Clubs convention here.

The Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company made known yesterday details of a proposed new issue of 100,000 shares of $100 par value preferred stock for effectuating a proposed consolidation with its wholly owned subsidiary, Bristol Mills.
The estimated 8,000 radio "hams" in New York State are being urged to volunteer their services and equipment for use in a statewide amateur radio network being formed by civil defense officials.
WASHINGTON, May 16--A new price regulation covering producers of cotton yarns and textiles at the manufacturing level was announced here today by the Office of Price Stabilization.

WASHINGTON, May 16--The dispute over whether Congress, or a subdivision of Congress, can require an executive official (in this instance General Bradley) to give testimony on matters reserved by the President as confidential is merely another facet of an old, unsettled issue evoked by the nature of the Constitution of the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 16-- Plans and guidance for national civil defense are not enough. The civil defense organization must have equipment and supplies, which it now lacks, in case of enemy aattack, James J. Wadsworth, deputy administrator of the Federal Civil Defense Administration, said tonight.
PARIS, May 16--Means of rearming France as an effective military power on this continent remains at this moment a cardinal factor in United States European policy.

About 250 shareholders of the Sinclair Oil Corporation attending the annual meeting here yesterday were informed by P.C. Spencer, its president, that earnings for the first half of 1951 appeared almost certain to compare favorably with those of the 1950 period.
While most consumers had their eyes fixed on the much discussed "rollback" of retail beef prices, beef prices at wholesale jumped up an average of 12 cents a pound this week.

Two City College students have dedicated themselves to perpetuating the culture of the American Indian. Inspired by early experiences as Boy Scout troopers, and having more than ordinary skill in crafts, John Christgaw and Martin Cohen, students in the college's industrial arts program, have chosen their careers.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 16-- Miss Caroline Nichols Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Baker of Guard Hill, Westport, has completed plans for her marriage on June 16 to Henry Moore Halsted 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Halsted Jr., of Englewood, N.J.
BALTIMORE, May 16 (AP)-- Jockey Ted Atkinson changed horses today and picked Big Stretch for his mount in Saturday's $75,000 Preakness at Pimlico.

The coup d'etat in Bolivia had an element of inevitability about it. Anyone watching the situation in recent months as the May 6 Presidential elections approached could predict trouble. The fact that the exiled Victor Paz Estenssoro won a plurality but not the necessary majority in those elections made it almost certain that something extralegal was going to happen.

Summer staged a sneak preview on the Eastern seaboard yesterday. Public reaction was mixed. Fortunates who were able to leave their chores to bask in the broiling sun or loll in the shade enjoyed the day's record high temperature of 87.4 degrees, a record so far this year and for the date, registered at 2:35 P.M. Others, who toiled, found the hottest May 16 something less than a joy.
Senior Judge Learned Hand, who has been called "the greatest living American jurist," will retire from the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, on June 1.

CHICAGO, May 16--After a bulge based on expectations that Congress would sanction the sale or gift of breadstuffs to India, local longs started to take profits in wheat futures and discovered an extremely thin demand.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 16-- President Mamerto Urriolagoitia resigned today and handed over the Government of this turbulent tin-mining nation to a junta of three generals and seven colonels.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 16-- While the Bergen County grand jury today was handing up indictments against eleven persons, Nelson F. Stamler, Deputy Attorney General directing the investigation of gambling, received word that Police Chief Alexander Flannery of Edgewater, sought for questioning by the grand jury, had applied for retirement.

WASHINGTON, May 16--An Immigration and Naturalization Service official told a citizens' con ference on immigration matters today that the pending "omnibus" McCarran bill would repeal the "declaration-of-intention" step in naturalization, in effect since 1795, with considerable dislocation of established practices concerning aliens.

ACURIOUS baseball fan skimmed quickly through the weekly tabulation of the batting averages last Sunday to see how his old friend, Ted Williams, was doing. His finger slid down the list, stopped half way and started all over again.

There will be a lot of fuss and feathers, not to mention smoke, in Yonkers today.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters)-- London-born Leopold Stokowski was called back eight times tonight to receive the homage of nearly 6,000 cheering music-lovers packing the Royal Albert Hall for his performance with Sir Thomas Beecham's Royal Philharmonic Orchestra.

LA PAZ, May 16 (UP)--General Ballivian, 50-year-old veteran of the Chaco war with Paraguay, who heads the junta, said today that the shift from a civilian to a mil itary administration should not be interpreted as an Army coup. He said the Army had acted to save Bolivia from extremists of the Right and Left.

The submission of Government evidence through depositions in the anti-trust suit against certain investment banking houses "is degenerating into a colossal waste of time," Judge Harold R. Medina declared yesterday in Federal Court here.
PITTSBURGH, May 17--The Giants reallly looked to be off and running today. But on the first turn they took one spill, Ralph Kiner helping to trip them with a three-run homer.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The House by a vote of 312 to 68 overrode today President Truman's veto of a bill to require the Army, Navy, Air Force and Federal Civil Defense Administration to seek advance congressional approval of all real estate transactions.

Three vacant lots at 136, 138 and 140 Broome Street, used for a playground by St. Marks Orthodox Catholic Church of 142 Broome Street, were purchased from the city for $11,400 at an auction sale yesterday by the Orthodox Catholic Alliance, represented by the Right Rev. B.R. Burden of the church.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 17--G. Stanley McAllister has announced the engagement of his daughter, Maridon, to John Wells Morrison, son of Mrs. A. Wells Morrison of Salt Lake City and the late Mr. Morrison.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- Most of a $5,500,000 cut which the House made in Bonneville Power Administration construction funds for next year will be taken from Washington state projects under present B.P.A. plans, Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 17--The leading social work educators of the country sent a message today to President Truman condemning the "arbitrary" action of Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, in ordering the destruction of all copies of "Common Human Needs."
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- Signs of a possible butter shortage next fall and winter showed up in a Government report today.

CORNING, N.Y., May 17--The ability of militant organized labor to improve the workingman's lot at home and on the job has given this country its strongest defense against the advance of communism, A.J. Hays, president of the International Association of Machinists, declared tonight.

The appointment of Lowell C. Wadmond, senior partner of the law firm of White Case, as president of the Metropolitan Opera Association, was announced yesterday after a meeting of the board of directors at the opera house.

Bishop Michael J. Ready of Columbus, Ohio, charged yesterday that Secretary of State Dean Acheson had shown "a peculiar insensibility to the horrible religious persecution in Yugoslavia" and that large parts of the press had helped mislead the American people as to the true nature of Marshal Tito's regime.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 17--The voluntary credit restraint effort is misnamed, officers of the Investment Bankers Association of America were told here today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- The New York New Haven and Hartford Railroad company today dropped its plan to buy all of the outstanding securities of the bankrupt Boston and Providence Railroad Corporation.

A majority of the steamship companies under contract to the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F.L., have agreed to a revolutionary vacation plan that guarantees seamen paid vacations on the basis of two weeks for each twelve months of service.

An appeal by Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, U.S.A., retired, for continued military strength was made yesterday as Armed Forces Week was marked with ceremonies on the steps of the Subtreasury, Wall and Broad Streets.

Plans to hire "ten or more" college professors and instructors who can be released from teaching assignments because of shrinking college enrollments were announced yesterday by Frank W. Abrams, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

Some of the fun and the colorful spirit of the "beautiful Isle of Capri" has been captured and brought to the department called "Macy's by the Sea." Seaside play togs in the manner of those worn at the Italian resort, many made by the people of Capri and some faithfully copied, will be available at Mary's on Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The Office of Price Administration took steps today to relieve mail order houses, selling at retail through published catalogues, of a "squeeze" resutling from the general price "freeze" of last January.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17-- Twentieth Century-Fox has purchased "The Love Man," a current Collier's Magazine serial by John D. Weaver for production as a film by Sol C. Siegel, with Clifton Webb as the star. The sale was negotiated by E. Henry Lewis as Weavver's representative.

YONKERS, May 17--Possibly, this is a year for horses with misspelled names. What with Repetoire having fared well on the flats, along came Thomas B. Scott tonight to capture the United States Harness Writers' Trophy, the featured $7,500 mile pace at Yorkers Raceway.
Several "firsts" were made on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. There was the first trade by a non-member actually initiated from the floor.
NEW ORLEANS, May 17 (UP)--Cotton futures sellers on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange have defaulted on delivery of 12,700 bales of cotton, exchange President E.F. Creekmore dis closed today.

WASHINGTON, May 17--Declaring he had been considering dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur off and on for about a year, President Truman said today he had made up his mind finally to remove him after the Far Eastern commander had sent his March 24 ultimatum to the Chinese Communists.

THE summary for the weekend anglers indicates fairly good prospects on both fresh and salt water fronts, with the trout outlook excellent for fly fishermen in the Catskills, Adirondacks, Central New Jersey and Eastern Pennsylvania.

United States adoption of a "Development Corporation Tax Exemption Act" similar to liberal tax incentives and exemptions granted to most new and many established businesses by the Puerto Rican Government was urged yesterday by Gustave Simons, economist.
Families in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn were drinking milk instead of soda pop yesterday and, what's more, paying as little as 6 cents a quart for it.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur said last night that he had reacted "with astonishment bordering on incredulity" to President Truman's statement earlier that he had been considering removal of the general for the last year.
BERLIN, May 17--United States clubwomen touring West Germany are convinced that the United States is justified in helping the Germans to regain their former place in the family of nations.

ALBANY, May 17--A longrange master plan for a special authority to construct and operate an $80,000,000 state office center in Albany was proposed today by Bertram D. Tallamy, Public Works Superintendent.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 17-- Miss Charlotte Peterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Peterson of Plainfield, was married to Frederick Lewis Hyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Christopher Hyer of Rahway, this evening in the home here of her brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Peterson Jr.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- The House of Representatives voted a 12.5 per cent vut today in the Agriculture Department's $820,005,546 budget for the fiscal year starting July 1. By voice vote it passed and sent to the Senate a bill to give the department $717,295,233 instead of the $820,005,546 requested by President Truman.

DETROIT, May 17--Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, announced today that production cuts ordered by the Government would force his company to lay off 10,000 workers in the next sixty days.

Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey warned industry yesterday that the shrinking in draft calls is only temporary and that by the autumn of 1952 the Armed Services are going to have "a very hard time" getting the 3,500,000 men they need.

Irresponsible partisanship that tries to pry secrets from our highest officials is a travesty of democracy that threatens national security, Dr. Grayson Kirk, vice president and provost of Columbia University, said yesterday.
TOKYO, May 17 (AP)--The Dowager Empress Sadako died today of a heart attack at the age of 66. Her husband, Emperor Yoshihito, died Christmas Day, 1926. She was the mother of Emperor Hirohito.

Apparently reflecting an increasing volume of borrowing for defense purposes, loans by New York banks for business purposes resumed their expansion in the week ended on May 16, advancing $55,000,000 in the largest single weekly increase since March 21.

A resolution calling on all governments to impose an arms embargo against Communist China and North Korea was approved yesterday by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly despite Soviet claims that only the Security Council had the right to take such action.
WASHINGTON, May 17--Sharp increases in steel to be set aside for July delivery on rearmament orders were called for by the National Production Authority in telegraphic orders to all mills today.

Retailers will seek legislative action by Congress that will put the Office of Price Stabilization "back on the tracks of its original control concepts," it was said yesterday by J. Gordon Dakins, manager and treasurer of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Undeterred by defeat in the first phase of their spring offensive, the Chinese Communists have launched new assaults all along the Korean front.

A weather-beaten little craft with a rakish bow and the stern of a cutter slipped quietly into New York Harbor yesterday from points north. The Canadian colors fluttered atop her taffrail as she moved, a complete stranger, through the Sound, down the East River and across the Upper Bay to Staten Island. There she tied up at an oil pier on the Kill van Kull.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The nation's independent meat packers called upon Congress today to exempt meat from price regulation, arguing that the alternative under the rollback was a cut in production, growing scarcity and an uncontrollable black market.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 17 (AP)--Achmad Subardjo, Indonesian Foreign Minister, reversed his stand on trade with Communist China and said today that his rubber-producing country would obey any embargo voted against the Communists by the majority of United Nations members.

CHICAGO, May 17--The passage of the India relief measure providing for the shipment of 75,000,000 bushels of wheat on a loan basis by the Senate yesterday gave wheat an unexpectedly strong opening, but there was a quick recession to new lows for the current price movement.

PARIS, May 17--United States policy, particularly through the Marshall Plan, succeeded in assisting Western European production to attain a level by the middle of last year that was 24 per cent higher than before World War II.

LONDON, May 17--All markets were dull on the Stock Exchange here today. The weakness was most pronounced in British funds, where some of the longer-term loans lost point or more. Uneasiness about the international situation and the terms of the new World Bank loan were chiefly responsible.
The political storm over General Bradley's refusal to disclose confidential talks with President Truman ended in a victory for the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that the Board of Estimate had decided unanimously to authorize construction of a $12,500,000 nurses' residence and training school for Bellevue Hospital.

ALBANY, May 17--Lawrence E. Walsh, counsel to Governor Dewey since December, 1949, resigned today to resume his post as counsel to the Public Service Commission. He will be succeeded by George M. Shapiro, a member of the legal staff of the Governor since December, 1945.
LONDON, May 17--Field Marshal Lord Birdwood, one of Britain's most distinguished soldiers and her oldest field marshal, died today at his home in Hampton Court Palace. His age was 85.

The four-story business building at 1155 Avenue of the Americas, southwest corner of Forty-fifth Street, has been resold by Henry Goelet, operator, to an investing client of F. and G. Pflomm, brokers. L.V. Hoffman Co. were co-brokers in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $150,000.
Following is the text of a statement yesterday by Ernest A. Gross, deputy United States representative to the United Nations, before the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly:

Earlier in the month this department pointed out that on the basis of weight, white potatoes are the cheapest food on the market. Today we follow through on this fact, derived from the New York metropolitan area office of the State Extension Food Marketing Program, with some potato-cookery recipes.
Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader of the Bronx, accused the Senate Crime Investigating Committee last night of unfairly besmirching the reputations of officials and Democratic organizations here.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- Price Stabilizer Michael V. DiSalle says he has been advised that a rumored $9 a ton increase in the price of Canadian newsprint is "no more than a rumor."

WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., May 17--The fuselages of tomorrow's supersonic airplanes will be much more slender and the wings match thinner and shorter than on any aircraft now flying, and the planes themselves will be much faster.

ONE of the smartest maneuvers ever executed by the late Col. Matt Winn was to juggle the dates of his beloved Kentucky. Derby so that the Run for the Roses always would be held before the Preakness and not the other way around as had sometimes been the case. By coming first he never had to be concerned if the bottom dropped out of the basket. It no longer was his basket.
Publishers' Adclub--Publishers' Weekly annual awards for the best book advertising campaigns of 1950 were presented yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 17--One of the striking observations of the writer in a 1,000-mile tour of southwestern Yugoslavia was the virtual disappearance from the villages of young men capable of bearing arms.
MORRIS PLAINS, N.J., May 17 --Dr. Earl W. Fuller of 8 Mill Road, director of the Northern New Jersey Mental Hygiene Clinic of Greystone Park, died last night at the age of 65.
HOUSTON, May 17--Proponents of universal military training went to work today to muster support among the 1,200 delegates attending the convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs here.

WASHINGTON, May 17--Congress gave signs today of reviving the row over the functions that President Truman, by executive order, gave to the Wage Stabilization Board in disputes other than those over wages. Business spokesmen protested strongly.
This is a world of exiles. They form a nation of themselves, these scattered fugitives who have escaped from terror and tyranny for a breath of free air.

Ten thousand persons lined Bronx streets yesterday while representatives of the city, state and Federal governments paid their last respects at the funeral of Bronx County Judge Samuel J. Foley, who died Monday at Union Hospital, the Bronx, at the age of 60.
Two fire boats, two hook and ladder trucks, four engine companies, three police radio cars and an emergency truck answered a fire alarm yesterday on the lower East Side. What was burning?

As of last night men outnumbered women by four to one as candidates for an $11,021 State Labor Department vacancy that had been regarded until recently as one requiring a woman's direction exclusively. Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein altered the traditional concept by ruling it could be filled by men as well as women.
Despite worries over shortages and taxes, the United States was described yesterday as standing "at the threhold of a magnificent new phase of the industrial revolution."

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 17--Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich Country Club won the oneday tournament of the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association at Innis Arden Golf Club today by carding 80 on steady halves of 41 and 39.

Fourteen handicapped children, victims of cerebral palsy, polio and similar crippling diseases, held a practice evacuation drill yesterday at the New York Philanthropic League's center, 150 West Eightyfifth Street.

James M. Lyons, 48-year-old former assistant postmaster of Scarsdale, N.Y., was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in jail and put on probation for a year for embezzling $11,194 in Government funds with which to gamble.

ROME, May 17--The Italian Government today received $71,000,000 more from the Economic Cooperation Administration, bringing to $237,000,000 the total United States contribution to support the Italian recovery and defense program during the 1950-51 fiscal year.

The visit of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion to this country has set off a new wave of antiIsrael propaganda and agitation in the Communist-ruled states behind the Iron Curtain, a review of press and radio reports from those countries reveals.
FRANKFORT, Germany, May 17--West German and Allied officials are working on a plan for curtailing illegal trade with the East by establishing a central licensing agency.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 17--Just at dusk tonight small fires spelling out the letters. M.N.R., the Spanish initials of the National Revolutionary party, were lighted in at least two places on the mountains that ring this small city set in a 14,000-foot-high bowl in the Andean range.

The Inwood team won the Long Island championship in series 1 as interclub team matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association ended yesterday. Inwood next will play the Westchester and New Jersey winners for metropolitan honors.

The Board of Education's proposal for solving the teachers' salary controversy, which has resulted in a teachers' boycott against extracurricular activities for more than a year, will be announced next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- Money for home mortgage loans is vanishing across the nation-- with a suddenness startling to builders and government officials alike.
TRENTON, May 17 (AP)--A defendant in the Trenton six murder trial testified today that he "blacked out" after smoking a cigarette given to him by the police.

Though there is great variety from which to choose at the vegetable counter this week-end, prices on many items are several centshigher than a week ago. Cauliflower advanced 6 cents to 45 a head while green peas at 23 and peppers at 19 cents both are up 4 pennies.

Montant of Ridgewood, N.J., and Mrs. Anderton Montant of New York, took place yesterday afternoon in the home of the bride's mother at 163 East Eightyfirst Street.

Two five-story apartment houses at 1038-52 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx, containing 173 suites, have been resold by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, to the Androme Realty Corporation, of which Elmer L. Litvin is president. Mrs. Anne Inselstein was the broker. The sellers bought the property last year from Louis Bregman. It is assessed at $490,000.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- The United States is going ahead with plans to export vast quantities of grain during the coming marketing season despite poor crop prospects in some areas.

CHICAGO, May 17--Home-run balls crushed the league-leading Dodgers again today, as Frank Hiller hurled a seven-hitter to give the Cubs a 7-0 victory. The Bruins moved into a second-place tie with the Pirates and the Braves dropped to fourth.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP)--In a move to strengthen their infield, the Cardinals today swapped pitcher Erv Dusak and first baseman Glenn Nelson to Pittsburgh for shortstop Stan Rojek. No cash was involved.

Simultaneously with the issuance of a report of a new high earnings record for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28, last, the Lionel Corporation announced yesterday a proposal to split the stock two for one. The various unions representing the 40,000 employer of the municipal transit lines were warned yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri that he would not tolerate "strikes or interference with the operations of the Board of Transportation" in violation of the two-year agreement signed by union representatives in June, 1950.
Should underwriters selling securities to the public offer them at a price slightly below the exact value, to encourage investors to buy?

Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Ford Foundation, announced yesterday that it had established the Free Russia Fund, Inc., to help refugees and exiles from the Soviet Union. The trustees of the foundation, it was made known, have approved a $200,000 interim budget for the fund's organization and initial operations.

Kid Gavilan of Camaguay, Cuba, and Johnny Bratton of Chicago, National Boxing Association 147 pound titleholder, will meet in the main event of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight for the world welterweight championship, with Gavilan the favorite at 1--2.
New York commodity futures markets moved easily yesterday with generally light volume and almost nominal changes.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 17-- One of the lowest qualifying rounds on record in the historic Walter J. Travis Memorial tourney at the Garden City Golf Club brought the medal to Jack Lyons today as he led 153 players with a par-equaling 73.

Three steps to help untangle the city's snarled traffic web were advanced yesterday, and one of them brought into the open the first sharp traffic split between Mayor Impellitteri and Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator.

Uncle Edgar of the Marise Farm came along toward the close to capture the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. The event was run over a distance of seven furlongs and the favored son of Peace Chance negotiated the course in 1:23 2/5 to score by a length and a half over Gaffery of the Foxcatcher Farms. E.P. Taylor's Bull Page was third, more than a length in back of Gaffery.

Plans have been completed by Miss Edna Brokaw Lowell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Lowell of 812 Park Avenue, for her marriage on June 12 to John Haldeman Leib, son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Leib of 625 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 17--W. Averell Harriman, special assistant to President Truman, told the youth evening session of the sixth annual Conference on Citizenship that young persons growing up today must not only be good citizens of their own community and country but of the world.

Madam Chairman, Mr. Attorney General, distinguished guests, and ladies and gentlemen: It is a very great pleasure for me to be here this morning, and I am glad to join in welcoming this conference to Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 17--Roy A. Brewer, a labor union official, told the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities today that Communists gained such control in Hollywood during the mid1940's that they came dangerously close to taking over the motion picture industry, but were beaten back.

WINTER PARK, Fla., May 17--Dr. Paul A. Wagner, who was dismissed on Sunday as president of Rollins College here, made public today a report by a committee of educators that supported his contention that the college was in serious financial straits.

WASHINGTON, May 17--New offerings of corporations in the first quarter of this year totaled $1,800,000,000, or $400,000,000 more than a year ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. The rate of financing was also $250,000,000 greater than in the last quarter of 1950.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)-- Contempt of court charges against Dr. Joseph W. Weinberg, the "Scientist X" of an investigation into alleged atomic spying, were dismissed today.
