Furnishings traditional in style rather than modern are favored by the average American, according to a group of consumers who engaged in a panel discussion at the Fashion Group luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to exempt from the 20 per cent Federal admissions tax performances of such organizations as the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The second round of the enemy's spring offensive in Korea has scored indecisive successes against the South Korean Third and First Corps on the eastern flank.

Patrolman Sydney Hutchins began his fiftieth year as a policeman yesterday and celebrated by contentedly doing what he has been doing daily since April 19, 1906--directing traffic at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and Broadway, at Twenty-third Street. The genial, 74-year-old policeman hopes to fill out half a century on the force before he retires. He joined the force May 17, 1902.

LONDON, May 17--The United States Congress will demand evidence of the Europeans' will to resist Communist aggression before appropriating more funds for their rearmament, Thomas D. Cabot told a convocation of about 100 American diplomatic, military and economic representatives who ended a two-day meeting here today.
Top defense officials are mapping a large new aluminum expansion program--the second "round" since outbreak of hostilities in Korea last June.

The American Car and Foundry Company announced the elections yesterday of John E. Rovensky as board chairman, Robert H.R. Loughborough as a director, and Charles J. Hardy Jr. as chairman of the executive committee in addition to his office of president.

Bina, a 9-year-old Seeing-Eye dog, led her blind owner through the one-day blood donor center set up for advertising women at the Midston House yesterday and demonstrated to members of that profession the proper technique for public relations.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 17--The West German Government has begun a campaign to win the abandonment by the Allies of the major reserve clause in the Occupation Statute, which gives to the three powers full authority in Germany in time of crisis.

William H. Draper, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, notified New York City officials last night that he was ready to open negotiations immediately for the sale of the road's Rockaway branch to the city for incorporation into its rapid transit system.

The work of twenty-two men and 681 women volunteers serving in New York hospitals was commended yesterday by speakers at the eleventh annual awards meeting of the United Hospital Fund's committee on volunteers, held in the Plaza Hotel.

Shopping for a vacation wardrobe has been made as simple as possible in Hearn's new main floor "sun and fun" shop, which will open on Monday. Here under red and white striped awnings have been grouped clothes for travel, active sportswear and accesories, daytime coordinates and informal evening frocks.

WASHINGTON, May 17--General of the Army Omar N. Bradley's refusal to divulge his private conversations with President Truman on the recall of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was upheld today by his Senate interrogators.

Norway, strongly recovered from its heavy war losses and damage, is a full and willing partner in the Atlantic Pact because its people are willing to make sacrifices for "peace with freedom" as against "peace without freedom," Premier Einar Gerhardson asserted last night.

The National Department Stores Corporation, which operates a chain of sixteen department stores, increased its sales 3.6 per cent to $81,328,369 in the fiscal year ended last January from the previous year's volume of $78,466,644.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that Milton Berle's television show has been renewed by the sponsor for the 1951-52 season. There had been reports that the program might move to the DuMont network in the fall.

Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, voted no confidence in their top officers yesterday and authorized a referendum on their impeachment. The action was taken at a stormy meeting in Beethoven Hall, 210 Fifth Street.
LONDON, May 20--If the Iranian Government insists upon taking possession of the British oil concession in Iran the concessionaires have a trump card to play in the form of severe economic sanctions.

UNITED STATES FIFTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, May 20--This war's best-known jet flier became the world's first jet ace today when Capt. James Jabara shot down his fifth and sixth MIG's within ten minutes late this afternoon.

TOKYO, Monday, May 21--United Nations forces struck back at the Communist offensive in Korea yesterday, thrusting out strong patrols on the western and central fronts to seek out enemy concentrations and rock the attack off balance.

A weatherbeaten three-masted schooner, her canvas furled and her stays, shrouds and ratlines shaking in the off-shore breeze, warped her way alongside Pier 18, Jersey City, yesterday and dropped her starboard anchor.

Plans for converting the threestory brownstone dwelling at 246 East Sixty-second Street into apartments were announced in connection with the sale of the house for cash by the Estate of Herman Trost to the 246 East Sixty-second Street Corporation in a deal negotiated by R.F. Castleman, broker. The sale was the first of the house since 1899.

ATLANTA, May 20--The proposed construction of 24,841 lowcost housing units in six southern states, for which a total of $3,308,000 in preliminary loan contracts has been advanced, is faced with cancellation because of recent action by the House of Representatives.

To help protect lives, prevent panic and minimize property damage in an emergency, more than 100,000 booklets on building control will be distributed by air wardens to managers and owners of industrial, business and residential structures, Arthur W. Wallander,

Today marks the seventieth anniversary of the founding of the American Red Cross by Clara Barton and a handful of volunteer supporters on May 21, 1881. While not the first of the Red Cross societies to be formed, the American society is today one of the largest, with 1,650,000 volunteers in 3,738 chapters in almost every county in the United States and its insular possessions.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- This country's output of goods and value of services performed rose to an unprecedented $313,900,000,000a-year rate in the first three months of 1951. This figure represents a gain of $42,000,000,000 since the start of the Korean fighting.

GENEVA, May 20--European production could increase by a further 13 per cent in 1951 if adequate supplies of industrial raw materials were available, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe estimates in the first part of its annual survey published today.

The sixty-fifth anniversary of the New York State Board of Mediation calls attention to the peaceful state of labor-management relations that has existed in New York for many years. A good deal of the credit unquestionably belongs to the Sate Mediation Board and its counterpart agencies, the...
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- The Veterans Administration spelled out today the newly enacted benefits available to veterans who entered service after the outbreak of the Korean war.
LONDON, May 20--In the past few days the stock markets have received their first definite check to the post-budget rise.

HONG KONG, May 21--An analysis of the Chinese Communists' order of battle disclosed here today that many, perhaps most of the troops being dispatched in droves against the withering United Nations firepower in Korea were former Nationalist soldiers whose...

OSLO, Norway, May 20--A vast and revolutionizing American project to supply the United States and European steel makers with sponge iron manufactured in Norway at highly competitive rates made possible by record low-cost power here is presently being considered by the Norwegian Government.
Alaska's colorful Protestant Episcopal Bishop, the Right Rev. William J. Gordon Jr., declared yesterday:...

Take a look at the sketches accompanying this article. Would it have occurred to you that the patterns for so many styles all can be taken from one envelope, and that the cost of the pattern illustrated is just 35 cents? It provides you with the basic features of a summer week-end wardrobe.

WASHINGTON, May 20--The State Department used the words of Premier Stalin tonight in its rejection of the Soviet plan for negotiating a Japanese peace treaty. It termed the Soviet position "conniving at aggression."

Since the New York Exchange for Woman's Work is the market place for products made by housewives in their own homes, it is a logical spot to go for breads and pastries with an authentically home-made flavor. Currently the shop, located up one flight of...

WASHINGTON, May 20--Joint union-management administration of pensions is one of the chief aims of the Communication Workers of America, C.I.O., in contract negotiations with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

PITTSBURGH, May 20 (U.P.)-- The Phillies batte their way out of the cellar today by thumping the Pirates in both ends of a doubleheader, 17 to 0 and 12 to 4, on thirty-five hits before 36,166 fans, largest crowd at Forbes Field since 1949. It was the fourth straight defeat for the Bucs.

Joseph Durst has purchased the leasehold on the Brewster Building in Long Island City from the 484 Corporation through Milner Realties, Inc., broker. The property occupies the blockfront on the north side of Queens Plaza between Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 20--A young cocker spaniel just about at the start of his ring career became best in show today in the fortyninth all-breed event of the Long Island Kennel Club at the Meadow Brook Club.
Eight new films, including importations from Ireland and England, are slated to arrive in first run theatres this week. The programs follow:
CHICAGO, May 20 (U.P.)-- Satchel Paige came back to the pitching mound today and gave up a scratch hit in four innings with the Negro Chicago American Giants.

"THE writing of 'The Foundling' stems from out the deliberate purposing of my life-- to help my fellow-man." So writes Francis Cardinal Spellman about his first venture into the field of fiction, a novel which is the June selection of the Literary Guild. "Simple, too, it was, for a little babe actually was found abandoned in the Christmas Crib of St. Patrick's...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 20-- A gift by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to Brown University in the form of securities from which $400,000 has been realized for the university's Housing and Development Fund was announced today by Arthur B. Homer, chairman of the

The persons who helped arrest George Martin, a 27-year-old metal worker, for stealing a chair at 2:30 A.M. yesterday from the lobby of an apartment house at 1015 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, tried to save him from jail when he was arraigned later in Brooklyn Week-End Court.
TOKYO, May 20 (AP)--Eighth Army communique 379, issued at 7 P.M. Sunday (5 A.M. Sunday, Eastern daylight time):
BAY SHORE, L.I., May 20-- Johnny Humm of Rockville carded a 73 today at the South Bay Golf Club, but it wasn't good enough to take the team championship.
CINCINNATI, May 20--A threat to kill Jackie Robinson, Dodger second baseman, sent F.B.I. men and local police into action early today.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)--A Catholic priest and a Baptist Minister joined forces tonight in a warning that communism was out to capture the very souls of men.
HAVANA, May 20 (AP)--Browning Ross of Gloucester, N.J., won the 1,500-meter run in a CubaUnited States track and field meet today.

CLEVELAND, May 20--In this city, generally considered the "capital" of Great Lakes shipping, the ore-boat operators are making plans for the greatest fleet expansion in forty years. This is coupled with expectations of a record tonnage movement down from the ore regions.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 20-- With two winning positions in three races, Bus Mosbacher has captured the Sparkman Trophy at the helm of his International Class Susan. He took the initial contest a week ago, dropped into sixth place yesterday, but climbed back to the top again in the final contest today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

George A. Wrisley Jr., formerly manager of private brand sales, has been appointed general sales manager of the Allen B. Wrisley Company, Chicago. L. Norton Wrisley has been named assistant general sales manager. M.P. Rosenthal is manager of the special sales division and R.E. Tyriver becomes sales manager of the grocery division.

Mayor Impellitteri made public yesterday a memorandum from Construction Coordinator Robert Moses recommending a four-year extension of the city's 1948 program for use of garbage as landfill on city-owned property.

Delegates from twenty-three colleges in the New York-New Jersey region of the National Federation of Catholic College Students have urged 600,000 Roman Catholic college graduates in the United States to spread social and interracial justice.

Two large group shows head the week's roster of new art attractions. On Wednesday the Museum of Modern Art will open an exhibition of selected work from the collection of the late Alfred Stieglitz, providing a survey of his activities in introducing modern art to America. The examples chosen are...
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 10--Western Europe is only beginning to feel the economic repercussions of its defense effort.

Reorder activity was good here last week in the wholesale dress, lingerie and accessory markets, with cottons, voiles, chiffons and nylons wanted in all price ranges, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
The American Assembly, organized by Columbia University to promote objective public discussions of the major problems that confront the nation, will open formally this evening.
TOKYO, Monday, May 21 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 890, issued at 10:10 A.M. Monday (8:10 P.M. Sunday, Eastern daylight time):

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 20--The sound of church bells, firecrackers and Indian pipes and drums succeeded that of rifle and machinegun fire today as the sad Indians of this sad little Andean country took a day off from the crisis and from the mines to celebrate the religious festival of El Senor Jesus del Gran Poder (Jesus of the Great Power).
WASHINGTON, May 20--The Taft-Hartley Law does not permit an employer to assist one union because he believes a rival union is Communist-led, the National Labor Relations Board held in a ruling today.

The national newspaper advertising volume has more than doubled since 1929, according to Ben Duffy, president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc. In 1929, the highest national newspaper billing year until that time, $260,000,000 was spent for newspaper space.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20-- Bidding by independent rental motion-picture studios for television film business has increased in tempo in recent weeks.
The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund marked its seventy-fifth anniversary last night with a dinner at the St. Regis Hotel, where a $1,000,000 campaign for underprivileged children was opened.

Although Ed Lopat's earned-run average zoomed from 1.17 to 1.29, the veteran southpaw pitched well enough to turn back the Browns, 7--3, at the Stadium yesterday. It was Lopat's seventh straight victory and his seventh complete game.
Shipping interests in the Port of New York began yesterday a three-day observance of National Maritime Day with open house and memorial services at the Seamen's Church Institute.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 20-- The marriage of Mrs. Dorothy Brill Steckler of New York, widow of Edward L. Steckler and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max D. Brill of New York, to Jerome W. Blum of Scarsdale and New York, took place this afternoon at Three Willow Lane, the bridegroom's home here. The Rev. Arthur S. Wheelock performed the ceremony in the presence of the immediate families.

The general election in France and the municipal elections in Italy, both to be held within the month, will be watched almost as anxiously as the communiques from the Korean front. The vote will register the present strength of the Communist party in the two Western countries in which it is most powerful.

PORTCHCAWL, Wales, May 20 (AP)--All but the most resolute British boosters are resigned to an American victory in the British amateur golf championship starting tomorrow over the treeless, sandy reaches of the Seaside Royal Portchcawl course.

CINCINNATI, May 20--The National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association proposed at a trustees meeting here yesterday that the Government treat the industry's apprentice training program like the approved programs for college students by allowing apprentices to

First significant improvements since last fall have appeared in operating supplies for gray-iron foundries in this region, it was revealed here over the week-end by members of the Gray Iron Founders Society, Inc. For the first time since metal scarcities set in in

Players sharing the Clarence Derwent acting prizes of $1,000 for giving the best supporting performances in non-featured roles during the 1950-51 season are Phyllis Love ("The Rose Tattoo"), Logan Ramsey ("The High Ground") and Frederic Warriner

The New York joint board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., will give a plaque to a manufacturer Wednesday for building a new factory. Both the union and the employer regard the structure as "the last word" in the march of clothing workers out of the sweatshop.

CHICAGO, May 20--Bullish developments in regard to grain prices having failed to stimulate any aggressive investment buying, professional traders have switched to the bear side of the market in the last few days, and found the market vulnerable.
A score of stage and screen stars are scheduled to appear in summer theatre this season. Those due to be seen at country playhouses until the end of the season in September include:

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 20-- Attorneys for a group of professors of Oklahoma College of Agricultural and Mechanical Arts, ordered dismissed yesterday for failure to sign the state's new loyalty oath, said they would appeal to the Oklahoma Supreme Court.

Totalitarian states have long known how to use trials as political weapons. The Reichstag fire trial staged by Hitler was a spectacular example, as were the Soviet purge trials of the Nineteen Thirties. Now, however, comes news that democratic forces will use the trial technique against the totalitarians. In...

In their frenzied rebuff of the latest British note on the nationalization of oil the Iranian nationalist extremists are taking a course of action that in the long run could be far more hurtful to Iran than to Britain. The British note is moderate in tone. It contains no threat graver than that of bringing the case before the International Court of Justice.

NEW ROCHELLE, May 20-- Peg's Pride, the gallant campaigner who is one of the most consistent open jumpers hereabouts, turned in another series of outstanding exhibitions today to capture the grand championship award at the annual spring horse show at Hutchinson Farms.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 20-- Arrangements for building the largest pipeline in the world to carry Iranian oil to the Mediterranean are going ahead in Baghdad and here as if no one had ever heard of the projected nationalization of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, announced yesterday that it had decided to go ahead with a $1,240,000 addition to Public School 27 in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn despite the opinion of the Education Management Survey that the project was not needed.
Rabbi Solomon Landman of Temple Isaiah, Kew Gardens, Queens, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, Manhattan, after an illness of six weeks. His age was 55.

The American interim aid program for Yugoslavia, which has provided that country with more than 500,000 tons of food since last fall, is about to be concluded. Reporting after a thousand-mile journey through the provinces, our Belgrade correspondent finds that this help has saved the situation.

WASHINGTON, May 20--The Wage Stabilization Board's approval of a nine-cent hourly pay rise for meat packing workers means that the board's policy still is in the development stage. Until the policy matures, it is expected that the national wage average will continue creeping to higher ground.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)-- Eddie Robinson's double with two out in the ninth inning scored Orestes Minosos from second base and gave the White Sox a 5-4 victory over the Senators today, Robinson previously had slammed a two-run homer and a single.
MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L.I., May 20--The Air Force played Cupid here today for four young recruit airmen who are on furlough prior to going on overseas duty.
MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L.I., May 20--The Air Force played Cupid here today for four young recruit airmen who are on furlough prior to going on overseas duty.

The State Department of Education has agreed to include the non-teaching personnel of the New York City school staff among the recipients of the $100 bonus that the Legislature voted for teachers last March.

The people of the Philippines are completely confident that their position in the Far East will be upheld by the United States, Myron M. Cowen, United States Ambassador to the Philippines, declared yesterday. Mr. Cowen, who arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens,
This city needs temporary shelters where psychological treatment of neglected children would be stressed, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy declared yesterday.
There comes a day in the life of every parent --it may be tomorrow, it may arrive next week --when the child comes

WINTER PARK, Fla., May 20-- The controversy over the dismissal of Dr. Paul A. Wagner as president of Rollins College here resulted today in an appeal by forty-two local civic, business and professional leaders for unity in carrying on the college's democratic, tradition.

ZURICH, May 20--At first sight the news from Bonn that for the first time since World War II exports from West Germany in April exceeded imports might give the impression that West Germany would soon be self-supporting again. Experts deny this.
LONDON, May 20 (AP)--Germany, playing in its first Davis Cup tennis competition in eleven years, advanced to the third round today along with Sweden, Belgium and Poland.
BOSTON, May 20 (AP)--The Tigers combined thirteen hits with nine bases on balls today to defeat the Red Sox, 8--4. Boston relief pitching failed again as 30,320 paid fans watched.
The New York harness racing scene shifts to Roosevelt Raceway on Long Island tonight after a successful thirty-night meeting that was completed at the Yonkers Raceway last Saturday.

CHICAGO, May 20 (U.P.)--The Cubs came from behind twice today to beat the Braves, 4 to 3 and 5 to 4, with the veteran Dutch Leonard gaining both victories in relief roles. A crowd of 42,088 saw the games in Wrigley Field.
ROME, May 20--Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza today asked the United States, the United Kingdom and France to take under immediate consideration a complete revision of the Italian peace treaty.

Unless new rules are provided for restoring inventory levels to steel warehouses throughout the country, sales volume and profits in the second half of 1951 will drop below comparable figures for last year.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns, director of research for the National Bureau of Economic Research, in his annual report released for publication today, said that an increase in the labor force and a lengthening of working hours throughout the country were the means available to attain needed output of military goods without reducing living standards.

PITTSBURGH, May 20--For the third straight week steel output last week was unchanged at 104 per cent of rated capacity. That a new record will be hung up by the industry this month goes without saying.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 20--The Iranian Government officially rejected today a request for arbitration made on May 8 by the AngloIranian Oil Company in an attempt to save its holdings in Iran from imminent expropriation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) --The Indians snapped a six-game losing streak today by defeating the Athletics, 5--3, in the second game of a double-header after the A's Dick Fowler spun a neat three-hitter to edge the Indians' Bob Lemon, 2--1, in the opener.

HOUSTON, May 20--Realty executives who handle the operations of office properties and skyscrapers throughout the country are expecting a virtual shutdown shortly in Government approval of new commercial construction.

VIENNA, May 20--The introduction in the Hungarian Parliament of a bill calling for the accomplishment of the Hungarian five-year plan in four years lends credence to recent reports that the Soviet Union has ordered its satellites at all costs almost to double the pace of their industrialization.

PARIS, May 20--Applause greeted Mme. Gres' midsummer collection of beautiful couture clothes. Though every model is unmistakably Gres by the way fabric is manipulated into significant form without trimming, she renews her style by the way she handler contrasting scarf panels.
ST. LOUIS, May 20--The Giants were within two innings of that elusive .500 mark in a 3-hour 22minute battle with the Cards today.
Dr. John J. Wittmer, a leader in the field of industrial medicine, died of a heart attack Saturday night at his conutry home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 55 years old.
ST. LOUIS, May 21 (AP)--Franklin W. Olin, founder of a large gunpowder and cartridge empire, died of a heart malady at Barnes Hospital today. His age was 91. He lived at near-by Alton, Ill.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP)-- Jose Ferrer, the Hollywood actor, said today he had "always been opposed to communism" but admitted he had been gullible about lending his name to "good causes" that turned out to be red fronts.

While Mayor Impellitteri was asserting yesterday that the question of converting First and Second Avenues to one-way flow was still being studied, Traffic Commissioner Lloyd B. Reid formally announced that the program would go into effect there on June 4.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., May 21-- Plans have been completed by Miss Elizabeth Huntting Howell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Huntting Howell, for her marriage to Fergus Reid Buckley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Buckley of Camden, S.C., and Sharon, Conn. The wedding will take place here on the afternoon of June 9 in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer intrenched himself with the insurance world during a thirty-minute speech last night when he delineated its plight in an inflationary period and urged "some further leeway in the exercise of investment judgment."

WASHINGTON, May 21--The State Department said today that this Government had neither changed nor modified its policy on China and that contrary interpretations based on a recent address by Assistant Secretary Dean Rusk were without justification.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Attempting to forestall strike threats by employes of independent meat packers, the Wage Stabilization Board has decided to have its staff act swiftly on some 150 applications for wage increases.
DULUTH, Minn., May 21--Economy and more economy is increasingly the watchword of the operators of the vital ore-carrying ships on the Great Lakes.

The world's largest operating electric and gas utility, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., called for higher rates yesterday in order to offset increased operating expenses, replacement costs and larger taxes.

Mary Chelf, mezzo-soprano from Harrodsburg, Ky., gave her first New York recital last night at Times Hall. She had some of the limitations of a beginner, but she made a favorable impression. Her manner was pleasant and she sang sincerely. She has an agreeable voice that has been schooled carefully.

ST. LOUIS, May 21--The Giants' brief invasion of the Mound City tended in complete disaster today as Leo Durocher's somewhat befuddled Polo Grounders blew the series finale to the Cardinals, 5 to 2. That Gave Marty Marion's Redbirds a clean sweep of the twogarie set.

The stock market suffered a new relapse yesterday, sandwiched in between two periods of strength. The late rally proved insufficient to eliminate the losses of the early afternoon although inroads were reduced by late buying. The list first climbed as much as a point, then receded slightly more on balance and in the final analysis showed declines of major fractions.

LONDON, May 21--From the deerstalker cap to the old microscope, the intriguing world of Sherlock Holmes has been recreated for the Festival of Britain. At the spot where most folks think Sir Conan Doyle imagined his protege to have become the greatest detective of them all, a compact little exhibition sets forth the familiar aura of Holmesian fiction fused with Conan Doyle fact.

Sugar prices, both in the actual market and in futures trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, swung sharply upward yesterday under the influence of news from Cuba. The No. 4 world sugar contract in New York jumped 3 to 16 points, with the July position closing at 6.78 cents a pound. Volume was 9,000 tons.
DETROIT, May 21--David BenGurion, Prime Minister of Israel, was honored at a civic reception here today on the steps of the Detroit City Hall.

FAIRFIELD, Ala., May 21 (UP)-- More than 400 persons were left homeless today when flames razed two blocks in the Negro residential section of this Birmingham industrial suburb. Damage was estimated at $100,000.
That anonymous British officer accused of having mortally wounded a captured American general in Queens at the time of the Revolution is not in the clear yet--and he's not so anonymous any more.

CHICAGO, May 21--Receipts of cattle at the country's stockyards declined sharply today, the first marketing session after the Office of Price Stabilization rollback on the price of live cattle went into effect yesterday.
WINTER PARK, Fla., Way 21-- Dr. Paul A. Wagner, deposed president of Rollins College here, filed a $500,000 damage suit today against the eleven trustees who voted to dismiss him.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 22 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 891, issued at 9:45 A.M., Tuesday (7:45 P.M., Monday, Eastern daylight time):

NEW DELHI, India, May 21-- Negotiations between the All-India Newspaper Editors Conference and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru over the Government's proposed restrictions on freedom of speech and expression broke down today, according to reliable sources.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, Mrs. MacArthur and 21,623 other baseball fans saw Vic Raschi beat Stubby Overmire in an old-fashioned pitching duel at the Stadium last night. The righthanded ace of the Yankees was a 2-0 victor over the Browns southpaw. Each hurler allowed five hits.

BERLIN, May 21--Seventeen years after the murder of Dr. Erich Klausener, Minister of Traffic and Roman Catholic leader under Hitler, provided one of the greatest sensations of the Nazi regime, former Major Kurt Gildrich of Hitler's Elite Guard confessed today in open court that he ...

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 21-- Tony Tiso, Vernon Hills Country Club pro, led the Metropolitan sector's qualifying squad for the National Professional Golfers Association championship at the Cherry Valley Club today.

MEXICO CITY, May 21--A thousand disgruntled migratory workers staged an angry demonstration at Monterrey today in protest against job preferentials they alleged were being granted to hundreds of others seeking work on Texas and Louisiana cotton fields.
The American note to the Soviets makes a point regarding China which is clearly of very great importance for the future.

ARDEN, N. Y., May 21--Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, and Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, agreed tonight in backing this Government's broad strategy of resisting Communist aggression wherever we can but differed on the tactical...

WASHINGTON, May 21--The National Production Authority made it clear today that its limitations on tire inventories apply to retail outlets as well as to any other stage of distribution in the industry in an amendment to its May rubber order (M-2).

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP)-- A Senate Armed Services preparedness subcommittee said today the recruit processing center at Fort Knox, Ky., was in a "deplorable situation" three months ago because it had too many different duties to perform.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The Supreme Court upheld the California Senate Fact-Finding Committee on Un-American Activities today in a case bearing importantly on the time-honored freedom of legislators to speak and act in their legislative pursuits without fear of legal liability.
WASHINGTON, May 21--David K. Niles of Boston resigned today, effective May 31, as an administrative assistant to President Truman.

CHICAGO, May 21--The "Norway design for living" exhibit of home furnishings, which was opened officially by Norway's prime minister, Einar Gerhardsen, on Saturday, contains the products of sixty-nine Norwegian concerns and artisans in furniture, ceramics, silver and gold ware, pewter, textiles, wallpaper, glassware, lamps, flooring and rugs.
The Board of Transportation is expected to have a new problem in its lap tomorrow, when engineers hired ten months ago to advise on ways to install a forty-hour week make their report.
THOSE who braved the elements over the week-end found the fishing situation rather spotty, but as usual a few of the really persistent anglers were rewarded on both fresh and salt water.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 21-- Joe Adonis, the racketeer described by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee as one of the nation's top gang leaders, apparently was headed today for the first prison term of his long criminal career.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz ordered yesterday a blue-ribbon jury for the trial of twenty-one past and present police officers charged with conspiracy to obstruct justice. The trial opens June 4.

HAVANA, May 21 (UP)--Roscoe Browne of New York slashed a full second off an 800-meter mark set last year by Olympic champion Mal Whitfield today to lead United States athletes in domination of the second day of the CubanAmerican track meet.

An exhibition of seascapes by Winslow Wilson will open tonight at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, with a preriew for the benefit of Greenwich House. Admission to the preview will be $6; thereafter, the show will be free to the public.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21-- Joseph Bernhard and Anson Bond, independent producers, have concluded arrangements for Shirley Yamaguchi, Japanese film star, to make her American debut in their picture, "East Is East," which King Vidor will direct starting June 1, with Don Taylor as the leading man.

If there had been any doubt previously that the lid was off so far as wage increases were concerned, that doubt should be removed by the decision of the newly created Wage Stabilization Board in the case of the packing house workers.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The House Ways and Means Committee voted tentatively today to have further increases in individual income taxes start on Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The Food and Drug Administration today announced a court injunction prohibiting 15,000 door-to-door salesmen from making "extravagant therapeutic claims" for Nutrilite, a vitamin and mineral diet supplement.
Trustees of the Police Department Pension Fund set a ten-year record yesterday when they approved the mass retirement of 505 police officers and patrolmen.

A District Attorney who con fines himself to prosecution performs only half his duty--the other half is to help prevent crime, Miles F. McDonald, District Attorney of Kings County, declared yesterday.

BOSTON, May 21 (UP)--Ted Williams pulled out of his batting slump today to drive in three runs with the aid of a 375-foot homer, as the Red Sox beat the Tigers, 9--7, before a ladies day crowd of 6,977.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- College students were advised today against buying any books on how to pass the forthcoming Selective Service aptitude tests.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 21--Yugoslavia today informed the United Nations that all former war prisoners had been repatriated, except for 431 German and twenty-seven Austrian captives serving sentences as war criminals.

GREENWHICH, Conn., May 21-- Albert H. Wiggin, former chairman of the governing board of the Chase National Bank in New York, died here early today at his summer home. Field Point Park, after a long illness.

The Starmount Stable's Primate won the Juvenile Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. Worth $10,000 added and being run for the seventy-fifth time, the fixture for 2-year-olds attracted only three contestants, with Jet Master of the Marlboro Stud Farm finishing second and Mrs. Vera S. Bragg's Mixture a distant third.

The Marquis de Lafayette was hailed here yesterday as the forefather of the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights. The debt of gratitude owed to him by free men throughout the world was stressed at a ceremony marking the 117th anniversary of his death.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 21 --Yugoslav authorities announced today the discovery of an underground Cominform organization in Belgrade and the arrest of Lazar Plavcic, former president of the central administration of the metalurgical workers union on the charge of being in contact with the conspirators.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 21-- Dr. Harlan Henthorne Hatcher, 52year-old vice president of Ohio State University, was elected president of the University of Michigan at a special Board of Regents meeting today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21-- Harvey E. Emmart, vice president of the Baltimore National Bank, said here today there is nothing of more pressing importance to the nation's banks than the success of the Voluntary Credit Restraint Program.

WASHINGTON, May 21--United Nations forces in Korea, who are said to have killed or wounded more than 58,000 Chinese and North Korean Communists in five recent days of fighting, suffered a total of 1,618 casualties in the same period, a ratio of 1 to 36, the Defense Department disclosed today.

A chemical substance extracted from muscles of rabbits has been used at Columbia University to produce fibers that contract and do work like natural muscles. The findings, expected to lead to a better understanding of the manner in which muscle cells work, were made by Dr. Teru Hayashi of Columbia's Department of Zoology.

OTTAWA, May 21 (AP)--Production Minister C.D. Howe announced today that rationing of aluminum, copper and brass would come under Government control beginning June 1. Previously, these items were rationed informally and on a voluntary basis by the producing companies to manufacturers.

PARIS, May 21 (AP)--World Middleweight Champion Ray Robinson stopped Kid Marcel of France in the fifth round of a non-title fight tonight. The New York Negro toyed with his rival for four rounds and then tossed some hefty punches in the fifth. Marcel's handlers quickly threw in the towel.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Whether executive officials, on the claim that they "partake of the President's immunity" from personal penalties by the courts, including contempt, are not subject to such penalties is the most important public issue in the litigation between a set of these officials and ...

PORTHCAWL, Wales, May 21 (UP)--The defending champion, Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, fought an uphill battle to defeat an obscure but clever British playet today and led ten other Americans into the second round of the British amateur golf championship.

Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Stern of 145 West Fifty-eighth Street have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss. Stern's daughter, Miss Joan Sondheim, to Peter Hadley Vogel, son of Mrs. Howard H. Vogel of 40 East Fiftysecond Street and the late Mr. Vogel. The wedding will take place June 28.

Count Sforza has again proposed that the Italian peace treaty be revised. The timing of this request a week before the crucial municipal elections was doubtless calculated. At the height of the electoral campaign in the spring of 1948 a judicious declaration by the United States, Britain and France fa- ...

The troubles that Arthur Faernstrom, 43-year-old unemployed plumber, suffered as the result of an accident in which he was injured in June, 1948, were cited yesterday in his complaint as his $40,000 suit against the owners and drivers of the two automobiles involved began in Queens Supreme Court.

LA PAZ, Bolivia. May 21--Juan Lechin, head of the Bolivian miners' union and one of the leaders of the National Revolutionary party, who had been sought since the Army seizure of the Government on Wednesday, was arrested at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Both houses of Congress passed and sent to the White House today the third supplemental appropriations bill with a rider that would prohibit economic or financial assistance for nations that knowingly permitted export of strategic materials or commodities to Communist countries.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 21-- Ambassador Henry F. Grady received from Foreign Minister Bagher Kazemi today an aide memoire expressing Iran's painful surprise at what was termed United States meddling in the internal affairs of Iran through the issuance of a statement on Iran's oil dispute with Britain.

WASHINGTON, May 21--President Truman submitted to Congress today requests for supplemental appropriations totaling $1,090,491,704, including $800,000,000 "for stock-piling of strategic and critical raw materials needed for national defense."

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 21--The 90-year-old "Taj Mahal of the Hudson Valley." one of the strangest private residences in the country, has been saved from the wreckers' hammets. Now historians are eyeing it for permanent preservation as a relic of the Civil War era.

ROME, May 21--Admirals in command of the Italian, United States, British and French naval forces in the Mediterranean began a series of meetings today in Malta to study tactical and strategic problems involved in the protection of merchant shipping in wartime.

An experiment in mutual understanding got under way yesterday at Arden House, in Arden, N. Y., when a group of representatives of business, labor, farming, government and the professions met to organize the American Assembly.
Sea and air traffic in the New York area was stalled or slowed most of the day yesterday by heavy fog that caused one large oil tanker to run aground near Sandy Hook, N.J.
BOSTON, May 21--A serious challenge was posed today to the rain-making industry in the West in its use of silver iodide particles for the seeding of clouds.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The United States high command believed General of the Army Douglas MacArthur to be jeopardizing this country's military position and its Constitutional Govern ment as well, the Senate inquiry on his ouster was told today.
The City Council adopted yesterday without change the 1951-52 budget of $1,336,400,675, the largest in the city's history, by a vote of 21 to 2.

BURSSELS, Belgium, May 21-- A panorama of the Soviet Union's concentration camp system was drawn in indramatic but harrowing terms here today as the International Commission Against Concentration Camp Regimes opened its widely publicized "tribunal."

CHICAGO, May 21--Further sharp declines were registered in wheat, corn, rye and soybeans in the early trade on the Board of Trade here this forenoon, but there was evidence of some investment buying causing a part recovery.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, under its new, and only Administrator, W. Stuart Symington, has turned up an "improper" deal by one of its officials and discharged the individual concerned.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The Congress of Industrial Organizations put itself on record before Congress today against exempting meat from price control, warning that such action would destroy any possibility of over-all economic stabilization.
WASHINGTON, May 21--A specially trained "flying squad" versed in all aspects of enforcement of regulations of the Office of Price Stabilization is in the process of formation.

Now that the Treasury has sidestepped calling a maturing bond issue on its first optional call date, the bond market's big interest lies in the means the authorities will use to take care of the big chunks of Treasury debt maturing beginning next month. Consisting of four issues of notes and one issue of called bonds, these maturities ...

"Fair trade" received a severe blow, trade sources said here yesterday, when the Supreme Court ruled that state "fair trade" laws did not bar stores from reducing prices if they refused to sign pricing agreements.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21--The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, prominent Baptist clergyman, announced his candidacy for the Republican mayoralty nomination today. The primary will be held July 24.
Charles Triller, chairman of the board of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, died yesterday at his home, 109 East Thirty-fifth Street. He would have been 89 years old on July 15.

Essential export trade by Great Britain and other Western European countries must be maintained as a necessary part of joint defense efforts against communism, it was declared yesterday by Sir Cecil Weir, chairman of the British Dollar Exports Board.
The first of the new educational deferment tests for college students in the metropolitan area to enable them to continue their schooling will be held Saturday.

A purge of top Communist party leadership in a number of areas of the Soviet Union has taken place recently, latest information from the Soviet Union indicates. Those purged have been the heads of the party central committees in different republics and provinces over the country.

The new 900-foot superliner United States, scheduled for launching on June 23 at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company yard in Virginia, will give the country its first liner in the 50,000-ton class. Officials of the line said yesterday the vessel would measure more than 51,000 gross tons.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 21--The pain and shock that were felt here over the United Nations Security Council's resolution on the Lake Huleh drainage project had sufficiently worn off today to allow calmer consideration of Israel's future actions.
This is the time when apartments look dingy and one longs for the country--a tree, a book and, less idyllic perhaps but equally appealing, a meal cooked over an open fire.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 21 (AP)--G.H. Archambault, veteran foreign correspondent, who represented THE NEW YORK TIMES in South Africa for the last five years, died tonight at the age of 74.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 21 (AP)--Otto Mayer, chancellor of the International Olympic Committee, said today that the East German Olympic Committee was "ready to accept all the conditions put by the West German committee" to achieve an amalgamation of the two bodies.

A report recommending the establishment of a tuition-free, twoyear "community college" on Staten Island under joint city and state sponshorship was submitted last night to the Board of Higher Education at its annual meeting.

HOUSTON, May 21--Revival of proposals for commercial rent control, mounting taxes and expenses, defense shortages, the possibility of continued decentralization and "socialistic" trends were in the long list of current problems cited here today as major threats to private realty ownership.

FRANCISCO JOSE DE GOYA Y LUCIENTES, one of the master painters of the world, appeals to the modern imagination as few great artists do. The tempestuous genius who produced "the disasters of war" etchings speaks to the rebellious, fear-and-guilt-ridden modern mind with sardonic and terrible power.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 11--The North Atlantic countries have spent a great deal of time and energy in a fruitless effort to find a formula for sharing the burdens of defense.
WASHINGTON, May 21--Margaret Truman, back in Washington today for three farewell parties before sailing for Europe on Saturday, had her mind on matters other than national politics.

The Ritz-Carlton Hotel was a magnet yesterday for hundreds of former patrons who for frankly sentimental reasons attended the last rites of the all-but-defunct landmark--an auction sale of its furnishings. While parts of the famed building were being demolished, several of its public rooms, which had been turned into storage space, were speedily being emptied of items for the sale.

ST. LOUIS, May 21--Manager Leo Durocher of the Giants learned today that he had been fined $100 by Ford Frick, National League president, for using "vile and abusive language" in his blast against Umpire Lon Warnecke in yesterday's game here with the Cardinals.

MADRID, May 21 (UP)--Troops were ordered confined to barracks tonight in readiness for a showdown tomorrow, when workers threaten to paralyze the capital by a general strike against the high cost of living. Police patrols were reinforced.

A New York County grand jury investigating the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association returned a four-court perjury indictment yesterday against Jerome F. Heaney, the organization's bookkeeper, charging he had lied under oath about the number of tickets printed for the group's annual entertainments.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 21--Athough there are about 3,000,000 refugees in southwest Korea, military operations so overtax available transport that only the limited relief being furnished by the Eighth army can reach them, the United Nations reconstruction chief for Korea said today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21--In his annual message to Congress, President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla today expressed his confidence in the political and economic structure of Chile, but he affirmed that communism was a major menace.
Women can look with pride at the attractive designs created for summer wear. Fashion-wise in the smallest detail, they keep pace with misses' sizes in adapting the best in style.

Major aspects of television's future role in college football--a role already drastically reduced by the colleges' fears of video competition with the box office--will be up for review Friday at a meeting in Philadelphia.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 22--The Communists' vaunted spring offensive ground to a standstill yesterday and United Nations troops resumed the initiative on the central and western fronts. Reports from Korea indicated that the enemy was pulling back in many ...

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 21--The United States proposed today the merger of the United Nation Atomic Energy Commission and the Commission for Conventional Armaments, and suggested that the new commission should prepare "comprehensive plans to include the international control of all armaments and armed forces."

POINT-OF-THE-MOUNTAIN, Utah, May 21--With additional guards mounted in searchlight towers, and state police patrols on stand-by duty, an uneasy truce existed at the Utah State Penitentiary this evening as Gov. J. Bracken Lee and members of the ...

WESTBURY, L.I., May 21-- Harness racing, long removed from the horse-and-buggy class, returned to Roosevelt Raceway tonight and before 18,098 fans, launched a 108-night meeting. That this uninterrupted session, which got under way with William C. Harris' Harold Abbe winning the featured "The Inaugural," will prove successful everyone connected with game is most confident.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 21--Police pressed a search here today for three men who poured bullets into the office of Local 867, International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., 204 River Street, this morning and fatally injured a dock worker.

Eugene Kinckle Jones, retired executive of the National Urban League, wah honored yesterday by 400 associates and members at a reception in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Senafor George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, proposed today creation of a foreign trade authority to succeed the Tariff Commission and to exercise all tariff-making powers delegated by Congress.
